metas.title: Yellow License Plates
metas.description: Namibia primarily uses yellow front and back licence plates. Vanity plates are white, with blue lettering.
metas.note: Botswana and Namibia are the only countries in southern Africa where yellow rear plates are predominantly found.

metas.title: Left-Hand Traffic
metas.description: Namibia drives on the left side of the road.
metas.note: This is also true for other countries in southern and eastern Africa. However all Middle Eastern countries with coverage drive on the right side.

metas.title: White Pickup With Antenna
metas.description: All the coverage in Namibia was taken with a white pickup truck with a short antenna on the front. Notably, this antenna will always lean slightly to the left.
metas.note: No other country in southern Africa has a similar car. The most similar country with this type of car is Oman, however the antenna there will never lean left, but often clearly to the right.

metas.title: Yellow Outer Lines
metas.description: Most roads in Namibia use single yellow outer lines and white centre lines.
metas.note: The other southern African countries also use single yellow outer lines.

metas.title: Green Directional Signs
metas.description: Namibia uses green directional signs with the road number in yellow.
metas.note:
Green directional signs with yellow road numbers are also used in South Africa and the other Southern African countries.

Namibia uses A, B, C, D, M, and sometimes F-roads.

South Africa uses N and R-roads.

metas.title: German Architecture & Language
metas.description: Namibia used to be a German colony, and as such, you can still notice the German influence, most notably in their place names. Some older buildings can have a German style as well.

metas.title: Square Stone Bollards
metas.description: You can spot these small stone bollards at intersections and on the sides of roads.

metas.title: Green/White Round Bins
metas.description: Round metal bins, often painted green and white like the Nigerian flag, can be spotted at many rest stops and intersections.
metas.note: On some roads, the bins are blue and white.

metas.title: Main Road Coverage Only
metas.description: The coverage in Namibia is mostly limited to main roads, with only sparse coverage on minor roads.

metas.title: Pavement & Driving Direction
metas.description: This map shows pavement type as well as the driving direction on all major roads.

metas.title: Area Codes Map
metas.description: Namibian area codes are a simple way to get the right region or city on urban rounds.

metas.title: Blurred Car Locations
metas.description:
Knowing where the Google car is blurred, will help narrow down your options significantly. Below are some useful use cases:

In the north, the blurred car is only northwest of Ondangwa.

The blurred car on an unpaved road likely places you on one of many sideroads of the B1 or other major roads, or in a town.

The paved road between Nordoewer and Aussenkehr has the car unblurred.

Other notable paved roads not north of Windhoek include the C20, C22 (south of Gobabis), C23.
metas.note: The blurred car strongly correlates with a 2024 copyright. Use with caution.

metas.title: Lush Northern Vegetation
metas.description: Roads surrounded by tall and lush trees on both sides will generally place you in the north of the country. The more trees and the greener they are, the further north-northeast you should click.

metas.title: Oshakati Sandy Soil
metas.description: A pocket around Oshakati, and to a lesser extent the rest of the north features more agricultural land and has very light sandy soil. This map also closely lines up with where you can find the Hyphaene Petersiana fan palms.

metas.title: East Windhoek Savanna
metas.description: The landscape east of Windhoek closely resembles that of Botswana, with a generally flat and dry landscape, featuring slightly reddish soil, short golden grass and shrubbery, as well as acacia trees.

metas.title: Western & Southern Arid Hills
metas.description: Dry mountains and hills dominate much of the western and southern parts of the country.

metas.title: Northwest Green Hills
metas.description: Further northwest, you’ll find a somewhat greener region, where the mountains and hills will be covered in shrubbery and trees.

metas.title: South Tsumeb Lush Pocket
metas.description: This pocket south of Tsumeb features the most lush coverage in Namibia, with the grass and mountains being completely green in colour.

metas.title: Windhoek Dry Rolling Hills
metas.description: Around Windhoek, you’ll find a small region with a somewhat dry rolling hills landscape, with hills that are covered in dry yellow grass and dead-looking bushes and small trees.

metas.title: Coastal Sand & Dunes
metas.description: A coastal sandy landscape with the occasional sand dunes can be found around and north of Swakopmund, as well as two small pockets around Luderitz and Oranjemund further south.

metas.title: Southeast Rollercoaster Roads
metas.description: The southeast part of Namibia has countless small ridges that are NW to SE in orientation. Roads ‘riding’ these red sandy ridges appear bumpy, almost like a rollercoaster. Roads winding between the ridges make them appear like miniature valleys.

metas.title: Sossusvlei Pink Dunes
metas.description: Tall pink sand dunes are mainly found just east of Sossusvlei, and can also be seen from further away on a few roads.

metas.title: Aussenkehr Vineyards
metas.description: Vineyards are exclusively found around Aussenkehr on the South African border in the south.

metas.title: West Mariental Agriculture
metas.description: These somewhat baity agricultural fields can be found just west of Mariental.

metas.title: A1 Divided Highway
metas.description: Road A1 between Windhoek and Okahandja, featuring a savannah-like landscape, is just one of two major roads that are divided in Namibia. The other one can be found just southeast of Swakopmund, and features a dry coastal landscape, with light sandy soil and sand dunes.

metas.title: B1 South Desolation
metas.description: Road B1 south of Grunau is a desolate paved road going generally N-NE through a desert landscape with only very low and dry vegetation.

metas.title: B1 Missing Yellow Lines
metas.description:
Outer yellow road lines are missing on the following sections of the B1:

Between Grunau and Keetmanshoop, the landscape becomes hillier, and the road quality deteriorates in general.

This small section north of Keetmanshoop is cloudy.

The third section is between Gibeon and Mariental, which is flat, and goes in a N-NE direction.

metas.title: B1 Gibeon to Tses
metas.description: Between Gibeon and Tses, the road has wider shoulders, and the pavement quality in general is excellent.

metas.title: B1 Mariental to Rehoboth
metas.description: The section of road B1 between Mariental and Rehoboth can be recognised by a combination of the generic arid steppe landscape, the paved road, and mainly the distinct NW bound road angle. It can also help to know that the sun is in the SE for this section.

metas.title: Rehoboth Hills
metas.description: Around Rehoboth the landscape gradually becomes more vegetated, and as you get closer to Windhoek, the hills become more prominent, with a lot of somewhat pointed lonestanding hills, as well as ridges being visible. The weather is fairly clear with small clouds across the sky.

metas.title: B1 North of Okahandja
metas.description:
North of Okahandja, the B1 follows a general northbound direction, with the sun shining brightly to the N-NW. The sky is otherwise clear of clouds. As for the landscape, it’s flatter than around Windhoek, with only the occasional hill or mountain, otherwise the short golden grass, somewhat green acacia trees and shrubbery further away from the road is typical for middle to north Namibia.

South of Sukses, you’ll see these two pointy mountains, one of which has a sharper peak than the other, to the west of the road.

metas.title: B2 Northeast of Swakopmund
metas.description: You can recognise the B2 NE of Swakopmund by the sandy soil, and the mountain ridge visible to the east. A few lone mountains or hills can be seen to the NW as well. Beware that close to Swakopmund the sky is hazy, and you’ll not see the ridge. On this stretch, the coastal looking sandy soil and the NE bound road angle is still generally sufficient to confirm the road.

metas.title: B2 Karibib to Usakos
metas.description: A bit further east, between Karibib and Usakos, you’ll find sunrise coverage combined with a sky covered in fairly thin clouds. There are mountains to the north, as well as smaller hills just south of the road, while it's mostly flat to the E-NE.

metas.title: B2 East of Karibib
metas.description: East of Karibib, the weather becomes completely clear, and the mountains are only visible further in the distance. The wide shoulder lines combined with the E-NE road angle makes this section distinct.

metas.title: B3 Desolate Road
metas.description: This desolate paved road goes in a general E-SE direction through a fairly flat and dry landscape. Small clouds dot the sky. The shrubbery is quite green for the most part, especially in the east, which is also very hilly.
metas.note: The easiest way to tell it apart from parts of the B4 is the eastwards driving direction on this road, as opposed to westwards on the B4.

metas.title: B4 East of Luderitz
metas.description: The B4 east of Luderitz has almost blindingly bright sandy soil. The landscape close to the road is generally flat, with hills and mountains in the distance. Close to Luderitz the landscape becomes much hillier. A railway follows the road closely on the south side for most of this section.

metas.title: B4 East of Aus
metas.description: East of Aus, the road winds through some table-topped mountains, with the railway still just to the south. A similar landscape can briefly be found further east on the road, just east of the intersection with the D432, however the mountains are bigger, closer to the road and redder in colour.

metas.title: B4 Kuibis Plateau
metas.description: After the road climbs onto the plateau east of Kuibis, the landscape will seem mostly flat until you reach the intersection with the D432, but you can notice the road having a gradual incline for long stretches. The soil around is very red in colour, with limited shrubbery or signs of life. The weather is clear, with some clouds far in the distance.

metas.title: B4 Seeheim to Keetmanshoop
metas.description: Between Seeheim and Keetmanshoop, the landscape close to the road is flat, with mountains always close by. Just east of Seeheim, you’ll see a short ridge to the NE, with a lone mountain just west of it, as well as a long ridge far away to the west. A bit east, on the NE-bound stretch, mountains are in all directions, but you’ll see a long uneven tabletop ridge to the west. A railroad can also be seen to the south on this stretch.

metas.title: B6 Windhoek to Gobabis
metas.description: Road B6 goes in a general eastwards direction from Windhoek, with the landscape ranging from hilly close to Windhoek, to mostly flat closer to Gobabis. The soil is somewhat orange in colour, with short green grass and otherwise green vegetation growing from it. The cloud cover also varies, but no part of this road has a clear sky.
metas.note: The only other similar paved road, road C39, has brighter soil.

metas.title: B8 Grainy Pavement
metas.description: You can recognise this long stretch of B8 by the light coloured grainy pavement as well as the general E-NE angle and vegetated northern landscape.

metas.title: C13 Bright Soil
metas.description: Bright soil, clear skies with cloud cover to the east over a tabletop mountain ridge makes this paved N-NW bound road distinct.

metas.title: C14 Unpaved & Cloudy
metas.description: The C14 bears resemblance to the previous road, except this road is unpaved, and the skies are covered in a blanket of clouds, especially in the northern half. Near the southern end, the sky becomes clear.
metas.note: The stretch south of Bethanien is paved.

metas.title: C19 Red Soil
metas.description: Very red soil and small tufts of golden grass lining the road can be used to recognise the paved C19. The sky is mostly covered in dark clouds, especially to the north.

metas.title: C22 Orange Grass
metas.description: The C22 is a paved road generally going east, with freshly cut, orange tufts of grass along the road. A couple of large, rocky hills almost hug the road near the middle. The blinding sun low on the horizon to the east can also be helpful.
metas.note: A short stretch near Okakarara was taken at a different time, making it less distinct. Look for the low ridge N-NW and the sun to the NNE to confirm.

metas.title: C13 Rugged Mountains
metas.description:
A large rugged mountain formation can be seen to the west from the paved C13. Other smaller hills and mountains can be seen in other directions. Light coloured soil hugs the road, while more orange coloured soil can be seen further from the road, with light green vegetation and shrubbery acting as a contrast.

Another easy way to get the road is to look for the wispy clouds trying to hide the sun in the east.

metas.title: C34 Black Sand
metas.description: The C34 looks like darker streaks of black sand surrounded by more sand as far as the eye can see. Some coastal shrubbery, and even the coast can be seen in some parts. Unique white bollards with two yellow reflectors on the front, and one red in the back can also be seen along the road at regular intervals.

metas.title: C35 Red Pavement
metas.description: Red tinted and slightly grainy pavement along with the green savannah-like grassy landscape crowned with low-lying cumulus clouds can be used to recognise the northern section of road C35.

metas.title: C35 South Section
metas.description: South of the C41 intersection, the road loses its red pavement, and the quality worsens. The landscape is less grassy, and more sandy, with hills to the west, though often hidden behind the vegetation. The road generally goes in a S-SE direction. Further south, it gets hillier, and parts will have a more SE bound angle. The sky is consistently covered by scattered cirrostratus and cumulus clouds.

metas.title: Kamanjab Clouds
metas.description: A short section NW of Kamanjab along with the same somewhat green and hilly landscape, features an impressive array of clouds in the sky, with the sun attempting to peek out from the west. Hues of orange can be seen on the horizon.

metas.title: C35 Rugged Mountains
metas.description: A very rugged mountain formation can be seen to the west from a few sections of the C35 and its sideroads.

metas.title: C38 Cloudy Sky
metas.description: The C38 is yet another indistinct paved northern road with sandy soil, somewhat green vegetation and short grass lining the road. The sky, which is covered with a spotty blanket of clouds, is generally the most distinct clue. The sun is faintly shining through the clouds to the north.

metas.title: C39 Valley
metas.description: Most of the C39 travels through a wide valley, with small vegetation-covered hills on both sides, which are mostly visible to the north. The N-NE angle and puffy cumulus clouds dotting the sunny sky are also noteworthy.

metas.title: C40 Flat & Cloudy
metas.description: The C40 has a general NW angle going through flat terrain with the usual northern landscape of short grass next to the road, trees further away and some hills further in the distance. Similar to the C39, a lot of cumulus clouds dot the sky, and the closer to Kamanjab you get, the lower the sun sets to the west.

metas.title: C41 Road Angle
metas.description:
East of the intersection with the C35, the road has a constant SW to NW angle, and grainy pavement. The grass looks soft to the touch, and the somewhat sandy soil is typical of this region. Cumulus clouds dot the sky.

West of the C35 intersection, the same grainy pavement and clouds remain, but the landscape is much hillier, and the road angle changes.

metas.title: C43 Red Tabletop Mountains
metas.description: Along the C43 you can find some of the most impressive red-coloured tabletop mountains. The road is wide and unpaved with light coloured gravel contrasting the otherwise red landscape.

metas.title: C44 Sandy Road
metas.description: The C44 is a wide unpaved sandy road lined with trees, easily recognised from the general E-SE angle, and the westbound driving direction.
metas.note: The D3301, a bit further south looks similar, but the soil is generally much redder, and the car is driving east.

metas.title: C47 Wide Unpaved
metas.description: The C47 is an even wider unpaved road, with slightly redder soil when compared to the C44. The road angle on this road is NE bound, with a SW driving direction. You can also look for either a clear sky, or wispy clouds.

metas.title: C49 Panhandle
metas.description: Often fairly poor quality pavement with only white road lines, no road lines at all, or just slightly faded road lines and red tinted pavement, are all good clues for the C49 in the panhandle. Near the western end, the sun is very low in the sky, and the weather is fully clear.
metas.note: A small section by Makolonga has good pavement with wide shoulders, so look for the orange patches on the road.

metas.title: D3600 Light Pavement
metas.description: The D3600 and the unlabelled road going NE to Mpungu, have a very light coloured, sometimes grainy pavement, with at times very faded yellow lines, which are hard to even see. Combined with the either exactly N to S or NE angle, as well as the northern landscape, make this road very distinct.

metas.title: Northern Roads Without Yellow Lines
metas.description:
A few roads in the north lack the typical outer yellows.

The C46, which is a long road going generally NW to SE. The E-W section by Ruacana, has very poor pavement. SE of Oshikuku, the sun is low in the sky to the NW.

C41 (M123) also has a NW angle but has more clouds in the sky than the C46.

B10 west of Eenhana is an E-W stretch, which is more vegetated, and also has the sun low in the sky to the west.

B10 east of Nkurenkuru is another NW bound stretch with the sun low in the sky, but this part is much more vegetated than the C46. You can also see the moon to the east.

D3615 is a short road with a constant N-NE angle that technically has outer yellows, but they are quite faded.

metas.title: Windhoek
metas.description:
Windhoek is by far the largest city in Namibia, as well as the richest, with many high rise buildings near downtown. Affluent and often gated single family houses are a common sight on the sides of hilly streets, which are often well marked with simple white street signs.

In the northwest of the city you’ll find the slums dotting the hills.

metas.title: Gobabis
metas.description: Gobabis is a big north-south gridded city in the desert, with red soil permeating the landscape and roads, which are very often unpaved. A faint green ridge is sometimes visible to the north to northwest. The street signs, while rare, are also green, with silver framing on the top and bottom. Blue bins are also a good clue for Gobabis.

metas.title: Swakopmund & Walvis Bay
metas.description:
The coastal cities of Swakopmund and Walvis Bay are flat and often have sandy streets, with palms and Norfolk pines planted around. Street and road signs often have square-shaped signposts.

Road angles can be used to line up parts of the city, but a northeast bound angle is common in both.

These white and blue plastic containers are common in Swakopmund, as are yellow lamp posts in downtown areas.

metas.title: Henties Bay
metas.description:
While very similar to Swakopmund and Walvis Bay, Henties Bay is less gridded and noticeably poorer, with most roads being unpaved. Unlike in Swakopmund, where yellow lamps are only found near the downtown, here they can occasionally be found throughout the town.

The cloudy weather can be used to confirm the town.

metas.title: Langstrand Sidewalks
metas.description: Langstrand is a small resort town between Swakopmund and Walvis Bay with pink brick sidewalks next to essentially every road. The weather is always overcast and gloomy.

metas.title: Luderitz Hills
metas.description: Light coloured rocky hillsides are everywhere in the hilly coastal town of Luderitz.

metas.title: Oranjemund Norfolk Pines
metas.description: Oranjemund is a well-off gridded city with almost exactly east to west streets, with an abundance of planted vegetation all around the city. Multiple Norfolk pines can be seen almost everywhere. Streets are well organised with E-W avenues and N-S streets, which can be seen written on small blue markers next to the gates or on street signs, which have varying designs.

metas.title: Aussenkehr Orange Fences
metas.description: Orange coloured thatched fences, walls, and huts are everywhere in the desert town of Aussenkehr, which is built on the slope of a hill.

metas.title: Noordoewer Architecture
metas.description: While not as common, the same thatched architecture is present in Noordoewer, and unlike Aussenkehr, the town was built on flat land, with an imposing cliffside visible to the southwest, across the border in South Africa. Similar mountains can be seen to the north as well.

metas.title: Rosh Pinah Mountains
metas.description: Rosh Pinah can easily be recognised by the dry mountains just northeast of the city, as well as slightly further away to the southwest.

metas.title: Aus Rocky Hills
metas.description: The landscape of Aus is very rocky, with dry hills devoid of vegetation all around. The hills to the north have a fairly smooth sloped shape, while the peaks to the south are more rugged.

metas.title: Rundu Sand Streets
metas.description: While not entirely unique, most streets in Rundu consist of deep and light coloured sand, with a bumpy texture, and tire tracks engraved into it.

metas.title: Opuwo Orange Mountains
metas.description: Orange coloured mountains, which are covered in green vegetation surround the partly hilly town of Opuwo, from where you have a great vantage point of the mountains.

metas.title: Otavi Greenery
metas.description: Otavi sits in between many sets of mountains, all of which are quite far away, but can be seen from the city. Being a northern town, Otavi is quite green, with slightly reddish sandy soil, which is common for the more northern cities. The entire town is on a northeast to southwest grid, which can rule out similar looking cities like Grootfontein and Tsumeb.

metas.title: Karibib Erongo View
metas.description: From almost anywhere in Karibib the dark silhouette of Erongo Mountain can be seen to the north. Dry hills covered in shrubbery flank the town to the south.

metas.title: Usakos Ridge
metas.description: A lone tall ridge with a rugged, striated texture lies to the SSE of Usakos. Another smaller plain textured mountain, which has a red tint to it, is just to the east, or northeast, depending on part of town. From the northern part of town, the cliffy edges of Erongo Mountain are visible to the north.

metas.title: Uis Brandberg View
metas.description: The crown-like outline of Mt Brandeburg is barely visible to the northwest from most parts of Uis, while Many other dry hills surround the town. The open pit mines, which have a distinctive white colour, can be seen from the western half of Uis.

metas.title: Ariamsvlei Hill
metas.description: Ariamsvlei can be recognised by a single flat-topped hill with rocky ridgelines near the top, and small amounts of green shrubbery dotting the slopes. The hill is either to the north, or east, depending on the part of town. The soil has a dark red tint to it, with lots of bushes and small trees growing around the place.

metas.title: Desert & Mountain Landscape
metas.description: Most of Oman features a desert landscape with little vegetation. While the middle and southern half is mostly flat, the north coast features dry mountains similar to those found in the UAE. The southern coast also has mountains, though less dry.

metas.title: Desert Tracks
metas.description: The Omani Google car drivers covered a lot of small tracks in the middle of the Omani desert.

metas.title: Yellow License Plates
metas.description: Licence plates on private vehicles are generally yellow, while commercial vehicles have red plates.

metas.title: White Pickup
metas.description: All the coverage in Oman was taken with a white pickup truck, meaning you will either see most of the car or a large front blur.

metas.title: Arabic Language
metas.description: The official language in Oman is Arabic.
metas.note: Due to high tourism, signs in Oman often have English writing alongside Arabic. The same also applies to the UAE.

metas.title: Yellow Outer Lines
metas.description: Roads in Oman use yellow outer and white middle lines.
metas.note: This is also common in the UAE, Israel, Jordan, as well as occasionally found in Qatar.

metas.title: Black-Yellow Curbs
metas.description: Black-and-yellow curbs are common in Oman.
metas.note: The UAE also commonly uses similar curbs.

metas.title: Light Stone Architecture
metas.description: Buildings in Oman are typically made of light-coloured stone. The houses are ‘blocky’ but still quite ornate, and they are usually surrounded by a matching fence, which often has an even more ornate gate.
metas.note: Buildings in the UAE are often very similar.

metas.title: Blue Directional Signs
metas.description: Directional signs are blue with white text and are usually in Arabic and English.
metas.note: The UAE and Qatar use similar signs.

metas.title: Striped Signposts
metas.description: Many signposts in Oman have black-and-white stripes.
metas.note: Within the Middle East, striped signposts are only found in Oman and the UAE.

metas.title: Wooden Poles
metas.description: Oman typically uses wooden poles, which have pole tops consisting of three varying designs. The first two have 3 insulators, symmetrically attached to a horizontal metal bar. The design with the metal triangle above the wooden pole is unique to Oman. The third design has the insulators attached to the side. Poles in general are more common in Oman than in the UAE or Qatar.

metas.title: Multi-Arrow Chevrons
metas.description: Oman uses black-and-yellow chevrons that have an unusually large number of arrows.

metas.title: Red-White Pylons
metas.description: High voltage pylons painted with a red and white pattern are common in Oman.
metas.note: Within the Middle East, red and white painted pylons can also less commonly be found in Qatar.

metas.title: Black/Grey Bins
metas.description: The vast majority of garbage bins in Oman are either black and made of plastic or metallic and grey, with a three-leaf logo and the text ‘be’ah’ below it.
metas.note: Garbage bins in the UAE will occasionally have the text “bee’ah”, with two E’s. The bins are often more colourful too.

metas.title: White-Orange Taxis
metas.description: Oman uses white taxis, which have orange-coloured panels on each side.

metas.title: Northern Mountains
metas.description: Northern Oman features a dry mountainous landscape similar to eastern UAE. The south coast of Oman also rarely features some similar mountains.

metas.title: Salalah Greenery
metas.description: Close to the southern coast, especially around Salalah, you will find a rolling hills landscape. The area commonly features rocky ground, bushes and small trees as well as some fairly green valleys.

metas.title: Nizwa Green Mountains
metas.description: The mountains north of Nizwa have an amount of green bushes that are unusually large for the north. The mountains are very rocky and jagged, which differentiates them from the more rolling mountains in the south.

metas.title: Bidiyah Green Shrubs
metas.description: Sandy desert with light coloured green and yellow shrubs can be found in northeastern Oman, mainly south and west of Bidiyah.

metas.title: South Bidiyah Dunes
metas.description: South of Bidiyah you can find a couple of dirt roads going through a slightly rolling landscape consisting of orange-pink sand and small yellow-ish shrubs. The roads mainly go between long and low sand dunes with a general south-south-west direction.

metas.title: Salalah Coastal Plain
metas.description: Salalah is located on a flat coastal plain with rolling mountains surrounding it to the north.

metas.title: Masirah Island
metas.description: Masirah Island features a dry and slightly hilly landscape, typically with somewhat grey soil and with brown shrubs visible. Road 51, which circulates the island, usually only has a white centre road line, which can help in recognising it. The front camera on the island is slightly smudged.

metas.title: Acacia Trees
metas.description: Acacia trees, recognisable by their relatively short height and umbrella-like flat crowns, are most abundant and common in northern Oman, but can also be found close to the rest of the coast.

metas.title: Date Palms
metas.description: Date palm plantations are most common along the northern coast.
metas.note: Coconut palms, on the other hand, are usually found near Salalah.

metas.title: Red Sand Dunes
metas.description: Sandy dunes, that usually look quite red, are found near the border with Saudi Arabia and further inland in the middle of Oman.

metas.title: Gas Pipelines
metas.description: Gas pipelines, often paralleling the road, are most common around Fahud, in Ad Dhahirah Governorate. But they can also be found in many pockets in central-southern Oman.

metas.title: Bin Codes
metas.description: You can use the colour of the bins in Oman to narrow down your location. The purple regions are mixed.
metas.note: Even the dark blue and red regions are not 100% a certain colour.

metas.title: Bin Codes Map
metas.description:
Many bins have a set of numbers on them that can be used to always get the region.

The first pair of numbers give away the governorate, and the second pair further divide the governorates into smaller subdivisions.
metas.note: This map does not list every regional code.

metas.title: Black Bin Black Sticker
metas.description: Black bins with a black sticker on the front can be found in Al Buraimi, Ash Sharqiyah North, and Muscat Governorates.

metas.title: Grey Bin Black Sticker
metas.description: Grey bins with a black sticker on the front are found in Ad Dhahirah Governorate.

metas.title: Black Bin White Sticker
metas.description: Black bins with a white sticker are found in Ad Dakhiliyah Governorate, southern Dhofar Governorate, and Muscat Governorate.

metas.title: Grey Bin White Sticker
metas.description: Grey bins with a white sticker are commonly found in Ad Dakhiliyah Governorate, and sometimes in Dhofar Governorate.

metas.title: Black Bin No Sticker
metas.description: Black bins without stickers are mainly found in Al Batinah South Governorate and north of Al Khaburah in Al Batinah North Governorate.
metas.note: Black bins throughout Oman may appear like they lack stickers, so use this with caution.

metas.title: Grey Bin No Sticker
metas.description: Grey bins without a sticker on the front are found in Al Batinah North Governorate.
metas.note: They can have a sticker on the side.

metas.title: Small Western Black Bins
metas.description: Western-style small black bins are found in Muscat and eastern Al Batinah North Governorate.

metas.title: Chevron Sticker Bins
metas.description: Bins in Muscat governorate often have white-and-red chevron-like stickers on the sides.

metas.title: Side Sticker Bins
metas.description: Regardless of colour, if the bins have a sticker on the side, you should be in one of the North Coast governorates.

metas.title: Copyright Year Map
metas.description: Some of the following hints are split into 2 by copyright year, the number that appears in the Google copyright of each pano.
metas.note: When a panorama is updated, the copyright changes to the current year, so copyright is not always accurate.

metas.title: Upward Antenna
metas.description: A regular-looking antenna that faces upwards is mainly found around and west of Muscat, as well as on highways in the northwest. A few other pockets include Al Buraimi and Sohar.

metas.title: Forward Antenna
metas.description: A forwards-facing antenna is only found in and around Muscat.

metas.title: Coiled Cable Mess
metas.description:
A car with a coiled cable mess can be found in the middle and parts of the north.

In 2024 coverage, it’s only found in the far northeast and central-north Al Batinah South Governorate.

metas.title: No Cable
metas.description: A car with no cable is found in the northwest, both in 2024 and 2025 coverage.

metas.title: Cable Between Bar/Roof
metas.description: A cable in between the bar and roof is found in most of central Al Wusta, and eastern Dhofar Governorates.

metas.title: Over Cable
metas.description:
The ‘Over Cable,’ which goes over the bar, can be found in most of the country. 

In 2024 coverage, it’s found in some pockets of the north, as well as most main roads elsewhere. While in 2025 coverage, it’s mainly found in southern Dhofar Governorate.

metas.title: Top Cable
metas.description: The ‘Top Cable,’ which runs on top of the bar is found primarily in western and eastern Al Wusta Governorate.

metas.title: Looping Side Cable
metas.description: This small looping cable attached to the side of the bar is found in northeastern Oman, and more rarely, in Sohar.

metas.title: Double Side Cables
metas.description: A car with cables on both sides is found in central Dhofar Governorate.

metas.title: Long Thin Cable
metas.description: This long and thin cable is only found in and west of Muscat.

metas.title: Side Cable
metas.description: The ‘Side Cable,’ which runs along the side of the bar, is on the main roads south of Ibri, as well as south of Al Khaburah, in Al Batinah North Governorate.

metas.title: Looping Down Cable
metas.description: A cable that does a loop and goes down into the truckbed is found along a thin line north of Dhahir, in Al Wusta Governorate.

metas.title: Bar Tape
metas.description: This small piece of tape attached to the bar is found in the majority of coverage in Al Wusta and Dhofar Governorates.

metas.title: Left Rusty Nut
metas.description:
If there is a rusty nut on the left screw of the front left mounting bar connector, that places you in northeastern/northern Oman.

In 2024 coverage, this meta overlaps with the more easily identified coil wire, and places you in either the far northeast, or west of Seeb.

In 2025 coverage, it will place you in the general northeast quarter, muscat, or sohar.

metas.title: Right Rusty Nut
metas.description: If the rusty nut is on the right screw of the front left mounting bar connector, that places you in either central Oman, or Musandam Governorate, which is the northern exclave.
metas.note: The central part is generally flat, while Musandam is very mountainous.

metas.title: Two Cut Zip Ties
metas.description:
If there are two cut zip ties on the left side of the bar/cable, it will place you in southern Dhofar, western Al Wusta*, or more rarely in the north around Sinaw or Nizwa. 

See below hint*

metas.title: Right Uncut Zip Tie
metas.description: All the Al Wusta ‘2 cut zip tie coverage,’ which is located northwest of Haima, has a third zip tie on the right side, which is uncut.

metas.title: Left Roof Stripe
metas.description: This small stripe on the bottom left corner of the roof, places you either west of Nizwa, or to the northeast between Nizwa and Seeb.
metas.note: The stripe is more clear in the coverage between Nizwa and Seeb.

metas.title: Dirty Roof Specks
metas.description: A dirty roof covered in small black specks means you are in western Al Wusta Governorate between the 39 and 31 yellow roads.

metas.title: Left Roof Orange Speck
metas.description: A faint orange speck on the middle left side of the roof places you west or northwest of Ibri.

metas.title: Bottom Left Stain
metas.description: Similar to the last hint, if the stain is on the bottom-left of the roof, it places you in Al Wusta Governorate. Either southeast of Haima, or the east coast.

metas.title: Roof Edge Stripes
metas.description: If the edge of the roof is stained with distinct short stripes, with a gap between each one, you are likely in southeastern Ad Dakhiliyah ‍Governorate, or over the eastern border.

metas.title: Truck Bed Water Bottle
metas.description: A water bottle in the truck bed places you northeast of the Oman label, in Al Wusta Governorate.
metas.note: If the water bottle is on the right side, you are likely near the eastern extent of coverage.

metas.title: Brown Roof Splatter
metas.description: This brown splatter stain on the roof means you are around Sohar.
metas.note: If the splatter is accompanied by a dirty roof, you are northwest of Ibra.

metas.title: Mirbat Ridge
metas.description: The ridge east of Mirbat is similar to the Salalah ridge, but more pronounced, and the terrain just south of it is more rugged and hilly.

metas.title: Sinaw Lone Mountain
metas.description: A prominent lone-standing mountain can be seen from afar just southeast of Nizwa. It is more wide than it is tall, and has a crown-like shape.

metas.title: North Adam Landscape
metas.description: Just north of Adam, you’ll find a flat desert landscape with greyish soil and mountains in the distance, notably one long ridge to the south followed by two smaller and rounder hills to the east and southeast. Other mountains are also visible to the north and west.

metas.title: Adam Haze
metas.description: In and close to Adam, the coverage is usually quite hazy, and the ridge and hills from the previous tip can be seen to the north. Though sometimes, only one or two are visible. Unlike north of Adam, you won’t see mountains in any other direction.

metas.title: Ubar Agriculture
metas.description: Around the town of Ubar, you can find patches of green agricultural land surrounded by desert.

metas.title: Amal Oil Drills
metas.description: Oil drills are common around Amal and sometimes seen along Road 39. As well as northwest of Fahud, in Ad Dhahirah Governorate.

metas.title: Al Amarat Mountains
metas.description: If you are surrounded by mountains on all sides, and you are in a somewhat urban area, you are likely just southeast of Muscat, in Al Amarat.

metas.title: Fahud Pipes
metas.description: The bumpy and sloped ridge of hills combined with all the pipes and other oil related infrastructure makes the town of Fahud very distinct.

metas.title: Musandam (Coastal Cliffs)
metas.description: Most of the coverage in the Musandam Governorate exclave is coastal, with rocky cliffs usually hugging the road. A majority, but not all, of this coverage will have the coast to the west, excluding any other roads in the country with a similar look.

metas.title: Ibri-Saudi Road
metas.description: The road going to Saudi Arabia from Ibri can be recognised by the completely flat desert landscape with bright pink-greyish soil along with the road having very wide shoulders and the overall great road condition. The southern portion goes in a straight northeast direction, and the northern section curves more and can have more shrubs.

metas.title: West Fahud Road
metas.description: Similar to the previous road, the road west of Fahud goes through a flat desert with pink-greyish soil. The main difference is that the road itself is in poor shape and without roadlines as well as the direction of the road being southeast.

metas.title: Road 29 Mountains
metas.description: Road 29 south of Ibri features a fairly shrubby landscape, with low and jagged mountains on the eastern side of the road. The low-lying sun to the northwest is particularly distinct.

metas.title: Road 29 South
metas.description: The southern section of Road 29 only has a middle white line, which along with the greyish and sandy desert landscape makes this road unique.

metas.title: Road 31 North
metas.description: This long stretch of Road 31 can be recognised by the light-coloured flat desert landscape along with the wide shoulders and the often faded road lines. The weather is usually somewhat cloudy.

metas.title: Road 31 Divided
metas.description: The divided section of Road 31 is the only divided road going through a flat desert landscape.

metas.title: Road 32 North
metas.description: Road 32 north of Duqm travels through a hilly desert landscape, in a general northern direction.

metas.title: Road 32 Sharqiyah
metas.description: Crossing into the Ash Sharqiyah North Governorate, the shoulders become wide, like those on Road 31. However, unlike Road 31, the desert here is darker and has more shrubs and greenery. A long portion of the road also has overcast coverage. The lighter red section is no longer road 32 but still features the wide shoulders. The landscape further north also gets hillier and more vegetated.

metas.title: Road 35 Hills
metas.description: Road 35 is surrounded by hills and mountains, and the ground is mostly covered in green shrubs. Curved lamp posts are posted at regular intervals on the northeastern side of the road.

metas.title: Road 37 Angle
metas.description: Road 37 travels in a generally northwest direction through a very generic, flat desert landscape. The angle is one of the best clues for this road. On the southern half, a big power line is visible to the northeast, while on the northern half, you can find distinct sunset coverage.

metas.title: Road 39 Shoulders
metas.description: Road 39 is also one of the more generic roads. Probably the best way to recognise it are the narrow, or even non-existent shoulders. The western parts can get quite hilly, but overall, the desert landscape is flat.

metas.title: Road 41 Coast
metas.description: Coastal Road 41 features one of the sandiest landscapes in Oman, with very light sand all around. The coast is sometimes visible in the distance. On the north-to-south stretch, you can see a distant ridge to the west.

metas.title: Road 41 West
metas.description: The western stretch of Road 41 has wide shoulders similar to Road 31, however, the more northwest-bound angle along with the reddish soil should tell them apart. The eastern half has cloudy coverage.

metas.title: Road 42/49 Cliffs
metas.description: Road 42/49 east of Salalah is a scenic coastal road that features a lot of light-coloured tall rocky cliffs. The coast is also often visible.

metas.title: South Shalim Overcast
metas.description: Just south of Shalim, you’ll find a stretch of overcast coverage, along with a power line to the west of the road, but only north of the plateau.

metas.title: North Shalim Unpaved
metas.description: North of Shalim Road 42 turns into a very wide unpaved road, with the soil being quite light in colour. You’ll sometimes see oil drills in the distance along this stretch.

metas.title: Southeast Ubar Road
metas.description: The road southeast of Ubar has a general northwest bound angle, along with a power line to the left of the road. You will often see signs of life in the form of farms or buildings on this road.
metas.note: Don’t mix this up with the 37, which has a similar angle, but is more desolate and can have sunset coverage.

metas.title: Road 43 Sunset
metas.description: Road 43, also south of Ubar, is unpaved and features sunset coverage along with a dust trail behind the car.

metas.title: Northwest Ubar White Marks
metas.description: The unlabelled road northwest of Ubar can be recognised by the small white markings between the dashes.

metas.title: Methane Road
metas.description: Just west of ميتان, only labelled in Arabic on Google Maps, literally translating to methane, there is a stretch of road, which has a uniquely light-coloured pavement. To the north, you can see sand dunes.

metas.title: Road 45/39 West
metas.description: Roads 45 and the western stretch of 39 both feature a similar slightly hilly desert landscape, sunny weather, and a general east-to-west direction. What makes them unique is the light-coloured shoulders the roads share, though it is most pronounced on Road 45. The roads also mostly have a faded white middle line. To tell the 45 and western 39 apart, look at the sun, which is overhead on the 39, but to the west on 45. The section north of Mudayy is also the 45, but unlabelled on Google Maps.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Cyprus uses both standard white European license plates, and UK-style plates that have a yellow rear plate. Most license plates have the EU strip on the left. Rental cars, which have a distinct red plate, are not uncommon either.

metas.title: Coverage Extent
metas.description: Only the southern half of the Island, namely the Republic of Cyprus and the British overseas territories of Akrotiri and Dhekelia are covered.

metas.title: Greek Alphabet
metas.description: Cyprus uses the Greek and English languages. Greek has a unique alphabet not used in any other language. It shares similarities with both the Latin and Cyrillic alphabet, however the lower case letters generally have softer shapes than the Cyrillic letters.
metas.note: It goes without saying, but Greece also uses the Greek alphabet.

metas.title: Left-Hand Traffic
metas.description: Cyprus drives on the left side of the road.
metas.note: Malta also drives on the left.

metas.title: British Infrastructure Influence
metas.description: A former crown colony of the United Kingdom until 1960, Cyprus continues to use some borrowed infrastructure, like signs and roadlines. This is also why Cyprus drives on the left, and why English is so widely used.

metas.title: Generation 4 Smallcam
metas.description: Most coverage on the island was taken with a Generation 4 “smallcam”, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, with a short antenna sometimes visible on the back.
metas.note: Greece also has a significant amount of smallcam coverage, but will never have a visible antenna.

metas.title: Triangular Bollards
metas.description: Bollards are superficially similar to Turkish bollards, with a red reflector at the front and a white one at the back. However, unlike Turkish bollards, they are not flat but rather triangular, with a slanted top.

metas.title: Greek Style Directional Signs
metas.description: Directional signs are very similar to Greek directional signs, with the one notable difference being that the Greek text is written in all-caps.

metas.title: Unique Town Entry Signs
metas.description: Town entry signs consist of either a yellow rectangle with a red border, or just the smaller white rectangle that contains the town name in both Greek and English. The signs will also contains a speed limit sign above them. These designs are unique to Cyprus.

metas.title: Dark Brown Wooden Poles
metas.description: Utility poles are primarily wooden, typically quite tall and have a distinctly dark brown colour.
metas.note: All of these features are shared with Greek utility poles.

metas.title: Common Poletops
metas.description: Poles commonly have one of three poletops. The first consists of a crossbar with zero or three insulators on top. The second consists of five insulators attached directly to the side of the pole. And the third one consists of a metal frame shaped vaguely like a harp.
metas.note: These are also commonly found in Greece.

metas.title: Painted Stone Architecture
metas.description: Most buildings are made of brightly painted stone, with either a tiled or a flat roof.
metas.note: These features are also common in Greek architecture.

metas.title: Mediterranean Landscape
metas.description: The island has a Mediterranean landscape, with bright exposed rock, olive trees, palm trees, cypress trees, and green coastal farmland. The interior consists of pine forests in the mountains.

metas.title: White Water Tanks
metas.description: Houses in Cyprus often have a horizontal and cylindrical water tank that is white in colour, and has a circular access lid near one end on the top.

metas.title: Road Numbers
metas.description: Cyprus uses A, B, E, and F roads, and they are grouped by their first digit.
metas.note: E and F roads are located near the B road with the matching first digit. This is useful because B roads are easier to find.

metas.title: Area Codes
metas.description: Each of the 5 provinces uses a two-digit area code, starting with a 2.

metas.title: Postal Codes
metas.description:
Cyprus uses four-digit postal codes, grouped by region. They can be found on street signs, and are denoted by either T.K. or T.T. 

The first digits can be useful to memorise.

metas.title: Mountainous Interior
metas.description: Being a small island, the terrain will be the easiest way to narrow down your location. Most of the country is hilly to mountainous, with the centre having the highest elevation, that you can use to orient yourself.

metas.title: South Coast Limestone
metas.description: While the bright exposed limestone rock is a good clue for the country, it is mainly found along its southern coast.

metas.title: Interior Red Soil
metas.description: On the other hand, reddish soil is found in the interior and northwest of the country.

metas.title: Southwest Vineyards
metas.description: Vineyards are found more towards the southwest of Cyprus.

metas.title: Wild Mustard
metas.description: Wild Mustard, which looks like bushes of yellow flowers, while possible to find on most of Cyprus, is most common in these areas, mainly in the eastern half of the country.

metas.title: Paphos Forest
metas.description: The Paphos Forest nature reserve consists of windy mountain roads with red soil on the sides, passing through the mostly uninhabited Mediterranean forest. You will not see any bollards in the reserve, with few exceptions.

metas.title: Kyrenia Ridge View
metas.description: In the northeast of Cyprus, you will often be able to see the Kyrenia Mountain ridge to the north, overlooking the otherwise flat farmland.

metas.title: Famagusta Red Fields
metas.description: Dark red fields, even if covered in vegetation, are a good clue for northern Cyprus and Famagusta, the far eastern region.

metas.title: Famagusta Shitcam
metas.description: Famagusta can easily be recognised by the mostly flat landscape, with lots of red fields. Maybe more importantly though, all of the coverage is shitcam.
metas.note: Shitcam is quite rare in the rest of Cyprus.

metas.title: Wind Turbines General
metas.description: Wind turbines are found in two main clusters on Cyprus: west of Larnaca in the east, and southwest of Anogyra, near the Limassol-Paphos subdivision border.

metas.title: East Wind Turbines
metas.description: The wind turbines in the east are built on sandy rolling hills, surrounded by agricultural fields .

metas.title: Southwest Wind Turbines
metas.description: The wind turbines in the SW are located within the Oreites Forest, a shrubby hill surrounded by more extreme elevation. There is a noticeable incline towards the coast, which is often visible to the southwest.

metas.title: Slovenia-Style Bollard
metas.description: A different kind of bollard with a black top, resembling those found in Slovenia for example, can sometimes be found in north-eastern Cyprus.
metas.note: The presence of regular Cypriot bollards does not exclude the highlighted region.

metas.title: Snow Coverage
metas.description: Snow coverage can be found on a few roads southeast of the Cyprus island label, near the Holy Monastery of Panagia Machaira.

metas.title: Mount Olympus Blue Lines
metas.description: Dashed blue lines between the outer and inner road markings can be seen on a few roads around Mount Olympus.

metas.title: Peyia Bananas
metas.description: Banana plantations can be found along the western coast around Peyia.

metas.title: Limassol Russian
metas.description: With a Russian-speaking population of around 17%, many commercial signs in Limassol feature Russian translations.

metas.title: Right-Hand Traffic
metas.description: Vietnam drives on the right side of the road.
metas.note: Cambodia and the Philippines are the only other southeast Asian countries with normal Street View that drives on the right side.

metas.title: White License Plates
metas.description: Vietnamese licence plates are white with black lettering. Both long and short versions are in use.

metas.title: Vietnamese Script
metas.description: The Vietnamese language uses a modified version of the Latin script, but with a far larger number of diacritics than any other script found on Street View. Words are generally somewhat short, typically consisting of a single syllable.

metas.title: Concrete Bollards
metas.description: The most common bollard type is a small square concrete bollard that is painted white with a red top.

metas.title: Striped Signposts
metas.description: The posts of road signs are usually painted with a red and white stripe pattern.

metas.title: Yellow Road Signs
metas.description: Road signs have a yellow-orange background. Within southeast Asia, this is unique.

metas.title: Colourful Waystones
metas.description: Waystones that are painted white with a colourful top, usually red or blue, are common throughout the country.
metas.note: Waystones like these are also common in Thailand and Cambodia. Often, they will include the road number in a large font on the side, and in a smaller font in the red area on the back and front. In addition, the front and back will list distances to towns. This information can be really helpful with pinpointing.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description: Chevrons are either black on yellow or white on red and typically only have one arrow.

metas.title: Blue Directional Signs
metas.description: Directional signs are typically blue with either a very thin white border or no border at all. The signs usually contain white arrows, which rather than being orthogonal often point in slightly strange directions.

metas.title: Short Yellow Dashes
metas.description: While multiple different types of road lines, both white and yellow, can be found in Vietnam, unusually short yellow middle dashes are particularly common and distinct.

metas.title: Concrete Roads
metas.description: Minor roads made of concrete blocks are very common in Vietnam.
metas.note: This is also common in both the Philippines and Thailand, and to a lesser extent in Indonesia.

metas.title: Concrete Barriers
metas.description: Red and white striped concrete safety barriers are somewhat common on mountain roads.

metas.title: Holey Poles
metas.description: Holey poles, with holes either only on the lower half or almost all the way to the top, are common in Vietnam.
metas.note: The only other Asian country that commonly has holey poles is Sri Lanka, where the holes are significantly larger.

metas.title: Pinhole Poles
metas.description: Vietnam often has round concrete poles with indents and small pin holes near the top.
metas.note: The same type of pole is also common in Cambodia.

metas.title: Trapezoid Poletops
metas.description: Poletops shaped like upside down trapezoids are common in Vietnam.
metas.note: These may look similar to the poletops found in central and northern Sulawesi, Indonesia.

metas.title: Double Poles
metas.description: Double poles, which can be of different varieties, are fairly common in Vietnam.

metas.title: Electricity Boxes
metas.description: Utility poles often feature these light grey electricity boxes, which can have anywhere from 1 to 4 small indented windows. They have a very characteristic shape, where the bottom part slopes down slightly.

metas.title: Motorcycle Coverage
metas.description:
Vietnam has a fair amount of motorcycle coverage. This can be recognized by the unique shape of the car blur, which vaguely resembles the shape of a bone, and extends slightly higher up on one side. Sometimes you will only see the helmet of the motorcyclist.

There is both Generation 3 and Generation 4 motorcycle coverage.

Vietnam has by far the most motorcycle coverage in the world. In particular, if you see this type of coverage in a rural place, you are almost guaranteed to be in Vietnam.

metas.title: Shitcam Blur
metas.description: Shitcam can be found in some areas of Vietnam. Notably, the shitcam coverage has a car blur similar to the one from the previous tip, which makes it distinct from other countries where shitcam usually has a larger and more circular blur.
metas.note: The areas in which shitcam can be found will be discussed further at the end of step 2.

metas.title: Drying Grains on Roads
metas.description: It is somewhat common to see grains being spread out on roads to dry.
metas.note: This practice is also common in the Philippines, and more rarely in Thailand as well.

metas.title: Address Signs
metas.description:
Addresses on signs are extremely common in Vietnam, in particular on storefronts. These addresses follow a hierarchical sequence that usually goes from specific (house/building) to general (city/province). These can be tremendously helpful to find your exact location.

Usually an address will contain all or some of the following elements, from left to right:

House and street number

Ward/commune:

Ward (urban areas): phường

Commune (rural areas): xã

District:

Urban district: quận

Rural district: huyện

District level town: thị xã

Municipal/provincial city: thành phố

Province/City

Province: tỉnh

Municipality: thành phố (a municipality in Vietnam is a city that is on the same administrative level as a province, such as Ha Noi, or Hải Phòng)

These words are often abbreviated. For example, huyện can be abbreviated as just H., thành phố as just TP., etc. Additionally, sometimes the province itself may be abbreviated, for instance here Thái Bình is abbreviated as TB.

metas.title: Province Names Map
metas.description:
The provinces are the most useful part of an address. They are easy to scan for on the map, but it is recommended to learn them by heart to find them even quicker on the map. 

Often, the names of provinces are abbreviated. For example, Tien Giang is abbreviated TG. These can be especially useful to learn by heart to get an edge over your opponent.

It is important to note that Vietnam is currently undergoing an administrative reform, combining most provinces into larger provinces, reducing the number of provinces significantly. Google hasn’t updated its map to reflect this change yet, but it is expected to happen soon. This makes learning the provinces by heart even more important: the overwhelming majority of coverage will be from before the administrative reform, meaning that in the near future, you cannot simply scan the map for some of the provinces’ names.

There are lots of resources available to learn the province names and abbreviations. We recommend https://helloquiz.app/.

metas.title: Area Codes Map
metas.description: Area codes in Vietnam always start with a 2, followed by one or two more digits, which are generally ordered from north to south.

metas.title: License Plate Codes Map
metas.description: Vietnamese licence plate codes, which are often painted onto the sides of trucks and other vehicles, are another useful clue to figure out the region.

metas.title: Place Name Prefixes Map
metas.description: Some place name prefixes, meaning the start of a city name, are regional within Vietnam.

metas.title: Red River Delta Fields
metas.description: Wide open and completely flat agricultural fields are most commonly seen in the Red River Delta and somewhat less commonly found in the Mekong River Delta.

metas.title: Mekong Delta Landscape
metas.description: The Mekong Delta is an exceedingly flat, water-rich area. It is traversed by numerous very straight canals, often flanked by linear villages. It is one of the most densely populated parts of Vietnam, with cultivated fields essentially everywhere. The area is even more tropical than the rest of Vietnam, with lots of palm trees and lush wetland vegetation.

metas.title: Central Highlands Landscape
metas.description: The Central Highlands region tends to have a landscape with a somewhat distinct vibe: often hilly with distant mountains, red soil, and often fairly dry, rolling agricultural fields. Additionally, the vegetation is a bit drier than in the rest of Vietnam (depending on the season).

metas.title: Rubber Plantations
metas.description:
Rubber tree plantations are primarily found in the provinces to the north of Ho Chi Minh City, as well as in several parts of the Central Highlands.

Rubber trees can be recognized by their thin trunks. In Vietnam, it is typical for a section of the tree trunk to be wrapped in a piece of plastic. These trees tend to be neatly organized in a dense grid-like pattern.

metas.title: Tea Plantations
metas.description:
Tea plantations are primarily found in the north, limited to several disconnected areas. 

A major exception is the southern province of Lâm Đồng, which has a large tea area centred around the city of Bảo Lộc.

Tea plants can be recognized by their compact and neatly trimmed shape, with small dark green leaves. They are often, but not always, planted in windy rows on hillsides.

metas.title: Khasi Pines
metas.description: Clusters of Khasi pines growing on hills are very typical of far northeastern Vietnam, specifically the provinces of Lạng Sơn and Quảng Ninh.

metas.title: Dragonfruit Farms
metas.description:
Dragonfruit farms are mostly found in two small areas in the south: 

around the city of Phan Thiết in Bình Thuận province

a small area on the border between Long An and Tiền Giang, northeast of Mỹ Tho .

Dragonfruit resembles the end of an upturned wet mop.

metas.title: Phan Thiet Dry Coast
metas.description: The coastal region northeast of Phan Thiết city is noticeably dry and sandy, compared to the typical Vietnamese landscape. Some parts of this region are very rocky as well.

metas.title: Black Pepper Plantations
metas.description: Black pepper plantations are common in the area in and around the Central highlands. Black pepper is a type of vine that is cultivated on tree trunks: the pepper plants shroud these trees with a dense cover of downward-pointing leaves, completely obscuring the tree’s trunk.

metas.title: Wind Turbines Map
metas.description:
Wind turbines can be found in a few clusters mainly in the southern half of the country.

Here are the clusters from most to least common:

Southeast of Dalat, near the coast

North of Buon Ma Thuot, Dak lak

South of Pleiku, Gia Lai

Southeast of Dong Hoi, Quang Binh

East of Quy Nhon, Binh Dinh

South of Ho Chi Minh City, near the coast.

Western Quang Tri province.

metas.title: Roof Spires
metas.description: Thin spires on the roofs of houses are almost exclusively found in the northern half of the country.

metas.title: Red River Delta Architecture
metas.description:
Houses in the Red River Delta (the flat, densely populated area around Hanoi) tend to have a boxy look, typically tall with multiple storeys. These houses often feature gaudy details that borrow heavily from antique Greco-Roman architecture: pillars, pediments, classical-looking balconies, etc.

Note that similar houses are sometimes found in the direct vicinity of Ho Chi Minh City.

metas.title: Mekong Delta Architecture
metas.description: Houses in the Mekong Delta also have a boxy, concrete look, but are usually much less tall: they almost always consist of just a single, ground-level storey.

metas.title: Traditional Wooden Houses
metas.description:
Traditional wooden houses are common in the northwest. They commonly have one or several of the following features:

Stilts holding up the house,

corrugated metal roofs,

triangular openings on the side of the roofs.

metas.title: Field Graves
metas.description: Single graves in the middle of agricultural fields can be found in the Red River Delta.

metas.title: Stick Fences
metas.description: Wooden fences made out of sticks, or even bamboo, in a grid-like pattern, similar to fences commonly found in northeastern India, are found in the northern parts of Vietnam.

metas.title: Large Hole Poles
metas.description: Utility poles with large holes along most of the pole are common in northern Vietnam.
metas.note: Do not confuse this with the regular holey pole, which is where the holes extend only halfway up the pole. This ½ of the holey pole is found throughout the entirety of Vietnam.

metas.title: No Pinhole Poles
metas.description: Round concrete poles usually feature many pinholes on the top half of the pole, however in the north they often feature a minimal amount or even no pinholes.
metas.note: Although more rare, pinhole poles may be found in the north.

metas.title: Trapezoid Poletop Region
metas.description: Poletops shaped like upside down trapezoids are common in central and northern Vietnam.
metas.note: Trapezoidal pole tops may be off-centre which is not the same as regular off-centre poles.

metas.title: Triple Trapezoid Pole
metas.description: The trapezoid shaped poletops can sometimes be off-centre. If a utility pole has three off-centre incomplete trapezoids then you will be in the north of the country.

metas.title: Southern Triangle Pole
metas.description: Poletops shaped like a triangle, with the support bars underneath the crossbar, are found in southern Vietnam.
metas.note: The middle insulator must be mounted onto the pole itself, rather than on a metal extension of the crossbar.

metas.title: A-Shaped Pole
metas.description: A poletop shaped like an A above a crossbar can be found in the centre of the country.

metas.title: Off-Centre Crossbar
metas.description: Utility poles with uneven crossbars, meaning the crossbar is significantly more to one side of the pole than the other, are found in the south of the country. Sometimes, they are not fully uneven but are more in the style of Indonesian off-centre poles.
metas.note: You may mistake partially off-centre trapezoid poletops for regular off-centre poletops, however any pole with a trapezoid connector belongs in a different category. In the exception, the connector is not a straight bar, rather it is an incomplete trapezoid.

metas.title: Bamboo Poles
metas.description: Thin bamboo poles can be found in rural areas of the northwestern mountains.

metas.title: Black Pole Stickers
metas.description: Poles in the northern parts of the country will often have black pole stickers, similar to those found in Malaysia but often with a more simple design.

metas.title: Shitcam Region
metas.description: Shitcam is only found in a few spots in the Red River Delta.

metas.title: Dalat Greenhouses
metas.description: The countryside directly around the city of Đà Lạt is densely covered in greenhouses.

metas.title: Dong Van Karst
metas.description: The Đồng Văn Karst Geopark in northern Hà Giang province, in the extreme northernmost tip of Vietnam, is characterized by a very distinct landscape: rounded, pointy mountains with relatively sparse vegetation, exposing the very dark rocks underneath.
metas.note: The broader region of northern Vietnam is also characterized by pointy mountains. The Geopark is unique because of the exposed rocks.

metas.title: Phu Quoc Island
metas.description: The island of Phú Quốc is found in southern Vietnam near Cambodia. Phú Quốc only has Generation 3 coverage and has a lot of dark red soil. You may sometimes see a large forested ridge, which sits northeast on the island.

metas.title: Ha Long Bay
metas.description: On the coastal roads of the Hạ Long Bay, east of Hải Phòng, you can see numerous pointy, rocky islands rising out of the water, making for idyllic views.

metas.title: Tay Ninh Mountain
metas.description: A single large mountain in the middle of an otherwise completely flat landscape can be found just northeast of the city of Tây Ninh.

metas.title: Khanh Hoa Peninsula
metas.description: This peninsula in far northern Khánh Hoà can be recognised by the many sand dunes hugging the road, which is mostly a divided highway, but also a smaller paved road for a shorter stretch.

metas.title: Hoi An Old Town
metas.description: The historic town of Hội An, just south of Da Nang, can be recognised by the old yellow buildings typically with dark brown doors and details.

metas.title: Sa Pa
metas.description: Sa Pa is a resort town deep in the northern mountains overflowing with touristy stores and restaurants with excessive signage, and palace-like grand hotels throughout the town. The architecture is a mixture of an affluent European style and a more typical southeast Asian style.

metas.title: Phan Thiet Cyrillic
metas.description: Near the beach resorts just east of Phan Thiết city, most signs will have Cyrillic text alongside Vietnamese, catering to Russian tourists.

metas.title: White Car No Antenna
metas.description: All of Botswana was covered by a white Google car without an antenna.
metas.note: Within Africa, this car can also be found in South Africa, Lesotho and Eswatini.

metas.title: White & Yellow License Plates
metas.description: Botswana has white front plates and yellow rear plates, similar to UK-style plates.
metas.note: Botswana and Namibia are the only countries in southern Africa where yellow rear plates are predominantly found.

metas.title: English Signs
metas.description: Signs in Botswana are usually in English. Most town names, however, are derived from any of the indigenous languages spoken in the country.
metas.note: The Afrikaans language, which is closely related to Dutch and common in South Africa, is very rare in Botswana. You will almost never find Afrikaans place names.

metas.title: Dry Flat Landscape
metas.description: The typical Botswana landscape is dry and mostly flat, though a limited amount of elevation can be found in certain regions. Common vegetation includes shrubs, small trees, and occasionally dry, golden grasslands. The soil is arid, sandy and ranges in colour from white to red.
metas.note: The border region of South Africa can have a similar landscape.

metas.title: Southern African Road Lines
metas.description: Like the other countries in Southern Africa, outside road lines (if present) are yellow, while centre road lines are white.
metas.note: Outside yellow road lines in arid environments also exist in Israel, Palestine, Jordan, and the UAE. However, these countries all drive on the right side.

metas.title: Striped Signposts
metas.description: Botswana has a unique black-and-yellow striped signpost. More rarely, you can see red-and-white signposts.
metas.note: In Southern Africa, these signposts are only found in Botswana.

metas.title: Striped Curbs & Guardrails
metas.description: Curbs and guardrails are usually striped. Possible colour schemes are black-and-yellow, red-and-white, and black-and-white.

metas.title: Red-White Chevrons
metas.description: These small red-and-white chevrons can sometimes be found next to the road.
metas.note: They are also very common in South Africa.

metas.title: Green Directional Signs
metas.description:
Just like the other Southern African countries, direction signs have a green background.

The numbers of major roads start with A. These road numbers frequently appear on direction signs.
metas.note: Road numbers in South Africa never start with A.

metas.title: Old Blue Road Signs
metas.description:
Some road signs have a blue background. This is an older style of sign that was used before signs with white backgrounds were introduced. They are relatively unique to Botswana.

Note that most road signs will have the newer white background.

metas.title: Botswana Architecture
metas.description: Typical Botswana houses range from small impoverished shacks to comfortable middle-class bungalows. Some buildings have exposed grey bricks. On occasion, you might find traditional round huts.
metas.note: All of these house styles are also found in the other southern African countries.

metas.title: Random Small Blurs
metas.description: Random small blurs are common in Botswana’s coverage. These blurs are similar to the ones found on licence plates and faces, but they cover seemingly random parts of the panorama instead. This is especially noticeable in urban areas, and mostly absent on more rural roads.

metas.title: Region Map
metas.description:
Botswana has many unique and distinct regions throughout the country. This image breaks down the main factors that differentiate each distinctive landscape by soil, vegetation and other clues.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

RESOURCE: This image was made possible by the invaluable research done by Jasper Woodard. You can check out his Botswana videos on his YouTube channel.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Coverage in Botswana is fairly limited due to the country’s sparse road system. In addition to regular paved roads, you can still expect to see some rural unpaved road coverage. The most dense coverage is in the east and near Gaborone. The larger towns have extensive side road coverage.

metas.title: Paved vs Unpaved Map
metas.description: This map shows which covered roads are paved, and which ones are unpaved. It is slightly simplified for ease of reading. Small, unpaved side roads in and near towns are not shown.

metas.title: Elevation Map
metas.description: Most of Botswana is as flat as a pancake. However, every now and then you will find some elevation. If you see hills, you are most likely in one of the two areas indicated on the minimap.
metas.note: Even in the indicated areas, there are a lot of very flat areas, as many of Botswana’s hills are geographically isolated. Some lone hills may also appear far outside the indicated areas.

metas.title: Southeastern Hills
metas.description: The southeastern region near Gaborone has many semi-arid hills covered in short shrubs. If you see a lot of these, you are likely to be in the area between Gaborone and Lobatse.
metas.note: Similar hills can be found elsewhere in the country and across the border in South Africa. If you see a large quantity of them, and use other clues to rule out South Africa, you can be fairly certain that you are in southeastern Botswana.

metas.title: Eastern Red Soil
metas.description: The landscape in the eastern pocket north of Francistown is characterised by red soil and a somewhat arid look. The soil in these two areas often looks firm and rocky, rather than sandy or dusty. Trees and bushes with yellowed leaves and other “autumn” colours are common. Many trees are bare and withered. You might see fallen leaves on the ground here and there.

metas.title: White Sandy Soil
metas.description: A large region in the middle western part of the country is characterised by very white sandy soil. In addition, the vegetation tends to look very dry.
metas.note: Sandy soil can be found in many places in Botswana. This tip specifically refers to the bright white colour of the sand.

metas.title: A35 Power Line
metas.description: The A35 is a very recognisable road: there is always a power line to your west. It can also be recognised by its grainy asphalt with faded markings. Many small tracks can be found parallel to the road, disappearing into the bushes.

metas.title: A33 Lush Vegetation
metas.description: The A33 is characterised by a landscape that is more lush than usual. Trees have lots of green leaves and the grass is very tall. The more north you go, the more lush the vegetation becomes.

metas.title: Middlepits Red Asphalt
metas.description: The road that runs along Botswana’s southern border, through the town of Middlepits, has asphalt with a distinct red tint. The landscape is arid. In some sections, slight hills can be seen.
metas.note: Near the town of Middlepits itself, the soil is very red and dotted with small white pebbles.

metas.title: Gaborone
metas.description: Gaborone is the capital and largest city. It tends to look richer and more developed than the rest of Botswana, though some neighbourhoods may still look impoverished. In some southern parts of the city hills can be seen, but most of the town is flat.
metas.note: The only other place in the country that often looks similar is Francistown.

metas.title: Francistown Hill
metas.description: In Francistown, you can often see a lone hill with radio antennas, which is located on the north side of the city. This hill is a good way to distinguish Francistown from Gaborone.
metas.note: The town of Serowe has a similar hill with antennas. Here, the towers are taller, red-and-white striped, and the hill has a flat top.

metas.title: Maun White Soil
metas.description: Maun is the only relatively large city in Botswana that has this bright white sandy soil, which is typical for the middle western region of the country.

metas.title: A2 West Overcast
metas.description: The western part of the A2 has overcast coverage, making it recognisable.

metas.title: Chobe National Park Dirt Roads
metas.description: Chobe Flood Plains National Park in the far north has a lot of small, winding dirt road coverage, with a lot of it being just south of the Chobe River. It has scattered lush bushes on either side, and you will often find wildlife such as elephants and warthogs.

metas.title: A30 Autumn Trees
metas.description: This portion of the A30 has a distinct autumn feel unique to it. Notably, there are trees with orange coloured leaves lining the road in straight rows. In addition, there is often tall grass as opposed to other autumn looking locations.

metas.title: Salt Pans
metas.description: Salt pans can be found in central-eastern Botswana. Dirt road coverage can be found leading to the pans and has similar soil and grass, but you can also find many trees along the road. They are mainly found around the Nwetwe pan. The salt pans show up as lakes on the map.
metas.note: A lot of the dirt road coverage near the pans was taken in June, and will feature trees without leaves or those that are beginning to lose their leaves.

metas.title: Gaborone Dirt Tracks
metas.description: Just outside Gaborone, there is a lot of coverage along very rural, small dirt tracks. They can be identified by the orange-red shade of dirt and abundance of green trees and bushes surrounding the road.

metas.title: A33 Construction
metas.description: The section of the A33 within the Sibuya Forest Reserve and the CT/3 (Tamafupa) Commercial Wildlife Utilisation is under construction. This is most visible by the service road or embankment alongside the road.
metas.note: Despite being in the construction zone, some locations may still look normal.

metas.title: Maun to Khwai Road
metas.description: The mostly unpaved road north of Maun to Khwai can be identified by extremely white sandy soil and tall green trees surrounding the road. The first section of the road, between Maun and Shorobe, is paved. But that section can still be identified by the trees, faint road markings, and power lines to the west of the road.

metas.title: A20 Red Soil
metas.description: The A20 has mostly clean, recent asphalt. Some sections of the road are much thinner than usual. The landscape is characterised by red soil, dry grey-coloured trees, and very little grass.

metas.title: A20 Southeast
metas.description: Southeast of Tshabong, the A20 has been recently repainted and has very bright yellow lines and relatively dark asphalt. There is a powerline running alongside it to the northeast, it has orange-tan sandy soil, and you can often find patches of yellow flowers.

metas.title: Tsodilo Hills
