metas.description: The Tsodilo Hills World Heritage Site is memorable due to its large protruding hills with exposed rock faces. The coverage around the hills is entirely on dirt roads.

metas.title: Pandamatenga Silos
metas.description: These distinctive silos are found in Pandamatenga in northeastern Botswana and can be seen all around the town.

metas.title: Trekker Coverage Map
metas.description:
Egypt has very sparse coverage. The entirety of the coverage is in Generation 3, made with a trekker camera. Trekkers can be recognized by the fact that the camera is lower to the ground, having smaller blurs, and no car shadow.

Instead of learning a lot of country-specific clues, it is more practical to simply memorise what the trekkers look like. There are seven sections of coverage, each centred around historic places of interest, ranging from the Pyramids to Coptic churches and medieval citadels.

The coverage is limited to two general areas:

Cairo: four trekkers.

Alexandria: three trekkers, two of which are fairly far outside the city to its southwest (Monastery of Saint Mina and nearby archeological excavations).

metas.title: Sandstone Buildings
metas.description: Many of the buildings you see in the trekker coverage are made of sandstone.

metas.title: Arabic Script
metas.description: The official language in Egypt is Arabic. You can occasionally see it on signs in several of the trekkers. Its script can be identified by its lines and dots.

metas.title: Giza Pyramids
metas.description: The great pyramids of Giza have trekker coverage.
metas.note: This is not to be confused with the pyramid in Memphis, which is made of glass instead of sand stone.

metas.title: Khafre Temple
metas.description: The coverage inside the valley temple of Khafre can be recognised by the rows of massive square pillars.

metas.title: Djoser Pyramid
metas.description: The Djoser pyramid, which can be recognised by the stair-like sections combined with the scaffolding surrounding it, is located south of Cairo. You can also find some other minor historical excavation sites and some plain desert coverage.

metas.title: Cairo Citadel Walls
metas.description: The Cairo Citadel is an enormous fortification with a trekker walking through and around it. It can be recognized by its massive walls that are made of clean-cut sandstone blocks.

metas.title: Muhammad Ali Mosque
metas.description: Inside the Citadel, you can see the Ottoman-era Mosque of Muhammad Ali. It has light grey domes and very tall minarets.
metas.note: This mosque looks superficially similar to the Hagia Sophia mosque in Istanbul.

metas.title: Hanging Church Exterior
metas.description:
The trekker in and around the Hanging Church consists of two parts that look fairly different from each other.

Outside the church, the trekker is walking around a normal urban Cairo street. At most points, you will still see the church complex, its spires with crosses, and historic sandstone walls. But you will also see apartment buildings, shops, and normal pedestrian traffic.

This trekker can be found just east of Giza, near the map label Fustat.

metas.title: Hanging Church Interior
metas.description: At a certain point, the trekker moves from the street into the Hanging Church. Inside, you will see a beautiful courtyard with religious mosaics and two white church spires.

metas.title: Qaitbay Citadel
metas.description: The Qaitbay Citadel consists of a large castle surrounded by thick walls, which are both made of sandstone.

metas.title: Saint Mina Monastery
metas.description: The monastery complex of Saint Mina consists of several large, palace-like buildings in a somewhat modern, Arabic style. Most of the buildings have several spires crowned with Christian crosses.

metas.title: Abu Mena Excavation Site
metas.description: The Abu Mena Heritage Site is a major excavation area southwest of Alexandria, just south of the Saint Mina monastery. In the middle of the site, you can find a small, yellow wooden chapel.

metas.title: Green Hills & Grass
metas.description: Eswatini’s landscape is known for its green, wooded hills and tall golden grass.
metas.note: In contrast, Lesotho’s mountains are typically barren, and long grass is not a common sight there.

metas.title: Wooden Poles
metas.description: Poles in Eswatini are made of dark brown wood and follow a simple design. The insulators are mostly mounted on the side.
metas.note: In Southern Africa, three insulators on the pole are more commonly found in Eswatini.

metas.title: MR Roads
metas.description: Roads starting with the letters “MR” are exclusive to Eswatini.

metas.title: Southern African Road Lines
metas.description: Eswatini typically uses yellow outside lines and occasionally, triple white middle lines.
metas.note: Similar road lines can also be found in South Africa, Lesotho and Botswana.

metas.title: White Car No Antenna
metas.description: All of Eswatini was covered by a white Google car without an antenna.
metas.note: Within Africa, this car can also be found in South Africa, Lesotho and Botswana.

metas.title: Green License Plates
metas.description: Licence plates in Eswatini are long and green at the bottom.
metas.note: These may look similar to certain South African plates. Make sure to refer to other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Concrete Bus Shelters
metas.description: Concrete bus shelters are a common sight on roads in Eswatini.

metas.title: Montane Grasslands
metas.description: Montane grasslands with long golden grass and a mountainous landscape are typical of Western Eswatini.
metas.note: Long grass can be found in almost all areas of Eswatini. This clue refers specifically to the pristine golden colour most commonly seen in the Western highlands.

metas.title: Pine Plantations
metas.description: Pine tree plantations are found in select areas in the West of the country.
metas.note: Similar plantations can also be found in South Africa.

metas.title: MR9 Green Region
metas.description: This distinct region in the central South of the country, mostly along the MR9, can be recognized by the dark, overwhelming greenness and tall wooded mountains.
metas.note: If you are struggling to see why this is unique, try comparing this to other areas of the country, which are more “golden” and light-coloured.

metas.title: Eastern Flatlands
metas.description: You can recognise this region in the east of the country thanks to the unusual flatness and the mountains often visible in the distance.

metas.title: Sugar Cane Fields
metas.description: Sugar cane is grown in several areas along the Eastern border.

metas.title: MR3 South Ngomane
metas.description: The MR3 South of Ngomane can be recognized thanks to flatness, long dry grass and the dirt on the camera.

metas.title: MR3 Divided Highway
metas.description: The MR3 from Manzini to the South African border is divided by metal and stone guardrails, making it recognisable.
metas.note: This road is the only divided highway found in Eswatini.

metas.title: MR8 Ridge
metas.description: The MR8 in Southeastern Eswatini straddling the South African border is recognisable because of this distinct ridge to the east.

metas.title: Mlawula Nature Reserve
metas.description: You can recognise the Mlawula Nature Reserve thanks to the narrow dirt tracks, tall grass and overall savannah landscape.

metas.title: Lomahasha Portuguese
metas.description: If you see Portuguese text in Eswatini, you are most likely in the small town of Lomahasha.
metas.note: This is because of its proximity to Mozambique, where Portuguese is spoken.

metas.title: Roof Rack Car
metas.description: All regular road coverage in Ghana was made with a unique Google car. It has a visible roof rack with a piece of black tape on the right end of the front bar. In addition, the hood of the car is usually visible, showing a street view car wrapping that features a red rectangle and some other recognizable elements. Normally, this unique car is all you need to identify Ghana.
metas.note: Several natural reserves were covered with different unique cars.

metas.title: Ghana License Plates
metas.description: Ghana uses white plates on normal vehicles, and yellow plates for commercial vehicles. They can be long or short. Because commercial vehicles are really common, you will often see a mix of both plate colours.
metas.note: Nigeria has similar white plates, but a green tint should be visible, which helps differentiate them.

metas.title: Red Soil Landscape
metas.description: Ghana is mostly flat with red soil, however hills and mountains can be seen in some regions. Tropical vegetation is very common, and palms are common especially toward the south.

metas.title: Orange Fender Taxis
metas.description: Taxis in Ghana typically have multicoloured body panels. The fenders and quarter panels are always coloured orange-yellow.

metas.title: White Road Lines
metas.description: Road lines in Ghana are always white. However, many paved roads do not have road lines at all.

metas.title: 3-Insulator Poles
metas.description: Ghana typically uses wooden poles with 3 insulators on a metallic crossbar.

metas.title: Flag Colors
metas.description: Ghana is a patriotic country, and you can often see things painted in the national flag’s colours: red, yellow, green, and sometimes including the black star.

metas.title: Striped Signposts
metas.description: Black and white striped signposts in Ghana are typically seen in cities. On rural roads, you will mostly see classic, non-painted, metal signposts.
metas.note: Black and white signposts can be seen in other countries as well. Make sure to look at other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: The coverage in Ghana is limited and easy to memorize, as most of it was taken on its main roads and in major cities. The most dense coverage is located in the south, around the cities of Accra and Kumasi.

metas.title: Paved vs Unpaved Map
metas.description:
This map shows the distribution of paved and unpaved roads across the country.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Ghana Tape
metas.description:
Ghana features 3 distinct types of tape on the google car:

In the southwest, you can find the ‘unpeeled tape’, which is essentially a mostly intact tape, which is not peeling off.

In the east and north, you can find the ‘peeled tape’, which unlike the ‘unpeeled tape’, is slightly peeled off.

North of Kumasi, and west of Tamale, you can find this ‘scotched tape’, which has two distinct white spots on the left side of the tape.

metas.title: Northern Savannah
metas.description: Northern Ghana features a savannah landscape, which can be identified by its dry soil and less dense vegetation.

metas.title: Mountain Ranges
metas.description: Tall mountain ranges in Ghana are typically seen near Lake Volta in the highlighted area.
metas.note: Mountain ranges to the east are more common in the area near Togo.

metas.title: Dense Forests
metas.description: Dense forests in Ghana are typically found in the southwest and east. You will usually see many naturally occurring palm trees, making the two regions recognizable.

metas.title: Coastal Palms
metas.description: Tall palm trees are commonly found along the coast. Most of them are located in the west.

metas.title: Wa Unpaved Roads
metas.description: Most unpaved roads in a dry savannah landscape are found north of Wa, as well as near the town itself.
metas.note: The other unpaved roads in northern Ghana are the Yendi-Nkwanta road in the east, and part of the Salaga-Tamale road, which has very distinct soil. See the tips below.

metas.title: Sawla-N10 Road
metas.description: The road connecting the town of Sawla with the N10 has very crisp, new road lines. Most of the road runs in a general east-west direction, through a lush savannah landscape. The middle line can be solid or dashed.
metas.note: There are a couple of other roads with crisp road lines like these, however these tend to have a different road angle or landscape.

metas.title: Salaga-Tamale Road
metas.description: The Salaga-Tamale road up to Kpalbusi is a dirt road with very moody overcast coverage. The soil tends to be very dark, with a purple or brown tinge to it. The road also has a unique tropical savannah feel. The soil is most dark near the town of Salaga.
metas.note: Unpaved roads with overcast coverage and a savannah landscape can be found in other places. The unique aspect of this road is the dark purplish brown soil and the especially dark cloud cover.

metas.title: Nkwanta to Domanko Road
metas.description: The road between Nkwanta and Domanko is unpaved, with a powerline close to the road to your east or northeast. The road itself runs in a general SE-NW direction, through a lush savannah landscape that is typical of central Ghana.
metas.note: In urban areas, there can be a powerline on both sides of the road. In addition, a section of the Salaga-Tamale road has a powerline to the east as well, but the darker soil and moody cloud cover makes it distinguishable.

metas.title: N2 Ridgeline
metas.description: On a section of the N2 east of Lake Volta, you can often see a ridgeline to your southeast, somewhat close to the road. The road itself also has a distinct angle, running in a general SW-NE direction. The sky is very overcast and grey.

metas.title: East Accra Coastal
metas.description: The coastal area just east of Accra, especially on the N1, has a distinct landscape: it is very flat and wide open, with significantly less vegetation than the rest of southern Ghana. Some parts can look somewhat dry.

metas.title: N1 Elubo New Road
metas.description: The section of the N1 road near the border town of Elubo is very new: it has dark and unblemished asphalt, a very crisp-looking middle line, and no outer lines. The vegetation is dense and occasionally features palm trees.
metas.note: This new road surface continues until the town of Azuleti. The middle line can be dashed or solid. Near Azuleti, the road does not have a middle line.

metas.title: Keta Lagoon
metas.description: The Keta Lagoon in the southeast of Ghana can be seen on the road that runs along it, with the lake being most visible in the northern section. You can sometimes see grey rocks on the side of the road. The soil is quite sandy in comparison to the rest of the country, and it should have a coastal feel.

metas.title: Nature Reserve Car
metas.description: Several nature reserves and sanctuaries have this unique car. A white car and side mirrors will be visible instead of the regular car, however, the ‘Ghana tape’ will still be there.

metas.title: Ankasa Game Reserve Car
metas.description: The Ankasa Game Reserve has a unique Google car. The entire front of the Google car can be seen, with only the actual camera blurred. The roof of the car will have a street view vinyl and the ‘Ghana tape’ will be present.

metas.title: Boabeng Fiema Car
metas.description: The Boabeng Fiema Monkey Sanctuary has a unique Google car. The ‘Ghana tape’ and roof rack will not be visible however, the black right side mirror will be slightly visible just outside the blur.
metas.note: The red soil and surrounding vegetation should still be good clues for the country, despite the lack of the typical car meta associated with Ghana.

metas.title: Snorkel Cars
metas.description:
Kenya has many unique Google cars, almost all of which will have visible car meta. In Generation 3 you will typically see a car with a roof rack and a snorkel. In Generation 4 you will always have a large pickup truck, which will either be white or grey. The grey car comes in two slightly different variations, of which one can either be with or without a snorkel.

It is the only country other than Mongolia with a snorkel.
metas.note: You can see National Park Cars in other countries with a snorkel on the front of the vehicle. Each vehicle will have its own distinct look.

metas.title: Follow Car
metas.description: On a lot of the coverage you will see a grey Toyota SUV following the Street View car.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Kenya uses long white front licence plates. The rear counterpart is square and yellow.

metas.title: Safaricom Ads
metas.description: This mobile network brand named Safaricom is unique to Kenya, and almost every city has one location.

metas.title: Road Lines
metas.description: Outer lines in Kenya will always be solid white, while inner lines will be yellow and either solid or dashed.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Directional signs are green with a white border and text. They often display road numbers in white or yellow.

metas.title: Red Road Signs
metas.description: While infrequent, road signs in Kenya will mostly be red and white.

metas.title: County Names
metas.description:
Upon closer inspection of signs, billboards and posters, you will notice that the county name is often written. Therefore, knowledge of Kenyan counties can be extremely useful in region guessing.

You can practise Kenyan counties using the quiz in the resource section.

metas.title: Repurposed Vans
metas.description: These repurposed vans can be found all over Kenya.
metas.note: While these vans can also be found in Uganda, the design of the vehicle wrap is clearly different.

metas.title: Eucalyptus Trees
metas.description: Many species of eucalyptus are commonly found in Kenya. They can be identified by their long, often clumped leaves, and smooth bark.
metas.note: Eucalyptus trees can be found in other countries. Use this information to help reinforce your country guess.

metas.title: Gen 3 No Car
metas.description: While the vast majority of Kenyan car coverage has a visible Street View car, it is possible to find Generation 3 coverage with no visible car.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
Most of the coverage in Kenya outside of the southwest is limited to main roads.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Topography Map
metas.description:
The natural formation of land has great diversity between regions. The east and large portions of the north are extremely flat. In contrast, the further southwest you travel, the higher the elevation becomes on average.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Climate Map
metas.description:
Kenya has distinct regional climates. Some of these include:

Humid

Semi-Arid

Arid

Very-Arid

As regions vary, this means that there will be many transitional climates. Use this as a guide to quickly determine the general area to assist with region guessing.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Big Snorkel Grey Car
metas.description: This Generation 3 grey car with a large snorkel is mostly found in the west, but can also be found in the Mombasa and Nairobi areas, and regions east of Nairobi near Kitui.
metas.note: Most Generation 3 coverage has been overridden by Generation 4.

metas.title: Small Snorkel Black Car
metas.description: This Generation 3 black car with a small snorkel is mostly found in the east of the country. You can also see it north and south of Nairobi.
metas.note: Most Generation 3 coverage has been overridden by Generation 4.

metas.title: Gen 4 Grey Car
metas.description:
Kenya has mostly Generation 4 coverage covered by a large grey Google car, with or without a snorkel. There are many metas regarding Generation 4, too many in fact to break down here.

RESOURCE: Therefore, please use this document. It covers this area in depth, and was created by snowf_lake#9088.

Key meta information can be found in the tips below. Other less extensive, but still noteworthy car meta, can be found in the spotlight section.

metas.title: Tape on Roof
metas.description: You can see pieces of white tape on the roof of the Google car in a lot of the coverage north and south of Nairobi.

metas.title: A109 Orange Dirt
metas.description:
The A109 between Mombasa and Nairobi has light orange dirt and many hills around the road and in the distance. You will additionally see many transportation trucks delivering various goods.

Most of the coverage between Mombasa and Emali also has a unique car, which has a cord on the left.

metas.title: Mombasa Coast
metas.description: Mombasa and the other coastal towns are easily identified from the white sandy soil, palm trees and coastal feel.

metas.title: Far West Agriculture
metas.description: The far west areas of the country that are northwest and southwest of Kisumu are the most agricultural parts of the country. You will often see farms, grassy hills, and tall eucalyptus trees in this region of the country.

metas.title: Kitui Dry Hills
metas.description: The area around Kitui is semi-arid, usually mountainous, and has light orange, sandy dirt.

metas.title: Northwest Landscape
metas.description: The northwest part of the country has very limited coverage, most of which is on the A1 or in Sibiloi National Park. It has faintly tan soil and sparse low trees. A lot of the coverage in this area is very flat, but you can also see hills or mountains.

metas.title: White Flowers
metas.description: White flowers, especially when they are in large numbers, are commonly found east of Chyulu Hills National Park, as well as in Tsavo National Park and near the A109 south of Nairobi.

metas.title: National Parks Overview
metas.description:
Kenya has many unique Google cars in and around its National Parks and Reserves. These are still identifiable by the snorkel which is present in almost all of them.

Many of the National Park and Reserve cars must be used in conjunction with landscape, as they can be found in multiple areas.

You can learn more about these National Parks and Reserves in the spotlight section.

metas.title: B9 Red Dirt
metas.description: The B9 in the Northeast is entirely unpaved and has bright reddish orange dirt with many trees surrounding the road. Most of it is very flat, but the coverage at the western end of the road can have hills and mountains. The soil also transitions into a more sandy colour.

metas.title: A2 South Marsabit
metas.description: The A2 between Isiolo and Marsabit has many plants alongside the road and you will often see large mountains in the distance. The stretch going through Namunyak Wildlife Conservation Trust will have a very large mountain range to the west.

metas.title: A2 North Marsabit
metas.description: North of Marsabit will be much flatter, with some mountains in the distance. The stretch just north or Marsabit will have mountains visible to the south, while further north, a different range can be seen. It will also have much less vegetation.

metas.title: A3 North Garissa
metas.description: The A3 north of Garissa is very unique, with light coloured soil and many green trees on either side of the road.

metas.title: Western C34
metas.description: The western part of the C34 is a flat, east to west road. There are two long, straight sections with an abundance of sugar cane. Furthermore, you will see a large mountain range north along the entire mentioned stretches of road.

metas.title: Dirt-Speckled Car
metas.description: This car that is covered in specks of dirt is unique to these stretches of the A3, B9, and the Habaswein-Dadaab Road connecting the two.

metas.title: Nairobi City
metas.description: Nairobi is the largest city in the country, and capital of Kenya. It is the only city to have a considerable amount of skyscrapers, and is highly developed. It is densely populated, and is surrounded by small, poor settlements.

metas.title: Kilimanjaro View
metas.description: In a lot of the coverage north of Mt Kilimanjaro, the mountain is visible to the south, usually obscured by clouds. In the city of Oloitoktok, the mountain will often be visible directly to the south.
metas.note: The map shows the location of Mt Kilimanjaro, but it can be seen from very far away.

metas.title: Homa Bay Hill
metas.description: Homa Bay has this protruding hill to the east that is often visible.

metas.title: Mara Triangle
metas.description: Mara Triangle has no considerable mountains and most of it is either flat or hilly. It has a white car that can be found in other Kenyan National Parks. Generation 4 coverage exists there as well.

metas.title: Amboseli NP
metas.description: Amboseli National Park has a grey car with a small snorkel. It is very flat with tan grass, few trees, and dried up lake beds. You can always see the base of Kilimanjaro to the south, with most of it obscured by clouds.

metas.title: Aberdare NP
metas.description: Aberdare National Park has a grey and brown car that features a large snorkel. Almost all of the coverage is outside of the National Park, with only two roads within the park covered. The main road through the park has these rubber bands on the roof rack, which can only be found in one other National Park in Kenya.

metas.title: Mt Elgon NP
metas.description: Between Kitale and Mt Elgon, you can find the Aberdare car as well, but it will always have rubber bands, unlike in Aberdare where it will only have them on the main roads through the park. It can be differentiated from Aberdare by its redder dirt, and greener landscape.

metas.title: Sibiloi NP
metas.description:
The area surrounding and between Kerio and Lodwar uses the same car as the Aberdare National Park, but with a vastly different landscape. It is very sandy, dry, and has little vegetation.

You may also find yourself in Generation 3 coverage without car meta.

metas.title: B8 Succulents
metas.description: This stretch of the B8 just north of Kibaoni has many succulents on the side of the road.

metas.title: Generation 3 White Car
metas.description: All coverage in Lesotho is Generation 3. In almost all locations, the back of a white Google car without an antenna is visible.
metas.note:
The other three southern African countries of Eswatini, Botswana and South Africa also have the same white car in Generation 3 coverage.

While Botswana and Eswatini only have Generation 3 coverage, South Africa also has Generation 2 and Generation 4 coverage. In addition, Generation 3 coverage is somewhat rare in South Africa.

metas.title: Lesotho Mountains
metas.description:
One of the best ways to identify the country are the characteristic ‘Lesotho mountains’. They are bare and treeless, often have tabletop-like shapes, and recognizable horizontal rocky ridgelines.

Depending on where you are in the country, the mountains can vary a bit in appearance. Especially inland areas towards the southeast, where they appear more like rolling green hills rather than isolated tabletop mountains. However, you will still often be able to see the horizontal rocky ridges.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Lesotho uses long white licence plates with blue text. If partially unblurred, you may see the Mokorotlo hat symbol on the left.

metas.title: Road Lines
metas.description: Lesotho uses yellow outer lines and white inner lines.
metas.note: These are also found in the other three southern African countries.

metas.title: Triple Middle Lines
metas.description: Some roads have unique triple middle lines, consisting of two solid lines with a dashed line in between.
metas.note: These are also found in the other three southern African countries, but nowhere else in the world.

metas.title: Left Hand Traffic
metas.description: Like the three other Southern African countries, Lesotho drives on the left.

metas.title: Round Huts
metas.description: In rural areas, you will often see traditional round huts with thatched roofs.
metas.note: These are less common in the other three southern African countries, but can still be seen.

metas.title: Agave Plants
metas.description: These agave plants are common throughout the countryside and often a good clue for the country.

metas.title: Short Grass
metas.description: Grasslands in Lesotho primarily consist of short grass.
metas.note: This is mostly useful to distinguish Lesotho from Eswatini, which famously has a lot of tall grass.

metas.title: Basotho Blankets
metas.description: Many people in Lesotho wear traditional clothing. Most recognizably, a lot of people can be seen wearing a Basotho woollen blanket.

metas.title: Livestock
metas.description: Lesotho is a very rural society. You will often see a lot of free-roaming livestock on Lesotho’s roads: most commonly cows, but also horses, donkeys, and other farm animals.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Coverage in Lesotho is very sparse, particularly in the southeastern half, where it’s mostly limited to yellow roads. All urban coverage is found in the northwest.

metas.title: Flat Region
metas.description:
Lesotho can be roughly divided into two regions, based on landscape: flat and mountainous.

In the flat region, the road itself runs through a mostly flat or hilly landscape. “Flat” is a bit of a misnomer, as you will usually still see tabletop-like mountains around you. However they will usually be significantly further away from the road, giving you a more clear line of sight. This “flat” part is the region with the most coverage, settlements and agriculture.

metas.title: Mountainous Region
metas.description:
Conversely, in the mountainous part, the road will usually be directly on the side of the mountain, instead of slightly away from it. The mountains are often large, closer to the road, and covered in green grass.

Coverage in the mountainous part of Lesotho is very sparse: there are only 6 main roads (and a couple of very small off-roads) with coverage, meaning that you can learn each road by heart if you feel so inclined.

metas.title: Water Reservoirs
metas.description:
There are two large man-made water reservoirs in the mountainous part of Lesotho, which can be seen from several road sections.

The larger Katse reservoir is visible from parts of the A25. The smaller Mohale reservoir is visible from an off-road of the A3.
metas.note: Do not confuse these with the small industrial lake found near the Letseng diamond mine.

metas.title: A2 Good Pavement
metas.description: The section of the A2 between Maseru and Mafeteng has by far the best road quality in all of Lesotho.

metas.title: A25 Raindrop Camera
metas.description: On a section of the A25, just east of the big reservoir, the camera is covered in raindrops in one direction.

metas.title: A5 Road Construction
metas.description:
Several sections of the A5 south of Nyakosoba are under construction. As a result, you will often see a sort of temporary “bollard” next to the road, consisting of a stick that is mostly painted white.

Even on sections without the bollard, you can often recognize this road, as it is a wide dirt road with very dark brown soil.

metas.title: Sehlabathebe Road
metas.description:
The road going from Ramatsediso to Sehlabathebe NP, in the southeast on the border with South Africa, is very recognizable. Consider guessing there if the following three things are all true for your location:

Unpaved road with light brown soil.

Good weather with little fluffy clouds.

Grassy landscape high in the mountains.

You will also often be able to see exposed, light-coloured rocks next to the road.

metas.title: Maseru City
metas.description:
The only city with a significantly urbanised downtown area is Maseru, the capital. All other towns have a very provincial feel in comparison to Maseru.

Note that the suburbs of Maseru can still have a very rural feel.

metas.title: Qacha's Nek
metas.description:
Qacha's Nek is a very recognizable town that is located far away from most other towns, on the southeastern border with South Africa.

It is situated right in the middle of green mountains, and it had noticeably bad weather when the Google car drove there.

metas.title: Generation 3 Trekker
metas.description: All coverage in Madagascar was taken with a Generation 3 trekker camera.
metas.note: While there are some unusual vehicles seen on some of the coverage, the camera and blur is still the same.

metas.title: Boat Trekkers
metas.description: Several boat trekkers can be found throughout the country.

metas.title: People Following Trekker
metas.description: Most coverage features one or several people walking alongside the trekker. These people can be used both to recognise the country and to regionguess it.

metas.title: Malagasy Language
metas.description: Madagascar has two official languages: French and Malagasy, which is written with the Latin alphabet and contains many long, multiple-syllable words.
metas.note: English can still be found on some commercial signs.

metas.title: Climate Variation
metas.description: The climate of Madagascar generally varies from extremely dry in the southern and central parts, to tropical in the north.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
Street View in Madagascar is very limited, with a mixture of land and boat coverage, most of which is on or near the west coast. It is worth noting that almost all the coverage was taken using trekkers, with only two exceptions, both of which have a visible, unique Street View car.

Because of the limited coverage, this guide will be structured differently than most other guides. It will be divided into two main sections: one for land coverage and one for boat coverage, which in turn is divided into subsections based on region.

metas.title: Ambanja Person
metas.description: The coverage in Ambanja can be recognized by a person wearing a dark blue T-shirt and black sunglasses.

metas.title: Nosy Ambariovato People
metas.description: The coverage on the island of Nosy Ambariovato can be recognized by the people, one wearing a blue T-shirt and sunglasses on their forehead, one with a light red T-shirt and one with a darker red tank top. There is also a fourth person in some of the coverage, wearing a light blue T-shirt. The coverage is very hilly and forested.

metas.title: Nosy Ambariovato Village
metas.description: There is a village by the northern shore of Nosy Ambariovato.

metas.title: Ambiky Palms
metas.description: Ambiky can be recognized by the large number of palms combined with the brown, sandy dirt road. In most of the coverage, there is a person walking in front of the trekker with a grey T-shirt and a brown backpack.

metas.title: Beach West Ambiky
metas.description: A beach west of Ambiky can be recognized by the low trees combined with low mountains to the northwest.

metas.title: South Ambiky Forest
metas.description: An area with coverage south of Ambiky can be recognized by the large, solitary green bushes combined with a very slight red tinge in the dirt. Certain parts of the coverage are quite wet.

metas.title: Sambirano River Person
metas.description: There are three major sections of coverage along the Sambirano river, most of which can be identified with the single person, wearing a dark blue T-shirt and sunglasses on their forehead. The same person is also present on Nosy Ambariovato.

metas.title: Sambirano River Group
metas.description: A small section of the coverage by the Sambirano river has two different people present on the coverage; one with a red T-shirt and white cap, and one with a spotted dress.

metas.title: Northern Atoll
metas.description: A couple of atolls on the central west coast can be seen on Street View. The northernmost is the smallest, and is easily recognizable as it only consists of sand and you can always see from one shore to the other.
metas.note: Among the five atolls with land coverage, only the two furthest south appear on the map.

metas.title: Southern Atolls
metas.description: The other atolls can be recognized by their small size relative to other landmasses and the broad leaved palms which is rarely found anywhere else in the country.

metas.title: Antananarivo Hill
metas.description: Most of the coverage in Antananarivo was taken on the side of a hill looking out over the city, which leads up to the Queen’s Palace, which can be seen near the top of the hill.

metas.title: RN8 Silver Roof Rack
metas.description: The coverage on the RN8 between Andriamena and Marofandilia can easily be recognized by the large silver roof rack on the Street View car. The coverage is very dry and sandy.

metas.title: RN8 Trekker People
metas.description: The trekker next to the RN8 can be recognized by its extreme dryness, combined with the four people wearing red, blue, grey and light blue respectively.

metas.title: Avenue of the Baobabs
metas.description: Baobab Avenue is easy to recognize by the extremely broad trunked baobab trees along the side of the road.

metas.title: Morondava Town
metas.description: Morondava is most easily recognized by the bald person wearing either a light green or a light red striped shirt. It is also one of few towns where the trekker walks on a paved road.

metas.title: Morondava Beach
metas.description: Morondava has a very smooth sand beach, with the ocean to the northwest. There are a large number of palms visible.

metas.title: Belo Sur Mer Town
metas.description: Belo Sur Mer can be recognized by the large number of palms combined with the blanket of white sand on the ground.

metas.title: Belo Sur Mer Beach
metas.description: The beach outside Belo Sur Mer can be recognized by the somewhat dirty sand and the curved shoreline with the ocean to the northwest.

metas.title: Kirindy Mitea Soil
metas.description: Kirindy Mitea National Park can be most easily recognized by having the reddest soil present on Street View in Madagascar.

metas.title: Manahy Car
metas.description: A car with a barely visible grey metal roof rack can be seen by Manahy. There are some locations where the car is completely blurred out, where the shape of the blur is the best indication of the area.

metas.title: South Manahy Dune
metas.description: A piece of coverage, partly taken on a large grassy field, and partly on the side of a sand dune, can be found south of Manahy.

metas.title: North Andavadoaka Village
metas.description: A village with the shore to the east can be found north of Andavadoaka.

metas.title: Cape Village
metas.description: A small, very sandy village with the shore to the north can be seen on a small cape north of Andavadoaka. Part of the coverage was taken just outside the shoreline.

metas.title: Andavadoaka People
metas.description: The town of Andavadoaka can be recognized by three different people appearing on the coverage; One wearing a greyish hat and a light blue shirt, and two with red and white T-shirts.

metas.title: Andavadoaka Trekker 1
metas.description: The main part of the trekker coverage surrounding Andavadoaka can be recognized by either the person wearing a greyish hat and light blue shirt or a person wearing a yellow T-shirt.

metas.title: Andavadoaka Trekker 2
metas.description: A second Trekker, going to the northeast of Andavadoaka can be recognized by a person with a light blue T-shirt.

metas.title: Blue Cow Cart
metas.description: A blue cart dragged by a black cow on the left and a brown-white cow on the right can be found south of Andavadoaka.

metas.title: Cow Cart (Andavadoaka)
metas.description: Another cart dragged by a white cow on the left and a black and white cow on the right can be found just south of Andavadoaka.

metas.title: Velondriake Village
metas.description: A small seaside village, with little to no visible people can be found in the northern end of the bay, south of Andavadoaka.

metas.title: Velondriake Rocky
metas.description: Coverage on a somewhat rocky ground with no people following the trekker can be found southwest of the bay.

metas.title: Velondriake Shallow Water
metas.description: Coverage with multiple different people walking near and around the trekker, and with a small village to the west, can be found in the southeastern part of the bay. Part of the coverage goes through a very shallow body of water.

metas.title: Velondriake Fishing Nets
metas.description: A cluster of fishing nets can be found in the bay.

metas.title: Tsaranoro Massif
metas.description: The Tsaranoro Massif is a large monolithic mountain with trekker coverage. The steep mountainsides, combined with the mountainous area surrounding the coverage makes it very recognizable. The four people following the trekker can also occasionally be a useful clue.

metas.title: Tsaranoro Forest
metas.description: A small part of the coverage in Tsaranoro was taken inside a forest, which occasionally hides the surrounding mountains. The best way to recognize this area is the relatively dark coverage, combined with the four people following the trekker.

metas.title: Tsaranoro Camp
metas.description: A small settlement is found in the northeastern end of Tsaranoro. The mountains can typically be seen in the background.

metas.title: Toliara Town
metas.description: Toliara can be recognized as being a generally quite busy-looking town and the only large town on Madagascar with no person following the trekker.

metas.title: St Augustin People
metas.description: Two pieces of coverage can be recognized by two people following the trekker; one with a yellow tank top and one with a blue T-shirt. The first of these two parts is located in the town of St Augustin.

metas.title: East St Augustin
metas.description: The second part with the same two people is found to the east of St Augustin, going through a hilly landscape with a lot of shrubs.

metas.title: Nosy Ambariovato Boat
metas.description: A white boat, containing many people, can be found going around the island of Nosy Ambariovato.

metas.title: Ankify Blue Boat
metas.description: A mainly blue boat can be found along the coast south of Nosy Ambariovato.

metas.title: Ambohimena Row Boat
metas.description: A row boat containing five people with a wide wooden frame surrounding it can be found northwest of Ambohimena.

metas.title: Sambirano River Boat
metas.description: A boat going up the Sambirano River can be seen with two people; a tourist with a blue T-shirt and a gondolier with a brown shirt. The northernmost part of the coverage is very dark, as it was taken during sunset.

metas.title: West Coast Atoll Boat
metas.description: The boat covering some small atolls along the central parts of the west coast can be recognized by the driver, wearing a white cap and no shirt.

metas.title: North Andavadoaka Boat
metas.description: The boat north of Andavadoaka can mostly be recognized by the large sail almost filling up the entire screen and the bow which is painted yellow and blue. Note that the sail is not present in the northern parts of the coverage.

metas.title: South Andavadoaka Boat
metas.description: The boat in the bay south of Andavadoaka can be recognized by either the somewhat smaller sail than the one north of Andavadoaka, or the person sitting by the bow wearing a red T-shirt with the text “Diesel”. Beware that only one of the two will appear on most of the coverage.

metas.title: St Augustin Boat
metas.description: Four people; one dressed in red, one in blue and one in yellow in the back, and one dressed in brown at the front, can be seen on a boat by the town of St Augustin.

metas.title: Coverage Overview
metas.description: Mali has very limited coverage. There are only ten small trekkers, divided over seven locations. Instead of learning a lot of country-specific clues, it is more practical to simply memorise what the trekkers look like.

metas.title: Tripod Camera
metas.description:
All this trekker coverage is made with a regular consumer-grade camera on a tripod. This gives all the coverage a very peculiar and recognizable look, which is different from the normal backpack trekkers. It can have a slightly ‘ethereal’ look to it, but it is recommended to simply click on a few of the locations to get a feeling for what it looks like. Objects in the image will usually have motion blur, and slightly saturated colours.

From here on, the Mali tripod trekkers will be simply referred to as “tripods”.
metas.note: Tripods can also be found in several other countries.

metas.title: Mud Brick Mosques
metas.description:
Almost all the tripods focus on showing historical mosques. These tripods usually have an indoor part and an exterior part, which are sometimes not connected to each other.

These mosques have a recognizable look: they are made out of mud bricks and adobe plaster. The walls of the buildings are decorated with wooden sticks. Inside, you will usually see the same adobe walls, and prayer rugs on the floor.

metas.title: Pinpointable Mosque Exteriors
metas.description:
The exterior parts of the mosque tripods can look like a normal street. These will sometimes have enough information available (when moving) to be included in pinpointable maps, like A Community World.

This guide has separate sections for the pinpointable and non-pinpointable coverage. You can choose to study only the coverage that is relevant for competitive maps, or all the coverage. Note, however, that the interiors of the mosques are not considered pinpointable, even though they are covered in the section next to their respective exteriors.

metas.title: Arid Landscape
metas.description: Mali is generally an arid country. Seeing a sandy, dry landscape can help with immediately distinguishing the Mali tripods from most tripods in other countries.

metas.title: Niono Mosque (Exterior)
metas.description:
The Niono mosque is located in a busy area by the side of a wide, sandy and fairly dirty road, with trees right by the walls of the mosque.

It is most easily located on the map by first looking for the “Centre Commercial” slightly north of the centre of Niono.

metas.title: Niono Mosque (Interior)
metas.description: The inside of the Niono mosque can be recognized by its fairly detailed “European style” pillars, which is not found in any of the other Malinese mosques with coverage.

metas.title: Sidi Yahiya Mosque (Exterior)
metas.description:
The roads around the Sidi Yahiya mosque are a mixture of sand and tiles shaped like slices of bread, which within Mali, is unique to this coverage.

The surrounding buildings are mostly built of bricks having a peachy orange colour with a brown undertone. This can also be found around the other two mosques with coverage in Timbuktu. The area generally looks busier than around the Djingareyber mosque.

metas.title: Sidi Yahiya Mosque (Interior)
metas.description: The interior of Sidi Yahiya mosque is recognized by the yellow painted walls combined with the bottom of the walls, which consists of unpainted bricks. The mosque has a courtyard, with walls made of bricks and a floor made of bright, square tiles.

metas.title: Djingareyber Mosque (Exterior)
metas.description: Coverage outside of the Djingareyber mosque in Timbuktu features brick buildings and a paved street with rectangular tiles.

metas.title: Djingareyber Mosque (Interior)
metas.description: The inside of the Djingareyber mosque can be characterised by yellow painted walls, wide round archways, and red carpet.

metas.title: Sankore Mosque (Exterior)
metas.description: The Sankoré Mosque is surrounded by very sandy ground. The mosque itself has a prominent pyramid-shaped tower.

metas.title: Sankore Mosque Doors
metas.description: The Sankoré Mosque has richly decorated doors, which are made of wood adorned with metal details.

metas.title: Sankore Mosque (Interior)
metas.description: The interior of the Sankoré Mosque has blue carpet, yellow painted walls, and a fairly low ceiling supported by wooden beams.

metas.title: Gao Mosque (Exterior)
metas.description: The exterior of the mosque in Gao can be recognised by the large desolate space outside the walls, the ground consisting of reddish dirt, and some trees in the background.

metas.title: Gao Mosque (Interior)
metas.description: The inside of the Gao mosque consists of undecorated corridors with low roofs. You can see the pyramid shaped structure, with a very large number of dry branches sticking out of it, from the courtyard.

metas.title: Djenne Mosque (Exterior)
metas.description: The Djenné mosque has a very recognizable front, with some distant trees and a clear sky. The mosque is surrounded by low houses, making the area look fairly open.

metas.title: Djenne Mosque (Interior)
metas.description: The interior of the Djenné mosque is quite dark, with a high roof and narrow corridors with gothic arches. There is also a large courtyard with sandy ground and brown wooden doors along the walls.

metas.title: Mopti Mosque (Exterior)
metas.description: The Mopti mosque is similar in style to the Djenne mosque, but has trees growing closer to the walls and a slight amount of clouds in the sky. The streets with coverage around the walls of the mosque also appear more narrow than the ones in Djenne.

metas.title: Mopti Mosque (Interior)
metas.description: The interior of the Mopti mosque can be recognised by the somewhat open space, with a high roof, no arches, and a blue carpet across the entire floor.

metas.title: Misplaced Bamako Mosque
metas.description:
In the north west of Bamako, you can find a tripod inside an empty modern mosque. The interior’s light blue walls and pink floor make this location instantly recognizable.

The coverage on the exterior is in the mosque’s yard. The outside walls are made of concrete, and are painted yellow and orange.

This coverage is severely misplaced, being actually located in an unidentifiable rural area, rather than inside Bamako.

metas.title: Bandiagara Gorge
metas.description: This natural rocky gorge is part of the Bandiagara Escarpment. It features dry trees and bushes following the path. It is located southwest of Sangha Ogol Leye, and is the only completely rural coverage in Mali.

metas.title: Misplaced Tripods (Sankore)
metas.description: Inside the Sankore mosque coverage in Timbuktu (but not connected to it), there are several misplaced locations: The inside of a tour business actually located in Bamako, a classroom, a couple of streets and some other miscellaneous places.

metas.title: Pickup Truck
metas.description: A visible Street View car is present in most of the coverage, being a pickup truck with the cab and bed visible. The colour of the cab and other features of it varies. In Generation 3, a roof rack is present. You may also find a large blur covering the entire pickup truck.

metas.title: Police Follow Car
metas.description: A police car, most commonly white or black, can almost always be seen following the Street View car. The follow cars may differ slightly from the ones shown in the image.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Nigeria uses short licence plates that appear somewhat green through the blur.

metas.title: Concrete Poles
metas.description: Most Nigerian poles are made of concrete, have indents with a few horizontal supports, and are similar to the ones used in Brazil, but do not have holes through them.

metas.title: Poor Road Quality
metas.description: Roads are not always well-maintained in Nigeria, so roads without roadlines or faded roads are common. Potholes, cracked roads and unpaved roads are also relatively common.

metas.title: House Architecture
metas.description: Most Nigerian houses are single-storey, with steeply pitched roofs commonly made of metal sheets. Cinder block walls surrounding the houses are also common.

metas.title: Storefront Signs
metas.description: City and state names are often found on storefronts or banners in Nigeria, so knowing them can be quite useful.

metas.title: Shitcam Coverage
metas.description: Within mainland Africa, Nigeria is currently the only country to have this low-quality coverage, known as official ari, or “shitcam”.

metas.title: Topography Map
metas.description: Nigeria is generally a fairly flat country with subtle elevation changes throughout. The south is relatively flat apart from some noticeable hills in the southeast, in Enugu state and in the southwest, between Ife and Lokoja. In the north, more prominent hills and mountains are found from Abuja and Jimeta. The largest mountains are found in the east, making up the Mandara mountain range and the Nigeria-Cameroon border. However, due to little coverage, the mountains are rarely visible.

metas.title: Climate Map
metas.description: Shown is a Köppen climate map of Nigeria. The climate ranges from tropical rainforest in the far south, where you can find an abundance of palms with lush, green vegetation, to a more arid, savannah landscape in the centre, with more scattered trees. In the far north, it transitions to an arid steppe where the vegetation becomes even more sparse.
metas.note: Due to dry/wet seasons, the coverage may look drastically greener/drier than expected for certain latitudes.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
Nigeria is a sparsely covered country, with very few roads in the northwest and east. Most of the coverage is centred around big cities and the highways that connect them.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Gen 3 Map
metas.description:
Knowing where you can find each generation is very useful. Notably, Generation 3 is not found north of Abuja.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Gen 4 Map
metas.description:
Generation 4 is not found in the northwest or far south. Shitcam is now found in most of Nigeria.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Vehicle Tuktuk Colours
metas.description: This map shows states with unique vehicle and tuk tuk colours. If a vehicle is shown, the state will have yellow tuk tuks.
metas.note:
There may be some rare exceptions to what is shown in the image. Paint jobs in-game may also differ slightly to those shown in the image.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Religious Attire
metas.description: Nigeria is mainly Christian in the south, and Islamic in the north. As such, seeing women in hijabs and men in muslim attire is more common in the north.

metas.title: Kaduna Haystacks
metas.description: These haystacks are extremely common and are almost exclusively found in Kaduna state.

metas.title: Kano Corn Fields
metas.description: If you find yourself in an arid, but green, agricultural landscape with an abundance of corn around, you are likely to be in Kano state. It is only covered by shitcam, without any Generation 3 or 4.

metas.title: Benue Vegetation
metas.description: Benue state can be recognized by the lush, green grass covered ground, with reddish soil. The vegetation is somewhat scattered, with the grass making way for taller trees. Shorter trees and shrubs between the grass and taller trees are somewhat uncommon. Thatched huts are also common in comparison to other southern states.
metas.note: An abundance of palms should make you lean toward the bordering southern states that can look similar.

metas.title: Niger State Shitcam
metas.description: Niger state is the shitcam equivalent to Benue state. It is almost entirely covered by shitcam, and can be recognized by the scattered trees, reddish soil, and dry grass.

metas.title: Northwest Arid Roads
metas.description: The highways that run through the northwestern states of Kebbi, Sokoto, Zamfara, and Katsina can be recognized by an even more open and arid landscape compared to Niger state. The tree coverage becomes even more sparse, or there may not be trees at all. These states are entirely covered by shitcam.

metas.title: Northeast Hills
metas.description: A savannah landscape combined with rocky hills can most commonly be seen in the northeast in the states of Plateau, Bauchi, Gombe, Adamawa, and the north of Taraba. The hills in the far east and west of this region are typically greener and covered in more vegetation compared to the hills toward the middle of the range.
metas.note: Around the city of Gombe, hills composed of softer, clay-like soil can be seen instead.

metas.title: Abuja Monoliths
metas.description: These monolithic mountains with exposed, weathered rock are common in and around Abuja.

metas.title: Lekki Palms
metas.description: A flat landscape with coastal vegetation and many palms can be seen east of Lekki. The ground is very sandy. Almost all of the coverage is old Generation 3, with a silver follow car.

metas.title: A121 Highway
metas.description: The A121 can be recognized by the lush, tropical vegetation surrounding the divided highway, with a short, concrete median. Being a major highway, many vehicles, especially trucks, can be seen along it.
metas.note: The A232 heading east of Benin City is also divided, however the median is noticeably wider than that of the A121.

metas.title: A3 Divided Highway
metas.description: The A3 going east of Potiskum to the Borno State border can be recognized by the Generation 4 coverage, mostly open arid landscape, and the highway being divided.

metas.title: Dark Red Soil
metas.description: Dark red soil is most commonly found in and around Benin City and Enugu.
metas.note: Red-tinged soil can be found in many places. This tip refers specifically to dark red soil.

metas.title: Obudu Plateau Road
metas.description: The Obudu Plateau road can be recognized by having the tallest mountains in Nigeria with street view coverage. The road winds up lush, green mountains and the coverage is slightly foggy and wet.

metas.title: Blue Tint Shitcam
metas.description: This variant of shitcam with a distinct blue tint can be found in these areas.

metas.title: Follow Car Map
metas.description: This map shows where each old Generation 3 follow car can be found. They are uncommon, but can still be useful to know.
metas.note: The A121 is not shown on the map as it is recognizable from other clues. This silver Lexus, not shown on the map, can rarely be seen on the highway between Onitsha and Enugu.

metas.title: French Overseas Department
metas.description: Réunion, officially the Department of Réunion, is an overseas department and region of France, east of Madagascar in the Indian Ocean. As such, for country streaks purposes, it is counted as France.

metas.title: Car (Black Tape/Roof Rack)
metas.description: Réunion has a Street View car with visible side mirrors, a roof rack, and black tape at the end of the rear right bar.
metas.note: Make sure not to get this confused with the Ghana car, which has tape on the front right bar.

metas.title: French Infrastructure
metas.description: Being a French Department, you will see French infrastructure, such as signs, bollards and poles.

metas.title: Landscape (Volcanic/Tropical)
metas.description: Réunion is a mountainous volcanic island in the Indian Ocean on a similar latitude to Queensland, Australia. Most roads are along the coast, with lush green mountains visible close by. Vegetation consists of palms and ferns, pine trees at higher elevation, and flowering plants due to the island’s tropical savanna climate.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Only a handful of roads were covered without a trekker. Learning the general regions with coverage will help you get those extra 10 points.

metas.title: Bus Stops (Yellow/L-Shaped/Pink/Orange/Green/Red)
metas.description:
There are six distinct bus stop designs on Réunion:

Yellow - This is the most common type and can be found all over the island. It is usually accompanied by another bus stop, meaning you can get a good region guess if you see it on its own.

L Shaped - It can either be white, or an olive colour. It may also be in the form of a bus shelter. It is almost never accompanied by a yellow bus stop.

Pink - Rarely accompanied by a yellow bus stop.

Orange - Almost always accompanied by a yellow bus stop.

Green - Almost always accompanied by a yellow bus stop.

Red - Rarely accompanied by a yellow bus stop.

This infographic shows where each one can be found. The list above is ranked by how common each one is found.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Sugarcane Plantations
metas.description: Sugarcane plantations on Réunion can be found in two regions: the northeast and the southwest. The southwest is generally more built up and densely populated, meaning you will see more buildings or cars around.

metas.title: Cilaos Caldera
metas.description: Cilaos is a town inside a caldera. It can be recognized by the wall of mountains surrounding the town with overcast coverage.

metas.title: Rectangular Front Blur (North of Saint-Louis)
metas.description: You can spot this rectangular blur on the front camera in all the coverage going north of Saint-Louis.

metas.title: Coastal N1 Highway (Divided)
metas.description:
The northwestern section of the N1 is divided, with a distinct ridge to the southeast and the ocean to the northwest.

Note that although a bridge appears on the map, the coverage was taken before the bridge was built, meaning you will not see the bridge.

metas.title: Route du Volcan (Martian Landscape)
metas.description: Route du Volcan can be recognized by the Martian landscape. The only vegetation is scattered shrubs and the soil is a distinct brown-red colour. These white stones lining the road are also a good clue.

metas.title: Route Forestiere 58 (Dirt Track/Dense Vegetation)
metas.description: La Route Forestière 58 de la Scierie et du Haut des Makes is a winding dirt track that can be recognized by the dense vegetation surrounding it, particularly pine trees and eucalyptus. The track itself is also dark in colour, with grass growing in the middle of it.

metas.title: Eastern N2 (Sparse/Vegetated)
metas.description: The eastern region of Réunion is the least densely populated, evident by the eastern part of the N2, which is a single carriageway passing through somewhat dense vegetation on both sides, or a vast landscape with little to no trees.

metas.title: City Bollards (Saint Paul Black / Saint Denis Green)
metas.description: The two largest towns in Réunion can be differentiated by their bollards, commonly seen at intersections. Saint Paul uses black bollards, while Saint Denis uses green bollards, often with white balls on top. Saint Denis is also more built up, being the capital.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Rwanda uses long white front and yellow back licence plates.

metas.title: Gen 4 Pickup
metas.description: All the coverage in Rwanda is made with a Generation 4 camera. In most of the coverage, the Google car is entirely visible: it is a big white, black, or brown pickup truck. The camera mount is visible.

metas.title: Car Blur
metas.description: Occasionally, the Google car will be covered entirely by a big blur.

metas.title: Hazy Sky
metas.description: The coverage has a noticeable hazy tint to it, which is especially apparent in the sky.
metas.note: In Africa, similar hazy Generation 4 coverage is common in Senegal.

metas.title: Architecture
metas.description: Rwandan architecture features a lot of brick and concrete. Most houses in Rwanda are single family houses, which can have rather steep roofs. Houses also often have fences for protection. The most notable feature of Rwandan architecture are the ‘ventilation bricks,’ which are present in many houses.

metas.title: Hilly Landscape
metas.description: Rwanda is generally quite hilly, but not very mountainous.

metas.title: Red Soil
metas.description: Most of the soil in Rwanda has a noticeable red tint to it.

metas.title: Banana Plants
metas.description: Banana plants are common throughout Rwanda.

metas.title: Bollards
metas.description: Rwanda uses multiple different red and white cylindrical bollards.

metas.title: Waystones
metas.description: Rwanda uses various different styles of white concrete waystones.

metas.title: Clean Streets
metas.description: Streets in Rwanda are noticeably very clean and free of garbage.

metas.title: Striped Kerbs
metas.description: Kerbs are often painted with black and white stripes.

metas.title: Fences & Walls
metas.description: Villa neighbourhoods often have a lot of tall security fences and walls.

metas.title: Driving Side
metas.description: Rwanda drives on the right.

metas.title: Moto Vests
metas.description: All motorcyclists in Rwanda are required to wear red vests and helmets.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Rwanda has quite limited coverage: street view is limited to Kigali, and a couple of other patches elsewhere in Rwanda.
metas.note:
Coverage is being sporadically released, so click the link below to view an up-to-date map.

You can check out the coverage in detail on this site.

metas.title: District Codes
metas.description: Street names often have a two-letter code, which tells you the district you are in.

metas.title: Lamp Types Map
metas.description:
Lamps are fairly consistent on National Roads in Rwanda, but other designs can be sometimes found on some sections.

Roads marked in green mainly use lamps, with lamp arms that have a slight curve near the end and extend past the lamppost.

Roads marked as red have lamps with shorter arms and a sharper bend near the top of the lamppost.

Roads marked with blue use lamps with a longer arm that curves for the entire length.

Grey roads rarely have lamps.

metas.title: Lamp Post Numbers
metas.description: Lampposts along many national roads will have the road number painted in black letters. Below that, you will find the lamp number, which generally, but not always, increases the further from Kigali you get.

metas.title: Kigali Black Pickup
metas.description: The black pickup truck can be found in most of Kigali.

metas.title: Tea Plantations
metas.description: Tea plantations are common in Western Rwanda, and a couple other pockets.

metas.title: Northeast Rolling Hills
metas.description: Northeastern Rwanda has less extreme elevation compared to the rest of Rwanda. It more so consists of rolling hills and open agricultural land or undeveloped grassland.

metas.title: Northwest Volcanoes
metas.description: Volcanoes and volcanic rocks can be seen in northwestern Rwanda.

metas.title: Akagera NP
metas.description:
The Akagera national park features a very vegetated yet dry landscape with wide unpaved roads that are reddish-brown in colour.

You can also find these rectangular waystones at intersections.

This coverage was taken with the brown Google car.
metas.note: There is some coverage on the paved section south of the national park.

metas.title: Dirty Car Cyangugu
metas.description: Around Cyangugu, the Google car is often exceptionally dirty.
metas.note: This is not a 100% meta, but something to take into consideration.

metas.title: Nyungwe Forest NP
metas.description:
The Nyungwe Forest National Park goes through a lush and hilly landscape, which has 2 distinct covered roads; The yellow NR10 is paved, with roadlines. French style bollards and green lamp posts can be seen on the sides of the road. The white NR26 going south is mostly paved, except for the southernmost section. No roadlines are present.

This coverage was taken with the brown Google car.

metas.title: NR10 Roof Specks
metas.description: On the NR10 between Butare and Mont Gabegi, there are two small specks on the bottom left side of the Google car roof.

metas.title: NR11 White Lines
metas.description: The NR11 north of Mabanza uses all white road lines.

metas.title: NR15 Poor Pavement
metas.description: The section of NR15 from Muhanga till the Western Province border has very poor pavement, with a lot of potholes and a lack of road lines.

metas.title: NR15 Unpaved Section
metas.description: The section of NR15 from the Western Province border to this point is under construction, with no pavement at the moment; making it the only covered National Road to be unpaved for this long. Also, most of the road hugs a steep cliffside made of red dirt.
metas.note: Non-national roads are often unpaved, but they are usually not as wide, and have more stuff going on around them.

metas.title: NR16 Dashed Lines
metas.description: The NR16 is the only road that predominantly uses dashed outer white lines.
metas.note: Dashes are also used to indicate intersections elsewhere.

metas.title: Kigali River
metas.description: A wide river can be seen along the northeastern border of Kigali City.

metas.title: Kigali Villas
metas.description: Much of the Kigali coverage is in the richer neighbourhoods. You will see a lot of luxury villas.

metas.title: Butare Cobblestone
metas.description: Many roads in Butare feature cobblestone pavement.

metas.title: Blue License Plates
metas.description: Senegal is the only African country to use fully blue licence plates. A newer version exists in Generation 4 which looks like the standard European licence plate which is white with a blue strip on the left.

metas.title: Gen 4 Truck Cab
metas.description:
A silver or white truck cab is visible in the Generation 4 coverage. Several variants of each exist, most of which are region or road specific. The most useful and recognizable ones will be shown in the spotlight section. For a complete overview, see this document by Lupus.

In the area around Dakar and Thies you can also find a black pick up truck.
metas.note: The car may sometimes be fully blurred. Make sure to look at the landscape or other clues in the absence of car meta.

metas.title: Gen 3 Roof Rack
metas.description: A Google Car with a visible roof rack and the right side mirror is seen in Generation 3 coverage. Rifts can also be seen in the sky.
metas.note: This specific Google Car with the right side mirror visible is unique to Senegal. Roof racks and rifts however can be seen in various other countries.

metas.title: Driving Side
metas.description: Senegal drives on the right.
metas.note: This is mostly useful to distinguish it from Kenya, which drives on the left. The other countries with coverage in Africa that drive on the right are Ghana, Nigeria, Rwanda and Tunisia.

metas.title: French Infrastructure
metas.description: Being a former French colony, Senegal uses French infrastructure such as bollards, poles, signs and road lines.

metas.title: Language
metas.description: The official and most common language seen in Senegal is French.
metas.note: The other sub-Saharan countries with street view coverage use English (Rwanda being a minor exception to this – however landscape should be sufficient to always tell the difference).

metas.title: Kilometre Markers
metas.description: The road number and the distance to the nearest towns can be seen on these white kilometre markers with a red top.
metas.note: The town that is the furthest distance away is usually the largest.

metas.title: Town Entry Signs
metas.description: Most town entry signs in Senegal are white and feature a thick pink outline. The town is also written in a bold, black font.

metas.title: Solar Lamps
metas.description: These simple black lamps with a solar panel at the top are commonly seen in Senegal.

metas.title: Yellow-Orange Taxis
metas.description: Yellow-orange taxis with black fenders can commonly be seen in Senegal.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
This is a coverage map of Senegal. Most of the coverage is west of Touba, with very few roads apart from main roads covered in the east.

You can click on the image to enlarge it. Alternatively, you can look at the coverage in more detail on this site.

metas.title: Northern Savannah
metas.description: The landscape north of The Gambia and for Senegal generally is a flat, arid, savannah-desert landscape with sparse trees. The trees themselves will be somewhat short and have leaves that are faded in colour.

metas.title: Southern Greenery
metas.description: The vegetation in the region south of The Gambia is more lush and green compared to the rest of Senegal, and palm trees can be seen closer to the coast.
metas.note: Coverage toward the west will also be especially tropical. In addition, make sure not to confuse the south with some coverage near Dakar, which can look deceivingly green. However, here the vegetation will look a lot more low and coastal.

metas.title: Diourbel Rural
metas.description: Diourbel Region is the only region in Senegal with extensive rural coverage. The coverage in the region will look like this, with the Google Car driving on a sandy road with sparse trees. Some of the coverage extends to the west in the Thies region up to Babou.
metas.note: The sand in the coverage around Touba tends to be more grassy.

metas.title: Coastal Dunes
metas.description: A very slightly rolling landscape consisting of vegetated sand dunes can be seen along the northwestern coast.

metas.title: Bakel Hills
metas.description: A dry landscape with slight hills can mostly be seen around Bakel, but also south to Nayé.

metas.title: Kedougou Hills
metas.description: A greener landscape with larger hills can be seen around Kedougou and Mako.

metas.title: Northern Rice Fields
metas.description: Irrigated rice fields can sometimes be seen in the region between St Louis and Richard Toll.

metas.title: Long Antenna Car
metas.description: The silver Generation 4 car with a long antenna at the front left can be seen on many roads, but none past the eastern border of Diourbel Region.
metas.note: The antenna is visible even if the car is blurred.

metas.title: White Gen 4 Car
metas.description: The regular Generation 4 white car is most commonly found south of The Gambia, but can also be found on the northeastern coast and a small region between Kaolack and Saly.

metas.title: Divided Highways
metas.description: Divided highways are found between Dakar and Touba. The two divided highways are between Dakar and Touba, and between Dakar and Saly.
metas.note: On Google Maps, the road shows as a yellow road but without road number. There are also no divided highways in Generation 3.

metas.title: N1 Railway Parallel
metas.description: The N1 between Tambacounda and Nayé generally runs in a northeast east direction. A railway runs parallel to the road. The railway is to the south of the road between Tambacounda to just before Youpe Amadi, and is to the north from Youpe Amadi to Bellé.

metas.title: N2 Hazy Low Sun
metas.description: Hazy coverage with a low sun through a sometimes agricultural landscape can be seen on the N2 between St. Louis and Richard Toll.

metas.title: N2 Desert Road
metas.description: The N2 between Richard Toll and Matam is a wide road going through a flat desert landscape with very sparse trees. It can be recognized by the bright blue skies with no clouds. The road itself goes east-west and northeast-southwest.
metas.note: The higher the sun is, the more east you are.

metas.title: N3 Yellow Grass
metas.description: Distinct, tall patches of bright yellow grass can be seen along the N3, mostly to the east in the Matam Region.

metas.title: Bushfire Haze
metas.description: The road northeast of Kedougou to the Malian border can be recognized by the hazy bushfire coverage. Smoke trails can sometimes be seen in the distance. The road is paved south of Saraya.
metas.note: The car is always blurred.

metas.title: Saloum Delta
metas.description: A flat, slightly marshy landscape with low vegetation can be seen on a few sections of roads in the Saloum River Delta.

metas.title: Kola-Velingara Soil
metas.description: The Kola-Velingara road between Saré Amirou and Badion is a dirt road that can be recognized by the late afternoon to evening coverage. The coverage gets later toward the west.

metas.title: Forest of Thies
metas.description: The white road in the Forest of Thies can be recognized by the dry, slightly hilly landscape with brown vegetation. The road itself is made of bright orange dirt. There is also a noticeably haze in the coverage.

metas.title: Box Car
metas.description: The silver Generation 4 car with a box in the back right of the cab can mainly be seen on the road between Richard Toll and Louga, and the N3 between Tiourene and Matam. It can also be seen on the dirt road hugging the Mauritanian border, from Matam to Gassamberi. Finally, it can be seen on a few roads near Diolotène.

metas.title: Dirty Left Car
metas.description: The silver Generation 4 car with a stain at the back left of the cab can be seen on the N2 from Richard Toll to Matam and Bakel to Nayé. It can also be seen on the N1 between Tambacounda and Nayé.

metas.title: Dirty Left & Roof
metas.description: The silver Generation 4 car with a stain at the back left and a dirty roof can mainly be seen on the N1 between Kaffrine and Tambacounda, and the N7 between Tambacounda and Kedougou. It can also be seen between Dahra and Diakhao.

metas.title: Red Cloth Car
metas.description: The silver Generation 4 car with a red cloth at the front left can be seen on this eastern road between Ouro Sogui and Bakel.

metas.title: Antenna Down Car
metas.description: The white Generation 4 car but with the antenna down, parallel to the car’s roof, can be found on the N6 between Ziguinchor and Kolda.

metas.title: White Dirty Back Car
metas.description: The white Generation 4 car with a noticeably dirty back can be seen on the road going north of Kolda, up to Katonfara.

metas.title: Dakar City
metas.description: Dakar is the largest and capital city of Senegal. It can be recognized by the denseness of the city and taller, more modern buildings.

metas.title: Touba Mosque
metas.description: The infamous Great Mosque of Touba can be recognized by the five tall minarets, which can be seen from afar.

metas.title: Driving Side
metas.description: South Africa drives on the left.
metas.note: A handful of other countries also drive on the left. See this infographic for more information.

metas.title: Road Lines
metas.description: On most roads, South Africa utilizes single yellow outer lines and white centre lines.
metas.note:
The other southern African countries of Botswana, Eswatini, and Lesotho also use single yellow outer lines.

Australia practically never uses yellow outer lines.

metas.title: Triple Center Lines
metas.description:
South Africa occasionally features unique white triple centre lines with 2 solid lines on the outside and a dashed line on the inside.

You may also sometimes encounter another unique triple centre line, consisting of two white lines with one yellow line in the middle. These centre lines are usually found on larger main roads.
metas.note: The only other countries where you will find road lines like these are the other southern African countries of Botswana, Eswatini, and Lesotho.

metas.title: Gen 2 Halo
metas.description:
Generation 2 coverage is quite common in the country.

It can be recognized by the large circular car blur and the halo-like colour distortion in the sky.
metas.note: On the continent of Africa, Generation 2 is only found in South Africa.

metas.title: Languages
metas.description:
South Africa has 11 official languages: English, Afrikaans, and various Bantu languages. English is the lingua franca and therefore appears most often on signage.

Afrikaans is a Germanic language that is closely related to Dutch. Common Afrikaans place name suffixes are -fontein, -kraal, -kop, -dorp, -nek, and -berg or -burg. While Afrikaans is most commonly spoken in the western half of the country, you will find Afrikaans place names all over South Africa, meaning that it is not useful for region-guessing.
metas.note: Afrikaans is rare to non-existent in Eswatini and Lesotho. It is also abundantly rare in Botswana, but has some limited presence in the form of place names.

metas.title: Bird Poles
metas.description: The most common type of pole in South Africa features 1 to 5 horizontal bars with thin white insulators that resemble rows of birds, which is why they are referred to as “bird poles” in the community.
