metas.note: South Africa has a wide variety of other poles and pole tops. Some of these are (mostly) limited to a certain region; you can learn more about them in the region guessing section.

metas.title: Green Directional Signs
metas.description: South Africa uses green directional signs with the road number in yellow.
metas.note:
Green directional signs with yellow road numbers are also used in Lesotho, Eswatini and Botswana. Here, the format of road numbers is useful:

N and R-roads are exclusive to South Africa.

A and B-roads are exclusive to Botswana and Lesotho.

MR-roads are exclusive to Eswatini.

metas.title: Warning Signs
metas.description: South Africa utilizes triangular warning signs with a red border and a white background.
metas.note:
Botswana, Eswatini, and Lesotho use similar warning signs.

Australia and New Zealand use yellow diamond-shaped warning signs.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description:
South Africa uses white-and-red chevrons. You can find a similar chevron pattern below directional signs.

In addition, unique-looking small, thin chevrons with one arrow are common next to roads.
metas.note: The thin chevrons can also be found in the other southern African countries of Botswana, Eswatini, and Lesotho.

metas.title: Walled Houses
metas.description: Suburban houses in and around large cities will often be surrounded by high walls, fences, and gates to deter criminals.

metas.title: Gen 4 Blue Car
metas.description: All Generation 4 coverage in South Africa was taken by a blue Street View car with a short antenna.
metas.note: The antenna is sometimes hidden by the blur.

metas.title: Gen 4 Smallcam
metas.description: South Africa also has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, but with a short antenna on the back.

metas.title: License Plates Map
metas.description:
Each province features a different licence plate design, which can be somewhat visible through the blur. Most notably Free State or KwaZulu-Natal, which have a slight green tint and blue tint respectively.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Highways Map
metas.description:
A map of major highways in South Africa. On road signs, the letter ‘N’ should appear in front of the highway number. On Google Maps, however, the letter ‘N’ will not be present. Instead, a blue pentagon with the number will be displayed.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: R-Roads Map
metas.description:
Most of the R-roads with three-digit road numbers are geographically grouped. However, many roads go through multiple provinces and some, especially the 100s, are spread throughout the whole country. The map shows roughly where you can find each set of R-roads.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Area Codes Map
metas.description: Telephone numbers are 10 digits long. The first three digits of landline numbers are the area code. The first digit is always a zero; the second and third digits give you the area. The area codes are geographically grouped, so even learning just the first digit is useful.
metas.note:
Mobile phone numbers start with 06–08. These numbers are not specific to an area.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

Image provided by dbldk.

metas.title: Western Cape A-Poles
metas.description: Poles with 3 bars forming the letter ‘A’, with the bottom insulators being attached at the edges of a horizontal bar, can be found almost exclusively in Western Cape, and rarely in bordering provinces.

metas.title: Eastern Cape A-Poles
metas.description: A similar poletop can be found in Eastern Cape, however the A-shape is noticeably wider and the bottom insulators are attached directly to the ‘A’ rather than a horizontal bar.

metas.title: KZN Trident Poles
metas.description: Trident pole tops are almost unique to KwaZulu-Natal.

metas.title: Northern Alternating Poles
metas.description: Poles with 3 alternating insulators sticking out horizontally at the top are mostly seen in the four northern provinces of Limpopo, Gauteng, North West and Mpumalanga. They can also sometimes be found in Northern Cape. In the rest of the country, these pole tops are exceedingly rare.

metas.title: Triangle Poles
metas.description: Poles with 2 diagonal bars forming a ‘<’ shape can be found mostly in the northeastern provinces, most commonly in Limpopo and North West.

metas.title: Mpumalanga Metal Arms
metas.description: Poles with 1 or 2 metal arms holding up insulators are most commonly seen in Mpumalanga.

metas.title: Red Sign Stickers
metas.description: Square, red stickers on the back of regular signs are often found in Eastern cape and close to Eastern cape in Northern Cape and Free State. You may see them in the North West province as well, but to a lesser extent.
metas.note: Red stickers on the back of chevrons can be seen in almost every province.

metas.title: White Chevron Stickers
metas.description: White stickers on the back of chevrons are often seen in the Cape provinces.

metas.title: Limpopo Pink Pavement
metas.description: You can find this grainy, almost Texas-like pavement with a hint of pink in Limpopo.

metas.title: Bird Nests
metas.description: Big bird nests on top of poles are commonly seen in the northern part of the Northern Cape Province.

metas.title: Power Plants
metas.description: Power plants are often seen in between the town of Secunda and eMalahleni in Mpumalanga.

metas.title: Northeast Arid
metas.description: The northeast of the country can look very dry and somewhat barren, with a lot of orange or red soil. You will often see hills or mountains covered in shrubs.
metas.note: Depending on the season, the coverage can change drastically from dry to very green.

metas.title: Western Cape Mountains
metas.description: Unique rocky, treeless mountains can be seen in Western Cape, with most of the mountains having tall, steep sides and sharp peaks.
metas.note: Similar mountains can be seen in and around Lesotho.

metas.title: Vineyards
metas.description: Vineyards are almost exclusively found in Western Cape, mostly in valleys near the coast. You can also commonly find them near Upington, in Northern Cape.

metas.title: Northern Cape Desert
metas.description: A dry landscape with red soil is typically found in the Northern Cape.
metas.note: This map is a useful guide in guessing based on the climate of South Africa.

metas.title: Sugar Cane
metas.description: Sugarcane plantations are most commonly seen in KwaZulu-Natal, mostly along the coast. However, they can also be seen in Mpumalanga on the Mozambique border. For an overview, see this map.

metas.title: Cook Pines
metas.description: Uniquely tall Cook pine trees are found mostly between the cities of East London and Durban along the southeastern coast.
metas.note: These are planted and not native, so they can be found anywhere along the coast.

metas.title: Pine Plantations
metas.description: Tree plantations that consist mostly of pine are common to the west of Eswatini, and some to the south in KwaZulu-Natal.
metas.note: Pine tree plantations are typically seen within the country of Eswatini itself.

metas.title: Rolling Hills
metas.description: Grassy rolling hills are generally located in the coastal area of Western Cape between Cape Town and George, and just north of Cape Town. Tall ridges are usually visible to the north or east.

metas.title: Mozambique Border Flat
metas.description: The landscape near the Mozambique border in the highlighted area is noticeably flat, with green subtropical vegetation.

metas.title: Kruger Camo Car
metas.description: A camouflage car with black side mirrors and roof racks can be seen in Kruger National Park, on the Mozambique border.
metas.note: The Park now also has generation 4 coverage.

metas.title: Kruger Landscape
metas.description:
The landscape around Kruger National Park is generally flat, with a savannah climate and dry vegetation. You will not see any agriculture and the vegetation is mostly made up of grasses, with small trees dotting the landscape. Red soil can also be seen below the grass.

In addition, this distinctive directional waystone is commonly found at many junctions.
metas.note: Within the coverage of the park, you will mostly find unpaved gravel roads or small and paved roads without road lines.

metas.title: Metro Route Signs
metas.description:
Metropolitan Routes are major roads around cities. They are designated with the letter M.

These distinct and unique M route signs are commonly found in Port Elizabeth (Gqeberha) and Durban, respectively.

metas.title: Joburg Reflective Tape
metas.description: Traffic lights and pedestrian crossing poles in Johannesburg are encircled by three strips of reflective tape.

metas.title: Durban Lamps
metas.description: While this lamp and arm can be found uncommonly across the country, Durban uniquely has this bump on the top. You may, however, still see the standard lamp and arm.

metas.title: Pole Ads
metas.description: Poles or any public infrastructure will often be plastered with dodgy adverts for abortion services or penis enlargement pills in and around Gauteng, in particular in Johannesburg and Emalahleni.

metas.title: R360 Red Asphalt
metas.description: The section of the R360 north of Bokspits, next to the Botswana border, has asphalt with a recognizable reddish tint. The landscape is arid and features dry greyish trees, shrubs and long golden grass. The road runs in a general north to south direction.
metas.note: Asphalt with a reddish tint can be found on other roads and the southern part of the R360. However, the landscape north of Bokspits looks predominantly like this.

metas.title: Table Mountain
metas.description: The distinct Table Mountain, located west of Cape Town, can be recognized by its prominent three-kilometre plateau. It is flanked by Devil’s Peak, which is more pyramidal.

metas.title: George's Peak
metas.description: Mountains in the Witfontein Nature Reserve, likely George’s Peak, will be visible north from the city of George.

metas.title: Low Quality Shitcam
metas.description: All the coverage was taken with a low quality camera that’s commonly referred to as “Shitcam”. The car will often be completely blurred, with a very large blur covering the back and a somewhat smaller blur covering the front.
metas.note: The coverage is a newer variant of shitcam, where the image is dimmer and hazier than the original shitcam primarily found in India and Nigeria.

metas.title: Portuguese Language
metas.description: Portuguese is the main language used on São Tomé and Príncipe.

metas.title: Portuguese Infrastructure (Ladder Poles)
metas.description: On top of the language, the Portuguese influence can also be seen in infrastructure, such as ladder poles and pedestrian signs with the same design as in Portugal.

metas.title: Tropical Rainforest (Bananas)
metas.description: São Tomé and Príncipe are tropical islands, which are almost completely covered in rainforests. Banana plants are especially common throughout the islands.

metas.title: Slanted Antenna
metas.description: In many locations, you will notice a slanted antenna protruding from the side of the car.

metas.title: Blue Pole Paint (CST)
metas.description: Some wooden poles are painted blue on the bottom. You can also read the letters CST on them.

metas.title: Yellow Taxis/Minibuses
metas.description: Taxis and minibuses are painted in a bright yellow colour.

metas.title: Principe Dim Shitcam
metas.description: This desaturated and even dimmer variant of shitcam is most common on Príncipe.

metas.title: Principe Car (Blue Roof/Silver Rails)
metas.description: The car used on Príncipe can be recognised by the blue roof and silver roof rails.
metas.note: Remember that it can sometimes be blurred out.

metas.title: Sao Tome Car (Black Roof Rails)
metas.description: The car used on São Tomé is black with black roof rails. In most locations, it is blurred out.

metas.title: Southern Oil Palms
metas.description: You can find oil palm plantations in southern São Tomé.

metas.title: Trinidade Red/White Poles
metas.description: The town of Trinidade has poles with red and white pole paint.

metas.title: Coverage Map (Gombe/Kilimanjaro)
metas.description:
Tanzania has extremely limited coverage:

Several Generation 3 trekkers in Gombe National Park. There is also one small indoor tripod in this park.

A couple of tripods on Mount Kilimanjaro.

Some spill coverage, made with a regular Google car, on the border with Kenya.

This guide only discusses the trekkers and tripods. For the spills, see our spillover guide.

It should be noted that none of the trekkers and tripods are pinpointable, or even on a road, and therefore they typically do not appear in serious competitive maps. This guide describes them primarily for the sake of completeness. The spills however do appear in maps from time to time.

Due to the sparse nature of the coverage, that is also entirely not on any streets, it is not useful to learn any territory identification metas. Instead, it is better to just memorise what the trekkers and tripods look like.

metas.title: Kilimanjaro Tripods (Ethereal)
metas.description:
On Mount Kilimanjaro, there are a couple of tripods.

This is a type of coverage made with a regular camera mounted on a tripod. As a result, this coverage has a distinct ethereal look, compared to normal street view: objects in the image will usually have motion blur, and slightly saturated colours.
metas.note: Tripods can also be found in several other countries.

metas.title: Kilimanjaro Landscape (High Altitude)
metas.description: The Mount Kilimanjaro tripods show a high altitude landscape, with dark grey rock and in some places eternal snow in the distance. In some panos, you will see mountaineers and tents.

metas.title: Gombe Trekker (Jungle/Lowland)
metas.description:
A walking trekker goes through a large part of Gombe National Park. The landscape varies somewhat from place to place.

In the lowland parts, you will see dense jungle and usually very little sunlight, leading to dark coverage. Sometimes, you can see chimpanzees.

metas.title: Gombe Trekker (Savannah Trees)
metas.description: Higher up on the hills, the forest becomes more open and you will see savannah-like trees around you.

metas.title: Gombe Trekker (Hill Tops)
metas.description: On top of the hills, the trees make way for a bare grassland landscape. Here, you have breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape and Lake Tanganyika.

metas.title: Lake Tanganyika Boat Trekker
metas.description:
There is a boat trekker in Lake Tanganyika, that hugs the coast very closely, next to Gombe National Park. The coast is always to your east. You will see hills that are mostly covered in tropical forest, with some bare and grassy hilltops.

You can see the boat through the blur: it is painted olive green and white, and has some people in it. The boat and people are always pixelated due to the blur.
metas.note: Do not confuse this boat trekker with the boats in Madagascar.

metas.title: Jane Goodall's House
metas.description: There is one more tripod in Tanzania, inside Jane Goodall’s house. It is also located in Gombe National Park, adjacent to the normal Generation 3 trekker coverage.

metas.title: Black Plates
metas.description: Tunisian licence plates are black with white text.
metas.note: Military plates feature a small Tunisian flag on the left side of the plate, which is visible on the dark green follow car.

metas.title: Follow Cars
metas.description:
One of the best ways to recognize Tunisia is that, in most coverage, the Google car is escorted by a follow car.

There are several different follow cars and these are four of the most commonly found ones.
metas.note: Follow cars can be in front of the street view car, or very far behind. Make sure to pan and zoom if you do not find them immediately.

metas.title: Black Google Car
metas.description: The Google car in Tunisia is black with a medium-length, thin antenna.
metas.note: The colour of the car is not always perceptible. Make sure to look around for other more helpful clues.

metas.title: Climate
metas.description: Tunisia has Mediterranean, dry and semidesert climates.
metas.note: In the second step, you will find more about region specific climate and landscape.

metas.title: Olive Plantations
metas.description: These olive tree plantations can often be found along roads. They consist of nicely arranged rows of olive trees on an often raked, weedless soil.

metas.title: Road Lines
metas.description: Tunisia usually has white road lines. Outer road lines can be dashed or solid.
metas.note: A few roads in Sfax have yellow middle lines.

metas.title: Bilingual Signs
metas.description: In Tunisia, both French and Arabic are common. The Arabic script can be identified by its lines and dots. You can often see bilingual signs.
metas.note: The UAE and (more rarely) Jordan use English and Arabic.

metas.title: Direction Signs
metas.description: Most direction signs have a white background with towns listed in Arabic and Latin script. The font of the Latin script is usually quite distinctive.
metas.note: Many direction signs include the capital Tunis, but this does not necessarily mean you are anywhere near that city.

metas.title: Blue Doors
metas.description: Doors, windows, gates and other architectural elements are sometimes painted with this specific traditional shade of blue.
metas.note: This shade of blue can be found all over the country, but is especially common on the island of Djerba, where buildings tend to be older and more traditional.

metas.title: Striped Curbs
metas.description: Red and white striped curbs are common in Tunisia.
metas.note: Similar curbs are also common in Israel and Palestine. Make sure to look for additional information!

metas.title: Km Markers
metas.description: These white concrete markers with a rounded red or yellow top can be found throughout Tunisia. The top can be red, yellow, or green.
metas.note: They are very useful for pinpointing your exact location. On either side, they show the distance in kilometres to the nearest town. The side facing the road shows the road number.

metas.title: Stop Sign
metas.description: Tunisia has a fairly unique stop sign with Arabic and Latin script.
metas.note: Similar stop signs can be found in Jordan and the UAE. However, Israel and Palestine use a different unique stop sign with a hand instead of text.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Coverage is mostly limited to the east coast, between Bizerte in the north and Medinine in the south. Most coverage is in bigger towns and on main roads. The biggest towns and the island of Djerba have quite extensive side road coverage.

metas.title: North Toyota Follow Car
metas.description: This light green Toyota follow car can be found everywhere in the northernmost part of Tunisia. You will never see it south of Hammamet.

metas.title: South Mazda Follow Car
metas.description: The dark green Mazda is the most common follow car in Tunisia. This becomes apparent if you look at the coverage map, it can be found all the way from Hammamet to Djerba. Aside from the darker colour, it can also be recognized by its military licence plate with a red strip on the left.

metas.title: Tunis Follow Cars
metas.description: Tunis, the capital of Tunisia, has a lot of different follow cars. Most of them can be found all over the city. The light green Toyota can also be spotted here.

metas.title: Kairouan Mitsubishi
metas.description: The city of Kairouan in central-northern Tunisia has this unique follow car, a white Mitsubishi with white mirrors. The dark green follow car can also sometimes be spotted following the Mitsubishi.
metas.note: Some white follow cars in Tunisia can look similar to the Kairouan car. However, none of them are Mitsubishis.

metas.title: Djerba No Follow Car
metas.description:
The island of Djerba is the only region of Tunisia where you are usually not accompanied by a follow car. Most coverage completely lacks one.

While it is rare, this white Mercedes and the dark green follow car can be present.

metas.title: North Tunis Hilly
metas.description: The area north of Tunis has a Mediterranean climate with hilly terrain. The region is very agricultural and at the time the coverage was captured, almost all fields laid fallow.

metas.title: Tunis-Hammamet Hilly
metas.description: The area between Tunis and Hammamet looks similar to the area north of Tunis, but the hills tend to be higher and more vegetated.

metas.title: Central Flat Arid
metas.description: The large middle region between Hammamet and Gabes is very flat, and more arid. Olive tree plantations are common and the more south you go, the drier the landscape becomes.

metas.title: South Desert
metas.description: South of Gabes is where the landscape changes into something more akin to a desert. A lot more rubbish and small white rocks can be found along the roads. Olive tree plantations are still somewhat common. A mountain range far in the distance is often visible to the southwest.

metas.title: Djerba Vibe
metas.description: The island of Djerba can sometimes have a distinct vibe. There tend to be a lot of palm trees. Whitewashed, traditional buildings with blue doors and windows are common.
metas.note: Not all locations on the island will have this distinct vibe. A lack of a follow car is another good way to confirm that you are on Djerba.

metas.title: Bizerte Lake
metas.description: Bizerte Lake is instantly recognizable due to its teal coloured waters. There are slight hills to its south, with the rest of the area around the lake being flat. The city of Bizerte is located on the northeast side of the lake.

metas.title: Gabes Palms
metas.description: If you see a large amount of palm trees in a single place, you are probably in Gabes.
metas.note: While Djerba also has many palm trees, the towns and surrounding area tend to look more rural.

metas.title: Medinine Sandy Hills
metas.description: On the P1 road northwest of Medinine, you can occasionally find sandy hills that look like this. These hills are quite unique, as most coverage in southern Tunisia is in very flat areas.

metas.title: Sousse Offroad
metas.description: An offroad from road P12 southwest of Sousse can be recognised by the dark pavement surrounded by bright sandy soil combined with the east-west road angle. The eastern part of the road is fairly vegetated, with large numbers of prickly pears, while the western part of the road is very arid with little to no vegetation.

metas.title: Djerba Causeway
metas.description: You can easily recognise the Djerba-Zarzis causeway thanks to the water on both sides and the pipeline that is always present to your west.

metas.title: Trekkers
metas.description: Trekkers can be found all over the country, even in places far away from the area with car coverage. Coverage includes archaeological sites, forts, mosques, and a Star Wars set, among other things.

metas.title: Limited Coverage Map
metas.description:
Uganda has very limited coverage, with most of the coverage in the capital city of Kampala and the nearby city of Entebbe. The rest of the coverage is located in the various national parks that will be covered below.

Note: Because the coverage in Uganda is limited, this guide is structured differently than most of the other country guides, with two separate sections for Kampala and the National Parks. These sections also include most of the tips needed to identify the country.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Driving Side
metas.description: Uganda drives on the left hand side of the road.
metas.note: African countries are split between right and left hand drive. For a full overview of countries and their driving side, see here.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Uganda uses white front plates with yellow rear plates. These plates can be long or tall.

metas.title: Kampala Car
metas.description: In all coverage in Kampala, a unique Google car is visible. This car is white with square side mirrors and a boxy look.
metas.note: This Google car is only found in Uganda and is unique to the city of Kampala and its outskirts.

metas.title: Kampala Vibe
metas.description: Kampala is a fairly busy-looking city, with many signs, narrow unpaved roads and typically fairly small, one-storey houses. Like many African countries, houses will often be surrounded by tall walls, commonly with barbed wire on top.

metas.title: Kampala Red Soil
metas.description: Like most of the national park coverage, Kampalan soil is typically very red. Even paved roads normally have a noticeable red, purple or pink tinge.

metas.title: Kampala Hills
metas.description: Kampala is a very hilly city, and as such it is rare to get a round without elevation or noticeable hills.

metas.title: Taxi Buses
metas.description: Throughout Kampala, you will often see these taxi buses, with a blue blocky pattern on the sides. These are a good clue for the city if you are not able to see the Google car.

metas.title: City Centre Curbs
metas.description: In the city centre of Kampala, you will see paved roads with black-and-white curbs. In contrast to the rest of the city, the city centre looks richer and very built-up, with lots of multi-storey buildings.

metas.title: Entebbe Vibe
metas.description: The city of Entebbe, southwest of Kampala, can often be recognized by feeling slightly emptier than most of the capital, with more greenery and somewhat fancier houses. The area also has significantly more street signs than the rest of the capital.

metas.title: National Park Car
metas.description: Most coverage in the Ugandan national parks was taken with this Street View car, which is similar to the one seen in Kampala, but with a black bar along the front of the car. The visibility of the car varies greatly, and it is somewhat common for it to not be visible at all.

metas.title: Kidepo Savannah
metas.description: The National Park is located in the northeastern parts of the country and mostly consists of a large savannah with mountains being visible in most directions. The most recognizable mountain range can be seen to the east and is visible in most of the coverage.

metas.title: Kidepo South Forest
metas.description: The southern half of the north road in Kidepo is somewhat forested, and as such it may occasionally be hard to see the various mountains.

metas.title: Kidepo North Mountains
metas.description: The northern half of the north road in Kidepo is located in a savannah and can be easily recognised by the wide mountain to the north.

metas.title: Murchison Landscape
metas.description: The National Park is located by the northern end of Lake Albert and can commonly be recognized by the low dirt barriers along the side of the roads. A savannah can be seen in the western part, while the eastern parts contain many small trees and bushes. Apart from a fairly low and wide mountain range far away to the west, there are no mountains in the vicinity.

metas.title: Murchison Palms
metas.description: Seeing these palms in Uganda means you are extremely likely to be in the northern parts of Murchison Falls.

metas.title: Kibale Wide Road
metas.description: The National Park has three types of coverage, the first of which is a very wide dirt road going through a dense, tropical forest. It is by far the widest dirt road in the country outside of Kampala with Street View coverage.

metas.title: Kibale Small Road
metas.description: The second type of coverage in Kibale is on a small forest road, which is still large enough to be covered using a car. The forest appears to be quite dense, however it is typically not very dark. The area is mostly flat.

metas.title: Kibale Forest Paths
metas.description: The final type of coverage is a number of tiny forest paths. The coverage is somewhat dark, with the sun shining through every so often.

metas.title: Lake Mburo Dry Grass
metas.description: The park is located west of lake Victoria and has by far the driest coverage in the country. The grass is almost always completely dried out, which is normally enough to recognise it. Bushes and trees along the road also typically look very dry. The area is quite hilly, but not mountainous.

metas.title: Semuliki Forest
metas.description: The coverage in the national park consists of two small forest paths running parallel to each other. The forest appears very humid, and on much of the coverage, drops of water can be seen on the camera lens.

metas.title: Mt Elgon Forest
metas.description: The national park is located near the Kenyan border and has two stretches of paths covered, the first of which is in a forest with a fairly steep slope heading upwards to the east. The dirt typically has a very dark red colour.

metas.title: Mt Elgon Open Hilly
metas.description: The eastern stretch of path covered is easily recognized by its small palm-like trees on an open hilly field and a man following the photographer, who is dressed in green and holding a rifle.

metas.title: QE Brown Dirt
metas.description: Queen Elizabeth National Park, north of Lake Edward, is one of the only places in Uganda where you will commonly see dirt which is not red. Instead, the dirt will typically be either brown or greyish.

metas.title: QE Cacti
metas.description: On top of the brown dirt, the national park also contains large cacti with many branches going almost straight upwards, resembling the shape of trees.

metas.title: QE Craters
metas.description: On the northern coverage, it is common to see large, water-filled craters. Similar craters cannot be found elsewhere in the country.

metas.title: QE Paved Road
metas.description:
The only paved road with coverage outside Kampala can be found here. The pavement almost entirely lacks the red tinge which is typical for most roads in the country. The road has white, solid outer lines and a yellow middle line.

A power line runs parallel to the road, to your east. To your north, you will be able to see hills.

metas.title: Katwe Village
metas.description: Katwe village is the only significant settlement outside of Kampala with Street View coverage.
metas.note: Much smaller villages, safari lodges and single houses with coverage can be found elsewhere.

metas.title: Snow and Ice
metas.description: Most of Antarctica is covered in snow and ice.

metas.title: Dark Soil
metas.description: The soil will always be dark.

metas.title: Penguins
metas.description: Penguins can be found on parts of the coverage.
metas.note: This is mostly useful to exclude coverage in the Arctics.

metas.title: Half Moon Island
metas.description: Half Moon Island was covered by a tripod. It can also be recognized by the numerous other people in red jackets.

metas.title: Deception Island Bay
metas.description: The Deception Island Bay can be recognized by the blue and white ship in the bay, and the abandoned equipment on the beach.

metas.title: Deception Island Trekker
metas.description: The trekker can be seen walking in a line on Deception Island.

metas.title: Deception Island Beach
metas.description: A beach with black sand and many penguins can be seen on Deception Island.

metas.title: Cuverville Island
metas.description: Cuverville Island can be recognised by the overcast weather combined with the coastline to the northwest. You’ll also see a decent number of penguins, particularly toward the east.

metas.title: Danco Island
metas.description: Danco Island can be recognised by the beautiful sunset coverage over a snowy fjord.

metas.title: Petermann Island
metas.description: Petermann Island can be recognized by the layer of snow with patches of exposed rocks, and the overexposed camera.

metas.title: Ross Island West
metas.description: The coverage at the western tip of Ross Island can typically be recognised by the extremely dark, and mostly barren, rocky soil.

metas.title: Ross Island Cabin
metas.description: A tripod featuring the exterior and interior of a small wooden cabin with a grey metal roof can be found south of the eastern tip of Ross Island.

metas.title: McMurdo Station
metas.description: McMurdo Station is the largest research station on Antarctica, and can be recognized by the dark brown soil, many buildings, American infrastructure and sunset coverage.
metas.note: A lot of the coverage around McMurdo Station has the sun setting in the south, which shouldn’t lead you to guess in the northern hemisphere.

metas.title: McMurdo Interiors
metas.description: You can also find tripod coverage inside several buildings at McMurdo Station.

metas.title: McMurdo Hut
metas.description: On the eastern side of McMurdo Station you can find a small wooden cabin, having a tripod going inside.

metas.title: McMurdo Ice Trekker
metas.description: Southeast of McMurdo station, the trekker can be seen walking on a layer of ice around various machinery.

metas.title: Mainland Valleys
metas.description: The trekker can be seen walking through a fantastical landscape consisting of many desolate valleys on mainland Antarctica, west of Ross Island.

metas.title: South of McMurdo
metas.description: A vast, snowy landscape with spread out hills can be seen south of McMurdo station.

metas.title: South Pole
metas.description:
The tripod at the south pole can be recognized by numerous countries’ flags around the tripod, and a sign with ‘Geographic South Pole’ written on it.

This location is often on community-made world maps for a better scoring range.

metas.title: South Pole Observatory
metas.description: The South Pole Observatory has tripod coverage going around and inside of it.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands are a British Overseas Territory east of the Falkland Islands. As such, for country streaks purposes, they are counted as the UK.

Coverage is very limited: there are only a couple of Generation 3 trekkers:

One trekker in the abandoned town of Grytviken

Three trekkers in the isolated fjords of the rest of the island.

Due to the sparse nature of the coverage, that is also entirely not on any streets, it is not useful to learn any territory identification metas. Instead, it is better to just memorise what the trekkers look like.

metas.title: Grytviken Machinery
metas.description:
Abandoned, rusted machinery can be seen in Grytviken.

Grytviken is the only pinpointable trekker in South Georgia. Therefore, this trekker appears in pinpointable maps like A Community World.

metas.title: Grytviken Church
metas.description: A church and another building made of white painted wood can also be seen in Grytviken.

metas.title: West Side Valley
metas.description: This wide open valley with lightly snow capped mountains can be seen on the west side of South Georgia Island.

metas.title: Prion Island
metas.description: Prion Island can be recognized by the wooden walkway, lush green plants and numerous seals which inhabit the island.

metas.title: Hercules Bay Boat
metas.description: This boat trekker in Hercules Bay can be recognized by a man in a red jacket and the MS National Geographic Explorer in the background.

metas.title: License Plates (White/Black/Turquoise)
metas.description: Bangladeshi licence plates are either white, black or turquoise.
metas.note: The turquoise plate can only be found in Bangladesh.

metas.title: Bengali Script (Horizontal Line/Triangles)
metas.description: The Bengali script features a continuous horizontal line at the top of each word. It has a similar look to Devanagari (Hindi), however it can usually be recognised by the many letters featuring triangular shapes.
metas.note: Bengali is an official language in Bangladesh and parts of eastern India.

metas.title: Gen 3 Cars (Red Mirror/Classic/Striped)
metas.description: In Generation 3 coverage, these three cars can be seen in Bangladesh: the red mirror with bars, classic white and striped white car.
metas.note: The classic white car is the only car that is not unique to Bangladesh. Make sure to not mix up the striped white with the Cambodian car, since they look similar.

metas.title: Gen 4 Cars (Black/White)
metas.description: In Generation 4 coverage, two Street View cars can be seen in Bangladesh: a black car and a white car.

metas.title: Shitcam (Black/White Car)
metas.description: Bangladesh, as well as a variety of other countries, has received some poor quality coverage, also known as “Shitcam”. The Shitcam car colours are black and white.
metas.note: Sometimes the car colour can be fully obstructed by a big circular blur.

metas.title: Rickshaws (Green Auto)
metas.description: Rickshaws are frequently found all around Bangladesh, especially the green auto rickshaws.
metas.note: They are found in other Asian countries as well.

metas.title: Signposts (Black & White Stripes)
metas.description: Signposts in Bangladesh often have black-and-white stripes.
metas.note: Within Asia, these posts are also found in Sri Lanka, Bhutan, India and Malaysia. Make sure to check other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Water Bodies and Fields
metas.description: Bodies of water and agricultural fields can be often seen beside the streets of Bangladesh.

metas.title: Tree Paint (White Bottoms)
metas.description: Streets in Bangladesh are often lined by trees, which sometimes have white paint on the bottom of their trunks.

metas.title: Concrete Bollards (Red & White)
metas.description: Bangladesh uses red-and-white concrete bollards throughout the whole country.
metas.note: They can also be found in a square form instead of a circular form.

metas.title: Tin Roofs
metas.description: Tin roofs are commonly found in Bangladesh.
metas.note: Due to the humid climate, many countries in South and Southeast Asia use tin roofs.

metas.title: Gen 4 Smoky Quality
metas.description: The Generation 4 coverage in Bangladesh will often have a smoky feel to it.

metas.title: Western Roofs (Hip/Sheet Metal)
metas.description:
Bangladesh has several distinct roof styles that create an east/west divide in the country.

The west, particularly the divisions of Rajshahi, Khulna and Dhaka, is dominated by hip roofs made of sheet metal. The states of Rangpur and Chittagong tend to have mixed roofs.

metas.title: Eastern Roofs (Triangular Window)
metas.description: In the east, you will commonly see sheet metal roofs with a triangular "window" just below the ridge of the roof. The state of Sylhet will exclusively have this style, which can also be seen in Chittagong, Mymensingh, eastern Rangpur and northern Dhaka.

metas.title: Tiled Roofs (Khulna/Indian Border)
metas.description: Tiled roofs are uncommon in Bangladesh, but the ones you do see are of West Bengal origin, and are thus only found on the Indian border in the state of Khulna.

metas.title: Rice: Early Growth (Short Green)
metas.description:
Rice is the main agricultural crop in Bangladesh and is planted twice a year. The different rice seasons can be told apart by the height and colour of the rice and are very useful for regionguessing.

Short green rice that is barely sticking out of the water is known as early growth rice. Early growth rice can be seen in the states of Khulna, Mymensingh and south of Padma River in Dhaka.
metas.note: Beware that this, and the following tips, are only accurate in Generation 4 coverage.

metas.title: Rice: Mid Growth (Green)
metas.description: Slightly taller rice, in the middle of growing, which still remains green, can be seen in the states of Rangpur, Barishal and Chittagong.

metas.title: Rice: Fully Grown (Yellow/Tall)
metas.description: Fully-grown rice is characterised by being noticeably taller, as well as having a yellow or orange colour and fluffier tips - the fluffiness signifies that the rice is ripe. Fully-grown rice is mostly seen in the state of Rajshahi, but it is also present in Rangpur and Chittagong.

metas.title: Rice: Harvested (Beige/Cut)
metas.description: Harvested rice can be identified by its beige or brown colour and shorter, cut down appearance. It can be seen alongside fully-grown, unharvested rice as well as freshly planted early growth rice in adjacent fields. This is most commonly seen in the states of Sylhet and southern Khulna.

metas.title: Rice: Off-Season (Barren Fields)
metas.description: Rice fields require some rest time, so it's natural to come across some off-season barren, empty fields without rice altogether. Off-season fields are mostly seen in the state of Dhaka, north of Padma River.

metas.title: Vast Empty Rice Fields
metas.description: Vast rice fields with almost nothing else in view can be seen in the border area between the states of Dhaka, Mymensingh and Sylhet.

metas.title: Chittagong Hills
metas.description: While most of Bangladesh is almost completely flat, in the eastern parts of Chittagong you may find fairly tall, forested and uncultivated hills.

metas.title: Sylhet Ridge (Indian Border)
metas.description: A sizable east-west ridge can be seen on the Indian border from the northern parts of Sylhet and eastern Mymensingh. It is often obscured or diminished by heavy haze.

metas.title: Corn Fields (West)
metas.description:
Corn tends to be planted in the west of Bangladesh - large and medium-sized fields can be found in Rajshahi, Rangpur, western Mymensingh and northern Khulna.

Smaller patches of corn can be found in the south of Barishal, usually adjacent to other crops.

metas.title: Jute (Rangpur)
metas.description: Jute is a tall-growing green crop which gets dried and used in the making of rugs, bags and other goods. Because of when the coverage was taken, jute can almost exclusively be found on Street View in Rangpur. In its dried state it can be found hanging off fences and drying on the roads anywhere in the country.

metas.title: Canola (Yellow Flowers)
metas.description: Canola is a low-growing crop with yellow flowers that is used to make cooking oil. It is usually planted during the off-season for rice, making it extremely common north of Padma river in the state of Dhaka.

metas.title: Tea Plantations (Sylhet)
metas.description: Tea production in Bangladesh is concentrated in the highlands of southern Sylhet and, rarely, Chittagong.

metas.title: Fruit Orchards (Rajshahi/Rangpur)
metas.description: Standalone fruit trees in Bangladesh are most commonly seen in the states of Rajshahi and Rangpur. Fruit orchards with systematically planted trees, however, are concentrated near the Indian border in both states.

metas.title: Sunflower Fields (Barishal)
metas.description: Sunflower fields are found in the south of Barishal state.

metas.title: Watermelon Fields (Barishal)
metas.description: Fields of watermelons can also be found in the south of Barishal.

metas.title: Eucalyptus Trees (North)
metas.description: Eucalyptus trees are tall trees with lush crowns and ivory-coloured trunks. In Bangladesh they are more common in the north, with Rangpur, Rajshahi and Mymensingh being the most likely states.

metas.title: Blossoming Trees (Spring Coverage)
metas.description: Blossoming trees are tied to coverage and seasonal metas in Bangladesh, and are only found in the states where coverage was taken during spring time - Khulna, Mymensingh and southern Dhaka.
metas.note: Beware that this is only accurate in Generation 4 coverage.

metas.title: Beach Sheoaks (Coastal)
metas.description: Beach Sheoaks (Casuarina equisetifolia) are thin evergreen trees with thin, long, drooping branchlets. Like the name suggests, they are mostly observed in coastal regions - along the coast of the Teknaf Peninsula and around Noakhali city in Chittagong.

metas.title: Copyright 2022 (Mymensingh/Dhaka)
metas.description: For legal reasons, Google has added small labels noting their copyright on all Street View coverage. These labels contain a year, typically the year when the coverage was released, which can be used to regionguess Bangladesh. Generation 4 coverage with 2022 written on the copyright labels can be found in Mymensingh, Dhaka and less commonly Chittagong.
metas.note: Beware that the copyright labels will rarely get updated to a later year, without any other changes to the coverage.

metas.title: Copyright 2023 (North/South/Sylhet)
metas.description: Similarly, Generation 4 coverage with 2023 written on the copyright labels can be found in Rangpur, Rajshahi, Khulna, Barishal, Sylhet and less commonly Chittagong.
metas.note: 2024 and 2025 now make up around half of all copyright dates. These can be found all over the country.

metas.title: Shitcam Map (Dhaka)
metas.description: Shitcam coverage is only found in and around Dhaka.

metas.title: White Car Gen 3 Map
metas.description: Generation 3 coverage with the white Street View car can be found in Dhaka, Chattogram as well as on the highway connecting them.

metas.title: Striped Car Gen 3 Map
metas.description: Generation 3 coverage with the striped Street View car can be found mostly on yellow roads west of Dhaka.

metas.title: Sylhet Guard with Hayfork
metas.description: In the city of Sylhet there will often be a guard at the side of the car visible, usually holding a hayfork. Note that this only applies to Generation 3 coverage.

metas.title: Barishal Guard
metas.description: In the city of Barishal there can also be a guard at the side of the car visible, not to be confused with the Sylhet guard.
metas.note: The same man can rarely be found elsewhere on trekker coverage.

metas.title: Khulna Black Cover Trekker
metas.description: This interesting trekker with a black cover can be found in the city of Khulna.

metas.title: Nijhum Dwip Red Mirror Trekker
metas.description: The trekker with red colour in the mirrors is unique to the island of Nijhum Dwip.

metas.title: Hatiya Island Scooter
metas.description: A scooter trekker, where mostly the left mirror and some hair is visible, can be found on Hatiya Island.

metas.title: Saint Martin's Island Guard Trekker
metas.description: A trekker escorted by a security guard is found on Saint Martin's Island.

metas.title: Red License Plates
metas.description: Licence plates in Bhutan are almost always red and can easily be seen on vehicles.
metas.note: Within Asia, Bhutan is the only country that uses full red licence plates.

metas.title: Grey Google Car (No Antenna)
metas.description: Coverage in Bhutan was taken by a grey Google car without an antenna.
metas.note: Bhutan is the only left hand driving country which has a grey Google car. Make sure to not mix it up with a white Google car, since they can look similar.

metas.title: Stone Block Barriers
metas.description:
Bhutan commonly uses these stone blocks as safety barriers on winding rural roads. These blocks are very common and often one of the best ways to recognize rural Bhutan rounds.

Guardrails, on the other hand, are rare.

metas.title: Traditional Architecture (Tin Roofs/Wood)
metas.description: The traditional Bhutanese architecture is very distinct. Most of the houses have tin roofs and wooden painted frames, which give them a unique look.

metas.title: Dzongkha Script
metas.description: Dzongkha is an official language in Bhutan and has unique-looking letters.
metas.note: On street view, these letters can only be found in Bhutan.

metas.title: Mountainous Landscape
metas.description: Bhutan is a mountainous country and most of the coverage is located on its main mountain roads.
metas.note: In the south are flat areas where you cannot see any mountains.

metas.title: Prayer Flags
metas.description: Prayer flags near the road are typically seen in Bhutan.

metas.title: Thin Metal Poles (Black Bottoms)
metas.description: Thin metal poles are occasionally found in Bhutan. They are often painted black at the bottom.

metas.title: Road Markers (Yellow Top/White Bottom)
metas.description: These are the Bhutanese road markers, notice the yellow top and the white bottom.
metas.note:
If you are on rural roads and would like to find out where you are, these markers are the best clue to narrow down the exact location.

On national highways, the road number is found on the top of the marker, but is not labelled on the map. However, it can still be used to identify the road using this table.

metas.title: Town Signs (Blue/Red)
metas.description: These signs are frequently found in the cities of Bhutan and are often coloured red or blue.
metas.note: As seen here, they will typically have the town name you are in written on them.

metas.title: Taxis (Yellow Roof/Plate)
metas.description: Taxis in Bhutan have yellow licence plates and yellow roofs.

metas.title: Signposts (Black & White Stripes)
metas.description: Signposts in Bhutan frequently have black-and-white stripes.
metas.note: Within Asia, these posts are also found in Sri Lanka, India, Malaysia and Bangladesh. Make sure to check other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Coverage Map (Main Roads)
metas.description: Most of the Bhutanese street view coverage was taken on the main roads and cities.

metas.title: Double White Lines
metas.description: Two solid white outside lines are only seen in western Bhutan south and close to the capital Thimphu.

metas.title: Flat Southern Landscape
metas.description: Flat landscapes like this in Bhutan can only be found in the south.
metas.note: The coverage in the south is limited to the four regions shown on the map.

metas.title: Phobjikha Valley
metas.description: The Phobjikha Valley, south of Nubding, is a wide and relatively flat agricultural valley. It is by far the largest open valley with no major river visible on Street View.

metas.title: Haa Vehicle Hook
metas.description: A hook can be seen on the back of the car in Haa District, mainly in the town of Ha.
metas.note: The hook is sometimes just barely visible due to the car blur.

metas.title: Late Sunset (Mongar/Paro)
metas.description: Late sunset coverage can be found in two places in the country; on a small rural sideroad in the east of Mongar District and in a significantly more urban area around the town of Paro in the west.

metas.title: Gelephu Airport
metas.description: Gelephu Airport is the only airport located in the flat south part of Bhutan, making it recognisable.

metas.title: Paro Airport (Dry Valley)
metas.description: The Paro International Airport is located in a dry northwest valley and is one of the two northern airports.

metas.title: Bumthang Airport (Wet Valley)
metas.description: While the Paro International Airport is located in a dry northwest valley, the Bumthang Domestic Airport is located in a wet northern valley.

metas.title: UK Overseas Territory
metas.description:
The British Indian Ocean Territory is an United Kingdom overseas territory in the Indian Ocean. As such, it is counted as the UK for country streaks purposes.

Beware that none of the coverage is considered pinpointable, and as a result you are unlikely to get it in most community-made maps. As such, this guide is mainly intended to give a general idea of what type of coverage you can find on the islands.

metas.title: Gen 3 Trekker
metas.description: Coverage was taken with a Generation 3 trekker.

metas.title: Northern Atolls Coverage
metas.description: Coverage is mostly found on small atolls in the northern half of the territory.

metas.title: Sand Beaches (Palms)
metas.description: A large portion of the coverage is taken on sand beaches. You will typically see many palm trees along the beaches.

metas.title: Coconut Palm Forests
metas.description: Coastal palm forests also comprise a significant portion of the coverage. They almost exclusively consist of coconut palms.

metas.title: Mangroves
metas.description: Mangroves can be found on several of the atolls.

metas.title: Grassy Fields
metas.description: Some of the larger islands with coverage have grassy fields surrounded by bushes and palms.

metas.title: Offshore Water Trekker
metas.description: The trekker can occasionally be found walking offshore in the water.

metas.title: Coin du Mire
metas.description: Coin du Mire is a small island with a dark rocky shore and a grassy field with no bushes or palm trees.

metas.title: Nelsons Island Shipwreck
metas.description: A white medium-sized shipwreck can be found on the beach at the eastern tip of Nelsons Island.

metas.title: License Plates (White/Blue Text)
metas.description:
Licence plates are white with blue letters. The blue sheen of the letters can be hard to see through the blur, and the plates might appear as plain white.

Plates on government vehicles are green.

metas.title: Gen 3 Cars (Stubby Antenna/Striped)
metas.description:
On the Generation 3 coverage you can find two different Google cars:

A car with a short, stubby antenna. The antenna has three ridges. It can sometimes be hard to tell if the antenna has ridges.

A white car with stripes and no antenna. There is a white stripe on the left, and a yellow stripe on the right. The stripes are sometimes poorly visible.

The car is not always as visible as shown in the example images.
metas.note:
This specific striped white car is unique to Cambodia. Make sure not to mix it up with the Bangladeshi striped car, which looks slightly different.

The Latin American countries of Mexico, Colombia, Ecuador and Brazil also have cars with similar short antennas. However, these have a diagonally coiled ridge, instead of Cambodia’s three ridges.

metas.title: Driving Side (Right)
metas.description: Cambodia drives on the right.
metas.note: Thailand drives on the left, while Laos also drives on the right.

metas.title: Khmer Script
metas.description:
Khmer is the official language of Cambodia. It has its own unique script, which is very distinct and recognizable. In most fonts, letters have an intricate, curvy look.

Khmer can look fairly different depending on the font used. A compilation of what this script looks like in street view can be found here.
metas.note: The Thai and Lao scripts look similar, but the letters tend to have a less intricate look. However, some simplified Khmer fonts can look a bit like Thai and Lao.

metas.title: Poles (Ladder/Round with Holes)
metas.description:
Two types of poles are common:

Concrete ladder poles (so named because the indents and ridges resemble a ladder).

Round concrete poles with small holes.

Rarely, you might see simple wooden poles.
metas.note:
The same type of round concrete pole is also common in Vietnam.

You can easily distinguish between Thailand and Cambodia based on the poles. Thailand uses square concrete poles with rows of small pinholes on the sides. Such poles are very uncommon in Cambodia (but not completely absent).

metas.title: Bollards (Red & White/Stone)
metas.description:
Cambodia has a variety of different bollards. The most common ones are:

A stone bollard with red-and-white stripes.

A stone bollard with a red top and a white base, usually with a reflector in the red part.

Some bollards are unique to a road or region. More details can be found in the region-guessing section.

metas.title: Road Markers (White/Red Top)
metas.description: Cambodian road markers are made of stone, with a white-coloured base and a rounded red top. You will find the road number on the narrow side and a town name with a distance on the main side.

metas.title: Chevrons (Black/Yellow Arrows)
metas.description:
Chevrons in Cambodia are black with yellow arrows.

Chevrons are somewhat rare. On many occasions, Cambodia prefers to use bollards instead of chevrons to mark curves in the road.
metas.note: Chevrons in all other Southeast Asian countries have the reverse colour scheme: yellow with black arrows.

metas.title: Road Lines (Yellow Middle/White Outer)
metas.description: Roads have dashed or solid yellow middle road lines. Outer road lines are somewhat rare, but when present, they are solid white.
metas.note: Thailand uses similar road lines.

metas.title: Unpaved Roads
metas.description: Many roads are unpaved. Usually, only main roads and roads in and near urban areas are paved.

metas.title: Stilt Houses
metas.description: Wooden houses on stilts are common. Walls are often made of vertical planks. Many homes have double or triple roofs.

metas.title: House Colors (Red/Blue/Orange)
metas.description:
In addition, traditional Cambodian wooden stilt houses tend to have very recognizable colour schemes.

Walls are commonly painted dark red-brown, light blue or an ochre orange.

Doors, windows and other architectural details are often painted bright blue.
metas.note: More modern houses tend to have a wider variety of colour schemes.

metas.title: Roofs (Tiled/Metal)
metas.description:
Many traditional homes have tiled orange or red roofs, sometimes with ornaments on the ridges and corners. Corrugated and plain metal roofs are also common.

On other, more modern buildings, you can see a wider variety of roof colours and materials.

metas.title: Buddhist Temples
metas.description: The majority of Cambodians are Buddhist. Temples are common throughout the country. Temple architecture is highly decorative, with ornamented roofs. You might also see Buddhist flags.
metas.note: Thailand and Laos are also majority Buddhist. Temples in these countries can look similar.

metas.title: Beer Ads
metas.description: You will see a lot of advertisements for the beer brands Angkor, Anchor, and the very creatively named Cambodia Beer.

metas.title: CPP Party Signs
metas.description:
Throughout the country, you can find distinct blue signs from the Cambodian People’s Party (CPP).

These signs occasionally feature the likenesses of major party politicians: usually three men side by side.

metas.title: Shitcam (Ari)
metas.description: Google used a weird, low-quality camera in Cambodia. This camera is known as the official Ari (or “Shitcam”). It has a wide circular car blur and often somewhat brownish colours. A good map will not usually include this coverage, but it is good to be aware of its existence, in order to not be caught off-guard by it.
metas.note: Within Asia, India, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka also have shitcam coverage.

metas.title: Coverage Map (Cities)
metas.description:
Street view coverage is somewhat limited. Most of the coverage is located around the cities of Phnom Penh, Siem Reap and Battambang.

You can click on the image to enlarge it. You can also view the official street view coverage in more detail on this site.

metas.title: Shitcam Map (Southwest)
metas.description: Shitcam in Cambodia is only found in the southwestern half.

metas.title: Central Plain
metas.description: The low-lying central plain is home to most agricultural land. The landscape is flat, cultivated, and dotted with villages and farms.

metas.title: Northeast Landscape
metas.description: Conversely, the northeast is much more uncultivated: there is less agriculture and more natural vegetation. Some areas are slightly hilly.

metas.title: Southwest Landscape (Hills)
metas.description: The southwest is the area with the most elevation in Cambodia. This region is characterized by hills and low mountains. Some inland roads feature dense forest cover, but the coastal areas in particular are fairly densely populated.

metas.title: White Sandy Soil (Southeast)
metas.description: Sandy, white soil is very common in the region southeast of Phnom Penh, as well as around the city itself. The colour can range from bright white to slightly beige.
metas.note: You may find sandy, white soil in other parts of the country, however it is by far the most common in this area. Conversely, some roads in this region can have darker soil than expected.

metas.title: Thai Border Mountains
metas.description:
Near the northern border with Thailand, you can often see a mountainous ridgeline to your north. The soil in this region tends to be red, ranging from a slight reddish tinge to deep dark red.

The ridgeline closely corresponds with the border with Thailand. The drop-off to the Cambodian lowland to its south is abrupt. This means that the roads you are on are themselves located in a very flat landscape (see inset map).

metas.title: Rubber Plantations
metas.description:
Rubber tree plantations are found in three places:

In a narrow belt northeast of Phnom Penh, mostly centred around the southern sections of Roads 7 and 71

Around the town of Ban Lung in the far northeast, as well as east of it on and near Road 78.

Around the town of Pech Sreada. This area has a distinct look. See the tip in the spotlight section.

Rubber trees can be recognized by their thin trunks and dark green crowns. The trees are neatly arranged in rows. They often have small taps near the bottom of the trunk.
metas.note: Rubber trees are common in Thailand. Only use this clue to region-guess if you are certain that you are in Cambodia, and not to identify the country.

metas.title: Thai-Style Bollards (Road 48)
metas.description: Black-and-white bollards in Cambodia are only found on Road 48, between Tatai and the intersection with Road 4.
metas.note: Make sure to check other clues before guessing, because this style of bollard is commonly found in Thailand.

metas.title: Kiri Sakor Construction
metas.description: The road between Road 48 and Kiri Sakor is under construction and only has one paved road side. The unpaved side has red soil.

metas.title: Southwest Jungle Roads
metas.description: Several unpaved jungle offroads in the southwest of the country, northeast of Road 48, have a distinct look: red soil, dense jungle, and generally hilly terrain.
metas.note: Some rural jungle roads in the east of the country can look similar. Here, however, the soil tends to be more brownish or orange rather than red.

metas.title: Phnum Samkos Area
metas.description: The coverage close to Phnum Samkos has a distinct look: overcast weather, and large, prominent mountains that are visible in the distance. The roads are unpaved and consist of brown soil. Wild, very green vegetation can be seen all around you.

metas.title: Triangular Red Stripe Bollards
metas.description:
Unique triangular bollards with red stripes can be found in three places in Cambodia, all located in the same area in the southwest:

On Road 4 between Angk Snuol and Preah Sihanouk. They are especially common in the section between Kirirom National Park and Preah Sihanouk.

One small off-road of Road 4, in Ream National Park near Preah Sihanouk.

In Preah Monivong National Park.

metas.title: Road 4 Wide Red Shoulders
metas.description: There is another good way to recognize Road 4 between Angk Snuol and Preah Sihanouk: in most sections, it has a distinctive wide, red-brownish shoulder on both sides of the road.
metas.note: Near Phnom Penh, the soil of these shoulders tends to have a lighter, pinkish or beige colour. In the hills and closer to Preah Sihanouk, the soil tends to have a darker colour.

metas.title: Oil Palms (Road 4)
metas.description: Oil palm plantations can only be found on Road 4, as well as some of its rural offroads, just north of Preah Nob.
metas.note: Oil palm plantations are much more common in Malaysia and Indonesia. Only use this clue to region-guess if you are certain that you are in Cambodia, and not to identify the country.

metas.title: Preah Monivong NP
metas.description: Preah Monivong National Park in the south of the country has a unique and recognizable landscape. It is situated on a highland plateau. The soil is white and very rocky. The vegetation consists of stunted, windswept bushes and low trees. The foliage has a distinct dark green tint that contrasts with the white rocks. Some parts of the park are more forested but will still have the same rocky soil.

metas.title: Road 41 (Gravelly/NNE)
metas.description:
Road 41, southwest of Phnom Penh, has a recognizable look and road angle:

It is a wide road, with a grey and very gravelly road surface

It runs in a general NNE direction

The landscape close to the road is flat and agricultural. However, you can often see hills in the distance.
metas.note: There are other roads that can look similar. Therefore, the road angle is very important to identify this road.

metas.title: Unique Poles (1-Side Insulators)
metas.description: In the sections of Road 6 west of Siem Reap, to Sisophon, and Road 5, south of Sisophon to Krong Battambang, you can find power lines with unique poles that are found nowhere else in Cambodia. The pole tops have three horizontal beams, with hanging insulators on only one side. The bottom of the poles have indents.

metas.title: Unique Poles (2-Side Insulators)
metas.description: The powerline from the previous tip continues on the section of Road 5 west of Sisophon. However, here the pole tops have insulators on both sides. The rest of the pole is identical however.

metas.title: Road 76 South
metas.description: The southern section of Road 76, south of Krong Saen Monourom, has recognizable coverage: overcast weather, dark asphalt, the presence of outer road lines, and relatively crisp lines for Cambodian standards. Furthermore, a large part of the eastern half of this road runs through hilly terrain with dense jungle.

metas.title: Road 76 North
metas.description:
Most of the northern section of Road 76, between Lumphat and Mayura Wild Park, is recognizable too: it is a wide, unpaved road, with brown soil, and a semi-open jungle forest all around you.

Weather conditions start off as overcast on the southern end of the road, and quickly improve the further north you go, with almost completely clear skies on the northern end.
metas.note: There are other, smaller roads that can look similar. However, this road is by far the longest that has this distinct look.

metas.title: Pech Sreada Rubber
metas.description: Around the town of Pech Sreada, in the far east of Cambodia, you can find rubber tree plantations that were covered during the dry season, leading to a distinct look. In addition, the soil is very orange, making it easy to distinguish this area from other regions in Cambodia with rubber tree plantations.

metas.title: Angkor Wat
metas.description: Angkor Wat is a massive temple complex built by the historical Khmer Empire. It is located just north of Siem Reap and has extensive trekker coverage. It can be recognized by its dark, weathered stone buildings. While this location is unlikely to show up in competitive maps, it is extremely common in GeoGuessr’s official Cambodia map.

metas.title: Mainland Tripods (Motion Blur)
metas.description: All official coverage in mainland China is taken with a tripod. Objects in the image will usually have motion blur, and slightly saturated colours.
metas.note:
Coverage in Hong Kong and Macau both have full Google Car coverage.

A separate Plonk It guide to Hong Kong can be found here. The Macau guide can be found here.

metas.title: Simplified Chinese
metas.description: Chinese writing consists of often complicated symbols made up of several strokes. On mainland China, you’ll typically find simplified Chinese, where the number of strokes of many symbols have been greatly reduced compared to traditional Chinese.
metas.note: Traditional Chinese is widely used in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau.

metas.title: License Plates (Blue/White Text)
metas.description: Chinese licence plates are blue with white text.

metas.title: Coverage Map (East Coast)
metas.description: Coverage in mainland China is limited to several small spots, mainly in or near major urban areas on the east coast. A significant portion of the coverage is considered hidden, which is also shown on this map. Hidden means it won’t show up on Google Maps, however you can still access it in the Map Making App.

metas.title: Museums (Beijing/Shanghai)
metas.description: A significant portion of the coverage was taken inside museums and can be found in many cities, however a majority of the covered museums are located in and around Beijing and Shanghai.

metas.title: Ancient Cities
metas.description: Ancient cities with coverage can be found along the east coast in Zhoucun, northeast of Xuzhou, in Yangzhou, west of Jiaxing and west of Zhangzhou.

metas.title: Urban Coverage (Modern)
metas.description: Coverage taken outside in modern urban areas can be found in Beijing, Yangzhou, Shanghai, Shenzhen and Chengdu.

metas.title: Forbidden City (Beijing)
metas.description: The Palace Museum (commonly referred to as the Forbidden City) is a massive palace in the centre of Beijing.

metas.title: Today Art Museum (Beijing)
metas.description: By the Today Art Museum in Beijing you can find this modern urban street with several cafes and bars along the road. In front of the museum you can also find this uncanny statue.

metas.title: Sichuan Museum (Chengdu)
metas.description: The parking area outside Sichuan Museum in Chengdu has a lot of greenery.

metas.title: Hubei Museum (Wuhan)
metas.description: The Hubei Museum in Wuhan can be recognised by its palace-like architecture with grey roofs.

metas.title: Silk Museum (Hangzhou)
metas.description: The Museum of silk production in Hangzhou can be recognised by the rounded glass facade and the fountain by the front.

metas.title: Long Museum (Shanghai)
metas.description: Shanghai Long Museum can be recognised by the boxy concrete main building.

metas.title: Suzhou Museum
metas.description: Suzhou Museum can be recognised by the white and grey symmetric angular architecture.

metas.title: Yangzhou Museum
metas.description: The Yangzhou Museum can be recognised by the beige rounded stone building.

metas.title: Zhoucun Ancient City
metas.description: The ancient city of Zhoucun is the only pinpointable ancient city in China, and can be recognised by the street going straight north to south.

metas.title: Southern China SAR
metas.description:
Hong Kong is located in Southern China, sharing a border with the Guangdong province. It is a Chinese Special Administrative Region, so for country streaks purposes, it is counted as part of China.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: License Plates (White Front/Yellow Rear)
metas.description: Hong Kong has white front licence plates and yellow rear licence plates. The licence plates can be long or short. Some cars have an additional black mainland Chinese licence plate.

metas.title: Driving Side (Left)
metas.description: Hong Kong drives on the left.
metas.note: Singapore also drives on the left, however Taiwan drives on the right.

metas.title: Urban Landscape (Dense/Skyscrapers)
metas.description:
Hong Kong is a densely populated city with millions of inhabitants. In urban areas, modern skyscrapers are common, with busy streets filled with vehicles and pedestrians.

The city has a unique vibe that you can quickly pick up on. In many cases, this vibe alone should be sufficient to identify urban Hong Kong locations.

metas.title: Rural Landscape (Mountainous/Green)
metas.description:
There is also a plethora of rural locations that are harder to identify.

Outside the urban areas, Hong Kong is generally quite mountainous, with green, subtropical vegetation. There is extensive coverage in rural areas outside the city, with many roads going through the mountains. You might see low-rise rural buildings, however usually you will not need to travel far to see tall apartment blocks.
metas.note: Singapore, on the other hand, is very flat.

metas.title: Tall Apartment Buildings
metas.description: One very striking aspect of Hong Kong architecture are the many extremely tall apartment buildings found throughout the city.
metas.note: Apartment buildings in Singapore and Taiwan tend to be not nearly as tall as those in Hong Kong.

metas.title: Air Conditioners
metas.description: Because of the subtropical climate, air conditioners attached to the walls of apartments are very common in Hong Kong.

metas.title: Bilingual Signs (English/Chinese)
metas.description:
Hong Kong has two official languages: English and Chinese (legally, no variety is specified, but residents primarily speak Cantonese).

Bilingual signs are common, with English next to traditional Chinese characters.

metas.title: Grey Lamp Posts (Wide Base)
metas.description: Cylindrical grey lamp posts with a wide base are common. Many lamp posts have a white sticker.

metas.title: Rural Utility Poles (Wooden/Concrete)
metas.description: Utility poles will never be seen in urban rounds, however you might see cylindrical wooden poles in rural areas. The poles can be single or double, with electricity counters or transformers attached to them.

metas.title: No Striped Kerbs
metas.description: In Hong Kong, you will almost never see striped kerbs, which are extremely common in Singapore. In addition, grey pedestrian guardrails are also common.

metas.title: Yellow Road Markings (Crossings/Grids)
metas.description: Hong Kong uses yellow pedestrian crossings. Some intersections have yellow grids.

metas.title: Road Lines (White Center/Yellow Outer)
metas.description: Hong Kong usually uses white centre lines and white or yellow outer lines. These lines can be single, double or dashed. Roads are also commonly made of concrete. Yellow outer lines are most commonly found on small roads to indicate no-stopping.

metas.title: Road Signs (White Rectangular)
metas.description: Road signs are white and rectangular, with a thick black outline and bilingual text.

metas.title: Give Way Signs
metas.description: Give way signs feature a white upside down triangle with a thick red border and bilingual text.

metas.title: Rock Walls & Plaques
metas.description: Distinct weathered rock walls can be seen on the side of mountains. Some of them have nets, to prevent rockslides. In addition, green or blue plaques are a common sight.

metas.title: Fire Hydrants (Red/Yellow)
metas.description: Most fire hydrants are red, and usually have circular tops and three protrusions. There is also a pipe-like variant. Some fire hydrants have other colours, so make sure to look at their shape or other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Yellow Bollards (Blue Arrow)
metas.description: Yellow bollards with a white arrow in a blue circle are commonly seen at pedestrian crossings, but also elsewhere, indicating where cars should go. There is a flat and a cuboid version.

metas.title: Orange Bins
metas.description: Distinct bright orange bins can be found on sidewalks.

metas.title: Taxis (Red/Green/Blue)
metas.description:
Hong Kong taxis come in two variants: sedans or station wagons, with the sedans most commonly seen. They can be easily identified by their silver roofs, green stickers on the front and rear bumper, and the taxi sign on the roof.

Red taxis are most common on Hong Kong Island and Kowloon, green taxis in the New Territories in the northern region and blue taxis on Lantau Island and Chek Lap Kok. Keep in mind, Hong Kong is a small city and taxis travel all around it.

metas.title: Double-Decker Buses
metas.description: Buses in Hong Kong are mostly double-decker, with various colour schemes and adverts on the side. Single-decker versions do exist, but are less common. Smaller minibuses can also be seen, with a green or red roof.
metas.note:
Place names are sometimes visible on the front of the buses, which can be useful for region guessing.

Double-decker buses are also somewhat common in Singapore, but these will often have a recognizable light green colour scheme.

metas.title: Village Houses (Boxy)
metas.description: Boxy houses that are a few storeys high are a common sight in small villages, mostly to the north of Hong Kong.

metas.title: Double-Decker Trams (HK Island)
metas.description: A double-decker tram line runs along the north of Hong Kong Island. A full map of the route can be seen here.
metas.note: Make sure not to mistake this tram for the red MTR railway line, which has some sections above ground.

metas.title: Light Rail (Northwest New Territories)
metas.description: The northwestern part of the New Territories is served by a distinct light rail system. It can be recognised by its green-and-orange platforms, single-level train cars and the fact that the tracks are separated from the street.

metas.title: Mong Kok (Dense/Gridded)
metas.description: Mong Kok and the surrounding districts in Kowloon can be recognized by the crowded, busy, gridded streets, with apartment blocks situated above the shops.
metas.note: These buildings are usually older, which means there will be a lack of glass walls (as opposed to parts of Hong Kong Island which feature more glass).

metas.title: Northwest New Territories (Flat/Paddies)
metas.description: The north-western area near the Mainland China border is mostly flat and features a patchwork of waterlogged rice paddies. The Shenzhen skyline is visible in the distance, to your north.

metas.title: Central District (Skyscrapers)
metas.description: The Central District can be recognized by the large concentration of modern skyscrapers. The district feels quite busy, affluent and well-kept, with lots of luxury brand stores and ads.

metas.title: IFC vs ICC Skyscrapers
metas.description:
You can use these two skyscrapers to determine whether you are on the Kowloon or Hong Kong Island side. The IFC is on the Hong Kong Island side and the ICC is on the Kowloon side.

The ICC has straighter edges and looks more like a cuboid, while the IFC is rounder. The IFC will also have noticeable vertical window frames, while the ICC has none.

metas.title: Mid-Levels (Hilly Residential)
metas.description: Mid-Levels is a residential district that is easily recognized by the non-identical tall modern apartments and hilliness.

metas.title: Sai Wan Ho (Residential)
metas.description: The residential district of Sai Wan Ho has a lot of identical white and brown apartment blocks, and tall glass office buildings.

metas.title: Chek Lap Kok (Construction)
metas.description: Chek Lap Kok Island and the Boundary Crossing Facilities can be recognized by the various large scale construction works going on in the area. From the outside, it can be identified by the many bridges that connect other parts of Hong Kong to the two islands.

metas.title: Tung Chung (Wall of Buildings)
metas.description: The residential district of Caribbean Coast and Tung Chung has identical apartment blocks that face the same direction, almost like a “wall” of buildings. There are a lot of planted palm trees in between and on the side of roads.

metas.title: Tsing Ma Bridge (Suspension)
metas.description: The Tsing Ma Bridge can be recognized by being one of three suspension bridges in Hong Kong. The bridge has two ladder-like support towers, and yellow and red guardrails.

metas.title: Ting Kau Bridge (Yellow)
metas.description: Ting Kau Bridge, another suspension bridge connecting Ting Kau and Tsing Yi, can be identified by the generally clean asphalt and newer condition, three cylindrical support towers, hangers coming directly from the towers themselves, and yellow paint seen in the median and on the outsides.

metas.title: Stonecutters Bridge
metas.description: While similar to the Ting Kau Bridge, the Stonecutters Bridge can be identified by the lack of yellow paint, and its box beam guardrail design, as opposed to the cable design seen on the other two bridges.

metas.title: Lung Wo Road (Skylines)
metas.description: Lung Wo Road can be recognized by the Hong Kong Island skyline to the south and the Kowloon skyline to the north. The road is also in good condition and the sidewalks are clean.

metas.title: Tai Chung Kiu Road
