metas.description: The Tai Chung Kiu Road is a divided road that runs in a north-east direction, and has views of the Shing Mun River to the west. The median has palm trees. In addition, a bicycle path runs alongside the road. Further north, Route 2 also runs alongside the river, but this road has more lanes.

metas.title: Fan Kam Road (Tropical)
metas.description: Fan Kam Road runs in a general north-east direction, and can be recognized by the dense tropical vegetation surrounding the road, and sometimes mountains in the background. The road is also quite narrow and does not have any outer lines. Many small villages branch off of the road, south and north of the country park.

metas.title: Lam Kam Road (Busy)
metas.description: Lam Kam Road is similar to Fan Kam Road, however it runs in a more east-west direction. The road should also feel busier with more cars driving along the road and more houses on the sides of the road. In addition, the road is usually wider and a median containing trees can be seen separating sidewalks near the villages.

metas.title: Kai Tak Cruise Terminal
metas.description: The Kai Tak Cruise Terminal can mainly be seen from the Eastern Corridor, north of Tsat Tsz Mui, and from the Kwun Tong bypass south-west of Kwun Tong. The cruise terminal can be recognized by its shiny, cylindrical appearance, with triangular windows along the side.

metas.title: HK-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge
metas.description: The Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge can be seen from the South Perimeter Road, on Chek Lap Kok Island. Its length stretches into the horizon, spanning across the ocean. The road itself can be recognized by the black and yellow concrete barriers on either side.

metas.title: Disneyland Roads
metas.description: The roads going to Disneyland are divided, with palm trees along the side of the road with teal coloured street lamps.

metas.title: Outlying Islands
metas.description: Between Hong Kong Island and Lantau Island, there are three unique islands: Peng Chau, Cheung Chau and Lamma Island, with trekker coverage. These islands can be identified by the lack of cars, narrow streets, and rural architecture. Lamma Island is also the hilliest of the three.

metas.title: Lugard Road Trekker
metas.description: The Lugard Road trekker around Victoria Peak can be recognized by the distinct black guardrail, view of the skyline and tourists walking along the path.

metas.title: Shitcam Coverage
metas.description: The vast majority of the coverage in India was taken with what’s commonly referred to as “shitcam”, which is a low-quality camera that can typically be recognised by the brownish colours and often, but not always, by a large circular blur covering the Street View car.
metas.note: Within Asia, Nepal is also entirely “shitcam”, while it’s also common in Cambodia and can rarely be seen in Sri Lanka and Bangladesh.

metas.title: Gen 4 Smallcam
metas.description: All the Generation 4 coverage in India was taken using the smallcam, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.

metas.title: Gen 3 Trekker Coverage
metas.description: While most of India is covered in shitcam, there is also a significant amount of Generation 3 trekkers throughout the country.

metas.title: Driving Side (Left)
metas.description: India drives on the left side of the road.

metas.title: Scripts Variety
metas.description: A wide variety of scripts can be found in India. Most of them can be used to narrow down the region.

metas.title: English Signage
metas.description: English is also an official language in India and can be seen on a lot of signage.

metas.title: License Plates (Long/White/Yellow)
metas.description: Indian licence plates are typically fairly long, with the most common design being white. Commercial vehicles typically use yellow plates, while electric vehicles use green.

metas.title: Signposts (Black & White Stripes)
metas.description: India typically has black and white striped signposts.
metas.note: Bangladesh and Sri Lanka also have black and white signposts.

metas.title: Utility Poles (Concrete/Trident)
metas.description:
The most common Indian utility pole is a concrete square pole with a trident pole top.

Beware that many regions have their own distinct poles and poletops.
metas.note: Indian poles will almost always be made of concrete or metal. Wooden poles are extremely uncommon.

metas.title: Hindi (Devanagari Script)
metas.description: Hindi is the most common language in India and can be found in many central and northern regions. It uses the Devanagari script, which can be recognised by the line going through the top of each word and the straight vertical lines found in the majority of all letters.

metas.title: Marathi (Devanagari with ळ)
metas.description: Marathi, found in Maharashtra, also uses the Devanagari script, however it sometimes uses the letter ळ which is not found in Hindi.

metas.title: Punjabi (Gurmukhi Script)
metas.description: Punjabi can be found in Punjab in northwestern India. While the script looks somewhat similar to Hindi, it can generally be differentiated by the softer shape of the letters and the horizontal bar being broken over certain letters. It also has some distinctly different features, such as the letters ਨ, ਲ and ਅ as well as a diacritic in the shape of a soft curve beneath a letter.

metas.title: Gujarati Script (No Top Line)
metas.description: Gujarati, found in Gujarat, has a script with several similarities to the Hindi script, however it notably lacks the horizontal line at the top of every word.

metas.title: Bengali Script (Triangles)
metas.description: Bengali is found in northeastern India and has a similar look to Devanagari (Hindi), however it can usually be recognised by the many letters featuring left-facing triangular shapes.
metas.note: This is also the language found in Bangladesh.

metas.title: Assamese (Bengali with ৰ/ৱ)
metas.description: Assamese, mainly found in Assam, also uses the Bengali script, with the addition of some characters, most notably ৰ and ৱ.

metas.title: Kannada Script (Rounded/Squiggly Tail)
metas.description: Kannada is found in Karnataka and has a script with a lot of smooth curves and small circles. It is very similar to the Telugu script, with Telugu having one additional feature described in the next tip. Many characters also feature a distinct squiggly tail in the top right corner, which is less common in Telugu.

metas.title: Telugu (Tick Marks)
metas.description: Telugu, found in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh, has a script very similar to Kannada, but you’ll often see diacritics resembling checkmarks at the top of letters.

metas.title: Tamil Script
metas.description: The Tamil script is found in Tamil Nadu and has a distinct combination of curves, straight lines and 90° angles. Some letters also have diacritics shaped like dots.
metas.note: Tamil is also commonly found in Sri Lanka.

metas.title: Oriya Script (Curvy/Skull)
metas.description: The Oriya script is found in Odisha and has a curvy look, with many letters having wide semi-circles covering the top. Many letters have a distinct diacritic in the shape of a wide curve above the top of the letter. A useful mnemonic is that the shape of the characters resembles a skull emoji.

metas.title: Malayalam Script (U-Shapes)
metas.description: The Malayalam script can be found in Kerala and mostly consists of somewhat simple-looking curvy letters, often containing upside-down U-shapes.

metas.title: Manipuri Script (Vertical Lines)
metas.description: Manipuri, also called Meitei, is the official language of Manipur. It is written using the Meitei script, which can be recognised by its many vertical lines and right angles.

metas.title: Mizo (Latin Script)
metas.description: Mizo, found in Mizoram, is the language most commonly found on the Indian coverage other than English, which uses the Latin script.

metas.title: Meghalaya (English Only)
metas.description: While English can be found anywhere in India, Meghalaya is the only region which almost exclusively uses English.

metas.title: Southern Tuk-Tuks (Yellow/Black)
metas.description: Yellow tuk tuks with black roofs are common in the southern Indian states of Telangana, Andhra Pradesh, and Tamil Nadu.
metas.note: They can also rarely be found elsewhere.

metas.title: Gujarat Holey Poles (Square)
metas.description:
Concrete holey poles are unique to Gujarat and the Union territory of Daman and Diu, and Dadra and Nagar Haveli.

Gujarat uses a variety of poletops, some of which can be used to identify other states. Beware that holey poles generally take precedence over poletop metas.
metas.note: They are rarely found in other states especially Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, and Chhattisgarh.

metas.title: Andhra/Telangana Split Poles
metas.description: Poles divided in two sections, in a similar fashion to Brazilian poles, are common in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana.

metas.title: Sikkim Mesh Poles
metas.description: Metal poles with a mesh pattern are commonly found in Sikkim.

metas.title: Kerala Metal Holey Poles
metas.description: Metal holey poles are common in Kerala.

metas.title: Northeast/Himalaya Grey Poles
metas.description: Thin grey metal poles are seen all over northeastern India and in the Himalayan region of Uttarakhand and Himachal Pradesh. You will commonly see two of these poles in close proximity.

metas.title: Punjab Green Power Counters
metas.description: Electricity counters in Punjab are usually mint green with small window-like squares. They can rarely be seen in Haryana.

metas.title: Punjab Window Poletops
metas.description: Small metal poletops in the shape of a window are found in Punjab and Haryana.

metas.title: Karnataka Trident Poletops
metas.description: In Karnataka, and sometimes in Haryana, you can find trident poletops on concrete poles where the central insulator is attached directly to the top of the pole, while the other two are attached to a horizontal crossbar positioned slightly further down. There is also a variant having several bars instead of one.

metas.title: Manipur Metal Tridents
metas.description: In Manipur you can often find trident poletops on poles made entirely out of metal. They sometimes have small bars on the top of the trident.

metas.title: Maharashtra Inverted Triangle Poletops
metas.description: Upside down triangle poletops placed below the top of the pole are commonly found in Maharashtra, Chhattisgarh, and less commonly in Madhya Pradesh.

metas.title: MP Inverted A Poletops
metas.description: Poles in Madhya Pradesh often have a metal bar shaped like an upside down A slightly below the top of the pole.

metas.title: Chhattisgarh Trapezoid Connectors
metas.description: A connector on the pole which looks like an upside down trapezoid is most common in Chhattisgarh and somewhat common in Meghalaya, Tripura and Maharashtra, but can rarely be found in many other states.
metas.note: They can also be paired with Holey Poles in Gujarat and Ladder Poles in Andhra Pradesh, thus only use the trapezoid when no other pole meta is present.

metas.title: West Bengal Rectangle Poletops
metas.description: A variety of poletops attached to the pole with two vertical bars forming a tall and narrow rectangle can be found in West Bengal.

metas.title: West Bengal Crossbar Poletops
metas.description: In West Bengal you may also find poletops containing two crossbars which are connected to each other with thin vertical supports on either side. The lower bar is connected on either side to the pole with diagonal supports.

metas.title: Northeast Even/Uneven Poletops
metas.description: In the northeast you may find poles with a combination of an even and uneven poletop.

metas.title: Meghalaya Diagonal Poletops
metas.description: Poles with two diagonal bars forming a ‘<’ shape are common in Meghalaya and Arunachal Pradesh and occasionally found in Assam.

metas.title: Northeast Double Crossbars
metas.description: In Assam, Meghalaya and Mizoram you commonly see poles with two crossbars, each with two insulators. If there are more than two bars, you should be in Meghalaya or Mizoram.
metas.note: They can rarely be seen in other states.

metas.title: Assam Bent Trident
metas.description: Trident poletops with the tip of the middle bar bent at a 90° angle can be found in Assam.

metas.title: Goa Short/Long Crossbars
metas.description: Poletops with a short crossbar above a longer crossbar can be found in Goa.

metas.title: Tamil Nadu Pole Markings
metas.description: Markings on poles and trees, consisting of one black stripe in-between two white ones, are common in Tamil Nadu.

metas.title: Delhi Pole Stripes (5+)
metas.description: Pole paint consisting of five or more thin black and yellow stripes can be found in Delhi.

metas.title: Bihar Pole Stripes (4)
metas.description: Pole paint consisting of exactly four thicker black and yellow stripes can be found in Bihar.

metas.title: Bihar Red/White Tree Stripes
metas.description: In Bihar, and less commonly Jharkhand, you may find trees with four red and white stripes painted near the bottom.

metas.title: Kerala Yellow Pole Stickers
metas.description: Small yellow pole markings are commonly found in Kerala.
metas.note: Similar stickers can rarely be found in other states.

metas.title: Central Rounded Tiles
metas.description: Rounded roof tiles are common in central India. They often appear disorganised and are kept in rows/columns that are not completely straight.

metas.title: South Orange Tiles
metas.description: Roofs in southern India are characterised by more organised tiles that are bright orange and flat with a ridge in the middle. It is particularly common in Tamil Nadu.
metas.note: Similarly shaped tiles with a darker brown colour are common further north.

metas.title: WB Flat Diamond Tiles
metas.description: Flat roof tiles, similar to the ones found in the south, with a small diamond shaped protrusion in the middle, are commonly found in and around West Bengal.

metas.title: WB Metal Hip Roofs
metas.description: Large hip roofs made of corrugated sheet metal are found in West Bengal and adjacent areas in Bihar and Odisha.

metas.title: Northeast Triangle Metal Roofs
metas.description: Metal roofs, with a small triangle near the top, are common in Northeast India.

metas.title: Northeast Panel Houses
metas.description: Houses made of square panels separated by thin beams are found in Northeast India.

metas.title: Thatched Roofs (East/North)
metas.description: Houses or huts with thatched roofs are mainly found along the east coast and northern plains. Large hay mounds are also generally more common in this region. Note that thatched roofs from Uttar Pradesh to Odisha tend to be made of fine pieces of hay whereas thatched roofs from Odisha to Tamil Nadu tend to be made of dried palm fans.

metas.title: Sikh Gurdwaras
metas.description: Gurdwaras, which can typically be recognised by their white domes and ornate walls, are most common in Punjab. You can also sometimes recognise them by the Sikh Khanda symbol, which represents the religion.

metas.title: Wealthy Homes (Goa/Kerala)
metas.description: Goa and Kerala are two of the most developed states in India and often have very wealthy and modern homes.

metas.title: Chir Pines (Northwest)
metas.description: Chir pines are more or less exclusive to Uttarakhand, Himachal Pradesh, Jammu and Kashmir as well as in westernmost Arunachal Pradesh. These pines can be identified from their generally smooth-looking conical or spherical crowns with very long needles.

metas.title: Khasi Pines (Northeast)
metas.description: Khasi pines are mainly found in Meghalaya and Manipur. While the needles appear similar to those of chir pines, the overall crown formed by its branches will appear more jagged and disorganised.

metas.title: Cacti Fences (West)
metas.description: This type of cacti (Euphorbia neriifolia) can commonly be seen as part of fences throughout Gujarat, western Maharashtra and the southern half of Rajasthan.

metas.title: Palmyra Palms (South/East)
metas.description: Palmyra Palms have a round crown with fan shaped leaves and a trunk with consistent thickness, giving them a lollipop shape. If you see them in large numbers you should be in the south or east of the country.

metas.title: Areca Palms (Coast/Northeast)
metas.description: Areca Palms can be recognised by their very thin trunk and a small crown. They are mainly found near the southwestern coast, in the northeast and on the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

metas.title: Date Palms (Central Dry)
metas.description: Date palms are commonly found in drier areas of the central regions of India where there are fewer tropical and coastal palms.

metas.title: Andhra Oil Palms
metas.description: Oil palm plantations are most commonly found in the panhandle of Andhra Pradesh, especially near the eastern border with Telangana.

metas.title: Tea Plantations
metas.description: Tea plantations can be found in the northeast and the far south.
metas.note: If you find tea plantations in a flat area, you are likely in Assam or northeastern West Bengal, near the Assam border.

metas.title: Sugarcane (UP/Southwest)
metas.description: Sugarcane is most commonly found in the north in and around Uttar Pradesh, and in the southwest.

metas.title: Cotton (West)
metas.description: Cotton is commonly found in the western parts of India, particularly in Gujarat and Maharashtra.

metas.title: Canola (Rajasthan)
metas.description: Canola is mostly found in and around Rajasthan.

metas.title: Himalayas
metas.description: The by far tallest mountains in India are found in the Himalayas.

metas.title: Ladakh/Himachal Dry Mountains
metas.description: In Ladakh and northern Himachal Pradesh you can find an extremely dry landscape with little to no vegetation within the Himalayan mountains.

metas.title: Northern Plains (Gangetic)
metas.description: The northern plains, also known as the Ganges River Valley, of India are very fertile with extremely flat and open agricultural fields.

metas.title: Maharashtra Dark Soil
metas.description: Distinctly dark soil is mainly found in Maharashtra and adjacent regions.

metas.title: Red Soil (South/East)
metas.description: Red soil can be found in several regions, but mainly near the southern west coast and in and around Chhattisgarh and western Odisha.

metas.title: Rajasthan Desert
metas.description: The western parts of Rajasthan can commonly be recognised by the dry landscape with sandy soil.

metas.title: Western Ghats
metas.description: The Western Ghats Mountains in the western part of Maharashtra can be recognised by their distinct ridgelines, often having plateaus rather than peaks. The northern part is drier while the southern part has more vegetation.
metas.note: During the rainy season the mountains will turn green and appear quite different.

metas.title: Mizoram Hills
metas.description: The landscape in Mizoram mainly consists of lush, green valleys with fairly low vegetation with eroded hillsides having many small peaks scattered around.
metas.note: A somewhat similar landscape can be found in Meghalaya, however rather than distinct peaks, the hillsides will have a mostly smooth and flat top.

metas.title: Boxy Cars (Punjab/TN)
metas.description: Large visible, square shaped cars can be found in the areas shown on the map.
metas.note: A somewhat similar car with a visible hood on the car can be found in Odisha.

metas.title: Northeast Stick Fences
metas.description: In the northeast you will commonly see fences made of thin wooden sticks in a square pattern.

metas.title: Buddhist Prayer Flags
metas.description: Buddhist prayer flags are found in Sikkim and Arunachal Pradesh.

metas.title: Andaman Pole Stickers
metas.description: On the Andaman and Nicobar Islands you can find these black pole stickers, containing several digits as well as an arrow in the middle.

metas.title: Chandigarh Planned City
metas.description: The City of Chandigarh is a planned industrial city. As a result, the city features a lot of unique infrastructure, such as blue signs mentioning sectors and industrial areas, round yellow markings on street lights, and street signs which will typically feature several numbers rather than street names.
metas.note: The nearby cities of Sahibzada Ajit Singh Nagar and Panchkula are also planned industrial cities, which feature somewhat similar signs.

metas.title: Delhi Orange/Green Buses
metas.description: Orange and bright green buses are typically found in Delhi.

metas.title: Ahmedabad/Surat Bus Lanes
metas.description: On large roads in Ahmedabad and Surat you can find separated middle lanes for buses. Beware that people will still often drive in these lanes.

metas.title: Mumbai/Meghalaya Taxis
metas.description: Black Taxis with yellow roofs are found in Meghalaya and Mumbai.

metas.title: Sikkim Yellow Hood Taxis
metas.description: Taxis in Sikkim often have a painted yellow hood or a small yellow circle on it.

metas.title: Elevated Railways
metas.description:
Elevated railways can be found in the following cities:

Bengaluru

Chennai

Delhi

Hyderabad

Jaipur

Kochi

Kolkata

Mumbai

metas.title: Telangana/Karnataka Grey Bricks
metas.description: The area on the border of Telangana and Karnataka often have houses with roofs made out of distinctly thin grey bricks. These grey bricks and similar coloured rocks are sometimes also seen in walls and scattered on the ground in stockyards.

metas.title: Bihar/UP White Clay Huts
metas.description: White painted clay huts are found in northwestern Bihar and northeastern Uttar Pradesh.

metas.title: Bihar Cross-Pattern Huts
metas.description: Wooden huts with a cross pattern can be found in central Bihar.

metas.title: Japanese Cedar Trees
metas.description: Japanese cedar trees can typically be recognised by their significant height combined with their narrow, fluffy-looking crowns. They are most commonly found near the border of Sikkim and West Bengal, as well as in Meghalaya.

metas.title: Himalayan Cedar
metas.description: The Himalayan cedar is most commonly seen on the NH34 from Harsil to Gangotri, as well as around the city of Shimla.

metas.title: Bhutan White Pine
metas.description: The Bhutan white pine can be recognised by its hanging needles all pointing downwards. They are mainly found in the Mechuka Valley as well as near the Bhutan border in Arunachal Pradesh.

metas.title: Doum Palms (Diu)
metas.description: Doum palms, which appear similar to Palmyra palms but with multiple branches, are almost exclusive to the union territory of Diu.

metas.title: Indian Pitcher Plant
metas.description: The endangered Indian pitcher plant is exclusive to the Khasi Hills, which are mainly in Meghalaya. They can occasionally be spotted on road sides, especially on the NH206 north of Umlārem.

metas.title: West Uttarakhand Barren
metas.description: The western half of Uttarakhand is typically far more barren than the other Himalayan regions, due to logging and erosion. The coverage northwest of Dehradun on the Himachal Pradesh Border has some especially barren hills full of brown grass and small roads next to cliffs.

metas.title: Mechuka Valley
metas.description: The Mechuka valley is the only place in Northeast India where snowy mountains are visible. The valley contains brownish grass and a plethora of Bhutan white pine. North of Mechuka the coverage gradually becomes overcast and somewhat dark.

metas.title: Chaukhamba Peaks
metas.description: Chaukhamba, located near the town of Ukhimath, is a mountain massif covered in snow which can be recognised by its three distinct peaks, with the centre peak being the tallest.

metas.title: South Meghalaya Hills
metas.description: The landscape south of Shillong in Meghalaya, is characterised by V-shaped, green eroded valleys with somewhat flat and smooth ridgetops.
metas.note: Mizoram hills are less smooth with more rises and falls instead of long smooth ridges.

metas.title: Gujarat Salt Flats
metas.description: Salt flats and coastal marshes with nearly no vegetation, other than short yellow or brown grass, can be found in parts of Gujarat. Shallow bodies of water can often be seen around these areas.
metas.note: The soil in western Rajasthan will be a lot more sandy and you’ll typically be able to see short desert shrubs.

metas.title: Tamil Nadu Monoliths
metas.description: Near the southern tip of Tamil Nadu, you can find these large monolithic mountains, with huge exposed rocks. Several of these mountains can be seen from afar, especially the Magenthiragiri hills.

metas.title: Tamil Nadu Red Soil
metas.description: A flat, bushy landscape with very red soil can be found in southern Tamil Nadu.

metas.title: Lakshadweep (Coconuts)
metas.description: Lakshadweep, located off the coast of Kerala, can be easily recognised by the abundance of coconut trees. They are often painted red-and-white, resembling the Polish flag.

metas.title: Odisha Antenna Road (NH326)
metas.description: The coverage on road NH326 (labelled 326) west of Brahmapur in Odisha has a thin grey antenna. The images are generally very high-quality for shitcam, with an especially high quality near the Harabhangi Reservoir.

metas.title: Meghalaya Yellow Lines (NH6/NH206)
metas.description: Parts of roads NH6 and NH206 southeast of Shillong can be recognised by the presence of khasi pines with distinct yellow outer road lines and fresh dark pavement.
metas.note: This is the only road in Meghalaya that uses yellow outer road lines, but these lines exist in other states as well.

metas.title: License Plates (Black/White)
metas.description:
Indonesian licence plates are black with white letters. The letters usually appear as three white sections through the blur.

Commercial vehicles use yellow licence plates.

Plates in newer coverage can be white too.
metas.note: Malaysian licence plates are also black, but generally have two white sections.

metas.title: Driving Side (Left)
metas.description: Indonesia drives on the left.
metas.note: Malaysia drives on the left, while the Philippines drives on the right.

metas.title: Road Lines (White/Yellow)
metas.description:
Indonesia uses white or yellow centre lines. Outer lines will always be white. The centre lines will be solid or dashed.

In Generation 3 coverage, yellow centre lines are more rare, as Indonesia only recently started using this colour for its road lines.
metas.note: Malaysian road lines are always all white.

metas.title: Poles Overview
metas.description:
Poles in Indonesia are typically round and made out of either steel or concrete. Many of the steel poles are painted black, and also feature the Indonesian flag colours on them. The pole tops are usually either even or uneven, depending on the region.

You can learn more about regional poles in the region-guessing section.

metas.title: Bollards
metas.description: Indonesia commonly uses these black-and-white square or circular bollards, as well as these yellow-and-black ones, which can also have a red reflector. Other designs can also be found.
metas.note: UK-style bollards are mostly found in Kalimantan.

metas.title: Waystones
metas.description: Usually yellow waystones that are angled towards the road, and have a cutout close to the top are unique to Indonesia. They include shorthand for three cities or towns, with the biggest one being on the top in the cutout section.
metas.note: Waystones in the Philippines are perpendicular to the road and have the text facing away from the road.

metas.title: Language Check (Indo vs Malay)
metas.description:
Indonesian can look very similar to Malaysian, however Indonesian has been influenced by Dutch, and Malaysian by English. These small changes in spelling may help differentiate the two.

An example is the word television in English, which translates to ‘televisi’ in Indonesian, similar to the Dutch word ‘televisie.’ In Malaysian, it translates to ‘televisyen’, more similar to English.

metas.title: Red/White Banners
metas.description: You can find these rows of red and white banners all around Indonesia. Sometimes, more colourful flags can be found.

metas.title: Cigarette Ads
metas.description: Cigarette ads can be found all over Indonesia, usually with a black or red colour scheme and around a price of 18,000 Rp. Keep an eye out for illustrated graphic pictures, and the word ‘PERINGATAN’.

metas.title: Motorcycle Front Plates
metas.description: Motorcycles in Indonesia have front licence plates, as opposed to other south-east Asian countries which do not.

metas.title: Currency (Rupiah)
metas.description: The official Indonesian currency is the Rupiah (Rp).

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Coverage in Indonesia is fairly limited. Notably, there is no coverage on Papua or adjacent islands, and coverage is sparse in areas such as Kalimantan, Aceh, Central Sulawesi and North Maluku.

metas.title: Kabupatens (Regencies)
metas.description:
The names of 2nd level subdivisions, named ‘Kabupaten’ or ‘Kab’ for short, translating to regency, can be found all over Indonesia on various signs and billboards. Each province is split up into multiple Kabupatens, totalling to 417 which are covered by street view, and therefore applicable in Geoguessr. These are learnable with enough time and patience.

See the resources section for more information.

metas.title: Cardinal Directions
metas.description:
You can find the cardinal directions written on many addresses. They are as follows:

North = Utara

East = Timur

South = Selatan

West = Barat

Central = Tengah

metas.title: Pole Tops (Even/Uneven)
metas.description: Indonesia uses two types of pole tops: even and uneven. This refers to the bar that holds the insulators and whether it is symmetrical to the pole itself. Knowing where even and uneven poles are most commonly found is useful for region guessing.

metas.title: Triangle Connector Poles
metas.description: You can find these poles with a triangle attachment under the horizontal bar in the following regions.
metas.note: This does not apply to stacked poles.

metas.title: Trident Poles
metas.description: Trident style pole tops are most commonly found in Central Java and Yogyakarta, and rarely in South and West Kalimantan, and North Sumatra and Riau.

metas.title: Bali Rectangle Poles
metas.description: Bali features both even and uneven poles, as well as the Lesser Sunda island variants. You can also find this unique rectangle attachment on the pole tops in Bali.

metas.title: Nusa Long Support Poles
metas.description: On the Lesser Sunda Islands (“Nusas”), you can find poles with an extra long support on the pole top. Sometimes, two supports can be present.

metas.title: North/Central Sulawesi Poles
metas.description: Pole tops in North and Central Sulawesi, and Gorontalo commonly feature an extra attachment right under the horizontal bar.

metas.title: Central Sulawesi Thin Poles
metas.description: You can often see thin, black poles next to regular poles near the East Peninsula of Central Sulawesi. Two pieces of tape can be seen near the top of the poles, usually light blue and green. These can rarely be seen in northern South East Sulawesi.

metas.title: North Sumatra Uneven Insulators
metas.description: These poles are almost exclusive to North Sumatra. The bar which holds the insulators is even, but features uneven insulators with one on one side and two on the other.

metas.title: Satellite Dishes
metas.description: Satellite dishes can help you determine whether you are north or south of the equator. For example, if the satellite dish points north, you are most likely south of it, and vice versa. The angle of the satellite dish can also tell you how far away from the equator you are. The more levelled it is, the closer you are.

metas.title: Central Sulawesi Bollards
metas.description: Central Sulawesi features these unique bollards that are painted black on the bottom, white in the middle, and yellow on the top.

metas.title: Painted Fences (Sulawesi)
metas.description: These painted fences are typically found on Sulawesi. They will be mostly painted white with blue or red.

metas.title: Kalimantan Green Bridges
metas.description: Green paint can often be seen on the side of bridges in South and Central Kalimantan.

metas.title: Oil Palm Plantations
metas.description: Within Indonesia, oil palm plantations are mostly concentrated in Sumatra and Kalimantan. Palm plantations can rarely be seen in Sulawesi.

metas.title: Rice Paddies (Java)
metas.description: The majority of rice production is concentrated in Java, but can sometimes be found in other provinces, namely South Sulawesi and South Sumatra. They can rarely be found in other provinces as well. For a full overview, see this map.

metas.title: Dry Landscape (Nusas)
metas.description: The Nusas typically look drier than other regions in Indonesia. The islands get especially dry towards the east, especially in Generation 3. Vegetation tends to look less tropical, but instead more brown with a lack of leaves. Sumba Island is also the driest of the Nusas.
metas.note: While less common, other regions such as Java can look similarly dry. Make sure to look out for other clues before guessing.

metas.title: North Sumba Savannah
metas.description: This savannah landscape is occasionally seen on North Sumba.
metas.note: In Generation 3, you will always see a white car.

metas.title: Red Soil (Batam/Bangka)
metas.description: Red soil can often be found on Batam and the Bangka Belitung islands, located east of mainland Sumatra.

metas.title: Tiled Roofs (Java)
metas.description: Tiled roofs are most commonly found on the island of Java, and sometimes nearby regions such as southern Sumatra, the Lesser Sunda Islands, and South Kalimantan.
metas.note: The tiles on roofs in South Kalimantan and Jambi look slightly different. The tiles are usually less rounded but flatter.

metas.title: Metal Roofs (North)
metas.description: Plain sheet metal roofs are more commonly found toward the north, where tiled roofs are not found. They are most commonly found on Kalimantan, Sulawesi and Sumatra.

metas.title: South Sulawesi Roof Slots
metas.description: These horizontal slots inside the triangles of the roofs are almost unique to Southern Sulawesi.
metas.note: They can rarely be found in East Kalimantan and West Nusa.

metas.title: Sumba High-Pitched Roofs
metas.description: You can find these distinct roofs with uniquely high-pitched peaks on Sumba.

metas.title: Bali Architecture
metas.description: Architecture in Bali is unique because it was influenced by old Balinese culture and Hinduism. The most important thing to look for are these crown-like roof pinnacles, found everywhere in Bali. Guardian statues and slit-drum towers are common too. Andesite, a dark, volcanic rock, is a common building material in Bali. You can often see gates, walls, and other intricately carved ornaments built from this material.

metas.title: West Sumatra Boat Roofs
metas.description: West Sumatra features these distinct boat-shaped roofs.

metas.title: North Sumatra Boat Roofs
metas.description: North Sumatra features similarly distinct boat-shaped roofs, however the roofs are less angled upward and they do not feature spires.
metas.note: These roofs are most commonly found near Lake Toba, due to its sacred history.

metas.title: Kalimantan Wood Chip Roofs
metas.description: On Kalimantan, you can find these unique roofs made out of wooden chips.

metas.title: Gable Horn Roofs
metas.description: Roofs with gable horns can be found most commonly in South Sulawesi, Riau and Central and South Kalimantan.
metas.note: Horned roofs are often found with Bugis roofs in South Sulawesi. Use this tip along with other clues to determine which region you are in.

metas.title: Toraja Saddle Roofs
metas.description: A small region of South Sulawesi, around the city of Rante Pao, features these very unique houses, called Tongkonan, that have saddle-shaped roofs. The houses themselves are also elevated from the ground.

metas.title: License Plate Codes
metas.description: In the rare case a licence plate is unblurred, knowing regional licence plate codes can be helpful for region guessing. 1 letter codes can only be seen in Java, and are mostly found in the west. 2 letter codes can still be seen on Java, but in the east.
metas.note:
The highlighted areas on the map only refer to the first letter. A detailed map of all the codes can be seen here.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Churches (Christianity)
metas.description: Indonesia is religiously a Muslim majority country, so seeing churches, and other Christian signs, is a good clue for these regions.

metas.title: Gen 3 Antenna (East Java)
metas.description: Generation 3 antenna coverage is most commonly found on Java, but can very rarely be seen on Bali in and around Denpasar. It is most commonly seen in East Java, as most of the antenna coverage in the west has been overwritten by Generation 4.

metas.title: Black Gen 3 Car
metas.description: Black Generation 3 coverage can be found almost everywhere in Indonesia, but is most common in Sulawesi.

metas.title: Lake Toba
metas.description: The region around Lake Toba, in North Sumatra, can be recognized by mountains surrounding the lake and Samosir Island in the middle. Overcast coverage is also common for the region.

metas.title: Batam/Medan Camera Glitch
metas.description: In some of the Generation 4 coverage in the city of Batam, a purple tint and a black blurred object can be seen. Although this camera glitch is most commonly found in Batam, you may spot it in nearby regions such as North Sumatra, around Medan. Make sure to look out for other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Palu Bay
metas.description: Palu Bay is a unique slightly north-west facing bay just north of Palu city, which features mountains to the west of the bay, and a flat, more urbanised landscape to the east.

metas.title: Nias Island Roofs
metas.description: Steeply pitched roofs made of palm tree leaves can sometimes be seen on Nias Island, south west of North Sumatra.

metas.title: East Bali SUV
metas.description: A white SUV with black bars and a wooden plank on the roof can rarely be seen in eastern Bali.

metas.title: Bali Pick-up Truck
metas.description: A black cab with men sitting in the truck bed can be seen near Jagasatru on Bali.

metas.title: National Museum (Trekker)
metas.description: The coverage in Iraq is limited to a single trekker in the Iraqi National Museum in Baghdad.

metas.title: Gen 1.5 Trekker (Overexposed)
metas.description: All of the coverage in Iraq is taken by a trekker with a camera similar to Gen 2 but with distinctly worse image quality and colour. This coverage tends to be overexposed, even becoming blindingly so at some points.
metas.note: This camera quality is sometimes referred to as Gen 1.5.

metas.title: Pointed Trekker Blur
metas.description: The trekker blur has a well-defined, pointed shape.

metas.title: Museum Patio (Outdoors)
metas.description:
The only piece of coverage outdoors is a small patio with a diagonal walkway. In this patio you can see many date palms.

This is the only piece of the coverage that can rarely appear on serious maps.

metas.title: Museum Interior
metas.description: The inside of the museum features statues, steles, a variety of artefacts, and a few back rooms.

metas.title: License Plates (Yellow/Blue)
metas.description: Israeli licence plates are yellow with a blue strip on the left.
metas.note: While this design is specific for Israel, it is also very common on the West Bank. Jordan and the UAE use white licence plates. Tunisia uses black plates.

metas.title: Gen 3 Car (Black Antenna)
metas.description:
Most Generation 3 coverage was taken by a black Street View car with a long antenna.

You may also see the black car without an antenna and a silver car with a short antenna.

metas.title: Languages (Hebrew/Arabic)
metas.description: You will typically find two languages; Hebrew, which is practically only found in Israel and the West Bank, and Arabic, which is particularly common in the West Bank.

metas.title: Landscape Overview
metas.description: The landscape ranges from a greener Mediterranean landscape in the north, to a very arid landscape in the south.

metas.title: Architecture (Stone/Blocky)
metas.description: Architecture tends to consist of bright and warm-coloured stone buildings, often with a blocky appearance. While Mediterranean-style houses with orange tiled roofs are more common than in other Middle Eastern countries, flat roofs are still just as common.

metas.title: Road Lines (Yellow Outer)
metas.description: Most roads feature yellow outer lines with white centre lines.

metas.title: Striped Kerbs
metas.description:
You will very often see striped kerbs: red and white and fairly commonly black and white.

Red and yellow and blue and white are also rarely found.

metas.title: Guardrails (A/B Type)
metas.description: Both A-type and B-type guardrails are common.
metas.note: The only other Middle Eastern country where B-type guardrails are common is Turkey.

metas.title: Chevrons (White/Black)
metas.description: Chevrons are white on black.

metas.title: Kilometer Markers
metas.description: Kilometre markers are white with a thick border, which can either be red, green or blue.

metas.title: Stop Signs (Hand)
metas.description: Rather than having a word meaning ‘stop’ written on them, stop signs have a hand painted on them.

metas.title: Striped Pole Bottoms
metas.description: Utility poles commonly feature these painted black and white striped bottoms.

metas.title: Mesh Poles
metas.description: Utility poles with a mesh framework are very common.

metas.title: Yellow Pole Warning Sign
metas.description: You can often find this yellow warning sign on poles.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
This is a coverage map over Israel and the West Bank. Notably, southern Israel and most of the West Bank has very sparse coverage.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Area Codes
metas.description: Here is a map of area codes in Israel and the West Bank. Note that only the phone codes featured on the map are regional.

metas.title: Gen 4 Map
metas.description:
Generation 4 coverage is only found in Israel, in the areas marked on the map.

The coverage was taken with a black Street View car.

metas.title: Gen 4 Dirty Camera
metas.description: Most of the Generation 4 coverage features a dirty front camera.

metas.title: Gen 4 Clean Camera
metas.description: Generation 4 coverage with a clean front camera is mostly found in and around Tel Aviv.

metas.title: North Landscape (Green/Hilly)
metas.description: Northern Israel is usually far more mountainous and green than the rest of Israel. Throughout the region you will almost always see forested hills and mountains.

metas.title: Central Landscape (Flat/Urban)
metas.description: Central Israel is usually flat and has several cities. Highways are usually in better condition than roads in the south and north.

metas.title: South Landscape (Dry/Sandy)
metas.description: Southern Israel and eastern West Bank are extremely dry and sandy.

metas.title: Jerusalem West Landscape
metas.description:
The area west of Jerusalem can often look deceptively similar to northern Israel, with green forested hills and some agriculture sprinkled across the landscape.

Two things can occasionally be used to tell the two apart. Firstly, in northern Israel you may occasionally see wide, flat valleys, while the Jerusalem area is always going to be hilly. Secondly, if you see houses made of Jerusalem stone, you are likely to be near Jerusalem.

metas.title: West Bank Landscape
metas.description: Most of the West Bank has a semi-arid Mediterranean landscape. It is generally greener than southern Israel, drier than northern Israel and west of Jerusalem, and hillier and less agricultural than central Israel.

metas.title: Jerusalem Stone Architecture
metas.description: In Jerusalem and surrounding cities in the West Bank, nearly every building is built with the same type of material, called Jerusalem stone. Beware that the stone will look much smoother on newer buildings.
metas.note: Single houses with the same material can be found in other towns and cities.

metas.title: Date Palm Plantations
metas.description: Date palm plantations can often be seen close to the Jordanian border.

metas.title: Cement Rock Walls
metas.description: Rock walls put together with cement are found in the north of Israel.

metas.title: Dead Sea
metas.description: The Dead Sea can easily be recognised by the dryness surrounding it.
metas.note: It is also visible from Jordan and the West Bank.

metas.title: Sea of Galilee
metas.description: Other than the Dead Sea and the Mediterranean Sea, the only major body of water is the Sea of Galilee. It is noticeably more vegetated than the Dead Sea, making it easily recognisable.

metas.title: Mount Carmel
metas.description:
Mount Carmel is a long mountain ridge, going northwest to southeast, near the city of Haifa. From the northeast, it can easily be recognised by its direction and size.

There is also a lot of coverage on top of the mountain range, which is generally fairly green and looks noticeably high altitude.

metas.title: Mount Gilboa
metas.description:
Mount Gilboa is a very dry looking mountain, which can be seen from far away and from many angles.

There is some coverage on top of the mountain, which is very green and often with a very good view over the surrounding valleys.

metas.title: Beit She’an Irrigation Canals
metas.description: You can find these small irrigation canals on the side of the road, in the area around the city of Beit She’an.

metas.title: West Bank License Plates
metas.description:
Licence plates in the West Bank are often white with green text, often giving blurred plates a slight green tint. On public transport vehicles, such as taxis and buses, the colours will be inverted; green with white text, making blurred plates almost completely green.

Beware that Israeli licence plates are also very common in most of the West Bank.

metas.title: Security Follow Car (White Suzuki)
metas.description: A significant portion of the coverage in the West Bank has a visible security follow car. The most extensive of these is a small white Suzuki, which is found in the central and southern regions.

metas.title: Security Follow Car (Blue Ford)
metas.description: Another follow car is a small dark blue Ford, which is found in the northwest.

metas.title: Security Follow Car (White Citroën)
metas.description: This larger white Citroën follow car with a West Bank licence plate can be found in a region surrounding Jerusalem. It is noticeably found in the cities of Bethlehem and Ramallah.
metas.note: The side of this car features the text “SECURITY” in a bold font. Furthermore, this coverage will always feature a black Street View car with no antenna.

metas.title: Road 90 (Dry/North-South)
metas.description:
Road 90 is the longest road in Israel, and can often be recognised by its dryness combined with the general north to south angle.

Be careful, as road 90 can sometimes look quite similar to roads 31 and 40.

metas.title: Road 90 South
metas.description: The southern stretch of road 90 will have a dry mountain range to the east. It is also common to see palm trees.

metas.title: Road 2 (Coast)
metas.description: Road 2 can usually be recognised by the Mediterranean sea being visible on the west side of the road.
metas.note: If you see mountains to the east, you will be somewhere between Haifa and Zikhron Yaakov.

metas.title: Mount Tavor
metas.description: Mount Tavor is located in the Northern District and can be recognised by its soft, round shape.

metas.title: Timna National Park
metas.description: Timna National park can be recognised by the complete dryness combined with the mountain ridges in all directions.

metas.title: Eilat Mountains
metas.description: These tall, rocky mountains can be found east of Eilat, making the city very easy to recognize.

metas.title: Kiryat Shmona Mountains
metas.description:
This mountain range, in the far north of Israel, can be recognised by its shape, somewhat resembling a camel's back.

As a bonus, if you are in a city and see these mountains to the west, you will be in Kiryat Shmona.

metas.title: Hasolelim Reservoir
metas.description: North of the Hasolelim forest reserve you can see this large reservoir.

metas.title: Tel Aviv Parking
metas.description: Finding parking in Tel Aviv is notoriously difficult, meaning the side of almost every road will be full of parked cars.
metas.note: If you are confident that you are in Tel Aviv and see available parking spots, you are more likely to be in the north of the city.

metas.title: Jerusalem Street Signs
metas.description: These white rectangular signs with a thin blue border are typically found in Jerusalem.

metas.title: Jericho
metas.description: Jericho can commonly be recognised by the date palms in a somewhat sparsely built and poor-looking urban setting.

metas.title: Ramallah Water Tanks
metas.description: In the city of Ramallah you will generally see several black water tanks on most houses.
metas.note: Several other cities in both the West Bank and Israel can have black water tanks. What makes Ramallah stand out is the sheer number of them on most buildings.

metas.title: Harish Mosaic Walls
metas.description: This grey mosaic brick work shaped like towers is unique to the city of Harish.

metas.title: Nahariya Lamps
metas.description: This white lamp is unique to Nahariya. It has three arms, with round light bulbs on top.

metas.title: Acre Lamps
metas.description: These lamps, shaped similarly to Barad Dûr, are unique to Acre. It can be found in several different colours.
metas.note: Similar looking lamps can be found around central Israel, however the gap between the two horns on top of the lamp should confirm Acre.

metas.title: Netivot Lamps
metas.description: These metal lamps, characterised by one high and one low lamp put together with a very angular look, are unique to Netivot.

metas.title: Eilat Blue/White Poles
metas.description: Poles with blue and white paint on the bottom are unique to Eilat.

metas.title: Kiryat Motzkin Yellow Fences
metas.description: These yellow fences and signposts are unique to Kiryat Motzkin.

metas.title: Ashdod Blue/White Fences
metas.description: This style of blue and white fence is very common to see in Ashdod.

metas.title: Bethlehem House Numbers
metas.description: Blue house numbers with the number written with Arabic numerals in the top left and with Eastern Arabic numerals in the bottom right, with a thin diagonal line between them, can be found in Bethlehem. Street signs will generally have the same format.

metas.title: Rosh Haayin House Numbers
metas.description: House numbers in Rosh Haayin are blue, with a G-clef in the bottom left corner.

metas.title: Ness Ziona House Numbers
metas.description: In Ness Ziona, There is an Israeli flag on house numbers.

metas.title: Herzliya House Numbers
metas.description: Blue, shield-shaped house numbers are unique to the city of Herzliya.

metas.title: Bnei Brak (Ultra-Orthodox)
metas.description: Bnei Brak is an ultra-Orthodox Jewish stronghold, which can be seen only by looking at the people around. There will usually be people wearing Jewish religious clothes.

metas.title: Raanana Roundabout Signs
metas.description: Roundabout signs which are either very thick or attached to a large cube, can be found in the city of Raanana.

metas.title: Netanya Chimneys
metas.description: These tall industrial chimneys, by the coast north of Netanya, are visible from far away.

metas.title: Rahat Grey Follow Car
metas.description: This grey Hyundai follow car is unique to Rahat.

metas.title: Israel National Trail
metas.description: The Israel National Trail goes through the entire country and has one of the longest trekkers in the world. The trail goes through more or less every landscape present in the country, from the rocky desert in the south to lush forests in the north. Along the trail you may find these markings, which will typically be orange, blue and white, but can also feature other colour schemes.

metas.title: Geography Terms
metas.description:
Japan consists of three main terms used to identify land, groupings and borders: Islands, Regions and Prefectures.

Islands: The four main islands that make up the country of Japan. From the top they are: Hokkaido, Honshu, Shikoku and Kyushu.

Regions: Some islands are further broken down into groupings of prefectures.

Prefectures: These form the currently 47 different subdivisions within the country.

Many of these names are used in this guide, on maps, and when referring to areas of Japan. Therefore, it is recommended to learn and become comfortable with each category, and the titles within.

metas.title: Low-Cam Car
metas.description:
The appearance of the standard Japanese Google car is often black and white. You may find it in black or rarely with an antenna.

In addition, due to privacy reasons, the camera is intentionally set lower to the ground. This is known as low-cam. You can identify it by:

Looking downwards. The blur will be noticeably larger.

The road will look wider, and objects will be viewed from a lower perspective.
metas.note: The only other country that always has low-cam is Switzerland. It can also be seen in Generation 4 coverage in Sri Lanka. Also, the car will be blurred in Switzerland.

metas.title: Driving Side (Left)
metas.description: Japan drives on the left hand side of the road.
metas.note: Hong Kong drives on the left hand side of the road, same as Japan. South Korea and Taiwan drive on the right hand side instead.

metas.title: Writing Systems (Kanji/Hiragana/Katakana)
metas.description:
Japanese is written with a mixture of three main systems: kanji and two syllabic scripts: hiragana and katakana. Formal signs and texts will mostly use kanji and hiragana. The kanji system is directly borrowed from Chinese and thus looks very similar, while the syllabic scripts are more loosely inspired by Chinese. Hiragana generally looks simpler than Chinese characters, many of the symbols have loops, which are not present in Chinese. The shapes are also typically slightly softer than the shapes present in most kanji.

You can learn more about hiragana, katakana and kanji in the region guessing section, learning frequent terms and names.

metas.title: Katakana
metas.description: Katakana is mainly used for loan words, and are thus common to find in commercials. They are generally quite simple, with a lot of geometrical shapes rather than the more artistic shapes present in hiragana and kanji.

metas.title: City/Prefecture Kanji (Cardinals)
metas.description:
On the left hand side you can find the pronunciation and meaning of eight of the most commonly featured kanji in town and city names. Learning to recognise these can make finding cities considerably easier.

On the right you see the shape and pronunciation of the cardinal directions and the shape of some kanji commonly found at the end of place names. If you see the kanji for prefecture or city, chances are you will be able to find it fairly quickly. Wards are typically findable granted you know the city, while towns are often fairly difficult to locate.
metas.note: Most of these kanji have alternative, less common pronunciations.

metas.title: Architecture Overview
metas.description:
Japanese architecture has many distinct and expressive styles, with many unique buildings. These can range from traditional country houses, regional designs, modern large cities, coastal reinforced buildings, and anything in between.

You can learn more about different types of architecture and styles in the region guessing section.

metas.title: Poles Overview
metas.description:
Japan mostly uses these round concrete poles, which have these screw-like extensions. Other information can often be found on or attached to the pole including:

Electrical plates.

Guy-wires.

Pole reflectors.

Therefore, they are a key asset in region guessing Japan.

You can learn more about plates, reflectors, and guy-wires in the region guessing section.

metas.title: Pole Reflectors (Vertical/Diagonal)
metas.description:
You can find a variety of pole reflectors in Japan. They are typically short and do not touch the ground. Common patterns found all across Japan include:

Yellow vertical stripes.

Yellow diagonal stripes.

Vertical or diagonal white stripes.
metas.note:
The Taiwanese variant has diagonal stripes that reach the ground. The South Korean ones have diagonal, thicker stripes.

You can learn more about the different regional reflectors in the region guessing section.

metas.title: License Plates (White/Yellow)
metas.description: Japan uses a standard short white licence plate with green text. You will often see a different short yellow version with black text issued to “light automobiles”, otherwise known as Kei Cars.

metas.title: Road Lines (White/Yellow)
metas.description:
Japan has three common variations of road lines. They are as follows:

The most common being white, solid outer lines with a dashed white middle line.

White solid sidelines with a yellow solid middle line.

White solid sidelines with yellow and white middle lines.

While you may find other, more rare combinations, Japan will never have yellow outside road lines.

metas.title: Bollards Overview
metas.description:
Japan usually uses simple white bollards with circular reflector(s) on the top. However, sometimes these bollards are black, or have other extensions. They can also have the city or prefecture written on it in kanji.

You can learn more about the bollards and kanji in the region guessing section.

metas.title: Guardrails Overview
metas.description:
Japan generally uses these simple, white guardrails.

You can learn more about the exceptions in the region guessing section.

metas.title: Prefecture Roads (Hexagons)
metas.description:
Prefecture roads are identified by their hexagonal-shaped shields. The prefecture is often written under the road number in kanji. While the shield design remains, other variations can be found:

On prefectural highway shields (with kanji).

On directional intersection signs.

Or on small, directional arrow signs.

As multiple prefectures can have the same road number, it is recommended to first find the prefecture you are in.

metas.title: Infrastructure (Stop Sign/Crossing/Mirrors)
metas.description:
Some frequently seen infrastructure in Japan consists of:

This unique stop sign.

A school pedestrian crossing.

And these traffic mirrors.

While many infrastructural clues exist, these three are very common, and may very well help you identify Japan on a difficult round.

metas.title: Retaining Walls
metas.description: Retaining walls can be an excellent clue for Japan in rural areas with little to no information.

metas.title: Area Codes
metas.description: Area codes are commonly found throughout the country and increase to the south.
metas.note: Area codes ending with a 0 are often not regional, most notably 0120.

metas.title: Pole Plates
metas.description: Every region in Japan features a distinct plate on their utility poles.

metas.title: Pole Reflector Pads (Regional)
metas.description: The pole reflector pads vary by region in Japan.

metas.title: Road Diamonds (Prefecture)
metas.description: You can narrow down the prefecture you are in based on the style of road diamond.

metas.title: Signpost Stickers
metas.description: Most Japanese prefectures have unique stickers you can find on their signposts.

metas.title: Guy Wires
metas.description: Most regions in Japan have unique guy wires.
metas.note: Only the most consistent ones are on this map.

metas.title: Chugoku Orange Arrow
metas.description: You may sometimes find an orange arrow located above the top most pole plate in Chugoku.

metas.title: Shikoku Orange/Black Bands
metas.description: These orange and black bands wrapped around poles can often be found in Shikoku.

metas.title: Kansai 120-Degree Attachment
metas.description: These attachments with an approximately 120-degree angle can commonly be found on poles in Kansai.
metas.note: Sometimes there is no angle, and instead just an angled downward attachment.

metas.title: Shikoku 90-Degree Attachment
metas.description: These smaller attachments with a 90-degree angle can commonly be found on poles in Shikoku.

metas.title: Hokkaido Transformers
metas.description:
The electrical poles in Hokkaido either have this plus-shaped bar attached to the side of the pole, or one transformer mounted on two bars.

However, if there is more than one transformer, they will often be mounted on the sides of a square.
metas.note: While the Kanto transformer may also be mounted on two bars, Hokkaido will never have a wooden plate.

metas.title: Tohoku Transformers
metas.description:
The transformers in Tohoku, which often have additional square holding brackets and the logo of the Tohoku Electrical Company, are sometimes mounted on a round plate with a zigzag bar.

Furthermore, you may also find transformers mounted on the side of a square, with a straight bar mounted on the top of the square. Rarely, you may find a square without a bar.
metas.note: While Kansai may have a square attachment as well, the bar will be mounted on the bottom rather than the top.

metas.title: Kanto Transformers
metas.description: The transformers in Kanto, which can have three or two insulators, are often mounted on a wooden plate and two bars, or a round plate and a T-shaped bar.
metas.note: While the Hokkaido transformer may also be mounted on two bars, it will never have a wooden plate. Kanto ones can also be mounted without a wooden plate.

metas.title: Hokuriku Transformers
metas.description: The transformers in Hokuriku, which are attached with thin metal bars, often have these small “lamp” shaped insulators. There will never be a bar present except for the attachment mentioned above.
metas.note: The prefecture of Niigata will have the Tohoku transformer design, as opposed to Hokuriku one.

metas.title: Chubu Transformers
metas.description: The transformers in Chubu, which often have painted yellow numbers and black “tap” connectors, are either attached with large triangle and horizontal bars, or these thin metal brackets.

metas.title: Kansai Transformers
metas.description:
The transformers in Kansai have either a straight or zigzag bar mounted on the bottom of a square. The transformer(s) will be mounted on the sides of that same square.

While this is uncommon, the bar and transformer(s) may be mounted on a vertical bar, rather than a square.
metas.note: While Tohoku may have a square attachment as well, the bar will be mounted on the top rather than the bottom.

metas.title: Chugoku Transformers
metas.description:
The transformers in Chugoku, which have a cross-shaped bar attached in the middle of the pole, mounted by a full triangle, will have a long horizontal or short vertical insulator(s) at the end.

A white sticker will often be stuck to the bottom of the transformer with red numbers. They may also be painted on the side.

metas.title: Shikoku Transformers
metas.description:
The transformers in Shikoku, which also have a cross-shaped bar attached in the middle of the pole, mounted by a half triangle, will have “hat shaped” short horizontal insulators at the end.

A white sticker will often be stuck to the bottom of the transformer with black numbers.

metas.title: Kyushu Transformers
metas.description: The transformers in Kyushu, which have a straight bar attached on the side of the pole with three insulators at the end, will have transformers mounted 180-degrees from one another.

metas.title: Okinawa Transformers
metas.description: Transformers in Okinawa, which have a T-shaped bar attached on the side of the pole, will have transformers mounted on opposite sides of the pole.

metas.title: Grey Insulator Blocks
metas.description: These grey “insulator-esque” blocks, which wires are fed through, can be found in the regions of Chubu, Kansai, Chugoku, Shikoku, and very rarely in Hokkaido.

metas.title: Chubu Pole Top
metas.description: This pole top, with four thicker bars and a circle piece at the top, is common in the Chubu region.

metas.title: Hokuriku Pole Top (Tent)
metas.description: This pole top, with two sides filled in and shaped like a tent, is common in the Hokuriku region.

metas.title: Chugoku Pole Top (Skinny Bars)
metas.description: This pole top, with four thin, skinny bars, is common in the Chugoku region.

metas.title: Kanto Tuning Fork
metas.description: This tuning fork pole top, with a long top bar that sticks out each end and horizontal bar(s) below, is found the majority of the time in the Kanto region.

metas.title: Chubu Tuning Fork
metas.description: This tuning fork pole top, with a short top bar and horizontal bar below, is found the majority of the time in the Chubu region.

metas.title: Kansai Tuning Fork
metas.description: This tuning fork pole top, with a thin wire and horizontal bar below, is common in the Kansai region.

metas.title: Hokkaido Snow Arrows
metas.description: This infrastructural arrow informs drivers of where the shoulder line is when under snow, and is located almost exclusively in Hokkaido.
metas.note:
While much more rare, other variations can be found here:

This arrow, found in the Aomori prefecture (or more rarely Hokkaido), has distinct silver bolts around the border.

This variation, found in the Gifu prefecture, is long and thin.

This alternate yellow and black design can often be found on the northern part of National Highway 275 in Hokkaido.

This yellow and green arrow is found southwest of Sapporo.

This yellow and black arrow can be found on Hokkaido.

metas.title: Kyushu Flat Bollard
metas.description: This flat, white bollard, found on the island of Kyushu and in Yamaguchi Prefecture, will have a series of separated orange reflectors on one side, and the same white on the opposite.
metas.note: Rarely, you may find similar bollards in Hokkaido. However, both sides will have orange reflectors.

metas.title: Shikoku Black Stripe Bollard
metas.description: Some bollards on the island of Shikoku can have a black stripe just under the reflector. They can be found normally, attached to guardrails or walls.

metas.title: Tohoku Thick Bollard
metas.description:
This thick, white bollard, found in the Tohoku region, will have an octagonal reflector, and yellow stripe just underneath. In addition, you can find the same bollard, but with a rectangular top.

Finally, there are two other variations. You can find a black octagonal, and rectangular version. They are often found on National Highways or Expressways and can have the number printed on them.

metas.title: Akita Two-Stripe Bollard
metas.description: This bollard, much like Tohoku, will be a thick, white bollard with an octagonal reflector. However, this Akita prefecture variation will have two yellow stripes underneath the reflector.

metas.title: Toyama Red Stripe Bollard
metas.description: The Toyama prefecture bollard has one reflector, is extendable and has a red stripe underneath the reflector.
metas.note: Be careful: if there is either a second reflector, or a yellow stripe instead of a red one, these are different bollards. These are more common variations found across many prefectures.

metas.title: Okayama Red Stripe Bollard
metas.description: This bollard, with an octagonal reflector, and red stripe underneath it, is exclusive to the Okayama prefecture. Additionally, there will be a sloped connection where the base meets the reflector.

metas.title: Aomori Yellow Stripe Bollard
metas.description: This bollard, found in the Aomori prefecture, has two yellow stripes, a single circular reflector, and is extendable. Sometimes, only one thicker stripe near the top may be present.

metas.title: Akita Striped Bollard (Cover)
metas.description: These striped bollards (which cover over the original) have a thinner top half, and no reflectors, and are common to the Tohoku region. They are especially common in Akita prefecture.

metas.title: Chugoku Snow Poles
metas.description: In the northern parts of the Chugoku region, you can primarily find these basic snow poles, with either a thin extended, or thin contracted top. They can also sometimes be found in Iwate.

metas.title: Kyushu Green Guardrails
metas.description: Green bands on guardrails are most commonly found in Oita and Miyazaki, but can be found on all of Kyushu.

metas.title: Yamaguchi Yellow Guardrails
metas.description: These distinctive yellow guardrails can be found in the Yamaguchi Prefecture.

metas.title: Hokkaido Guardrail Stickers
metas.description:
You can find these chevron-like stickers, or more rarely orange ones, on guardrails in Hokkaido.

On the end or side of a guardrail.

Stuck to metal posts between wire fences, which are often found in Hokkaido.

On railings, which are often found on bridges, underneath the inside of the railing.

metas.title: Chugoku Guardrail Endings
metas.description: Guardrail endings with these red and yellow striped stickers can commonly be found across Chugoku, except in Yamaguchi. They can also rarely be found in Niigata.

metas.title: Vertical Traffic Lights
metas.description: Vertical traffic lights can be found in Hokkaido, and along the northwestern coast. The usual horizontal traffic lights can be found everywhere else.

metas.title: Kagawa Black Signs
metas.description: These specific black signs with two yellow circles are found in Kagawa. Other variations can be seen, including them stacked on top of each other, or with an arrow attached above.

metas.title: Kerosine Tanks (Claymores)
metas.description: Kerosine tanks, otherwise known as “Claymores”, can be found more commonly the further north you go. They are abundant in Hokkaido, but can be found in prefectures south of it, or in high elevation mountainous areas.

metas.title: Gas/Propane Tanks
metas.description:
Hot water, gas and propane tanks can be found more frequently in northern prefectures or high elevation mountainous areas. Here are a few common variations you can find:

The standard hot water tank.

Covered propane tanks.

Exposed propane tanks.

These cylindrical tanks.

And finally, these circular tripod tanks.

Moreover, these are even more common in rural towns or villages, where major water or gas lines are unavailable.

metas.title: Snow Prevention Roads (Shosetsu)
metas.description: Snow prevention roads, known as ‘Shosetsu’, are found mainly in northwest coastal prefectures. They appear as tiny circles in the pavement, and spray warm underground water to clear snow.

metas.title: Ehime Cycling Routes
metas.description:
Cycling routes in Ehime use an outside white, with an inside blue line. They are more commonly found along the coast but may be found further inland too.

While exceptions do exist, and can be found in other prefectures, they are the extreme minority.

metas.title: Chugoku Red Tiled Roofs
metas.description: These unique red-tiled roofs are most commonly found in Chugoku, especially in the prefectures of Hiroshima and Shimane.

metas.title: Northern Roofs (Snow/Ladders)
metas.description: The further you are north, roofs generally transition from tiled to level or flat sloped in order to compensate for heavy snowfall. Northern houses often have ladders attached to the side, giving roof access to clear snow.
metas.note: In addition to north to south, high-elevation mountainous regions or high snowfall areas often use such roofs, even in more central or southern prefectures.

metas.title: Okinawa Flat Roofs
metas.description: Okinawa can often be recognised by the white concrete buildings with flat roofs.

metas.title: Giant Butterbur (Hokkaido)
metas.description: Giant butterbur (commonly referred to as cabbage) is abundant in Hokkaido and some northern prefectures. Plants found south of Hokkaido often have smaller leaves. It is often found growing along the roadside.
metas.note: Cabbage is also found on the island of Sakhalin, Russia. However, the Google car will not have low-cam there.

metas.title: Green Tea Plantations
metas.description:
Green tea plants are often grown in hedged rows. You will often see these fans mounted on poles, which serve the purpose of preventing frost from falling on the plants.

The prefectures of Shizuoka (36%) and Kagoshima (34%) make up the majority of the production, with Mie (7%), Miyazaki (4%), and other prefectures (17%) making up the minority.

metas.title: Rice Paddies
metas.description:
Rice is mainly produced north of Tokyo. During growth, it resembles straws of grass. And when ready for harvest, brown husks are visible. They are also commonly planted in beds of water.

The regions of Chubu (21%), Kanto (15%), Tohoku (27%), and Hokkaido (7%) make up the majority of production.

metas.title: Japanese White Birch
metas.description: Japanese White Birch grows dominantly in the Chubu and Hokkaido regions, and to a lesser extent in Tohoku. Small areas of white birch can be found throughout Japan, so use this information primarily to help assist your region guess.
metas.note: Japanese Beech is another species of tree found in Japan. They, however, have more grey and spotted bark, as opposed to the mostly white Japanese White Birch.

metas.title: Bamboo
metas.description: In general, bamboo grows more often in the south, and slowly decreases further north. Population size and areas where it grows can vary, so use this information primarily in helping assist your region guess.

metas.title: Kyushu Grass (Silver Grass)
metas.description: Chinese Silver Grass, referred to as Kyushu grass, is indeed very abundant on the island of Kyushu. However, use this tip with caution, as they can be seen outside of this area.
metas.note: Another notable region they can be found in is the prefectures of Niigata, Yamagata and Akita. Though, combining the rather large quantity found on Kyushu, its normally distinct vegetation, along with other information, there often will be a clear distinction.

metas.title: Sugarcane (South)
metas.description: Sugarcane is almost exclusively found on the islands in southern Kyushu and Okinawa.

metas.title: Hokkaido Winter Coverage
metas.description: Hokkaido has very limited winter and snow coverage. Unless you are certain, it is often better not to guess this prefecture. Though, if you do find yourself in Hokkaido, these regions are most likely. Other low amounts of miscellaneous coverage is primarily in the southern half of the island.

metas.title: Flat Plains (Kanto/Nobi)
metas.description: Japan is notably a very mountainous country. However, there are some regions that are quite flat, being the Nobi and Kanto plains. While at times they can look very similar, determining that it is one or the other can be very helpful.
metas.note: While there are, of course, other flat areas in Japan, these two are the most recognizable.

metas.title: Shisa Lions/Plaques (Okinawa)
metas.description: You can find these ‘Shisa’ guardian lions and house plaques with these specific characters in Okinawa. The colour and shapes of both can vary.

metas.title: Red Soil Fields (Miyakojima/Ishigaki)
metas.description: Agricultural fields with red soil are commonly found on several southern islands, most notably on the islands of Miyakojima and Ishigaki in southern Okinawa.

metas.title: Mount Fuji
metas.description:
Mount Fuji is the tallest mountain in Japan, with a gradual incline and often snowy summit.

Depending on the elevation, it can be seen from far away. This can create some excellent region guesses, especially if you account for direction and distance.

metas.title: Tokyo Manhole Cover
metas.description: Tokyo City features a nice manhole design, with a 5 petal flower and many small circles on the outside.

metas.title: Cyrillic Signs (Hokkaido)
metas.description: Cyrillic can be found on signs in the cities of Wakkanai and Nemuro, in northern Hokkaido.

metas.title: Date Birch Poles
metas.description: These artistically painted poles, made to resemble birch trees, are unique to the city of Date in Hokkaido.

metas.title: Trekkers Overview
metas.description:
There are a variety of trekkers and tripods, covering a vast amount of locations which span over multiple prefectures and regions.

Due to the enormous volume of information on this topic, and it being too large to be contained in this guide, we recommend this resource to learn more about the various trekkers.

metas.title: Google Car (Black/No Brake Light)
metas.description: Coverage in Jordan was taken by a black Google car, without a red brake light.
metas.note: Jordan is the only Middle Eastern country where a black Google car without an antenna or a red brake light can be found.

metas.title: License Plates (White/Commercial Green)
metas.description: Jordanian licence plates are white and can be long or short. Commercial transport vehicles, such as taxis, have a distinctive green strip on the left.
metas.note:
In the Middle East, the green strip is only found in Jordan.

The UAE also uses long white plates. Israel however only uses yellow licence plates. In Palestine, both white domestic and yellow Israeli plates are common.

metas.title: Language (Arabic)
metas.description: The official language used in Jordan is Arabic and can be identified by its lines and dots.
metas.note: Unlike the UAE, Jordan does not have English writing on most commercial signs. This can be helpful to distinguish the two countries.

metas.title: Road Lines (Yellow/White)
metas.description: Roads in Jordan typically feature yellow outside and white middle lines.
metas.note: Other Middle Eastern countries such as the UAE and Israel can also have these road lines. Make sure to check other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Chevrons (White/Red)
metas.description: Jordanian chevrons are white with red arrows.
metas.note: You can use chevrons to distinguish between Jordan and Israel: the Israeli chevrons are black with white arrows.

metas.title: Electricity Poles Overview
metas.description: These are three common electricity poles that you will find in Jordan. Rounded concrete poles have either a diagonal support or consist of three horizontal Y pole tops. You may additionally see thin, two support metal poles with three vertical coils.

metas.title: Landscape Overview (Arid)
metas.description: Jordan is a very arid country, with limited vegetation and a lot of almost completely lifeless desert. The lushest parts will still only have the look of an arid Mediterranean landscape.

metas.title: Architecture (Sandstone Bricks)
metas.description: Most buildings in Jordan are made of bright sandstone bricks and have flat roofs.
metas.note: Similar sandstone bricks are also common in Jerusalem and in the West Bank.

metas.title: Road Quality (Cracks)
metas.description: On occasion, the road quality in Jordan is reflective of its age. Roads are well travelled and can be in poor condition. The heat has caused the asphalt to buckle, creating warped cracks in the road.
metas.note: In general, the road quality as a whole tends to be worse than Israel.

metas.title: Coverage Map (Western Jordan)
