metas.description: Jordan only has Street View coverage in the far western part of the country. Coverage is limited to bigger towns and main roads in this area.
metas.note: Coverage ends just north of Jerash. Even though Irbid is the second largest city of Jordan, it has zero official coverage. In the south, coverage extends all the way to the coastal town of Aqaba, but not south of it.

metas.title: Amman Overview
metas.description: Amman is by far the largest city in Jordan with extensive coverage. It is a bustling, developed metropolis with a distinct “big city” feel to it. It is slightly hilly and most of the city consists of medium-sized apartment blocks.

metas.title: Highway 15 (Desert Landscape)
metas.description: Highway 15 is the longest divided highway with coverage in Jordan. Most of the road is surrounded by desert landscape. It is also surrounded by rocky hills in the south closer to Aqaba.
metas.note: Highway 35 north of Madaba and highway 40 west of Amman are also divided but do not feature a desert landscape, while the divided highway 80 in the south runs mainly from east to west, making it distinguishable.

metas.title: Highway 35 (Hills/Vegetation)
metas.description: Highway 35 connecting Amman and Jerash is a divided road surrounded by hills speckled with green vegetation.
metas.note: Highway 40 west of Amman is also divided and features a similar landscape. However, the T-shaped lamppost shown in the image is only found on highway 35 which helps distinguish the two.

metas.title: Highway 40 (Low Green Shrubbery)
metas.description: Highway 40 is a recognisable divided road surrounded by low, green shrubbery that makes its way west of Amman through the hilly terrain into the sandy area close to the Dead Sea.
metas.note: Y-shaped lamp posts as shown in the image can be found along the length of highway 40, making it distinguishable from highway 35 north of Amman.

metas.title: Dead Sea Highway 65 North
metas.description: The Dead Sea can be found directly west along the northern portion of Highway 65.
metas.note: There is a long, flat, expansive ridge on the other side, which is useful to differentiate this from other bodies of water.

metas.title: Highway 65 South (Sandy)
metas.description: Highway 65 is a single lane, north to south highway. It features long, sandy stretches of road south of Feifa valley. Now and then, you may encounter overcast coverage on some sections.
metas.note: When on the portion of road near the airport by Aqaba, you can find sunset coverage.

metas.title: Madaba Red Soil Fields
metas.description: Near and in the city of Madaba, you will find flat fields which are sometimes tilled. They uniquely have the characteristic of rich, red soil.
metas.note: The fields continue both north and south of Madaba, along Highway 35.

metas.title: Wadi al Hasa Valleys
metas.description: This arid rolling hill valley is located near the almost dried out river of Wadi al Hasa on Highway 35. The rock is rounded and smooth, with a single lane highway running through the center.

metas.title: Highway 80 (Rigid Mountains)
metas.description: For a large majority of Highway 80 and its turns, this divided valley road is surrounded by large, rigid mountains. When turning onto the stretch of road leading to Aqaba, the mountains level off.
metas.note: The road direction of Highway 80 is east to west, as opposed to Highway 15, which runs north to south.

metas.title: Aqaba Mountains
metas.description: This long stretch of jagged mountains can be found on the eastern to southern side of Aqaba.

metas.title: Amman Taxis (Yellow/Green)
metas.description: In Amman, taxis are yellow and green.
metas.note: The colours of taxis can be useful to distinguish between Jordanian cities.

metas.title: Aqaba Taxis (Green/Black)
metas.description: In Aqaba, taxis are olive green on the top and black at the bottom.

metas.title: Madaba Taxis (Yellow/White)
metas.description: In Madaba, taxis are yellow with white bumpers.

metas.title: Wadi Musa Bulbous Rocks
metas.description: In some parts of the town of Wadi Musa, unique mountains with distinctive, bulbous rock formations can be seen in the background.

metas.title: Petra Trekker
metas.description: West of the town of Wadi Musa, a collection of trekkers can be found in and around Petra, a rock-cut city from antiquity. This trekker coverage features highly eroded reddish rocks, narrow gorges, and occasionally groups of tourists crowding around the archaeological sites.
metas.note: While not likely to appear in competitive or pinpointable maps, these trekkers are a mainstay in many maps, including the default World map.

metas.title: White-Blue Plates
metas.description: When blurred, the standard Kazakh licence plates are mostly white, with a small hint of blue on the left side.

metas.title: Dual Script Alphabet
metas.description:
Kazakhstan uses both Cyrillic and Latin alphabets.

Though sometimes, Russian is used monolingually.

The following letters are found in the Kazakh but not Russian alphabet: Ә (Ä), Ғ (Ǵ), Қ (Q), Ң (Ń), Ө (Ö), Ұ (W), Ү (Ü), Һ (H), І (I).

Kazakh is related to Turkish, so the Latin text can appear similar.

metas.title: White Pickup Meta
metas.description: All of the coverage in Kazakhstan was taken with a white pickup truck, which can either be fully visible or mostly blurred.

metas.title: Birch Forests
metas.description:
Kazakhstan is a big and diverse country, which features a plethora of distinct landscapes like deserts, grassy steppes, mountain passes, and birch forests.

Most strikingly, most of the rural coverage in Kazakhstan is in a very empty, open and mostly flat landscape.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: A lot of Kazakh infrastructure, from pedestrian signs, poles, houses, to bollards, is very similar to what you see in Russia.

metas.title: Striped Crosswalks
metas.description: Like Russia, Kazakhstan uses yellow and white stripes on their pedestrian crossings. However, unlike Russia the stripes often have white dashes on either side. Sometimes, you can find the dashes without the stripes.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description: Street Signs in Kazakhstan are often attached to buildings and are blue in colour, with white intricate patterns on the top and bottom. They are usually bilingual or trilingual and can also contain a QR code.
metas.note: They are often inconsistent, with many designs being found in a single city.

metas.title: Angled Bollards
metas.description: Kazakhstan uses a variety of post-Soviet style bollards, as well as ones that resemble Turkish bollards. Notably, the bollards seemingly consisting of two thin bollards attached at a 90° angle are unique to Kazakhstan.

metas.title: White-Painted Trees
metas.description: The bottom of tree trunks are very often painted white.
metas.note: This is common in several eastern European countries, as well as in parts of Russia.

metas.title: Yellow-Black Chevrons
metas.description: Unlike neighbouring countries, Kazakhstan primarily uses yellow and black chevrons, except on T Intersections, where you will find the more generic red and white chevrons.

metas.title: Urban Gas Pipes
metas.description: Gas pipes are extremely common in Kazakh cities.

metas.title: Koshkar-Muiz Pattern
metas.description: This ornamental pattern known as the koshkar-muiz can be found as part of decorations in all kinds of settings in Kazakhstan.

metas.title: Town Entrance Arcs
metas.description: Many cities and towns in Kazakhstan have these entrance arcs, which are often quite intricate and ornate.

metas.title: Limited Coverage Map
metas.description: Coverage in Kazakhstan is fairly limited. While most major roads and cities are covered, coverage on small rural roads is fairly uncommon. As such, knowing which roads have coverage can help narrow down the guess.

metas.title: Seasonal Coverage
metas.description:
Kazakhstan can easily be divided into coverage regions based on the season.

Summer in western and central Kazakhstan.

Autumn in the northeast.

Winter in the southeast.

metas.title: Driving Directions
metas.description: Driving directions can help you narrow down your options when you are on a rural road.

metas.title: Area Code Map
metas.description: Kazakh area codes are useful to learn, and they generally follow an east to west pattern along three horizontal lines.

metas.title: Plate Region Codes
metas.description: You can occasionally spot licence plate codes on the back of trucks and buses. The codes themselves follow an alphabetical order, with smaller numbers corresponding to regions that start with earlier letters. Note that cars do travel, and as such not all codes are reliable. Buses and smaller utility vehicles are the most reliable.

metas.title: QR Code Signs
metas.description: While rarely possible, being able to read the letters under a QR code on a street sign will give you the region.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description:
Kazakhstan is a generally flat country, so getting locations that are hilly or mountainous are useful for narrowing the options.

For example, the region around Karaganda is often either quite hilly, or you can see hills in the distance.

Another notable set of hills would be the ones around Aktobe.

And of course getting bigger mountains will mean you are in the south, or east.

metas.title: Birch Forests
metas.description: These lush birch forests next to green fields are common in northern Kazakhstan.
metas.note: This landscape often appears very similar to that found in and around Omsk Oblast in Russia.

metas.title: Grassy Plains
metas.description: Vast grassy green plains are found in northwestern Kazakhstan. They are especially common in Akmola and Kostanay regions.

metas.title: Sandy Desert
metas.description: Sandy and shrubby desert-like landscapes are common in southwestern Kazakhstan.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: Tall mountains, which are often snow-capped, can be seen in southeastern Kazakhstan.

metas.title: Hazy Mountains
metas.description: The East Kazakhstan Region is hilly and forested. It was covered in october, so you will see fall colours on the vegetation. The town of Ridder itself is flat, but surrounded by hazy mountains.

metas.title: Snow Coverage
metas.description: Snow coverage can be found in southeastern Kazakhstan, especially east of Almaty.

metas.title: Rolling Hills
metas.description: The landscape in southern Kazakhstan near Uzbekistan is hilly and quite dry and shrubby, with a lot of orange looking grass. The landscape consists of dry but grassy rolling hills or dead flat agricultural land near Zhetisay.
metas.note: These red and white KM markers that look like Kyrgyz ones, are only found near Zhetisay.

metas.title: Rolling Hills
metas.description: Grassy green rolling hills can be found in southern Kazakhstan. They are especially common just north of Bishkek.

metas.title: Pine Forests
metas.description: Around Semey, you can find small clusters or entire forests consisting mostly of pine trees and some deciduous trees, which will have fall colours.

metas.title: Driving Directions
metas.description:
The divided section of the E38 goes southeast to northwest from Shymkent to Kyzylorda. The road is made of asphalt, and it has all white road lines. The landscape varies quite a lot; in the south, it is very green and in the north, it gets dry, sandy, and shrubby.

Driving direction: Both ways

metas.title: Driving Directions
metas.description:
The section of the M36 going from Karaganda to Almaty can often be recognised by the road being under construction, with a second lane being built. Yellow lines are common. As for the landscape, it’s a wintery dry steppe, which looks noticeably orange-brown.

Driving direction: South from Karaganda.

metas.title: Driving Directions
metas.description:
Between Karaganda and Astana, the M36 is now a divided highway, with yellow outer lines. The landscape consists of a grassy, sometimes hilly, steppe with an occasional row of trees along the road. Note that the general southeast to northwest road angle is important.

Driving direction: Both ways

metas.title: Driving Directions
metas.description:
The P4/A17 from Astana to Pavlodar is a divided road, generally going east to west, through a hilly steppe landscape similar to the M36, but is generally less vegetated. Most of the road has outer yellow lines.

Driving direction: Both ways

metas.title: Driving Directions
metas.description:
The roads from Kyzylagash to Druzhba feature a unique hilly landscape, which looks hazy and dead. On most sections, you will see small mountains either south or east of the road.

Driving direction: East from Kyzylagash.

metas.title: Driving Directions
metas.description:
The A26 goes from Kandyagash to the intersection of M32/E38.

It has very bad road quality throughout, ranging from poor grainy pavement, to completely unpaved. Apart from the northernmost section, the weather is either cloudy or overcast.

The landscape consists mostly of flat, semi-arid grassy plains.

Driving direction: North towards Kandyagash. (Mostly)

metas.title: Driving Directions
metas.description:
The section of the A1 going from Astana to Shchuchinsk is a 6-lane divided highway. The landscape around is generally quite green, with trees and grassy plains or hills.

Driving direction: Both ways

metas.title: Green Steppes
metas.description:
The A17 going to Ulytau Region can be recognised by the bad pavement quality, where the edges of the road are almost crumbling away, along with the single white middle road line, which can be dashed or solid. The landscape itself is a grassy steppe, with some fall coloured trees occasionally lining the roads.

West of Atasu, the sun is distinctly low on the horizon.
metas.note:
A small section east of Atasu has pristine new pavement, which has a slight red tint to it.

Driving direction: Towards Atasu from both directions

metas.title: Driving Directions
metas.description:
The road north of Zhezqazghan has no road lines. The landscape is very dry, desolate, with very limited vegetation and slightly hilly. The soil can look very red or orange at times.

The weather is sunny, with a lot of cumulus clouds.

Driving directions: North from Nikolskiy

metas.title: Driving Directions
metas.description:
The R260 road is mostly paved, but not in the best condition; many cracks can be seen, and it mostly lacks road lines. The weather is overcast and the landscape is a slightly hilly steppe, consisting of somewhat yellow grass and reddish soil, which is very evident when the road is unpaved.

The R217 is very similar, but the road is in better condition and mostly has very faded dashed white middle road lines, which are often quite difficult to see. The further east you go, the more sparse the cloud cover gets.

Driving directions: South from Atbasar

metas.title: Painted Poles
metas.description:
These regions/cities have the most useful pole paints you can learn.

The descriptions will be written from top to bottom:

West Kazakhstan Region uses red, white, and black paint.

Atyrau Region uses blue, white, and black paint.

Akmola region has a very thin layer of red, then white, and a thin layer of black on the bottom.

Kostanay uses a thin layer of turqoise, and yellow.

Petropavl has a thin layer of white, and light grey.

Taraz has red, yellow, and black.

Kyzylorda poles have a thin layer of yellow and red, then white.

Kyzylorda lamp posts are white, and have turquoise on the bottom.

metas.title: Painted Poles
metas.description:
These pole paints are less useful than the above hint, but still worth learning if you want to master Kazakhstan.

The descriptions will be written from top to bottom:

Rudny has red, yellow, red on the top, with white below it.

Kokshetau uses a few designs, but they all have light blue on the bottom, and sometimes, a thin strip, or two, of yellow on top.

Shchuchinsk has a thin layer of red, and yellow.

Ekibastuz has a thin layer of blue, and white

Shymkent poles have a thin layer of yellow and red, then green.

Kentau poles have thin layers of blue, yellow, and red, then blue and black below them.

metas.title: Bus Stop Designs
metas.description:
These are the most useful to learn bus stops.

Atyrau has a modern design, with white and lime/neon green walls. The bus stop name is prominently written on top.

Kostanay uses simple brown bus stops, that have a blue and yellow crest on one of the glass panes.

Petropavl also has brown bus stops, with glass panes on all 3 sides not facing the road. The roof is angled slightly upwards.

Karaganda uses old looking turquoise bus stops, which have a curved roof.

Zhezqazghan has very wide blue bus stops, which have 2 sections; 1 indoors, and one outside. These sections are separated by a door.

metas.title: Bus Stop Designs
metas.description:
These cities have buses worth learning.

Aktobe uses orange and black buses.

Zhezqazghan has orange and white buses, with “Men ♥ Jezz/Zhez” written on the sides.

Astana commonly uses these white, black, and green electric buses.

Karaganda uses turquoise buses, just like their bus stops.

Semey has these light green and white buses.

Almaty uses fully green buses, with white patterns and the city name on the sides. Taraz can use similar buses, but they will have “Taraz” written on the sides instead.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description:
These street signs attached to buildings are generally quite inconsistent, but there are some worth knowing.

Aktobe has compact signs where half of the space is taken by the QR code.

Petropavl uses white signs, with a blue semicircle below the street names.

Astana consistently uses this fairly generic design.

Zhetisay also uses a fairly generic design, but it is not found in Turkistan or Shymkent.

metas.title: Yellow Gas Boxes
metas.description: Yellow boxes connected to the gas pipes are common outside houses in Shymkent, Turkistan, and Taldykorgan.

metas.title: Grey Street Lamps
metas.description: Turkistan consistently uses these thin grey lamps with two small light sources near the end.

metas.title: Blue Photocell Lamps
metas.description: Lamps in Kulsary have a sizable blue photocell on the top.

metas.title: Triple Lamp Design
metas.description: Some lamps in Uralsk have this very unique design, with 3 separate lamps in an ascending pattern.

metas.title: Visible Wire Meta
metas.description: A visible wire in the back of the Street View car can be found in all of western Kazakhstan.

metas.title: Roof Dot Meta
metas.description: This combination of 3 dots; 2 of which are close together near the back of the roof, and a third one above to the left, can be found in the coverage north of Zhezqazghan, but not in the city itself.

metas.title: Around Kyzylorda There
metas.description: Around Kyzylorda, there is another combination of 3 dots; one on the bottom right, and 2 dots side by side, closer to the middle.

metas.title: Zigzag Smudge Meta
metas.description: On the P24 between Oskemen and Semey, as well as in both cities, you can spot this “zigzag” shaped smudge on the left side of the car.
metas.note: The smudge is highlighted in the image, and will not appear pink on street view.

metas.title: Dirty Roof Meta
metas.description: In the highlighted coverage east of Almaty, the back of the roof is very dirty.
metas.note: Similar dirty cars can be found in some nearby cities.

metas.title: Roof Smudge Meta
metas.description: Between Petropavl and Kokshetau, there is a small smudge slightly to the left on the bottom of the roof.

metas.title: Dusty Roof Meta
metas.description: Between Kokshetau and Atbasar, the car has a thin coating of dirt and dust, which is most visible near the back of the roof.

metas.title: Dirt Line Meta
metas.description: East of Aktobe, there is a vertical line of dirt on the right side of the roof.

metas.title: Roof Dot Meta
metas.description: South of Beyneu, there is a faint dot on the middle-right of the roof.
metas.note: This dot along with other smudges can be found in some nearby cities.

metas.title: Pine Forests
metas.description: Coverage in dense baltic pine forests can be found north of Shchuchinsk, which is north of Astana.
metas.note: Baltic pines can be found in other parts of the country.

metas.title: Forest Fire Haze
metas.description: Parts of Oskemen have hazy forest fire coverage.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: In southern Almaty City, there is snow coverage in the mountains.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: The Altyn Emel National Park is a barren grassland with snowy mountains in all directions. Some parts are very snowy. And in the eastern section, there is a small curvy mountain pass.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The only May coverage in Kazakhstan is found in the Almaty exclave of Alataou, which is east of Almaty proper. All of the coverage is sunny and the mountains are visible to the south.

metas.title: Small Ridge Hills
metas.description: A small ridge of hills is visible to the north in a lot of Taldykorgan coverage.

metas.title: Sandy Desert
metas.description: Near the Turkmenistan border in southwest Kazakhstan, you will find this unpaved sandy desert road. The landscape is almost blindingly bright from the sand.

metas.title: Red Strip Plates
metas.description: Licence plates in Kyrgyzstan have a red strip on them.
metas.note: Licence plates with red strips can sometimes be seen in Albania and very rarely in the UAE.

metas.title: Gen 3 Silver Car
metas.description: Kyrgyzstan can be recognised from the silver car and four bars that are visible. All coverage is Generation 3.
metas.note: No other country with a similar landscape has a similar Street View car.

metas.title: Cyrillic Script
metas.description:
The Kyrgyz script is similar to Russian. However, the Cyrillic script used for Kyrgyz includes additional characters not found in Russian Cyrillic, such as:

Ө

Ү

Ң

metas.title: Winter Coverage
metas.description: All of Kyrgyzstan was covered during the winter months, so many of the trees will lack leaves, the landscape will be quite drab, and you can see snow in many parts of Kyrgyzstan.

metas.title: White Bottom Poles
metas.description: In Kyrgyzstan, you will often see trees and concrete poles that are painted white on the bottom.

metas.title: Black Stripe Bollards
metas.description: Kyrgyzstan uses these simple white bollards with a diagonal black stripe near the top.

metas.title: Triangle Km Markers
metas.description: These kilometre markers with a red-and white triangle pattern are unique to Kyrgyzstan.

metas.title: Mosques
metas.description: The majority of Kyrgyzstan’s population is Muslim. Hence, you will see a lot of mosques throughout the country.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
The coverage in Kyrgyzstan is very limited. So learning which roads are covered will help you improve a lot.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Driving Directions Map
metas.description:
Learning which direction the Google Car is driving on most major roads will help you narrow down your options when guessing.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Southern Mirror
metas.description: You can use the Google car’s mirror to region-guess Kyrgyzstan. In the southern region, less of the road is visible on the mirror. The car’s reflection is more diagonal. For comparison, this is what it usually looks like.

metas.title: Southern Dirty Mirror
metas.description: Within this southern region, west of the roundabout that takes you up to Jalal-Abad, the mirror will have a varying degree of dirt on it.

metas.title: Black Dot Mirror
metas.description: If you see a small black dot on the Kyrgyzstan car mirror, you will be in this region.

metas.title: Divided Roads
metas.description: Divided roads are mostly concentrated in and around the capital, Bishkek. A major divided highway runs from Bishkek to Balykchy in the east.
metas.note: The cities marked on the map also have at least one divided road.

metas.title: Lake Issyk Kul
metas.description: Lake Issyk Kul is the biggest body of water in Kyrgyzstan. You will often be able to spot it on the roads north and south of the lake. Sometimes it will be obscured by buildings or trees, but the lack of any mountains in the direction of the lake will be a good clue.
metas.note: There are two other significant bodies of water that can be seen from the road: the Toktogul Reservoir and Lake Song-Kul. With a bit of practice, you can reliably distinguish these from Issyk Kul however.

metas.title: Northern Snow
metas.description:
These northern roads have a considerable amount of snow, and the sky is generally bright.

The individual sections of these roads are discussed in more detail in step 3.
metas.note: There is also snow coverage in the south. However, you can use the mirror to distinguish these roads.

metas.title: Bishkek City
metas.description: As the capital city of Kyrgyzstan, Bishkek is by far the most developed city, featuring many taller multi-story buildings you would not see elsewhere. And on the outskirts, you can see fancier buildings as well. There are also mountains south of Bishkek, but these can be hard to see at times.

metas.title: Bishkek Snow
metas.description: You can find urban snow coverage in this region of Bishkek.

metas.title: South Bishkek Hills
metas.description: The coverage south of Bishkek is generally a bit hilly, and you will see the snowy Tian Shan mountains to the south. And as Bishkek has the most polluted air of any city, there will usually be visible smog to the north.

metas.title: Colourful Poles
metas.description: These towns east and west of Bishkek feature these colourful poles with yellow, green, white, and sometimes red on top.
metas.note: Sokuluk will not have the red paint on top.

metas.title: Osh Second-biggest City
metas.description:
Osh is the second-biggest city in Kyrgyzstan. It is one of several towns that has coverage with the southern mirror. This allows you to easily distinguish it from Bishkek.

The weather in Osh is fairly good, with some clouds, but never fully overcast.
metas.note: Jalal-Abad, the other big city with the southern mirror, will always have very overcast coverage.

metas.title: Also Distinguish Osh
metas.description: You can also distinguish Osh from Bishkek by looking at the trees: most still have their leaves.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: In the centre of Osh, you can see these unique mountains with radio masts on top of them.

metas.title: Snow Coverage
metas.description:
Jalal-Abad is the third-biggest city in Kyrgyzstan. Like Osh, its coverage has the southern mirror.

You can recognise it from the extremely overcast coverage, with no gaps in the clouds. This allows you to easily distinguish it from Osh, which has better weather.

To the east, you can see this slightly snowy hill.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: Arslanbob is a snowy town north of Jalal-Abad, with hills and mountains all around. As the town is located in the mountains, you can see a lot of elevation change inside the town.
metas.note: The town also features the southern mirror.

metas.title: Snow Coverage
metas.description: Uzgen is a slightly snowy town between Osh and Jalal-Abad, which features overcast coverage.
metas.note: The town also features the southern mirror.

metas.title: Painted Poles
metas.description: In Talas, most poles are painted white on the bottom, and feature red and yellow stripes.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: Karakol is a city located between snow capped mountains to the north and south. The coverage in the city is sunny, and you can see melting snow on the ground.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: Naryn features a steep orange ridge to the north, and big snow capped mountains to the south.

metas.title: EM-04 Overview
metas.description:
The EM-04 is a major road that runs from Bishkek to Osh.

Includes 10 tips.

metas.title: Sunset Coverage
metas.description: You can notice a distinct sunset on all the coverage from Sokuluk to Kara Balta.
metas.note: This section of road features the Black Dot Mirror.

metas.title: Tian Shan Range
metas.description: Here, you will see the Tian Shan mountain range to the south. The landscape is otherwise flat. The further away from the mountains you are, the foggier they seem.
metas.note: This section of road features the Black Dot Mirror.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description: The mountains here can be characterised by steep rocky cliffs that can have a slight purple or red tint to them. Not much vegetation grows on these mountains - only some grass and shrubs. A small river also runs alongside the road. You can also spot these brown metallic electricity pylons and curved concrete guardrails on the sides of this road.
metas.note: This section of road features the Black Dot Mirror.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: On this long stretch of road, you will see plenty of snow all around you, except on the road. The Landscape is generally hilly, except the northeastern and southwestern parts, which are in the mountains.
metas.note: Most of this section features the Black Dot Mirror.

metas.title: Spruce Forests
metas.description: This section of road goes through mountains that have rocky cliffs. These mountains are a habitat for lots of spruce trees that grow on the cliff sides. A more diverse selection of trees grows next to the river that follows the road. You can see that some mountains still have snow on the peaks. Most signposts along the road are coloured blue.
metas.note: The southern section of the road features more rocky cliffs that cannot sustain any trees.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description: You can see the mostly dried up part of the Toktogul Reservoir either to the south or north of the road. There are taller mountains quite close on every side. The northern half is more desolate, while the south features more vegetation and buildings as well.

metas.title: Hilly Terrain
metas.description: You will usually see the Toktogul Reservoir north of the road in this section. It now resembles an actual lake. The landscape is generally hilly, especially to the south.
metas.note: The road is in better condition than the one south of Issyk Kul.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The road then runs through a river gorge, with large, rocky mountains on both sides. It features overcast coverage. A sizable river (the Naryn) is usually visible to the north, next to the road.

metas.title: Hilly Terrain
metas.description: This southern region has a lot of agriculture and a lot of vegetation on the sides of the roads. The region is generally flat, but the road is very close to the hills that are usually to the north or east. The gaps in the minimap indicate exceptionally hilly spots.
metas.note: This section of road features the Southern Dirty Mirror.

metas.title: Snow Coverage
metas.description: In the south, this stretch of road northwest of Uzgen is characterised by overcast coverage and lots of snow.
metas.note: This section of road features the Southern Mirror.

metas.title: EM-11 Overview
metas.description:
The EM-11, which shows up as A365 on Google Maps, runs from Bishkek down to the Chinese border. The coverage ends here.

Includes 10 tips.

metas.title: EM11 Divided Highway
metas.description: The beginning section of the divided EM-11 has this grassy median up until Khun-Chi.

metas.title: Road Markings
metas.description: From Khun-Chi to the intersection east of Tokmok, the road uses these road lines with a wide gap as a median.

metas.title: Road Markings
metas.description: The gap in the road lines gets thinner east of that intersection up until this intersection east of Kemin.

metas.title: Concrete Barriers
metas.description: From there onwards, concrete barriers are used as medians.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The road then becomes undivided. This section south of Balykchy is extremely dry, with the landscape mostly consisting of small shrubs, unless you are next to the Chu river. To the north, you can spot these mountains that have clouds hovering above them. Otherwise, there are no clouds in this region.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: Further up the road, you enter a dry valley with mountains flanking both sides. There is barely any vegetation - just some shrubs close to the ground. The river next to the road brings some more greenery to the area. In the southern half of this section, you can see this slightly snowy ridge to the north.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Going further south, you will reach this next valley, which seems equally dry, but the mountains are more rocky and have trees growing on them. The road now has very bad pavement, and as such you can see dust clouds.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: Once you get out of the valley, you will notice this area is more vegetated, has more buildings, and more animals on the now grassy fields. The landscape is still hilly, with bigger mountains to the north, south, and west. The southern mountains are especially distinct, with them being covered in snow. The hills immediately north of Naryn can get very dry, but look out for snow that you can see in the shade.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: The mountains and hills south of Naryn have a unique combination of snow and red soil that make them very distinct.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The At-Bashi Valley has a very distinct mountain range, which you will see to your south from any section on this road. To the north, you can see scattered mountains that do not form a uniform ridge. There is also a big set of hills to the west.

metas.title: EM-9 Overview
metas.description:
Road EM-9 runs from Balykchy to Karakol in the far east. On many parts of the road, you will be able to see Lake Issyk Kul to your south. The car drives towards the east (and in the last section towards the south).

Includes 3 tips.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The section from Balykchy to Cholpon Ata is sunny, with mountains to the north, and a lake to the south.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description: The section east of Cholpon Ata appears overcast, with mountains to the north, and a lake to the south. Tall tree rows on either side of the road is a common sight.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: The vertical stretch of road north of Karakol is mostly flanked by tall tree rows on either side. There are also tall snowy mountains to the north and south.
metas.note: The weather changes here, around the midpoint of the road.

metas.title: EM-10 Overview
metas.description:
The EM-10, which also shows up as A363 in Geoguessr, is a beautiful road connecting Karakol to Balykchy. Here, you will often see Lake Issyk Kul again, but this time it is visible to your north. The car drives towards the west.

Includes 5 tips.

metas.title: Tian Shan Range
metas.description: On the road west of Karakol, you will see a lot of vegetation on the sides of the roads, and long expanses of green and yellow fields beyond them. You will usually be able to see the Tian Shan Mountain Range in the distance to the north. There are big mountains to the south as well, with smaller hills before them.
metas.note: The weather is completely clear east of this intersection.

metas.title: Tian Shan Range
metas.description: You will almost always see the Issyk Kul lake, and the Tian Shan mountains on this section. The soil here is sandy and rocky.

metas.title: River Gorge
metas.description: The section west of “Fairytale Canyon” has distinct sunset coverage.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: You will see a lot of mountains and hills to the south here, but only some hills to the north, with seemingly nothing behind them. You might even see Issyk Kul behind them. There is still a lot of sand on the sides of the roads.

metas.title: Western Issyk Kul
metas.description: The landscape around the western end of Issyk Kul is drier than the east. The lake itself and the southern hills are further away from the road as well.

metas.title: EM-17
metas.description:
The EM-17 runs southeast of Talas.

Includes 2 tips.

metas.title: EM-17 Snowy
metas.description: This section of EM-17 is very snowy. The hills and mountains around the road are almost fully covered in snow. Unlike the other snowy roads, this road is often covered in uncleared slush or melted snow.
metas.note: This section of road features the Black Dot Mirror.

metas.title: EM-17 West
metas.description:
Going further west, only the hills to the south will have snow on them. The landscape is generally dry, with hills to the north and south of the road.

Most of this section features the Black Dot Mirror.

metas.title: EM-13
metas.description:
The EM-13 is a small gravel road, which sadly only has small bits of coverage.

Includes 2 tips.

metas.title: Kazarman East
metas.description: The road going east of Kazarman is an unpaved gravel road, between two hilly ridges on either side. The ridge to the north is further away, and has a bigger set of mountains visible behind it. The mountain ridge has a unique mountain that towers above the rest.

metas.title: Naryn Valley Gravel
metas.description: The eastern side of EM-13 closely resembles the road going west of Naryn. (See tip below) This road, however, is an unpaved gravel road in the middle of the Naryn valley, so the hills to the north are now closer. The Landscape is filled with bushes, shrubs, and grass.
metas.note: The one town in the region can be recognized by these white-and-red fences with a white diamond pattern in the middle.

metas.title: M-072
metas.description: This road going west of Naryn is situated south in the dry Naryn valley. You will typically see hills close to the road on the southern side. There are also bigger mountains not too far behind. While to the north, there is a wide plain, with hills and mountains in the distance. Many parts of the road also have a pavement with a salt and pepper-like quality.

metas.title: M-068
metas.description: The road going east of Naryn is also in the Naryn Valley. Here you will also see hills close to the road in the south, and then further away to the north. The plains north of the road are however smaller. This side is also more built up, except the road, which is unpaved at certain parts. Here, the hills south also have small amounts of snow on them.

metas.title: M-082
metas.description:
The M-082 is a unique road, with only a small section being covered, from the shore of Song-Kul to the mountains right south of it.

Includes 2 tips.

metas.title: Song-Kul Lake
metas.description: Song-Kul is the second major lake in Kyrgyzstan. The surrounding area features dry rolling hills, with patches of snow. The only covered road is made of gravel.

metas.title: Song-Kul South
metas.description: The road in the mountains south of Song-Kul is the only unpaved road this high up in the mountains. You can see the clouds below you, down in the valleys below. The mountains have rugged peaks, and snowy cliff sides. Many of the mountains also have spruce trees growing on them.

metas.title: M-118
metas.description:
The M-118 takes you from the resort town Arslanbob down into the fertile Fergana Valley.

Includes 2 tips.

metas.title: M-118 South
metas.description: On this road, you should be able to see the Kara Darya river to the east in the valley below the road. The region is generally hilly and green. To the north, you can see some low-lying mountains in the distance, they have some snow on them. The hills east of the river have snow on the top as well.
metas.note: This section of road features the Southern Dirty Mirror.

metas.title: M-118 North
metas.description: There will generally be some snow on the ground on this road. You will see more snow depending on how north you are. You will often see the massive Gora Babash-Ata mountain to the north.
metas.note: This section of road features the Southern Dirty Mirror.

metas.title: M-107
metas.description:
The M-107 is a pretty road connecting Taskomur to Kerben. Only the first half is covered.

Includes 2 tips.

metas.title: M-107 Ridge
metas.description: This section of M-107 is dry and rocky. There are a lot of mountains around, but this one ridge specifically can be seen from most of this section.
metas.note: This is what the ridge looks like from further away.

metas.title: M-107 West
metas.description:
Going further west, you will encounter a very hilly landscape. The landscape features a lot of vegetation - tall grass, trees, bushes. This road uses these concrete barriers as guardrails, notice the cement above the gaps.

The general southeast to northwest driving direction on this road is also worth noting.

metas.title: Arkit Road
metas.description:
This road going all the way to Sary-Chelek lake is one of the most unique roads in Kyrgyzstan.

Includes 2 tips.

metas.title: Arkit Vegetation
metas.description:
This valley is full of vegetation. This area also has a lot of buildings and fences near the road. Most of the road is in poor shape, with it being unpaved and potholes littering parts of it. To the north, you can see some darker clouds, and closer to Arkit, the weather will get cloudier, and there are more dead trees.

The south to north driving direction on this road is worth noting.

metas.title: Arkit Snow
metas.description: This section near Arkit has a lot of snow everywhere and low broad leafed trees all around. This already unique landscape paired with the south to north driving direction makes it very easy to recognise.

metas.title: M-010 Spruce
metas.description: This section of the M-010 is surrounded by beautiful spruce covered snowy mountains. Some snow has also gathered on the sides of the road.

metas.title: Chunkurchak Road
metas.description: This rocky dirt road going to Chunkurchak is mostly high up in the snowy hills south of Bishkek. Some of the soil here has a red tint to it. On the northern part of the road, you can only see the snowy hills to the south. Also pay attention to the red-and-white bollards on the sides of the roads.

metas.title: East Chunkurchak Road
metas.description: There is another road with coverage to the east of the Chunkurchak road: it goes through a very rocky valley, with a variety of plants growing on the mountainsides, of which only some have small amounts of snow. You can also see some snow in the valley, and more so towards the south.

metas.title: A367
metas.description: You can easily recognise this side road, labelled as A367 on the map, from the snow covered mountain ranges in every direction. The sun to the south is almost blinding.
metas.note: This section of road features the Black Dot Mirror.

metas.title: Airport Road
metas.description: This divided road north of Bishkek, that leads up to the international airport, uses unique yellow-and-black curbs on the median, which consists of mostly grass. Some sections have small planted trees, and poles with red-and-yellow paint on the bottom. The horizontal section west of the airport has a lot more trees.

metas.title: Northeast Sunset
metas.description: This slightly northeast-bound road north of Bishkek can easily be recognised from the sunset coverage.

metas.title: Jeti Oguz Valley
metas.description: The road south of Jeti Oguz goes through a valley. The general landscape in this valley is very green by Kyrgyzstan standards, there are plenty of trees and bushes growing in the valley and on the hills. You can see small patches of snow still on the ground. From most of the valley, you can still see the Tian Shan mountains to the north, and other snowy mountains to the south. The valley also contains these unique orange rock formations.

metas.title: Grigorievka Valley
metas.description:
The road north of Grigorievka goes through a stunning river valley. This is one of the most unique roads in Kyrgyzstan. You can easily recognise it from the spruce covered mountains in this rocky valley. The lack of snow is also notable.

The northern half of this road is on an open rolling field with pine forests scattered around.

metas.title: EM-23
metas.description: There is a side road north of the Orto Tokoy Reservoir that has very broken coverage. This road is well maintained, and it passes through dry mountains. The only vegetation around is grass and shrubs. To the west, you can see this mountain which has little snow left. To the north, the mountains are dark, similar to silhouettes, and on the southern portion of the road, you will see the reservoir.

metas.title: Southwest Naryn Gravel
metas.description: This remote gravel road southwest of Naryn passes through a dry and desolate valley. Despite the river, there is nothing but some shrubs on the ground. Many of the mountains in the valley have steep, rocky cliff sides. You will also find snow here, but more so in the south.

metas.title: Limited Coverage
metas.description:
Street View coverage in Laos is very limited. Only five cities are covered: Vientiane, Vang Vieng, Luang Prabang, Savannakhet, and Pakse.

In addition, all coverage in Laos was taken by a Generation 3 camera.

All five cities have a distinct look and with some practise they are easily distinguishable from each other. The differences are discussed in more detail in the region-guessing section, but the summarized version is as follows:

Luang Prabang: historical architecture, hills, palms

Vang Vieng: distinct mountains

Vientiane: no roof rack, large city

Savannakhet: very flat

Pakse: red soil, arid, hills

metas.title: Silver Car
metas.description: In all cities except for the capital, Vientiane, this Google car will be visible. It is silver-coloured, with a roof rack with two metal bars and black side mirrors.
metas.note: A similar car can be found in Guatemala, so be sure to look at the other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Right Side Driving
metas.description: Laos drives on the right hand side of the road.
metas.note: This is mostly useful to distinguish between Thailand, which drives on the left hand side of the road.

metas.title: Yellow License Plates
metas.description:
Laotian licence plates are short and yellow. This distinguishes them from nearby Thailand and Cambodia, who both use white plates on non-commercial vehicles.

Laotian commercial plates are white, and government plates are blue.
metas.note: Thailand uses yellow plates for commercial vehicles, such as taxis.

metas.title: Lao Script
metas.description: Lao script is compact and curvy, with some diacritics on top and below characters.
metas.note: It is very similar to Thai script, but (in most fonts) Lao script has fewer straight lines.

metas.title: Buddhist Temples
metas.description: Laos is a majority Buddhist country. Buddhist temples are a common sight. They can be recognized by their ornate decorations, often with gold leaf detailing.
metas.note: Thailand and Cambodia are also majority Buddhist.

metas.title: Striped Curbs
metas.description: Striped curbs of various colours, such as red, yellow, or black with white, can be seen throughout Laos.

metas.title: Stop Signs
metas.description: Stop signs feature the Lao script. Sometimes, the sign features the word ‘stop’ in Latin script below the Lao script.
metas.note: In Laos, stop signs only have 2 characters, compared to 3 in Thailand.

metas.title: Square Poles
metas.description: Laos uses square concrete poles, with small pinholes on the sides in a row from top to bottom.
metas.note: Similar poles are found in Thailand, Sri Lanka, and less commonly, Cambodia.

metas.title: Square Bollards
metas.description: Laos uses square concrete black and white bollards with one or more black bands.
metas.note: Thailand, Indonesia, and rarely Cambodia use similar bollards.

metas.title: Striped Lamp Posts
metas.description: Some lamp posts have diagonal red and white striped markings that do not go down to the base.

metas.title: Cuboid Bollards
metas.description: A red and white painted cuboid concrete bollard can sometimes be seen a few metres off the side of the road.

metas.title: Communist Flags
metas.description: Laos has a communist government. You can sometimes see red hammer and sickle flags.

metas.title: Luang Prabang
metas.description: Luang Prabang is located on the Mekong River and surrounded by low mountains and hills (not always visible).

metas.title: Luang Prabang Palms
metas.description: Palm trees are common in Luang Prabang.

metas.title: Luang Prabang Architecture
metas.description: Luang Prabang is the former royal capital of Laos and a UNESCO heritage site. The city has a lot of historical architecture, including several temples. Many buildings make use of traditional dark wooden architectural elements. There are also some buildings dating back to French colonial rule of Laos.

metas.title: Blue Sign Backs
metas.description: Within Laos, blue sign backs are only found in Luang Prabang.

metas.title: Vang Vieng Mountains
metas.description: This rugged mountain range can be seen from almost any point in Vang Vieng, and is the most reliable way of recognizing it.
metas.note: Vang Vieng has very limited coverage; by far the least out of all 5 Lao cities. The actual coverage is also south of the Vang Vieng label on the map.

metas.title: Vang Vieng Tourism
metas.description: Vang Vieng is also very touristic: you will see a lot of signs for hotels, guesthouses, and other tourism-related enterprises. In the (very few) rounds that the distinct mountains are blocked by buildings, this is a good way to recognize the town.

metas.title: No Antenna Map
metas.description: As previously mentioned, the Vientiane area is the only part of Laos where the Google car is not visible. It also has a considerable amount of rural coverage, especially to its southeast.
metas.note: This may lead to toss-ups with Thailand and Cambodia. Use the driving side (Thailand being left, and Laos and Cambodia right), along with other clues to tell them apart.

metas.title: Road 450
metas.description: Road 450 east of Vientiane is made entirely of concrete blocks. It is also one of the very few divided highways in Laos with coverage.

metas.title: Nong Beuak Lamps
metas.description: The divided highway that passes through Nong Beuak can be easily recognized by these street lamps that line the sides of the road.
metas.note: These streetlamps can also be found on the divided section of road 13, but it is more urban, and has a different road angle.

metas.title: Conservation Area Road
metas.description: The road that goes through the conservation area features uniquely hilly terrain for Laos. Landscape around the road is also very dry, and mostly forested. Additionally, the road is in good condition with coloured curbs and dashed outer lines.
metas.note: It is the only single lane road that has black and white or yellow and white curbs.

metas.title: Patuxai Monument
metas.description: The only trekker in Laos is a view of the monumental Patuxai arch, a massive war memorial in the middle of Vientiane. Some of the coverage is made with a normal trekker, and some with a tripod.

metas.title: Savannakhet
metas.description:
Savannakhet is very flat: the only mountains that are visible are on the other side of the Mekong river, in Thailand.

It is also recognizable as its soil has a slight red tinge, however not as red as Pakse.
metas.note: On Google Maps, the label for Savannakhet is hidden under the label of the Thai province of Mukdahan until you zoom in relatively close. You can find Savannakhet by going west of Xeno.

metas.title: Pakse
metas.description:
The southern city of Pakse is easily recognizable thanks to the distinct red soil.

The vegetation is also uniquely dry, with equally dry hills nearby.

metas.title: Pakse Bridge
metas.description: This 1380-metre long bridge crosses the Mekong River next to the city of Pakse. It is the only major bridge in Laos with coverage.

metas.title: Red Strip Plates
metas.description: Standard Lebanese licence plates are either long with a blue strip on the left, similar to most licence plates in Europe, or short with a similar blue strip. Licence plates on taxis are notably deep red. You may also find licence plates with other colours.

metas.title: Arabic Language
metas.description: The official language of Lebanon is Arabic, however English and French are also common to see.

metas.title: Shitcam Coverage
metas.description: Lebanon is currently the only Middle Eastern country that has official shitcam coverage.

metas.title: Gen 3 Trekker Coverage
metas.description: Apart from the shitcam, all of the Lebanese coverage was taken with a Generation 3 trekker.

metas.title: Mediterranean Landscape
metas.description: Lebanon has a Mediterranean landscape, with a lot of hills and rocky cliffs.

metas.title: Painted Poles
metas.description: Lebanon uses a variety of metallic mesh poles, which are sometimes painted bright yellow. Generic-looking wooden poles are common too.

metas.title: Local Architecture
metas.description: While several types of architecture can be found on the Lebanese coverage, it is worth mentioning that many buildings are made of sandstone bricks.
metas.note: These bricks often look very similar to Jerusalem stone, commonly found in Israel and the West Bank.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: Most of the coverage is concentrated near the west coast, north of Beirut.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The region around Zahle has flat agricultural fields, with mountains visible to the northwest.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: Coverage where snow is visible on mountain tops, or on the ground, is found in the northeastern mountains, east of Tripoli.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Northern Lebanon is very flat and agricultural. You might see the mountains to the southeast.

metas.title: Zahle Features
metas.description: A visible black car can be found in and around Zahle.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: The Generation 3 trekker coverage in Lebanon is extremely limited, mostly being found around tourist attractions, university campuses and trails. Note that due to the large number of distinct trekkers, this guide will only cover those that are considered pinpointable.

metas.title: Capital City Features
metas.description: Beirut is the capital of Lebanon and the only covered city with many modern high-rise buildings. While the city might not be clearly visible from all parts of the coverage, you will almost always be able to see urban buildings or infrastructure in the background.

metas.title: Coastal Promenade
metas.description: Coverage was taken along parts of the promenade in Beirut, with a grey brick pavement and a large number of fan palms.

metas.title: University Campus
metas.description: Université Saint Joseph, southeast of central Beirut can be recognised by the old, grand-looking sandstone building.

metas.title: University Campus
metas.description: Campus Debbieh of the Beirut Arab University consists of somewhat sparsely built large modern sandstone buildings on top of a forested hill. The ocean can typically be seen far away to the west.

metas.title: University Campus
metas.description: The Lebanese International University (LIU) can be recognised by the many large stone buildings having unpainted bottom floors while the floors above are painted beige.

metas.title: University Campus
metas.description: The University of Balamand has a lot of modern white painted buildings. The buildings often have a very cubic look.

metas.title: University Campus
metas.description: The Lebanese American University, east of Byblos, has a very urban look, with a lot of construction work and large modern buildings.

metas.title: City Features
metas.description: The ancient city of Byblos is one of the oldest cities in the world and can be recognised by the many old historical buildings, almost all built out of the same type of unpainted stone bricks.

metas.title: River Gorge
metas.description: The trekker near Bsharri can be recognised by the large canyon to the south.

metas.title: Historical Site
metas.description: In Baalbek you can find a large complex of Roman ruins.

metas.title: Historic Fortress
metas.description: The Mseilha fortress can be found southwest of Tripoli and is built on a monolithic limestone rock.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: The only rural coastal road with trekker coverage in Lebanon can be found southwest of Tripoli.

metas.title: Macau Features
metas.description: Macau is a Special Administrative Region of China, so for country streaks purposes, it is counted as China.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description:
Coverage in Macau is limited to Generation 2.

Generation 2 can be recognized by the lower camera quality and circular blur above and below the camera. Colours will also seem slightly off.

The coverage in Macau specifically is some of the oldest Generation 2 available, meaning that the colours look even more washed out and overexposed than usual. This can be a great way to identify the Macau coverage in the absence of other clues.

metas.title: Black-White Plates
metas.description: Macau uses black licence plates with white text. Licence plates can either be long or square.

metas.title: Grey Street Lamps
metas.description: Cylindrical grey lamp posts with a black painted bottom can be seen in Macau.
metas.note: Similar lamp posts can be seen in Hong Kong, however they do not have a black painted bottom.

metas.title: Language Features
metas.description: Due to Macau’s history as a Portuguese colony, Portuguese language can commonly be seen, especially on storefronts, along with Chinese.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description: These white street signs with a blue border around the Chinese and Portuguese text are unique to Macau.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description:
Gambling is legal in Macau and its biggest source of revenue (50% of its GDP). As a result, you will see a lot of casinos and advertisements for gambling. The casinos often have very extravagant, kitsch designs.

Due to how old the Generation 2 is, many newer casinos can be seen under construction.

metas.title: Dense Apartment Buildings
metas.description: Dense apartment buildings with gridded, narrow streets and cars parked on both sides can be found in this region in the northern half of Macau.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description:
A hilly, rural region of Macau can be found in the south. Roads are narrow, winding up hills with trees on both sides. A helpful clue are the lamp posts, which are commonly seen.

When this area appears in a world map, it can be confusing to newer players, as there are very few language or architecture clues available. The washed out early Generation 2 coverage can help with identifying it as being located in Macau.

metas.title: Sai Van Bridge
metas.description: The Sai Van Bridge can be recognized by these unique cuboid towers with arches in them.

metas.title: the Amizade Bridge
metas.description: Red guardrails can be seen on the Amizade Bridge.

metas.title: Black License Plates
metas.description: Malaysian licence plates are black and generally have two white sections. These are visible even when blurred.
metas.note: Indonesian licence plates are also black, but they will have three white sections.

metas.title: Double White Lines
metas.description: Malaysia frequently uses double white centre lines on its two-lane roads. It is the only Southeast Asian country to do so.

metas.title: Yellow Road Bars
metas.description: These thick yellow bars are also almost exclusive to Malaysia.
metas.note: You can very rarely see similar patterns in Hong Kong and the United Kingdom.

metas.title: Pole Stickers
metas.description:
Electricity poles in Malaysia often have black or white stickers on them.

Sometimes you will also find red-and-white or red-and-blue stripes below the black sticker.

metas.title: Unique Stop Signs
metas.description: BERHENTI stop signs and BERI LALUAN yield signs are both unique to Malaysia.

metas.title: Malaysian Bollards
metas.description: Malaysian bollards will often have the colours black, white, grey and red. Here are three examples of typical Malaysian bollards.
metas.note: There can be multiple varieties of these bollards, but the layout is mostly the same.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: This is a typical Malaysian directional sign. Hexagonal yellow highway shields are unique to Malaysia.

metas.title: Kilometre Markers
metas.description: Malaysian kilometre markers have a unique white-and-blue colour scheme. Note that the hexagon shields are often visible.

metas.title: Malay Language
metas.description: The Malay language uses the Latin script. It is very closely related to Indonesian. These two languages are practically indistinguishable for people who do not speak either.

metas.title: Chinese Characters
metas.description: In contrast to neighbouring Indonesia, Chinese characters are often seen in Malaysia. In fact, 24.6% of the Malaysian population is of Chinese descent.

metas.title: Striped Signposts
metas.description: Signposts in Malaysia almost always have black-and-white stripes.
metas.note: Within Asia, these posts are also found in Sri Lanka, Bhutan and Bangladesh. Make sure to check other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Black and White Curbs
metas.description: Black-and-white curbs are commonly found in Malaysia.
metas.note: Many other countries in Asia can also have black-and-white curbs.

metas.title: Road Numbering
metas.description: Each Malaysian state, excluding the three federal territories, has its own road numbering system with a unique letter at the start of the road number.
metas.note: Sabah also has A roads, but only the A2 and A7.

metas.title: State Flags
metas.description: State flags can be seen with some regularity, so it is worth learning them.

metas.title: Mainland Black Stickers
metas.description: Black pole stickers are most commonly found on the mainland.
metas.note: The black stickers on Borneo only exist in Generation 4 coverage.

metas.title: Johor Black Stickers
metas.description: Black stickers with the text ‘TEL TNB’ at the bottom, are only found in Johor.

metas.title: Sarawak White Stickers
metas.description: White pole stickers are only found on electricity poles on the island of Borneo, in Sarawak.

metas.title: Mainland Lamp Posts
metas.description: Lamp posts with two small circles on the support are mainly found on mainland Malaysia.

metas.title: Triangular Lamp Posts
metas.description: Lamp posts with a triangular metal support are mainly found on mainland Malaysia.

metas.title: Sarawak Poles
metas.description: Electricity poles on the Borneo side typically have a 2-1 insulator configuration, and a long diagonal wooden support. They are exclusive to the Sarawak region of the island.
metas.note: Indonesian poles can look similar, but they are usually not made of wood, and use smaller or no diagonal supports.

metas.title: Sabah Poles
metas.description: Thin metal poles with two parallel pole tops are exclusive to the Sabah region of Borneo.

metas.title: Sarawak Lamp Posts
metas.description: This lamp post with a supporting piece of sheet metal resembling a boomerang is found in Sarawak.
metas.note: It is more common in cities other than Kuching.

metas.title: Southern Bins
metas.description: Trash bins with a logo resembling an ‘S’ are found in the states of Negeri Sembilan, Malacca and Johor.

metas.title: Northern Bins
metas.description: Trash bins with a logo resembling leaves are found in Perlis and Kedah.

metas.title: Alam Flora Bins
metas.description: Trash bins with this logo featuring a sunny landscape, saying ‘Alam Flora’ are found in Pahang, Kuala Lumpur and Putrajaya. The logo will occasionally be absent, and it will just say ‘Alam Flora’.

metas.title: Johor Street Signs
metas.description: Yellow street name signs with a black outline are specific to the state of Johor.
metas.note:
This arrow-shaped street sign, regardless of its colour, is exclusive to Malaysia.

NOTE: Yellow signs are also found in southern Negeri Sembilan, however only the tip of the arrow will be black.

metas.title: Sabah Street Signs
metas.description: Green street signs that form an arrow shape and have a yellow hexagonal symbol with the letters JKR on the left side are found in Sabah.

metas.title: Sabah Mountains
metas.description: Assuming you are on Borneo: the state of Sabah is very mountainous, and much of the coverage is on mountain roads like this one.
metas.note: Sarawak generally has flatter roads. Even if you see mountains, they will usually be at a distance.

metas.title: Perlis Rocks
metas.description: These isolated rock formations, rising abruptly from an otherwise flat landscape, can be found near the Thai border in Perlis state.

metas.title: Labuan Bins
metas.description: Urban areas in Labuan are dotted with blue cylindrical containers.

metas.title: Mulu National Park Car
metas.description: This unique grey car with a long front antenna can be found in Gunung Mulu National Park, Sarawak.

metas.title: White License Plates
metas.description: Mongolian licence plates are mostly white with a hint of red on the left side from the Soyombo symbol.

metas.title: Mongolian Script
metas.description: Mongolia primarily uses Cyrillic script, though Latin and traditional Mongolian script can also occasionally be seen. Mongolian Cyrillic contains the letters Ɵ and Ү, which do not exist in the Russian alphabet. Additionally, the use of double vowels, such as aa, ƟƟ or ЭЭ, is common in Mongolian.
metas.note: The letters Ɵ and Ү also exist in the Kyrgyz and Kazakh languages.

metas.title: Camping Car
metas.description: Mongolia very often has a visible Street View car as all of Mongolian coverage was driven with a large pickup truck. The truck can have several features such as a tent on top, red side-view mirrors, a snorkel, and roof-racks. All of these can be of help in identifying Mongolia.

metas.title: Steppe Landscape
metas.description: Mongolia can typically be identified by the steppe biomes found across the country. While some forested areas are found in Mongolia, most of the country features empty grasslands or deserts with a characteristic lack of trees. It is not uncommon to find rugged, rocky or rolling hills as well as rivers and lakes across Mongolia.

metas.title: Bowling Pin Bollards
metas.description: Mongolia uniquely features white bowling-pin shaped bollards with two red stripes around the top.

metas.title: Russian Influence
metas.description:
Mongolian infrastructure has clear Russian influence. Wooden poles with supporting stone blocks, white lamp posts, and three-striped pedestrian crossing signs are common to see.

Unique to Mongolia is the “ЗОГС” stop sign.
metas.note: Each town has unique lamp post designs, so learning them can be quite useful.

metas.title: Wooden Fences
metas.description: Mongolian neighbourhoods are very frequently separated by dirt alleys and wooden fences.

metas.title: Yurts
metas.description: White, round yurts are the traditional dwelling of nomadic families in Mongolia, and are often seen all around the country.

metas.title: Animal Herds
metas.description: It is very common to see large herds of animals in Mongolia, including horses, yaks, cows, sheep, goats, and camels.

metas.title: Ovoos
metas.description: Decorated piles of stones, known as ovoos, are used as ceremonial markers or shrines throughout Mongolia and are common to see.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Mongolia has very limited coverage, mainly along highways and in large towns. Learning which roads and towns have coverage can be very useful. The highest coverage density can be found around the capital of Ulaanbaatar.
metas.note:
Mongolia has lots of hidden coverage that will generally not be discussed in the guide.

You can click on the map to enlarge it.

metas.title: Driving Toward Capital
metas.description:
Driving directions can be a very useful clue for narrowing down your location in Mongolia. In general, the driving direction tends to be away from Ulaanbaatar.

You can click on the map to enlarge it.

metas.title: Topography Map
metas.description:
Mongolia has a very flat landscape in the east and in the south, with rolling hills in the north, and large mountains and rocky hills being common in the west.

You can click on the map to enlarge it.

metas.title: Northern Forests
metas.description: You can find forests, typically surrounded by grassy fields, all around northern Mongolia. Generally these will be Siberian Larches, with pines and birches being common as well.

metas.title: Eastern Tracks
metas.description: Small dirt tracks within flat, vast grassy fields are mainly found in far eastern Mongolia.

metas.title: Southern Desert Tracks
metas.description: There are several areas with off-road desert coverage in southern Mongolia. Most of this coverage is directly south or east of the town of Mandalgovi.

metas.title: Southern Paved Roads
metas.description:
There are a couple of paved desert roads in southern Mongolia.

You can learn more about these roads later in the guide.

metas.title: Southwestern Arid Steppe
metas.description: You can find arid steppe rangeland, characterised by the coarse soil, patchy grass, and small shrubs, throughout southwestern Mongolia.

metas.title: Western Rugged Hills
metas.description: These dry, rugged hills and mountains are common to see in far western Mongolia.

metas.title: Western Lakes
metas.description: Lakes and rivers are much more common in western Mongolia.

metas.title: Ulaanbaatar Snow
metas.description: Snow coverage is mostly found around Ulaanbaatar.

metas.title: Fall Coverage
metas.description: Fall coverage in Mongolia gives rise to very distinct orange-coloured trees and grass, and can only be found in a few areas; mostly between the towns of Lun and Hatgal, with some fall coverage around Ulaanbaatar. Trees are more commonly seen the further north you are.
metas.note: Some of the generation 4 coverage in Ulaanbaatar was also taken in the fall.

metas.title: Bugant Forest
metas.description:
Around the town of Bugant is a large forest that stands out for having narrow dirt trails with close trees, typically on both sides, in a way that can appear quite Russian. Additionally, it is very common to see birches around this area.

Keep in mind that the dirt trails in this forest do not appear on the map.

metas.title: Rare Crops
metas.description: Due to Mongolia’s harsh climate and terrain, crop fields are rare, but they do occasionally appear in the subdivisions of Selenge and Töv, near Ulaanbaatar.

metas.title: Ulaanbaatar
metas.description: The capital city, Ulaanbaatar, is by far the biggest city in Mongolia, with about 50% of the entire country's population living in it. As such, its urban development and sheer size is unlike anywhere else in Mongolia. The cityscape is bustling with many high rise buildings, chain stores, travelling cars, buses, and pedestrians, as well as clean roads and sidewalks. Meanwhile, the suburbs can be recognized from the vast yurt districts in hilly areas. Generation 4 coverage is common, however Generation 3 winter coverage is also common to see in the suburbs.

metas.title: Choir Highway
metas.description: The Choir Highway is the longest covered paved road in Mongolia, running from Nalaikh down to Zamiin-Uud on the Chinese border, and is mostly desert. The dry brown soil, lack of vegetation, clear skies, and general flatness are all characteristic of this road. Additionally, a railroad runs along the entire highway, which can be seen west of the highway north of Sainshand, and east of the highway south of Sainshand. Between the towns of Sainshand and Erdene there is some overcast coverage.

metas.title: Mandalgovi Highway
metas.description: The other main desert highway in Mongolia runs through Mandalgovi, and can be differentiated from the Choir Highway by its cloudy skies, darker pavement, and deep blue tent instead of the tentless car.

metas.title: Mandalgovi Highway Snow
metas.description: The Mandalgovi Highway runs south of the capital and was covered during a blizzard, making it extremely snowy and foggy. It also has a deep blue tent, which is found along this entire road, and a flat landscape which can differentiate it from other snowy roads.

metas.title: Millenium Road
metas.description: The Millenium Road runs just west of the town of Lun, and has late fall coverage, combined with a dry climate that gives it characteristic orange short grass. The silver tent, clear skies, and general flatness with low rolling hills also help in identifying this road. The sun gradually sets as the car continues west until it becomes sunset at the end of the road.
metas.note: At the end of the road, the car continues travelling northwest up to Murun on off-road dirt trails.

metas.title: Darkhan-Erdenet Highway
metas.description: The Darkhan-Erdenet highway can be identified by the low rolling hills, tall transmission towers, and occasional crop fields in the area. Additionally, most of the highway has winter coverage with the tentless car, light snow, and yellow grass. Beware that summer coverage can occasionally appear in the eastern half of the road.

metas.title: Eastern Highway
metas.description: The highway connecting the towns of Chinggis and Baruun-Urt stands out as one of the only paved highways in the east. It is considerably cloudy and the road seems freshly paved, making it a very dark road, combined with a mostly flat landscape.

metas.title: Khuder Railroad
metas.description:
A railroad can be seen along almost the entire road to the town of Khuder in the north. It is usually very close to the road, but can occasionally be quite far away, in which case it can still be identified by the mound it is built upon. In the western half of this road, the river to the south can also be seen.

Keep in mind that this railroad does not appear on the map.

metas.title: Roof Racks Split
metas.description:
The roof racks of the Street View car are very useful as they can effectively split Mongolia in half. The presence of rubber inlays in the roof racks are generally found in the west, while empty roof racks are generally found in the east.

You can click on the map to enlarge it.

metas.title: Spare Tire Split
metas.description:
You can split Mongolia into 4 zones based on the spare tire in the back right of the Street View car:

A netted spare tire shown in red

A single strap spare tire shown in green

A spare tire with no strap shown in orange

Without a spare tire shown in blue

You can click on the map to enlarge it.

metas.title: Eastern Car
metas.description: In the eastern grasslands, the Street View car has a light blue tent and a forward-facing snorkel.

metas.title: Roof Rack Straps
metas.description: The eastern region can be further divided into several smaller areas based on the layout of the orange roof rack straps. These straps can be seen by looking straight down.
metas.note:
Orange straps can be found in the west as well, this tip is only useful for the eastern car with a blue tent from the previous tip.

You can click on the map to enlarge it.

metas.title: Chinggis Straps
metas.description: The tent will have red tensioner straps at the front around the city of Chinggis.
metas.note: The Chinggis-Baganuur highway (in grey) is almost entirely hidden coverage.

metas.title: Northern Blue Tent Car
metas.description: North of Ulaanbaatar you can find this car, which has the same blue tent as the eastern tent, but with a backwards-facing snorkel. The snorkel can sometimes be difficult to see, so use other additional clues such as rolling hills and forests to confirm the region.
metas.note: The highway in pink can have either the blue tent car or the tentless car with snow coverage.

metas.title: Tentless Car
metas.description:
A Street View car with no tent can be seen in and around the capital city. It is generally found on a northwest diagonal going through Ulaanbaatar. Southeast of Ulaanbaatar, on the Choir highway, the car will have a double mirror on the left as well as a backward facing snorkel.

Driving direction is especially useful with this car as it is always travelling away from the capital.

metas.title: Silver Tent
metas.description: A Street View car with a bright silver tent is generally found in central and northwestern Mongolia.
metas.note: The Bulgan Highway (in grey) is almost entirely hidden coverage.

metas.title: Western Tent
metas.description: A Street View car with a grey tent and hooks on the tent can only be found in western Mongolia. It is the most common car to have the netted spare tire.

metas.title: Southwestern Tent
metas.description: If the grey tent has hook straps angled downwards, you should be in southwestern Mongolia.

metas.title: Tolbo Tent
metas.description: If the grey tent has no hooks on the left side and is billowing from the wind, you will be on the road between Khovd and Ölgii or around the town of Tugrug.

metas.title: Cage Car
metas.description: A Street View car with a cage on top of the roof instead of a tent can be seen near Ulaanbaatar. West of Ulaanbaatar, the car will have a green camouflage sleeping bag on top of the cage (coverage highlighted in green). Additionally, all coverage with this car was taken during winter, with most of it being in snowy areas.
metas.note: The cage car can very rarely appear in Kharkhorin and Zuunmod.

metas.title: Ulaanbaatar Gen 4
metas.description: Generation 4 coverage in the capital uses a silver truck with an ornate blue & white roof decal, with a snorkel and long antenna on the front right. While the unique roof can be seen in most locations, some locations blur most of the car, leaving only the snorkel and antenna visible. This car can only be found around Ulaanbaatar.

metas.title: Eastern Gen 4
metas.description: Generation 4 coverage in eastern Mongolia uses a silver pick-up truck with a large metal box and shovel on the roof. The car was sponsored by Bodi Group, however camera stitching generally hides one of the letters.

metas.title: Western Gen 4
metas.description: Generation 4 coverage in western Mongolia uses a silver pick-up truck with a big light blue tent. Different variations of the tent can be useful for narrowing down the region.

metas.title: Northwestern Tent
metas.description: The tent with 2 straps and a single knot in the straps covers most of northwestern Mongolia.
metas.note: Occasionally, camera stitching can hide the knot.

metas.title: Southwestern Knot Tent
metas.description: The tent with a knot on both straps covers most of southwestern Mongolia.

metas.title: Central Southern Tent
metas.description: The tent with the lower strap in a clump covers most of central-southern Mongolia, along the road from Ulaanbaatar to Altai.

metas.title: Central Northern Tent
metas.description: The tent with 4 straps covers most of central-northern Mongolia.

metas.title: Khorgo Tent
metas.description: You can find a tent with an open zipper in central Mongolia, near the town of Khorgo.

metas.title: Erdenet
metas.description: Erdenet is the second largest city in Mongolia. As such, it has many multistory buildings that can be seen from across town, a large stadium, and a ferris wheel in the south of the city.
