It is surrounded by large barren hills to the south and to the north, and was covered on a cloudy day in the winter, meaning all vegetation is dead.
metas.note: Erdenet can look very similar to Darkhan and Ulaanbaatar, but the lack of snow distinguishes it from Darkhan, while the cloudy skies and lack of rubber inlays on the roof racks can be used to distinguish it from Ulaanbaatar.

metas.title: Darkhan
metas.description: The city of Darkhan in northern Mongolia can be recognized by its distinct snow coverage. It is the third largest city in Mongolia and as such has many high-rising buildings and travelling cars.
metas.note: Other smaller towns can also have snow coverage but Darkhan is the only large city in Mongolia with snow coverage, apart from some Ulaanbaatar suburbs.

metas.title: Sukhbaatar and Altanbulag
metas.description: Sukhbaatar and Altanbulag are two neighbouring towns in the north near the Russian border. They have dry, forested hills all around and heavy overcast coverage. Sukhbaatar is completely overcast while Altanbulag is slightly less cloudy.
metas.note: Murun and Choibalsan are two other towns that also have overcast coverage, but lack forested hills and have different Street View cars.

metas.title: Chinggis
metas.description: Chinggis is a major town in the east with red straps on the front of the tent. It is a fairly dry and flat town with small hills to the north, and somewhat cloudy skies.
metas.note: Dundburd and Bayan-Ovoo are the only other towns with the same tent, but are much smaller towns with no paved roads.

metas.title: Choibalsan
metas.description: Choibalsan is the only major city to have several concrete roads. In most parts of the city there is a visible smoke stack, which is in the southeast corner of the city. It appears to have just rained as the roads are slightly wet and the sky is overcast. Additionally, you may occasionally find unique pedestrian signs with a short figure over three stripes.

metas.title: Baruun-Urt
metas.description: Baruun-Urt can be identified by the towering building under construction in the centre of town (on the map its POI is called “Smile”) combined with the dry landscape.
metas.note: Similar buildings under construction can be found in other towns such as Chinggis but they are not as large and do not feature an orange tower crane like the Smile building.

metas.title: Khalkhgol
metas.description: The town of Khalkhgol in far east Mongolia can be recognized by its flat, green landscape with low rolling hills and a giant sword statue visible in the distance.

metas.title: Dariganga
metas.description: The town of Dariganga can be recognized by the distinctive hill present to the northwest of the town in an otherwise flat landscape.

metas.title: Sainshand
metas.description: Sainshand is the largest town in the desert region and it has a dry climate, many buildings, and paved roads. A dry ridge separates the northern and southern parts of the town, distinguishing Sainshand from other desert towns that are mostly flat. In the downtown area you can find a miniature pink eiffel tower.

metas.title: Zamiin-Uud
metas.description: The desert town of Zamiin-Uud on the border with China has unique sailboat lamp posts featuring a golden flower pot around them. Often, white signs with Mongolian folded script can be seen attached to these lamp posts.
metas.note: The other desert towns of Choir and Sainshand look similar to Zamiin-Uud and have the same Street View car but use different lamp posts. Choir can be identified by its blue lamp posts and Sainshand by its white lamp posts.

metas.title: Mandalgovi
metas.description: Mandalgovi is a large desert town with notably cloudy coverage. It’s the only large desert town apart from Dalanzadgad which is not on the Choir Highway, and it has a deep blue tent instead of the tentless car.

metas.title: Dalanzadgad
metas.description: Dalanzadgad can be easily recognised by its distinct sunset coverage. Additionally it has a dry climate, fall-coloured grass, rocky hills to the south, some smoke stacks, and a unique loose tent cover on the left side.

metas.title: Arvaikheer
metas.description: Arvaikheer is a large central town recognizable by the warm, green, and grassy landscape in gen 4, with low rolling hills in every direction. Often you can see the town’s ferris wheel in a park in the centre of town.
metas.note: In older coverage, a distinct camera smudge can be seen on the right side of the camera.

metas.title: Bayankhongor
metas.description: The town of Bayankhongor, in central Mongolia, has an overall dry landscape and can be recognized from the nearby large dry hill to the east, with the Soyombo symbol inscribed onto it.
metas.note: In older coverage, a distinct camera smudge can be seen on the right side of the camera.

metas.title: Tsetserleg
metas.description: In the central town of Tsetserleg, you will see these distinct rocky, rugged hills, with small trees growing on them to the north. It has very clear skies and the neighbourhoods can often be seen on the hilly slopes.

metas.title: Murun
metas.description: Murun is a town in the north built on a north-south grid with a large jagged hill nearby to the north. It has a lot of alley coverage with dark cloudy skies and muddy, unpaved roads.
metas.note: Murun occasionally has sunny coverage where it isn’t cloudy, so consider other clues as well.

metas.title: Hatgal
metas.description: Hatgal is a small lake town on the Khuvsgul Lake. It can be recognized from its fall coverage with orange trees and grass, and the large lake in the northeast, where the Khuvsgul Ice Festival is held every year.

metas.title: Tosontsengel
metas.description: The small, hilly town of Tosontsengel, frequently has red-tinted roads and uses these unique lamp posts that have a wavy design.

metas.title: Uliastai
metas.description: Uliastai is a central-western Mongolian town, surrounded by large, green nearby hills. It is common to see a decent amount of trees or the river that runs through the town. In the centre of town, you can find a small hill with the Soyombo symbol inscribed on it.

metas.title: Altai
metas.description: In the town of Altai, you can see a range of dark, distant hills to the south and west and low rolling hills to the north and east. Additionally, it is common to see wet roads, as most of the coverage occurred after heavy rain.
metas.note: In older coverage, a unique tent can be seen, which is inflated on the left side.

metas.title: Khovd
metas.description: Khovd is a large, dry and shrubby town, in western Mongolia, that can be identified by the very distinct rocky, red-tinted hills, present to the north of town.
metas.note: The nearby Khar-Us, Tugrug, and the samely named Khovd have similar landscapes but are much smaller towns.

metas.title: Ölgii
metas.description: Ölgii is a large town in the west, that is surrounded by close, dry rocky mountains. Towards the south end of town, there is a tall red & white radio tower, that can be seen from all across town and is quite distinct to Ölgii.

metas.title: Ulaangom
metas.description: Ulaangom is a northwestern town with large, distant, dark mountains to the southwest. Additionally, these distinct double lamp posts with a blue or green painted base can frequently be seen in Ulaangom.
metas.note: Rarely, double lamp posts can be found in other cities such as Baruun-Urt and Chinggis, but these towns have flat landscapes.

metas.title: Western Mountains
metas.description: In the westmost part of Mongolia, there is some very remote coverage showcasing the tallest mountains in Mongolia where you can see glaciers and snow-capped peaks. This area also has a unique Street View car with a green or black bag above the right side roof racks.

metas.title: Uvs Lake Shrubs
metas.description: East of Uvs lake, you can find a lot of these small shrubs and patchy grass in a somewhat flat landscape.
metas.note: Similar shrubs can be found around Shaazgai Lake, but that area is considerably more hilly.

metas.title: Khan Khokhii Park
metas.description:
Khan Khokhii is a national park in northwestern Mongolia with some of the most dense forests in the country. It has partially cloudy skies, dark soil, and the western grey tent.

Keep in mind that the trails in this park do not appear on the map.
metas.note: There are other forests in Mongolia, but Khan Khokhii is one of the biggest and one of the only areas where you can be completely surrounded by trees.

metas.title: Gobi Gurvan Saikhan
metas.description: The Gobi Gurvan Saikhan National Park, in the far south of Mongolia, features bright orange sand and sand dunes. There are two separate spots covered in the park: one in the middle just north of Sevrei, which has distant southern mountains, and the other in the far southwest corner of the park, which has a Jeep follow car.

metas.title: Yolyn Am Valley
metas.description: Yolyn Am Valley is located just west of Dalanzadgad and can be identified by the extremely foggy coverage, and having dark coloured soil and hills.

metas.title: Khoridol Saridag Valley
metas.description: This beautiful river valley, just west of Lake Hatgal in the Khoridol Saridag mountains, is very recognizable from the surrounding rocky cliffs and forests, and the ground that is completely covered in pebbles.

metas.title: Nighttime Coverage
metas.description:
Mongolia has four main areas of nighttime coverage. Those areas are:

Northwest of Murun

West of Dashbalbar

South of Baruun-Urt

East of Dariganga

All of these locations are driving towards town. Driving direction and car meta can help identify which area of nighttime coverage you are in.

metas.title: Rainstorm Coverage
metas.description: East of the town of Khorgo there is a large stretch of road which was driven during a rainstorm. It features much darker skies, rain drops on the camera, and occasionally a rainbow can be seen.

metas.title: Black-White Plates
metas.description: Nepali licence plates are typically fairly long, with the most common design being white. Private vehicles use red plates, while public vehicles use black ones.

metas.title: Shitcam Coverage
metas.description: All of the road coverage in Nepal was taken with what’s commonly referred to as “shitcam”, which is a low-quality camera that can typically be recognised by the brownish colours and often, but not always, by a large circular blur covering the Street View car.
metas.note: Shitcam coverage is also very common in India and can rarely be found in Bangladesh and Sri Lanka.

metas.title: Left-Hand Traffic
metas.description: Nepal drives on the left side of the road.

metas.title: Devanagari Script
metas.description: Nepal uses the Devanagari script, which can be recognised by the line going through the top of each word and the straight vertical lines found in the majority of all letters.
metas.note: The characters ङ and especially ङ्ग are much more common in Nepali than in Hindi/Marathi. It is also quite common to find native Devanagari numbers on signage in Nepal, which is very rare in India.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description:
Nepal typically uses square concrete poles in the flat areas, and thin metallic poles in the mountainous regions. The poletops vary, but it is often some kind of trident.

The concrete pole with a trident pole top and triangle supports is unique to Nepal. Another common pole almost unique to Nepal is a concrete square pole with 2 vertical insulators on the sides with a wide gap between them. Other poles can often appear very similar to poles in India.

metas.title: Yellow Road Lines
metas.description: Nepal commonly uses outer yellow road lines that are either dashed or solid, with dashed white lines in the middle of bigger roads. Solid outer yellows are very common in eastern Bagmati province.

metas.title: Striped Bollards
metas.description: Nepal mainly uses black-and-white striped concrete bollards that often have a red marking on the top. The amount of stripes vary from 3 to 5.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: You will see flat agricultural areas in the south as well as high altitude mountain roads in the northern half of Nepal.

metas.title: Most Buildings Either
metas.description: Most buildings are either colorful blocky multi-story structures or small houses with painted concrete, red brick, or thatched looking walls, with either a tiled or tin roof. As part of the building facade, you will often spot triangle shaped decorations.

metas.title: Nepal Uses Black-and-white
metas.description: Nepal uses black-and-white striped signposts.
metas.note: Within South and Southeast Asia, India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and Malaysia also use black-and-white striped signposts.

metas.title: Nepal Features
metas.description: This type of white-painted buddhist stupa, sometimes with painted eyes on the sides, are only found in Nepal.

metas.title: English Features
metas.description: Districts can show up on addresses, often in English as well.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The area in the far south close to the Indian border is almost completely flat, while the central and northern parts are very high altitude and very mountainous.

metas.title: Dense Vegetation
metas.description: The western hills can be recognised by the dry landscape, with a lot of exposed hillsides lacking vegetation.

metas.title: Areca Palms Be
metas.description: Areca Palms can be recognised by their very thin trunk and a small crown. They are mainly found in the southeast.

metas.title: Canola Crop With
metas.description: Canola, a crop with bright yellow flowers, is mostly found in a few southern pockets in the western half of Nepal.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Chir Pines, which can be identified from their generally smooth-looking conical or spherical crowns with very long needles, are found everywhere in the mountains, but are much more common in the west, and near Kathmandu.
metas.note: The eastern region is generally greener than the west.

metas.title: Grass With White
metas.description:
Grass with white and fluffy-looking tips is most commonly found just southeast of Kathmandu.

While it can be found in most of the country, it usually won’t look as white and fluffy outside the dark red coloured region.

metas.title: Japanese Cedar Trees
metas.description: Japanese cedar trees, which are only found in far eastern Nepal, can typically be recognised by their significant height combined with their narrow, fluffy-looking crowns.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Tea Plantations are also only found in far eastern Nepal. Both in the mountains, and in the flat region.

metas.title: Rounded Roof Tiles
metas.description: Rounded roof tiles are most common in the flat regions south of Kathmandu, but are also prevalent further west.
metas.note: Don’t mix this up with the half-rounded tiles, which are part of the hint below this.

metas.title: West Bengal Style
metas.description: West Bengal style roof tiles, which are more organised and have small diamond shaped protrusions, are most common in the far west flat region. This hint also works for the half-rounded tiles.

metas.title: Birgunj Features
metas.description: Flat square shaped stone tiles that are grey in colour are common south of Kathmandu, more specifically around Birgunj and Janakpur.
metas.note: Neat, square, stone tiles are not found in parts of India that tend to look similar to Nepal.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Rectangular tiles that are less organised in shape and placement are common in western mountain towns, but can also be found towards the center of the country.

metas.title: Roofs Made From
metas.description: Roofs made from sheets of corrugated metal are most common between Birgunj and Janakpur.

metas.title: Valley Landscape
metas.description: Roofs that have a railing along the sides of the roofs, usually made of dark concrete, are found in some parts of western Nepal. They are most common in the Tulsipur valley, where the railings sometimes have a stair shape. The easternmost region where they’re found is the plains by Kawasoti. The westernmost regions often have lower quality “railings”, sometimes consisting of a few sticks.

metas.title: Kawasoti Features
metas.description: Gable ends decorated by carvings of gods, goddesses, and other religious symbols, usually painted in a golden colour, are mostly around Kawasoti, west of Bharatpur.

metas.title: Fences Varying Build
metas.description: Fences of varying build quality, made of mainly sticks, are most commonly found in the eastern plains of Nepal.

metas.title: Far East
metas.description: In the far east, you will mainly see roofs made of sheet metal with a triangular "window" just below the ridge of the roof, and an outwards sloping section below it.

metas.title: Biratnagar Hills
metas.description: Large hip roofs made of sheet metal with a small protrusion just below the ridge are found around Biratnagar in the east.

metas.title: Biratnagar Hills
metas.description: Similar to the above hint, hip roofs made of sheet metal with an even smaller protruding piece of metal at the ridge are mainly found west of and around Biratnagar.

metas.title: Mosques Concentrated Few
metas.description:
Mosques are concentrated in a few muslim majority spots in southern Nepal.

In the east, just around Janakpur.

In the east, just around Birgunj.

In the west, just around Nepalgunj.

In the east, around Biratnagar and west of the Koshi river.

metas.title: Birgunj Features
metas.description: Small round clay huts with thatched roofs are mainly found around Birgunj.
metas.note: These are also common just over the border in India.

metas.title: Utility Poles
metas.description: Poles with a cross attached near the top are common in the east.

metas.title: Utility Poles
metas.description: In Kathmandu, you’ll find poles with an asymmetrical crossbar, which has a triangular attachment on top of it, as well as a support bar below it.

metas.title: Nepal Features
metas.description: While the most common water tank colours in Nepal are green and black, which are found everywhere, yellow ones are mainly found in the east.

metas.title: Orange Google Car
metas.description:
An orange google car can be found around:

Nepalgunj in the west

Madi, south of Bharatpur in the central south

Biratnagar in the east

Birtamod in the far east.

metas.title: Biratnagar Features
metas.description: An orange car with a blue ribbon on the front is found around Biratnagar.

metas.title: Blue Car Found
metas.description:
A blue car is found around:

Pokhara, under the Nepal label

Birgunj, southwest of Kathmandu

Malangawa, near the Indian border southeast of Kathmandu.

metas.title: Pokhara Features
metas.description: If the blue car has an antenna, you will be around Pokhara.

metas.title: White Car Be
metas.description:
A white car can be found in the following areas:

Around Butwal, southwest of the Nepal label

On the H10 going to Pokhara

On the H04 east to Kathmandu

On some roads near Kathmandu

Northeast of Birgunj, southwest of Kathmandu

From Janakpur to Lahan, southeast of Kathmandu

Around Itahari, in the east.

metas.title: Janakpur Features
metas.description: A car with a black spoiler is found just around Janakpur, southeast of Kathmandu.

metas.title: Kathmandu Features
metas.description: A regular grey car can be found around Kathmandu, and to the southeast, around Lahan.

metas.title: Blocky Grey Truck
metas.description: A blocky grey truck can be found east of Birgunj and just south of Kathmandu.

metas.title: Grey Car With
metas.description:
A grey car with a visible backlight can be found in the following areas:

Around Pokhara, under the Nepal label

Around Kathmandu

North of Malangawa, near the Indian border southeast of Kathmandu

East of Itahari, in the east.

metas.title: Kathmandu Features
metas.description: A red car, that usually has a long antenna, can be found in Kathmandu, and north of Janakpur, which is southeast of Kathmandu.

metas.title: Regional Buses
metas.description: Some roads north of Siddhicharan, in eastern Nepal are unique due to the high elevation hills with dark green rhododendron bushes growing in abundance. The bushes have red flowers which can be hard to see.

metas.title: Foggy And Gloomy
metas.description: This foggy and gloomy road hosts the only natural forest dominated by east himalayan fir. You can recognise it from all the tall dark trees present around the road. It is located just northwest of Bhimeshwor Municipality, east of Kathmandu.

metas.title: Sketchy Yelloworange Dirt
metas.description: This sketchy yellow/orange dirt road can be recognised from the high elevation landscape with the high elevation oaks. It can be found northeast of Phungling in far northeastern Nepal.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: This dirt track in a northwestbound valley can be recognised by the snowcapped mountains to the northwest. You can find it north of the Khaptad national park in western Nepal.

metas.title: Limited Coverage Map
metas.description: Trekker coverage in Nepal is limited to the northeast of the country, in the general area southwest of Mount Everest.

metas.title: Green Forests And
metas.description: Green forests and trees are found in the southern parts of the Nepalese trekker coverage.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Barren mountain trails are found in the northern parts of the coverage.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: A lot of the coverage in the vicinity of Namche Bazar can be summarised as being sunny, with the trails going close to the treeline, meaning you will be either near the top of or just above a forest for most of this coverage. You will generally see barren or snowy mountains in some direction.

metas.title: Bazar Features
metas.description: Namche Bazar is by far the largest and most densely populated settlement with trekker coverage. There is also some coverage looking down on the town.

metas.title: City Features
metas.description: The southernmost trekker coverage is situated in the town of Lukla, which can be recognised by the narrow street with relatively large buildings, combined with the extremely dark coverage.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description:
Khumjung village, situated just north of Namche Bazar, can be recognised by the jagged mountain towering above the village. Almost every house in the village has a green roof.

Beware that there is a label for Khumjung further north, which is not close to the village.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description: Pangboche is a fairly large settlement with fairly bright coverage. The surrounding landscape mainly consists of forested mountains nearby and some taller mountains in the distance.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Phorste is a fairly scarcely built settlement with a massive recognizable mountain close by. There are a lot of dead-looking trees surrounding the village.

metas.title: Valley Landscape
metas.description: Around the southern tip of the Nepalese trekker coverage, you will get this dark, overcast coverage inside a forested valley.

metas.title: Valley Landscape
metas.description: North of Phakding you will get more overcast coverage in the same forest valley, however here the coverage is far brighter.

metas.title: Valley Landscape
metas.description: The coverage from Monjo up to Namche Bazar is also within the same valley, however here the coverage is mostly sunny and bright.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The valley by Thamu can be recognised by the generally forested mountainsides, combined with the angle of the valley, going northwest to southeast.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: Next to the village of Thame you can see this snowy, and shining bright mountain range.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Northeast of Namche Bazar, you can find this semi-green river valley with clouds covering all mountains surrounding it.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: On a section north of Phorste, you get a view of the mountain Tobuche, covered in a blanket of clouds.

metas.title: Further North Cloud
metas.description: Further north, the cloud blanket is replaced by small, spotty clouds somewhat resembling smoke coming out of chimneys.

metas.title: Even Further North
metas.description: Even further north, the clouds disappear completely, and you get a clear view of the Tobuche peak.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Leaving Tobuche behind, you will find this small, ice-covered lake, right by Gokyo, with jagged mountains as a backdrop.

metas.title: Lake Views
metas.description: North of the icy lake, you reach a barren landscape, with a trail going to the north-north-west.

metas.title: Valley Landscape
metas.description: East of Gokyo, you reach this dried out glacial valley, with bright grey rocks as far as you can see.
metas.note: This valley can less commonly be seen from the trail north of Gokyo.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: East of the glacial valley, you get to a somewhat red-coloured, rugged mountainside right next to the trail.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Leaving the red mountainside behind, you enter a somewhat U-shaped valley, going firmly upwards.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Above the U-shaped valley, you get a view of this spiky mountain range. While there are some clouds around the peaks, they are mostly clearly visible.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: As you lose sight of the spiky mountains, you cross over a glacier, which is the largest patch of snow covered ground with coverage in the country.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The area east of the glacier can be recognised by the many irregular clouds spread across the sky and covering various mountain peaks.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Further along the trail, you get this stunning view over Tobuche from the eastern side. The mountains get increasingly covered in clouds to the west.

metas.title: Valley Landscape
metas.description: Closing in on the final trek toward Everest, you get a view of this wide, high-altitude river valley.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Slightly east of Namche Bazar, you can find this very overcast trail following the mountainside. There are still some trees around, and the trail is noticeably higher above the valley than other overcast sections with trees.

metas.title: East Poi Called
metas.description: East of the POI called ‘Deboche’, you get this very overcast forest coverage. The dirt here is very bright and sandy, which can help differentiate it from the southern trail.

metas.title: Hazy Mountains
metas.description: You can recognise the trail between Pangboche and Dingboche by the massive mountains, combined with the sun looking somewhat hazy.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: North of Dingboche, you reach a high-altitude valley with very low clouds covering the sky and most of the surrounding mountains.

metas.title: Closing Everest Get
metas.description: Closing in on Everest, you get this completely barren landscape, with the trail going to the north-north-east.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description: Reaching the endpoint of the coverage, you finally get a stunning view of the world's tallest mountain, Mount Everest.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: Coverage in Pakistan was mainly taken with a Generation 3 trekker camera.

metas.title: Urdu Language
metas.description:
While many languages are spoken in Pakistan, Urdu is considered the National language and most commonly found on signage. It is written in the Urdu alphabet, which is closely related to the Arabic alphabet and may appear almost indistinguishable, however Urdu often uses softer and curvier fonts.

Notably, English is also an official language in Pakistan and is fairly common on signage.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Pakistan uses short licence plates and each region has its unique design. However, as all of the coverage was taken in Punjab, most plates will have the Punjab design, with a green strip on the left side. Fully green plates are also fairly common.
metas.note: India primarily uses long licence plates.

metas.title: Historic Fortress
metas.description: A significant portion of the Pakistani coverage was taken in large, well ordered gardens, often surrounded by stone walls and in combination with old temples or fortresses. This type of garden is typically referred to as a Mughal garden.

metas.title: Pakistan Features
metas.description: Typically brightly coloured, baggy pants are very common in Pakistan.
metas.note: This is mostly useful to differentiate it from Generation 3 trekkers in India, where pants tend to be tighter.

metas.title: Limited Coverage Map
metas.description:
Coverage in Pakistan is extremely limited, only being found in Punjab around major temples and tourist attractions.

Due to the number of distinct coverage spots, this section will only focus on the parts that are considered pinpointable.

metas.title: Lahore (Grey Car)
metas.description: You may find this grey car, with a visible right side, driving around Lahore Fort in the north of Lahore.
metas.note: This is considered hidden coverage, as it can not be accessed normally on Google Maps. It can however be accessed in the Map Making App and is still included in some community-made maps.

metas.title: Lahore (Urban Trekker)
metas.description: Just south of Lahore Fort you can find a trekker walking around some narrow urban streets that are typically very busy.
metas.note: This is also hidden coverage.

metas.title: Historic Fortress
metas.description: Lahore Fort is a large fortress in Lahore, with the Alamgiri Gate being one of the most iconic monuments in Pakistan.

metas.title: Inside Lahore Fort
metas.description: Inside Lahore Fort you may find this road completely surrounded by tall red brick walls on both sides.

metas.title: University Campus
metas.description: The Government College University of Lahore can be recognised by its gothic architecture.

metas.title: King Edward Medical University (Patiala Block)
metas.description: The Patiala Block of King Edward Medical University in Lahore is a large white colonial building with large white domes having black lines going around them.

metas.title: Kinnaird College
metas.description: Kinnaird College for Women University is mainly made up of traditional Pakistani red brick buildings, often combined with red brick paths.

metas.title: Jallo Features
metas.description: The coverage in Jallo, an eastern suburb of Lahore, can be recognised by the semi-urban coverage in a fairly poor-looking neighbourhood, with a very thick haze.

metas.title: Bahria Grand Hotel
metas.description: Bahria Grand Hotel, in the southwestern suburbs of Lahore, can be recognised by the minigolf course in front of the hotel. There is also a statue of a cow by the entrance to the hotel grounds.

metas.title: Harappa Museum Path
metas.description: West of Sahiwal, just northwest of Harappa, you can find a trekker starting in the south at Harappa Museum. This trekker can be recognised by most of the coverage being taken on a very narrow path made of concrete.

metas.title: Lake Views
metas.description: Hiran Minar is a small temple, completely surrounded by a small lake with a single bridge connecting it to land, can be found just northwest of the city of Sheikhupura.

metas.title: Kasur (Shrine of Hazrat Baba Bulleh Shah)
metas.description: The coverage around the shrine of Hazrat Baba Bulleh Shah, in western Kasur, can typically be recognised by the mosque with a large green dome, and two smaller green domes on top of the minarets. While the mosque itself isn’t visible from all of the coverage, the minarets can be seen from most spots.

metas.title: Pākpattan (Market Street Rug Roof)
metas.description: In Pākpattan you can find a busy market street with a roof made of rugs.
metas.note: Like the car coverage in Lahore, this, and the rest of the coverage in Pākpattan, is hidden coverage.

metas.title: Pākpattan (Busy Urban Street)
metas.description: Just west of the market street in Pākpattan you can find a very busy-looking urban street.

metas.title: Pākpattan (Narrow Alleyway)
metas.description: You can also find this narrow alleyway in Pākpattan, just north of the market street.

metas.title: Historic Fortress
metas.description: Rohtas Fort, west of Jhelum, can typically be recognised by the almost black fortress walls. While the walls aren’t always nearby, they can usually be seen in the distance.

metas.title: Katas Raj Temples
metas.description: The coverage in Katas, north of Sargodha, can be recognised by the hazy sky combined with the hilliness.

metas.title: Patriata Pine Forests
metas.description: Patriata, northeast of Islamabad can be recognised by the hilly forests, mainly consisting of tall pine trees. Interestingly, parts of the coverage were taken from an aerial lift.

metas.title: Changa Features
metas.description: The coverage in Changa Manga Forest Park can be recognised by the path angle being northeastern, and the narrow channel closely following the path, either on the northern or southern side.

metas.title: Concrete Roads
metas.description: Concrete roads are extremely common in the Philippines.
metas.note: Thailand also has a lot of concrete roads.

metas.title: Driving Side
metas.description: The Philippines drives on the right.
metas.note: Within Southeast Asia, Cambodia, Laos and Taiwan also drive on the right.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Standard white licence plates with black text are used for passenger vehicles. You can also find many that are privately issued, which are recognizable due to their green tint.

metas.title: Octagonal Poles
metas.description: Octagonal metal poles are quite common in the Philippines.
metas.note: They can sometimes be found in Bangladesh and some parts of Malaysia as well.

metas.title: Pole Insulator
metas.description: You will often see a single insulator at the top of a vertical bar which is attached to the side of a utility pole.

metas.title: Road Lines
metas.description:
Middle road lines in the Philippines can be either yellow or white. In particular, you will often see combined yellow and white middle lines, which is not common in any other East Asian country.

Yellow road lines commonly have a distinct orange tint.

metas.title: Yellow Kilometre Stones
metas.description: These tall, square yellow road stones are unique to the Philippines.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description: Chevrons are typically red on white.

metas.title: Sign Posts
metas.description: Sign posts are often painted red, orange or yellow.

metas.title: Tuk-tuks
metas.description: Tuk-tuks, also referred to as tricycles, are extremely common in the Philippines, in many areas they are more common than typical cars.

metas.title: English Language
metas.description: Although Filipino is the official language of the Philippines, English is extremely common to find on signs. It is the only major Southeast Asian country where you’re likely to come across English.

metas.title: Gen 3 Car
metas.description:
In Generation 3 you can come across a white Street View car with the black roof clearly visible.

You may also come across a silvery grey car, which is also found in Bhutan.

metas.title: Drying Grains
metas.description: It is somewhat common to see grains being spread out on roads to dry.
metas.note: This practice is also common in Vietnam.

metas.title: Pole Boxes
metas.description:
These black or white boxes are commonly seen on utility poles. Most of the time they feature a three letter abbreviation of the municipality you are in. The abbreviations will either have all three letters stand for the municipality, or the first two letters will abbreviate the municipality while the third letter indicates the province.

In the first image the "GMI" and "GMU" stands for the town of Gamu in the province of Isabela while the second image the "BGE" stands for the town of Bangued.
metas.note: Most towns do not have any standardised abbreviation so you might find many different abbreviations for the same place.

metas.title: Tuk-tuk Map
metas.description:
The Philippines have several different tuk-tuk and tricycle designs, roughly distributed as shown in this infographic.

This image was provided by AeroGelo. You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Province Names
metas.description:
Province names are very common to find on signs and can thus be very useful. However, they do not appear on the map, meaning they’re necessary to memorise in order to use them.

It is worth mentioning that Davao de Oro changed its name from Compostela Valley in 2019.

metas.title: Phone Codes
metas.description: Landlines will start with a 0 followed by the area code. Mobile phone numbers start with 09.

metas.title: Motorcycle Plates
metas.description: Motorcycles in the Philippines have regional colour-coded plates as seen on this map. Notably, the northern half of the country has the coloured strip at the top, while the southern half has it on the bottom of the plate.

metas.title: Northern Luzon Mountains
metas.description: The forested mountain range in Northern Luzon is characterised by somewhat dry mountainsides and an abundance of pine trees. You may rarely come across a similar landscape on high-altitude roads in Mindanao.

metas.title: Corn
metas.description: While corn can be found in most of the country, it is most common on northern Luzon and on Mindanao.

metas.title: Oil Palms
metas.description: The vast majority of Oil palm plantations are found on Mindanao.

metas.title: Sugarcane
metas.description: The majority of sugarcane in the Philippines can be found on the islands of Negros and Panay.

metas.title: Pineapples
metas.description: Pineapple plantations are mostly found on Mindanao.

metas.title: Bananas
metas.description: Banana plantations are almost exclusively found in central and southern Mindanao.
metas.note: Wild growing banana plants can be found all over the country, so make sure what you are seeing is an actual plantation before guessing.

metas.title: Mindanao Trees
metas.description: Moluccan albizia are trees with light coloured trunks and pinnate leaves near the top of the tree. They are mainly found on Mindanao and are especially common in the eastern and central regions of the island.

metas.title: Diamond Pattern Houses
metas.description: Houses built with amakan walls, a traditionally woven bamboo mat, with a diamond pattern are almost exclusively found in the southern half of the country.

metas.title: Palawan Pattern Houses
metas.description: Houses built with amakan walls (referred to as Sawali in the north) with a diagonally woven pattern are mostly found on the island of Palawan, but can also be found throughout the northern half of the country.

metas.title: CAR Guardrails
metas.description: In the Cordillera Administrative Region you can find yellow and black striped concrete guardrails.

metas.title: Bicol Guardrails
metas.description: White guardrails with three recurring black stripes are unique to the region of Bicol in southern Luzon.

metas.title: Chile-style Poles
metas.description: Square concrete poles with an indent on both side, similar to the poles found in Chile, are mainly found north of Manila and in and around the city of Bacolod on the island of Negros.

metas.title: Manila Poletop
metas.description: A poletop made up of two tall vertical metal bars having an L-shaped cross-section which are connected via several thin wires, making it resemble a ladder, is unique to Manila and the surrounding area.
metas.note: You may sometimes come across similar looking poletops, with square bars instead of L-shaped ones, throughout the entire country. They will however almost never have more than two connecting wires.

metas.title: Zamboanga Poles
metas.description: Square metal mesh poles are found on Mindanao, mainly on the Zamboanga peninsula.
metas.note: Most of the poles found outside of the Zamboanga peninsula are found along highways and have poletops with three hanging insulators.

metas.title: Muslim Region
metas.description: While most of the Philippines is strongly Christian, a region of western Mindanao is majority Muslim.

metas.title: Mountain Dew Decorations
metas.description: Decorations made of neon-green Mountain Dew bottles are commonly found in the north, particularly on northern Luzon.

metas.title: Kuliglig
metas.description: This type of tractor, called a kuliglig, is mostly found on the plains around Cauayan on northern Luzon.

metas.title: Chocolate Hills
metas.description: On central Bohol you can find these distinct round grassy hills. The hills generally have dark brown soil beneath the grass, earning them the name of Chocolate Hills.

metas.title: Arayat Volcano
metas.description: The Arayat Volcano can be recognised by being completely surrounded by flat agricultural fields.

metas.title: Mayon Volcano
metas.description: The Mayon Volcano is one of the tallest mountains in the Philippines and can be recognised by its almost perfect smooth cone shape. Beware that it will very often be covered in clouds.

metas.title: Marawi Ruins
metas.description: In and around the city of Marawi, Mindanao you can find many destroyed houses and ruins from the Marawi siege in 2017.

metas.title: Bataan Death March Markers
metas.description: These large decorated white waystones, commemorating the Bataan Death March, can be seen along roads going from Mariveles and Bagac in the south to San Fernando in the north.
metas.note: The Bataan Death March continued from San Fernando to Capas by train, where a larger memorial has been built.

metas.title: Puerto Princesa Highway
metas.description:
The highway going south from Puerto Princesa on Palawan can be characterised by being very wide, often featuring six lanes, while simultaneously having very little traffic.

Along the road you will usually see this double electrical wire, which can help confirm your guess.

metas.title: Siquijor Lamp Posts
metas.description: Lamp posts on Siquijor are typically painted yellow, with black stripes at the bottom.

metas.title: Marinduque Statues
metas.description: Images and statues of ancient Roman soldiers can be found on the island of Marinduque.

metas.title: General Santos Car
metas.description: You may find this black Street View car with a visible roof rack in and around the city of General Santos.

metas.title: Bohol Car
metas.description: In northwestern Bohol you can find this Street View car with tape on the back.

metas.title: Corregidor Car
metas.description: An orange Street View car with visible side mirrors can be found on Corregidor Island.

metas.title: Mayon Car
metas.description: This vehicle with several thick black bars can be found just south of the Mayon Volcano.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Regular cars in Qatar have long, white licence plates with a maroon strip on the left. Trucks have square, black licence plates and police plates are blue.

metas.title: Qatar Car
metas.description:
The Google car will usually be blurred, with only the antenna on the left and a sliver of the car visible. Sometimes the entire white pickup truck can be visible. Rusty clips can be seen on the crossbar.

See the region guessing section for more information.

metas.title: Landscape
metas.description: Qatar's landscape is predominantly desert, with arid, and mostly flat expanses of sand as far as the eye can see. You will often not see a lot of trees or other greenery.

metas.title: Road Lines
metas.description: Qatar typically uses solid outer white lines with either white or yellow in the middle. More rarely, you can also find outer yellow lines too.

metas.title: Qatar Poles
metas.description: Qatar uses round poles with 3 insulators on the pole top, with the middle one being slightly higher. The crossbar also has 2 diagonal bars connecting it to the pole.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description: Qatar uses white on red and white on blue chevrons.

metas.title: World Cup Banners
metas.description: Since some coverage was taken before the 2022 World Cup took place, many banners can be seen mentioning the event.

metas.title: Crossing Signs
metas.description: Qatari crossing signs feature a man in a thobe.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Qatar is pretty well covered, with almost every main road and some side roads having coverage. Only the south and west lack coverage at the moment.

metas.title: Municipalities
metas.description: Qatar is divided into municipalities, further divided into numbered zones, which can be seen on street signs. This infographic shows which number corresponds to each zone.

metas.title: Northern Antenna
metas.description: This very short antenna is found in northern Qatar.

metas.title: Doha Antenna
metas.description: This fairly long antenna is found in and around Doha.

metas.title: Southwestern Antenna
metas.description: And this long antenna is mostly found in southwestern Qatar.

metas.title: Bollards
metas.description:
Bollards in Qatar are only found on a few roads, and you can easily tell them apart.

The horizontal road just west of Qatar map label uses black and yellow centre lines.

The horizontal road south of Madinat al Ka`ban has a lot more greenery and, the coverage is also very overcast.

The coastal road south of Fuwayrit has coastal shrubs all around, and you can often see the coast.

If the road doesn’t fit the above descriptions, guess on the long vertical road west of Qatar map label.

metas.title: Al Bayt Stadium
metas.description: Al Bayt Stadium can be recognized by the black and white horizontal stripes on the stadium along with the tent-like roof.

metas.title: Lusail Stadium
metas.description: Lusail Stadium, in Lusail, can be recognized by its golden bowl-like shape.

metas.title: Lusail Towers
metas.description: Four towers, resembling a screw thread, can be seen from almost every point in Lusail.

metas.title: Ahmed bin Ali Stadium
metas.description: A structure resembling a gahfiya can be seen around the Ahmed bin Ali Stadium, in Rawdat Al Jahhaniya district.

metas.title: Mall of Qatar
metas.description: The Mall of Qatar in Rawdat Al Jahhaniya can be recognized by the boxy appearance with many ads on the side of the building. Large car parks are also seen next to the mall.

metas.title: Education City Stadium
metas.description: Education City Stadium can be recognized by the large, grey cladding with a diamond pattern.

metas.title: Education City Roads
metas.description: Education City features distinct black-tiled roads.

metas.title: Education City Signs
metas.description: Brown street signs, often fixed to the ground, are seen in Education City.

metas.title: Khalifa International Stadium
metas.description: Khalifa International Stadium can be recognized by the dual arches shaped like a wide open mouth.

metas.title: The Torch Tower
metas.description: The Torch Tower can be seen from almost every point in the Baaya District, and can be recognized by its hyperboloid structure, along with it being the tallest building in Qatar.

metas.title: Bed Box (Lusail)
metas.description: This cardboard box in the right side of the bed is seen in Lusail. The rusty clips will also be visible.
metas.note: The box will not always be visible. Make sure to look out for other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Bed Box (Left - Ar-Rayyan)
metas.description: This black box on the left side of the bed is seen southeast of Ar-Rayyan, around the green area.
metas.note: The box will not always be visible. Make sure to look out for other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Bed Box (Right - Al Khor)
metas.description: The black box on the right side of the bed is seen in Al Khor, and in the green area around The Torch Tower and Khalifa International Stadium.
metas.note: The box will not always be visible. Make sure to look out for other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Airport Tripod
metas.description: A tripod was used to capture the interior of the Hamad International Airport. A unique tripod that captured the inside of a plane can also be seen here.

metas.title: Landscape
metas.description:
Singapore is a highly developed city-state, characterised by an overall cleanliness and orderliness.

Main roads are often divided, and commonly feature black-and-white curbs and double yellow outside lines. You will often see tall apartment blocks nearby.
metas.note: In many cases, this “general look” is all you need to easily identify Singapore. Nevertheless, we have listed some more specific tips below.

metas.title: Street Name Signs
metas.description: All street name signs in Singapore follow this unique format. They are green, with rounded edges and a distinct white font.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Most Singaporean licence plates are black, with white text. Occasionally, you will be able to see the British style white-and-yellow plates and very rarely red plates.
metas.note: Neighbouring Malaysia and Indonesia also use black plates with white text. However, the letters will usually be divided into two or three sections - this is not the case for Singaporean plates.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Directional signs are also green, with white letters and English writing.
metas.note: Expressways each have a three-letter code (e.g. TPE), making them easy to spot on signs.

metas.title: Square Road Signs
metas.description: Road signs in Singapore are unique in that they are always set on a square white background.
metas.note: Road signs in almost all other countries will not have this square background.

metas.title: Rain Trees
metas.description: Rain trees are seen all around Singapore, and are often planted along main roads.

metas.title: Road Warnings
metas.description: Warnings are often written on the road in large letters, such as the famous “HUMP AHEAD”.

metas.title: Buses
metas.description: Singaporean buses are mostly lime-green, making them easily recognisable. Other designs can also be found, for example the white-and-purple SBS Transit variants.

metas.title: Bus Stop Bollards
metas.description: Moreover, all bus stops are protected by concrete bollards with unique black-and-yellow warning bands.
metas.note: Similar, but not quite identical designs are found in some Malaysian cities.

metas.title: Bus Leaving Box
metas.description: In addition to the concrete bollards on bus stops, Singapore sometimes has a unique and yellow bus-leaving box with an arrow on the street.

metas.title: Traffic Lights
metas.description: Almost all Singaporean traffic lights follow this design and are supported by a curved sheet of metal containing several holes.

metas.title: Neighbourhood Signs
metas.description: Many streets are named after the neighbourhood they are in, especially in the suburbs.
metas.note: These neighbourhood names appear very quickly on the map, so you can save yourself a lot of time scanning for 5k’s that way. For example, the sign in the image refers to Street 31 in the neighbourhood of Ang Mo Kio.

metas.title: Tuas Industrial Area
metas.description: The Tuas planning area is an industrial area that is characterised by straight roads, industrial complexes, cranes and shipping containers, making it recognisable.

metas.title: Sentosa Island
metas.description: You can easily recognise the island of Sentosa thanks to the green signposts, winding roads and general resort feel. Occasionally you might see a green lane like this as well.

metas.title: Pulau Ubin Trekker
metas.description: The Generation 3 trekker on Pulau Ubin can be identified by the unusually rural forest coverage and the camouflage-type hat sometimes visible when looking down.

metas.title: St John & Lazarus Islands
metas.description: You can recognise St John and Lazarus Islands thanks to the Generation 3 trekker, the smooth asphalt roads and the sea almost always nearby.

metas.title: Kusu Island
metas.description: The miniscule Kusu Island is easily identifiable because of the red paving stones used for the entire pathway.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description:
South Korea uses a variety of different licence plates.

Pre-2006 plates are short and green. These will still show up in the street view coverage.

Post-2006 plates are white for private vehicles, and yellow for commercial vehicles. These can be long and short.

metas.title: Gen 3 Car
metas.description:
Almost all road coverage in South Korea is made with a Generation 3 camera.

In most, but not all, of the coverage, the back of the Google car is visible. You can see three colours: black, white and silver. The car never has an antenna.

metas.title: Season
metas.description:
A considerable amount of the coverage was made during autumn and winter.

Note that more pleasant-looking spring and summer coverage is also not uncommon.

metas.title: Hangul Script
metas.description: The Korean writing system (Hangul) is very unique and recognizable. One of its standout features is the presence of circles in many of its letters. This sets it apart from most other East Asian writing systems.

metas.title: Pole Markings
metas.description:
Utility poles almost always have these pole markings near the bottom, consisting of black and yellow diagonal stripes.

These markings look similar to the ones found in Taiwan. There are however two main differences:

In South Korea, the stripes do not reach all the way to the bottom, whereas in Taiwan they do.

In South Korea, the stripes are more yellow. In Taiwan, they have more of an orange tint.

metas.title: Pole Spike
metas.description: Most poles have a tapered “spike” on top.

metas.title: Driving Side
metas.description: South Korea drives on the right.

metas.title: Road Lines
metas.description: Roads generally have yellow middle lines and white outer lines.

metas.title: Red Block Markings
metas.description: You can sometimes see red block markings on the road.

metas.title: Warning Signs
metas.description:
Triangular warning signs have a yellow background.

Note that circular prohibition signs, such as speed signs, have a white background. Yield signs also have a white background.

metas.title: Street Signs
metas.description: Street signs will be blue, arrow-shaped and commonly hanging from a metal bar mounted to utility poles.

metas.title: Direction Signs
metas.description: Direction signs in South Korea have white text on a green background.

metas.title: Speed Bumps
metas.description: Speed bumps are often painted yellow and white.

metas.title: Crossing Signs
metas.description: South Korean pedestrian crossing signs can be easily recognised from the distinct pentagonal shape combined with the blue background.

metas.title: House Numbers
metas.description:
Korean buildings have very distinctive house numbers. They are blue and usually are shaped quite literally like a house. The full address of the building is written on them, in both Hangul and Latin script.

Some places have unique house numbers, which you can use to region-guess. More information about this can be found in the spotlight section.

metas.title: Wedge Bollards
metas.description: You will sometimes see these black and white wedge-shaped bollards. They have a round yellow reflector on the front, and a grey one on the back.

metas.title: Landscape
metas.description: The South Korean landscape is predominantly mountainous. It is very rare to not see at least some hills or mountains in the distance. Even in the flat areas, you can almost always see elevation on the horizon.

metas.title: Red Bricks
metas.description: Red brick is a very common building material in South Korea.

metas.title: Tiled Roofs
metas.description: Many buildings have traditional tiled roofs like these. These often have decorative elements on the corners, and tend to have sides that curve slightly upwards. Blue roofs are quite common.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: South Korea has fairly limited and very spotty coverage. Other than large highways, most of the coverage is concentrated in and around major cities.

metas.title: Phone Codes
metas.description: Area codes in South Korea increase to the south, from 02 in the north, to 064 on Jeju. It is also notable that Seoul has the only two-digit area code in the country.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description: Generation 2 coverage is almost exclusively found in Seoul and Busan. It can also be found on a couple of highways outside the cities, however almost all of that coverage has been overwritten.

metas.title: Rear Camera Car
metas.description: A small camera can be seen mounted above the brake light on the Street View car on coverage northeast of Seoul and around Pohang.

metas.title: Jeju Soil
metas.description: Jeju is a volcanic island with a lot of dark volcanic dirt, where you can also often see volcanoes in the distance.

metas.title: Jeju Rock Walls
metas.description: Jeju also has a lot of rock walls, made of dark volcanic rocks.

metas.title: Gimje Plains
metas.description: The area around Gimje can be recognised by being one of the only completely flat areas of South Korea, combined with the open, yellow-green fields along almost every road in the area.

metas.title: Hampyeong House Numbers
metas.description: House numbers in the Hampyeong region can be recognised from the large white section at the top of the sign.

metas.title: Sri Features
metas.description: Vehicles in Sri Lanka have long white front plates and short yellow rear plates.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: In most Generation 3 coverage, you will be able to see the front of the Google car partially through the blur: it is visible as blue-white-red patches, reminiscent of the French flag. The red patch is usually most visually distinct.
metas.note: This car is unique to Sri Lanka. Coverage in Ghana has a similar front of the car visible, but this coverage also has a roof rack.

metas.title: Gen 4 Low-Cam Coverage
metas.description:
All Generation 4 coverage is low-cam. This means that the camera on the Google car is intentionally set up lower than in most other countries. This can be recognized in two ways:

The car blur is significantly bigger. Generally, the bigger car blur is the most consistent way to recognize low-cam.

Roads look wider and objects around you are seen from a lower angle.

Note that Sri Lanka’s Generation 3 coverage is made with a normal height camera!
metas.note: All coverage in Japan and Switzerland is low-cam. However, landscape should be sufficient to tell these apart from Sri Lanka.

metas.title: Sri Lanka See
metas.description:
In Sri Lanka, you will see two scripts: Sinhala and Tamil. You will also sometimes see English, written in Latin script.

Sinhala is most common, and can be found throughout the entire country. It has a very curvy, ‘rounded’ look.

Tamil is more regionally limited. It has straighter lines. For an exact distribution, see the region-guessing section.
metas.note: Sinhala is unique to Sri Lanka. However, Tamil can also be found in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu.

metas.title: Concrete Poles
metas.description:
Sri Lanka typically uses concrete utility poles. Two pole types are common and distinctive:

Square poles with small pinholes in the sides. These pinholes are limited to the top part of the pole.

Poles with large see-through holes in the lower half of the pole (“holey poles“). These poles are unique to Sri Lanka.
metas.note: The square poles with small pinholes can look very similar to those found in Thailand. However, in Thailand the pinholes extend all the way to the bottom of the pole.

metas.title: Stone Bollards
metas.description: These short, wide stone bollards are unique to Sri Lanka. They have a tapered shape, with a black base and a white top.

metas.title: Waystones
metas.description: Tall, white concrete waystones with an indented section near the bottom containing a yellow road number, are unique to Sri Lanka.

metas.title: Signposts
metas.description: Sri Lanka commonly uses black and white striped signposts.
metas.note: Within South and Southeast Asia, such signposts are also found in Bangladesh, India and Malaysia.

metas.title: Road Lines
metas.description: Rural roads often have outside lines, but no middle lines. In the absence of other clues, this can sometimes be a way to decide a tough 50-50.
metas.note: Most small roads lack road lines entirely.

metas.title: Vegetation
metas.description: Sri Lanka is a tropical country. It usually has very lush, green vegetation. It is densely populated and many parts are covered in a patchwork of agricultural fields.

metas.title: Red Soil
metas.description:
Many parts of Sri Lanka have reddish soil.

Less commonly, you may encounter white, sandy soil.

metas.title: Palm Trees
metas.description: Palm trees are very common in Sri Lanka, more so than many other Asian countries.
metas.note: Palm trees are also very common in the Philippines.

metas.title: Tiled Roofs
metas.description: Houses often have orange or red tiled roofs. Due to wear and tear, these tiles often have an almost brown tint to them.
metas.note: Similar roofs are also common in parts of Indonesia.

metas.title: Buddhism
metas.description: The country is majority Buddhist: 70% of the population practise this religion. Throughout the country, you will often see signs of the religion, including temples, Buddha statues, stupas and the Buddhist flag.
metas.note: Thailand, Cambodia and Laos are also majority Buddhist.

metas.title: Other Religions
metas.description: A substantial minority of the population adhere to other religions: Hinduism (13%), Islam (10%) and Christianity (7%). These religions have strong regional distribution patterns; see the region-guessing section for more information.

metas.title: Tuktuk
metas.description: This style of tuktuk is common in Sri Lanka: it has a bulky shape and a black roof. They are usually coloured green, yellow or red, though other colours appear as well.

metas.title: Low-Quality Camera
metas.description: Google used a weird, low-quality camera in Sri Lanka. This camera is known as the official Ari (or “Shitcam”). It has a wide circular car blur and often somewhat brownish colours. A good map will not usually include this coverage, but it is good to be aware of its existence, in order to not be caught off-guard by it.
metas.note: Other tropical countries with shitcam include India, Cambodia, Ecuador and to a lesser extent Bangladesh.

metas.title: Phone Codes
metas.description:
Sri Lankan telephone numbers have 10 digits.

The first three digits of landline phone numbers are the area code. The first digit of that area code is always a 0, while the remaining two digits are shown on the map.

Mobile phone numbers always start with 07 and are not associated with any particular region.

You can click on the image to enlarge it. Image credit: Maccem.

metas.title: Religion Map
metas.description:
These maps shows the distribution of each of Sri Lanka’s four main religions. This can help with region-guessing when you spot a house of worship or other symbol associated with one of the religions.

Buddhism is found in most of the country but is mostly absent from the north and some parts of the east coast.

Hinduism is predominantly found in the north and parts of the east, as well as around the town of Nuwara Eliya in the central mountains.

Islam is strongest on the east coast, but not a majority in any district.

Christianity is mostly confined to the northwest, and is strongest around the town of Mannar.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Tamil Script
metas.description:
The presence of the Tamil script is strongly correlated with the distribution of Hinduism (though not all Tamils are Hindu and vice versa).

There are two groups that use the Tamil script:

Native Sri Lankan Tamils, who predominantly live in the north and the east.

Indian Tamils, who mostly live in and around the central Nuwara Eliya district.

Note that it is not uncommon to find bilingual Sinhala and Tamil signs far outside the area where Tamil is the predominant language. However, Tamil-only signage can be a strong indicator for one of the Tamil-majority areas.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Topography
metas.description:
This map shows Sri Lanka’s topography. Hills and mountains are strongly concentrated in the central-southern part of the country.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Wet Climate
metas.description: The southwest of Sri Lanka has a more wet climate that is characterised by lush, dense vegetation. Deep green tones dominate the landscape.

metas.title: Dry Climate
metas.description:
Conversely, the rest of the country has a slightly more dry climate. The vegetation is often lower and more open. The landscape usually has a mix of brown and green tones.

Note that the difference is not extreme, as the landscape in Sri Lanka never truly gets downright arid. However, with some practise, you can often learn to tell the difference. Your mileage may also vary depending on the season, local forest cover, or coverage type (Generation 3 often tends to make the landscape look more arid than it really is).

metas.title: Tea Plantations
metas.description:
Tea plantations are found in the central and southwestern parts of the country. They are most common in the area just west of Nuwara Eliya.

Tea plants look like small, compact shrubs with bright green leaves. They are usually planted in organised rows or clusters on hillsides.

metas.title: Horton Plains NP
metas.description: Horton Plains National Park has a very distinct and bait landscape, consisting of hilly plains covered in long grass. In the distance, you can see forests, but most of the park’s roads meander through a wide open landscape.

metas.title: Traditional Chinese
metas.description: Taiwan uses Traditional Chinese. It is one of the most complex scripts visible on street view, with intricate characters that consist of many strokes.
metas.note:
Hong Kong also uses traditional Chinese characters on signage.

Japanese uses some Chinese characters (kanji), meaning the script can look somewhat similar. However, Japanese will also have a considerable amount of more simplified looking characters (katakana and hiragana).

metas.title: Pole Markings
metas.description: Poles almost always feature these black and yellow diagonal-striped markings that run all the way to the bottom.
metas.note: Similar markings can be seen in South Korea. However, the markings are much shorter and do not run all the way to the bottom.

metas.title: Driving Side
metas.description: Taiwan drives on the right side of the road.
metas.note: Japan and Hong Kong drive on the left.

metas.title: Road Lines
metas.description: Roads in Taiwan generally feature double yellow middle lines with single white outer lines. Thinner roads sometimes use single dashed yellow lines instead.

metas.title: Outside Lines
metas.description: Roads with outside white road lines and no middle lines at all are common. In the absence of better clues, this type of road line can be a very good way to identify Taiwan.

metas.title: Red Outer Lines
metas.description: Red outer lines that indicate no parking are common in Taiwan, especially in cities. This is essentially unique to the country.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description: Taiwan uses black on yellow chevrons.

metas.title: Mirrors
metas.description: These mirrors with orange hoods are frequently featured in intersections and bends.

metas.title: Bollards
metas.description:
Taiwan uses these bollards with either two or three circular reflectors on a black rectangle.

You can also find these lollipop looking reflectors on guardrails, similar to the designs found in Japan.

metas.title: Drainage Ditches
metas.description: Concrete drainage ditches are commonly found on the side of roads.

metas.title: Transformers
metas.description: These distribution transformers that look like boxes are frequently found in Taiwan, especially in urban areas.They are mostly painted in dark green or grey.

metas.title: Architecture
metas.description: Architecture in Taiwan varies in designs, ranging from cramped, multiple-story housing to flat, single-story houses with backyards. Many residential buildings have a very boxy look. A lot of walls are covered in tiles, usually white. Sheds made out of tin are also featured, commonly painted in a light green colour.

metas.title: Gen 3 Black Car
metas.description: In Generation 3 coverage, you can find this black car with a long antenna and a red brake light in the middle, similar to the one you can see in Russia.

metas.title: Gen 3 Wide Blur
metas.description:
You can also find this Generation 3 car with a very large blur that covers the entire car and almost looks like low-cam.

Note that this is not the same as low-cam: the camera is still at a normal height, meaning you see the world around you from a normal vantage point.

metas.title: Counties Map
metas.description:
This is a map of the counties of Taiwan. Importantly, Taiwan has a couple of smaller islands and island groups with coverage that are fairly far away from the main island. It is important to be aware of these, as they often catch beginning players off-guard. These include:

Kinmen close to the coast of mainland China.

Lienchiang (Matsu Islands), also close to the coast of mainland China.

Penghu in the middle of the Taiwan Strait.

Green Island and Orchid Island, southeast of the main island. These two islands belong to Taitung County.

metas.title: Phone Codes
metas.description: Taiwan telephone numbers are 10 digits, with the first two digits indicating the area code. Area codes range from 02 to 08, increasing as you go south.
metas.note: Oftentimes the area code will be written within parentheses. Mobile numbers start with 09.

metas.title: Freeway System
metas.description:
Taiwan’s National Freeway system is organised so that odd numbers represent north-south roads and even numbers represent east-west. Generally, numbers also increase moving west to east and north to south. The 1 and the 3 are by far the longest, running across the west coast.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Township Roads
metas.description:
These signs indicate Township roads, with the character written before or above the road number indicating the county.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Pole Plaques
metas.description:
Many poles in Taiwan feature these blue plaques with strings of letters and numbers that act as precise coordinates.

For an example of how to read the plaques in-game, the only thing that is useful here is the string “E3264”. “BE08” can further narrow down the position but is not practical in-game.

“E” refers to the 50x80km rectangle from this map.

“3264” means that within the rectangle, we are 32% eastward and 64% northward.

This article explains how the string “BE08” can be further used to narrow down the exact coordinates of the telephone pole.

metas.title: Western Plains
metas.description: The central western plain of Taiwan mainly consists of flat to low rolling plains. It is common to find crops and other farmland in this area.

metas.title: Central Mountains
metas.description:
The central-eastern region that covers two-thirds of Taiwan consists of forested mountains.

The central mountain range that runs all the way to the south of the island is made up of tall mountains and rugged valleys. At high elevations, the vegetation can look less tropical and feature temperate or even coniferous trees.

metas.title: Hualien-Taitung Valley
metas.description: The Hualien-Taitung Valley is a thin and long valley located on the east coast of the island passing from Hualien City at the north to Taitung City at the south. It is very recognizable as it consists of flat gentle plains surrounded by densely-forested mountains to the east and west.
metas.note:
Most of the coverage on the east coast lies within this valley.

There are also other valleys in central Taiwan that can look similar.

metas.title: Yilan Plain
metas.description: The Yilan Plain is easily identifiable by the mountain ranges that are seen in the north, west, and south. Rice paddies are also extremely common as well as houses built right next to these fields.
metas.note: While the landscape on the surface can look quite similar to the valleys of Hualien and Taitung, unlike those two, you will almost never find mountains to the east in the plains of Yilan. Furthermore, the flat plains of Yilan are also generally more open.

metas.title: Kinmen
metas.description: The island of Kinmen can be recognized by these trees with fuzzy leaves lining the road and red-tinged soil.
metas.note: There is no Generation 4 coverage in Kinmen.

metas.title: Miaoli and Hsinchu
metas.description: Miaoli and Hsinchu share a landscape of low rolling hills and winding roads as well as sparse farmland with vegetation that can look messy and unkempt.

metas.title: Taichung
metas.description: Similarly, Taichung features these open plains surrounded by low mountains that are often in the distance.

metas.title: Areca Palms
metas.description:
Areca catechu, also known as areca palms or betel nut palms, are extensively found in central and southern Taiwan.

Areca palms are most common in the mountainous regions of Taiwan, you can still see dense areca palm patches in northern counties but they are few and far between.

metas.title: Coconut Palms
metas.description: Coconut palms (Cocos nucifera) are primarily found in the southern-half of the island, toward the coast.

metas.title: Norfolk Island Pines
metas.description: Norfolk island pines (Araucaria heterophylla) are extremely common in the county of Penghu, especially in tightly-packed rows next to roads.
metas.note: While these trees can be found on the main island as well, they are usually never found in such close proximity.

metas.title: Leafless Trees
metas.description: These leafless trees are most frequently seen in Penghu.

metas.title: Fish Farms
metas.description: Cultivated fish farms are mostly found right next to the coast in the western counties.They are generally seen in the southern-half of the island, anywhere from Changhua to Pingtung, but predominantly found in the counties of Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, and Kaohsiung.

metas.title: Tea Plantations
metas.description: Tea plantations are generally seen in mountainous areas all over Taiwan. You can find them commonly in Chiayi, Nantou, Hsinchu, and Miaoli.

metas.title: Pingtung Plantations
metas.description: These areca palm plantations are mostly found in the county of Pingtung.
metas.note: Plantations in Pingtung are mainly found in neat, organised rows like these, in the flat plains. While in most central and southern counties, they will be found in the mountainous areas. Additionally, the counties further north will also rarely have areca palms in the flat plains of the west coast.

metas.title: Disorganised Housing
metas.description: Old and disorganised housing units as well as tall dingy-looking apartment blocks are frequently seen in the urban areas of northern Taiwan.

metas.title: Taoyuan Apartments
metas.description: Taoyuan features these red brick and sometimes red tile apartment buildings.
metas.note: They can also be commonly spotted in the greater Taipei area and rarely in other urban areas but are most common in Taoyuan.

metas.title: Yilan Villas
metas.description: In Yilan, you can find these rich multiple-story villas.They come in all types of designs and are often gated.

metas.title: Penghu Houses
metas.description: White-tinged cream coloured houses are frequently seen in Penghu.

metas.title: Kinmen Houses
metas.description: You can find these small, traditional-looking houses in Kinmen.

metas.title: Lamp Stickers
metas.description:
Similar to the blue plaques found on utility poles, Taiwan also features stickers to ID the locations of lamps. These can be found on both lampposts and utility poles with lamps attached to them.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: White Speckles
metas.description: Pavement with white speckles is commonly found along the east coast.

metas.title: Kinmen Lampposts
metas.description: Kinmen often features lampposts with red and white diagonal stripes.
metas.note: Red and white striped markings are also found on the main island, especially in cities and urban areas.

metas.title: Kaohsiung Lampposts
metas.description: Similarly, lampposts with red and white diagonal stripes on a trapezoidal base are frequently found in Kaohsiung City.

metas.title: Yunlin Poles
metas.description: In Yunlin, you can find poles with a thicker support below the pole top.

metas.title: Chiayi Green Squares
metas.description: These green square stickers are typically seen on every pole in Chiayi City.

metas.title: Bent Sign Holders
metas.description: These bent sign and chevron holders with two black and yellow-striped stickers are only found in Pingtung, Kaohsiung, and Taitung.

metas.title: Raised Transformers
metas.description: Distribution transformers raised by a dark green holder are mostly found in New Taipei City and Keelung City.

metas.title: Blue Outer Lines
metas.description: Blue outer lines are almost entirely exclusive to Penghu.

metas.title: Orchid and Green Island
metas.description: The islands east of Taitung, Green Island and Orchid Island, are distinct due to the more tropical climate, abundance of coconut palms, and lush cliffs. Additionally, it is common to find run-down, concrete pavement.
metas.note: While the landscape between Green Island and Orchid Island are quite similar, a good way to distinguish the two is that Green Island frequently uses yellow outer lines. Additionally, Green Island is slightly more built-up.

metas.title: Matsu Islands
metas.description: Lienchiang County, also referred to as the Matsu Islands, is recognizable from the hilly landscape and frequent use of concrete roads. The coverage is overcast and this pavement can also commonly be found.

metas.title: Provincial Highway 8
metas.description:
The Provincial Highway 8 that runs from Taichung to Hualien is very recognizable, specifically in the Hualien part, due to the yellow guardrail that can be found all throughout the western half of the road in the county.

The eastern half of the road features these tall exposed-rock cliffs that tower over the road.

metas.title: Provincial Highway 20
metas.description: The Provincial Highway 20, specifically the part that runs through Yushan National Park, features tall mountains covered with coniferous trees. The road also utilises these tube-like double guardrails.
metas.note: This road is only covered in Generation 2 and 4. The Generation 4 coverage is very overexposed and features sunny weather.

metas.title: Taipingshan Road
metas.description: The road that leads up to Taipingshan National Forest in Yilan is distinct due to it often being very foggy when covered. Other features of this road include the coniferous trees and a guardrail with red legs.
metas.note: Certain parts of the roads feature a sunset in Generation 3.

metas.title: Hualien Plains
