metas.description: This open landscape with forests of short trees surrounding a narrow grassy road can be found in Hualien in the flat parts of Guangfu and Fenglin. This area can be distinguished due to it being commonly covered in Generation 2; however, you can find similar landscapes in Generation 3 and 4.

metas.title: Green Train Car
metas.description: A green train car can be found in east Chiayi around Alishan National Forest.

metas.title: Blue Truck
metas.description: A blue pickup truck can be seen in a few of the riverside parks in Taipei City.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Thailand uses large, white licence plates on passenger vehicles, and yellow ones on commercial vehicles.
metas.note: Within Southeast Asia, yellow commercial plates are only found in Thailand. Be careful, however, as Laos uses yellow licence plates for regular vehicles.

metas.title: Driving Side
metas.description: Thailand drives on the left hand side of the road.
metas.note: Cambodia and Laos drive on the right hand side.

metas.title: Bollards
metas.description: The Thai bollard is square shaped with a pointed top, and has black-and-white stripes.
metas.note: In Southeast Asia, these bollards are also found in Cambodia, Laos and Indonesia.

metas.title: Signposts
metas.description: Signposts in Thailand are square and bulky in shape, usually white, and often have the bottom painted black.
metas.note: In Southeast Asia, this design is unique to Thailand.

metas.title: Concrete Roads
metas.description: Concrete roads are common in Thailand. They often have a large square shaped pattern.
metas.note: In Southeast Asia, these can also be found commonly in the Philippines, and less commonly in Indonesia.

metas.title: Square Poles
metas.description: Thai poles are square and have small holes running vertically up the pole.
metas.note: You will see similar poles in Sri Lanka, Cambodia and Laos. Make sure to look for other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Thai Script
metas.description: Thai script is compact and in many fonts has tiny circles within most letters.
metas.note: The Cambodian (Khmer) script often has longer lines and more accents underneath the lettering, as opposed to the Thai script. The Lao script looks similar to the Thai script. Make sure to check the driving side before guessing.

metas.title: Middle Lines
metas.description: Thailand has yellow middle lines. These middle lines are either solid or dashed lines.
metas.note: Malaysia only has white middle lines.

metas.title: Lamp Post Stripes
metas.description: Street light poles have red-and-black or black-and-white stripes on the bottom.

metas.title: Lamp Posts
metas.description: Thailand has very distinct long, thin lamp posts that hang over the side of the road.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Directional signs on smaller roads are white, and are composed of two signs: one with an arrow at the bottom, and one with the information at the top. These can have place names. When they do not, you will see them as just the road number with a Garuda. Moreover, highway signs are green, and frequently feature the place names in Latin script below the Thai name.

metas.title: Stop Signs
metas.description: Stop signs in Thailand feature the Thai script, instead of Latin.
metas.note: Stop signs in Laos feature the Lao script, similar to Thai, but they have just 2 characters instead of 3.

metas.title: Road Markers
metas.description: These two road markers are generally found in Thailand. They will either have a white or a black Garuda on them.
metas.note:
White Garudas are found on country roads and appear white on the map, while black ones are found on province roads and appear dark blue on the map.

On the map, national roads are white-and-black, while provincial roads are blue-and-yellow.

metas.title: Flags
metas.description: Thailand often has many flags lining the side of its streets. Aside from the national flag, you can often see royal flags, which are usually yellow.

metas.title: Green Village Signs
metas.description: These distinctive green signs can be found all around Thailand, often in small villages.
metas.note: You will not find this sign in any other country.

metas.title: Gen 3 No Car
metas.description: Most Generation 3 coverage has no visible Street View car.
metas.note: Vientiane and some Generation 3 coverage in Cambodia will also not have a visible car. Bike trekkers and a white car with a brake light can rarely be found all throughout the country in Generation 3.

metas.title: Phone Codes
metas.description: Thai landline phone numbers have 9 digits. The first digits of phone numbers are the area code. The Bangkok area code is 02, the other area codes have three digits. The area codes are grouped, so even just learning the first digit is useful.
metas.note: Mobile phone numbers start with 08 or 09 and have 10 digits. None of these numbers overlap with the area codes. Numbers starting with 06 are also not regional.

metas.title: National Roads
metas.description: National roads are grouped into four regions based on their first digit. Roads beginning with 1 can be found in the north, 2 in the northeast, 3 in the centre and 4 in the south of the country.
metas.note: Large one- and two-digit highways may pass through multiple regions. Remember that this map does not apply to provincial roads.

metas.title: Province Abbreviations
metas.description:
Waystones and road signs on provincial roads will often provide a two-letter abbreviation of the province in Thai script. They will not appear on waystones or road signs for national roads.

You can use this site to view and practice all province abbreviations.

metas.title: Black Boxes
metas.description:
These black boxes will often provide a three-letter abbreviation of the province. Two formats are used:

Starting with the abbreviation followed by 4 numbers

Starting with TCC-L2, or rarely TCC-L1, followed by the abbreviation

Shown in the picture is the abbreviation “NTB” for Nonthaburi. The abbreviations may vary slightly in each province depending on the format.
metas.note: Other boxes may feature different formats that correspond to the subdistrict of the province.

metas.title: Islamic Influence
metas.description: The majority of Muslims in Thailand live in the very south of the country. In these areas, you will often see Islamic religious attire, Jawi script, based on the Arabic script, on signs and mosques.

metas.title: Flat and Dry Regions
metas.description: Thailand has two regions that are relatively flat and dry compared to other areas. One north of Bangkok, the other more east.
metas.note: The eastern area feels sometimes a bit drier than the area north of Bangkok.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description: Tall mountains are most often seen in northwestern Thailand.
metas.note: Some parts of the southern peninsular part are also mountainous.

metas.title: Low Mountains
metas.description: Low, smooth and forested mountains can be found in the centre-north of the country.

metas.title: Exposed Rock Mountains
metas.description: Steep mountains with a lot of exposed rock are most commonly found in the west and on the peninsula.

metas.title: Red Soil
metas.description: Red soil is most common in the northeast of Thailand, but can be seen throughout the entire country.

metas.title: Gravel Roads
metas.description: Gravel roads can be found all throughout Thailand, but are most common in the darkly highlighted areas.

metas.title: Rubber Wood Plantations
metas.description: Rubber wood plantations are typically seen in Thailand. Most of them are located in the south. You can recognize them by the small, black taps on the bottom of the tree's trunk.

metas.title: Rice Cultivation Area
metas.description: A majority of Thailand’s rice cultivation occurs within the highlighted area.

metas.title: Dry Season Rice
metas.description: Rice cultivated during the dry season is most common in the central plains. The dry season in Thailand can typically be recognized by a haze in the sky due to wildfires.

metas.title: Wet Season Rice
metas.description: During the wet season, the majority of rice cultivation occurs in the eastern plains.

metas.title: Palm Oil Plantations
metas.description: Over 90% of the palm oil in Thailand is produced in the south. This means that palm plantations are most often seen in southern Thailand.

metas.title: Short Coconut Leaves
metas.description: Dense plantations of short or medium sized coconut palms are most commonly found west of Bangkok.

metas.title: Tall Coconut Palms
metas.description: Slightly less dense plantations of tall coconut palms are most common in Prachuap Khiri Khan.
metas.note: The entire peninsula will have many coconut palms, this tip only refers to plantations.

metas.title: Palmyra Palms
metas.description: Large numbers of palmyra palms are typically found near the eastern coast of the peninsula, specifically just south of Bangkok as well as in the far south.
metas.note: Lone or small clusters of palmyra palms can be found all throughout the country.

metas.title: Areca Palms
metas.description: Areca palms are mainly found across the peninsula, but are especially common around Ranong.

metas.title: Sugar Cane
metas.description: Sugar cane is mostly grown in central and eastern Thailand.

metas.title: Cassava
metas.description: Cassava is a bush-like plant with digitate leaves. It can be found throughout most of Thailand, but is considerably more common in the central and northeastern plains.

metas.title: Corn
metas.description: Corn is most commonly found in the north and central regions of Thailand.

metas.title: Fruit Plantations
metas.description: The most extensive fruit plantations can be found in the valley between Chiang Mai and Lamphun as well as eastern Sa Kaeo and Chanthaburi.

metas.title: Durian Plantations
metas.description: Durian plantations are most common around Chanthaburi, but can be found around the peninsula and other areas. When they are young, they can be identified by their cone-shaped appearance. When fully grown, durian trees can be identified by their dark bark, branches that nearly reach the ground, and oblong leaves with pointed tips.

metas.title: Pineapple Plantations
metas.description: Pineapple plantations are most commonly found southeast and southwest of Bangkok.

metas.title: Eucalyptus Plantations
metas.description: Eucalyptus plantations are most common around Sa Kaeo.
metas.note: Eucalyptus can be found in smaller quantities, such as lining the road, in different areas. This tip is exclusively about dense plantations.

metas.title: Teak Trees
metas.description: Tectona grandis, also known as teak, is most commonly found in high densities in the north. It can be recognized by its large leaves and yellow flowers.
metas.note: Teak trees are often used for decoration along highways.

metas.title: Pine Trees
metas.description: Pine trees, specifically Pinus latteri, or Tenasserim pines, are more or less exclusive to the north and northwest of the country.

metas.title: Garden Croton
metas.description: Codiaeum variegatum, also known as garden croton, is a decorative plant recognised by its yellow, orange and red leaves. It is most common around Ranong and other coastal provinces.

metas.title: Corrugated Roofs
metas.description: Gray corrugated metal roofs are most commonly found in the north and south of the country, but can occasionally be found throughout the country.

metas.title: Indented Poles
metas.description: Regular poles with a Chilean style indent are found around Bangkok.
metas.note: Larger and thicker poles with indents are found on highways all throughout the country.

metas.title: Wind Turbines
metas.description: Wind turbines are most often found on the western side of Chaiyaphum and Nakhon Ratchasima as well as the eastern coast of Songkhla and Nakhon Si Thammarat.

metas.title: Chiang Mai Bollard
metas.description: This black bollard with three large white reflectors is most frequently seen in Chiang Mai and Mae Hong Son.

metas.title: 7 Ridge Insulator
metas.description: Insulators with 7 or more ridges are found in the southern half of the peninsula, as well as highways in Chiang Rai and Phayao.
metas.note: In the north, you may still find 5 or 6 ridges on insulators, as these are the standard amount throughout the country.

metas.title: One Insulator
metas.description: Poles with only one insulator on the crossbar can be found from south on the peninsula to Ranong and Chumphon.

metas.title: Utility Poles
metas.description: Conversely, poles with two insulators on the crossbar can be found in the rest of the country.

metas.title: Phuket
metas.description: The island of Phuket is very touristy and wealthy. You will often see modern buildings, resorts, and heavy traffic among hills.

metas.title: Gulf Islands
metas.description: Koh Samui and Koh Pha-Ngan are touristy islands with narrow, crowded roads and a tropical feel.

metas.title: Bangkok Taxis
metas.description: Bangkok uses pink and yellow on green taxis.
metas.note: Yellow on green taxis may rarely be seen elsewhere, but pink taxis are practically exclusive.

metas.title: Red Songthaews
metas.description: These red trucks, known as songthaews, are transport vehicles found most commonly in Chiang Mai.

metas.title: Bangkok Street Signs
metas.description: Street signs with a smaller green section underneath a blue section are found in Bangkok and Nonthaburi.

metas.title: Pattaya Street Signs
metas.description: Street signs shaped like a helm are exclusive to Pattaya City.

metas.title: Chiang Rai Street Signs
metas.description: Red street signs with golden decorated borders can be found in Mueang Chiang Rai.
metas.note: It is possible to see blue street signs with the same border in the city.

metas.title: Phrao Valley
metas.description: The Phrao District in Chiang Mai is a fairly flat valley surrounded by mountains in all directions. The valley will commonly grow rice and fruit.

metas.title: Doi Luang Chiang Dao
metas.description: Doi Luang Chiang Dao is the 3rd tallest mountain in Thailand. It along with other distinctly shaped mountains can be seen clearly from the Chiang Dao district of Chiang Mai.

metas.title: Phayao Mountains
metas.description: A large and slightly jagged north-south mountain ridge runs through the middle of Phayao. It can be seen to the east from afar.

metas.title: Western Tak
metas.description: Rolling hills of corn or sugar cane fields can be found in the west of the Tak province. In this area, paved roads are often very brown.

metas.title: Phetchabun Valley
metas.description: Large north-south mountains can be seen on either side of the Phetchabun valley.

metas.title: Kanchanaburi Fields
metas.description: Deep red fields with cassava and rubber trees can be found in Kanchanaburi.

metas.title: Lopburi Mountains
metas.description: These distinctly shaped mountains can be found in southwestern Lopburi.

metas.title: Saraburi Mountains
metas.description: The northern half of Saraburi consists of large, exposed rock mountains in an east-west orientation.

metas.title: Chaiyaphum Ridges
metas.description: Chaiyaphum features very long and flat mountain ridges that can be seen from nearly anywhere in the province.

metas.title: Khao Yai National Park
metas.description: The area around Khao Yai National Park in southern Nakhon Ratchasima is a large tourist attraction. You will see many advertisements, businesses, restaurants, and resorts along otherwise rural roads. Large rocky hills can be seen closer to the border with Nakhon Nayok and Prachin Buri.

metas.title: Mukdahan Hills
metas.description: The province of Mukdahan features many long, low hills among fields of rice, sugarcane, cassava and rubber trees.

metas.title: Khao Sam Roi Yot
metas.description: Khao Sam Roi Yot National Park in western Prachuap Khiri Khan features large, distinct exposed rock mountain massifs. Notably, the mountains can be seen from the center of the province.

metas.title: Khao Sok National Park
metas.description: Khao Sok National Park in northern Phang-nga and western Surat Thani features some of the tallest and steepest exposed rock mountains in the south of Thailand. The mountains generally run east-west.

metas.title: Western Krabi Mountains
metas.description: Western Krabi and parts of eastern Phang-nga also feature large exposed rock mountains running north-south.

metas.title: Southeastern Nakhon Ratchasima
metas.description: Brown paved roads among fields of sugarcane, cassava, and corn can be found in southeastern Nakhon Ratchasima.

metas.title: Southern Sisaket
metas.description: Brown paved roads among fields of bananas, durians, rubber, and corn can be found in southern Sisaket.
metas.note: Southeastern Nakhon Ratchasima may look similar at times.

metas.title: Lopburi Grid
metas.description: Southern Lopburi features a large, slightly north-north-west grid with fields of rice, corn, sugarcane, and cassava. Ridges can often be seen to the north, south and west.

metas.title: Pathum Thani Grid
metas.description: A large, almost perfectly north-south grid can be found in central and eastern Pathum Thani.

metas.title: Rayong Grid
metas.description: Western Rayong province features a northeast-southwest grid filled with modern and industrial buildings among fields of rubber trees, cassava, and pineapple.

metas.title: Highway 44
metas.description: Highway 44 going through Krabi and Surat Thani is a divided four-lane highway with very large spacing in the middle. Often, you will not be able to see the other side of the highway. Rather, a yellow inner line will imply that the road is divided.

metas.title: Southern Thailand Car
metas.description: This rare Google car with a visible mirror is only found in far southern Thailand.
metas.note: Due to most of the coverage being overwritten by new Generation 4, this car is rarely seen.

metas.title: Ko Sichang Car
metas.description: This rare Google car is only found on the island of Ko Sichang. It is recognizable due to the bar(s) protruding out of the blur.

metas.title: Khao Yai Smudge
metas.description: A smudge on the front left of the camera can be seen on the densely forested road going through Khao Yai National Park. This smudge can also be found in nearby areas of Nakhon Nayok and Prachin Buri.
metas.note: Other smudges may rarely exist elsewhere in the country.

metas.title: White-Blue Plates
metas.description: Turkey uses the same licence plates as most of Europe: they are long and white, with a blue strip on the left.

metas.title: Turkish Language
metas.description:
The Turkish language has a fairly unique look. It uses the following special characters:

Ç ç and Ş ş with a cedilla (“hook” below the letter).

Ö ö and Ü ü with an umlaut (two dots).

Ğ ğ with a breve.

Dotless I ı. This letter in particular is noteworthy, as it is essentially unique to Turkish. In case you are confused: this is similar to the letter i, but without a dot when written in lowercase.

Capital İ with a dot.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Turkish bollards have a simple design: rectangular, plain white, and with a red reflector on the front. They are thin when seen from the side.
metas.note: Romania has similar bollards. However, bollards are relatively rare in Romania.

metas.title: Yellow Road Lines
metas.description: The colour of Turkish road lines is somewhat inconsistent. Most roads simply have white road lines. However, it is not uncommon to see yellow road lines. These roads can have fully yellow lines, or a combination of yellow and white lines.

metas.title: Salt and Pepper Roads
metas.description: Many roads have pavement with a grainy “salt and pepper” texture.

metas.title: Mediterranean Landscape
metas.description: Divided highways are extremely common, especially compared to other Mediterranean countries.

metas.title: Red-White Chevrons
metas.description:
Turkish chevrons are typically red on white. Beware that there are some other regional variants.

Usually, the tip of the arrow does not touch the edge of the chevron. Some chevrons have a neon yellow border.

metas.title: Yellow-Black Chevrons
metas.description: On intersections, you can often find this distinctive black and yellow chevron, with multiple arrows that point upward.

metas.title: Red-White Chevrons
metas.description: Sometimes, you can see these narrow chevrons that have a red and white colour scheme.
metas.note: Almost identical chevrons can be found in South Africa.

metas.title: Direction Signs Use
metas.description: Direction signs use a very distinct font that can often be recognised by the noticeably wide letter spaces.

metas.title: Utility Poles
metas.description: Snow poles usually feature a colour sequence of black-orange-black-white from top to bottom, with small red reflectors.

metas.title: Stop Signs Have
metas.description: Stop signs have the word “DUR” written on them. This is unique to Turkey.

metas.title: Mediterranean Landscape
metas.description:
Turkey uses both main types of guardrails:

A-type guardrails, which have rounded edges.

B-type guardrails, which have square edges.

While most Mediterranean countries use the A-type, B-type can help solve some tough 50-50s. Furthermore, seeing both types will exclude all southern European and Middle Eastern countries, other than Montenegro and Israel & the West Bank. For a full overview of which guardrails are found in which European country, see this infographic.

metas.title: Metal Poles
metas.description: Metal poles, either in the shape of a ladder or with a mesh pattern, are extremely common in Turkey.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: In the Generation 3 coverage, the Google car never has an antenna.

metas.title: Turkey Features
metas.description: The Generation 4 coverage in Turkey typically features a white Google car. Usually, only a tiny sliver of the back of the car is visible. The car can have a short antenna, or no antenna at all.

metas.title: Pickup Truck Meta
metas.description: A grey pickup truck can be found in some Generation 4 coverage.
metas.note: Similar pickup trucks can also be found in Senegal and Kenya.

metas.title: Turkey Also Has
metas.description: Turkey also has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.

metas.title: Flat Agricultural Land
metas.description:
The Turkish landscape ranges from arid in the southeast to a Mediterranean landscape in the southwest. In the north you will often find a more forested and lush landscape. The most typical landscape is semi-arid, either rolling or flat, with vast agricultural fields, containing very limited vegetation other than crops.

Beware that Turkey is a very naturally diverse country with many landscapes that are not mentioned in this tip.

metas.title: Turkey Features
metas.description: Tall and somewhat square apartment blocks are very common in Turkey.

metas.title: Turkey Features
metas.description: Turkey is a muslim country, and as such mosques can be found in most towns. In particular, tall minarets are extremely common and a good clue for the country.

metas.title: Brick Pavement Very
metas.description: Brick pavement is very common in urban areas, and the bricks will typically have the shape shown in the image.

metas.title: Area Code Map
metas.description: Turkish area codes follow a fairly easy to learn pattern and can be very useful to get the general region. Most notably, the first digit of area codes are ordered from 2 in the west to 4 in the east.
metas.note: Phone codes starting with 5 are not regional.

metas.title: Turkey Has Three
metas.description: Turkey has three main types of numbered roads. The largest type are the O-roads, which on kilometre markers feature an O followed by a hyphen and the road number. The second largest type are the D-roads, which omit the “D” on kilometre markers and instead only feature a 3-digit road number, followed by the road section number on the top and the kilometre at the bottom. The section number will generally increase to the southeast.

metas.title: Language Features
metas.description: The third type of roads are provincial roads. While these generally aren’t labelled on the map, they can still be used to regionguess since the kilometre markers feature the provincial code as the first two digits on the sign. These codes generally increase alphabetically from 01 to 76 with some newer regions being unordered. Shown in the image is a road from the Afyon Province (03).

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description:
Generation 4 truck coverage is mainly found in the far east of the country and along the southern coast, with smaller pockets in the west and around Kastamonu.

For a more detailed look, see this document.

metas.title: Northern Turkey Tends
metas.description: Northern Turkey tends to be significantly lusher and more forested than the rest of the country.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: In the northeast you will find uncultivated grasslands in valleys surrounded by round hills. Trees are very limited in the region. In Generation 3 the area has an extremely distinct look, with deep green grass covering the hills. It is significantly more difficult to recognise in Generation 4, where the grass has a more arid look.

metas.title: Mediterranean Landscape
metas.description: Turkish pines (pinus brutia) are mainly found near the Mediterranean coast.
metas.note: Turkish pines can appear very similar to Aleppo pines, which are uncommon in Turkey, but are often found in other Mediterranean countries.

metas.title: Tea Plantations Common
metas.description: Tea plantations are common in the province of Rize.

metas.title: Mediterranean Landscape
metas.description: Olive trees are mainly found on the Mediterranean coast.

metas.title: Sunflowers Mainly Found
metas.description: Sunflowers are mainly found in northwestern Turkey.

metas.title: Turkey Features
metas.description: A majority of all vineyards in Turkey can be found in a region east of Izmir.

metas.title: Cotton Features
metas.description: Cotton is mainly found in the region surrounding the city of Şanlıurfa.

metas.title: Lake Views
metas.description: Lake Van is by far the biggest lake in Turkey and has a semi-arid landscape, being surrounded by dry grassy hills and occasional trees and agricultural fields near the shore.

metas.title: Dark Volcanic Rocks
metas.description: Dark, volcanic rocks are commonly found between the cities of Şanlıurfa and Diyarbakır.

metas.title: Valley Landscape
metas.description: River valleys surrounded by steep, barren and rocky cliff sides can be found between the cities of Erzurum and Artvin and in the southeast near the city of Hakkâri.

metas.title: Tiled Roofs Mostly
metas.description:
Tiled roofs are mostly found in the western two thirds of the country.

Note that for this and the following roof-related tips to be reliable, the majority of all visible roofs should preferably be of that type.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: Flat roofs are mostly found in the southeast and to a lesser extent along the south coast.

metas.title: Metal Roofs Most
metas.description: Metal roofs are most common in the east.

metas.title: Lake Views
metas.description: Sheet metal roofs shaped like low pyramids are mainly found far east, particularly in the general area surrounding Lake Van.

metas.title: Local Architecture
metas.description: Many buildings in the Nevşehir Province are built by large, light and unevenly coloured, sandstone bricks.

metas.title: Yellow-Black Chevrons
metas.description: Yellow on black chevrons are mainly found in and around the Balıkesir Province in the west and in the Kars Province in the far east. Beware that you may very rarely find them elsewhere.

metas.title: Yellow-Black Chevrons
metas.description: Black on yellow chevrons are mainly found north of Izmir.

metas.title: Road Markings
metas.description:
Four-lane divided highways with no divider, other than double middle road lines, are almost exclusively found in the eastern half of the country.

Beware that divided highways with clear dividers, such as guardrails, can still be found in the east.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: Vertical water tanks can be found in most of Turkey, but are notably uncommon along the south and west coast.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: Horizontal water tanks placed on top of vertical water tanks are primarily found in a line following the south coast and going up to Elâzığ.

metas.title: Square Water Tanks
metas.description: Square water tanks with angled corners are found in the south, approximately from İskenderun to Sanliurfa.

metas.title: White Spherical Water
metas.description: White spherical water tanks can be found in the southeast, mainly south of Batman.

metas.title: Utility Poles
metas.description: In the European part of Turkey, except Istanbul, utility poles, and other electrical infrastructure, will have a 6 digit code, which is often seen on a small pole plate under the yellow electricity warning plate.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description:
Street signs in the Ankara Province are blue with a small round top. Similar street signs can very rarely be found in Giresun.

Beware that some newer street signs are red.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description: Street signs in the Izmir Province are dark blue, noticeably bulge outwards and very commonly have the emblem of Izmir in white at the top of the sign.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: If you find yourself surrounded by greenhouses, you are likely to be along the south coast west of Adana.

metas.title: Local Architecture
metas.description: Around the city of Bodrum you will commonly find this type of whitewashed buildings with flat roofs, often combined with blue details or unpainted stone walls.

metas.title: Sandstone Buildings
metas.description: Göreme, west of Kayseri, can be recognised by the tall sandstone monoliths with ancient dwellings carved into them.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description: Mount Ararat, labelled as Ağrı Dağı on Google Maps, is a dormant volcano in far eastern Turkey and the tallest mountain in the country. It is often seen together with Küçük Ağrı, a smaller volcano to the southeast.

metas.title: Banana Plants Found
metas.description: Banana plants are found around the city of Alanya.

metas.title: Flat Agricultural Land
metas.description: Road E99 south of Şanlıurfa is a divided highway which can be recognised by the slightly hazy Generation 4 sunrise coverage combined with the flat agricultural landscape and general south-north road angle.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: Road D525 south of Söke is a completely straight road going south-south-west to north-north-east with winter Generation 3 coverage. Along the road you will typically find a large amount of reed.

metas.title: Lake Views
metas.description: Along the western shore of Lake Beyşehir and Lake Eğirdir you can find this small single lane road with jagged, exposed rock and Turkish pines to the west. These two can be differentiated by the road west of Lake Eğirdir having a middle road line.

metas.title: Light Blue And
metas.description: These light blue and grey touristic signs which are either arrow shaped or rectangular with a half circle on the top can be found on the island of Bozcaada.

metas.title: White Street Signs
metas.description:
Red street signs with a coloured bottom strip are found in several cities. In the bottom right corner, you can find a white arrow and some numbers. If this arrow is pointing in both directions and has a single arrowhead, rather than double, then you are almost certainly in Istanbul.

Beware that simple arrows pointing in only one direction can be found in both Istanbul and in other cities. However, if you see such signs in combination with red house numbers, then you should be in Istanbul.

metas.title: Street Signs
metas.description: Street signs in Trabzon and Yalvaç are red and oval-shaped. House numbers also feature the same design.

metas.title: Street Signs
metas.description: Street signs in Bursa are green, and generally have slightly extruded letters, meaning the signs are not completely flat.
metas.note: Several other types of infrastructure in Bursa, such as fences and guardrails, may also be coloured green.

metas.title: Street Signs
metas.description: Street signs in Bolu are also green, but are completely flat and lack any kind of border.

metas.title: Flat Desert
metas.description: The UAE typically features a flat desert landscape.

metas.title: Road Lines
metas.description: Outer roadlines are yellow, middle lines either white or yellow.
metas.note: Other Middle Eastern countries, like Jordan, Israel and Oman, also use these lines.

metas.title: Gen 3 White Car
metas.description: In almost all Generation 3 coverage, a white car with visible black roof racks was used.
metas.note: The UAE is the only Middle Eastern country where a white Google car can be found.

metas.title: Gen 4 White Pickup
metas.description: In Generation 4 coverage, a white pickup truck with a trekker camera was used for much of the coverage. In a lot of the coverage, the truck is completely blurred out.
metas.note: A similar truck can be found in Qatar and Oman. In the UAE the antenna at the front of the cabin is on the middle of the car, while in Qatar it is on the left.

metas.title: Gen 4 Black Car
metas.description: You can also find regular Generation 4 coverage taken with a black car. The brake light is commonly visible.
metas.note: A similar Generation 4 black car can be found in Israel.

metas.title: Arabic Script
metas.description: The official language in the UAE is Arabic. Its script can be identified by its lines and dots.
metas.note: Due to high tourism, signs in the UAE often have English writing alongside Arabic. While this is also common in Qatar and Oman, it is not common in Jordan.

metas.title: Architecture
metas.description: Houses in residential areas are typically made of light-coloured stone. Reddish stones are often used for sidewalks.

metas.title: Striped Signposts
metas.description: Many signposts in the UAE have black-and-white stripes.
metas.note: Within the Middle East, striped signposts are also found in Oman.

metas.title: Striped Curbs
metas.description: Similarly, almost all curbs are striped. They can be either black-and-white, or black-and-yellow.

metas.title: Roundabouts
metas.description: Divided roads and roundabouts are both very commonly seen in the UAE.

metas.title: Electricity Poles
metas.description: Electricity poles in the UAE are mostly made of dark brown wood. The pole tops consist of three insulators, symmetrically attached to a horizontal metal bar.
metas.note: Similar poletops can be found in Oman. Jordanian poletops may look similar, but they are usually made of grey concrete, and the insulators are more spaced out.

metas.title: Unpaved Residential Roads
metas.description: Although the UAE is a wealthy country, it is not uncommon for residential roads to be unpaved.

metas.title: Rifts
metas.description: Rifts can occasionally be found in the UAE.
metas.note: They are most commonly found in Albania, Montenegro and Senegal.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Coverage in the UAE is mostly limited to the Northeastern part of the country.
metas.note: The only car coverage outside of this region exists on Sir Baniyas Island. All other remote coverage was taken by a trekker.

metas.title: Dubai Skyline
metas.description: The skyline of Dubai is dominated by numerous skyscrapers, including the iconic Burj Khalifa.

metas.title: Eastern Mountains
metas.description: Mountains are only found in the far east of the country.

metas.title: Ras al Khaimah Mountains
metas.description: You can easily recognise the Northern part of the emirate of Ras al Khaimah thanks to the light-coloured mountains visible to the east.

metas.title: Gulf of Oman Coast
metas.description: If you see mountains to the west, and flatness to the east, you are likely near the Gulf of Oman, in the extreme East of the country.

metas.title: Sir Baniyas Island Car
metas.description: This rare white Google car with visible side mirrors and sparse vegetation is found on Sir Baniyas Island.

metas.title: Dubai Old Town Trekker
metas.description: In some parts of Dubai, including the old town, a Generation 4 sidewalk trekker was used. Sometimes, the employee’s black hair is visible.

metas.title: Dubai Street Signs
metas.description: These blue street name signs, with a narrow metal border, are specific to Dubai.

metas.title: Al Ain Trekkers
metas.description: The city of Al Ain has several trekkers, far away from the area with car coverage: two forts (Qasr Al Muwaiji and Al Jahili) and a zoo.

metas.title: Abu Dhabi Racetrack
metas.description: This racetrack coverage is found slightly east of Abu Dhabi.

metas.title: Southern Desert Trekkers
metas.description: Remote trekkers, with sand dunes all around, can be found in the far south of the country, between the towns of Taraq and Alyhyali.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Albanian licence plates either have blue strips on both sides or a single red strip on the left side.
metas.note: Albania is the only European country with red on the left side of the licence plate. Furthermore, Italian licence plates also have blue strips on both sides, however Italian front plates are distinctly shorter.

metas.title: Rifts
metas.description: ‘Rifts’ can commonly be seen in Albanian coverage, due to poor stitching.
metas.note: Rifts are also equally common in Montenegro, and can rarely be seen in various other countries.

metas.title: Bollards
metas.description: Albanian bollards have a black top with a red and grey reflector. The bottom is painted white.
metas.note: Italy uses the same kind of bollards.

metas.title: Triangular Poletops
metas.description: These pole tops, with an upside down triangle shape, are a good clue for Albania.
metas.note: Serbia, Czechia, Slovakia and Romania use similar pole tops.

metas.title: Horizontal Bar Poletops
metas.description: Other, more simple Albanian pole tops will often have horizontal bars.
metas.note: If you are not sure between Montenegro or Albania and see these poles, guess Albania.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description: Albanian chevrons are white on black.
metas.note:
Within southern Europe this chevron is also used by Italy, Greece, and Spain.

Montenegro uses two chevrons, both of which are different from the Albanian chevron: black on white and red on yellow.

metas.title: Black Sign Backs
metas.description: The backs of road signs are often painted black.
metas.note: This is also common in Italy and Romania.

metas.title: Stop Sign Font
metas.description: The “S” on Albanian stop signs feature a distinct shape; the ends of the S are quite short and have the same angle as the middle, rather than being vertical. This is also sometimes seen on directional signs.
metas.note: Italian stops signs and directional signs have the same feature.

metas.title: Speed Sign Font
metas.description: The numbers on speed signs are written in a bold font.
metas.note: The font is much thinner on speed signs in Montenegro.

metas.title: Guardrail Endings
metas.description: These flat and wide guardrail endings that bend away from the road can often be found in Albania.
metas.note: The same endings are found in Italy.

metas.title: Language
metas.description:
Albanian is not very closely related to any other European languages, and therefore has a fairly distinct look.

Words often contain the letter Ë, ë, and sometimes Ç ç.

metas.title: Rruga
metas.description: The Albanian word for street is rruga.

metas.title: Landscape
metas.description: Albania is generally a mountainous country, with a Mediterranean climate and vegetation. In between the hills and mountains, you can sometimes find more flat, agricultural valleys. The mountains are usually quite green, sometimes with patches of exposed rock visible.

metas.title: Red Soil
metas.description: Albania has a lot of exposed red soil next to roads.
metas.note: This is less common in Montenegro. Greece on the other hand also has a fair amount of similar-looking red soil, especially closer to the Albanian border.

metas.title: Water Tanks
metas.description: You will see a lot of cylinder-shaped water tanks on the roofs of buildings.
metas.note:
This is less common in Montenegro.

Some parts of Turkey also have a lot of similar-looking water tanks.

metas.title: Architecture
metas.description: Albania has a lot of Italian-style buildings: pastel colours, orange tiled roofs, and blocky shapes with lots of balconies.

metas.title: Mercedes
metas.description: Mercedes is the most popular car brand in Albania, by quite a margin. The specific style of sedan pictured here is particularly common.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
Coverage in Albania is limited. Generally only the larger towns have extensive side-road coverage.

Note that while the coverage is limited, a lot of it still appears to be very rural. It is not just on big main roads or urban areas.

You can click on the image to enlarge it, or use this site to study the official coverage in detail.

metas.title: Camera Metas
metas.description:
There are two types of car and camera meta in Albania:

Coverage where the Google car has a long antenna and you can see rifts in the sky.

Coverage where the Google car has a short antenna and there are no rifts visible.

You can click on the image to enlarge it. You can also use this Maps layer to look at the coverage in more detail (credits to icraig1205).

metas.title: Albania Elevation
metas.description:
Albania is generally a very mountainous country. This map shows the elevation and relief.

Low-lying areas are mostly concentrated in the west, around Shkodër, Tirana and Vlorë. This part of the country is characterised by agricultural flatlands and low, undulating hills. Note that the highland plateau around Korçë in the southeast is also very flat.

The highest mountains can be found in the far north and the far south. In places, these mountains can have an almost alpine look.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Theth National Park
metas.description: The road leading into Theth National Park can typically be recognised by the tall, jagged mountains, often with bare mountainsides.

metas.title: Montenegro Border Valley
metas.description: The road by the eastern part of the Montenegrin border goes in a valley with tall, fully exposed cliff sides along the road.

metas.title: Maja e Papingut
metas.description: Maja e Papingut is a massive mountain in the south of Albania, with an almost completely vertical cliffside near the top. It can be seen from several nearby roads.

metas.title: Devoll River Valley
metas.description: A wide, almost dried out river valley going southeast to northwest, can be seen along the SH71 between Pishaj and Kokel.

metas.title: Bay of Vlorë
metas.description: The large Bay of Vlorë can be seen on many parts of the SH4 between Vlorë and Orikum. It can be recognized by the large Karaburun peninsula jutting out into the ocean from the south, and the small Sazan island just to its north.

metas.title: Vlorë Pine Forest
metas.description: A couple of small roads northwest of Vlorë can be recognised by the very coastal-looking Aleppo pine forest.

metas.title: SH4 Road Lines
metas.description: On the SH4 between Levan and Tepelenë and right by the Greek border, you may see double outer road lines with a wide gap between them.

metas.title: E86 Bollards
metas.description: On this section of the E86 near the Greek border, you will sometimes see these unique bollards. They have a round shape and a simple red reflector. They look superficially similar to the flatter Turkish bollard.

metas.title: E86 Yellow Lines
metas.description: There are three sections of road in Albania with yellow centre lines. The first is on the E86 near lake Ohrid with the lake in the east, making it easily recognisable.

metas.title: SH97 Yellow Lines
metas.description: The second is the SH97 which goes through a fairly hilly landscape. It also goes through some smaller valleys.

metas.title: SH1 Yellow Lines
metas.description: The final road with a yellow centre line is the SH1 north of Tirana. It goes through a wide valley with fairly tall mountains on either side.

metas.title: A1 Highway
metas.description:
Albania only has a few divided highways covered on Street View. All of these and how to differentiate them will be covered in the tips below.

The most easily recognisable divided highway is the A1 between Fushë Milot and Thumanë, which is the only one with a triple guardrail.

metas.title: Concrete Dividers
metas.description: The sections of the SH2 between Durrës and Tirana and of the SH4 between Lushnjë and Rrogozhinë are both divided by simple concrete blocks.

metas.title: Grassy Concrete Dividers
metas.description: In Tirana, Durrës and on the A3 and SH3 south of Tirana you can find highways which are divided by concrete blocks, with grass and greenery in between.

metas.title: SH4 Guardrails
metas.description: Most of the SH4 between Durrës and Fier is divided by a basic double guardrail. The road does not go through any mountains.

metas.title: E851 Guardrail
metas.description: The E851 is the only divided road with a basic double guardrail that goes directly through mountains.
metas.note: A section of the A3 goes through the mountains but is either divided by a double guardrail with a fence above, or with concrete blocks.

metas.title: A2 Highway
metas.description: The A2 north of Vlorë can be recognised by the fairly flat surroundings combined with the double guardrail with an extra tall fence dividing the highway.

metas.title: Lezhë
metas.description: The city of Lezhë can often be recognised by the old castle at the top of a tall hill.

metas.title: Gjirokaster
metas.description: Gjirokaster is a city situated on the western hillside of a wide valley.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Andorran licence plates have an orange dot on the left side and can be regularly found throughout the country.
metas.note: Within Europe, this plate is unique to Andorra.

metas.title: Camera Generations
metas.description:
Andorra only has Generation 2 and Generation 3 coverage. In all Generation 3 coverage, a medium-short antenna is visible on the Google car.

Generation 3 is by far the most common. Almost all of Generation 2 is overwritten and is mostly confined to a couple of smaller off-roads.

metas.title: Autumn Colors
metas.description: All the Generation 3 coverage was taken in October, meaning that many deciduous trees have autumn colours.

metas.title: Architecture
metas.description: Andorra has a lot of these stone buildings. They can be seen almost everywhere in the country.
metas.note: These buildings can also be found close to Andorra, in the French and Spanish Pyrenees.

metas.title: Snow Poles
metas.description: Andorran snow poles are made out of wood and can have a variety of colours on them.

metas.title: Language
metas.description:
Catalan is the main language in Andorra. It is a Romance language that is closely related to Spanish and French.

If you are unfamiliar with Romance languages, it can be hard to distinguish between Catalan and Spanish. If you see i instead of y (“and” in English), it is Catalan. In addition, more Catalan words end with consonants.
metas.note: The Catalan language is also used in eastern Spain: in Catalonia, the Valencian community and the Balearic islands.

metas.title: Carrer
metas.description: The Catalan word for street is “carrer”.

metas.title: Kilometre Markers
metas.description: These kilometre markers with CG and CS road numbers are found in Andorra.
metas.note: Similar kilometre marker designs can be found in Spain.

metas.title: Guardrail Reflectors
metas.description: Andorra uses yellow reflectors on its guardrails.
metas.note: Within Europe, yellow reflectors are only found in Andorra, Spain and Belgium. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: Bollards
metas.description: The Andorran bollard has an orange reflector and can be occasionally found on the main highways.
metas.note: This bollard can also be found in Spain.

metas.title: Traffic Cones
metas.description: Yellow and turquoise-green traffic cones are used in the whole country.

metas.title: Pedestrian Signs Have
metas.description: Pedestrian signs have 8 stripes.
metas.note: Spain is the only other European country that has pedestrian signs with 8 stripes.

metas.title: Snow Trekkers
metas.description: Andorra has a lot of Generation 2 snow trekkers, especially on ski resorts.
metas.note: Other countries have snow trekkers as well, but Andorra has the highest amount for its size.

metas.title: Andorra la Vella
metas.description: Andorra la Vella is a capital city surrounded by high mountains, making it recognisable.
metas.note: It is the highest European capital with an altitude of 1023 metres.

metas.title: Caldea Tower
metas.description: In the capital Andorra la Vella you can often see the Caldea tower and the sky wheel.

metas.title: Pas de la Casa
metas.description: Pas de la Casa, a touristy city in eastern Andorra, can be easily recognized by the plethora of shops and hotels. As it is located at an altitude of 2080 metres, there are no trees visible on the mountains surrounding it.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Austria has long, white licence plates with the standard blue EU strip on the left.
metas.note:
Italian plates have two blue strips, on both sides of the plate. Italian plates also tend to be noticeably shorter.

Swiss plates are long and white, but lack the blue strip.

metas.title: Bollards
metas.description:
Austria uses white bollards, with a black top. The colour of the reflector is (dark) red or dark grey.

Many bollards also feature a small nipple-shaped black cap on the top. Bollards sometimes have a snow pole on top.
metas.note: Slovenia and Montenegro use the same bollards, but with bright red reflectors instead of grey or dark red. Germany uses simple white bollards with grey reflectors.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description:
Austria uses two colour schemes for chevrons:

white on red

red on yellow
metas.note: Germany mostly uses red on white chevrons, and rarely red on yellow.

metas.title: Wooden Poles
metas.description: Round wooden poles are the most common type of pole found in Austria.

metas.title: Landscape
metas.description: Most of Austria is mountainous and covered in forests. However, some areas in the east and northeast are much more flat and agricultural.

metas.title: Architecture
metas.description: Alpine architecture is common in Austria and other countries in the Alps. Houses commonly have distinct light coloured walls, with wooden elements such as balconies or panelling around the top floor, with dark-coloured wooden roofs that extend outward. The roofs can sometimes be angled downward at the front and back. In addition, houses are also often multi-storeyed.
metas.note: Germany uses similar architecture in its southern states.

metas.title: Language
metas.description: The official language of Austria is German. The German language uses the special letters Ä, Ö, Ü and ß.
metas.note: The other majority German-speaking countries with coverage are Switzerland and Germany. In addition, German is spoken in East Belgium and the Italian province of South Tyrol.

metas.title: Camera Generations
metas.description:
You can tell the three German-speaking countries apart by camera meta alone:

Austria only has Generation 3 and Generation 4 coverage (the only exceptions being Generation 2 on one road in Burgenland, and several ski resort trekkers).

Germany only has Generation 4 coverage. (the only exceptions being spills and trekkers)

Switzerland car coverage is always low-cam. This can be recognized by the much bigger car blur.

metas.title: Smallcam
metas.description: Austria also has generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.
metas.note: Most of Western Europe also has smallcam.

metas.title: Direction Signs
metas.description: Direction signs have a white background, a blue outline, and a unique font.

metas.title: Town Entrance Signs
metas.description: Similar white signs with a blue outline and unique font can also be seen at the entrance of towns.
metas.note: Germany uses yellow town entrance signs with a black outline.

metas.title: Green Signs
metas.description: Green signs can commonly be seen, giving directions to different local facilities.

metas.title: Pedestrian Signs
metas.description: Pedestrian signs have a unique design: instead of zebra stripes, they have two horizontal dashed lines.
metas.note: All neighbouring countries have pedestrian signs with zebra stripes.

metas.title: Sign Mounting
metas.description: Road signs in Austria are sometimes mounted by four metal clips, which is unique within central Europe. However, plenty of Austrian signs are attached in other ways.

metas.title: Road Markers
metas.description: Road markers are blue with white numbers. They have one decimal separated by a comma, making them very recognizable.
metas.note: Slovenian road markers are white. And German markers have a thin white outline.

metas.title: Bus Stop Signs
metas.description: Austrian bus stop signs contain a yellow and green circle with the letter H.
metas.note: This design is relatively unique in Europe. The only other country with similar bus stop signs is Germany.

metas.title: One-Way Signs
metas.description: These one-way traffic signs, with the word ‘EINBAHN’ written on them, are unique to Austria.
metas.note: In Germany there will be “Einbahnstraße” written on the sign.

metas.title: No Stopping Signs
metas.description: “No Stopping” and “No Waiting” signs in Austria will often have the words “Anfang” or “Ende” (meaning “beginning” and “end”) written on, or below, them.

metas.title: Dead-End Signs
metas.description: These simple dead-end signs with a white upside down T are unique to Austria.

metas.title: Gas Poles
metas.description: These yellow natural gas poles, which resemble snow poles, are unique to Austria.

metas.title: Elevation Map
metas.description:
Elevation is very important when region-guessing Austria based on landscape alone.

The central and western parts of Austria are the most mountainous. The flatter areas are found in the east, mostly near the borders. Note that “flat” is a relative concept in Austria: even in the flat areas, rolling hills are still common.

metas.title: Autobahn Map
metas.description:
A map of Austrian A-roads can be seen here, following the general trend of increasing in number from east to west.

You can click the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: B-Roads Map
metas.description:
Austrian B-roads, indicated by white text inside of a blue rectangle, also follow the general trend of increasing in number from east to west.

An important exception to this are roads 222-230, which are located inside the state of Vienna.

You can click the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: State Flags
metas.description:
Each Austrian state has its own unique flag, shown in the image.

You can click the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Bus Companies
metas.description:
Each Austrian state has its own unique bus company, the logo of which can be seen on the side of buses.

You can click the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Vorarlberg Bus Stops
metas.description: Bus stops consisting of neon-yellow poles are found in Vorarlberg.

metas.title: Vorarlberg Pole Stickers
metas.description: These yellow and white stripes around poles and signposts are found in Vorarlberg.

metas.title: Vorarlberg KM Markers
metas.description: White kilometre markers can be found in Vorarlberg as well as on a road in western Salzburg.

metas.title: Salzburg Road Squares
metas.description: A large white painted square in the middle of the road can be found next to kilometre markers in Salzburg.

metas.title: Burgenland Güterweg Signs
metas.description: Green “Güterweg” signs are found in Burgenland.

metas.title: Upper Austria Güterweg Signs
metas.description: White “Güterweg” signs with a black outline are mainly found in Upper Austria.

metas.title: Lower Austria Sign Borders
metas.description: In Lower Austria, you may find signs with yellow and blue sign borders, corresponding to the flag of the region.

metas.title: Vineyards
metas.description:
Vineyards are limited to the far eastern part of the country.

You can find a very precise map here. Notably, there are a lot of vineyards close to Vienna and around Lake Neusiedl.

metas.title: Highest Mountains
metas.description:
The highest parts of the Alps are found in the west and central parts of the country.

The tallest mountains are found in the panhandle of Austria, on the Italian border. These mountains can be recognized by their generally sharper peak and grander appearance.

metas.title: Tin Foil Antenna
metas.description: This unique tin foil antenna can be found in western Austria, mostly near the Swiss border.
metas.note: This antenna is unique to Austria.

metas.title: Vienna Street Signs
metas.description:
Vienna street signs are extremely recognizable dark blue plaques with a traditional-looking white serif font. The number at the start will indicate which district you are in (see the map).

You can click the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: City Street Signs
metas.description: Most other major cities in Austria also have their own unique street signs.
metas.note:
Many of the arbitrary blue ones can look similar, but the 4 listed in the graphic can be differentiated by:

Vienna - District Number

Salzburg - Unique Font

Klagenfurt - Irregular White Border

St Polten - Rounded White Border

You can click the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Vienna/Innsbruck Pole Tape
metas.description: Poles in Vienna and Innsbruck feature these red-and-white pieces of tape that look like the Austrian flag. They can be differentiated by the fact that the tapes in Vienna are thinner, and there are typically two on each pole.

metas.title: Lake Constance
metas.description: Lake Constance (known in German as the Bodensee) is a large lake on the western border of Austria. It can be recognized by its vastness, which is not seen in other lakes within the mountainous part of the country.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Since the Azores is an autonomous region of Portugal, you will often come across various types of Portuguese infrastructure, such as poles, chevrons and bollards.

metas.title: Agricultural Area
metas.description: Most of the Azores visible on Street View consists of open agricultural fields in a rolling landscape, often with taller round hills in the background.
metas.note: Madeira has a very mountainous landscape, and very rarely has open agricultural fields.

metas.title: Dry Rock Walls
metas.description: Dry rock walls made of volcanic rocks are very common on the Azores.
metas.note: Dry rock walls are not common on Madeira, and while they are somewhat common on mainland Portugal, they will not be made of volcanic rocks.

metas.title: Hydrangeas Commonly Be
metas.description: Hydrangeas can commonly be seen on the Azores.
metas.note: They can rarely be found on Madeira.

metas.title: Japanese Cedars Cryptomeria
metas.description: Japanese cedars (cryptomeria japonica) are very common on the Azores.
metas.note: While they can less commonly be seen on Madeira, they are not native to any part of mainland Europe.

metas.title: Houses Azores Typically
metas.description:
Houses in the Azores are typically one or two stories, with an orange tiled roof. They are painted white or in pastel colours, and dark green shutters on windows are common.

While you can also find yellow or blue highlights like in mainland Portugal, grey highlights are almost exclusive to the Azores.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description: Street signs in the Azores are almost exclusively painted ceramic tiles, with blue letters and, typically, a decorative pattern around the edge.

metas.title: Signposts Azores Often
metas.description: Signposts on the Azores are often striped.
metas.note: These are also seen on Madeira.

metas.title: Black And White
metas.description: Black and white cows are very common on the Azores.
metas.note: Cows on Madeira are usually brown with white spots.

metas.title: Only Islands Azores
metas.description: The only islands in the Azores with car coverage are Ilha de São Miguel, Ilha Terceira and Ilha do Faial.

metas.title: Only Island With
metas.description: The only island with Generation 4 coverage is Ilha de São Miguel.

metas.title: Shitcam Coverage
metas.description:
Shitcam coverage is found on Ilha de São Miguel and Ilha do Faial. 

The car seen on São Miguel has an indentation in the centre, while the one on Faial appears as a smooth surface, sometimes with an antenna visible.

metas.title: Lake Views
metas.description: Ilha de São Miguel is the only island in the Azores or Madeira where you can find lakes.

metas.title: Rock Walls With
metas.description: Rock walls with a white painted concrete top are somewhat common on Ilha Terceira.

metas.title: Ilha Do Faial
metas.description: On Ilha do Faial, you will sometimes find traditional whitewashed rock walls with unevenly sized dark basalt stones.

metas.title: Trekker Going Along
metas.description: A trekker going along the edge of a crater can be seen on Ilha do Faial.

metas.title: Only Coverage Belarus
metas.description:
The only coverage in Belarus, apart from spills, is a single walking trekker in the historic centre of Minsk.

Instead of learning a lot of country-specific clues, it is more practical to simply memorise what the trekker looks like.

You can recognise trekkers by the fact that the camera feels a bit lower than the usual Google car. In Belarus’ case, the trekker is also mostly on pedestrian-only roads.

You can find information about the border spill coverage in the Spillover Guide.

metas.title: Local Architecture
metas.description: The Minsk trekker features a historic part of the city, with well-maintained classical European architecture. Many buildings have white or pastel coloured walls. Most of the roads you see are pedestrian-only.

metas.title: Holy Spirit Cathedral
metas.description: The Holy Spirit Cathedral features prominently in the coverage. Its two towers can often be seen from far away.

metas.title: Minsk Features
metas.description: The pavement which the trekker walks on in Minsk is mostly grey rectangular tiles. On a small part, there are pink-ish tiles in a specific pattern.

metas.title: Cyrillic Script
metas.description: Signs will be in Belarusian or Russian. Both languages use the Cyrillic alphabet.
metas.note: The letters ў and і are not found in Russian.

metas.title: Street Signs
metas.description: The Minsk centre street signs are sea-green, and can be seen almost everywhere.
metas.note: If you are close enough to the sign, you can make out the Cyrillic letters “вул (vul)”, the Belarusian name for “street”.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Licence plates in Belgium use red text. You can recognise this distinct colour even through the blur.

metas.title: Bollards
metas.description: Belgium uses white bollards with a yellow rectangular reflector on the front and white on the back. A second type of bollard is dark brown with two red stripes at the top. Occasionally, other bollards can be seen.
metas.note: Denmark uses similar white bollards, but they have a red stripe at the top and the reflector is not rectangular. The dark brown bollard with two red stripes can also be seen in the Netherlands.

metas.title: Guardrail Reflectors
metas.description: Belgium uses A-type guardrails with yellow reflectors.
metas.note: In Europe, only Spain, Andorra, and Belgium use these reflectors. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: Poles
metas.description: Most poles in Belgium are concrete, square shaped, and have tiny holes running up them. They often have small metal wrappings around them. The second most common type of pole has oval-shaped holes. You can find many different types of concrete poles in Belgium.
metas.note: The small metal wrappings can be found in France as well.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Directional signs in Belgium are most often blue or white.

metas.title: Blue Signs
metas.description: Road signs often have an additional small blue sign. In other European countries, these small signs are usually just white.

metas.title: Pedestrian Signs
metas.description: Belgium uses pedestrian crossing signs without any stripes, but with two horizontal dotted lines. The man on the sign has a square head.
metas.note: France and the Netherlands use a pedestrian sign with a regular zebra crossing with five vertical stripes.

metas.title: Kilometre Markers
metas.description: Kilometre markers in Belgium are often green, but can have red text as well.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description: Belgium uses white chevrons, with a red arrow.
metas.note: The Netherlands also uses this chevron. You will not see these in France.

metas.title: Concrete Slab Roads
metas.description: A lot of rural roads in Belgium are made out of concrete slabs, almost like you would see in the Philippines or Thailand.
metas.note: The Netherlands almost never uses concrete slabs for roads.

metas.title: Road Lines
metas.description: Belgium uses all white road lines. These can be continuous or broken. Roads are often accompanied by bike lanes on both sides.
metas.note: Bikes and cycling lanes are most common in the Netherlands, but they can be often seen in Belgium as well.

metas.title: Red Brick Architecture
metas.description: A lot of houses in Belgium are made of distinctive red bricks.
metas.note: This is more common in the North and West of the country.

metas.title: Stone Architecture
metas.description: Houses in the South of the country use a lot of stone, have gray tones and generally look more French.

metas.title: Orange Signposts
metas.description: Signposts in Belgium are often orange. The backs of signs are also sometimes orange. This is unique to Belgium.

metas.title: Street Name Signs
metas.description: Street name signs in Belgium are very diverse, and often unique to a city. Most common colours are white and dark blue. They often have the town or city name written on them.
metas.note: These signs often have variable designs, but most of them are fairly short and tall. In comparison, Dutch street signs are almost always much longer than they are tall.

metas.title: Town Entry Signs
metas.description: Town entry signs in Belgium are white with a black border. They also mention the name of the city or municipality in bold, black text.

metas.title: Priority Signs
metas.description: Priority signs in Belgium have an orange diamond and are much smaller than in other countries.

metas.title: Bus Stops
metas.description: Bus stops are always marked by yellow signposts. Bus shelters often have yellow roofs.

metas.title: Traffic Lights
metas.description: Traffic lights are most often supported by black-and-yellow or red-and-white striped poles.
metas.note: The regional differences are discussed in Step 2.

metas.title: Water Hydrant Signs
metas.description: Belgium uses these red water hydrants signs with the letter H on top.
metas.note: You can also find these in Germany.

metas.title: Gutters
metas.description: Almost all roads (big or small) in Belgium use gutters on both sides. This is much less common in neighbouring countries.

metas.title: Bicycle Path Lines
metas.description: Belgian bicycle paths have short dashed outer lines.

metas.title: Blurred Houses
metas.description: After Germany, Belgium is the next country in which you can find the most blurred houses.

metas.title: Red Car Antenna
metas.description: Coverage with a red car and a long antenna can rarely be seen in Belgium.
metas.note: This is much more common in Ukraine.

metas.title: Smallcam
metas.description: Belgium also has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.
metas.note: Most of Western Europe also has smallcam.

metas.title: Flatness
metas.description: Belgium is generally flat in the northwest of the country, especially near the coast. The further south east you go, the hillier.

metas.title: Languages
metas.description:
Belgium has 3 official languages.

Dutch (Flemish), spoken in Flanders, the Northern part of Belgium. There is an abundance of letters and combinations like z, w, ee and ij.

French (Walloon), spoken in Wallonia, the Southern part of Belgium. You can see letters like ç, é, è and à.

German, spoken in Ostbelgien, a small region in the east of the country. You can see letters like ä, ü, ö and ß.

metas.title: Bilingual Brussels
metas.description: Brussels, the capital of Belgium, is bilingual. You will see both French and Dutch on signs.

metas.title: Regional Bus Stops
metas.description: Bus stop signs in Flanders (and Brussels) have a white rectangle at the top. In Wallonia they will have a yellow top.

metas.title: Warning Sign Borders
metas.description: In Flanders (and Brussels), 95% of warning signs have a thick red outline, without a white border. Contrarily, you will most often find warning signs with a small white outline in Wallonia.
metas.note: The signs found in Flanders are the same as the Spanish ones.

metas.title: Traffic Light Poles
metas.description: Traffic lights held up by yellow-and-black poles are unique to Flanders. In contrast, Wallonia and Brussels frequently use a red-and-white design.

metas.title: Phone Codes
metas.description:
Phone codes in Belgium are very useful to determine the region you are in. They are 9 digits long. The 1 or 2 number(s) after the leading 0 indicate the area code.

0X XXX XX XX (Brussels, Antwerp, Liege, Ghent.)

0XX XX XX XX (Other cities.)
metas.note:
Mobile numbers start with 04 and are 10 digits long.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Street Signs Map
metas.description: As mentioned before, municipality names are often mentioned on street signs, usually in smaller font than the street name. The map shows a selection of recognizable street signs in the bigger cities.
metas.note:
Of the big cities, Bruges (Brugge) is an exception to the rule of signs usually mentioning the municipality name.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Ardennes
metas.description: The Ardennes, located in the southeast part of Belgium, have a very distinct landscape. You can see a lot of steep hills, dense forests, and valleys.
metas.note: The Ardennes extend partially into France, Luxembourg, and Germany.

metas.title: Polders
metas.description: The coastal plain is extremely flat and consists of so-called polders, which are man-made fields at or below sea level, surrounded by many waterways. This landscape is situated near the North Sea coast, as well as near the western part of the border with the Netherlands, particularly around Antwerp.
metas.note: This part of Belgium is especially often confused with the Netherlands. Carefully look around for clues to distinguish the two countries if you find yourself in this landscape.

metas.title: North Sea Coast
metas.description:
Many parts of the Belgian North Sea coast are lined by apartment blocks, in a manner that is often derisively referred to as a “wall” of buildings by locals.

Near the coast, you will also sometimes be able to spot a dune landscape, with low bushes, long grass and sandy soil.

metas.title: Baarle-Hertog
metas.description: Baarle-Hertog, located north-east of Antwerp, is composed of several exclaves and enclaves of Belgium and the Netherlands. You can often see the country's borders in this city (indicated by small white crosses). Street name signs tell you whether you are in Belgium or The Netherlands.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Bulgarian licence plates have the typical European design, with the blue strip on the left.

metas.title: Cyrillic Script
metas.description:
Bulgaria mainly uses the Cyrillic alphabet. However, a lot of signs will also have the Latin alphabet.

The letter “Ъ” is only found in Bulgarian and Russian, although it is fairly uncommon in Russian.

metas.title: Ulitsa
metas.description: The Bulgarian word for street is улица (ulitsa), sometimes abbreviated ул. (ul.).
metas.note:
In older street signs seeing only Cyrillic is more common.

Russia also uses улица/ulitsa.

metas.title: Gen 4 Cars
metas.description:
There are three types of Generation 4 cars that were used to cover Bulgaria:

A blue car, which can be found in most European countries.

A red car, which is also found in Latvia, Lithuania, Russia, Slovakia, and Sweden. Of these, Russia and Slovakia are easiest to confuse with Bulgaria.

A black car, which is found in many European countries; of which Greece and Croatia are the ones more likely to be confused with Bulgaria.

All cars can be found with or without antenna. Additionally, you can also encounter coverage where the car is completely hidden.

metas.title: Winter Gen 3
metas.description: The majority of Generation 3 coverage in Bulgaria was taken during March and April, resulting in very distinct dead-looking “winter” coverage.
metas.note: Hungary and Czechia also have a lot of similar dead-looking Generation 3 coverage. Furthermore, while not common, Bulgaria has some summer Generation 3.

metas.title: Flag Antenna
metas.description:
You can commonly see a small piece of grey tape at the top of the car antenna in Generation 3 coverage. The community sometimes refers to it as “flag antenna”.

Not all Gen 3 coverage has this tape.
metas.note: This can also be seen in Czechia, Slovakia, Hungary, and Romania.

metas.title: Concrete Poles
metas.description:
Most utility poles in Bulgaria are cylindrical and made of concrete.

There is also a less common concrete ‘ladder pole’ variation. You can also sometimes see simple wooden poles.

metas.title: Hook Insulators
metas.description: Most poles have small, alternating hook-shaped insulators.

metas.title: Three Hook Poletop
metas.description: This style of pole top, with 3 large, alternating insulators that are shaped like upward facing hooks, is a good clue for Bulgaria. This pole top is probably unique to the country.
metas.note: You can also find this pole top with the insulators facing downwards.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description: Bulgarian chevrons are typically red on white.
metas.note: Many other European countries have similar chevrons. Crucially, among neighbouring countries, Romania, Turkey, and North Macedonia use the same chevrons. Greece and Serbia use black and white chevrons however. See this infographic for an overview.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Bulgarian directional signs are blue, arrow-shaped, and use both the Cyrillic and Latin alphabet. Importantly, even if you are far away and cannot decipher the script, you can still see that the sign has two lines of text instead of one.

metas.title: Town Entry Signs
metas.description: Town entry signs have a simple white design and also use both the Cyrillic and Latin alphabet. Like with the directional signs, the two lines of text are obvious, even when seen from far away.

metas.title: Pedestrian Signs
metas.description: Bulgarian pedestrian signs have four stripes, and the person is wearing a hat.
metas.note: No other eastern or central European pedestrian signs have four stripes.

metas.title: Bollards
metas.description:
Bollards are generally fairly rare in Bulgaria.

When you see them, they almost always have this somewhat generic design, which is relatively similar to the bollards found in Croatia and Hungary. They have a red reflector on the front, and a white one on the back. The design isn’t terribly consistent: sometimes they are thinner, and the shape of the reflector varies.

metas.title: Thin Road Lines
metas.description: Bulgaria usually has thin roadlines. This is particularly useful to tell Bulgaria apart from Romania, where roadlines are usually much thicker.

metas.title: Road Quality
metas.description: Bulgaria generally has fairly poor-quality roads, with many small cracks and occasionally potholes.

metas.title: Roofs
metas.description:
Most houses in Bulgaria have orange tiled roofs, with distinct patches of mortar along the corner tiles.

Famously, Bulgarian roofs often seem poorly constructed: the roof tiles and mortar tend to be uneven, especially when compared to other European countries.

metas.title: Suburbs
metas.description: Suburbs in Bulgaria are generally among the poorest areas in Europe, with small, densely built houses and generally an almost ghetto-like look.

metas.title: Metallic Bins
metas.description: Metallic trash bins with this shape are very common in Bulgaria.
metas.note: This style of bin is also common in Turkey and other balkan countries such as Serbia, Albania and North Macedonia.

metas.title: Topography
metas.description:
The Balkan mountains cut across Bulgaria and divide the country in two distinct halves. North of them, you will find a mostly flat area that goes all the way to the border with Romania.

The Rhodope Mountains start close to Sofia and run South-East into Greece. In them you will find the highest peaks of Bulgaria.

Between both mountain ranges you will find the second biggest flat area of Bulgaria.

The westernmost part of the country usually features many small valleys surrounded by hills and small mountains.

metas.title: Area Codes
metas.description:
Area codes in Bulgaria are one of the best clues to regionguess urban rounds. Conveniently, they are ordered by first digit, so just learning the first digit can yield high results with little effort.

Numbers between parentheses in the map are area codes from a neighbouring province that frequently spill into that one.

Codes next to a small dot represent area codes unique to the province capital.

metas.title: National Parks
metas.description: The towering mountains of Pirin and Rila National Parks can be recognised by the tall pyramid-shaped peaks, and can be seen from a few different vantage points in Blagoevgrad, Kyustendil and Sofia Provinces.

metas.title: Wind Turbines
metas.description: Wind turbines are most common in Dobrich Province, and usually towards the coast.

metas.title: Smolyan Architecture
metas.description: Buildings with features similar to Alpine architecture, such as white walls with brown wooden details are commonly found in and around the Smoljan region in the south.

metas.title: Invisible Gen 4 Car
metas.description: Locations with an invisible Generation 4 Street View car can be found along the North and West borders of Bulgaria, as well as the northern half of the coast.

metas.title: Red Gen 4 Car
metas.description:
