A red Generation 4 Street View car is mostly found in central and southeastern Bulgaria.

This car can be found with and without an antenna.

metas.title: Tape Antenna
metas.description: Generation 3 coverage with a piece of tape on a short antenna can be commonly found in the eastern part of Bulgaria.
metas.note: Tape antennas can very rarely appear in other provinces, the only provinces where it’s never found are Vratsa, Montana, Pazardzhik and Smolyan.

metas.title: Long Antenna Tape
metas.description: Generation 3 locations with a taped long antenna and visible white car can be found in Stara Zagora, and rarely a few small roads in Plovdiv and Burgas.
metas.note: This combination of car and antenna can be found more commonly in other European countries as well. Make sure to use other clues.

metas.title: Varna Antenna
metas.description: This antenna with unpeeled tape at the top, resulting in a bulkier antenna tip, can be found in the Varna Province. Coverage with this antenna is exclusively in March, resulting in a dead winter look.

metas.title: Vratsa Mountains
metas.description: The mountains overlooking Vratsa from the southwest have a very distinct “bumpy” shape, and can be seen from afar in the province.

metas.title: Old Towns
metas.description: The old town of Nessebar, and to a lesser extent Sozopol, can be recognised by the well-preserved old buildings made of a combination of unpainted stone, white stone walls and brown wood. Most of the streets are paved with cobblestone.

metas.title: Sofia Street Signs
metas.description: White street signs with two red strips; one covering the bottom and one covering part of the top, can be found in Sofia.
metas.note: You can also find other types of street signs in Sofia.

metas.title: Stara Zagora Street Signs
metas.description: Brown street signs with bright yellow text can be found in Stara Zagora.

metas.title: White-Blue Plates
metas.description: Croatia has long, white licence plates. Some plates have a blue strip on the left, some are fully white. Most cars seen in Generation 3 will not feature a blue strip on their licence plates. In addition, there is a mix of cars with or without blue strips in Generation 4, with blue strips more common on newer cars.
metas.note: Blue strips are more common along the coast due to travelling tourists from other EU countries such as Italy.

metas.title: Angled Bollards
metas.description: Croatian bollards are white with a black rectangle and red or white reflector. From the top, it is shaped like a triangle.
metas.note: Hungarian and Lithuanian bollards look similar, but have more rounded edges compared to Croatia’s sharper edges. Lithuanian bollards will also have an orange reflector.

metas.title: Language Features
metas.description: Croatian is a Slavic language. It is always written in the Latin alphabet. ‘IJE’ is common in Croatian whereas Serbian uses only ‘E’ instead.
metas.note: The Slovene language also features a lot of ‘J’s. Serbian and Montenegrin are also very similar, but Serbia and Montenegro use both Latin and Cyrillic script.

metas.title: Red-White Chevrons
metas.description: Croatia features chevrons with a red arrow on a yellow or white background.

metas.title: Road Guardrails
metas.description: Croatia has square (B-type) guardrails.
metas.note: Croatia is one of the few European countries that use B-type guardrails. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: Generation 3 coverage often has a non-standard car blur where the side mirrors of the car are partially visible. This is not unique to Croatia, but by far most common there.
metas.note: Sometimes, you can see a small circular yellow sticker on the car mirror. This sticker is unique to Croatia.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description:
Another quirk of Generation 3 coverage is that the majority of it was made in autumn. This means that the vegetation in this coverage will often have distinct yellowish or orange fall colours.

Take note that this seasonal meta is not found in Generation 4 coverage.

metas.title: Croatia Features
metas.description: A black generation 4 car that will never have an antenna can be found in Croatia.
metas.note: A black car can be found in many European countries, though it will often have an antenna visible.

metas.title: Croatia Features
metas.description: A white generation 4 car that will never have an antenna can be found in Croatia.
metas.note: A white car can be found in many European countries, though it will often have an antenna visible.

metas.title: Stickers With Letters
metas.description: Stickers with the letters HR can be found on Croatian cars. HR stands for Hrvatska, the Croatian name for Croatia.
metas.note: These were mainly used before EU plates were introduced, meaning they will be less common in Generation 4.

metas.title: Croatia Has Direction
metas.description: Croatia has direction signs with a yellow background and a black outline. They often have a pencil-shaped tip.
metas.note: The other former Yugoslav countries of Slovenia, Serbia, Montenegro and North Macedonia have similar signs. A comparison can be seen here.

metas.title: Concrete Poles
metas.description: Croatian utility poles are cylindrical and made of concrete or wood, often with alternating hooks on the wooden poles (somewhat similar to Latvian poles).

metas.title: Local Architecture
metas.description: Buildings in Croatia sometimes feature exposed red brick walls. This architecture is more common in inland areas.
metas.note: This type of architecture can also be found in Slovenia and Serbia.

metas.title: Generation Features
metas.description: Croatia features blue fire hydrants with two diagonal protrusions on either side. Newer fire hydrants seen in Generation 4 have a smaller top but are still recognisable due to the blue paint.
metas.note: Similar fire hydrants can be found in bordering countries, most commonly in Hungary.

metas.title: Croatias Pedestrian Sign
metas.description: Croatia’s pedestrian sign features a pedestrian with a belt and a zebra path with 5 stripes.
metas.note: The pedestrian on Slovenia’s sign does not have a belt.

metas.title: Karlovačko And Ožujsko
metas.description:
Karlovačko and Ožujsko are common Croatian beer companies, with advertisements seen around the country.

Konzum and Plodine are common supermarket chains, mostly found in big cities. Plodine is exclusive to Croatia, while Konzum also operates stores in Bosnia.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description: Croatia does not have Generation 2 car coverage. However, in some historic downtown areas, a Generation 2 trekker camera was used.
metas.note: In some of this trekker coverage, the Google employee’s red cap is visible.

metas.title: Area Code Map
metas.description: Croatian landlines typically start with a zero followed by the area code.

metas.title: Flat Agricultural Land
metas.description: The north-eastern region of Croatia is mostly flat and features a lot of agriculture. It is similar in terms of landscape to Hungary and north-western Serbia.

metas.title: Hilly Terrain
metas.description: The region north and west of Zagreb is hilly and agricultural.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The Adriatic coast features rocky mountains similar to those seen in Montenegro or Albania. Shrubs are more common instead of trees along the coast, especially in the south. This coastal region has a lot of islands and peninsulas.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: Houses and walls made of beige brick are common on the Adriatic coast. They often feature green shutters.
metas.note: Similar architecture can also be found in some regions in Italy. Additionally, Croatian shutters can also be white, beige etc.

metas.title: North-western Region Istria
metas.description: The north-western region of Istria, south of the Italian city of Trieste, sometimes has distinct red soil.

metas.title: Istria Features
metas.description: Bilingual street name signs with Croatian and Italian are typically found in Istria, especially in the western cities.

metas.title: Town Names Ending
metas.description: Town names ending with “-ec” are common to see in the northern parts of central Croatia.

metas.title: Hilly Terrain
metas.description: Croatia’s capital Zagreb has a distinct big city feel. Apartment blocks can be seen throughout the city. The northern part of the city is hilly. Furthermore, Zagreb has blue electric trams.
metas.note: In addition to regular car coverage, Zagreb also has various urban sidewalk trekkers, often made with a Generation 2 camera.

metas.title: Croatia Features
metas.description: Zagreb and Osijek are the only two cities in Croatia with trams.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The region northeast of Zadar is recognizable as it is flat with a mountain ridge visible in the distance north.

metas.title: There Lot Vineyards
metas.description: There are a lot of vineyards around the town of Ilok, near the Serbian border, west of Novi Sad. You can find vineyards in other parts of Croatia as well, but they are most common in this area. If you see lots of vineyards in a northeastern Croatian landscape, you are more often than not near Ilok.

metas.title: Utility Poles
metas.description: Traffic lights in Rijeka are held up by long blue poles that extend out over the road. These are exclusive to the city.

metas.title: Town Petrinja Severely
metas.description: The town of Petrinja was severely damaged by an earthquake in 2020. As a result, many buildings can be seen ruined and undergoing repair.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: The city of Dubrovnik in the far south of coastal Croatia is famous for its beautifully preserved medieval city walls, which can be seen from many points in and around the Old Town.

metas.title: Tall Cypress Trees
metas.description: These tall cypress trees are commonly found near the southern tip of Croatia.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Bollards in Czechia have orange double reflectors on the front and a single white reflector on the back. There are also rarer blue and red variants.
metas.note: The only other country with the same design is Slovakia.

metas.title: Road Guardrails
metas.description: Czechia and Slovakia both use a special kind of type B guardrail, which is wider than the normal type. No other European countries use the same kind.
metas.note: While Slovakia occasionally uses other types of guardrails, Czechia is fairly consistent. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: Concrete Poles
metas.description: Czechia and Slovakia most commonly use wide, round concrete poles, which are quite often attached in pairs.

metas.title: Metal Poles
metas.description: Czech and Slovak pole tops typically feature short metal bars that hold the insulators.

metas.title: Metal Poles
metas.description: Two support bars holding up the metal bar on pole tops, resembling an upside down triangle, can sometimes be found in Czechia and Slovakia.
metas.note: This is also found in Germany, Albania, Serbia and Romania.

metas.title: Concrete Poles
metas.description: You may also see concrete poles with trident poletops, with two arms angled upwards. The number of insulators and other details will vary, however the general shape will be the same. Out of the pole tops listed, these are the least common, but unique to the two countries.

metas.title: Street Lamps
metas.description: Lamp posts with a thick base mounted by opposing pairs of bolts are common in both countries. The exact shape of the base may vary.

metas.title: Striped Sign Posts
metas.description: It is common in both Czechia and Slovakia to see temporary square sign posts coated in red and white stripes.

metas.title: Red-White Chevrons
metas.description: Czech and Slovak chevrons are white with red arrows. Less commonly, you may find red on yellow chevrons.

metas.title: Utility Poles
metas.description: Stripy gas and water poles reminiscent of snow poles can often be found next to the road.
metas.note: Dozens of poles of various utilities all over Europe use stripy patterns. Consider the location of the pole, as well as other clues before making a guess.

metas.title: Czechia Features
metas.description: Hiking markers, made up of one colourful strip between two white ones, are commonly found in Czechia and Slovakia. They sometimes form an arrow.
metas.note: While by far being the most common in Czechia and Slovakia, similar signs can be found in other European countries such as Poland, Hungary and Germany.

metas.title: Like All Former
metas.description: Like all of the former Eastern bloc, prefabricated panel apartment buildings are a common sight in urban areas. What distinguishes Czechia and Slovakia is the relatively good maintenance often combined with vibrant colours and patterns. Some smaller buildings also adhere to this style.
metas.note: To a lesser extent, you can find this kind of architecture in neighbouring countries, like Poland and Hungary.

metas.title: Roofs With Diamond
metas.description: Roofs with diamond shaped tiles are common in both Czechia and Slovakia.
metas.note: This is also somewhat common in Hungary.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: A car antenna with a grey piece of tape stuck to the top can be seen on much of the Generation 3 coverage in Czechia and Slovakia.
metas.note: This can also be seen in Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria.

metas.title: Red Generation 4
metas.description: A red generation 4 Google car can be found in both Czechia and Slovakia.
metas.note: A red car can be found in other European countries too.

metas.title: Black Generation 4
metas.description: A black generation 4 Google car can also be found in both Czechia and Slovakia.
metas.note: A black car can be found in many other European countries too.

metas.title: end of Bridge
metas.description: These black signs can often be found by the end of bridges in Generation 4 coverage. The road number is displayed on the left.

metas.title: Czech And Slovak
metas.note: Acute accents on vowels are not found in South Slavic languages.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description: The Czech landscape is fairly rolling, with a lot of hills and altitude changes, but not a lot of tall mountains. Generally speaking, Slovakia has more mountains, but also more completely flat areas.

metas.title: Czechia Often Has
metas.description: Czechia often has solid outer roadlines, with no centre line.
metas.note: While these roadlines can be found in all neighbouring countries, it is notably also common in Germany.

metas.title: Czechia Uses Arrow-shaped
metas.description: Czechia uses arrow-shaped directional signs with a filled in tip. Due to the shape, they are recognizable from behind.
metas.note: Slovakia has small white arrows instead.

metas.title: Borders Czech Road
metas.description: The borders of Czech road signs are almost always separated from the edge by a strip in the same colour as the sign background.
metas.note: In Slovakia, it is more common for signs to have the border on the edge of the sign.

metas.title: Czech Highway Signs
metas.description: Czech highway signs can be either blue or green, and have a thin white border, which is separated from the edge by a second coloured border.
metas.note: Slovak highway signs have a white border right on the edge.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description:
The most common type of street sign in Czechia are bright red signs, which can either be wide and stuck on walls, or thin and attached to signs posts. Note that other street signs do occur in some areas, most notably in Brno. Similarly designed blue signs are also fairly common.

Furthermore, the Czech word for street is “ulice”, unlike most Slavic languages which use “ulica”. This word is usually omitted, but finding “ulice” on street signs is still possible.
metas.note: Slovakia typically uses white street signs with a red border and blue text.

metas.title: Czechia Features
metas.description: House numbers in Czechia are generally written on blue or red signs with thin white borders.
metas.note: On the contrary, Slovak house numbers are typically written on white signs with a thin red or black border.

metas.title: Czech Sign Posts
metas.description: Czech sign posts typically have thick, black caps.
metas.note: While some European countries have similar caps, Slovakia usually does not have them.

metas.title: Czech Pedestrian Signs
metas.description: Czech pedestrian signs have five stripes.
metas.note: The stripes on Slovak pedestrian signs are a smaller scale. This is noticeable when comparing the outermost stripes to the edge of the triangle.

metas.title: Czech Road Signs
metas.description: Czech road signs have a fairly thin font.
metas.note: Slovak signs normally have a much bolder font. The same font is however used in Luxembourg and Germany.

metas.title: Czech Kilometre Markers
metas.description: Czech kilometre markers have a yellow outline outside the black frame and do not have a black horizontal middle line.
metas.note: Slovak kilometre markers typically have a black horizontal middle line and do not have a yellow outline.

metas.title: Czechia Features
metas.description: Bicycle signs in Czechia are yellow. You may also find markings similar to hiking markers, but with yellow stripes instead of white.

metas.title: Czechia Features
metas.description: Suburban houses in Czechia are commonly connected in pairs.
metas.note: This is less common in most neighbouring countries, including Slovakia.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: Much of Czech Generation 3 coverage was taken during winter, resulting in very grey, and occasionally snowy, coverage.
metas.note: This is not common in Slovakia.

metas.title: Czechia Features
metas.description: A white Google car is present in Czechia but not Slovakia.
metas.note: Other European countries can have a white Google Car.

metas.title: Czech Railway Crossing
metas.description: Czech railway crossing signs do not have a background.
metas.note: Slovak railway crossing signs have a white rectangular background.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description: While rare, it is possible to find Generation 2 in Czechia.
metas.note: Slovakia does not have any Generation 2.

metas.title: First Digit Road
metas.description:
The first digit of road numbers can be anything between 1-6. Though, roads starting with 6 are scattered across most of the country. There are three exceptions, being roads 7, 8 and 9, which all start in Prague and go to the north and northwest.

Roads starting with 1-5 are mostly distributed as the map shows, with some overlap and exceptions mainly due to longer, two-digit roads.

metas.title: Four-digit Bike Paths
metas.description: Four-digit bike paths follow a geographical pattern, increasing clockwise, starting in Southern Bohemia. They do not show up on Google Maps, and as such remembering the general pattern is necessary to make them useful. Single- and two-digit bike paths are shown on this map, however they are far less useful to know.
metas.note: Paths starting with A are unique to Prague, regardless how big the number. Some paths spill into neighbouring regions.

metas.title: Area Code Map
metas.description: Czech phone numbers are typically made up of 9 digits, of which the first 1-3 digits are the area code. Note that if the first digit is 6 or higher, it does not indicate a specific area. They’re not very common.
metas.note: Slovak phone numbers typically begin with a 0.

metas.title: Czechia Features
metas.description: Around 95% of all wine produced in Czechia comes from the Moravian wine region.

metas.title: Much Northern Bohemian
metas.description: Much of the northern Bohemian landscape can be characterised by a rolling landscape combined with steep solitary hills.
metas.note: The hills can sometimes have castles on the top, which look absolutely awesome.

metas.title: Czechia Features
metas.description: Timber framed houses in Czechia are mostly found along the northern parts of the German border.

metas.title: Wooden Poles
metas.description: Houses with thick, dark wooden poles supporting the upper floors are common in the northernmost parts of the country.

metas.title: Dark Wooden Houses
metas.description: Dark wooden houses, with white stripes shining through the wood, are common in most of northern Czechia.

metas.title: Town Houses Moravia
metas.description:
Town houses in Moravia typically have two distinctive features:

Houses have the long side parallel to the road and are often connected in large groups.

Front doors are abnormally large, similar in size and shape to barn doors.
metas.note: This is also common in northeastern Austria.

metas.title: Local Architecture
metas.description: A variant of baroque architecture called Selské Baroko (folk baroque) can be found in the region surrounding České Budějovice. The style is characterised by highly decorated walls, with the setting being small villages rather than towns and cities.

metas.title: It Features
metas.description: It is more common to see houses with single pane windows in the northwestern parts of the country.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description: While possible to find in most of the country, blue street signs are more common in the east of the country, with Ostrava being the only major city to mainly use them.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description: If you see a white street sign with blue text and a red border, the same as is typical for Slovakia, then you should be near the Slovak border.

metas.title: White Street Signs
metas.description: White street signs with red text are most commonly found in the eastern parts of the country. They can also be found in the southernmost parts.
metas.note: Brno notably uses this design.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description: White street signs with blue text are most common in the eastern parts of the country, but can also be seen in the central northern parts.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description: White street signs with black text are most commonly found in the southeastern parts of the country. Note that these can look very similar to the ones with blue text.

metas.title: Streets Downtown Prague
metas.description: Streets in downtown Prague are commonly paved with grey and white marble stones, which is also typical for Portugal. They’re often arranged in intricate square mosaics, but some sections are far more plain.
metas.note: Similar pavement can be found in much lower volume in other towns too. Consider the apparent size of the city before guessing Prague.

metas.title: Cube Shaped Functionalist
metas.description: Cube shaped, functionalist red brick houses are found in Zlín, as a remainder of the shoemaking company Baťa’s houses for their workers. In the city centre, high rise buildings are constructed in similar style.
metas.note: So-called Bata-villes were also constructed outside of Czechia, most notably in Slovakia and France.

metas.title: Brno Features
metas.description: Pairs of black and white house numbers are found in Brno.
metas.note: The city district can be found written on the black house number.

metas.title: Pilsen House Numbers
metas.description: Pilsen house numbers typically consist of two red and white octagonal plates with inverse colour schemes.

metas.title: House Numbers České
metas.description: House numbers in České Budějovice have one red and one white plate with underlined numbers.

metas.title: Red House Numbers
metas.description:
Red house numbers with a dividing line and a Roman numeral are unique to Liberec.

The dividing line is an important identifying factor, as Roman numerals can be found on house numbers in other cities.

metas.title: Písek Uses Yellow
metas.description: Písek uses yellow house numbers with a black outline.

metas.title: Street Signs
metas.description: Polish bilingual street signs are found in Český Těšín, and very rarely in other nearby towns.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description: The street signs in Šumperk can be recognized by being blue, with text filling out almost the entire sign.

metas.title: License Plate Types
metas.description: Standard plates are long and white, with a blue strip on the left. Commercial plates are yellow. And so-called “Parrot” plates have a yellow section on the left hand side. These are unique to Denmark.
metas.note: The Netherlands, Luxembourg and the UK use yellow plates for private vehicles.

metas.title: General Landscape
metas.description: Denmark is a generally flat country with wide, open fields between towns. Suburban areas are usually open, with space between buildings. Urban cores are more dense and built up.

metas.title: White Road Lines
metas.description: Denmark has all-white road lines. Double middle lines are very common.
metas.note: Some other European countries, most notably Poland and Greece, can have double middle lines.

metas.title: Square Dashed Outer Lines
metas.description: Outer road lines often consist of small white squares. These unique-looking lines are a good way to identify Denmark.

metas.title: Pipe-Framed Signs
metas.description:
Denmark has very unique-looking direction signs that are very useful to recognize the country. They are low to the ground and framed by pipes. They are either coloured red and white or blue and white, with a directional arrow incorporated into the background. Signs often feature road numbers.

Some larger road signs have a more standard layout without the pipe frame. Highway signs have blue or green backgrounds.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs & '-vej'
metas.description: Most Danish street names end in “vej.” This is the Danish word for “street.” Street signs most commonly have a blue background with white text.

metas.title: Unique Danish Bollards
metas.description: Denmark has a very recognizable white bollard with a yellow reflector and a dark orange stripe. This bollard is unique to the country. You may also find this green variant.
metas.note: Belgium has bollards that may look somewhat similar. However, it will never feature the orange stripe.

metas.title: Danish Language Chars
metas.description: Danish is a North Germanic language that is closely related to Swedish and Norwegian. The Danish alphabet contains these special letters: Æ, Ø, and Å.
metas.note:
The special letters found in Danish can also be found in some of the other Northern Germanic languages:

Norwegian uses Æ, Ø, and Å.

Faroese uses Æ and Ø but not Å.

Icelandic only uses Æ.

Swedish only uses Å. In addition, Swedish uses Ä and Ö, which are not found in Danish.

metas.title: Red Brick Architecture
metas.description: Much of the architecture in Denmark consists of red brick. Roofs often have orange, dark brown or black tiles.
metas.note: Similar brick architecture is also common in the Netherlands and Belgium.

metas.title: Thatched & Corrugated Roofs
metas.description:
Some houses in Denmark have thatched roofs, especially in rural areas.

You can also sometimes find grey corrugated roofs. These look somewhat similar to roofs commonly found in Baltic countries.

metas.title: Timber Frame Buildings
metas.description: Some older or rural buildings have timber frame walls.
metas.note: Timber framing can be found in other Western and Central European countries as well, but are an especially common wall type for historical buildings in Denmark.

metas.title: Pipe-Bent Signposts
metas.description: This signpost, where the pipe frame is bent around the sign, is unique to Denmark.

metas.title: Square Guardrails
metas.description: Denmark has square (normal B-type) guardrails, with no reflectors.
metas.note: Denmark is one of only a very few European countries with this type of guardrail. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: 5-Stripe Pedestrian Sign
metas.description: This Danish pedestrian sign has 5 stripes. Uniquely, the first and fifth stripe touch the edge of the white triangle.
metas.note: Sweden’s pedestrian sign has 4 stripes. Norway almost always has 4 stripes too, but very rarely you can find signs with 5 stripes.

metas.title: Town Entry/Exit Sign
metas.description: This unique sign is found when entering a town. When leaving, there will be a red slash through the sign.

metas.title: Bus Stop Signs
metas.description: Bus stop signs in Denmark are black and yellow. A small sign is attached to the top of the pole, with the bus schedule underneath. Additionally, you may see this older blue and white version.

metas.title: Red & White Chevrons
metas.description: This red-and-white chevron is found in Denmark. They are often low to the ground.

metas.title: Lack of Utility Poles
metas.description: Standard street level utility poles are rare in Denmark. Most of the electricity infrastructure you will find in the countryside are large, towering overhead power lines, often near highways.

metas.title: Bicycle Paths
metas.description: You may sometimes see bicycle paths on the side of the road.
metas.note: Bicycle paths are also commonly seen in the Netherlands and Belgium.

metas.title: PostNord Postal Boxes
metas.description: The PostNord, or Post Danmark company, is the national provider of postal services in Denmark. It uses these unique postal boxes.

metas.title: Gas Stations
metas.description:
These four gas station brands are common to Denmark, but each are shared between one other country:

Ingo can be found in Denmark and Sweden.

Ok can be found in Denmark and the Netherlands.

Uno-X and Yx can be found in Denmark and Norway.

metas.title: Stone Bicycle Path Bollards
metas.description: You will rarely see these stone bollards, which may be painted red at the top, near bicycle paths.

metas.title: Road Numbering System
metas.description:
Denmark has an easy to learn road numbering system. They order their roads from east to west.

Roads starting with the numbers 2 to 5 are grouped by region.

Roads starting with the number 1 can be found nationwide, but the second digit still follows a rough regional distribution. Notably, Bornholm only has roads starting with the number 1.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Ring Road Numbering
metas.description:
Ring roads are special highways near bigger cities, labelled from O1 up to O4. The number increases from the centre, and each fully or partially encircles the city.

These cities have ring roads: Copenhagen, Odense, Aarhus, Aalborg, Hillerød, Kolding, and Velje.

metas.title: Regional Bus Companies
metas.description:
There are six regions in Denmark that each use a different bus transportation company. Each bus will have the brand written on the front, and have a unique colour scheme.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Regional Bus Stops
metas.description:
In addition, these regions each have their own bus stop sign.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Greenland Guide
metas.description:
Greenland is the world’s largest island country, and is a part of Denmark.

A separate Plonk It guide to Greenland can be found here.

metas.title: Faroe Islands Guide
metas.description:
The Faroe Islands is a group of united islands in the North Atlantic, and are an autonomous territory of Denmark.

A separate Plonk It guide to Faroe Islands can be found here.

metas.title: Bornholm Bus Stops
metas.description: The bus stops on the island of Bornholm have this unique green, red and white colour scheme.

metas.title: Bornholm Bicycle Signs
metas.description: These green bicycle signs are found on the island of Bornholm.

metas.title: Ls Seaweed Roofs
metas.description: These traditional “seaweed roofs” are found on the island of Læsø. They are made from a type of seaweed known as eelgrass.

metas.title: Anholt Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description: The island of Anholt only has Generation 2 coverage, with distinct gloomy, overcast weather. A large portion of coverage is recognizable due to the sandy dirt on the roadside.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Estonian licence plates are long and white, with the standard blue European strip on the left.

metas.title: Estonian Bollards
metas.description:
Estonian bollards have a round, baton-like shape.

They have a rectangular reflector on the front and two circular reflectors on the back. The reflectors can be white or orange.
metas.note:
Latvian and Lithuanian bollards look different.

This infographic shows the main similarities and differences between the bollards of the Baltic and Nordic countries.

metas.title: Utility Pole Variety
metas.description:
Estonia uses a variety of different poles and poletops. Of the three Baltic countries, it has the least consistent utility poles.

Round wooden poles are the most common, sometimes with diagonal supports.

metas.title: Square Concrete Poles
metas.description: You can additionally find a fair amount of square concrete poles, often also with diagonal supports. These are similar to those found in Lithuania.

metas.title: Trident Pole Tops
metas.description: Trident pole tops are somewhat common: This pole top features one insulator on top, and two to the side.

metas.title: Pole Top Caps
metas.description: Most wooden poles have a small metal cap on top, similar to those found in the Nordic countries.
metas.note: Alongside the Nordic countries of Sweden, Finland and Norway, these caps can also sometimes be found in Latvia.

metas.title: Short Dashed Outer Lines
metas.description: Outer road lines sometimes consist of short dashes.
metas.note:
Lithuania also sometimes has short dashes.

In addition, Sweden primarily uses short dashes as outer road lines.

metas.title: Chevron Color Scheme
metas.description: Estonia uses red chevrons with white arrows.
metas.note:
Russia and Ukraine use the same chevrons.

However, Latvian and Lithuanian chevrons have the opposite colour scheme: they are white with red arrows.

metas.title: Kilometer Marker Angle
metas.description:
All Baltic countries use the same blue kilometre marker. However, they can be distinguished from each other by their angle relative to the road.

In Estonia, the marker will be perpendicular to the road. It has numbers on both sides of the marker.

For a quick overview of all three Baltic countries, see this infographic.

metas.title: Thin Red Sign Border
metas.description:
Each Baltic country has a slightly different border for its warning and speed signs.

Estonian signs have a thin red border, with no white outline around it (the red border extends all the way to the edge of the sign).

metas.title: A-Type Guardrails
metas.description: Estonia has normal A-type guardrails with no reflectors.
metas.note: The other two Baltic countries can have reflectors on their guardrails. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: 3-Stripe Pedestrian Sign
metas.description: Estonian pedestrian signs have 3 stripes. The shape of the pedestrian has a relatively high level of detail, detailing shoes and an attached head.
metas.note:
Lithuanian signs also have 3 stripes, but the pedestrian looks less detailed.

Latvian pedestrian signs have 5 stripes.

metas.title: Bus Stop Signs
metas.description:
Estonian bus stop signs have this design.

The bus has four windows. This is mostly useful to distinguish it from the Latvian bus stop sign, which has five windows.

Note, however, that Lithuania has the same bus stop signs as Estonia.

metas.title: Blue & White Pole Wrappings
metas.description: These blue and white signpost wrappings are very common in Estonia.
metas.note: They are also common in Finland and Sweden.

metas.title: Language Characteristics
metas.description:
Estonian belongs to the Finnic languages, a branch of the Uralic language family. It is closely related to Finnish.

Within the Baltic languages, the following letters are unique to Estonian:

Vowels with umlauts (two dots): Ä Ö Ü.

Õ with a tilde.
metas.note: Latvian and Lithuanian are both Indo-European languages that are not related to Estonian, and therefore look very different.

metas.title: Street Naming ('Tnav/Tee')
metas.description:
The Estonian words for street and road are tänav and tee, respectively. These words are unique to Estonian. Tänav is often abbreviated as ‘tn’.

Many streets, especially in urban areas, have a simple name that completely lacks the tänav and or tee suffix.
metas.note: The Finnish suffix -tie, meaning street, can look similar.

metas.title: Oval Blue House Numbers
metas.description: It is fairly common to find oval-shaped blue house numbers in Estonia.
metas.note: This is not common in the other Baltic countries, but can also be found in Russia.

metas.title: Wood & White Brick Architecture
metas.description: Estonian architecture generally consists of a combination of wood and white brick, typically with somewhat steep corrugated metal roofs. Painted stone walls are also somewhat common. While wooden buildings can be found in all three Baltic countries, they are more common in Estonia.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Directional signs in Estonia are blue with white text and a white outline.
metas.note: In Finland, the arrow is built into the white border instead of being an icon inside the border. The arrow on Latvian signs is more stylized than in Estonia and Lithuania, where the back part of the arrowhead is vertical.

metas.title: Gen 3 Green Tint
metas.description:
Generation 3 coverage in Estonia often has a slight green tint to part of the panorama, which is referred to as “green blur” by the community.

For many players, this green blur can be hard to identify at first. The location shown in this tip’s image is a fairly extreme example. To familiarise you with how it might look in-game, here are some more examples where it is fairly visible: 1, 2, 3, 4.
metas.note:
This discoloration usually does not occur in Latvia and Lithuania.

It can however also be found in Sweden, often on the island of Gotland.

metas.title: Rural Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description:
The Generation 3 coverage in Estonia is more extensive than the other two Baltic countries, meaning that a lot of very rural roads are covered. As a result, if you are considering guessing in one of the Baltic countries, and your location is Generation 3 on a very thin and rural road, you are slightly more likely to be in Estonia.

Of course, use caution. This meta has many variables, and is not always reliable. Only use it as a last resort in no-info Baltic roulette rounds, when you have no better clues available.

metas.title: Hilly Areas
metas.description:
Estonia is a fairly flat country throughout, with only 10% of the country being higher than 100 metres, and the highest point being 318 metres tall.

Still, the hilly parts can sometimes be recognizable. The hilliest areas are in the southeast, and the southern half of Lääne-Viru County. Note that the colours of this map are highly exaggerated to show the location of the hills more clearly.

metas.title: Russian Cyrillic Signs
metas.description:
Estonia has a large Russian minority. In most of Ida-Viru County, they form a majority. As a result, you will sometimes see bilingual signs with Russian Cyrillic and Estonian in the region in and around Narva.

Note that the majority of signs will still be in Estonian. You may occasionally see Cyrillic in other places.

metas.title: Tallinn Old Town
metas.description: The old town of Tallinn looks very different from any other urban area in Estonia. It is an almost perfectly preserved historic area, with lots of medieval and renaissance-era buildings. In places, it can look a lot like cities in central Europe.

metas.title: Kihnu Fall Coverage
metas.description:
Kihnu is a small island off the coast that has recognizable coverage:

All coverage is Generation 4, taken during late autumn (recognizable by the fallen brown leaves on the ground).

Noticeably, it has a very moody, dark cloud cover, taken close to sunset.

If you see a combination of these two things, Kihnu is a good place to guess.
metas.note: Note that near Tartu you can also get a fair amount of autumn coverage, sometimes with a fair amount of cloud cover.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The landscape of the Faroe islands is characterised by long, wide fjords with jagged green mountains that rise straight out of the water, with rocky ridge lines along the mountainsides. The mountains generally look more imposing and greener than coastal mountains in Iceland, which can often be used to tell them apart.

metas.title: Faroe Islands Have
metas.description: The Faroe islands have almost no naturally growing trees.

metas.title: Pickup Truck Meta
metas.description: The generation 4 coverage was captured with a black pickup truck with an antenna on the front. The truck is always blurred.
metas.note: The truck in Iceland does not have a similar antenna.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: All Generation 3 car coverage on the Faroe Islands has a black Street View car with a plain grey roof rack.
metas.note: No other country with a similar landscape has a car similar to this.

metas.title: Faroese Houses Typically
metas.description: Faroese houses are typically made of wood, often with an above ground basement made of stone which is painted in a different colour than the wooden part. Roofs will usually be either metal or have grass on top (turf).

metas.title: Language Features
metas.description: The Faroese language is most closely related to Icelandic, with the special letters Á, Ð, Í, Ó, Ú, Ý, Æ and Ø. It differs from Icelandic by using the letter Ø, while Icelandic uses É and Þ.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Faroese bollards are small wooden sticks that are mainly painted yellow and sometimes red on the top.

metas.title: Road Guardrails
metas.description: Guardrails on the Faroes have yellow reflectors.
metas.note: Yellow reflectors are not found on guardrails in any other northern European countries.

metas.title: Iceland Features
metas.description: Directional signs are yellow with a thin white border, identical to the ones in Iceland.

metas.title: Torshavn By Far
metas.description: Torshavn is by far the biggest town on the islands, and the only place where you will find buildings taller than three floors. The landscape is somewhat open relative to the rest of the country, particularly to the east.

metas.title: Klaksvik City
metas.description: Klaksvik is the second biggest town in the country by a significant margin and can often be recognized by the narrow fjord with fairly steep hills going roughly north to south.

metas.title: There Three Wind
metas.description: There are three wind parks visible on the Faroes. The largest one by far is northwest of Torshavn, while the other two are northeast of Torshavn and east of Vestmanna respectively.

metas.title: Village Kirkjubøur
metas.description: The village of Kirkjubøur at the southern tip of the main island can be recognised by the black houses, almost all having grass roofs. The town also has a small church ruin.

metas.title: Trekker Koltur Island
metas.description: The trekker on Koltur island can typically be recognized by the narrow and low peninsula on the southeastern tip of the island.

metas.title: Trekker Eiðiskollur Be
metas.description: The trekker on Eiðiskollur can be recognized by the extremely low clouds surrounding the peninsula.

metas.title: Trekker West Skopun
metas.description: The trekker west of Skopun can be recognised by the wide strait to the north with the main islands of the Faroes in the background.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: There are two distinct pyramid-shaped mountains to the south of the trekker on Klakkur, with a very thin layer of snow on top.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: The trekker by Gjógv features a view of the village to the south with snow covered mountains in the background.

metas.title: Grey Boat Featuring
metas.description: A grey boat featuring several people in reflective clothes and with the text “RIB62” can be seen going to Koltur island.

metas.title: License Plate Dimensions
metas.description: Finland has shorter than normal white plates with the standard European blue strip on the left.
metas.note: Åland has small, fully white plates with blue lettering.

metas.title: Solid White Outer Lines
metas.description: Where present, outer road lines will always be solid white lines.
metas.note: Unlike Sweden and Norway, Finland does not use dashed outside lines. The only exception to this are the Åland Islands in southwest Finland, which do use dashes.

metas.title: Yellow Middle Lines
metas.description:
Finland has several different types of middle road lines, including:

white dashes, with or without a solid white line next to it

solid yellow with white dashes

double yellow.

Yellow lines are being phased out and are increasingly rare in newer coverage.
metas.note: Sweden never has yellow middle lines. Norway has middle lines that have a distinct orange tint.

metas.title: Black & White Bollards
metas.description: Finland has long black-and-white bollards with a rectangular, white reflector on the front and two dots on the back. They can be either round or thin and curved. The black strip is typically diagonal.
metas.note: They can look somewhat similar to bollards found in other Northern European countries. This infographic shows the differences.

metas.title: Orange Snow Poles
metas.description: In Finland, it is common to find orange snow poles with a thin white band near the top.
metas.note: These are also found commonly in Norway and Sweden, but with a much wider white band, lower down on the pole. They can also have multiple white bands, while Finnish snow poles usually have just one band.

metas.title: Finnish Language Chars
metas.description: The Finnish language is not related to most other European languages, so it has a very unique look. It has a lot of long words and double vowels. The Finnish alphabet includes the letters ä and ö.
metas.note: Estonian is closely related to Finnish, so it can look similar. Estonian uses the letters õ and ü, which are not used in Finnish.

metas.title: Street Names ('-tie/katu')
metas.description: Most Finnish street names end in “tie” or “katu.” These are the Finnish words for road and street. Street signs most commonly have a white background with black text.
metas.note: You may find roads ending in “polku” and “kuja”.

metas.title: Yellow Sign Backgrounds
metas.description: Finnish road signs have a yellow background.
metas.note: Signs in Sweden and Iceland also have yellow backgrounds. Norway, however, has signs with a white background.

metas.title: Yellow Stroke on Signs
metas.description: On traffic signs that have a red border, you will find a thin yellow stroke on the edge of the sign.
metas.note: You will not see this in any other Nordic country.

metas.title: 5-Stripe Pedestrian Sign
metas.description: Finnish pedestrian signs have 5 stripes.
metas.note: Pedestrian signs in Sweden and Norway usually have 4 stripes. In rare cases, you can find 5 stripes in Norway.

metas.title: Blue Directional Signs
metas.description: Finnish directional signs consist of a solid blue background, white text, and a white border with guiding arrows.

metas.title: Black & Yellow Chevrons
metas.description: Finnish chevrons are black with yellow arrows.
metas.note: Norway and Iceland have similarly coloured chevrons. Sweden, on the other hand, has unique blue and yellow chevrons.

metas.title: Wooden Utility Poles
metas.description: Finland primarily uses wooden utility poles. Most of them tend to have a simple design, but they can have a variety of poletops. Poles often have a street light attached to them.
metas.note: In Northern Europe, wooden poles are also common in Sweden, Norway, and Estonia.

metas.title: Double-Bolted Lamps
metas.description: Lamps attached to wooden poles in Finland are normally mounted to the top of the pole with a double bolting.
metas.note: Within Scandinavia, Sweden also uses double bolting. However, in Sweden the lamps are mounted further down and the lamp arms are usually not straight.

metas.title: Blue/White Signpost Stripes
metas.description: Traffic signposts often have blue and white striped markings.
metas.note: This pattern can also be found in Sweden. While the same colour scheme is also common in Estonia, the markings typically have a wider shape and attach to the signpost in a looser way.

metas.title: Birch & Pine Forests
metas.description: Most of Finland is covered by dense boreal forests. Pine trees are common, as well as birches, which are easily recognizable by their white trunks.

metas.title: Fall Colors (Gen 3)
metas.description: A lot of Generation 3 coverage was taken in autumn, meaning that trees in this coverage often have distinct fall colours.
metas.note:
This is significantly less common in Generation 3 coverage in the other Nordics. This means that when you are faced with a tough decision between countries, a fall vibe can be a good clue for Finland.

Take note that this season meta is not present in Generation 2 and Generation 4 coverage.

metas.title: Abundance of Lakes
metas.description: Lakes are so common in Finland, that the country is also sometimes known as the Land of a Thousand Lakes. Usually, you do not have to drive long to find a body of water.

metas.title: Modern & Wooden Architecture
metas.description: Finnish architecture is mostly modern and utilitarian. Downtown areas tend to be very modern, with lots of apartment buildings and use of concrete. Suburbs mostly consist of freestanding single family homes. Many houses have wooden cladding. Like Sweden and Norway, some wooden buildings, especially in the countryside, are painted in a distinctive dark red colour.

metas.title: Bus Stop Signs
metas.description: Finland has two styles of bus stop signs, a blue and white one, and a yellow and black one.
metas.note: This can be used to tell Finland apart from Sweden, which has many different bus stop signs (example), most of which have the names of the stops on them.

metas.title: Supermarket Chains
metas.description:
K-Market and S-Market are two Finnish supermarket chains with recognizable logos. Both chains operate only in Finland.

K-Market is sometimes known as K-Supermarket or K-Citymarket.

metas.title: Shitcam (Low Quality)
metas.description: Google used a weird, low-quality camera in Finland. This camera is known as the official Ari (or “Shitcam”). It has a wide circular car blur, and can be distinguished from Generation 2 by its lack of a sky halo and often somewhat brownish colours. A good map will not usually include this coverage, but it is good to be aware of its existence, in order to not be caught off-guard by it.
metas.note: Within Europe, Finland and Spain are the countries that have the most coverage with this camera. This camera should not be confused with unofficial coverage, which is also common in Finland.

metas.title: Smallcam Coverage
metas.description: Finland also has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.
metas.note: All of Northern Europe also has smallcam.

metas.title: Regional Road Numbering
metas.description:
Finnish regional roads have 3- or 4-digit road numbers. The first digit of those road numbers is region-specific. These regions are distributed in a rough south-to-north order, starting from 1 in the south to 9 in the north.

These road numbers often appear on direction signs. Learning the regions can help with cutting down on scanning time for 5k’s, or give you a rough region to plonk in during quick no move games.
metas.note: Major roads with 2-digit road numbers do not adhere to this geographic pattern.

metas.title: Lapland Snow Poles
metas.description: Snow poles which have 2 long reflectors can be found on bigger roads in Lapland.
metas.note: They can only be found in coverage from 2023 onward.

metas.title: Coastal Farmlands
metas.description: Finland has a lot of farmlands, but the majority of them are concentrated near the west and south coast.

metas.title: West Coast Wind Turbines
metas.description: Wind turbines are most commonly found along the west coast of Finland, with some exceptions.

metas.title: Northern Stunted Trees
metas.description: Small, stunted trees with spindly, thin trunks are common in northern Finland.

metas.title: Lapland Gen 3 Snow
metas.description: Generation 3 snow coverage is only found in far northwestern Lapland.
metas.note: Be careful: this tip is specifically about regular Generation 3 coverage. Generation 2, 4, and trekker snow coverage can be found elsewhere.

metas.title: Swedish Speaking Areas
metas.description: The Swedish language is common in some coastal areas in the south and the west. In these areas, bilingual Swedish or Finnish texts are common. If you see Swedish language in a Finnish setting, do not guess inland.

metas.title: Smi Languages
metas.description: The Sámi languages are spoken in the far north of Finland. In this region, you can sometimes find bilingual signs with place names in both Finnish and Sámi. Unlike Finnish, its alphabet uses the letter c.

metas.title: Southwest Tilted Antenna
metas.description: This slightly tilted, long antenna can be found in southwestern Finland.
metas.note: Do not mix it up with the straight long antenna.

metas.title: South-Central No Antenna
metas.description: Generation 3 coverage with no antenna at all can be found in south-central Finland.

metas.title: land Islands Status
metas.description: Åland is a group of islands off the southwestern coast. It is an autonomous, mostly self-governing region of Finland with its own flag. Though it has a special status, for country streaks purposes it is still counted as part of Finland.
metas.note: Åland has no Generation 4 coverage.

metas.title: land Swedish Language
metas.description: Åland is monolingually Swedish. If you see only Swedish, and no Finnish language, but you suspect that you are in Finland, consider the Åland Islands.

metas.title: land Road Features
metas.description: Åland roads have two unique aspects that separate them from the rest of Finland: their pavement tends to have a red tint, and they have dashed outside road lines that resemble those found in Sweden.

metas.title: land License Plates
metas.description: Licence plates on Åland are white with blue text, making them appear almost completely white on Street View. They are noticeably quite short and lack the European blue strip on the left side.

metas.title: land Pedestrian Signs
metas.description: Some pedestrian signs on Åland have four stripes, with the exact same design found in Sweden. Beware that many pedestrian signs will still be the typical Finnish design.

metas.title: land Bus Stops
metas.description: Bus stops on Åland include a white plate with 4 numbers. Some also include this semicircle sign on top.
metas.note: Some bus stops in Mariehamn do not follow this rule.

metas.title: Road 970 (North)
metas.description: Road 970 in the far north, on the border with Norway, is easily recognizable: it runs through a river valley with hills on both sides. The river is visible in many places, usually to the northwest. The birch trees around the road are small and stunted.
metas.note: The Generation 3 coverage on this road was taken in the autumn, meaning that the vegetation looks dead and mostly devoid of leaves.

metas.title: Kilpisjrvi Landscape
metas.description: Due to its proximity to the Scandinavian Mountains, the area near Kilpisjärvi features a unique hilly landscape, with low vegetation.
metas.note: The Generation 2 coverage on this road was taken during Spring, so the vegetation looks dead.

metas.title: Helsinki Sidewalk Trekker
metas.description: Downtown Helsinki has a lot of Generation 4 sidewalk trekker coverage.
metas.note: This tip is specifically about Generation 4 trekker coverage. Generation 3 sidewalk trekkers can be found in many other Finnish cities.

metas.title: Helsinki Trams
metas.description: Helsinki features these unique green-and-yellow trams.
metas.note: Tampere is the only other Finnish city with trams, but they are red instead of green and yellow.

metas.title: Helsinki Buses
metas.description: The buses in and around Helsinki are typically blue-and-white, with a vertical split. Buses elsewhere can have the same colour scheme, so look for one of these logos on the bus.

metas.title: Tampere Buses
metas.description: The buses in and around Tampere are blue on the bottom and white on the top. The word ‘NYSSE’ is written on the sides of the buses.

metas.title: Turku Buses
metas.description: Buses in Turku are uniquely yellow, with a white rear.

metas.title: Jyvskyl Buses
metas.description: Buses in Jyväskylä are almost completely green.

metas.title: Oulu Buses
metas.description: Buses in Oulu have a pink front.

metas.title: Tampere Metallic Plates
metas.description: You can find these unique metallic plates on houses, lamp posts, and signposts in Tampere.

metas.title: Seinjoki Street Signs
metas.description: This style of blue street sign with white text is unique to the cities of Seinäjoki and Isokyrö southeast of Vaasa.

metas.title: Lahti Street Signs
metas.description: Lahti uses these street signs with a black border and all capital letters.
metas.note: You can rarely find similar signs in other cities, but Lahti almost exclusively uses this design. Notably, Kuopio can use these signs, which use a thicker, more compact font.

metas.title: Kerava Coat of Arms
metas.description: The city of Kerava uses street signs with this blue-and-yellow coat of arms in the top-left corner.

metas.title: Jrvenp Coat of Arms
metas.description: The city of Järvenpää uses street signs with this blue-and-grey coat of arms in the top-left corner. The neighbourhood name is also written above the street name.
metas.note: If you see a street sign with a coat of arms not mentioned in this guide, you should be near Kerava or Lahti.

metas.title: License Plate Stripes
metas.description:
Modern French plates are long and white, with blue strips on both sides of the plate. The left strip will be more visible than the right strip.

Some older French plates lack the right blue strip, with the rear plate being yellow. These are very rare in newer coverage.
metas.note: Italian plates also have two blue strips, which are equally visible. In addition, Italian front plates are considerably shorter.

metas.title: French Language Chars
metas.description:
French is a Romance language that is closely related to languages like Catalan, Spanish and Italian. It uses these diacritics and special letters:

Accent aigu: é

Accent grave: à, è, ù

Accent circonflexe: â, ê, î, ô, û

Trema: ë, ï, ü, ÿ

Ligature: œ

Cédille: ç with a small hook

In addition, the -ux suffix is only found in French.
metas.note: Other European countries with sizable francophone populations include Belgium, Luxembourg, Monaco and Switzerland.

metas.title: Street Name ('Rue')
metas.description: The French word for street is “rue”.

metas.title: White Bollard w/ Red Band
metas.description: The French bollard is extremely recognizable and appears very often. It is a round white post with a pointed top and a reflector band going all the way around. The band can be grey or red. Some rare variations have a fully red top.
metas.note: A bollard that is commonly found in Scotland looks similar, but has a blunt top instead of a pointed one.

metas.title: Double-Indented Bollard
metas.description:
A different round white bollard, with two reflective indented bands, is unique to France.

You can also find this design in other colours like green or yellow.

metas.title: Wedge-Shaped Bollard
metas.description: Less common wedge-shaped bollards with wide rectangular white reflectors on both the front and back are also unique to France.

metas.title: Ladder Poles
metas.description: Concrete poles with step-like indents are common in France. They are referred to as ladder or waffle poles by the community.
metas.note: They are also common in Spain.

metas.title: Rural Wooden Poles
metas.description: Wooden poles and thin octagonal metal poles are very common in rural areas and small towns.

metas.title: Blue Pole Stickers
metas.description:
Small blue rectangular markings on utility poles are unique to France. They are often referred to as ‘stickers’ by the community, but are actually small plates.

You will find these plates on almost all wooden and metallic poles, but not as often on ladder poles.

metas.title: French Poletops
metas.description: Diamond shaped pole tops with three wires are commonly called “French poletops” within the community. They are most frequently found on top of ladder poles.
metas.note: Within Europe, “French poletops” in conjunction with ladder poles are also common in Spain.

metas.title: Arrowhead Insulators
metas.description: Some variations of the French pole tops have the insulators on top. These variations may resemble an arrowhead and are unique to France.

metas.title: Smallcam Coverage
metas.description: France has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.
metas.note: Most of Western Europe also has smallcam.

metas.title: Yellow D-Road Signs
metas.description: Small yellow signs displaying the road number, which typically starts with a “D”, are unique to France. They are commonly placed on top of directional signs or town entry signs.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description:
French directional signs are usually white with a black outline slightly offset from the edge. They have an arrow-like shape, with the black border getting thicker at the point.

Highway directions have either a blue or green background.

Smaller places and points of interest are frequently written in an italic font.

metas.title: Town Entrance Signs
metas.description: Town entrance signs in France have a red border with a thin white outline.

metas.title: Red Border Signs
metas.description: French road signs have a red border with a thin white outline. You will often find white rectangular signs with black text below traffic signs.
metas.note: Road signs in Spain have a thick red border that goes all the way to the edge.

metas.title: Flat Signposts
metas.description:
Many traffic signs in France have flat rectangular signposts.

Signposts, along with signbacks, can be dyed with unorthodox colours, more so than in other countries. Some of those are regional, which you can learn more about in the regionguessing section.
metas.note: The only other European countries with flat signposts are Portugal, Spain, and Andorra.

metas.title: Short Signposts
metas.description: Traffic signs with particularly short signposts are very common in France.

metas.title: Multi-Arrow Chevrons
metas.description: France uses chevrons with white arrows on a blue background. They can have a wide amount of arrows, ranging from one to five.
metas.note: The only other European country with this colour scheme is Spain, where you will only find chevrons with two or four arrows.

metas.title: 5-Stripe Pedestrian Sign
metas.description:
Pedestrian crossing signs in France have five stripes and a disconnected head on the person. They have the usual white border of French traffic signs.

Less commonly, you can find a design with two dashed lines instead of stripes.

metas.title: Kilometer Markers
metas.description: Kilometre markers in France most commonly have a yellow or red semicircle on top of a white rectangle. They can be found in the form of a waystone or as a flat sign and can be either parallel or perpendicular to the road. Major highways can have square markers with a red top.

metas.title: Outer Road Dashes
metas.description: Typical French roads have long spaced out dashes on the outside.

metas.title: Offset Block Lines
metas.description: These middle road lines, where each dash consists of two offset blocks, are unique to France. They are not extremely common, but when you see them, you can safely guess France.

metas.title: Long Dashed Lines
metas.description: Middle lines with dashes that are longer than usual can be a good clue for France.
metas.note: Unusually long dashes are also common in the UK.

metas.title: Passing Zone Arrows
metas.description: These arrows on the road signalling the end of a passing zone are only found in a couple of European countries, including France. In France, the middle dashes will be very close together in these areas.
metas.note: Other countries where this style of arrow can be found are Spain, Portugal and Romania. These arrows can also be found in the UK, but they will point towards the left lane instead of the right one.

metas.title: A-Type Guardrails
metas.description: France uses A-type guardrails, usually without reflectors. On rare occasions, you can find thin B-type, the standard guardrail in Czechia and Slovakia.
metas.note: Spanish, Andorran and Belgian guardrails use yellow reflectors.

metas.title: Austrian Flag Markers
metas.description: Roads may be lined by tall rectangles on a stick in the colours of the Austrian flag, which are not found elsewhere.

metas.title: Stone & Pastel Houses
metas.description:
French architecture largely consists of stone houses, which will normally be either unpainted or painted in greyish or yellow pastel colours. The roofs will typically have a simple gable design, with orange tiles or less commonly black slates. Townhouses will often lay wall to wall along the road.

Do note that France has some of the most diverse regional architecture of any European country, so don’t be surprised to see towns that look significantly different from the previously described architecture.

metas.title: Blue House Numbers
metas.description: House numbers in France are most commonly blue, typically written in a serif font with slightly exaggerated shapes. This is most useful when differentiating from Italy, which almost never uses blue house number signs.
metas.note: Similar designs can be found in all other neighbouring, as well as many other, countries.

metas.title: Domestic Car Brands
metas.description: French car brands Peugeot, Renault and Citroën together make up almost half of all cars in France.
metas.note: These car brands are also common in linguistically related neighbouring countries.

metas.title: Administrative Divisions
metas.description:
This guide will mainly operate with two types of administrative divisions: regions, totalling at 13 in European France, and 96 departments, which appear on google maps as the primary administrative divisions. Other rarer divisions you may come across include pre 2016 regions, historical provinces, and regions based on cardinal directions.

Departments are often named after physical geographical features and their logos may show up on various infrastructure, shown in the next tip.

You can practise them with this quiz.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description:
French telephone numbers are 10 digits long, with the first two pairs of digits being two separate area codes, following two patterns:

01 is in Île-de-France and 02-05 goes clockwise from the northwest.

2X is in the far north, with the numbers generally increasing anticlockwise. 9X is an exception, being found both in the far northwest and far southeast.

Secondary area codes in Île-de-France can be seen on this map.
metas.note: Phone numbers beginning with 06-09 are not regional.

metas.title: Department Numbers
metas.description: Each department has an assigned number to it, arranged mostly alphabetically. This is most useful in postal codes, consisting of 5 digits, the first two representing the department they’re in.
metas.note: the same regional codes are used inside the right blue strip on licence plates.

metas.title: Department Logos
metas.description:
Most departments have their own unique logo (formally called official flag), often containing stylized initials or the entire name. Notable infrastructure with department logos include bus stops, kilometre markers, trail banners, directional signs and signbacks. Learning what each logo looks like is not recommended for beginners, but it can be helpful to know what they stand for when scanning.

You can find the full list of logos here, or see them projected onto a map here.

metas.title: Occitanie Flag
metas.description:
A red and yellow logo with an Occitan cross and vertical stripes is the official flag of the Occitanie region.

The rest of the regions also have logos, which appear less frequently. You can see them projected onto a map here.

metas.title: Pyrnes-Orientales Flag
metas.description: A flag made up of red and yellow stripes, based on the Senyera, is the official flag and department logo of Pyrénées-Orientales. You will often find the pattern used in coats of arms on street signs.
metas.note: The flag of Provence looks similar, but with vertical stripes instead.

metas.title: Red Tinted Roads
metas.description: Roads with a significant red, purple or burgundy tint are most commonly found in an area between Paris and Dijon, with Normandy being a notable exception. The historical region of Burgundy, which gave the name to the shade of red, roughly corresponds to the highlighted area.
metas.note: Normal roads may deceptively look reddish under some lighting, so use this with caution.

metas.title: Green Signposts
metas.description: Dark green road signposts and backs are most commonly found in Brittany and around Paris, but also various southern regions in the country.
metas.note: Beware that this, and the following coloured infrastructure can rarely be found in other parts of the country.

metas.title: Green Sticker Signbacks
metas.description: Signbacks in Eure-et-Loir may include a green sticker, the department’s logo. They’re usually placed on a dark green back, without a matching post.

metas.title: Decimal D-Roads
metas.description: Still in Eure-et-Loir, this is also where D-roads with a superscript number are most common. On the map, these are expressed as decimals, e.g. D134.10 and D121.9.
metas.note: They are rarely found in other departments.

metas.title: Grey-Green Signbacks
metas.description: A greyish green signback supported by a darker green post, is found in three areas: Brittany (Côtes-d'Armor and eastern half of Ille-et-Vilaine), Pyrénées-Atlantiques and rarely near the Alps.

metas.title: Pas-de-Calais Signs
metas.description: In the Pas-de-Calais department, you may find road signs with the following colour arrangement: a dark green post paired with a signback of a lighter shade of green, ranging from matcha green to greenish turquoise. The department’s logo, a green and blue triangle, is occasionally present on the signback.
metas.note: Under certain lighting, they can appear similar to the greyish road signs mentioned in the previous tip.

metas.title: Brown Signposts
metas.description: Road signs where both the post and back are painted brown are most commonly found in Seine-et-Marne, and rarely in Ille-et-Vilaine. It is more reliable when the post is square, however round signposts are equally common.

metas.title: Burgundy Attachments
metas.description: Directional signs in Haute-Garonne often use burgundy red attachments and ornaments. This is sometimes paired with yellow signposts.

metas.title: Combined Entry Signs
metas.description: Most town entry signs in Marne follow a unique format: Instead of having separate entry and exit signs, they are combined into a single, noticeably thicker block.

metas.title: Paris Suburb Signs
metas.description: Street signs in the metropolitan area of Paris often say the name of the city, which is generally atypical for street signs in France. The signs will often be made in a modern design, and many city names will be river based, notably named after Seine and Marne.
metas.note: This can be seen sporadically throughout the country, so consider other clues.

metas.title: Corsican Stone Barriers
metas.description: Cuboid barriers made of stones and mortar are commonly found on Corsica. While by no means unique to Corsica, it is good to consider the island when you see them in rounds with a plausible Mediterranean landscape.
metas.note: Stone barriers with a rounded top are not found on Corsica.

metas.title: Topography Map
metas.description: This is a topographic map of France. Notably, the tallest mountains are found in the southeast and on the Spanish border. The north and the west coast is generally quite flat or rolling, while the southern half is often hillier.

metas.title: Normandy Hedges
metas.description: Rural roads surrounded by hedges blocking the view, reminiscent of the British Isles, are primarily found in the northwest, particularly in Normandy.
metas.note: Hedges by themselves are not sufficient for recognizing this area and are common all over France.

metas.title: Southern Stone Pines
metas.description: Stone pines are commonly found along the southern coast, often planted alongside urban roads. You may however find them as north as Nantes.

metas.title: Landes Pine Forests
metas.description: Forests made up entirely of Maritime pines (pinus pinaster) are found in the southwest of the country (Gironde and Landes departments). The whole area will be fairly flat, which is not typical of other areas with such pines.

metas.title: Wine Regions
metas.description: France is the second largest wine producer in the world, with many famed wine regions. The most common include the area around Bordeaux, southern coast and Champagne, East of Paris. Other regions include, but are not limited to, Loire Valley, Alsace and Corsica.
metas.note: This map is highly simplified, see this map for more detailed and extensive description.

metas.title: Southwest Sunflowers
metas.description: Sunflowers are mostly found in the southwest of the country, particularly around Toulouse.

metas.title: Northern Wind Turbines
metas.description: Wind turbines are considerably more common in the north of the country.

metas.title: Northwest Black Roofs
metas.description: Black shingle roofs are primarily found in the northwest, the rough cutoff being the Loire river. Other areas include near the Belgian border, the south-centre, and the Pyrenees, making black roofs a good clue for Alps-Pyrenees toss-ups.

metas.title: Brittany Architecture
metas.description: Brittany has one of the most recognizable and consistent architectures in the country. Common elements include, in addition to black roofs, edge chimneys, black slate walls and stones surrounding doors and windows. The walls will be either very light coloured or made of stone.

metas.title: Southern Tiled Roofs
metas.description: Roofs in the south of the country will often be made up of rounded tiles overlapping one another, often varying in colour.

metas.title: Red Brick Rows
metas.description: Rows of dark red brick houses, most similar to Flemish architecture in Belgium, are unsurprisingly found near the Belgian border. The individual bricks may be outlined by white mortar.

metas.title: Toulouse Orange Bricks
metas.description: In and around Toulouse, mainly in old towns, you will commonly find bright orange brick buildings. They differ from brick houses near Belgium by the bricks being brighter, as well as somewhat Mediterranean looking architectural features, such as wooden shutters, being common.

metas.title: Paris Area Stone Walls
metas.description: Walls made of uneven cream coloured to orange stones, glued with mortar and often incorporating red brick details can be found in the towns surrounding Paris. Note that the city of Paris itself generally does not have this architecture.

metas.title: French Riviera Architecture
metas.description: The French Riviera will mirror many characteristics of Monaco. Rich areas with planted palms and light coloured multi story buildings with wide balconies are good indications you’re in this area, with the rest of the southern coast and Corsican Bastia sharing similar vibes.
metas.note: Just like Monaco, several cities host boat trekkers in their harbour.

metas.title: Basque Timber Framing
metas.description: White houses with, often colourful, timber framing are a staple of Basque architecture that extends beyond the Basque speaking area. The timber frame colour (in this case red) will be consistent with other wooden elements, like window shutters and gates.
metas.note: They’re also common in parts of Northern Spain, where the timber frames are usually unpainted.

metas.title: Alpine Architecture
metas.description: Alpine architecture, unmistakable for its light coloured base and extensive wooden elements, is unsurprisingly found in the Alps.
metas.note: Similar houses can be found in the touristic parts of Pyrenees.

metas.title: Alsatian Architecture
metas.description:
Many elements of Germanic architecture are concentrated in Alsace, such as timber framing and half-hip roof. Furthermore, roofs with fish scale tiles are more common in this region.

Beware that these elements are sometimes incorporated into architecture in other parts of France, and are most reliable in conjunction with one another.

metas.title: Regional Languages
metas.description:
France is home to many minority languages, 6 of which will be covered in this guide:

Alsatian, a dialect of Alemannic German.

Basque, the only European language isolate.

Breton, a Celtic language.

Catalan, Corsican and Occitan, Romance languages which are related to French.

However, French, legally the only official language, is dominant in all regions of the country, so don’t exclude highlighted regions when you’re placed in an all French round.

metas.title: Breton Language Signs
metas.description: Breton is a Celtic language, visually most similar to Welsh. Common letters include d, k, w and the letter ñ, which is not found in French. It is commonly found on the Breton peninsula, with bilingual street signs as east as Rennes and rarely Nantes. The Breton word for street is straed.

metas.title: Plou- Towns Prefix
metas.description: Towns with the Plou- prefix are concentrated in Northwestern Brittany.

metas.title: Alsatian Language Signs
metas.description: Alsatian, a dialect of German, is occasionally found in Alsace, a region that changed countries 4 times in modern history. Most bilingual street signs use some variation of gasse or strasse.
metas.note: Streets containing German names are also concentrated in this region, though not as consistently.

metas.title: Occitan Language Signs
metas.description:
Occitan is a Romance language closely related to Catalan that’s sparsely concentrated in the South of France, most often found on street signs in big cities, and very rarely on town entry signs. It can be divided into dialects, each using a slightly different word for street, all similar to Catalan “carrer”. For example, in Toulouse, you’ll find the Languedocian carrièra and in Avignon carriero, in the Provençal dialect.

Click here for a more extensive infographic.
metas.note: The street sign designs pictured are also unique to the two cities respectively.

metas.title: Basque Language Signs
metas.description:
