Bilingual signs in Basque, a language isolate, are concentrated In the western half of the Pyrénées-Atlantiques department, bordering the Basque speaking regions in Spain. Common letters include K, X and Z. On directional signs, it’s written with a thinner font, which is unique within all minority languages in France.

The word for street is karrika, in contrast to “kalea” in the Spanish Basque country.

metas.title: Corsican Language
metas.description: On the island of Corsica, you may find bilingual signs in Corsican, a Romance language that utilises many features found in Italian, like words almost always ending in vowels. In particular, the endings u/iu/ju, changed from o/io, are common in Corsican. Moreover, placenames will usually have an Italian origin.

metas.title: Catalan Language
metas.description:
The far southern department Pyrénées-Orientales, also known as Catalunya Nord (Northern Catalonia), uses Catalan on their various signage.

It is closely related to both Spanish and French, with Ç being considerably more common than in French. The word for street is carrer.

metas.title: Toponymy Suffixes
metas.description:
Knowing basic toponymy in France is crucial for regionguessing, particularly suffixes. This map shows one of the most common and useful endings, with rare exceptions. Other, extraordinarily rare suffixes can be found here.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: River/Coastal Toponyms
metas.description:
Many French cities contain the name of the river they lay on, usually in the format -sur-[river]. On signage, sur are often shortened to ˢ/, in this case Chalonnes-sur-Loire (Chalonnes upon Loire). The picture shows five of the longest and therefore most common origins of river based names, but cities can bear the name of any river, regardless of length.

Similarly, city names containing -sur-mer (=on sea) or -plage (=beach) are found exclusively on the coast.

metas.title: Runion Overview
metas.description:
Réunion is an overseas department and region of France, east of Madagascar. As such, it is counted as France for country streaks purposes.

Plonk It has a more in-depth guide to Réunion here.

metas.title: Saint-Pierre & Miquelon
metas.description:
Saint-Pierre and Miquelon is a self-governing territorial overseas collectivity of France, south of Newfoundland in Canada. As such, for country streaks purposes, it is counted as France.

Plonk It has a more in-depth guide to Saint-Pierre and Miquelon here.

metas.title: Martinique Overview
metas.description:
Martinique is an overseas department and region and a single territorial collectivity of France, in the eastern Caribbean. For country streaks purposes, it is counted as France.

Plonk It has a more in-depth guide to Martinique here.

metas.title: Parisian Mansard Roofs
metas.description: Mansard roofs, also known as French windows, are a very common feature of Parisian architecture. They’re made up of steep black shingle roofs with inserted dormer windows. While not unique to Paris, it is a good clue in abundance and on wide boulevards.

metas.title: Belle-le-en-Mer
metas.description: On the Breton island Belle-Île-en-Mer you can find houses typical for Brittany combined with colourful façades and outlines, superficially similar to houses in Portugal.
metas.note: The entire island was only covered with an often oversaturated Generation 2 camera.

metas.title: Lavender Fields
metas.description: Lavender fields can be found in the southeast, appearing as small grey bushes when not fully grown.

metas.title: Atlantic Salt Farms
metas.description: Salt farms, which appear as flooded trenches with grass medians, are found along the Atlantic coast, most notably around Guérande, Noirmoutier, Île de Ré and Île d'Oléron.

metas.title: Arrondissement Signs
metas.description:
Paris, Lyon and Marseille are the three largest cities in France and the only ones divided into municipal arrondissements (Arrᵗ or Arrt. for short). The arrondissements appear on google maps, so finding these street signs can help a lot with pinpointing.

The street signs of these three cities will be further described in the following tips.

metas.title: Paris Street Signs
metas.description: Paris uses an iconic green & Prussian blue design with a top arch that has also been replicated in Bucharest, which is sometimes referred to as Paris of the east.
metas.note: The simple rectangular form of the sign can be found in the towns nearby and rarely in other cities.

metas.title: Lyon Street Signs
metas.description: Lyon’s street signs feature four corner bolts and an uninterrupted inner white border that cuts a notch for the arrondissement and each bolt.
metas.note: Outside Lyon proper, the street sign will display the name of the suburb instead.

metas.title: Marseille Street Signs
metas.description: Marseille’s street signs will usually feature the city’s emblem, a variation of the Greek cross. The white border will usually be interrupted at the top, even when the cross is absent.

metas.title: Bordeaux Arrondissements
metas.description: Small tables with “Arrᵗ” written on a small separate sign, are found in Bordeaux, despite being a city not divided into arrondissements.

metas.title: Montpellier Street Signs
metas.description: Montpellier street signs will typically contain a blue ‘M’ on a white background in the top left corner.

metas.title: Lille Street Signs
metas.description: Street signs with a red slanted fleur-de-lis are unique to Lille.

metas.title: Bordeaux Red Posts
metas.description: In the outskirts of Bordeaux, you may find square traffic signposts with the Bordeaux shade of red, named after the wine grown in the region.
metas.note: Red posts by themselves are not unique to Bordeaux, so apply this meta with caution.

metas.title: Riviera Blue Posts
metas.description: On the French Riviera (Côte d'Azur in French, literally translated as Blue Coast), you can find regular traffic signposts painted azure blue. Uniquely, Cagnes-sur-mer, west of Nice, will feature lighter, powder blue infrastructure.
metas.note: Blue infrastructure can be found to a lesser extent all across France, particularly Brittany, so consider the landscape as well.

metas.title: Northern Thin B-Guardrails
metas.description: Thin B type guardrail, typical for Czechia and Slovakia, is sometimes found on highways in the northern half of the country, often coming from Le Mans, Tours, Paris, Reims and Metz.
metas.note: On the highlighted sections, thin B can be the minority guardrail, and short sections of any highway will have no guardrails at all. It is also more common on smaller roads in the North, but less consistent as a clue.

metas.title: Gen 3 Antenna Flags
metas.description: On rare occasions, you may find a flag attached to the antenna in the generation 3 coverage. While much of the highlighted areas has been overwritten, learning the distribution of each antenna can yield very high scores.
metas.note: All pictured colourful antenna flags are unique to France.

metas.title: Gen 4 Coverage
metas.description: All car coverage in Germany was taken with a Generation 4 camera.
metas.note: There are some Generation 2 and 3 trekkers, and spill coverage with older dates.

metas.title: Black & White Bollards
metas.description: Germany uses these black and white bollards, with white and light-grey reflectors. The reflector will be orange on bollards next to intersections. They sometimes have plates containing the road number, and potentially other useful information. Many bollards also feature blue attachments on the side.
metas.note: Many European countries have similar bollards, however most will have different coloured reflectors. Luxembourg uses almost identical bollards, but they have 3 bolts instead of 2 on the reflector.

metas.title: German Language Chars
metas.description: The official language of Germany is German. The German language uses the special letters Ä, Ö, Ü and ß.
metas.note: The other majority German-speaking countries with coverage are Switzerland, Austria and Liechtenstein. In addition, German is spoken in East Belgium and the Italian province of South Tyrol.

metas.title: White Pole Sticker
metas.description: Most wooden poles in Germany will feature a rectangular white sticker.

metas.title: Common Pole Tops
metas.description: Germany has a wide variety of different poles and pole tops. The most common pole tops being the horizontal bar with uneven hanging insulators, Triangle pole top, and all kinds of T-Shaped pole tops, which can have varying insulator setups.

metas.title: Dark Grey Sign Backs
metas.description: Germany also has a wide variety of sign backs. Notably, you can commonly find black or dark grey sign backs, which are rather rare in Europe. Most signs will also feature this sticker, with an upside-down red triangle on a black rectangle.
metas.note: Italy, Romania and Albania also have black sign backs, however landscape should be sufficient to tell them apart.

metas.title: Bus Stop Signs (H)
metas.description: Like Austria, Germany uses a wide variety of regional bus stops, all of which have the big yellow and green H symbol on them.

metas.title: Yellow Mailboxes
metas.description: Mailboxes in Germany are bright yellow, and feature this black logo.

metas.title: Bollard Frequency
metas.description: You will find an excessive amount of bollards on most roads in Germany. Around every 50 metres to be exact.

metas.title: Yellow Town Entry Signs
metas.description: German town entry signs are yellow with black text and have a metallic frame.
metas.note:
These signs can include a lot of useful information too:

The town and or city name on the top.

The Municipality in the middle.

And the county on the bottom.

metas.title: Blue Distance Markers
metas.description: Germany uses these blue rectangular kilometre markers with slightly rounded edges and a white border.
metas.note: In some rarer cases, they can be white too.

metas.title: 5-Stripe Pedestrian Sign
metas.description: German pedestrian signs have five stripes and the person has a belt.
metas.note: The same design is used in Luxembourg.

metas.title: Einbahnstrae Sign
metas.description: These one-way traffic signs, with the word ‘Einbahnstraße’ written on them, are unique to Germany.
metas.note: In Austria, there will be “EINBAHN” written on the sign.

metas.title: No Stopping Arrows
metas.description: “No Stopping” and “No Waiting” signs in Germany will often have white arrows drawn on them.

metas.title: Wind Turbine Density
metas.description: Wind turbines are far more common throughout Germany than in any other European country.

metas.title: Terrain & Elevation
metas.description:
Using the surrounding elevation can be crucial to getting good guesses in Germany. Here are some general rules:

The north and especially northwest is very flat.

Central Germany is hilly.

Very southern Germany has big mountains.

Also note that despite having a higher elevation, many parts of southern Germany can still be flat.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description: German area codes are grouped by their first digit. You can practise them by playing this map.

metas.title: Postal Code Clockwise
metas.description: Postal codes are arranged in a counter-clockwise fashion, starting with 0 around Saxony and ending with 9 in northern Bavaria and parts of Thuringia.

metas.title: State Flags
metas.description: Each German state has their own flag. Many of them are rare to find, though.

metas.title: State Coats of Arms
metas.description: Each German state also has their own coat of arms. They are found on unblurred licence plates and some official buildings.

metas.title: Slavic Place Names (-ow/-itz)
metas.description: These are some of the more useful and common suffixes for regionguessing Germany. Due to their Slavic origins, endings like -ow and -itz are primarily found in the east, whereas place names ending in -weiler and -ach are mainly located in the southern half.

metas.title: Guardrail Distribution (A/B)
metas.description: While most of Germany uses B-Type guardrails, A-type guardrails are common in the northwest, as well as in Rhineland-Palatinate and parts of Bavaria.
metas.note: There will always be rare exceptions. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: Bicycle Sign Colors
metas.description: Bicycle direction signs typically feature a white background with green lettering. In Hamburg, North Rhine-Westphalia and a neighbouring part of Lower Saxony, you will instead find red lettering. The Saarland has its own distinctive design, with white text on a dark green background.

metas.title: Folded Sign Backs
metas.description:
You can use the backs of street signs to regionguess Germany.

Here are examples of a folded, and flat sign back.

metas.title: Sign Back Connectors
metas.description: You can also use the sign back connectors on street signs to regionguess Germany.
metas.note: The double connector on triangular signs are generally wider. T-shaped connectors may look like this.

metas.title: German Alps
metas.description: The German Alps is the most mountainous region in Germany, it is mostly concentrated on the Austrian Border.

metas.title: Northeast Pine Forests
metas.description: Baltic Pines or Pinus sylvestris are generally more concentrated in the northeast of Germany. They can be recognized by their orange-tinged trunk.
metas.note: This map is very approximate.

metas.title: White Bottom Trees
metas.description: You can spot trees that are painted white close to the bottom of the trunk in the northeast.
metas.note: You will rarely find them outside the shaded region.

metas.title: Regensburg Ridges
metas.description: The flat plains southeast of Regensburg can be recognised by the slight ridge often visible to the northeast. The plains themselves are flat, and quite agricultural.

metas.title: Vineyard Regions
metas.description: Vineyards are mostly concentrated in the southwest of Germany. However, there are a couple regions further east as well.

metas.title: Hop Fields (Munich)
metas.description: You can find hop fields in these regions. They are commonly seen just north of Munich.

metas.title: Northwest Brick Houses
metas.description: These brick houses are generally concentrated in northwestern Germany.
metas.note: This map is very approximate.

metas.title: Thatched Roofs & Rock Walls
metas.description: Thatched roofs and rock walls are most common on the North Frisian Islands, as well as mainland Schleswig-Holstein. You can also commonly find them in coastal resort towns in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern.

metas.title: Black Slate Walls
metas.description: Houses with black slate walls, resembling fish scales, are commonly found in a large area of central Germany.

metas.title: Plattenbau (Commie Blocks)
metas.description: These large, utilitarian apartment buildings constructed during the socialist era, that are also known as “Commie blocks” are common in all of former East Germany.

metas.title: Dark Reflector Bollards
metas.description: Bollards with darker reflectors than usual are found in these regions.

metas.title: Green Cap Bollards
metas.description: Some bollards in North Rhine-Westphalia have a green bit at the top. The top can also be another colour.

metas.title: LVR Green Caps
metas.description: Some of the green caps will have the text ‘LVR’, along with a small coat of arms. These specific green caps are unique to southern North Rhine-Westphalia.

metas.title: Bavarian Wooden Bollards
metas.description: These round wooden bollards, which have a painted top, are found in Bavaria.

metas.title: Lower Saxony K-Road Bollards
metas.description: These irregular looking bollards, which do not have a white encasing on the bottom half, are found on K-roads in this region of Lower Saxony. K-Roads in this region will not have any other type of bollard.

metas.title: Orange Snow Poles
metas.description: These simple orange posts are most commonly found in Bavaria, and also in the other highlighted states.

metas.title: Tree Markers (Green)
metas.description: Many trees in Brandenburg and Mecklenburg-Vorpommern have these tiny green markers on them. You can very rarely find them in Lower Saxony.

metas.title: Bavarian Road Markers
metas.description: Bavaria uses these white rectangular road markers, which are divided by black lines into three sections. The left section provides the road you are currently on.

metas.title: Lower Saxony Markers
metas.description: You can find these simple rectangular markers, with rounded edges in Lower Saxony.

metas.title: Metallic Border Markers
metas.description: These markers with a metallic border around the marker itself are found in Schleswig-Holstein and Lower Saxony.
metas.note: The numbers after the comma are usually smaller on the markers in Lower Saxony.

metas.title: Triangular Post Variants
metas.description:
These triangular posts are commonly found in these regions.

You can go more in-depth with them, too.

Rhineland-Palatinate and Saxony use unpainted, rocky-looking posts, with white plates stuck on each side.

Saarland, Thuringia, and Baden-Württemberg use white posts, with the same white plates attached. The posts are usually quite tall, except in Baden-Württemberg, where shorter ones are used.

Baden-Württemberg also uses grey posts.

North Rhine-Westphalia uses white posts without white plates on the sides. You can also find posts which go all the way to the ground.

Hesse barely uses these posts at all. However, when they do, it is quite unpredictable.

metas.title: White Bollard Plates
metas.description: These basic white plates on bollards can be found in these states.

metas.title: Black Disk Bollards
metas.description: Bollards standing on these black disks are commonly found in all of eastern Germany.

metas.title: Orange Bollard Plates
metas.description: Rhineland-Palatinate is the only state where the plates on the bollards are orange instead of white.

metas.title: Grey Bollard Plates (Baden)
metas.description: Similarly, Baden-Württemberg is the only state where the plates on the bollards can be grey instead of white.

metas.title: Red Cap Posts
metas.description: These white posts with a red cap are found in all of former East Germany, but most commonly in the state of Saxony-Anhalt.

metas.title: Yellow Posts (Brandenburg)
metas.description: Fully yellow posts are found in the state of Brandenburg.

metas.title: Yellow Posts with Plates
metas.description: Yellow posts with a white plate on them are found in Saxony-Anhalt.
metas.note: Sometimes there is only 1 plate, which can make it hard to tell apart from a Brandenburg post.

metas.title: East German Concrete Poles
metas.description: These round concrete poles are almost unique to Former Eastern Germany.

metas.title: Trident Pole Tops
metas.description: These trident-like pole tops can be found in Bavaria, Saxony-Anhalt, and Baden-Württemberg.

metas.title: Triangle Pole Tops (West)
metas.description: Triangle pole tops similar to the ones in Czechia and Slovakia are common in Western Germany.
metas.note: There may be some exceptions outside the highlighted areas.

metas.title: Thick Middle Bar Poles
metas.description: These pole tops where the middle of the horizontal bar is thicker can be found in all of former East Germany.

metas.title: Curved Bar Poles (Bavaria)
metas.description: Pole tops which have a curved horizontal bar can be found in Bavaria, though they are rare.

metas.title: White & Black Gen 4 Car
metas.description: You can find this rare white and black Generation 4 car in Hamburg and around Frankfurt.
metas.note: You can also find the same car around London and in Ireland.

metas.title: Aldi Equator
metas.description: There are two regional Aldi chains, which have split Germany in two; Aldi Süd in the south, and Aldi Nord in the north.

metas.title: City Street Signs
metas.description:
Berlin uses white signs with a grey border, and a separate section for numbers under the street name. Also note how the letter ß looks.

Munich has blue street signs with a white decorative border that does not touch the corners. Also note the unique font.

Stuttgart uses black signs without a border.

Düsseldorf has black signs with a white border, similar to Munich. The signs have a metallic frame.

Dortmund uses blue signs with a white border and a grey frame. The signs also have a separate section for numbers under the street name.

Essen has blue signs with a very thick metallic frame.

Dresden has blue signs with a unique font.

Hanover uses white signs with a wider than usual gap between the sign and metallic frame.

Nuremberg has blue signs with a unique font. The signs also have a grey frame with a small gap between it and the sign.

Wuppertal uses white signs with a unique font and a white painted frame with a small gap between it and the sign.

Mainz has a mix of blue signs, and this unique red variant.

Frankfurt uses blue street signs with a metallic border around the sign, as well as the separate section for numbers under the street name.
metas.note: More rarely, some smaller towns can use similar signs to those in this graphic.

metas.title: Sorbian Language Signs
metas.description: Sorbian, a Slavic language, is spoken near the Polish and Czech border. You can find it on a variety of signs in these regions.

metas.title: City State Bus Stops
metas.description:
Every city state uses a unique and recognisable bus stop.

Berlin uses segmented bus stops, with a yellow signpost.

Hamburg bus stops have a red signpost, and the route numbers are within hexagons. Note that they can be found outside of Hamburg as well

Bremen proper uses simple bus stops, which have the bus stop name within a red section. The edges can be rounded.

Bremerhaven, which is still part of Bremen, uses bus stops with a grey section on the opposite side of the signpost. And the bus stop name is red within a yellow section.

metas.title: City State Bins
metas.description:
Every city state has recognisable rubbish bins all around the city.

Berlin uses bright orange bins that have white text on them.

Hamburg uses bright red bins, with white speech bubbles.

Bremen has green and grey bins, with orange speech bubbles.

Bremerhaven uses a more generic green design, with a black logo.

metas.title: Cologne Lamp Stickers
metas.description: Lampposts in Cologne will often feature these bright yellow numbers on a black piece of plastic.
metas.note: Similar looking things can be found elsewhere as well.

metas.title: Arched Half-Timbered Houses
metas.description: This type of half-timbered house with arches at the ground floor is very common in this region of Saxony.

metas.title: Sylt Landscape
metas.description: The shrub and sand covered hills are unique to the island of Sylt. And like the rest of the North Frisian Islands, rock walls, brick houses, and thatched roofs are common.
metas.note: Some parts of Sylt look more generic, but still very flat.

metas.title: Singen Lowcam
metas.description: Lowcam coverage can be found around Singen and near Switzerland.

metas.title: Safari Park Gen 3
metas.description:
You can find a Generation 3 black car in this safari park southeast of Bielefeld.

You can commonly see 4x4s painted with a zebra pattern in the park.
metas.note: This car is unique to this park within all of Europe.

metas.title: Hamburg Gen 3 Antenna
metas.description: This rare Generation 3 car coverage with an antenna can be found in central Hamburg.

metas.title: Overview
metas.description: Gibraltar is a British Overseas Territory located at the southern tip of the Iberian Peninsula, bordering Spain. For country streak purposes, the territory is counted as the United Kingdom.

metas.title: Gibraltar Antenna
metas.description: All coverage in Gibraltar is Generation 3. The car will always have a unique long antenna with a silver tip, often referred to simply as the “Gibraltar antenna” by the community.
metas.note: This antenna can also be found in parts of Spain, but nowhere else in Europe. In addition, the parts of Spain where this antenna can be found do not border Gibraltar.

metas.title: Rock of Gibraltar
metas.description: The territory’s most recognizable feature is the Rock of Gibraltar, a massive limestone mountain that dominates every part of the territory. It can be recognized by its exposed white limestone rocks and distinct shape.

metas.title: Yellow Rear Plates
metas.description:
Like the UK, Gibraltar uses yellow back plates on vehicles.

However, note that unlike the UK, Gibraltar drives on the right.

metas.title: Driving Side (Right)
metas.description: Unlike the UK, Gibraltar drives on the right.

metas.title: English Language
metas.description: The main language used in Gibraltar is English. This can be especially helpful if you see English on official signs in a Mediterranean setting.
metas.note: Note that English is also one of the main languages of Malta, which also has a Mediterranean landscape and vibe.

metas.title: Architecture & Shutters
metas.description: The urban parts of Gibraltar are mostly fairly dense. Buildings look similar to those found in other Mediterranean countries. They have pastel colours and louvered window shutters (horizontal slats of wood set into a frame). These window shutters are usually painted green, blue or brown.

metas.title: Christmas Decorations
metas.description: All coverage is from December, so in many parts of town you will see Christmas decorations.

metas.title: Barbary Macaques
metas.description: Gibraltar is famous for its monkeys, of the species Barbary macaque. It is the only place in Europe where you can find wild monkeys.

metas.title: Ibrahim-al-Ibrahim Mosque
metas.description: Near the southern tip of the territory, you will be able to see the minarets of the Ibrahim-al-Ibrahim Mosque, the southernmost mosque in continental Europe.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Greek licence plates are either all white or have the standard European design, with a blue strip on the left side. Taxis have yellow licence plates.

metas.title: Greek Alphabet
metas.description: The Greek language features a unique alphabet not used in any other language. It shares similarities with both the Latin and Cyrillic alphabet, however the lower case letters generally have softer shapes than the Cyrillic letters.
metas.note: Cyprus also uses the Greek Alphabet.

metas.title: Dark Wooden Poles
metas.description: Greek utility poles are primarily wooden, and often have a distinctly dark brown colour. They will often be noticeably taller than in other countries.

metas.title: Harp Pole Tops
metas.description: These distinctive poletops, which have a metal frame shaped vaguely like a harp.
metas.note: They are unique to Greece and Cyprus.

metas.title: 5-Insulator Poles
metas.description: Many poles in Greece will have five vertical insulators. They can either be attached to the pole or the metal frames from the previous tip.

metas.title: Pole-Mounted Lamps
metas.description: This type of small lamp, attached to the side of poles with a round shade above the light bulb.
metas.note: You can also find them in North Macedonia and Serbia.

metas.title: Double White Middle Lines
metas.description: In Greece you will commonly see slightly faded, solid white double middle lines. This can be used to distinguish it from most other Mediterranean countries.

metas.title: Yellow Edge Lines
metas.description: Yellow road lines are more common in Greece than any other southern European country.

metas.title: Wedge-Shaped Bollards
metas.description: Greek bollards are wedge-shaped with almost square reflectors, being red on the front and white on the back.

metas.title: Black & White Chevrons
metas.description: Greek chevrons have white arrows on a black background.
metas.note: Similar chevrons are found in Albania, Italy and the UK. Spain has the same colours, but will almost always have either two or four arrows.

metas.title: Yellow Warning Signs
metas.description: Greek warning signs have a red border and a yellow background.

metas.title: Blue Directional Signs
metas.description: Greek directional signs are typically blue and arrow shaped. One of the most recognisable features are the place names, which are written in Greek with a yellow font, and in English with a white font.

metas.title: Town Entry Signs
metas.description: Greek town entry signs are white with thick horizontal blue stripes at the top and bottom.

metas.title: Blue KM Markers
metas.description: Greek kilometre markers are blue, having “km” written on the left with both the latin and greek alphabet.

metas.title: Dotted Line Pedestrian Sign
metas.description: Pedestrian signs have two dotted horizontal lines, rather than vertical stripes.

metas.title: Roadside Mini-Churches
metas.description: These types of miniature churches, put on small pedestals, are often found along Greek roads and are unique to Greece.

metas.title: White Stone Architecture
metas.description:
Greek architecture shares a lot of features with other Mediterranean countries: a lot of white and pastel-coloured stone houses with orange tiled roofs. White houses are very common when compared to most other Mediterranean countries.

Urban residential buildings will generally be multi-floored, light-coloured and typically have connected balconies along one or multiple walls.

Perhaps the most recognisable style of Greek architecture are the white houses with blue fences, window frames and doors. Beware that these are mainly found on islands.

metas.title: Mountain Roads
metas.description: Greece is a very mountainous country, with a large portion of the coverage being taken on winding mountain roads.

metas.title: Red Soil
metas.description: Red dirt is very common in Greece.
metas.note: Albania also has a lot of red dirt.

metas.title: Smallcam Coverage
metas.description: Greece has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.

metas.title: Winter Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: Greece has a lot of Generation 3 winter and fall coverage, which tends to look somewhat bleak and depressing.

metas.title: Island Coverage Map
metas.description:
Greece is a country with many small islands, some with coverage and some without. Furthermore, while mainland Greece and Crete have all three camera generations, this will not be true for most islands.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description: Greek area codes will always begin with a 2, followed by 1-3 digits determining the area.
metas.note: If the third digit is 1, you will be in the largest city of the region, and if the third digit is 9, you will be in the area surrounding that city.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The largest flat agricultural valleys in Greece are found close to Thessaloniki and Larissa, but smaller flat valleys, where the mountains generally appear closer, can be found in several other areas in the north and centre of the country.

metas.title: Western Mountains
metas.description: The tallest Greek mountains are found in the western half of the country, and contain most of the country’s high-altitude mountain roads with coverage.

metas.title: Cycladic Architecture
metas.description: One of the most well-known types of Greek architecture; houses with completely white walls, blue doors and shutters, is mainly found on the small central Cyclade islands.

metas.title: Barren Central Islands
metas.description: On many of the central islands you can find a very barren landscape, with small bushes and no trees in sight. This tends to be more common on the smaller islands with coverage.

metas.title: Olive Plantations
metas.description: Olive plantations are found in coastal areas, particularly on Crete and southern Peloponnese.

metas.title: Citrus Plantations
metas.description: Citrus plantations are mainly found in coastal areas, particularly on southern Peloponnese.

metas.title: Crete Antenna
metas.description: On Crete, you may find this unique car antenna, with a slight bulge at the tip.

metas.title: Mount Pangaion
metas.description: Mount Pangaion can be recognised from its shape, being more of a solitary mountain rather than a wide mountain range, combined with the fact that it is located to the south of a flat agricultural valley.

metas.title: Meteora Monoliths
metas.description: These extraordinary monolithic mountains are called Meteora, and can be found north of Trikala.

metas.title: Athens Taxis (Yellow)
metas.description: Yellow taxis are found in Athens.

metas.title: Thessaloniki Taxis (Blue/White)
metas.description: Blue taxis with a white roof are found in Thessaloniki.

metas.title: Thessaloniki Antennas
metas.description: In Thessaloniki, you will often see a large amount of unusually tall antennas on top of buildings.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description:
Hungary uses long white standard European licence plates. Taxi licence plates are yellow.

In July of 2022, Hungary switched to this new character format, which contains the coat of arms.
metas.note: Newer electric vehicles have green plates.

metas.title: Bollards & Reflectors
metas.description: Hungarian bollards are black-and-white, wedge-shaped, and typically have a red reflector at the front, and a white reflector at the back. Blue reflectors are also somewhat common.
metas.note: Croatian bollards are very similar. They do, however, typically have the reflector closer to the top, and appear somewhat thinner than in Hungary.

metas.title: Holey Concrete Poles
metas.description: The most common type of utility pole in Hungary is a concrete holey pole, with relatively thin holes going all the way down to the ground. Wooden poles are also somewhat common.
metas.note: In eastern Europe, Poland and Romania also commonly use holey poles. Polish holey poles typically do not have holes down by the ground, and tend to be relatively thin. Romanian holey poles normally either have much wider, or much taller holes.

metas.title: Chevron Color Scheme
metas.description:
Hungarian chevrons are white on red.

Black-and-white chevrons may also be seen, but are considerably less common.

metas.title: Language Characteristics
metas.description: The Hungarian language has a unique look, with a very large number of acute accents, umlauts over o’s, and long words. The letters "Ő" and "Ű", with double acute accents, are unique to the language.
metas.note: Hungarian is also spoken in some parts of neighbouring countries: notably there are large Hungarian-speaking communities in central Romania and southern Slovakia.

metas.title: Street Naming ('Utca/t')
metas.description: Hungarian street names typically end with the word “utca”. The word “út” is also used for bigger roads. These two words are unique to Hungarian, and translate to “street.”

metas.title: Green KM Markers
metas.description:
These green kilometre markers can be seen along most Hungarian roads.

On highways, the numbers correspond to the ones seen on the map in small yellow boxes near exits.

metas.title: Tall Sign Posts
metas.description: Hungarian sign posts commonly appear to be abnormally tall, often taller than the Street View camera.

metas.title: Sign Bolt Pattern
metas.description: Hungarian signs are usually bolted to the sign post using four bolts, going through the sign, in the shape of a tall rectangle.
metas.note: This is not common in any other Eastern European countries.

metas.title: 5-Stripe Pedestrian Sign
metas.description:
Hungarian pedestrian crossing signs have five stripes. The person is wearing a belt. There is also a second, less common, type with four stripes and the person holding a bag.

The belt is located noticeably low on the person’s body, almost as if the person is sagging his pants. This is unique to Hungary.
metas.note: Among neighbouring countries, Croatia and Slovakia also have five stripes and a belt.

metas.title: Road Number Shields
metas.description: Apart from European highways, there are two types of numbered roads in Hungary; roads marked with green signs, and highways beginning with the letter ‘M’, marked with blue signs. These road numbers are contained within a small shield shape on the sign.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Most directional signs are green, having a white inner border and a green outer border. Directional signs on M-numbered highways are blue, having a white inner border and a blue outer border.

metas.title: Gen 3 Antenna Flag
metas.description: It is somewhat common to see a small, grey flag on the antenna of Generation 3 Google cars in Hungary.
metas.note: This is also seen in the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Romania and Bulgaria.

metas.title: White Gen 4 Car
metas.description: A white generation 4 Google car can also rarely be found in Hungary.
metas.note: It can also be found in other European countries.

metas.title: Black Gen 4 Car
metas.description: A black generation 4 car that will never have an antenna can be found in Hungary.
metas.note: A black car can be found in many European countries, though it will often have an antenna visible.

metas.title: Winter Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: The majority of Generation 3 coverage in Hungary was taken during winter, resulting in very grey, dead looking coverage.
metas.note: This is also common in the Czech Republic and Bulgaria.

metas.title: Architecture
metas.description: Hungarian houses are typically made of stone, painted in a light colour and almost always with red tiled roofs. Suburban houses are typically only one storeyed, while more central houses may be taller. Houses in town and city centres are often fairly old but well-kept.

metas.title: Bike Lane Lines
metas.description: While Hungarian road lines are all-white, lines on bicycle lanes are typically yellow.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description: Hungarian phone numbers consist of either 8 or 10 digits. If the number has 8 digits, the first and second digit is the area code. And if the number has 10 digits, the third and fourth digit is the area code. The only exception is Budapest, where only the first or third digit, being a 1, respectively is the area code.
metas.note: Area codes whose second digit is 0 or 1 are not region specific.

metas.title: Road Numbering System
metas.description: The first digit of Hungarian numbered roads are ordered in a circle, centred around Budapest. Remembering this system should make it quite easy to find any numbered road.

metas.title: Town Name Prefixes
metas.description:
Many Hungarian town names use local prefixes, the most common of which are shown in this infographic. Note that some rare exceptions exist.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Western Metal Frames
metas.description: If you see a street sign with a thick metal frame around it, you are very likely to be in the western parts of the country.

metas.title: Eastern Arrow Signs
metas.description: If you see a blue or green street sign shaped like an arrow, attached to a utility pole or street light, you are likely to be in the county of Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg.
metas.note: Blue arrow-shaped street signs can also be found in Dunakeszi, north of Budapest. However, those are attached to blue sign posts.

metas.title: Northern Mountains
metas.description: While the southeastern parts of Hungary are extremely flat, with almost no noticeable hills, the northern and western parts mainly consist of forested hills and mountains. The tallest mountains are found in the north, while the southwestern mountains are generally slightly lower.

metas.title: Lake Balaton
metas.description: Lake Balaton is one of the largest lakes on mainland Europe, and the only large lake visible on street view in Hungary. The area surrounding the lake is moderately hilly, fairly built up and a big tourist destination, with a much higher density of small hotels than almost anywhere else in the country.

metas.title: Hortobgy National Park
metas.description: Unlike most of the Hungarian plains, which is almost entirely cultivated land, the Puszta, centred around Hortobágy National Park, mainly consists of barren and wet, natural grasslands.

metas.title: City Street Signs
metas.description:
This infographic showcases ten of the largest towns and cities with unique street signs, and explains what makes them unique.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Slovak Border Road
metas.description: The road east of Tornanadaska, right by the border to Slovakia, can be easily recognized by the snow on and along the road, combined with the bollards and the railway right next to the road.

metas.title: Gen 4 Pickup Truck
metas.description: The Generation 4 coverage was captured with red and white pickup trucks, which have been well blurred.

metas.title: Gen 3 Antenna
metas.description: The Generation 3 Google car in Iceland is a white car with a long antenna.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description:
Icelandic licence plates are fully white with blue characters. Unlike most of Europe, the plates do not feature a blue strip on the left.

It can be hard to see the blue of the characters through the blur of the plates.

metas.title: Yellow Bollards
metas.description: Iceland has unique yellow bollards with a white reflector. These bollards are extremely common and can be found throughout the country on almost every section of rural road.

metas.title: Volcanic Soil
metas.description: Iceland often looks barren and treeless. Most regions have a dark grey soil consisting mostly of volcanic rocks.
metas.note: Due to the lack of trees, the landscape in Iceland does not look like anywhere else in Northern Europe.

metas.title: Geological Landscape
metas.description: Iceland is a very geologically active country, where plate tectonics and volcanic processes have shaped the landscape. As a result, many regions are rugged, mountainous and a sight to behold. In addition, strange and bewildering landscapes can be found all over, such as geothermal lakes, lava fields, rift valleys, and towering rock formations.

metas.title: Yellow Direction Signs
metas.description: The road direction signs of Iceland are yellow. They usually have a white inset box that shows the road numbers. If the inset box has a dashed border, the number listed refers to a nearby road, not the road you are currently on.
metas.note: Direction signs for very local destinations, such as farmsteads, typically have different background colours: blue or white.

metas.title: Yellow Pedestrian Signs
metas.description: Icelandic pedestrian signs feature four stripes and often have a slight yellow tint.
metas.note: Iceland is the only European country that uses pedestrian signs with a yellow background.

metas.title: Language Characters
metas.description: The Icelandic language contains a couple of unique letters. These are some of the most recognizable ones: ð þ and æ. Vowels can have the following accents: á é í ó ö ú ý. The uppercase version of ð is Ð.
metas.note: ð is also found in the Faroese language. æ is found in Danish, Norwegian and Faroese.

metas.title: Street Signs
metas.description: Iceland’s street signs use a white background and black text. They often have a thin metal rim and are attached to lampposts or traffic lights.

metas.title: White Road Lines
metas.description: Iceland has all-white road lines. Outside lines, if present, can be either solid or, more rarely, dashed lines.
metas.note: Iceland has no yellow road lines. If you see yellow road lines in a Nordic environment, consider Norway or Finland.

metas.title: Chevron Color Scheme
metas.description: Icelandic chevrons are black with yellow arrows.
metas.note: Norway and Finland have similarly coloured chevrons. Sweden, on the other hand, has unique blue and yellow chevrons.

metas.title: Yellow Sign Backgrounds
metas.description: Just like Sweden and Finland, Icelandic signs feature a yellow background.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
Iceland is rather sparsely covered. The southwest region has the densest coverage. Only a few interior roads are covered.

You can click on the image to enlarge it. Alternatively, you can look at the coverage in more detail on this site.

metas.title: Road Numbering System
metas.description:
Iceland has a very sensible road numbering system that allows for quick 5k’s, provided you find the yellow direction signs that list the road numbers of the intersection you are on.

The main ring road, which circles the entire island, simply has the number 1. There are no other roads that start with 1.

The first digit of the other road numbers is region-specific. These regions have a sequential distribution around the island, starting from 2 in the south and increasing up until 9 in a clockwise direction (see map for approximate distribution).

metas.title: Westfjords Landscape
metas.description: The Westfjords region features numerous narrow fjords, surrounded by moderately tall, and mostly flat-topped mountains.

metas.title: Eastfjords Landscape
metas.description: The far east of the country is also home to several fjords. What distinguishes them from the Westfjords are the generally larger and more jagged mountains.

metas.title: North Valleys
metas.description: The mountains west of Akureyri contain many valleys, sandwiched between tall, often slightly snowcapped peaks. Most of these valleys generally face north to northeast.

metas.title: Interior Barrenness
metas.description: Barren landscapes consisting mostly of dark volcanic gravel, with little to no vegetation or signs of life, are typical of the inland regions of Iceland. Most such covered roads are located in the east.

metas.title: Southwest Agriculture
metas.description: The Southwest agricultural area in Iceland can be identified by its relatively flat farmland landscape scattered with numerous farmsteads, fields, meadows and grasslands.
metas.note: Although there are other smaller agricultural areas in Iceland, mountains in this area tend to be quite distant, making it unique.

metas.title: Hilly Terrain
metas.description: The wide valley around Eiðar is slightly hilly and agricultural, with tall, snowy peaks visible in the distance on either side, to the east and northwest, respectively.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The valley around Hallormsstaður has a distinct northeast/southwest angle with low-lying mountains on either side, a wide river flowing through it, and an unusual amount of trees for Iceland. Some of the sideroads are in the forests.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: You can recognise the area near the town of Selfoss from its distinct flat-ridge mountain. Due to the otherwise flat landscape, this mountain can be seen from a wide area.

metas.title: Capital City Features
metas.description: Reykjavík is the capital and by far the largest city in Iceland. The city is mostly flat with slight hills, and is located on the south side of a bay. It is most recognizable as it is significantly larger than other Icelandic cities, with a large urban area and “bigger city” feel.
metas.note: The city of Akureyri can feel urban in some places. You can distinguish it from Reykjavik as it has mountains to the east and west.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Akureyri is the second-biggest city in Iceland and is located in a North-South oriented valley, along the western edge of the bay. The city features mountains ranges to the east and west, making it recognisable.

metas.title: White Pickup Meta
metas.description: Iceland can be split in half depending on the colour of the pickup truck, with red being found in the southwest, and white being found in the northeast.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: The southern coast of Iceland features some impressive glaciers visible from the ring road, spilling into the sea from the Vatnajökull ice cap.

metas.title: There Only Handful
metas.description: There are only a handful of highways in Iceland which are either divided or have more than two lanes. The divided highways are shown in dark red, while the highways with three or more lanes are shown in bright red.
metas.note:
There are two exceptions to this:

Divided roads can be found inside cities other than Reykjavík.

Roads may temporarily be divided close to intersections.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: The Island of Heimaey can easily be recognised by seeing these ragged rocky cliffs overlooking the town of Vestmannaeyjabær. Similar cliffs can be seen on the islands off the coast.

metas.title: Very Foggy Coverage
metas.description: Very foggy coverage can be found around the town of Bakkagerði, in northeastern Iceland. The fog can also be seen from a distance.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description:
Ireland has long, white licence plates with the standard European blue strip on the left.

The white backplate is especially useful to distinguish it from the UK, which uses yellow backplates (but white fronts). In addition, most UK vehicles lack the blue strip on the left.

metas.title: Yellow Dashed Edge Lines
metas.description: It is very common to see yellow outside dashes on Irish roads.
metas.note: This is essentially never found in the UK. These dashes can also be seen in New Zealand.

metas.title: Architecture
metas.description: You will usually find cream white buildings with black roofs in Ireland. Sometimes, the buildings feature grey corner stones. In cities, you will typically find row buildings.
metas.note: British style brick buildings can still be found in Ireland.

metas.title: Yellow Diamond Warnings
metas.description:
Ireland is the only European country that uses yellow diamond-shaped warning signs.

Note that this only applies to warning signs. Regulatory signs (circles and upside down triangles) have the normal red border and white background, like most other European countries.

metas.title: Bilingual Signs
metas.description:
Irish signage is often bilingual, with English in a regular font, and Irish in italics. Place names, regular words and phrases are all translated.

Irish language is somewhat less common on non-official signage.

metas.title: Chevron Color Scheme
metas.description: Irish chevrons are yellow on black. Both single and multiple arrows are common.
metas.note: UK chevrons are white on black.

metas.title: Yellow Warning Stickers
metas.description:
The yellow warning stickers on utility poles can be a good way to distinguish between Ireland and the UK.

The most important difference is that UK stickers feature a guy getting zapped by a lightning bolt.

The Irish stickers usually have a lightning bolt, but lack the guy getting zapped. They also often have an extra second rectangular sticker with a black outline, below the lightning bolt.

metas.title: Yield Sign Text
metas.description: Irish yield signs feature the word “YIELD”.
metas.note: UK yield signs have the phrase “GIVE WAY”.

metas.title: Green & White Bollards
metas.description: These green and white bollards can be a good clue for Ireland. They are not entirely unique to the country, but they are especially helpful in 50-50s with the UK.

metas.title: Rounded Metal Gates
metas.description: Rural metal gates with rounded corners are very common in Ireland.
metas.note: This is mainly useful to distinguish it from the UK, where similar gates typically have square corners. However, gates in Northern Ireland also typically have rounded corners.

metas.title: Boreens (Grassy Roads)
metas.description: You will often see a strip of grass in the middle of tiny rural roads. Such roads are called “boreens”. While not unique, these boreens can often be a strong clue in a tough 50-50 between Ireland and the UK.

metas.title: Driving Side (Left)
metas.description: Ireland and the UK drive on the left side of the road.
metas.note: The only other European countries to drive on the left are Malta and Cyprus, but landscape should be sufficient to tell them apart.

metas.title: Hedgerow Landscape
metas.description:
Most of Ireland is dominated by a very green, agricultural landscape, with lots of hedgerows next to the roads and dividing the fields.

This type of landscape is also common in many parts of the UK, and can be virtually indistinguishable from Ireland.

metas.title: Pole Steps
metas.description: Both Ireland and the UK use wooden utility poles. Pole steps bolted on the side of the pole are very common. These pole steps are shaped like a series of thin horizontal metal rods.

metas.title: Double Yellow Lines
metas.description: In and around urban areas, you will sometimes encounter double yellow road lines on the sides of marked roads. These indicate a no parking zone, and are also very common in the UK. They are not really found anywhere else in Europe apart from Malta, but landscape should be sufficient to tell it apart.

metas.title: Pedestrian Posts (Belisha Beacons)
metas.description:
Pedestrian crossing signs are somewhat rare in Ireland. They are yellow and diamond-shaped, like other road signs.

Instead of pedestrian signs, you will often see these black and white signposts with a yellow bulb on top.

Note that the UK uses exactly the same signposts.

metas.title: Smallcam Coverage
metas.description: Ireland has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.

metas.title: Road Numbering (Regions)
metas.description:
Irish regional roads have 3-digit road numbers. The first digit of these road numbers gives you a general region within the country (see the infographic).

A good mnemonic to remember the rough location of each region: the numbers go in an anti-clockwise direction around the island, starting in Dublin.

Two important notes:

There is some overlap between numbers at the borders of each region, as well as some rare exceptions

Roads starting with 8 or 9 are newer roads that are mostly not limited to a certain region (though about half of the 8s are in the Dublin metro area).

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description: Irish phone numbers start with a two digit area code. The area codes are grouped geographically by first digit, and are therefore very learnable.

metas.title: West Coast Landscape
metas.description: Ireland’s west coast is defined by a rugged, hilly landscape. Steep hills and low mountains dominate. The neat fields of the east make way for wild grass- and moorlands. The grass often has more brownish and yellow tones to it. Sometimes you will be able to see exposed rocks.

metas.title: Donegal Gen 4 Roads
metas.description:
If a very small rural road has Generation 4 coverage and is located in an unusually hilly landscape, you are likely to be in Donegal.

Note that this meta only applies to the smallest roads: thin, without road lines, and sometimes with grass in the middle. This type of coverage is also not exclusive to Donegal, it is just likely to be there.

metas.title: Wicklow Mountains
metas.description:
One noteworthy area in the east is the Wicklow Mountains, just south of Dublin. They can look deceptively similar to the western coastal mountains. It can be very hard, if not downright impossible to distinguish these two areas.

Two things to look out for:

You will never see the coast from the Wicklow mountains.

Like Donegal, its small roads are mostly covered with Generation 4 instead of the Generation 2 that is more typically associated with small roads in the west.

metas.title: EV Coverage (Eastern)
metas.description:
An electrical vehicle (EV) with a Generation 4 camera was used to cover most of Eastern Ireland and parts of the Northwest. The back of the EV is visible in all this coverage: it is grey with a black semicircle.

Note that not all Generation 4 coverage in and around Dublin is made with this car. A considerable amount still has the regular blue Generation 4 car.

metas.title: Tabletop Mountains
metas.description:
In the north of counties Sligo and Leitrim you can find distinctive tabletop mountains.

Note that the mountains in the image are just an example, many of the mountains in this area have the same sort of shape.

metas.title: Burren Karst Landscape
metas.description: The area in and around Burren National Park is characterised by a unique karst landscape consisting of exposed grey limestone rocks.

metas.title: Cork Hills
metas.description: Cork is relatively unique in that it is significantly more hilly than the other big Irish cities.

metas.title: Overview
metas.description: Isle of Man is a British Crown dependency, situated between the United Kingdom and Ireland. So for country streaks purposes, it is counted as the United Kingdom.

metas.title: Low Quality Gen 2
metas.description:
Coverage on the Isle of Man is limited to Generation 2.

This camera can be recognized by the lower camera quality and circular blur above and below. Colours will also seem slightly off.

metas.title: Red Strip Plates
metas.description: Similar to the United Kingdom, the Isle of Man uses white front licence plates with yellow rears, but with a red strip on the left.

metas.title: Farmland Landscape
metas.description: The general landscape on the Isle of Man consists of hilly farmland, and narrow roads passing through them.

metas.title: Whitewashed Houses
metas.description: Houses with whitewashed walls and entrance walls are a common sight, similar to Ireland.

metas.title: Striped Kerbs
metas.description: Striped kerbs can sometimes be seen along main roads.

metas.title: Urban Blue Bollards
metas.description: These blue bollards can commonly be found in urban areas.

metas.title: Gorse Plants
metas.description: Gorse plants (or Ulex), which can be recognized by their bright yellow flowers, are very common on the Isle of Man.
metas.note: Gorse plants can also be found in other rugged areas of the UK and Ireland, such as the Scottish Highlands.

metas.title: Hilly Landscape
metas.description: Isle of Man is generally quite hilly, with a few exceptions.

metas.title: Northern Flats vs Southern Mountains
metas.description: Northern Isle of Man is very flat in comparison to the rest of the island. Usually, there are mountains visible to the south.

metas.title: Roof Smudge (South)
metas.description: A ‘twig smudge’ can be seen on the left side of the camera lens in southern Isle of Man.

metas.title: Douglas Terraced Houses
metas.description: Douglas, the capital and largest town on the Isle of Man, can be recognized by the rows of terraced houses, with a higher population density.

metas.title: Laxey Valley
metas.description: Laxey is a town located in a northwest-southeast valley.

metas.title: Blue Base Lamps
metas.description: This generic lamp design with a blue base and a small blue sticker can be found on most of the island, except for around Douglas, and some parts northeast and south. In addition, the top 2 letters can be used to narrow your location down to 1 of the 21 parishes.

metas.title: Green Lamps (Ramsey)
metas.description: All green lamps are commonly found in Ramsey and Castletown, as well as more rarely in the Malew, Santon, and Garff parishes.

metas.title: White Sticker Lamps (Douglas)
metas.description: A small white sticker with 2 green numbers will be present on lamps in Douglas.

metas.title: Yellow Sticker Lamps (Onchan)
metas.description: A small yellow sticker is present on lamps in southern Onchan. The 2 letters are the initials of the road name. E.g. ‘SD’ for Sunningdale Drive.

metas.title: Ramsey Signs (Coat of Arms)
metas.description: Many street signs in Ramsey feature the oval shaped coat of arms.

metas.title: Port Erin Signs
metas.description: The coat of arms is placed above the text on many signs in Port Erin.

metas.title: Ronaldsway Airport
metas.description: The Ronaldsway Airport can be recognized by the large, flat and open field with a boundary fence.

metas.title: Peel Castle
metas.description: The Peel castle, sitting atop an island, can unsurprisingly, be seen in Peel.

metas.title: Short Front Plates
metas.description: Contrary to most European licence plates, Italian plates have blue strips on either side of the plate. Furthermore, the front plate is distinctly shorter than most European plates, which in combination with the two strips, makes it unique.
metas.note: Albanian licence plates also have two blue strips, and French licence plates have a smaller strip on the right. However, neither Albanian nor French front plates are short.

metas.title: Black Top Bollards
metas.description: Italian bollards are triangular in shape, and white with a black top. They have a red front and a white rear reflector.
metas.note: Albania uses the same bollards.

metas.title: Solid White Outer Lines
metas.description: One of the most common types of Italian road lines are white solid outer lines with no middle line. This is generally less common in other Mediterranean countries.

metas.title: Italian Language
metas.description: Italian is the most spoken language in Italy. It uses many double consonants, and typically has a very large number of i’s. You can also find ì, é and à. Most words will end with a vowel.
metas.note: The Italian word for street is ‘via’, and can be found on most street signs.

metas.title: General Landscape
metas.description: Italy has a Mediterranean landscape with a lot of agricultural fields on rolling hills, and forested mountain valleys.

metas.title: Pastel Architecture
metas.description: Italian architecture mainly consists of pastel coloured stone houses, generally with terracotta roofs. Houses will very commonly have wooden shutters, which will typically be divided in two and open sideways.

metas.title: Round Concrete Poles
metas.description: Unlike most Mediterranean countries, Italy features a lot of round concrete poles.

metas.title: White Sticker Wooden Poles
metas.description: Wooden poles in Italy will commonly feature a small white pole sticker.

metas.title: Trident Pole Tops
metas.description:
The most common pole tops in Italy are concrete trident pole tops.

There are several possible configurations of insulators.The two shown in the image are the most common ones.

metas.title: Double Guardrails
metas.description: It is very common to find double guardrails in Italy.

metas.title: Red Reflector Guardrails
metas.description: Italian guardrails feature red front reflectors.
metas.note: This is most useful to distinguish Italy from Spain, which uses yellow reflectors. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: Flared Guardrail Ends
metas.description: Italian guardrails commonly end in this distinct shape. The guardrail gets flatter, wider, and it bends away from the road.

metas.title: Black Sign Backs
metas.description: It is very common for the back of Italian road signs to be black, or dark grey.

metas.title: Blue Directional Signs (Local)
metas.description: Directional signs are blue with a white arrow. All letters on these signs will be capitalised.

metas.title: Blue vs Green Highway Signs
metas.description:
Directional signs in national roads (Strada Statale) are blue with a white and blue border.

Divided highways (Autostrade) have green signs with a white and green border.

metas.title: Kilometer Markers
metas.description: Italian kilometre markers are white squares with a roman numeral on top and an arabic numeral on the bottom. The arabic numeral gives you the number of kilometres and the roman numeral gives you the number of hundred metres from the start of the road.

metas.title: Road Number Prefixes (SS/SR/SP)
metas.description:
Italian road numbers will normally begin with the letters “SS”, “SR” or “SP”.

The second letter can be used to identify the type of road.

"S" when it is a State road, so the number is unique within the country.

"R" when it is a Regional road, so the number is unique to the region.

"P" when it is a Provincial road, so the number is unique to the province.

metas.title: Chevron Color Scheme
metas.description: Italian chevrons are white arrows on a black background.
metas.note: In Southern Europe, white on black chevrons can also be found in Spain, Greece and Albania.

metas.title: White Street Signs
metas.description: Street signs are typically white with a thin blue border and black text.

metas.title: 5-Stripe Pedestrian Sign
metas.description: Italian pedestrian signs have five stripes and a basic person without a belt.

metas.title: Passo Carrabile Signs
metas.description: These signs, featuring a “no parking”-sign with the text “passo carrabile” are commonly found in urban areas. At the top of these signs you will typically find the municipality (comune) name.

metas.title: Smallcam Coverage
metas.description: Italy has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description: Italian area codes follow a pattern where the first digit generally increases to the east, then south.

metas.title: Regional Flags
metas.description: Each Italian region has its own unique flag.

metas.title: South Tyrol German Signs
metas.description: The region of South Tyrol has a German majority, and as such uses German bilingual signs.

metas.title: Aosta Valley French Signs
metas.description: French can be seen on signs in the Aosta Valley. Most notably, street signs often use both the Italian word “via” and the French word “rue”.

metas.title: Po Valley Haze
metas.description: The Padan Plain (commonly referred to as Po Valley) can typically be recognized by its complete flatness. The plain has some of the worst air quality in Europe, which has led to much of the coverage having a noticeable haze.

metas.title: Bari Olive Plantations
metas.description:
The landscape on the southeastern peninsula surrounding Bari has many olive plantations, which are often seen together with bright rock walls. The dirt in the region typically has a noticeably red colour.

Beware that a similar landscape can also be found in southeastern Sicily.

metas.title: Alpine Mountains
metas.description: The alpine region in northern Italy has tall, wide mountain ranges and deep valleys.

metas.title: Sicilian Landscape
metas.description: The Sicilian landscape is characterised by an arid, hilly agricultural landscape, often combined with rocky mountains.

metas.title: Sardinian Granite Rocks
metas.description: Grey rocks sticking up from the ground are commonly found on Sardinia, particularly in the northeast.
metas.note: A similar phenomenon can be seen on Sicily, however the landscape will typically be much drier than Sardinia.

metas.title: Cacti Distribution
metas.description: Cacti in Italy are most common in the south, particularly in Sicily, southern Sardinia and the south of Apulia.

metas.title: Citrus Plantations
metas.description: Citrus plantations are primarily found on eastern Sicily and the southern tip of Calabria.

metas.title: Rice Fields
metas.description: Rice is mainly produced in the western and central parts of Po valley, and less commonly in Sardinia.

metas.title: Tuscan Brick Architecture
metas.description: A lot of buildings in and around Tuscany are made of irregular unpainted brown-grey bricks.
metas.note: A similar style of architecture can be found in northeastern Spain.

metas.title: Alpine Architecture
metas.description: Alpine architecture, which typically features large buildings with white stone walls and wooden details, are found in the Alpine region.

metas.title: Aosta Valley Architecture
metas.description: Buildings in Aosta Valley are often built with grey uneven bricks, with an Alpine look.
metas.note: This can look superficially similar to Andorran architecture.

metas.title: Veneto Shutters
metas.description: Solid wooden shutters with black metal hinges is a common feature in the northeast of Italy, particularly in Veneto.

metas.title: Apulian Flat Roofs
metas.description: Houses in the Apulian region are generally very light coloured, and have flat roofs, typically with two to three floors. The architecture is sometimes reminiscent of the Middle East.

metas.title: Trulli Houses (Alberobello)
metas.description: This particular style of roof, called a trullo, is unique to the Itria valley in southeastern Italy. It is particularly common in and around the town of Alberobello.

metas.title: Slovene Bilingual Signs
metas.description: Close to the Slovenian border you can find Slovene bilingual signs.

metas.title: Campione d'Italia Exclave
metas.description: The Campione d'Italia exclave in Switzerland can be recognized by its low camera, having a long antenna and a flag. There is also a body of water to the west.
metas.note: This antenna can also be found in several areas in Switzerland.

metas.title: Mount Etna
metas.description: Etna, the tallest volcano in Europe, can be seen rising above the landscape from far away in eastern Sicily.

metas.title: Mount Vesuvius
metas.description: The volcano of Vesuvius can often be seen to the south or east from the plains around Naples.

metas.title: Venice Canals
metas.description: Venice can typically be recognized by its many canals running through most of the city.

metas.title: Fucino Plain
metas.description: Plana del Fùcino is a small plain surrounded by mountains in the middle of Italy with a grid of roads going completely north-to-south.

metas.title: Pantelleria Volcanic Rock
metas.description: The island of Pantelleria is a volcanic island southwest of Sicily. Dark volcanic rocks can be seen in the many rock walls of the island, as well as on some houses. It is fairly common to see yellow lichen covering the rocks. The island also has a very large amount of cacti.

metas.title: Aeolian Islands Landscape
metas.description:
The Aeolian islands are a volcanic archipelago north of Sicily. Here you will find a mix of volcanic soil and rocks with mediterranean vegetation, like stone pines or olive trees. Like in Sicily, cacti are fairly common.

In the mountains of the islands it is very common to see touristic white villas.

metas.title: Salina Twin Volcanoes
metas.description: Within the Aeolian islands, Salina can easily be distinguished from the twin volcanoes forming a valley across the island.

metas.title: Vulcano Island
metas.description: Vulcano is perhaps the most easily recognisable of the Aeolian islands, with its volcano having an almost white stripe of dirt following the top of the mountainside. It can typically be spotted from afar on the island.

metas.title: Favignana Topography
metas.description:
The island of Favignana has a distinct topography, with mountains running north to south splitting the island in two.

On both sides of the island you will find flat areas, with many rock walls similar to those found in Bari.

Unlike the other islands near Sicily, Favignana is not volcanic.

metas.title: San Domino Coverage
metas.description: The island of San Domino only has overcast Generation 2 coverage, which mostly looks quite gloomy.

metas.title: Overview
metas.description: Jersey is a self-governing island territory in the Channel Islands, located off France’s northwestern coast. It is a British Crown Dependency, so for country streaks purposes it is counted as part of the United Kingdom.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description:
The island is shaped by a unique mix of British and Norman influences. The many winding roads and hedgerows are reminiscent of English country lanes, with tree-covered roads being particularly common. However, due to Jersey’s unique geographical position, most coverage features sunny weather.

All images were taken by a Generation 2 camera.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Jersey licence plates follow the British model, having a long white front and yellow rear plate. In addition, you will notice the island’s red coat of arms on the left, as well as the letter ‘J’ at the beginning of all codes in unblurred plates.
metas.note: In contrast to the British mainland, Jersey was never a member of the European Union. This means that local plates do not have a blue strip.

metas.title: UK Style Infrastructure
metas.description: In general, road infrastructure is similar to that found in the United Kingdom. This includes driving on the left, as well as directional signs, chevrons and warning signs. Some of the subtle differences are discussed below.

metas.title: French Place Names
metas.description: Due to its proximity to France, the vast majority of street and locality names contain French words. The island’s traditional language, known as Jèrriais, is closely related to French and appears on some signs.

metas.title: Architecture
metas.description: Similarly, the local architecture shares many characteristics with that of northern France. This includes pastel-coloured walls and dark slate roofs. However, British-style terraced houses are also common.

metas.title: Red Granite Buildings
metas.description: Jersey is home to large reserves of red granite. As a result, it is a popular building material used for the construction of many walls and houses throughout the island.

metas.title: Yellow Phone Booths
metas.description: In contrast to the iconic red booths found on the mainland of the UK, telephone booths in Jersey are uniquely yellow.

metas.title: Cornish Palms
metas.description: Cornish palms (Cordyline australis) can be identified by their distinctive thin trunks and arching leaves. They are commonly used as decorative plants on Jersey.
metas.note: These palms can also be found on some stretches of the British mainland’s coastline.

metas.title: Yellow Give Way Lines
metas.description: Jersey uses yellow give-way lines at intersections.
metas.note: In contrast, the UK typically uses double dotted white lines for this purpose.

metas.title: Green Lane Signs
metas.description: Jersey has an extensive network of cycling routes. Most notably, you will find signs referencing the start or end of a “Green Lane”. Blue route markers, containing a map of the island in the centre, are also common.

metas.title: Asymmetric Signs
metas.description: Some road signs are asymmetrically attached to their signposts. This appears to be more prevalent on Jersey than on the British mainland.
metas.note: Keep in mind that this only applies to a minority of signs. Most are attached regularly.

metas.title: Parish Coat of Arms
metas.description:
Most street name signs in Jersey are adorned with the coat of arms of the parish in which they are located.

You can click on the graphic to enlarge it.

metas.title: St Helier Urban Area
metas.description: Contrasting with the island’s typically rural look, the area surrounding the capital city of St Helier is more urbanised, featuring taller buildings, narrower streets and a more lively atmosphere.

metas.title: Les Mielles Nature Reserve
metas.description: The Les Mielles Nature Reserve is a vast, treeless expanse located on Jersey’s western coast. Combined with the gentle westward slope and partially overcast coverage, this makes for a very recognisable area.

metas.title: Southwest Glitch
metas.description: Imagery containing a greenish-purple discolouration can be found in the southwest of the island.
metas.note:
This glitch typically makes parts of the screen appear darker than they actually are. In addition, it blends into the landscape more seamlessly than other glitches.

Moreover, this glitch is not unique to Jersey. It can be found in other countries as well.

metas.title: Jersey Airport Fence
metas.description: The roads surrounding Jersey Airport can be recognized thanks to the visible boundary fence.

metas.title: La Collette Power Station
metas.description: The La Collette Power Station is located on a peninsula south of the capital. Its chimney can be seen from various points along the south coast and serves as a useful reference point for pinpointing.

metas.title: Victoria Ave (Divided Road)
metas.description: Victoria Ave runs along the island’s southern coast, immediately west of St Helier. It is the only divided road on Jersey and features a distinct maroon median.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Latvian licence plates are long and white, with the standard blue European strip on the left.

metas.title: Curved Road Bollards
metas.description:
Latvian bollards have a thin, slightly curved shape.

They have a rectangular reflector on the front, and two circular reflectors on the back. The reflectors can be white or orange. The black strip is slightly angled. Bollards often have numbers below the front reflector.
metas.note:
Estonian and Lithuanian bollards look different.

This infographic shows the main similarities and differences between the bollards of the Baltic and Nordic countries.

metas.title: Hook-Shaped Insulators
metas.description: Latvian poles have distinctive poletops, with hook-shaped insulators, that are arranged in an alternating manner: left-right-left (or vice versa).
metas.note: These poletops are much more rare in the other two Baltic countries. They can however appear in some other European countries.

metas.title: Chevron Color Scheme
metas.description: Latvia uses white chevrons with red arrows.
metas.note:
Many other European countries, including Lithuania and Poland, use the same chevrons.

However, Estonia, Russia and Ukraine use chevrons with the opposite colour scheme: red with white arrows.

metas.title: Kilometer Marker Angle
metas.description:
All Baltic countries use the same blue kilometre marker. However, they can be distinguished from each other by their angle relative to the road.

In Latvia, the marker will be parallel to the road. It only has a number on one side.

For a quick overview of all three Baltic countries, see this infographic.

metas.title: Thin Red Sign Border
metas.description:
Each Baltic country has a slightly different border for its warning and speed signs.

Latvian signs have a thick red border, with a thin white outline around it.

metas.title: 5-Stripe Pedestrian Sign
metas.description:
Latvian pedestrian signs have five stripes, which is unique within the Baltics. Uniquely, the pedestrian has noticeably long legs compared to pedestrian signs in other European countries.

The other two Baltic countries have three stripes on their pedestrian signs.

metas.title: Bus Stop Signs
metas.description:
Latvian bus stop signs have this design.

Most importantly, the bus has five windows. Within the Baltics, this is unique to Latvia. The other two Baltic countries have four windows.

metas.title: A-Type Guardrails
metas.description: Latvia has normal A-type guardrails with white or red reflectors.
metas.note: Estonia has no reflectors. Lithuania has orange reflectors. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: Language Characteristics
metas.description:
Latvian belongs to the Baltic languages. The other major member of this branch is Lithuanian, to which it is closely related.

Within the Baltic languages, the following letters are unique to Latvian:

Vowels with a macron (horizontal stripe): Ā Ē Ī.

Consonants with a small hook: Ģ Ķ Ļ Ņ.
metas.note: Estonian is not a member of the Baltic languages(despite the name), and therefore looks significantly different.

metas.title: Street Naming ('Iela')
