metas.description:
The Latvian word for street is iela. This word is unique to Latvian.

Very rarely, you might see ‘gatve’ in Riga (abbreviated as gat.). This word is also the standard word for street in Lithuania (usually abbreviated as g.).

metas.title: House Numbers
metas.description: Latvian house numbers are often shaped like tall rectangles and can be found in several colours.
metas.note: This is not common in Estonia or Lithuania.

metas.title: Wood & White Brick Architecture
metas.description: Latvian architecture generally consists of a combination of wood and white brick, typically with somewhat steep corrugated metal roofs. Slightly modern houses with pastel coloured stone walls and houses with a combination of wood with another material, particularly white brick, are also common.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Latvian directional signs are blue with white text.
metas.note: The arrow on Latvian signs is more stylized than in Estonia and Lithuania, where the back part of the arrowhead is vertical.

metas.title: Red Gen 4 Car
metas.description: A red generation 4 Google car can be found in Latvia.
metas.note: It can also be found in a few other European countries, including Lithuania, but not Estonia.

metas.title: Black Gen 4 Car
metas.description: A black generation 4 Google car can also be found in Latvia.
metas.note: It can also be found in many other European countries, including Lithuania, but not Estonia.

metas.title: Jelgava Landscape
metas.description: The area south of Jelgava is characterised by a wide open landscape with considerably less forest and more fields than most of the rest of Latvia.

metas.title: Riga Art Nouveau
metas.description: The historic downtown area of Riga is characterised by majestic art nouveau architecture, that is in places reminiscent of the architecture in Vienna. This is unique within Latvia, and even within the entire Baltics.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Liechtenstein uses black plates with white lettering and a yellow-and-red emblem near the left side. When blurred, the plates will appear grey, with the emblem colours being visible.

metas.title: Valley Landscape
metas.description:
Most coverage in Liechtenstein is situated in a somewhat flat river valley, but with tall mountains in almost every direction. In particular, within this valley, you will almost always be able to see the nearby mountains towering above you to the east. Most of the mountainous coverage is just on the slopes of the mountains, with only a small amount properly in the mountains.

As a result of the flat Rhine River Valley, Liechtenstein has a lot of pastures and other agricultural land.

metas.title: Lowcam Coverage
metas.description:
All coverage in Liechtenstein is low-cam. This means that the camera on the Google car is intentionally set up lower than in most other countries. This can be recognized in two ways:

The car blur is significantly bigger.

Roads look wider and objects around you are seen from a lower angle.

Generally, the bigger car blur is the most consistent way to recognize low-cam.
metas.note: The only other countries that always have low-cam are Switzerland and Japan.

metas.title: Cylindrical Bollards
metas.description:
Liechtenstein uses black-and-white cylindrical bollards with a white or grey reflector and a rounded top. They also often have a blue attachment on the side.

When attached to guardrails, they will use the wedge design instead.
metas.note: Switzerland can use almost identical bollards.

metas.title: Green/White Bus Stops
metas.description: Bus stops in Liechtenstein use a green-and-white design, with a black metallic border around the sign. The phrase LIEMOBIL is written at the top.
metas.note: The metallic frame is not always black.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Like Switzerland, directional signs in Liechtenstein are generally white (smaller roads) or blue (bigger roads), and they have a pointed arrowhead, with a contrasting colour.

metas.title: 7-Stripe Pedestrian Sign
metas.description: Liechtenstein pedestrian signs have seven stripes. The signs also have an oddly tall rectangle.
metas.note: Switzerland uses identical signs.

metas.title: Yellow/Black Road Separators
metas.description: You can find these yellow-and-black striped road separators, with a rounded top, and a Lego-like knob on the top. They have 3 stripes of both colours, with yellow on the bottom.
metas.note: Switzerland uses a variety of different Road Separators, some of which will look identical to the ones in Liechtenstein.

metas.title: Grey Sign Borders
metas.description: Road signs in Liechtenstein commonly have a round, grey metal border around them.
metas.note: Swiss and German signs can also have similar metallic borders.

metas.title: Architecture
metas.description: Architecture in Liechtenstein is a blend of traditional Alpine styles and more modern buildings, especially in the bigger cities.

metas.title: Triesenberg Slope
metas.description: Triesenberg and its surroundings are a fairly densely populated area on the slope of the mountains just east of the Rhine River Valley, which can often be seen below to the west.

metas.title: Eastern Mountains
metas.description: Mountains can be seen all around in the coverage east of the mountain ridge that cuts through Liechtenstein.

metas.title: Ruggell Ridge
metas.description: Around Ruggell, there is a small, forested ridgeline to the south. This is a big contrast to the towering mountains seen elsewhere.

metas.title: Mauren Hills
metas.description: Around Mauren, you can see the aforementioned ridge to the north, but this side of the hills is much more developed and urban. And to the south and southeast, you will see the much bigger mountains usually seen to the east.

metas.title: Rolling Hills (Bendern)
metas.description: There is a set of rolling hills that run from Bendern, northeast, to the Austrian border. The rest of Liechtenstein is either very flat or in the mountains.

metas.title: Swiss Peaks View
metas.description: In the flat area west of Balzers, with the northeast-oriented gridded roads, to the North/Northwest, you can often see two rocky peaks on the Swiss side.

metas.title: Vaduz Bus Stops (Red)
metas.description: Unlike the rest of Liechtenstein, Vaduz sometimes uses red bus stop signs.
metas.note: Regular bus stops are also present.

metas.title: Balzers Bus Stops (Black)
metas.description: Unlike the rest of Liechtenstein, Balzers sometimes uses black bus stop signs.
metas.note: Regular bus stops are also present.

metas.title: Blue Signs (White Border)
metas.description: Blue street signs with a thin white border will place you either in the south of Liechtenstein or in the north around Bandern.

metas.title: Blue Signs (No Border)
metas.description: Blue street signs that don’t have an outline are found in Eschen.

metas.title: Black Signs
metas.description: Flat black signs are found in eastern Liechtenstein.

metas.title: Schaan Signs
metas.description: Black signs with a white border and embossed letters can be found in Schaan.

metas.title: Brown Signs (White Border)
metas.description: These brown street signs with a font reminiscent of traditional German typefaces, along with a white border, are found in Vaduz and the northern towns.

metas.title: Ruggell Arrow Signs
metas.description: Brown street signs that have an arrow design are unique to Ruggell.
metas.note: The regular brown signs are also present in Ruggell.

metas.title: Planken Signs
metas.description: Browns signs which have a more ‘generic’ font will place you in Planken.

metas.title: Maels Cliff
metas.description: This steep rocky cliff with trees at its base and on the top can be seen in and around Mäls.

metas.title: Steg Lakes
metas.description: The only lakes in Liechtenstein are located just south of Steg, near the middle of the mountains.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Lithuanian licence plates are long and white, with the standard blue European strip on the left.

metas.title: Wedge-Shaped Bollards
metas.description:
Lithuanian bollards are wedge-shaped.

They have an orange reflector on the front, and a white reflector on the back. Both reflectors are rectangular. You may find this thin version as well.
metas.note:
Estonian and Latvian bollards look different.

This infographic shows the main similarities and differences between the bollards of the Baltic and Nordic countries.

metas.title: Square Concrete Poles
metas.description: Lithuanian poles are usually square and concrete, and often feature a diagonal support beam.
metas.note: While most common in Lithuania, these are also found from time to time in Estonia, and on rare occasions in Latvia.

metas.title: Trident Pole Tops
metas.description:
Pictured here are some typical Lithuanian poletops.

They often have short horizontal rods, on which the insulators are placed.

In some poletops, the insulators are arranged in a trident-like shape, with one on top, and two on each side.

Note that these poletops are not unique to Lithuania: they can also be found in the other post-Soviet countries.

metas.title: Chevron Color Scheme
metas.description: Lithuania uses white chevrons with red arrows. The small single chevrons (pictured here) usually have a red outline on the edge of the sign.
metas.note:
Many other European countries, including Latvia and Poland, use the same chevrons (though without the red outline).

However, Estonia, Russia and Ukraine use chevrons with the opposite colour scheme: red with white arrows.

metas.title: Kilometer Marker Angle
metas.description:
All Baltic countries use the same blue kilometre marker. However, they can be distinguished from each other by their angle relative to the road.

In Lithuania, the marker will be at a 45° angle towards the road. The sign itself has an L-shape.

For a quick overview of all three Baltic countries, see this infographic.

metas.title: Thin Red Sign Border
metas.description:
Each Baltic country has a slightly different border for its warning and speed signs.

Lithuanian signs have a relatively thin red border, with a thin white outline around it.

metas.title: Road Guardrails
metas.description: Lithuania has normal A-type guardrails with orange reflectors.
metas.note: Estonia has no reflectors. Latvia has red or white reflectors. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: 3-Stripe Pedestrian Sign
metas.description: Lithuanian pedestrian signs have 3 stripes. The shape of the pedestrian has a relatively low level of detail.
metas.note:
Both Russia and Ukraine share the same design. Estonian signs also have 3 stripes, but the pedestrian looks more detailed.

Latvian pedestrian signs have 5 stripes.

metas.title: Bus Stop Designs
metas.description:
Lithuanian bus stop signs have this design.

The bus has four windows. This is mostly useful to distinguish it from the Latvian bus stop sign, which has five windows.

Note however, that Estonia has the same bus stop signs as Lithuania.

metas.title: Language Characteristics
metas.description:
Lithuanian belongs to the Baltic languages. The other major member of this branch is Latvian, to which it is closely related.

Within the Baltic languages, the following letters are unique to Lithuanian:

Vowels with small hooks: Ą Ę Į Ų.

Ė with a single dot.

Y (also in Estonian, but only in loan words).
metas.note: Estonian is not a member of the Baltic languages (despite its name), and therefore looks significantly different.

metas.title: Capital City Features
metas.description:
The Lithuanian word for street is gatve, often abbreviated as g. on signs and Google Maps.

This word is almost entirely unique to Lithuanian. However, very rarely, you might see ‘gatve’ (abbreviated as gat.) in the Latvian capital of Riga.

metas.title: Place Names ('-ai')
metas.description: Many Lithuanian place names end in -ai.

metas.title: Local Architecture
metas.description: Lithuanian architecture primarily consists of light coloured brick buildings, usually with somewhat steep corrugated metal roofs. Wooden buildings are also fairly common, however less so than in Estonia. Pastel painted stone buildings are somewhat common, especially in newer suburbs.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Lithuanian directional signs are blue with white text.
metas.note: The arrow on Latvian signs is more stylized than in Estonia and Lithuania, where the back part of the arrowhead is vertical.

metas.title: Historical Site
metas.description: Lithuania's historical state flag, known as the Vytis, depicts a mounted knight on a dark red background. It can sometimes be seen on both private and public buildings.

metas.title: Agricultural Area
metas.description: Lithuania has less forest cover than the other two Baltic countries. As a result, the landscape appears more open and agricultural. Your mileage may vary depending on the round however, so use this meta with some caution.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: In Generation 3 coverage, you will often see random small blurs. These blurs look similar to the ones that are used to blur out licence plates or faces, but instead they cover seemingly random parts of the image – often on direction signs.
metas.note:
This is also common in the Russian oblast of Kaliningrad, just to the southwest of Lithuania.

These random blurs are not typically found in Estonia or Latvia.

metas.title: Lithuania Features
metas.description: A black generation 4 Google car can be found in Lithuania.
metas.note: It can also be found in a few other European countries, including Latvia, but not Estonia.

metas.title: Lithuania Features
metas.description: A red generation 4 Google car can also be found in Lithuania.
metas.note: It can also be found in a few other European countries, including Latvia, but not Estonia.

metas.title: Hilly Terrain
metas.description: Lithuania is overall a fairly flat country, with no hills over 300 metres. However, you can sometimes distinguish the hilly areas from the more flat areas. The biggest hills are in the southeast, with some hills in the central part of the west.

metas.title: Metal Poles
metas.description:
Metal pole tags are predominantly found in the eastern part of the country.

For more information on Lithuanian pole stickers and car metas, please see this document.

metas.title: Pine Forests
metas.description:
The Curonian Spit is a long thin sand-dune spit south of Klaipeda, that separates the Curonian Lagoon from the Baltic Sea. The main road on this spit, road 167, has a recognizable combination of landscape and road direction:

The road runs in an approximate north-south direction and has Generation 4 coverage.

The road is surrounded on all sides by forest with many Baltic pines. In many places, you will see slightly windswept trees (visible in the example image).

metas.title: Curonian Spit (Architecture)
metas.description: On the Curonian Spit you can also find wooden, and often red, Scandinavian looking houses.

metas.title: Polish Bilingual Signs
metas.description:
Rarely, you can see bilingual signs with Polish language in a small area southeast of Lithuania.

Note that this is by no means very common, but it can help with getting very close guesses if you do see bilingual Polish-Lithuanian signs in an otherwise obvious Lithuanian setting.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description:
Luxembourg uses long yellow plates with a blue strip on the left.

Since Luxembourg is a small country, foreign cars with white plates are somewhat common.
metas.note:
There are only a few other European countries that use yellow plates for private vehicles:

The Netherlands has yellow plates front and rear.

The UK has yellow rear plates.

Some pre-2009 French cars have yellow rear plates.

metas.title: Striped Bollards
metas.description: Bollards are black and white. They are wedge-shaped and have grey reflectors. Some have a distinctive indent in the lower half.
metas.note:
They look more or less identical to German bollards. The most notable difference is that the reflectors on German bollards have two bolts, while in Luxembourg they have three.

The bollards of Belgium, the Netherlands and France look very different.

metas.title: Yellow-Black Chevrons
metas.description: Chevrons are black with yellow arrows. You may also rarely come across blue and yellow chevrons.
metas.note:
None of Luxembourg’s neighbours use these chevrons.

The only other European countries with this colour scheme tend to have wildly different landscapes: Iceland, Norway, Finland, Ireland, and Portugal.

metas.title: Utility Poles
metas.description:
Poles with poletops shaped like upside-down tridents are the most common type of pole in Luxembourg.

In addition, you can find a variety of other poletops.
metas.note: These poles can also be commonly seen in France, Spain and Portugal.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description:
Almost all coverage in Luxembourg is either Generation 2 or Generation 4.

Generation 3 is rare, but does exist.

metas.title: Multilingual Signs
metas.description:
Luxembourg is a highly multilingual country. It has three administrative languages: Luxembourgish, French, and German.

French is the language that is mostly used for public communication. Road signs and advertisements are usually in French.

Presence of German on signs is less common compared to French, but certainly not non-existent.

metas.title: Luxembourgish Language
metas.description:
Luxembourgish is closely related to German and can look very similar. Like German, it uses umlauts (dots over vowels). In addition, it uses a fair amount of double vowels, and sometimes an é with an accent.

Most town names have their origin in Luxembourgish, German, or both.

metas.title: Directional Signs (Yellow)
metas.description:
Directional signs are yellow with a thin black outline. Town names are written in uppercase. The signs have a pointed tip. They are completely surrounded by a frame, making them very recognizable.

Some directional signs feature road numbers:

Regional road numbers have 1 or 2 digits and a red box.

Local road numbers have 3 digits and a yellow box.

metas.title: Town Entrance Signs
metas.description:
Town entrance signs are also yellow and surrounded by a frame.

Most of these signs have bilingual versions of the town name. They frequently have the road number on the top, along with a speed limit sign.

metas.title: Sign Frames
metas.description: The frames mentioned in the previous two tips are also commonly found on a lot of other road infrastructure.
metas.note: Denmark notably also uses a lot of similar-looking frames on road infrastructure. A recognizable difference is that the corners on Luxembourg frames are more square, while Danish frames are more rounded.

metas.title: White Signposts
metas.description: Almost all Luxembourgish road signs will be supported by a white signpost.
metas.note: While not nearly as common, white signposts are also found in France.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description:
Street signs are almost always short and usually have a white background. The exact designs vary from town to town.

A very common design is the one pictured on the left in the example image, with slanted blue corners.
metas.note:
Belgian street signs often appear short as well, but can have other background colours – not just white.

In addition, Dutch street signs almost always have a blue background and tend to be much longer than they are tall.

metas.title: Blue/White Post Reflectors
metas.description: Some signposts have this bulky, round reflector with blue and white markings.
metas.note: Similar markings are found in Sweden and Finland. Landscape should be sufficient to tell these apart from Luxembourg, however.

metas.title: Pedestrian Signs Have
metas.description: Pedestrian signs have 5 vertical stripes.
metas.note: Belgian pedestrian signs have 2 horizontal stripes.

metas.title: Bus Stop Designs
metas.description: Bus stop signs are blue and always have this exact design. The bus has six windows.
metas.note: Bus stop signs in Belgium and the Netherlands have significantly different designs. For example, the Belgian bus stop sign always has a yellow signpost.

metas.title: Rolling Hills
metas.description: Almost all of Luxembourg’s landscape consists of green rolling hills, with a patchwork of agriculture and forests.
metas.note: If you see a yellow licence plate, and you are not sure what country it belongs to, landscape is often a good clue: almost all of the Netherlands is completely flat.

metas.title: Slate Roof Architecture
metas.description:
Houses tend to have dark slate roofs.

Walls and windows tend to be plain and undecorated. Walls are usually painted white, grey, or pastel colours.
metas.note: Such architecture can also be found in the surrounding regions in Belgium and France, but is especially prominent in Luxembourg.

metas.title: Capital City Features
metas.description:
Local road numbers have three digits. They are geographically clustered by first digit. The first digits range from 1-3.

1xx is found in the southern half.

2xx is found in and around the capital.

3xx is found in the northern half.

metas.title: Northern Hills
metas.description: The north of the country is hillier and has an overall higher elevation than the south.

metas.title: Southeast Vineyards
metas.description: Vineyards are primarily found in the southeast of the country.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: Some of Luxembourg City’s downtown area was covered by a Generation 3 urban trekker. Occasionally, the trekker’s sunglasses and greying hair can be seen.

metas.title: Portuguese Infrastructure
metas.description: Since Madeira is an autonomous region of Portugal, you will often come across various types of Portuguese infrastructure, such as poles and chevrons.

metas.title: Mountainous Landscape
metas.description: Madeira is a very mountainous and semi-tropical island.
metas.note: The Azores are less mountainous and more temperate.

metas.title: Eucalyptus Forests
metas.description: Similar to continental Portugal, Madeira has a lot of eucalyptus forests, which can sometimes look deceptively like the mainland.
metas.note: The Azores do not commonly have eucalypti.

metas.title: Hydrangeas
metas.description: Hydrangeas can occasionally be seen.
metas.note: They are even more common on the Azores.

metas.title: African Lilies
metas.description: African lilies (Agapanthus praecox) are very common in Madeira. They can be recognized by their long grassy leaves and round flower clusters at the end of a long stem. The most common colours are white and blue.

metas.title: Terrace Farming
metas.description: Due to the lack of flat terrain, terrace farming is extensively practised on the island. Stone walls are used to separate the individual plateaus.

metas.title: Ferns
metas.description: Ferns are very common throughout the island.

metas.title: Architecture Colors
metas.description: Houses are mainly painted white, grey, or pastel colours such as yellow and pink. In addition, the red tile roofs will often be in a good condition.

metas.title: Concrete Barriers
metas.description: Concrete block barriers, usually painted white, are often found along roads.

metas.title: Bus Stop Signs
metas.description: Bus stops signs on Madeira follow a unique black, white and yellow colour scheme.

metas.title: Yellow Taxis (Blue Stripe)
metas.description: Taxis on Madeira are yellow with a blue stripe running along the sides of the car.

metas.title: Stone Bollards
metas.description: Madeira commonly uses small and unique stone bollards with a red reflector. They are either cuboidal or cylindrical in shape.

metas.title: Guardrails (Yellow/Black)
metas.description: Madeira sometimes uses yellow-and black guardrails on its mountain roads.

metas.title: Highway Speed Signs
metas.description: These speed limit signs are unique to Madeira and can be found on its highways.

metas.title: Low Altitude Clouds
metas.description: Low altitude clouds are typical on the island, and are often seen on street view.

metas.title: Foggy Coverage
metas.description: Foggy coverage is quite common.

metas.title: Tunnels
metas.description: As a result of the island’s mountainous terrain, tunnels are very common.

metas.title: Green Bridge Railings
metas.description: On bridges you will often find railings painted dark green.

metas.title: Striped Signposts
metas.description: Signposts on Madeira are often striped.
metas.note: These are also seen on the Azores.

metas.title: Free Roaming Cows
metas.description: You can sometimes find free roaming cows on high-altitude roads on the island, as well as warning signs for those cows. The cows will typically be brown with white spots, contrary to the Azores, where the cows will typically be black and white.

metas.title: Low Quality Camera
metas.description:
Google used a weird, low-quality camera on Madeira, commonly known as the official Ari (or "shitcam"). It has a wide circular car blur and makes the image appear rather gloomy. On Madeira, you will often see the unblurred back of a white car.

A good map will usually not include this coverage, but it is good to be aware of its existence, in order not to be caught off-guard.

metas.title: Banana Plantations (South)
metas.description: The majority of banana plantations are found in the south.

metas.title: Central-West Plateau
metas.description: The centre-west of the island is home to an elevated plateau. It can be recognized by the unusual flatness, misty coverage, and the presence of wind turbines.

metas.title: Eastern Mountains (East of Plateau)
metas.description: The road east of the plateau can be recognized by its unique mountain formations and the black-and-yellow guardrail on the side of the road.

metas.title: Eastern Tip (Arid)
metas.description: The eastern tip of the island is very arid with little to no vegetation.

metas.title: ER211 Road (Dark Pavement)
metas.description: The ER211 can be recognized by the dark pavement combined with its exposed brownish soil.

metas.title: Pico Areeiro (Radar Station)
metas.description: Pico Areeiro is the second highest mountain on the island, and the highest with coverage. It can be recognized by its view over most of the island, and the white radar station at the top.

metas.title: Penha d'Aguia Rock
metas.description: The Penha d'Águia is located in northeastern Madeira, isolated on an elevated hill.

metas.title: Airport Pillars
metas.description: The Cristiano Ronaldo International Airport is located in eastern Madeira. The north of it is built on these numerous concrete pillars.

metas.title: Cascata dos Anjos
metas.description: Cascata dos Anjos is situated in the southwest and is a popular location on the island. It is a 100-metre-high waterfall, which cascades onto the road below.

metas.title: Ribeira da Janela Rocks
metas.description: The islands of Ribeira de Janela, located in the northwest, are a famous photographer spot with their vertical, jagged shape.

metas.title: Porto Moniz Rocks
metas.description: These dark, sharp rock formations with an island in the background are found in Porto Moniz in the northwest.

metas.title: Driving Side (Left)
metas.description: Malta drives on the left.
metas.note: Cyprus also drives on the left.

metas.title: Short Plates
metas.description: Like most of Europe, Maltese licence plates have a blue strip on the left. However, unlike most of Europe, short plates are very common.

metas.title: Dry Hilly Landscape
metas.description: The general landscape of Malta consists of slightly hilly dry agricultural fields. Many roads are also only 1 or 2 lanes wide, due to the island’s size. Having a mediterranean climate, cacti and various dry shrubs can be seen.

metas.title: Limestone Rock Walls
metas.description: Limestone rock walls are extremely common in Malta. This alone is usually enough to determine that you are in Malta.

metas.title: Limestone Architecture
metas.description: The vast majority of buildings in Malta consist of low storey buildings, with white to beige coloured walls. Buildings made of limestone are also fairly common.

metas.title: Traditional Balconies
metas.description: This style of traditional covered balconies is very common on Maltese buildings. They are often painted in bright colours.

metas.title: Street Naming ('Triq')
metas.description: The Maltese word for street is “triq”, which can be seen on almost every street sign.

metas.title: Bus Stop Signs
metas.description: Bus stops are a common sight in Malta. They may sometimes have useful information as to where you are.

metas.title: Double Yellow Lines
metas.description: Like the UK and Ireland, Malta uses these distinctive double yellow no parking lines.

metas.title: English Language
metas.description: English is the primary language of Malta.

metas.title: Maltese Language
metas.description:
Apart from English it is also common to see the Maltese language. Maltese uses the Latin script, but with unique letters, which include:

Ċ ċ

Ġ ġ

Ħ ħ

Ż ż

metas.title: Stone Barriers (Gozo)
metas.description: Regular metal guardrails are rare on Gozo Island. Low stone barriers are more common instead.

metas.title: Gozo Bus Numbers (300s)
metas.description: Uniquely, all bus routes on Gozo Island are in the 300s. These can be quite hard to see, meaning they are most useful in moving games.

metas.title: Valletta Blue Signs
metas.description: These blue signs are unique to Valletta.

metas.title: Gozo Ferry Trekker
metas.description: This trekker on a ship that is painted white and blue can be seen between the main island and Gozo Island.

metas.title: Location Overview
metas.description: Monaco is a European microstate on the French Riviera, a few kilometres west of the border with Italy.

metas.title: Urban Architecture
metas.description: Monaco is a rich and densely populated city state, with a Mediterranean feel to it. The architecture is similar to cities in southern France and northern Italy, but more luxurious. You will see a lot of apartment buildings, neoclassical details, and pastel colours. There are essentially no rural areas.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description:
Monaco’s licence plates are short and lack the blue strip.

You will still see a lot of normal French plates around, however. These French vehicles often still have the old yellow back plates, due to how old the Generation 2 coverage is.

metas.title: Hilly Landscape
metas.description: Monaco is a hilly country. The very few areas that are not built up show mediterranean vegetation.

metas.title: Palm Trees
metas.description: Planted palm trees are common.

metas.title: Tunnel Coverage
metas.description: There is a lot of coverage inside tunnels.

metas.title: Parked Mopeds
metas.description: Rows of parked mopeds are a common sight around Monaco’s streets.

metas.title: Harbour Boat Trekker
metas.description:
In the harbour, there is an extensive Generation 3 trekker on a boat. The Google employee’s brown hair and sunglasses are visible. You can see Monaco’s skyline and the hills beyond it. There are a lot of expensive yachts around.

This trekker shows up a lot in the official competitive game modes, so it is worth remembering.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Montenegro uses the standard European plate with a blue strip, and the Montenegro coat of arms on a red circle. The red circle is visible through the blur.
metas.note: The white section of Albanian licence plates do not have a red circle.

metas.title: Mountainous Landscape
metas.description: Montenegro is a small, mountainous country. Inland mountains are lush and green, while most coastal mountains have distinct exposed, light coloured rock. Most roads are also only 1 or 2 lanes wide.

metas.title: Black Top Bollards
metas.description: The most common bollard is white with a red reflector on the front and a white one on the back. The bollard also has a black top.
metas.note: These bollards are also found in Slovenia.

metas.title: Chevron Color Scheme
metas.description: Montenegro uses black on white or red on yellow chevrons.
metas.note: Albania uses white on black chevrons.

metas.title: Rusted Guardrails
metas.description: Guardrails in Montenegro are often rusted.

metas.title: A-Type & B-Type Guardrails
metas.description: Montenegro is the only Balkan country where you’ll commonly see both A-type and B-type guardrails.
metas.note: For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: Utility Poles
metas.description: Montenegro uses simple round concrete or wooden poles.

metas.title: Sky Rifts
metas.description: ‘Rifts’ can commonly be seen in Montenegrin coverage, due to poor stitching.
metas.note: Rifts are also common in Albania, and can rarely be seen in various other countries.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Coverage in Montenegro is limited to main roads, with very few minor roads covered. The only main road not covered is the A1, south of Kolasin.

metas.title: Rift Map (Inland vs Coast)
metas.description: This map shows the distribution of where rifts are found. Although rifts are common in Montenegro, coastal rounds will almost never have them. By the coast, there will be a short antenna with no rifts. There will be a long antenna with rifts inland.
metas.note:
An exception to this is the area around the coastal villages of Utjeha and Dobra Voda.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Northern Valleys
metas.description: Green, agricultural valleys with deforested hills to make way for farmland are most commonly seen in the north.

metas.title: Bay of Kotor
metas.description: The Bay of Kotor has a touristy and populated feel to it, with many people dressed in swimwear. A distinct steep, rocky ridge can also be seen.

metas.title: Dry Landscape (Podgorica)
metas.description: Dry mountains with a lack of trees are seen around Podgorica, and to the south of it. Vineyards are also commonly seen in this region.

metas.title: Pine Forests
metas.description: Pine forests can be found in the north and a small area north of Nikšić, but most commonly in the east.

metas.title: Durmitor National Park
metas.description:
Durmitor National Park can be recognized by a distinct landscape consisting of grassy, treeless mountains with a high-altitude feel.

The town of Žabljak is situated in this national park, and can be recognized by the landscape but also by the unique architecture.

metas.title: Podgorica
metas.description: Podgorica is the capital and largest city in Montenegro, and can be recognized by the modern buildings, wide roads and modern infrastructure.

metas.title: Cemi River Valley
metas.description: These distinct staircase-like mountainsides can be seen in the Cemi River Valley.

metas.title: Slansko Lake Islands
metas.description: Many small islands can be seen within Slansko Lake.

metas.title: Pljevlja Coal Mine
metas.description: The Pljevlja Coal Mine can be recognized by the wide, artificial wall of gravel. The mine can often be seen from afar.

metas.title: P15 Police Car
metas.description: The Google Car can be seen chasing this police car on the P15, between Lovcen National Park and Čevo.

metas.title: E80 Yellow Lines
metas.description: The southern part of the E80, between Orahovo and Đurmani, can be recognized by the yellow outer lines.

metas.title: Skadar Lake Bridge
metas.description: The Skadar Lake Bridge can be recognized by the railway and stone bollards next to the road.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: The Netherlands has long, yellow licence plates with the standard European blue strip on the left. Dutch taxis have blue plates.
metas.note: The only other countries in Europe with yellow licence plates are Luxembourg and the UK. For the UK, only the back plates are yellow, and they often lack the blue strip. In addition, some older coverage in France features the French yellow back plates. In Denmark, you can find yellow plates on commercial vehicles.

metas.title: Dutch Language
metas.description: Dutch is a Germanic language. It features a lot of double vowels. Typical letter clusters are ij, ieuw and oe. “IJ“ written as one capitalised letter is also unique to the language.
metas.note: Dutch is also used in the region of Flanders, which comprises the northern half of Belgium.

metas.title: White Bollards (Red Reflector)
metas.description: The Netherlands has a simple, white bollard with a red reflector.
metas.note: On rare occasions, you can find round French-style bollards with a red band and a pointed top. A difference with French bollards is that the red wrap usually does not go all the way around the bollard.

metas.title: Lack of Utility Poles
metas.description: The Netherlands usually does not have any utility poles. You might see larger power lines like the ones shown in the image, but essentially never any street-level smaller utility poles.
metas.note: Belgium does use utility poles somewhat commonly.

metas.title: Flat Landscape
metas.description: The Netherlands is extraordinarily flat. In most of the country, you will get no more than a few metres of elevation. Large swathes of the country are reclaimed land that is at or even below sea level.
metas.note: The most major exception to this is the south of Limburg, where you can get low hills. Another place with some amount of hills is De Veluwe in central Gelderland province.

metas.title: Water Management (Dikes/Canals)
metas.description: In addition, the Netherlands is a very water-rich country. The country has innumerous waterways. Canals and ditches next to the road are common. Water management is an important facet of Dutch infrastructure, so you will often see dikes (low earthen walls to protect against water), dams and bridges.

metas.title: Tree-Lined Roads
metas.description: Many rural roads are lined by rows of trees.
metas.note: This is also common in Poland.

metas.title: Urban Planning & Row Houses
metas.description: The Netherlands has a high amount of urban planning, and as a result tends to have a very organised look. Road infrastructure is well-maintained. Suburbs are usually master-planned and typically feature row houses.

metas.title: Road Markings
metas.description: Like most of Europe, the Netherlands has all-white road lines. Many roads have dashed outside lines. Sometimes, you can find unique green middle lines.

metas.title: Bicycle Paths
metas.description:
Many Dutch roads are flanked by bicycle paths. Different designs exist, but a very common one is a reddish-pink lane.

Cycling is one of the most common modes of transportation in the Netherlands. You will see cyclists and bicycles everywhere.

metas.title: Brick Roads
metas.description: Brick roads are common in the Netherlands, both in rural and urban areas. The brick pattern shown in the image is especially common.

metas.title: Sidewalk Tiles
metas.description: Most Dutch sidewalks use the same type of square grey tiles and offset tiling pattern. In some historic areas, you might find smaller brick sidewalks.

metas.title: Speed Bumps
metas.description: The Netherlands has very recognizable speed bumps. They usually have white warning stripes that alternate between long and short. The example image is on a brick road, but they also occur on asphalt roads.

metas.title: Brick Rumble Strips
metas.description: Many rural roads feature a sort of brick rumble strip on the sides. This is fairly unique to the Netherlands and a good way to identify the country in very rural rounds.

metas.title: Street Signs
metas.description:
Street signs are almost always blue with white lettering. Very rarely, you can find yellow, white or green street signs.

The Dutch word for street is straat. Other common road name endings are -weg, -laan, -pad, and -plein. However, if you see a blue sign with the word ‘fietspad’, do not search for it; it simply means ‘bicycle path’.
metas.note: Street signs in Belgium come in a variety of colours and usually mention the municipality, which is rare in the Netherlands.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Dutch direction signs are blue with white lettering. Signs for bicyclists are white with a red border.

metas.title: Town Entry Signs
metas.description: Dutch town entry signs are blue. The signs sometimes have very elaborate designs, often with frames and additional signs.
metas.note: Often, these signs list the municipality they are in, after the word ‘gemeente’ (gem). Many municipalities are named after larger towns or cities in the vicinity, which can help a lot with scanning.

metas.title: Green Hectometer Markers
metas.description:
Dutch road markers are green. Many list the road number in a small yellow or red box.

Highways have a red box and start with the letter A. Regional roads have a yellow box and start with the letter N.
metas.note: Some of them have province-specific designs. You can learn more about this in the region-guessing section.

metas.title: Sign Edges (Folded)
metas.description: Edges of Dutch road signs will extend to the back, creating a border visible from behind, sometimes retaining the colour of the sign. This is both consistent and unique to the country.

metas.title: Striped Signposts
metas.description: Many Dutch signposts feature striped markings with a black-and-white or blue-and-white colour scheme.

metas.title: Yellow Signposts
metas.description: Road signs on traffic islands often have these bulky yellow signposts.

metas.title: Striped Road Barriers
metas.description: On some roads, especially in rural areas, you might find these distinctive striped barriers.

metas.title: Brick Architecture
metas.description: Brick architecture is very common in the Netherlands. Many buildings feature red-brownish-coloured bricks. Roofs often have orange or dark grey tiles.
metas.note: Similar brick architecture is also common in Denmark and Belgium.

metas.title: Row Houses
metas.description: As mentioned before, row houses are very common in the Netherlands. Almost half of the Dutch housing stock are row houses, significantly more than almost all other European countries.

metas.title: Windmills
metas.description: Windmills, both traditional water or grain mills, and modern wind power turbines, are common in the Netherlands.

metas.title: Gen 4 Black Car Glitch
metas.description: Some Generation 4 coverage has a car blur glitch where the black back of the Google car is visible.

metas.title: Smallcam Coverage
metas.description: The Netherlands also has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.
metas.note: Most of Western Europe also has smallcam.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description: Dutch landline phone numbers start with a three- or four-digit area code. These are geographically grouped, except for the ones that start with 07, and two of the 02 codes.
metas.note:
Dutch mobile phone numbers start with 06, which is a code that is not used for any of the landline area codes.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Province-Specific Bollards/Markers
metas.description:
Some road markers (“hectometre markers”) have province-specific designs. This only applies to markers for regional N-roads, which have road numbers in yellow boxes.

Not all N-road markers have province-specific designs: some just have a generic design that can be found nationwide.

The A-roads all have the same signs and are recognizable because the road number is in a red box.

Bollards sometimes feature kilometre stickers, which are also limited to specific regions.

You can click on the image to enlarge it. Image provided by Timzkii.

metas.title: Provincial Flags
metas.description:
All Dutch provinces have their own flag. However, most of these are very rarely seen in the wild. The major exceptions to this are the flags of Friesland and Noord-Brabant.

In addition, you can sometimes see the unofficial but very popular flag of the Achterhoek cultural region in the east of Gelderland.

For a full list of all provincial flags, you can view this Wikipedia page.

metas.title: Frisian Language
metas.description:
In the province of Friesland, the Frisian language is commonly spoken. While Dutch language is still most prevalent on signs, a lot of town entry signs will feature bilingual town names.

Some street names in Friesland uniquely end in -wei or -strjitte.
metas.note: Frisian has vowels with circumflex diacritics (“little hats”): Â, Ê, Ô and Û. Dutch does not have these letters, except in loanwords. In addition, the Y is significantly more common compared to Dutch.

metas.title: Limburg Pole Stickers
metas.description: This long, vertically arranged white sticker with three to four digits is found on street lights in Limburg.

metas.title: North Brabant Pole Stickers
metas.description: Similarly to Limburg, North Brabant also has white stickers on their street lights, however it is horizontally arranged and only has one or two digits.

metas.title: Polder Landscape
metas.description: Most of the west and north is at or below sea-level. As a result, most of this region’s countryside has a distinct “polder” landscape: the landscape is marshy, often with a large amount of small waterways.

metas.title: Eastern/Southern Landscape
metas.description: Conversely, the south and the east tends to have a more typical flat European farmland look. Waterways are still common, but the landscape can look less marshy.

metas.title: Limburg Hills
metas.description: While most of the Netherlands is very flat, Southern Limburg has some low hills.

metas.title: Veluwe Forest
metas.description:
The Veluwe area is unusually forested for Dutch standards. Some parts feature a very slight amount of elevation.

Some parts of the Veluwe feature old-growth forest, heath or sandy soil. This area can look odd and unlike the rest of the Netherlands if you have never seen it before.
metas.note: Some other natural areas in the Netherlands can have a similar look, but the Veluwe is by far the largest.

metas.title: Flevoland Landscape
metas.description: Almost all of the land belonging to the province of Flevoland was reclaimed from the sea in the mid-20th century. As a result, the province has a distinct, man-made look: extremely straight roads and large crop fields dominate the landscape. Wind turbines are common. In urban areas, there are no historical buildings.
metas.note: The only exception to this description is the town of Urk, which is situated on a former island now surrounded by the rest of the province’s man-made polder landscape.

metas.title: Coastal Dunes
metas.description: Most of the Dutch North Sea coast is lined by dunes.

metas.title: Wadden Islands
metas.description: The islands in the northwest are called the Wadden Islands. They are very popular local tourism destinations, which is sometimes evident in the street view coverage. Their northwestern coastlines feature a lot of sand dunes.

metas.title: Northern Farm Roofs
metas.description: Farms in the north of the Netherlands often have very large roofs.

metas.title: Rolling Shutters
metas.description: Rolling shutters on house windows are more common in the southern half of the Netherlands.
metas.note: While more prevalent in the south, rolling shutters on homes in more northern regions are not unheard of. Use this meta with some caution.

metas.title: Curaçao
metas.description:
Curaçao is a constituent country in the Kingdom of the Netherlands, located north of western Venezuela in the Caribbean Sea. As such, for country streaks purposes, it is counted as the Netherlands.

Plonk It has a more in-depth guide to Curaçao here.

metas.title: Amsterdam Street Signs
metas.description: Amsterdam street signs feature the city district in a smaller font size below the actual street name.
metas.note: This design is very uncommon in the rest of the Netherlands.

metas.title: Oegstgeest Street Signs
metas.description: The municipality of Oegstgeest, just northwest of Leiden, uses uniquely illegible street signs with yellow text on a red background.

metas.title: Zaanstreek Architecture
metas.description: Buildings in the Zaanstreek region just north of Amsterdam often feature wooden architectural elements, usually painted green or black; with white trims. They sometimes have tall roof spires, usually painted white.

metas.title: Afsluitdijk
metas.description: The Afsluitdijk is a very recognizable man-made causeway between Noord-Holland and Friesland. It is a divided highway that runs in a very straight southwest to northeast direction. You can see water to your southeast, and a dike to your northwest.
metas.note: There are other large causeways and dams in the Netherlands, but the Afsluitdijk is the biggest and has a very recognizable road direction.

metas.title: Westland Greenhouses
metas.description: In the Westland municipality, just southwest of The Hague, greenhouses are extremely common. They cover most of the municipality’s land surface.

metas.title: Hoge Veluwe Trekker
metas.description: In the southern part of the Veluwe, in National Park De Hoge Veluwe, you can find a trekker that is recognizable because the Google employee’s brown hair is visible.

metas.title: Rotterdam Harbour
metas.description: The harbour of Rotterdam is one of the largest in the world. It extends all the way from downtown Rotterdam to the North Sea coast. If you see a lot of industrial activity, often in combination with large, round fuel storage tanks, there is a good chance that you are in this harbour area.
metas.note: Amsterdam and Delfzijl also have large harbours. Both also feature a lot of fuel storage tanks.

metas.title: Lelystad Street Names
metas.description: Many streets in Lelystad follow a fairly distinct naming scheme: instead of having unique names, they are named after the neighbourhood they are in, followed by a number. Some of these neighbourhood names show up on the Google map.

metas.title: Baarle-Nassau/Hertog
metas.description: Baarle is a town in the south of the Netherlands which contains a number of Belgian enclaves. Throughout the town, you can sometimes see signs of this, such as markings on the pavement and Dutch and Belgian flags being flown together.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: North Macedonian licence plates are white and sometimes have the standard European blue strip on the left. They also have a noticeable red block near the left side of the licence plate.
metas.note: Serbia will almost always have a blue strip on their licence plates.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: North Macedonia uses two types of bollards. One is rounded and very thin, while the other one is wedge-shaped. They both are white and have red or white reflectors, typically on a black surface.
metas.note: Croatia uses the same wedge-shaped bollard. Hungary has a similar wedge-shaped bollard but with more white space above the black rectangle.

metas.title: Guardrails
metas.description: North Macedonia uses A-Profile guardrails, like most of Europe. The guardrails have red reflectors.
metas.note: Serbia uses B-Profile guardrails. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: Bilingual Directional Signs
metas.description: Direction signs in North Macedonia are typically yellow with biscriptal text: town names are written in both Latin and Cyrillic script.
metas.note: Serbia, Slovenia, Croatia, and Montenegro have similar signs. Serbia is the only one that will have biscriptal text though.

metas.title: Language & Alphabet
metas.description:
Macedonian is a Slavic language which uses the Cyrillic script. Road signs have Latin on them too, although most other signs are fully in Cyrillic.

The letters ‘Ѓ’ and ‘Ќ’ are unique to Macedonian. ‘Љ’, ‘Њ’, and ‘Џ’ are only in Serbian and Macedonian.

metas.title: Gen 3 No Antenna
metas.description:
All coverage in North Macedonia is Generation 3. There will never be an antenna on the Google car.

Every other country in Europe will sometimes or always have an antenna in Generation 3 coverage. For clarity’s sake: this means that cars with no antenna can be found outside North Macedonia.
metas.note: The only other country to have no antenna the majority of the time is Serbia, although there will be an antenna sometimes.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Rural coverage in North Macedonia will normally mostly be on highways. This is because of the limited coverage outside urban areas in the country.

metas.title: Dry Grassland Landscape
metas.description: The general landscape of North Macedonia consists of relatively dry grasslands, and small hills and scattered trees.

metas.title: Greek-Style Lamps
metas.description: These ‘Greek Lamps’ on utility poles can be found in North Macedonia. They can also be found in various other countries, such as (unsurprisingly) Greece or Serbia.

metas.title: Yellow Warning Signs
metas.description: North Macedonia normally uses yellow-filled in warning signs. Most of Europe uses white ones.
metas.note: In southeastern Europe, Greece also commonly uses yellow-filled in signs. Slovenia sometimes has yellow-filled signs.

metas.title: Urban Coverage List
metas.description:
Coverage is sparse, only including some highways and some cities in the country.

The cities of Skopje, Bitola, Kumanovo, Prilep, Tetovo, Veles, Ohrid, and Strumica are the only ones with significant coverage inside the city.

You can view the official coverage in more detail on this site.

metas.title: Skopje
metas.description: Skopje is the capital and by far the largest city. If you see any large apartments or buildings, you are almost guaranteed to be in Skopje.

metas.title: Winter Coverage Cities
metas.description: Winter to late fall coverage is found in the cities of Skopje, Tetovo, Prilep, Bitola, and Ohrid.

metas.title: Green Truck Glitch
metas.description: A green truck is visible behind the Google Car for a portion of the E-65. The truck is visible from Kichevo to Arbinovo.

metas.title: E75 Triple Yellow Lines
metas.description:
For some of the E-75 north of Veles, there are triple yellow lines with a dashed centre line. In the northern part of the road, there is a yellow-truck following the Google car.

The rest of the road is either under construction or newly paved. This road is very similar to the A3 east of Veles, although that one is much flatter and has an arid landscape surrounding it.

metas.title: A3 Triple Yellow Lines
metas.description: A section of the A3 east of Veles also has triple yellow lines, which in Europe is extremely uncommon. The rest of the road has a very arid landscape and is noticeably under construction.

metas.title: Single Camera Smudge
metas.description: You can sometimes see some smudges on the camera. If you see one black smudge on the camera, you will most likely be on the A3 between Bitola and Prilep, or the R1302 in the far east. Keep in mind smudges can be randomly seen throughout the country.

metas.title: Triple Camera Smudge
metas.description: If you see three smudges, you will always be on the R1304. The only large city on this road is Kočani, although it has extremely limited coverage.

metas.title: Brown Camera Smudge
metas.description: If you see a brown smudge, you will be in the far southeast of the country.

metas.title: R1205 Fly Glitch
metas.description: A fly can be seen on the southern portion of the R1205. This is found nowhere else in the country.

metas.title: Divided Highways Map
metas.description:
Some roads in North Macedonia are divided. The map shown here gives an overview of where you can find such roads.

You can learn more about these roads below.

metas.title: E65 Concrete Median
metas.description: The E-65 just south of Tetovo has one concrete median separating each lane instead of a normal guardrail. This is the only highway in the country to have this.

metas.title: E65 Trees in Median
metas.description:
The E-65 between Tetovo and Skopje will sometimes have trees in between the guardrails.

This is the only highway to have them, besides a small part of the E-75/A1 road south of Veles (see the next tip).

metas.title: A1 Trees in Median
metas.description:
A small part of the E75 and the A1 also have planted trees in the median.

As mentioned, trees can also be seen on E-65 between Tetovo and Skopje. To distinguish between these roads, the E-65 is much more mountainous than the A1.

metas.title: E75 Sloped Hill Median
metas.description: For a section of the E-75 between Skopje and Kumanovo, there is a large sloped hill in between the lanes.

metas.title: E75 Single Guardrail Median
metas.description: Most of the E-75 next to the Greek Border has only one guardrail separating each lane. Some parts have a guardrail on one side and concrete median on the other. These are both only found on this highway.

metas.title: Obituary Posters
metas.description:
Each city has its own city-specific posters with public obituaries. They are commonly found on utility poles.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Kumanovo Obituaries
metas.description: Obituaries in Kumanovo are the most distinct. They are the only obituaries to have a thick light blue border.

metas.title: Bitola Obituaries
metas.description: Obituaries in Bitola are horizontal and can be either light or dark blue. The cross is in-between the border, leaving a gap in the rectangle.

metas.title: Ohrid Obituaries
metas.description: Obituaries in Ohrid are horizontal and either red or blue. The cross is underneath the border, which is unique to Ohrid when the obituary is red.

metas.title: Strumica Obituaries
metas.description: Obituaries in Strumica are vertical and blue. They are the only obituaries to have an intricate pattern in the corner of the poster.

metas.title: Veles Obituaries
metas.description: Obituaries in Veles are vertical and blue. Veles has the largest variety of obituaries, but will never have the pattern in the corner like the ones seen in Strumica. They are also the only city that will have the cross above the border when blue.

metas.title: Prilep Obituaries
metas.description: Obituaries in Prilep are vertical and black. The border does not go completely around the poster, which makes it easy to distinguish.

metas.title: Tetovo Obituaries
metas.description: Obituaries in Tetovo are vertical and black. There are 2 main types found in the city, one with the cross above the border and one with a thick cross in-between the border.

metas.title: Strumica Kerbs
metas.description:
If you see black and yellow striped kerbs, you are most likely to be in Strumica.

They are rarely found in Skopje and if you see them around roundabouts, you will most likely be in Tetovo.

metas.title: Ohrid Lake
metas.description: Ohrid is the only large city located next to a lake.

metas.title: Prilep Street Lamps
metas.description: These long rectangular lamps are only found in the city of Prilep.

metas.title: Prilep Rocky Hills
metas.description: These two extremely rocky hills are visible in some parts of the city of Prilep.

metas.title: Mountainous Landscape
metas.description: Norway is a very mountainous country, with many fjords along most of the coast.
metas.note: Finland and Denmark are both mostly flat, while Sweden has a mixture of flat, hilly and mountainous areas.

metas.title: Wooden Houses
metas.description: The vast majority of Norwegian houses are made of wood. Many houses are painted red, which is also typical for Sweden and Finland. Black painted houses are also quite common, more so than in Sweden or Finland.
metas.note: While the architecture is very similar to that of Sweden and Finland, there are some small, general differences. Sweden and Finland generally have more red and yellow houses, while Norway generally has more white houses. There is also a larger percentage of wooden houses in suburbs and near town centres in Norway than in Sweden and Finland, which use more brick than Norway.

metas.title: License Plates (Green Commercial)
metas.description:
Norway has long white licence plates with the standard European strip on the left.

Commercial plates are green. These are often seen on vans.
metas.note: Within Europe, green licence plates are most commonly seen in Norway, but can also be found on electric vehicles in several other countries.

metas.title: Road Lines (Long Dashes)
metas.description: Smaller Norwegian roads typically have long dashed white outer lines, while larger roads have solid outer lines and yellow middle lines. The yellow lines have a distinct tinge of orange.
metas.note: Sweden only has white road lines, and the dashes on outer lines are shorter than in Norway. Finnish outer road lines are always solid, and middle lines can be yellow or white.

metas.title: Dotted Road Lines
metas.description: Road lines will often be made up of small dots of paint.

metas.title: Language Characters
metas.description: The Norwegian language contains the special letters Æ, Ø and Å.
metas.note:
The special letters found in Norwegian can also be found in some of the other Northern Germanic languages:

Danish uses Æ, Ø and Å.

Swedish uses Å, but not Æ or Ø. Norwegian also uses more E’s than Swedish, while Swedish uses more A’s instead. Norwegian uses “kk” where Swedish uses “ck”.

Icelandic uses Æ, but not Ø or Å.

Finnish uses Å, although it is viewed as a Swedish letter.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Norway uses thin, curved rectangular bollards with the reflector inside of a black parallelogram.

metas.title: Orange Snow Poles
metas.description: Norwegian snow poles are typically orange, with a fairly thin white reflector. The reflector is normally toward the middle of the pole.
metas.note: Swedish snow poles typically have a wider reflector slightly higher up, and Finnish snow poles have their reflector at the very top.

metas.title: Painted Wooden Snow Poles
metas.description: It is also fairly common to find thin wooden snow poles with painted reflectors.
metas.note: While wooden snow poles can be found in other Nordic countries, they will typically not have reflectors.

metas.title: Wooden Guardrail Posts
metas.description: Guardrails often have wooden posts.
metas.note: This is not common in Sweden or Finland.

metas.title: Pedestrian Sign
metas.description: Norwegian pedestrian signs typically have four stripes and a very simply drawn person. Note however, that there is a version with five stripes and a version where the person is more detailed and wearing a hat.
metas.note: While Finnish pedestrian signs have five stripes, Swedish pedestrian signs have four stripes. However, the person on Swedish signs is detailed, but without a hat.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Norwegian directional signs are yellow with a black border. You will commonly see the road number displayed, either in a green box for European highways and major roads, or in a white box, for smaller roads.

metas.title: Meeting Point Sign (M)
metas.description: On smaller roads, it is common to see these blue signs with a large white M.
metas.note: Similar signs can be found in Sweden, however the font is distinctly different. The middle point of the M does not extend to the bottom of the letter. There are no similar signs in Finland.

metas.title: Bus Stop Sign
metas.description: Norwegian bus stops usually have this small, blue sign with a white bus.
metas.note: Sweden has a lot of different bus stops, none of which look like this.

metas.title: Zone Signs (Sone)
metas.description: White signs with the text “Sone”, generally featuring a speed limit, are common in urban areas.

metas.title: Street Name Suffixes
metas.description: The most common street name suffixes in Norway are vei and gate. While attached to the name, they take the forms -veien and -gata or -gate.
metas.note: Swedish street names use the suffixes väg or vägen and gata or gatan, where gata is always detached from the name. Danish uses vej and gade.

metas.title: Street Sign Position
metas.description: Street signs will generally be centred on top of sign posts.
metas.note: Street signs in Sweden will normally be attached either to the side of sign posts or lamp posts.

metas.title: Red Outline Traffic Signs
metas.description: Norwegian traffic signs have a red outline and a white background.
metas.note: Both Swedish and Finnish road signs have a yellow background.

metas.title: Yellow Construction Signs
metas.description: You can also find these road construction signs, with a bright yellow background.

metas.title: Sign Bolt Pattern
metas.description: Most smaller road signs will be attached with four visible sign bolts in the shape of a tall rectangle. Beware that you may occasionally find framed signs instead, particularly in urban settings.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description: Norway uses yellow on black chevrons.

metas.title: Road Number/Distance Sign
metas.description:
Small white square signs, displaying the road number on top, and the distance to the closest town, are common to see along medium sized roads.

The road number will be preceded either by an R or an F. F roads show up as Fv on the map and are generally difficult to locate, while R roads lack any letters on the map and are generally more findable.

metas.title: Wooden Poles with Metal Cap
metas.description: Norwegian poles are normally wooden and often have a small black metal cap on the top.
metas.note: This metal cap is also common in both Sweden and Finland.

metas.title: Street Lamp Bolting
metas.description: Lamps attached to wooden poles in Norway are normally mounted to the pole with a thick single bolting.
metas.note: Sweden and Finland use double bolting.

metas.title: Grass Roofs
metas.description: Traditional houses in Norway commonly have grass covered roofs.
metas.note: This is far less common in Sweden and Finland.

metas.title: Smallcam Coverage
metas.description: Norway has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.
metas.note: Most of Northern Europe also has smallcam.

metas.title: Road Number Zones
metas.description:
The first digit of Norwegian road numbers are region dependent. Note that there are some exceptions among single and two-digit roads.

There are also a small number of roads beginning with a 9: Road 9, going north of Kristiansand, and a couple of two-digit roads in the far north.
metas.note: Regional roads starting with “Fv” do not follow this pattern.

metas.title: Bilingual Sami Signs
metas.description:
Bilingual signs with Sámi can be found in several northern areas in Norway. While the Sámi languages are very different from Norwegian, the best way to recognize them are the letters Á, Đ and the use of several vowels in a row, something which is uncommon in Norwegian.

Note that not all signs in these areas will be bilingual.

metas.title: Bracken Ferns
metas.description: This species of fern (Pteridium aquilinum, also known as bracken) which typically has a fairly tall stem and many wide leafs branching out, is mostly found in the south of Norway. Beware that other species of ferns can be found further north.

metas.title: Spruce Forests
metas.description: Spruces are mainly found in the southern half of the country, particularly in the southeast and around Trondheim.

metas.title: Pine Forests
metas.description: Pines are most common in coastal and far inland areas in the southern half of the country.

metas.title: Oak Trees
metas.description: Oaks are mainly found in the far south of Norway.

metas.title: Maple Trees
metas.description: Maples are mainly found in the south, particularly by the farmlands around Oslo.

metas.title: Coloured Moss
metas.description: Brightly coloured moss is common to find in the area between Lillehammer and Oppdal.

metas.title: Farmlands Overview
metas.description:
Large farmlands are mainly found in three areas, the southeast, the area surrounding Trondheim, and south of Stavanger.

The following clues will explain how to differentiate between the three.

metas.title: Oslo Farmlands
metas.description: The largest concentration of farmland is found in the southeast, in the general vicinity of Oslo. The area is much flatter than most of the country, and it is common to get a rolling landscape with smooth, round forested hills in the distance. The area southeast of Oslo is particularly flat.

metas.title: Trondheim Farmlands
metas.description: The farmlands surrounding Trondheim are generally very hilly, and the hills are typically both steeper and more uneven than in the southeast.

metas.title: Jaeren Farmlands
metas.description: Similarly to the southeast, the farmland south of Stavanger is flatter than most of the country. However, the fields look more vast and open, and it is very common to see rock walls made of large, round rocks. Furthermore, rather than crops, most fields will only contain grass.

metas.title: Western Fjords
metas.description: While fjords can be found along most of the Norwegian coast, deep fjords surrounded by tall mountains are most common between Bergen and Trondheim.

metas.title: Lofoten Landscape
metas.description: Distinct, sharp, rocky mountains with few trees can be seen on the Lofoten Archipelago.

metas.title: Northern Birch Vegetation
metas.description: The northeast of Norway can typically be recognized by a somewhat rolling landscape, rather than tall mountains, and vegetation mainly consisting of very small birches combined with patched grass.

metas.title: Southwestern Highlands
metas.description: Barren highlands, with no trees or bushes, and often with rocky mountains along the road, are mostly found in the southwest.

metas.title: Rocky Coast
metas.description: Exposed rock, often spotted with small coastal pines and bushes, are mainly found on the south coast.

metas.title: Northern Coastal Grasslands
metas.description: Coastal grasslands with little to no other vegetation and only somewhat low, distant mountains can be found by coastal roads in the far north.

metas.title: Southern White Houses
metas.description: While completely white wooden houses can be found in the entire country, they’re especially common on the southern coast, where you’ll commonly see entire villages made up of them.

metas.title: Black Snow Poles
metas.description: Black snow poles are most commonly found between Bergen and Trondheim.

metas.title: Southeastern Pole Plates (Small)
metas.description: Small, wide black pole plates, with a single line of letters and digits, can be found in southeastern Norway.

metas.title: Rusty Guardrails
metas.description: Almost exclusively found in coastal regions, and particularly on the southern half of the west coast.

metas.title: Svalbard
metas.description:
Svalbard is an unincorporated archipelago within the Norwegian Kingdom.

A separate Plonk It guide to Svalbard can be found here.

metas.title: Oslo Pole Plates (Large)
metas.description: Fairly large black or red pole plates can be found in Oslo.

metas.title: Stavanger Lamp Stripes
metas.description: Two red stripes going around lamp posts are commonly found in Stavanger.

metas.title: Bergen Fire Hydrants
metas.description: You can find this specific design of green fire hydrants in Bergen.

metas.title: Russian Border Road
metas.description: Along the Russian border you can see this noticeably humid and green-looking road, with very overcast and occasionally foggy coverage. The trees are somewhat low and mainly consist of thin birches and pines.

metas.title: Russian Signs
metas.description: Russian can sometimes be seen alongside Norwegian on signs near the Russian border. It is mostly found on roads E6 and E105 near Kirkenes.

metas.title: Røros Wooden Architecture
metas.description: The old mining town of Røros can be recognised by the densely built traditional wooden architecture.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Poland has long white plates with the standard European blue strip on the left.
metas.note: Newer electric vehicles have green plates.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Polish bollards have a red strip that wraps all the way around the bollard. This strip has a red reflector on the front (sometimes hard to see), and a white reflector on the back. Bollards sometimes have numbers on them.
metas.note: The same design can be found in Zakarpattia Oblast in Ukraine.

metas.title: Holey Utility Poles
metas.description:
Poland usually has thin concrete utility poles with see-through holes. They are commonly known as “holey poles”. The holes often do not extend all the way to the bottom of the pole.

Sometimes, two poles are joined together, or put in an A-frame shape. You can also find round concrete poles.
metas.note: Hungary and Romania also have holey poles, but these are wider and more bulky. In addition, the holes extend all the way to the bottom.

metas.title: Road Lines
metas.description: Poland has all-white road lines. Double middle lines are very common and usually a good clue for Poland.
metas.note: Some other European countries, most notably Denmark and Greece, can have double middle lines.

metas.title: Guardrails
metas.description: Poland has square (normal B-type) guardrails, with circular red reflectors.
metas.note: Poland is one of only a very few European countries with this type of guardrail. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: Warning Signs
metas.description: Warning signs are triangular and have a yellow background and a distinct thin red border.
metas.note: In Europe, this combination of a yellow background with a thin red border is unique to Poland.

metas.title: Prohibitory Signs
metas.description: However, prohibitory signs are round and have a white background with a thicker red border.

metas.title: Pedestrian Sign
metas.description: Poland has a unique pedestrian sign. Instead of the usual zebra stripes, it just has a single horizontal line.
metas.note: Austria and Belgium also have horizontal lines, but they use two lines instead of Poland’s single line.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Regular Polish direction signs have a green background. These signs use a distinct font, which is a good clue for Poland.
metas.note: Signs on expressways have a blue background.

metas.title: Town Entry Signs
metas.description: Poland has two town entry signs: a green one with the locality’s name, and a white-and-black one with a stylized urban area.
metas.note: Like direction signs, town entry signs use a distinct font.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description: Polish chevrons are white with red arrows.

metas.title: Language Characters
metas.description:
Polish is a Slavic language. In contrast to other slavic languages, the Polish alphabet includes:

Ł with a stroke through it (unique to Polish)

Ą and Ę with a small hook (also found in Lithuanian)

Ć, Ń, Ó, Ś, Ź with an acute accent. Of these, Ń is unique to Polish. In addition, the only other language with Ś and Ź is Montenegrin.

Ż with a small dot (unique to Polish)

Polish is very consonant-heavy, with lots of consonant clusters. Polish does not use V. Instead, it uses W a lot, the only Slavic language to do so. Other unusually common consonants are the Z, K, and C.

metas.title: Landscape Overview
metas.description: Poland is generally a flat country, with occasional rolling hills. The country is very green, with a lot of agriculture, and some amount of forest cover.
metas.note: Mountains can be found near the southern border.

metas.title: Tree-Lined Roads
metas.description: Many roads in Poland are lined by rows of trees.

metas.title: Tiled Sidewalks
metas.description: Neatly tiled sidewalks are very common in Poland. Tiles are often grey or light red. Occasionally, even roads have tiled pavement. Many different types of tile patterns occur, including larger square tiles.

metas.title: Architecture Overview
metas.description:
Polish architecture is fairly similar to other Central European countries. Buildings usually have plain stone walls covered in light or pastel stucco. Frequent roofing colours are orange or red, black, and brown. Roof tiles and panes often have a tidy, almost plastic-like look. Some rural houses have corrugated sheet roofs similar to those often found in the Baltics.

Detached single family homes are common throughout Poland. They sometimes have a blocky look.

In bigger towns, apartment buildings are common. Many date from communist times, and some of them still have a somewhat austere look. However, many have been renovated and look nice and well-kept.

Downtown areas are usually dense and often have historic buildings.

metas.title: Catholic Shrines
metas.description: Poland is one of the most Catholic countries in Europe. You can often find Christian shrines on the side of roads. Blue-white and yellow-white Polish Catholic flags also sometimes appear.

metas.title: Gen 4 Black Car (Rare)
metas.description: A black generation 4 Google car can rarely be found in Poland.
metas.note: It can also be found in many other European countries.

metas.title: Gen 4 White Car (Rare)
metas.description: A white generation 4 Google car can also rarely be found in Poland.
metas.note: It can also be found in other European countries.

metas.title: 3-Digit Road Numbers
metas.description:
Regional roads have 3-digit road numbers. These numbers often appear in yellow boxes on direction signs. The first digit is usually region-specific, as there is a high level of geographic clustering of these road numbers.

There is some overlap between numbers near the margins of the regions. Some exceptions also exist.
metas.note: This tip only applies to 3-digit roads. Bigger roads with 2-digit road numbers mostly do not adhere to this geographic pattern.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description: Polish landline phone numbers have 9 digits. The first 2 digits are the area code. These area codes are distributed in a sensible manner across the country. Even just learning the first digit of the area codes can greatly narrow down the region. You can click on the infographic to enlarge it.
metas.note: Mobile numbers also have 9 digits, but luckily there is no overlap between the first two digits of mobile numbers and landlines.

metas.title: Place Name Suffixes
metas.description: When it comes to Polish place names, the -owo ending is mostly limited to the northern half of the country, and the -ów ending mostly to the southern half. You may also encounter -ino or -yno, mainly in the northwest, and -ew near the centre of the country.
metas.note: A good way to remember this is that Kraków is in the south of Poland, and most other towns ending in -ów are too.

metas.title: Minority Languages
metas.description:
While rare, bilingual signs can be found in the highlighted regions.

Kashubian, found in the north, is another West Slavic Language, featuring a lot of umlauts and accents.

Wszëtczi lëdze rodzą sã wòlny ë równy w swòji czëstnoce ë swòjich prawach. Mają òni dostóne rozëm ë sëmienié ë nôlégô jima pòstãpòwac wobec drëdzich w dëchù bracënotë.

German is mostly found in the Opole Voivodeship.

Lithuanian can be found around Puńsk, near the Lithuanian border.

Belarusian is found near the Belarusian border.

Lemko, another Cyrillic language, can be found in the southeast.
