metas.title: Southern Mountains
metas.description: Even though most of Poland is flat, the southern border area is very hilly. Some parts even have mountains.
metas.note: Some other areas in Poland are somewhat hilly, but the south has by far the most amount of significant elevation.

metas.title: Eastern Wooden Houses
metas.description: Traditional wooden houses are commonly found in the east, mainly in Podlaskie Voivodeship.

metas.title: Yellow Pole Markings
metas.description:
Electricity poles with yellow markings are predominantly found in western and southern Poland.

For more detailed information on Polish utility poles, including the markings and lamps discussed here, see this document.

metas.title: Black Pole Markings
metas.description: Black pole markings are most commonly seen in the southeast of the country, as well as some areas in the north.

metas.title: White Pole Markings
metas.description: Markings with a white background are most commonly found in Podlaskie voivodeship, and can occasionally be seen in Łódź voivodeship and elsewhere.

metas.title: Top-Mounted Street Lamps
metas.description: Street lamps mounted on top of the pole become more common towards the northeast of the country, with some pockets in the far south.

metas.title: Side-Mounted Street Lamps
metas.description: In contrast, lamps attached to the side of the pole are rarely found in the northeast.

metas.title: Tatra Mountains
metas.description: The Tatra Mountains are the highest mountains in Poland. They can be found near Zakopane, on the border with Slovakia.

metas.title: Gdańsk Architecture
metas.description: Gdańsk is a large city in northwestern Poland. Its historic downtown features unique buildings that were inspired by Dutch Golden Age architecture. These buildings look somewhat similar to Amsterdam.

metas.title: Hel Peninsula Road
metas.description: The main road on the Hel peninsula is very recognizable: it is a coastal forest road with a railway track running parallel to it.

metas.title: Białystok Street Signs
metas.description: Białystok uses turquoise street signs, with the district marked on the bottom.

metas.title: Szczecin Street Signs
metas.description: Szczecin uses colourful green and blue signs. The city district is marked on the bottom.

metas.title: Poznań Street Signs
metas.description: Street signs in Poznań are mainly black, with the district being marked on the blue section at the bottom.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description:
Portuguese plates are long and white, with a blue strip on the left. Most plates have a yellow strip on the right, which is unique to Portugal. 

The yellow strip was discontinued in 2020, so in Generation 4 coverage you may sometimes see plates with just the blue strip.

metas.title: Language Characters
metas.description: Portuguese is a Romance language that is closely related to Spanish. Unlike Spanish, Portuguese includes the letters Ç, Ã, Õ, Â, and Ê, while it does not include the letter Ñ, which is very common in Spanish.
metas.note: You can also find Ç in Catalan.

metas.title: Eucalyptus Trees
metas.description: Eucalyptus trees are very common in Portugal. The only other part of Europe where you’ll commonly see eucalyptus is northern Spain.

metas.title: Rua (Road)
metas.description: The Portuguese word for road is ‘Rua’.
metas.note: In Galician, the word for road is ‘Rúa’, with an accent on the ‘u’.

metas.title: Ladder Poles
metas.description: Concrete ladder poles, with very tall ladder steps, are common in Portugal. Each step often has a small see-through hole.
metas.note: In Spain and France you will commonly see ladder poles with short steps.

metas.title: Hunting Signs
metas.description: Hunting signs with a red and white colour scheme are a common sight in rural areas. They are either diamond shaped or rectangular.
metas.note: In contrast, Spanish hunting signs are white and black.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Portuguese bollards are either wedge-shaped with a noticeably thin white top, or flat with a wide reflector. While most reflectors will be white, you may also find orange reflectors. These are noticeably darker than the yellow reflectors in Spain.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Directional signs are generally white, with black arrows that are not touching the borders of the sign.
metas.note: Spanish directional signs will typically feature the road number in colourful boxes and do not have a black arrow, other than a thin black border.

metas.title: Kilometre Markers
metas.description: Most kilometre markers are wide rectangles with a coloured section on the left side divided diagonally from the white part. Every kilometre you will find a larger square sign with a coloured top half featuring the road number.

metas.title: Waystones
metas.description: Black and white waystones can commonly be found in Portugal.

metas.title: Stop Signs (Large Font)
metas.description: Stop signs in Portugal feature a fairly large font.
metas.note: This is mostly useful to distinguish it from Spain, where stop signs have a distinctly small and compact font.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description: Portuguese chevrons are black with yellow arrows.
metas.note: Portugal is the only Mediterranean country with this chevron colour scheme.

metas.title: Pedestrian Sign
metas.description: Pedestrian signs have five stripes, and the person is wearing a belt, which is noticeably high.
metas.note: Spanish pedestrian signs have eight stripes, Italian signs don't have a belt and Greek signs have two dotted lines instead of stripes.

metas.title: Guardrails
metas.description: Portugal uses A-type guardrails with red reflectors.
metas.note: This is mostly useful to tell apart Portugal and Spain, which uses yellow reflectors.

metas.title: White Bordered Signs
metas.description: Portuguese road signs are typically encased by a white border.
metas.note: Most Spanish signs don’t have a white border.

metas.title: Cobblestone Roads
metas.description: Cobblestone roads are very common in Portugal. These will typically be made of square cobblestones arranged diagonally compared to the road direction.

metas.title: Cobblestone Sidewalks
metas.description: Similarly, cobblestone sidewalks made of distinctly bright stones are very common.

metas.title: White Stone Houses
metas.description: White painted stone houses with orange tiled roofs are extremely common in Portugal.

metas.title: House Trim Colours
metas.description: You’ll commonly see blue or yellow lines painted around windows and doors, as well as around the edges of walls.

metas.title: Tiled House Facades
metas.description: Houses made of decorative mosaic tiles are somewhat common in Portugal.

metas.title: Smallcam Coverage
metas.description: Portugal has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description:
The first three digits of Portuguese landlines make up the area codes, which are distributed as seen on the map. Phone codes not starting with a 2 are not regional, and codes starting with 29 will either be the Azores or Madeira.

For a complete list of the third digits, see this page.

metas.title: Decorative Chimneys
metas.description: In the Faro district in the south of Portugal you will very commonly come across decorative chimneys, which will either be round or square shaped with small spire-shaped tops. The round chimneys are a particularly strong clue.

metas.title: Concrete Block Houses
metas.description: Houses in northern Portugal are often made of square concrete blocks, which are commonly put together with white mortar.
metas.note: Very similar architecture, but typically without the white mortar, is commonly found over the border in Galicia.

metas.title: Oak Fields
metas.description: Open fields sparsely populated with holm oaks (Quercus ilex) and cork oaks (Quercus suber) are very common in the southeast. These species of oaks tend to be on the smaller side, and have a Mediterranean look. While these fields will look quite dry during summer and fall, they will look much lusher during spring.

metas.title: Olive Plantations
metas.description: Olive plantations are generally more common in the eastern half of the country, particularly in the far northeast and slight southeast.
metas.note: The easiest way to tell apart the olive plantations from the oak fields from the last tip is to look at the pattern in which they’re planted. Olive plantations are typically planted in dense rows, while the oaks are planted more sparsely and not in an obvious pattern.

metas.title: Eucalyptus Forests
metas.description: Dense eucalyptus forests are mostly found in the northwest.

metas.title: Maritime Pine Forests
metas.description: Forests, or plantations of Maritime pines (Pinus Pinaster) are very common in the northern half of Portugal. You can recognize the tree by its grey bark with red undertones, and fluffy branches that point upwards. Older trees often don’t have any branches in the bottom half of the tree.
metas.note: Plantations of this pine are also common in northern Spain, particularly Galicia.

metas.title: Terraced Vineyards
metas.description: In the Douro wine region, straight east of Porto, you will commonly find steep terraced vineyards.

metas.title: Citrus Plantations
metas.description: Citrus plantations are mostly found along the south coast.

metas.title: Islands Overview
metas.description:
The islands of Madeira and the Azores are found southwest and west of mainland Portugal respectively. For country streak purposes they are both counted as Portugal.

Plonk It has more in-depth guides to Madeira here and a guide to the Azores here.

metas.title: Serra da Estrela
metas.description: The Serra da Estrela natural park can be recognised by the rocky mountainous highland landscape, often combined with yellow and black striped snow poles.

metas.title: Sandy Pine Forests
metas.description: Pine forests with extremely sandy white soil can be found near the coast between the cities of Setúbal and Sines.

metas.title: Southwest Landscape
metas.description: In the far southwest of the country you can find a flat uncultivated landscape with very limited vegetation, which typically appears quite dry. There are almost no trees nearby, and only very low bushes and grass.

metas.title: Porto Street Signs
metas.description: Lime green street signs can be found in Porto.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Romania uses standard long, white European plates with a single blue strip on the left.

metas.title: Language Characters
metas.description:
Romanian is a Romance language similar to Italian, containing the following special letters:

Ă ă

Ș ș

Ț ț

These letters are also found in some other European languages:

Â â, used in French, Portuguese and Turkish

Î î, used in French, Turkish and Italian

metas.title: Holey Utility Poles
metas.description: The most common types of utility poles in Romania are holey poles with the holes going all the way to the bottom. The holes are typically either quite wide or quite tall.
metas.note: Poland and Hungary also both use holey poles. Polish holey poles do not have holes near the bottom and Hungarian holey poles generally have smaller holes than in Romania.

metas.title: Round Concrete Poles
metas.description: Round concrete poles are also quite common.
metas.note: These are very similar to poles found in Bulgaria.

metas.title: White-Painted Trunks
metas.description: Trees and poles will often have white painted bottoms.
metas.note: This is also common in Ukraine and parts of Russia.

metas.title: Yellow Pole Stickers
metas.description:
This type of extremely large yellow pole sticker is specific to Romania.

Beware that smaller stickers are also common and that both Bulgaria and Hungary can have similar ones.
metas.note: The town or city name will typically be written close to the middle of these stickers. In this case Podu Iloaiei is written.

metas.title: Triangle Pole Top
metas.description: Two support bars holding up the metal bar on pole tops, resembling an upside down triangle, can sometimes be found in Romania.
metas.note: Czechia, Slovakia, Albania and Serbia also feature this pole top.

metas.title: Waystones
metas.description: It is very common to see waystones in Romania. They are typically fairly large, with red or blue framing with the road number on the side, or made of actual stone and somewhat rugged-looking. There is also a very small variant which is all white.

metas.title: Road Lines (Short Dashes)
metas.description: While there are many types of roadlines in Romania, these outer lines, consisting of short dashes with narrow spaces, can be a good clue for the country.

metas.title: Thick Middle Lines
metas.description: Middle lines are often noticeably thicker than average. This is especially useful to tell Romania apart from Bulgaria, which generally has thinner road lines.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Romanian directional signs are blue, arrow shaped, and have a white border. They will very often display the road number, which can be either red or blue.

metas.title: Town Entry Signs
metas.description: The most common type of town entry sign in Romania is a yellow sign displaying a speed limit and a city skyline, with a white sign displaying the town name below.
metas.note: The upper sign can also either be white or completely absent.

metas.title: Black Sign Backs
metas.description: Romanian sign backs are often black.
metas.note: This is also common in Italy, Albania and Germany.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description: Romanian chevrons are red on white, often with a yellow frame.
metas.note: Several eastern and central European countries have the red on white chevrons, however yellow frames are by far the most common in Romania.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Romanian bollards are thin and white, with a red vertical strip near the top. It is worth noting that bollards in Romania are somewhat rare.
metas.note: Turkey has a very similar bollard.

metas.title: Thick Border Yield Sign
metas.description: This yield sign, with an extremely thick red border, with a thin white outline, is unique to Romania. Beware that different yield signs also exist in Romania.

metas.title: Architecture Overview
metas.description: Romanian architecture primarily consists of single-family houses made of stone, typically painted in different pastel colours and with roofs ranging from orange tiles to grey metal. It is also somewhat common to see houses with walls made of painted square tiles in different patterns.

metas.title: Landscape Overview
metas.description: The Romanian landscape ranges from tall forested mountains and hills in the centre to flat or rolling agricultural landscapes in the south, west and east.

metas.title: Haystacks
metas.description: This type of haystack, typically featuring a stick going straight through, is very common in Romania.

metas.title: Dacia Cars
metas.description: Dacia is the most common car brand in Romania, making up more than a quarter of all vehicles in the country.
metas.note: No other eastern European country has more than 10% Dacias.

metas.title: Elevation Map
metas.description: This is an elevation map of Romania. The tallest mountains are found in the middle and north of the country, while the south and west are particularly flat.

metas.title: Southern/Western Plains
metas.description: Completely flat agricultural landscapes can be found in the south and west.
metas.note: If you can see distant hills or mountains to the north, you are likely in the south, and if you see them to the south or east, you are likely in the west.

metas.title: Western Tiled Roofs
metas.description: If you see several houses and almost all of them have orange tiled roofs, you are likely to be in the western half of the country.

metas.title: Eastern Metal Roofs
metas.description: Similarly, if you see several houses and almost all of them have metal or plastic fake tiled roofs, you will probably be in the eastern half of the country.

metas.title: Hungarian Border Villages
metas.description: Villages near the Hungarian border will often be built in the same style as villages in Hungary. This style can be summarised as having long, straight streets with single-storey houses being evenly spaced along the road, typically having the short side of the house facing the road. The vast majority of roofs will have orange tiles.

metas.title: Moldovan Border Valleys
metas.description: South of Iași, near the border to Moldova, you can find rolling agricultural valleys with a very specific north-north-west to south-south-east angle.
metas.note: Make sure to look for agricultural fields on top of the hills to confirm this region.

metas.title: Bilingual Hungarian Signs
metas.description: Bilingual signs with Hungarian are mostly found in the central regions of Covasna, Harghita and Mureş, but also less commonly near the Hungarian border.

metas.title: Maramureș Wooden Gates
metas.description: Elaborately decorated wooden gates are commonly found in the region of Maramureș.

metas.title: Sunflower Fields
metas.description: Sunflowers are primarily found in the far east of the country, and secondly in the far west.

metas.title: City Street Signs
metas.description: Several Romanian cities and towns have unique street signs. This infographic covers all with a population above 100 000.

metas.title: Road 67C
metas.description: The 67C is a mountain road with all yellow road lines.

metas.title: Road 7C
metas.description: The 7C is recognisable as going through some of the most dramatic mountains in Romania. The highest point on the road is right by the border between Sibiu and Argeș.

metas.title: Sibiu Eye Windows
metas.description: This type of window, shaped like a squinting eye, is most commonly found in the city of Sibiu.

metas.title: Brașov Gen 2 Hills
metas.description: If you see a mountainous landscape in Generation 2, you are likely close to Brașov.

metas.title: Bucharest Gen 2 Flats
metas.description: Flat landscapes in Generation 2 are mostly found near Bucharest.

metas.title: Danube Delta Boat
metas.description: A boat trekker, with a green boat, can be found in the far east of the country. It mostly goes through small, overgrown canals in a flat landscape.
metas.note: There is no road coverage in this region.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Russian licence plates are fully white with black text.
metas.note: Most European counterparts will feature a blue strip on the left hand side.

metas.title: Language Characters
metas.description:
The Russian language uses the Cyrillic script, and contains the special letters Ы, Э, Ё and Ъ.

Ё is also used in Mongolian and Ъ is used in Bulgarian.
metas.note: You may rarely come across Russian in both Ukraine and eastern Estonia.

metas.title: Ulitsa (Street)
metas.description: The Russian word for street is улица (ulitsa), sometimes abbreviated ул. (ul.).
metas.note: Bulgarian and most other Slavic languages also use улица / ulica. The Ukrainian word however is вулиця (vulytsya), abbreviated вул. (vul.).

metas.title: Gorod (City)
metas.description: The Russian word for city is город (gorod), abbreviated г. (g.).
metas.note: The Ukrainian word is місто (misto), abbreviated м. (m.).

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Russia has three main types of bollards: a very thin type being attached to a stick, one with a black top section and a red vertical reflector below and a German-style bollard.

metas.title: Intersection Bollards
metas.description: Near intersections in Russia you will commonly see a very large number of bollards.

metas.title: Wide Intersections
metas.description: Along with containing a large number of bollards, many intersections are unusually wide compared to other countries.

metas.title: Black Painted Pole Base
metas.description: Signposts in Russia often have black painted bottoms.
metas.note: This is also common in Kazakhstan.

metas.title: Pole Support Blocks
metas.description: You can often see concrete support blocks at the bottom of utility poles, with wooden poles often being raised above ground by the support.
metas.note: Similar blocks are found in several Central and Eastern European countries.

metas.title: Pedestrian Sign
metas.description: Russian pedestrian signs have a simply drawn person and three stripes. Signs will commonly have a bright yellow border.
metas.note: Ukraine, Lithuania, Mongolia, Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan use the same design.

metas.title: Zebra Crossings
metas.description: Russian pedestrian crossings contain alternating white and yellow stripes.
metas.note: This is also common in Kazakhstan.

metas.title: Striped Barriers
metas.description: Black and white striped guardrails, kerbs and bridge barriers are common in russia.

metas.title: Gen 3 Antenna Cars
metas.description: Three Generation 3 Street View cars are commonly found in Russia. The two most useful ones for recognising Russia are a black and a white car, both with a long antenna. You may also see a short antenna without a visible car.

metas.title: Urban Apartments
metas.description: The vast majority of urban housing in Russia are large rectangular apartment buildings made of simple concrete. Newer buildings in wealthier areas appear more modern.

metas.title: Rural Wooden Houses
metas.description: Rural housing in Russia consists mostly of a basic wooden structure with metal roofs.

metas.title: Decorated Window Frames
metas.description: This style of richly decorated window frames is commonly found on traditional Russian homes, especially on log cabins. They are often painted blue.

metas.title: Pole Shields
metas.description: Black & white-striped pole shields are common along highways, especially in European Russia.

metas.title: Birch Trees
metas.description: Birch trees, identified by their white peeling bark, have a wide range in Russia. Notably they are almost never found far south or far north in the western part of the country.

metas.title: Eastern Birch Forests
metas.description: Birches very close together, as well as forests consisting of only birches, are indicative of areas east of the Urals, most commonly between Chelyabinsk Oblast and Novosibirsk Oblast.

metas.title: Siberian Larches
metas.description: Siberian larches are one of the dominant tree species in much of eastern Russia, recognized by their unique needle-like leaves. Generally speaking, they become more prevalent the further east you go in the country, as well as at high elevations.

metas.title: Sakhalin Butterbur
metas.description: Giant butterbur (commonly referred to as Sakhalin cabbage) is very common in Sakhalin Oblast, particularly in the southern half. Related plants can very rarely be found in Adygea.

metas.title: Hogweed
metas.description: This type of white flower (heracleum sosnowskyi) is most commonly found around Moscow, Komi Republic, and Perm Krai.

metas.title: Fireweed
metas.description: Large amounts of the pink or red flower fireweed (Chamaenerion angustifolium) typically indicates a northern region of Russia. Similarly, most places north of Moscow commonly have fireweed.

metas.title: Sunflower Fields
metas.description: Sunflowers are common along the border with Ukraine as well as more eastern oblasts like Ulyanovsk, Samara, and northern Orenburg.

metas.title: Blue-pod Lupines
metas.description: Blue-pod lupines appear very commonly in northern Vladimir Oblast, eastern Ivanovo Oblast, and southwestern Kostroma Oblast. It can also be found less commonly elsewhere in Kirov Oblast and towards the Baltics.

metas.title: Black Poplar
metas.description: The black poplar is commonly found south, near the border with Ukraine, as well as toward the western border with Kazakhstan.

metas.title: Russian Olive
metas.description: The Russian olive is typically found along the Kazakhstan border.

metas.title: Kaliningrad Trunks
metas.description: Lined oak trees, often with a single white stripe around the trunk, are extremely common in Kaliningrad.

metas.title: Tatarstan Larches
metas.description: Sparsely planted larches along the road with open rolling fields is common in Tatarstan and adjacent federal subjects.

metas.title: Sandy Roadsides
metas.description: Sandy roadsides are common in Khanty-Mansi and Yamalo-Nenets and adjacent subjects, as well as areas around Nizhny Novgorod on the Volga river. Other notable areas are Karelia, Murmansk, and western Sakha. Beware, however, that sandy roadsides can less commonly be found near rivers in other regions.

metas.title: Red Soil
metas.description: Red soil is common in the highlighted areas, notably around Izhevsk and Perm, much of Arkhangelsk Oblast, Leningrad Oblast, and Pskov Oblast, and near Volgograd and Astrakhan. Note that this map is by no means exhaustive; red soil can be found almost anywhere in the country near water or iron mines.

metas.title: Kamchatka Soil
metas.description: The Kamchatka peninsula has unique grey gravelly soil, as well as the largest number of volcanoes of any region in Russia. They are frequently seen across the peninsula, and in some places can appear quite close such as in Klyuchi.

metas.title: Yakutsk Gravel Soil
metas.description: Extremely gravelly and sometimes dark soil appears as you approach the mountains east of Yakutsk, starting around Keskil.

metas.title: Vladivostok Landscape
metas.description: Lush and diverse forests in a hilly landscape characterises the noticeably warmer region around Vladivostok. Most of the coverage is overcast and has a white car with a long antenna. Further south, near the tri-border, you will find a more open rolling hill landscape.

metas.title: Magadan Road
metas.description: The eastern half of the Kolyma Highway going to Magadan features a lot of tall hills and mountains, usually shrouded in a haze. Most of the roads are unpaved and feature dark gravelly soil. The haze is not present in the western half.

metas.title: South Yakutsk Road
metas.description: A presence of Siberian larches and large mountains on a mostly paved, but sometimes wide-gravel road indicates the main road south of Yakutsk, with Generation 4 white car appearing north of Berkakit.

metas.title: Sakha Haze
metas.description: Very hazy coverage is found east and south of Mirny, especially along the Vilyuy river. The colour of the haze varies, but it is often orange or white.

metas.title: Buryatia Landscape
metas.description: The landscape in Buryatia is very unique, containing open grassy landscape with shrubs and mountains. It is lusher near Baikal, but the mountains persist.

metas.title: Buryatia Haze
metas.description: This forest fire haze is found near Lake Gusinoye, southwest of Ulan-Ude in Buryatia. While similar to the haze found near Mirny, the Buryatia haze coverage can typically be recognised by the open rolling landscape, which is not found near Mirny.

metas.title: Altai Mountains
metas.description: The main road of Altai Republic has a black car long antenna driving north through the Altai Mountains, often with foggy or rainy coverage.

metas.title: Tuva/Altai Landscape
metas.description: Dry steppe mountains with a long antenna will usually indicate the Tuva Republic. The south part of the main road in the Altai Republic and Tuva can appear similarly dry, so things such as driving direction and cloudiness can be used to distinguish them.

metas.title: Tundra Landscape
metas.description: The landscape in the far north can be recognised by the relatively flat landscape, with very low vegetation.

metas.title: Omsk Landscape
metas.description:
The coverage in Omsk Oblast is some of the most recognizable in Russia. It is typically summer Generation 4 and has a distinct landscape consisting of green agricultural fields, which are interrupted by isolated patches of (primarily) birch forest.

Note that in Generation 3, this landscape can be seen in a much larger area of Russia.
metas.note: This combination of coverage and landscape spills over slightly into the neighbouring Tyumen and Novosibirsk Oblasts (in the south, and near Tatarsk, respectively).

metas.title: Caspian Steppe
metas.description: The area west of the Caspian Sea can often be recognised by its extremely dry and flat landscape, especially in Kalmykia, Astrakhan Oblast, and Dagestan.

metas.title: Dagestan Spring
metas.description: Grassy fields, with bushy vegetation, in early spring Generation 4 coverage is typical for Dagestan. The landscape can either be completely flat or mountainous. These flowers are also quite common in the Generation 4 Dagestan coverage.

metas.title: Caucasus Mountains
metas.description: The Caucasus mountain range is one of the largest mountain ranges in Russia. The tallest mountain in Russia, Mount Elbrus, can be found on the border of the Kabardino-Balkarian Republic and Karachay-Cherkessia.

metas.title: Roadside Rocks
metas.description: Rocks along the road are extremely common throughout most of Karelia and Murmansk Oblast. They can also be found in Perm Krai and Buryatia but are less common and smaller in size.

metas.title: Murmansk Landscape
metas.description: An open, hilly landscape with low shrubbery and fireweed usually indicates Murmansk. The lower the shrubbery, the more north it generally is.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description: This is a map of Russian area codes. Notably, area codes starting with 8 are in the west, codes starting with 3 are fairly central and codes starting with 4 are either east or around Moscow.

metas.title: License Plate Codes
metas.description: In Generation 3 coverage you will somewhat commonly find unblurred licence plates, featuring a regional code on the right side. The codes are generally ordered alphabetically within each type of federal subject, starting at republics and ending with autonomous okrugs. Therefore, the Republic of Adygea will be represented by 01, and the Amur Oblast by 28, both being the first alphabetical subjects of republics and oblasts respectively. If you encounter a three digit code, the second and third digit will form the regional code, in this case 123 becomes 23, for Krasnodar Krai. You may also find the codes written out on the back of trucks and vans.

metas.title: Bus Stops
metas.description: These are the bus stops unique to specific federal subjects in Russia. Notably common and memorable ones include Krasnoyarsk Krai, Chuvashia, Tatarstan, and Mari El Republic.

metas.title: RHD Cars
metas.description: Japanese-made cars with the steering wheel on the right become more common the further east you go, generally starting around Novosibirsk.

metas.title: Thin Stick Bollards
metas.description: Russian bollards that appear very thin and attached to a stick are usually found in the eastern part of the country, starting around Omsk. Note that ordinary Russian bollards are still plentiful in this part of the country.

metas.title: Black Sign Backs (South)
metas.description: This black traffic sign bottom is primarily found in Stavropol and Chechnya, as well as western Dagestan. Rarely, exceptions can be found in other southern federal subjects such as Kabardino Balkaria, but these will typically be uncolored.

metas.title: Signpost Clips
metas.description: Clips on edges of signposts are found in Leningrad and St. Petersburg, and very rarely in Pskov, Novgorod or elsewhere.

metas.title: Kursk Road Lines
metas.description: Outer dashed road lines are usually found throughout Kursk Oblast. An exception can be found in Tuva Republic. Rarer exceptions include the Republic of Karelia, Primorsky Krai and Khabarovsk Krai.

metas.title: Concrete Slab Roads
metas.description: As you go further north in Russia, some roads are made out of several concrete blocks. It is notably common in the Komi Republic, Nenets, and Yamalo-Nenets.

metas.title: Ulyanovsk Red-White Poles
metas.description: These alternating red and white poles are mainly found in Ulyanovsk city, but also less commonly in the greater Nizhny Novgorod area as well as somewhat randomly elsewhere in the country.

metas.title: Saransk Striped Poles
metas.description: These striped red and white poles are found mostly in Saransk, but also in a few other cities in Mordovia.

metas.title: Bilingual Signs
metas.description: Some republics of Russia with minority languages use bilingual town entry and directional signs, such as in Bashkortostan and Tatarstan displaying Bashkir and Tatar respectively.

metas.title: Latin Script Town Names
metas.description: Town names written in both the Cyrillic and Latin alphabets are common near the Baltic border and around Moscow, and to a lesser extent in federal subjects on the Finnish border.

metas.title: Brown Tourist Signs
metas.description: These brown signs, pointing to typical tourist attractions, are common in Moscow Oblast and the oblasts bordering it. However, they can also less commonly be seen in city centres or near tourist attractions of other regions.

metas.title: Limestone Brick Buildings
metas.description: Buildings made of white limestone brick are indicative of Dagestan, as well as adjacent regions.

metas.title: Red Brick Buildings
metas.description: Buildings built almost entirely of red brick are mostly found south, but other notable exceptions include Magnitogorsk, Orsk, and Omsk.

metas.title: Mosques
metas.description: While mosques can be found everywhere in Russia, they are by far most common in areas with a Muslim majority, mainly in much of south Russia as well as Tatarstan and Bashkortostan.

metas.title: Mari El Architecture
metas.description: Historical buildings in Mari El often have a unique architecture style. You will frequently see design patterns that include green roofs, red brick sprinkled with white stone details. Local churches commonly feature a similar style.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
This is the full coverage map of Russia. It can be helpful to know areas where there isn’t any coverage. The coverage is notably very sparse in the east and north.

You can check out the extent of the official coverage on this website.

metas.title: White Car (Snow)
metas.description: White car long antenna is found in many places, most commonly in southern Chelyabinsk, on snow coverage around Novosibirsk, and in the Far East beginning in Amur Oblast.
metas.note: While Kamchatka technically has a silver car (with a B type antenna), it often appears white and is part of the small group of exceptions to black and white.

metas.title: A-Type Short Antenna
metas.description: The A-type short antenna has its highest ridge on the right. Notable areas for this antenna are around Kaluga, Orenburg, and Krasnodar.

metas.title: B-Type Short Antenna
metas.description: The B-type short antenna has its highest ridge on the left. This antenna is wide-ranging, but it is most notably found near Nizhny Novgorod, Elista, and Yekaterinburg and Tyumen.

metas.title: B-Type Pronounced Antenna
metas.description: The B-type pronounced antenna is the same as the B-type antenna but the ridge is more “rectangular”. This antenna is fairly limited, only being found commonly in Moscow Oblast, Kurgan Oblast, near Krasnoyarsk, and southwest Krasnodar.

metas.title: C-Type Short Antenna
metas.description: The C-type short antenna can be thought of as a low A-type or a “twisting antenna” with the ridges being further from the top. It is found north and east of Moscow, with the furthest south being Rostov Oblast.

metas.title: Blurred Short Antenna
metas.description: The blurred short antenna is visibly blurrier than any of the other short antennas. It is mainly found in two major clusters around Ufa and from Stavropol to Makhachkala.

metas.title: A-Type Long Antenna
metas.description: The A-type long antenna has its highest ridge on the right side. Notable areas include Leningrad Oblast, Republic of Karelia, and Vologda Oblast. Almost all the white car long antenna coverage is A-type, so checking for A-type can also help confirm car colour.

metas.title: B-Type Long Antenna
metas.description: The B-type long antenna has its highest ridge on the left side. Notable areas include Yaroslav to Vladimir, Tula Oblast, and much of the coverage near Tuva and Irkutsk.
metas.note: There are two other long antenna types, referred to as CA and CB, but due to their relative lack of usefulness they will not be covered here.

metas.title: Blurred Long Antenna
metas.description: Blurred long antenna is visibly blurrier than other long antenna cars, and is a strong clue for Sakhalin and various roads in the east, as well as much of Khanty-Mansi. On the other end there exists a blurred antenna in far western Bryansk Oblast and some of Tula Oblast.

metas.title: Tilted Short Antenna
metas.description: The tilted short antenna is visibly tilted to the left and can be found primarily on a diagonal from St. Petersburg down to Volgograd, with exceptions in Stavropol and Ufa. Since the ridge is on the same side, it can sometimes appear as the A-type short antenna.

metas.title: Large Red Brake Light
metas.description: A large, red brake light is common in Kaliningrad, however it can also be found in some older coverage in western Russia.

metas.title: Autumn Gen 3
metas.description: Autumn Generation 3 coverage is common in Kaliningrad, Bryansk, Tula, and Belgorod in western Russia, but Kaliningrad only has autumn coverage.

metas.title: Gen 4 Coverage Map
metas.description: Generation 4 coverage is quite extensive and is found in most federal subjects in the country. Notably, areas like the Altai mountains and most of the Far East lack Generation 4 completely. Knowing where Generation 4 can be found isn’t the most helpful at the beginner level; other clues like season and car are more important. The dark red signifies areas where all of the coverage is Generation 4.

metas.title: Winter Gen 4
metas.description: Winter Generation 4 is most common in the south of Russia, ranging from Ryazan all the way down to Kabardino-Balkaria and Dagestan. Winter can appear differently depending on the month (and even time of month the coverage was taken) which can be used to further regionguess.

metas.title: Spring Gen 4
metas.description: Spring Generation 4 is common in several distinct places, such as around Kemerovo and Krasnoyarsk, Orenburg and Kamyshin, around Lipetsk, and in Moscow city. Differentiating these places typically comes down to landscape, as they tend to be fairly distinct.

metas.title: Summer Gen 4
metas.description: Summer Generation 4 is the most common coverage in generation 4. It is pretty much everywhere except in the south and some of the east, but can be further subdivided by car colour.

metas.title: Autumn Gen 4
metas.description: Autumn Generation 4 is quite rare and only found around Kazan and a few roads in Murmansk, as well as some of Ulan-Ude.

metas.title: Gen 4 Red Car
metas.description: Generation 4 red car is the most common generation 4 car meta, found primarily east around Khanty-Mansi, as well as along the main highways down to Irkutsk and Ulan-Ude. There is also a sizable patch near Penza and Tatarstan, as well as Rostov-on-Don.

metas.title: Gen 4 White Car
metas.description: Generation 4 white car is found in the May coverage near Lipetsk, in Moscow city, and most notably across all the coverage north of Berkatit in the Sakha Republic and Magadan.

metas.title: Gen 4 Black Car
metas.description: Generation 4 black car is found mostly near Moscow, Tver, and Voronezh, with some also existing in Tatarstan and less commonly in the south.

metas.title: Vorkuta Winter
metas.description: Vorkuta in far northern Komi Republic has dead-looking winter coverage, sometimes with reddish soil. The apartment blocks will typically have large northern apartment block foundations.

metas.title: Vanino Winter
metas.description: Sovetskaya Gavan and Vanino in eastern Khabarovsk have winter coverage, somewhat similar to Vorkuta.
metas.note: While Vorkuta and Vanino have similar coverage types, Vorkuta is noticeably flatter, having lower vegetation and a more barren landscape.

metas.title: Okha Road
metas.description: The road to Okha in northern Sakhalin is unpaved, revealing its very sandy soil. The road is surrounded by short, stunted bushes and trees.

metas.title: Khabarovsk-Vanino Road
metas.description: The Khabarovsk-Vanino road has a mountainous landscape with very sunny coverage. It also drives west with a black car with a blurred, long antenna, which helps to confirm.

metas.title: JAO Foggy Road
metas.description: The Jewish Autonomous Oblast effectively has one road of coverage, outside of Birobidzhan. The west side has highly rainy and foggy coverage.

metas.title: JAO Wet Road
metas.description: On the east side of the Jewish Autonomous Oblast, the coverage turns from rainy to wet after the rain.

metas.title: P-297 Sunset
metas.description: Sunset coverage, with the sun very close to the horizon, with an eastern-looking landscape will be the P-297 in Amur Oblast, roughly between the towns of Never and Sivaki.

metas.title: Olkhon Island
metas.description: Olkhon Island on Lake Baikal has a single road, driving on rolling sandy hills during sunset. You can often see Lake Baikal directly with a mountain ridge across the bay.

metas.title: Tunkinsky National Park
metas.description: Tunkinsky National Park in western Buryatia is a very green river basin with tall, jagged mountains to the north. In comparison to most of Buryatia, it is much greener.

metas.title: Caspian Desert Gen 4
metas.description: In the desert-like region west of the Caspian Sea, this completely flat and rural Generation 4 coverage on small poorly-tracked dirt roads can only be found in northern Dagestan and southwestern Astrakhan Oblast.

metas.title: Black Sea Palms
metas.description: Tropical plants in Russia such as palm trees are only found on the Black Sea, most commonly around Sochi.

metas.title: Kamchatka Trekkers
metas.description: Kamchatka trekkers encompass a majority of the trekkers present in Russia. They can be recognized using the same clues to recognize Kamchatka normally.

metas.title: Moscow Blue Signs
metas.description: These blue signs are only found in Moscow and usually feature English translations of important tourist points.

metas.title: St. Petersburg Signs
metas.description: St. Petersburg street signs include a transliteration of the street name on a black background. They are primarily found downtown.

metas.title: Saransk Signs
metas.description: Saransk has an exclusive circular street sign design with the street name being written in up to 4 different languages.

metas.title: Tatar Street Suffix
metas.description: Tatar bilingual signs use “урамы” (ур., abbreviated) for street instead of “улица” and are unsurprisingly found in Tatarstan.

metas.title: Bashkir Street Suffix
metas.description: Bashkir bilingual signs are found in Bashkortostan and use “урамы” for street, the same as Tatar, but are often not abbreviated.

metas.title: Chuvash Street Suffix
metas.description: Chuvash bilingual signs, found in Chuvashia, use “урамӗ” for street.

metas.title: Mari Street Suffix
metas.description: Mari bilingual signs, found in Mari El, use “урем” for street.

metas.title: Komi Street Suffix
metas.description: Komi bilingual signs, found in the Komi Republic, use “улича” for street.

metas.title: Tatarstan Pole Plates
metas.description: Yellow pole plates attached by a metal band are commonly found in Tatarstan. They are found on the majority of poles, but not all.

metas.title: Murmansk Pole Bands
metas.description: On the main road of Murmansk in generation 4, as well as some roads in Karelia covered in 2018, the vast majority of signposts will have two yellow bands wrapped around them.

metas.title: Kaliningrad Cobble
metas.description: Cobblestone pavement is notably common in Kaliningrad, Nizhny Tagil in Sverdlovsk, and Kizel in Perm Krai.

metas.title: Extended Insulator Bars
metas.description: Extended insulator bars on poles are notably found in southern Chelyabinsk Oblast and eastern Orenburg Oblast, as well as southern Kemerovo Oblast.

metas.title: Mesh Poles
metas.description: Utility poles with a mesh framework are usually found in Petrozavodsk, but can much less commonly be found in cities like Tolyatti.

metas.title: Murom Red Poles
metas.description: These red painted poles are only found in Murom.

metas.title: Chita Angled Insulator
metas.description: An angled extended insulator bar on the pole as shown is found in Chita.

metas.title: Kostroma Bollard
metas.description: This unique bollard, with a grey rectangle and double red reflectors, is specific to the P100 in Kostroma Oblast.

metas.title: Chelyabinsk Sign Hooks
metas.description: Pedestrian signs with a U-shaped hook attached to a pole are unique to Chelyabinsk.

metas.title: Pskov Pedestrian Signs
metas.description: This distinct decorative design of pedestrian sign holders is specific to Pskov Oblast.

metas.title: Nizhnevartovsk Hanging Signs
metas.description: The city of Nizhnevartovsk has these unique hanging pedestrian signs.

metas.title: Chelyabinsk Fences
metas.description: Rounded rectangular fences with a line through the middle are unique to Chelyabinsk Oblast and eastern Orenburg Oblast.

metas.title: Syzran/Samara Fences
metas.description: This fence with a thin rounded rectangular design at the top is found in the cities of Syzran, Tolyatti, and Samara. In Tolyatti it will commonly be painted yellow.

metas.title: Irkutsk Orange Fences
metas.description: Decoratively designed fences usually with a bright orange colour are unique to Irkutsk.

metas.title: Monte Titano
metas.description: The 739m-tall Monte Titano dominates the surrounding landscape and is visible from almost every point in the Republic.
metas.note: Look for the three towers to safely identify it.

metas.title: Landscape Overview
metas.description: The landscape of San Marino largely consists of smooth agricultural hills, with many small winding roads. The vegetation is distinctly Mediterranean, and normally appears quite lush.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Sammarinese licence plates are short, white and have blue lettering on them.
metas.note: Other European countries will typically have longer licence plates, often with one or more blue strips.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Road signs and bollards are generally identical to the ones used in Italy.
metas.note: Many road signs give directions to the nearby Italian city of Rimini.

metas.title: Concrete Poles
metas.description: Just like Italy, most utility poles in San Marino are round and made of concrete. Wooden poles are also found in the country.

metas.title: Yellow Chevrons
metas.description: San Marino is the only country in the world to use yellow chevrons with burgundy red arrows.

metas.title: Blue-White Crosswalks
metas.description: These elaborate pedestrian crossings, with painted blue crosswalks and hanging signs, are specific to San Marino.

metas.title: Green/Black Bins
metas.description: Lime-green bins are particularly common in San Marino. In Generation 4 coverage some of them have been replaced by black bins.

metas.title: Superstrada Guardrails
metas.description: The Superstrada di San Marino runs from the border village of Dogana to the City of San Marino. It is the only divided road in the country, and the lanes are separated by a metal guardrail.

metas.title: Historic Centre Trekkers
metas.description: The historic centre is covered by a Generation 3 trekker camera.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Serbia has a few bollard designs, however most of them will have an off-centred reflector. The bollards are usually flat, with no depth to them.

metas.title: B-Profile Guardrails
metas.description: Serbia uses B-Profile guardrails exclusively.
metas.note: North Macedonia does not use B-Profile guardrails. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description: Serbia uses chevrons with a black arrow on a white background.
metas.note: Within Europe, these chevrons can also be found in Slovenia, Montenegro and North Macedonia.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Serbian licence plates are white with a blue strip on the left. Agricultural plates, on vehicles such as tractors, are green.
metas.note: Croatian and North Macedonian plates typically do not have a blue strip.

metas.title: Cyrillic & Latin Script
metas.description:
Serbian is a Slavic language which uses both the cyrillic and latin script. These letters are unique to Serbian:

Ђ ђ

Ћ ћ

These letters are found in Serbian and Macedonian:

Љ љ

Њ њ

Џ џ

metas.title: Latin Special Characters
metas.description: When written in the latin script, Serbian uses the special letters Č, Ć, Đ, Š and Ž. Note that all of these letters may also be found in Croatian and Montenegrin.

metas.title: No Antenna Coverage
metas.description: Most of the coverage in Serbia was taken by a Google car with no antenna.
metas.note: Other than North Macedonia, almost all of central and eastern Europe has antenna coverage in Generation 3.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: This is a coverage map of Serbia. Most of the coverage is in the north in Vojvodina, around Belgrade and in the southeast around Niš. Kosovo does not have any coverage.

metas.title: Landscape Overview
metas.description:
In the north of Serbia in the Vojvodina region, from the Hungarian border to Belgrade, the landscape is extremely flat, with no hills whatsoever. A slight ridge however can be seen at Fruška Gora National Park.

A more hilly landscape can be seen in the central-southern region. The most mountainous regions of Serbia are found in the southwest and southeast, where the Dinaric Alps, Carpathian and Balkan mountains run through Serbia.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description: Serbia uses 2 digit area codes, with the first digit between 1 and 3. Area codes starting with 2 are found in the north, area codes starting with 1 are found in central and eastern Serbia. Area codes starting with 3 are found in the south-west.

metas.title: Vojvodina Landscape
metas.description: Vojvodina, the northern region between the Hungarian border and Belgrade, can be recognized by the flat, agricultural landscape. The landscape will be completely flat with no hills whatsoever.

metas.title: Fruška Gora Ridge
metas.description: This slight ridge in an otherwise flat landscape can be seen in Fruška Gora National Park, southwest of Novi Sad.

metas.title: Central Rolling Hills
metas.description: Central-northern Serbia can be recognized by the slight rolling hills.

metas.title: Southern Morava Basin
metas.description: A similarly rolling landscape can be seen in the southern Morava River basin, however larger hills and mountains can be seen.

metas.title: Southern Mountains
metas.description: A lush, green, mountainous landscape can be seen in the south and southeast, along the Bulgarian and Kosovo border.

metas.title: Autumn Coverage (Valjevo)
metas.description: Fall coverage can be seen in this region south of Čačak, and a small area around Valjevo.

metas.title: Divided Highways Map
metas.description:
There are 3 main divided highways in Serbia:

The A1, or E-75 from the Hungarian border to south of Leskovac, running through Novi Sad, Belgrade and Niš.

The A3, or E-70 from the Croatian border to Belgrade

The A4 which branches off of the A1 north of Niš, to just before Sicevo Canyon Nature Park.
metas.note: Although Google maps shows that a highway is divided, it may not be divided on street view since the coverage was taken before the second carriageway was constructed. This map shows all the divided highways currently visible on street view.

metas.title: White Car Short Antenna
metas.description: A white Google Car with a short antenna can be seen in Novi Sad, Kovilj, in and around Belgrade, Niš, and the E75 connecting them.
metas.note: The white car is not always visible.

metas.title: Vršac Mountains
metas.description: The distinct Vršac Mountains can be seen east of Vršac near the Romanian border. The mountains protrude out from a flat landscape and vineyards can commonly be seen to the south of the mountains. The Vršac Castle can also be seen atop the mountain.

metas.title: Bilingual Hungarian Signs
metas.description: Bilingual signs with Serbian alongside Hungarian can be seen in northern Vojvodina, where there is a Hungarian majority.

metas.title: Tadpole Smudge
metas.description: This tadpole-shaped smudge can be seen east of Belgrade, from just west of Bavanište to the Romanian border.

metas.title: E-80 Yellow Lines
metas.description: A small section of the E-80 north of Pirot has yellow centre lines.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Bollards in Slovakia have orange double reflectors on the front and a single white reflector on the back. There are also rarer blue and red variants.
metas.note: The only other country with the same design is Czechia.

metas.title: Wide B-Profile Guardrails
metas.description: Slovakia and Czechia both use a special kind of type B guardrail, which is wider than the normal type. No other European countries use the same kind.
metas.note: While Czechia uses this type fairly consistently, Slovakia also uses other types occasionally. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: Double Concrete Poles
metas.description: Slovakia and Czechia most commonly use wide, round concrete poles, which are quite often attached in pairs.

metas.title: Metal Bar Poletops
metas.description: Slovak and Czech poletops typically feature short metal bars that hold the insulators.

metas.title: Triangle Support Poletops
metas.description: Two support bars holding up the metal bar on pole tops, resembling an upside down triangle, can sometimes be found in Slovakia and Czechia.
metas.note: This is also found in Germany, Albania, Serbia and Romania.

metas.title: Trident Poletops
metas.description: You may also see concrete poles with trident poletops, with two arms angled upwards. Some features, such as the number of insulators, will vary, however the general shape will be the same. Out of the pole tops listed, these are the least common, but unique to the two countries.

metas.title: Bolted Lamp Base
metas.description: Lamp posts with a thick base mounted by opposing pairs of bolts are common in both countries. The exact shape of the base may vary.

metas.title: Striped Sign Posts
metas.description: It is common in both Slovakia and Czechia to see temporary square sign posts coated in red and white stripes.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description: Slovak and Czech chevrons are white with red arrows. Less commonly, you may find red on yellow chevrons.

metas.title: Gas/Water Poles
metas.description: Stripy gas and water poles reminiscent of snow poles can often be found next to the road.
metas.note: Dozens of poles of various utilities all over Europe use stripy patterns. Consider the location of the pole, as well as other clues before making a guess.

metas.title: Hiking Markers
metas.description: Hiking markers, made up of one colourful strip between two white ones, are commonly found in Slovakia and Czechia. They sometimes form an arrow.
metas.note: While by far being the most common in Slovakia and Czechia, similar signs can be found in other European countries such as Poland, Hungary and Germany.

metas.title: Panel Apartment Buildings
metas.description: Like all of the former Eastern bloc, prefabricated panel apartment buildings are a common sight in urban areas. What distinguishes Slovakia and Czechia is the relatively good maintenance often combined with vibrant colours and patterns. Some smaller buildings also adhere to this style.
metas.note: To a lesser extent, you can find this kind of architecture in neighbouring countries, like Poland and Hungary.

metas.title: Diamond Roof Tiles
metas.description: Roofs with diamond shaped tiles are common in both Slovakia and Czechia.
metas.note: This is also somewhat common in Hungary.

metas.title: Gen 3 Antenna Tape
metas.description: A car antenna with a grey piece of tape stuck to the top can be seen on much of the Generation 3 coverage.
metas.note: This can also be seen in Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria.

metas.title: Gen 4 Black Car
metas.description: A black generation 4 Google car can also be found in both Slovakia and Czechia.
metas.note: A black car can be found in many other European countries too.

metas.title: Gen 4 Red Car
metas.description: A red generation 4 Google car can be found in both Slovakia and Czechia.
metas.note: A red car can be found in other European countries too.

metas.title: Bridge Markers
metas.description: These black signs can often be found by the end of bridges in Generation 4 coverage. The road number is displayed on the left.

metas.title: Language Characters
metas.note: Acute accents on vowels are not found in South Slavic languages.

metas.title: Landscape Overview
metas.description: The Slovak landscape varies between very mountainous and completely flat. Generally speaking, Czechia is hillier, but less mountainous.

metas.title: Blue Directional Signs
metas.description: Slovakia uses blue directional signs, with small white arrows.
metas.note: Czechia has large filled in white arrows instead.

metas.title: Borderless Road Signs
metas.description: Slovak road signs commonly have the painted sign border right at the edge of the sign.
metas.note: The borders on Czech signs are almost always separated from the edge of the sign by a strip in the signs background colour.

metas.title: Borderless Highway Signs
metas.description: Slovak highway signs can be either blue or green, and have a white border right at the edge of the sign.
metas.note: The borders of Czech highway signs are separated from the edge.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description: White street signs with blue text and a thin red border are by far the most common in Slovakia.
metas.note: The same design can also be found in Czechia, near the Slovak border. However, Czech street names never feature the word “ulica”.

metas.title: Slovakia Features
metas.description: House numbers in Slovakia are typically written on white signs with a thin red or black border.

metas.title: Top Slovak Sign
metas.description: The top of Slovak sign posts are typically either open, have a grey metal cap or a thin black cap.
metas.note: Most Czech sign posts have a thick black cap.

metas.title: Slovakia Uses Two
metas.description: Slovakia uses two major pedestrian signs, both having five stripes. The first has a simply drawn person with a belt, and the second has the stripes very close together.
metas.note: The same belted design is found in Germany. A similar design, with a distinctly lower belt, is found in Hungary. While very rare, pedestrian signs with similarly condensed stripes can also be found in Czechia.

metas.title: Slovak Road Signs
metas.description: Slovak road signs normally feature a very bold font.
metas.note: The font on Czech signs is much thinner.

metas.title: Slovak Kilometre Markers
metas.description: Slovak kilometre markers typically have two sections divided with a black horizontal line. The top section contains the road number.
metas.note: Czech kilometre markers do not have a black horizontal line.

metas.title: Slovak Cycling Signs
metas.description: Slovak cycling signs use the letter C as their symbol, unique to the country. They’re visually analogous to the Czechoslovak hiking markers mentioned in step 1.1, including the yellow post on directional signs.

metas.title: Slovakia Features
metas.description: Window shutters are considerably more common in Slovakia than in Czechia.
metas.note: They are also very common in Hungary.

metas.title: Many Slovak Houses
metas.description: Many Slovak houses have the short side facing the road with the roof ending in a hip end.
metas.note: This is also very common in Hungary, but less common in Czechia.

metas.title: Grey Metal Roofs
metas.description: Grey metal roofs are very common, particularly in the eastern parts of Slovakia.
metas.note: Apart from the most mountainous areas, it is far less common in Czechia.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: While Czechia has a lot of Generation 3 winter coverage, Slovakia has a lot of Generation 3 spring coverage.

metas.title: Slovak Railway Crossing
metas.description: The Slovak railway crossing sign has a white rectangular background.
metas.note: Czech railway crossing signs do not have a background.

metas.title: Slovakia Features
metas.description: It is fairly common to see small signs with double sign posts in Slovakia.
metas.note: While large signs may have double sign posts, small signs rarely do in Czechia.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Slovakia recently changed its standard bollard to a design very similar to the one found in Hungary: a standard European wedge-shaped bollard with a red front reflector. Note that for the time being, this bollard is still very rare.

metas.title: Concrete Poles
metas.description:
It is somewhat more common to see wooden poles, and in turn, white concrete supports in Slovakia rather than in Czechia.

Note that because there are many variables, it may sometimes be inconsistent. Therefore, this information should preferably be used to help decide between a difficult fifty-fifty.

metas.title: Area Code Map
metas.description: Slovak phone numbers typically consist of 10 digits, of which the first 2-3 digits are the area code.
metas.note: Czech phone numbers generally do not begin with a 0.

metas.title: Apart From Major
metas.description:
Apart from the major highways, for which the numbers do not follow any clear pattern, there are two types of numbered roads in Slovakia: 3-digit and 4-digit roads. While many 3-digit roads do not follow any pattern, the ones between 500-560 are generally ordered from west to east. Similarly, the 4-digit road numbers also increase to the east.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description: The tallest mountains in Slovakia are found in the central and northern parts of the country, while the flattest areas are found mainly in the southwest and in the southeast.

metas.title: Flat Agricultural Land
metas.description: The western lowlands in Slovakia are characterised by completely flat agricultural fields, which are rare to find anywhere else in the country.
metas.note: While there are some generally flat areas in Czechia, it is rare to see complete flatness which reaches beyond the horizon.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The eastern lowlands can typically be recognized by wide, flat fields, surrounded by hills or mountains in the far distance.

metas.title: Several Areas Southern
metas.description: Several areas in southern Slovakia have a Hungarian majority, with bilingual street and information signs.

metas.title: Painted Poles
metas.description: Concrete poles in Nitra and Trnava regions commonly have yellow circles painted on them, usually containing a number. They are also occasionally found in adjacent regions.
metas.note: This is only the case with circles, other shapes are found elsewhere in the country.

metas.title: Street Lamps
metas.description: Yellow lamp posts with a blue base are mainly found in the east, with a notable exception being the city of Zvolen.
metas.note: This rule only applies to lamps with this exact colour arrangement. Other infrastructure with similar colour schemes can be found all over the country.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description: Two wide valleys surrounded by tall, often sharp mountains can be found in the northern parts of the country. Due to the directions of the valleys, figuring out the direction to the closest mountain is typically enough to differentiate the two.
metas.note: The light red area has tall, sharp mountains to the northwest, and much lower hills and mountains to the southeast.

metas.title: Pine Forests
metas.description: Pine forests are common in the westernmost part of the country.

metas.title: Cyrillic Script
metas.description: In the northeastern parts of the Prešov region, you may find bilingual town entry signs in Rusyn, a Cyrillic based language closely related to Ukrainian.

metas.title: Not Only Bratislava
metas.description: Not only is Bratislava by far the largest city in the country, it is also the only major city with a large river running through it.

metas.title: Bratislava And Košice
metas.description: Bratislava and Košice are the only two cities with trams, using a red and a yellow-blue-white colour scheme respectively.
metas.note: Buses in Košice and Bratislava use the same colour schemes, however red buses can also be found in Prešov.

metas.title: Painted Poles
metas.description: Trolleybuses in Žilina use a green-yellow-white colour scheme. The trolley supporting electricity poles, often doubling as lamps, are painted with matching yellow and green colours.

metas.title: Street Signs
metas.description: Skalica, in the northwestern corner of the country, has red street signs, similar to the ones commonly found in Czechia. However, the somewhat stylized font distinguishes it from the Czech signs.

metas.title: Čičmany Westernmost Parts
metas.description: Čičmany, in the westernmost parts of the Žilina Region, is easily recognized by the dark brown wooden houses, whose walls are filled with art consisting of white lines.

metas.title: Landscape Overview
metas.description:
The Slovenian landscape is generally very hilly and forested, with occasional agriculture.

For exceptions to this, see the region guessing section.

metas.title: Forest Roads
metas.description: A very significant portion of the coverage in Slovenia was taken on small roads deep inside forest.

metas.title: Alpine Architecture
metas.description: Slovenian architecture takes much inspiration from alpine architecture, with light coloured walls, dark wooden details and semi-steep roofs. The most common roof shape is half-hipped roofs.

metas.title: Language Characters
metas.description: Slovene is a Slavic language featuring the special letters Č, Š, and Ž. It is closely related to Croatian, Serbian and Montenegrin.
metas.note: On top of having the same letters as Slovene, Croatian also has the letters Ć and Đ.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Slovenian bollards are white with a black top. The front reflector will typically be bright red, while the back reflector will be white.
metas.note: Austrian bollards have the same design, but with a dark red front reflector and a black or grey back reflector. Montenegrin bollards also have a very similar design, also with a red and a white reflector.

metas.title: Yellow Directional Signs
metas.description: Slovenian directional signs are yellow with a black border.
metas.note: Croatia, North Macedonia, Serbia and Montenegro all have similar directional signs. Austrian directional signs are typically white with a blue outline.

metas.title: Kilometer Markers
metas.description: Slovenian kilometre markers have a very distinct design. At the top left the road number is shown in a yellow rectangle, and a second number is to the right of it. A horizontal black line divides the top and bottom, and the distance is shown below.
metas.note: Austrian kilometre markers are blue with a white number.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description:
Slovenian chevrons usually have red arrows on a white background.

You can also find a less common version with a black arrow on a white background.
metas.note: Austrian chevrons are either white on red or red on yellow.

metas.title: Pedestrian Signs
metas.description: Slovenian pedestrian signs have five stripes and a simply drawn person without a belt.
metas.note: Austrian pedestrian signs have two dotted lines, while the person on Croatian signs has a belt.

metas.title: Long Outer Dashes
metas.description: Slovenian roads commonly feature long outer dashes.
metas.note: Neighbouring countries do not frequently use dashed outside lines.

metas.title: White Street Signs
metas.description: Slovenian street signs are most commonly white with a metal border attached to signposts, or red and attached to house walls.
metas.note: Czech street signs are also typically red and attached to walls. However, Czech street names will not contain the word “ulica”, which most Slovenian street names have.

metas.title: Red House Numbers
metas.description: Slovenian house numbers are typically red with white text.
metas.note: Czech house numbers are also commonly red.

metas.title: A-Type Guardrails
metas.description:
Slovenia uses a regular A-type guardrail, like most European countries. This guardrail type has rounded edges.

This is mostly useful for 50-50s with Croatia, which uses B-type guardrails. This type has square edges.
metas.note: For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: Kozolec Hayracks
metas.description: This type of shed, called a kozolec, made of thin wooden beams with noticeable gaps in between, is very typical for Slovenia.

metas.title: Gen 4 Black Car
metas.description: A black generation 4 car can be found in Slovenia.
metas.note: A black car can be found in many European countries.

metas.title: Gen 4 White Car
metas.description: A white generation 4 Google car can also rarely be found in Slovenia.
metas.note: It can also be found in other European countries.

metas.title: Alpine Mountains
metas.description: The tallest mountains in the country can be found in the northwestern alpine region.

metas.title: Eastern Plains
metas.description: Flat, or rolling, agricultural fields with no mountains or tall hills in view can be seen in the east of the country.

metas.title: Coastal Landscape
metas.description: Near the coast you get a landscape similar to the rest of the Adriatic coast; white cliffs with bushy vegetation, vineyards and Mediterranean architecture.

metas.title: Southeast Valley
metas.description: A wide valley going east to west, with mountains to the north and south can be found in the southeast.

metas.title: Bilingual Italian Signs
metas.description: Italian bilingual signs can be found in the westernmost region.

metas.title: Green House Numbers
metas.description: Instead of the normal red house numbers, Ljubljana will typically feature green house numbers.
metas.note: Street signs in Ljubljana are also occasionally green.

metas.title: Celje Street Signs
metas.description: Street signs in Celje feature the emblem of the city, a blue shield with three yellow stars.

metas.title: Trbovlje Street Signs
metas.description: Similar to Celje, Trbovlje also features the city’s coat of arms, which is a blue and green shield with a black crest.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Spain uses standard long, white European plates with a single blue strip on the left.
metas.note: Most Portuguese plates have a yellow strip on the right. Italian plates have two blue strips on either side of the plate.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: The standard Spanish bollards have a yellow-orange reflector on the front and two white dots on the back (though the back can also be blank). They are typically hollow.
metas.note: Very close to Andorra, you can find a slightly different bollard, which is also used in Andorra itself.

metas.title: Concrete Ladder Poles
metas.description:
In Spain, you can find a variety of electricity poles and pole tops. In small towns and sparsely populated rural areas concrete ladder poles and wooden poles are the most common.

“Ladder” poles have indents that resemble a ladder, hence the name.

metas.title: French Poletops
metas.description: “French style” poletops are common in Spain. They are shaped like an upside down triangle, with a horizontal top bar that is curved slightly upwards. They are usually found on top of tall ladder poles or medium sized steel poles.
metas.note: As the name suggests, French poletops are also very common in France.

metas.title: Mediterranean Landscape
metas.description: High voltage electricity lines supported by pylons are very common in Spain, especially compared to other Mediterranean countries.

metas.title: Road Markers
metas.description: Spain has distinct road markers with a variety of colourful borders. The code on top is the number of the road.
metas.note: Andorra has similar markers and the letter codes preceding the road number on these markers are often an important region-specific clue. You can learn more about these codes in the region guessing section.

metas.title: Hunting Signs
metas.description: In rural areas you will often find hunting signs. There are two versions, both of which are unique to Spain. One is a simple white sign with a text starting with “coto” and ending in “caza”. The other one has a diagonally divided black and white background.
metas.note: These signs have an identifying code that can sometimes be read. In this case “Ex” stands for Extremadura.

metas.title: A-Type Guardrails
metas.description: Spain has yellow reflectors on rounded A-type guardrails.
metas.note: Belgium, Andorra, Gibraltar and most Latin American countries also have yellow reflectors. For a good overview of European guardrails, see this infographic.

metas.title: 8-Stripe Crosswalks
metas.description: Spanish pedestrian crossing signs have 8 stripes. This is the highest number of stripes in Europe, and almost unique to Spain.
metas.note: The only other European country with 8 stripes is Andorra.

metas.title: Small Stop Sign Font
metas.description: Spanish stop signs have a distinct small font.
metas.note: These are mostly useful to distinguish Portugal from Spain: Portuguese stop signs have a noticeably larger font.

metas.title: Borderless Red Signs
metas.description: Red borders on road signs extend all the way to the edge of the sign. There is no small white border separating the red part from the edge.
metas.note: France, Italy and Portugal have a small white border on the edge of such road signs.

metas.title: Flat Signposts
metas.description: Almost all traffic signs, kilometre markers, chevrons and some direction signs in Spain have a flat signpost.
metas.note: Flat signposts in Europe are also present in Portugal, France and Andorra.

metas.title: Chevrons
metas.description: Spain has two chevrons: black with white arrows, and blue with white arrows. Chevrons with a single arrow are rare.
metas.note:
In Southern Europe, black with white chevrons can be found in Italy, Greece and Albania.

France is the only other European country that has blue with white chevrons.

Portugal has black with yellow chevrons.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description:
Spanish direction signs have a white background. They often feature colourful boxes with road numbers, making them recognizable. These road number boxes can be many different colours.

Highway signs have a blue background.

metas.title: Dashed Outer Lines
metas.description:
Rural roads sometimes have dashed outer lines. This can help tell Spain apart from Portugal and Italy, where such road lines are (almost) non-existent.

Note that the reverse is not true: like Italy and Portugal, many Spanish roads do have solid outer lines.

metas.title: Language Differences
metas.description:
Spanish is the main language in most of the country. It is a Romance language that is closely related to Portuguese.

Spanish and Portuguese can look very similar. Some key differences between the two:

Ñ is unique to Spanish.

Ç and lh are unique to Portuguese (Ç is also present in Catalan).

Portuguese uses the -ao word ending, and -nh- instead of ñ.

Spanish uses de and del, while these are often contracted to da, do, das and dos in Portuguese.
metas.note: Spain also has several regional languages, some of which are more common than Spanish in their respective regions. These languages are discussed in more detail in the region-guessing section.

metas.title: Word for Street (Calle)
metas.description: The Spanish word for street is calle.

metas.title: No Parking Signs (Vado)
metas.description:
You will often find no parking signs in front of garage doors and gates. They will usually read “Vado permanente”.

These signs will very often have the name of the municipality after “Ayuntamiento de”.
metas.note: Italy uses signs that read “Passo carrabile”.

metas.title: Landscape Variety
metas.description: Spain has highly diverse landscapes, ranging from lush Atlantic forests to bone-dry semideserts. Elevation is also varied: highland plateaus interspersed with rolling hills are common, but you might also encounter jagged mountain ranges and very flat lowland areas.

metas.title: Mediterranean Landscape
metas.description: While there is not one single definitive Spanish landscape, most of the country has a somewhat dry, Mediterranean climate, with matching vegetation and agriculture.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: Generation 3 cars can have long, short or no antennas. The back of the car is usually not visible, but when it is, it can be either black or white.
metas.note: Coverage in Eastern Andalusia, Huesca, and Lleida sometimes has a long antenna with a distinctive white top.

metas.title: Gen 4 Cars
metas.description: Generation 4 cars are blue or less commonly black. The car can be completely hidden.

metas.title: Gen 4 Smallcam
metas.description: Spain also has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.

metas.title: Ari / Shitcam
metas.description: Google used a weird, low-quality camera in Spain. This camera is known as the official Ari (or “Shitcam”). It has a wide circular car blur, and can be distinguished from Generation 2 by its lack of a sky halo and often somewhat brownish colours. A good map will not usually include this coverage, but it is good to be aware of its existence, in order to not be caught off-guard by it.

metas.title: Regional Road Codes
metas.description:
Spanish regional road numbers feature region-specific codes. These are found on road markers, and sometimes on direction signs.

For example, the SG code on road markers refers to a road in Segovia province.

The infographic shows almost all the regional codes, except for some very rare codes. Click on the image to enlarge it.
metas.note:
National roads use the following codes: E, AP, A, R, N. These can be found anywhere in the country.

Be careful: A is also used for community roads in Andalusia and Aragon.

Some autonomous communities do not have community roads, only provincial roads. These have been indicated with grey on the map.

Asturias uniquely has a large variety of local road codes.

Ceuta only has N-roads. Melilla uses the code ML.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description:
Area codes in Spain are very useful, as you only need two digits to get a very accurate guess. Every landline number starts with “9”, followed by the regional numbers.

Mobile numbers start with “6”, and are not relevant in region guessing.

metas.title: Regional Languages
metas.description:
Spain has several regional languages. The ones that are most useful to GeoGuessr are Catalan, Basque and Galician.
