A lack of road infrastructure or buildings, until you reach the next urban area.

Low amount of traffic.

metas.title: Summer Coverage
metas.description:
Almost all Ukrainian coverage was made in the summer, meaning the foliage is green and the people around are dressed for sunny weather.

Five major cities have autumn coverage, with distinct fall colours and colder weather. See the region guessing section for more information.

metas.title: Poplar Trees
metas.description: These tall poplar trees are common in many parts of the country.
metas.note: They can be found in some regions of Russia, but most of the country completely lacks them.

metas.title: Coverage Distribution
metas.description:
Coverage in Ukraine is mostly limited to urban areas and the main roads between them. See the region-guessing section for a map.

However, one type of coverage that can sometimes trick people are ultra-rural tracks close to cities. This is a decently common type of coverage in Ukraine, despite the general rule that most coverage is either urban or on a main road.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
This is a map of street view coverage in Ukraine. Most coverage between cities is on yellow roads.

Notably, there is almost no coverage in the southeast. The only exception is Donetsk. There is also no coverage south of Odesa in the area near Romania.

You can view the extent of official coverage on this site.

metas.title: Area Codes
metas.description:
Ukrainian landline phone numbers start with a two-digit area code. Each oblast has its own area code. If the third digit is a 2, it refers to a phone number in the oblast’s capital (typically the biggest city).

Mobile phone numbers start with 50, 63, 66-68, 73 or 91-99. They are not unique to a geographic area.

metas.title: Plate Codes
metas.description: The first two letters on Ukrainian licence plates determine in which oblast the vehicle is registered in, making unblurred licence plates very useful for regionguessing. Unlike most regional plates in Europe, they’re not intuitive, so learning the codes beforehand is essential for utilising them.
metas.note: The map shown only applies to the most recent and common plates, with a blue and yellow strip. The older plates use a regional number code, similar to Russia.

metas.title: Internet Domains
metas.description: Oblast-specific second-level internet domains can occasionally be found in Ukraine. Seen in the image is the domain for Ternopil Oblast (.te.ua). They can typically be used without being memorised, as they’re mostly intuitive. You can however learn them here.

metas.title: 2011 Fall Coverage
metas.description:
Five major cities were covered in 2011, years before the rest of the country was covered: Kyiv, Lviv, Kharkiv, Odesa and Donetsk.

This coverage was made during autumn, meaning that the trees have distinct fall colours and people are dressed for colder weather.

In Kyiv, Lviv and Kharkiv, almost all of this coverage has been overwritten by the newer summer coverage. However, in all of Donetsk, and most of Odesa, it is still intact. In Donetsk specifically, there is no newer coverage at all.

metas.title: 2011 Car Meta
metas.description:
This older 2011 coverage was made with a black or white Google car, instead of the standard red one. Both cars have a long antenna.

The black car was used in Donetsk. Note that Donetsk has no newer coverage whatsoever, so never guess in that city if you see a red car.

The white car was used in Lviv, Kyiv and Kharkiv. As the coverage in these cities is mostly overwritten, the white car is very rare.

metas.title: Carpathian Forests
metas.description: The Carpathian Mountains is an area in western Ukraine that is significantly hillier than the rest of the country, in some places bordering on mountainous. It is also much more forested, with very little agriculture, and a lot of pine trees. The roads going through it tend to be more curvy, rather than the straight highways found in the rest of the country.

metas.title: Northern Pine Forests
metas.description:
Forests with Baltic pines (Pinus sylvestris) are most commonly found in the north, most often near the border with Belarus. Baltic pines are usually tall and have orange-red bark.

While some of these forests consist solely of this species, many of them are a mix of Baltic pines and broadleaf trees.
metas.note: Note that the Carpathians are also covered in a lot of pine forests. They are noticeably hilly however, allowing you to distinguish this area from the very flat north.

metas.title: Southern Climate
metas.description: Towards the south, the climate becomes warmer and drier. The landscape is more arid. Forests are considerably more rare, and make way for shrubs and open fields. The difference is not extreme, but can become noticeable after some practice.

metas.title: Sunflower Fields
metas.description:
Sunflowers are grown in most of Ukraine. However, they only start to bloom as early as late July. Due to the way Ukraine was covered, this means you will usually only see sunflower fields that are in bloom in the far south and east of the country.

These fields are most common in Kherson, Mykolaiv and Odesa Oblast. The road T0403 to Nova Kakhovka especially has a lot of them.

Note that sunflower fields that are not in bloom can be found in most of the country. These will just look like regular crop fields to most people.

metas.title: Russian Language
metas.description:
The Russian language can be found in Ukraine, particularly in the east and south. While there are several differences between Russian and Ukrainian, these are some of the most noteworthy:

The letters Ы ы, Э э are only found in Russian.

The Russian word for street is улица, abbreviated ул.

The Russian word for city is город, abbreviated г.

metas.title: Leaf Antenna Meta
metas.description: A leaf can be seen on the back of the Google car from: Ternopil to Zolochiv on the H02, Ternopil to Brody on the P39, and from Brody to Dubno on the E40. It can also be seen from Brody to Pochaiv on the P26 and from Dubno to Mlyniv on the E85.

metas.title: Odesa Silver Car
metas.description: The older 2011 coverage in Odesa was made using a silver car with a short antenna, rather than a black or white car with a long antenna. The car may sometimes be fully blurred.

metas.title: Kryvyi Rih Red Soil
metas.description: Red soil can be seen on some ultra-rural dirt tracks around the iron mine in Kryvyi Rih, due to mining activity. Brazilian-style poles can also be seen, making locations around the mine very convincing bait. The foliage, however, will be significantly less tropical, and a long antenna can be seen.

metas.title: Kryvyi Rih Red Band
metas.description: These poles, with a red band across them, are unique to Kryvyi Rih.

metas.title: Sunflower Bus Stops
metas.description: Bus stop shelters with a vibrant yellow-and-green paint scheme, featuring sunflowers and the name of a local brand (Оліс), can be found in the Mykolaiv and Kherson oblasts.

metas.title: Ivano-Frankivsk Glitch
metas.description: Within Ukraine, this visual glitch is unique to the city of Ivano-Frankivsk.

metas.title: Red-Reflector Bollards
metas.description:
These “Polish” bollards can be found in the Zakarpattia Oblast. They have a red reflector that wraps around the bollard.

They are identical to the standard bollard used in Poland (hence the name).

metas.title: Hungarian Signs
metas.description: The area near the border with Hungary is majority Hungarian. As a result, you will see a lot of signs with Hungarian language on it – bilingual or even monolingual.

metas.title: Hungarian Architecture
metas.description: In addition, the villages in this region look similar to Hungarian architecture. Settlements are fairly linear and organised, with predominantly single-storey houses that are closer to the street. Many roofs have orange tiles or diamond-shaped slate tiles that are similar to roofs found in central European countries like Hungary, Czechia and Slovakia.

metas.title: Chernobyl Coverage
metas.description:
Google sent a special car trekker to the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, where the nuclear disaster happened in the 1980s. This car goes from Ivankiv all the way to the abandoned town of Pripyat.

On most of the road to Pripyat, you will not really be able to tell that you are inside the Exclusion Zone. However, inside Pripyat you will see completely abandoned and overgrown buildings, giving the place an eerie look.

metas.title: Chernobyl Yellow Flag
metas.description: On one side of the road going to Chernobyl, a yellow flag with an Opel logo can be seen on the Google car’s antenna.

metas.title: UK Plates
metas.description:
UK front plates are white, while back plates are yellow. Some plates have a blue strip on the left, but most do not.

Additionally, you might see a plate with a green ‘Zero Emissions’ strip.
metas.note: Ireland uses white front and back plates, always with a blue strip on the left.

metas.title: Left-Hand Traffic
metas.description: The UK drives on the left side of the road.
metas.note: The UK, Ireland, Malta and Cyprus are the only European countries that drive on the left.

metas.title: No Stopping Lines
metas.description: Double yellow road lines are often found on the sides of marked roads, especially in urban areas. These lines indicate a no stopping zone.
metas.note: These lines can also be found in Ireland.

metas.title: UK Middle Lines
metas.description: These middle lines, that consist of long dashes with cat’s eyes (reflectors) in the gaps between the dashes, are a good clue for the UK.

metas.title: UK Bollards
metas.description: The most common bollard in the UK looks like this. It has a rounded shape, with a red reflector on the front and a white one on the back. The base and top are black, with a white stripe in the middle.

metas.title: Pole Steps
metas.description: The UK uses wooden poles. Pole steps bolted on the side of the pole are very common. These pole steps are shaped like a series of thin horizontal metal rods.
metas.note: Ireland also commonly uses wooden poles with pole steps.

metas.title: Black-White Chevrons
metas.description: Chevrons are black with white arrows.
metas.note: Irish chevrons are black with yellow arrows. French chevrons are blue with white arrows.

metas.title: Warning Signs
metas.description: Like most European countries, the UK uses triangular warning signs with a red border and a white background.
metas.note: This is mostly useful to distinguish between the UK and Ireland, as Ireland uses diamond-shaped yellow warning signs (being the only European country to do so).

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Direction signs in the United Kingdom can be blue, green, or white. Look for the letters A or M, as these are the major roads in the country. Smaller roads start with B.
metas.note: Irish direction signs are typically bilingual, with Irish names in italics, making them easy to distinguish from the UK ones.

metas.title: Street Signs
metas.description:
The UK commonly uses these white street signs with black text, that are positioned low to the ground. They are usually supported by two small posts. Many street signs in suburban areas will have a small cul-de-sac icon.

They can sometimes have different colours or feature small designs, like coats of arms.

metas.title: Give Way Sign
metas.description: UK yield signs feature the phrase “GIVE WAY”.
metas.note: Irish yields signs just have the word “YIELD”.

metas.title: Danger of Death
metas.description:
The yellow warning stickers on utility poles can be a good way to distinguish between the UK and Ireland.

The most important difference is that UK stickers feature a guy getting zapped by a lightning bolt.

The Irish stickers usually have a lightning bolt, but lack the guy getting zapped. They also often have an extra second rectangular sticker with a black outline, below the lightning bolt.

metas.title: Yellow Bollards
metas.description: This yellow traffic bollard is commonly found in the UK.

metas.title: Belisha Beacons
metas.description: Pedestrian crossing signs are almost non-existent in the UK. Instead, pedestrian crossings will often have these distinctive black and white striped poles, with a yellow light bulb on top.
metas.note: These signposts are also common in Ireland.

metas.title: Square Metal Gates
metas.description: Rural metal gates with square corners are very common in the UK.
metas.note: This is mainly useful to distinguish it from Ireland, where similar gates typically have rounded corners. Gates in Northern Ireland also typically have rounded corners.

metas.title: British Countryside
metas.description: The British countryside tends to be very green, with lots of hedgerows lining the road. Low, rolling hills are common throughout most of the country.
metas.note: The Irish countryside looks very similar, so make sure to look at other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Terraced Houses
metas.description: Terraced houses (row houses) are very common in the UK. This housing type shares walls on both sides with neighbouring homes. You will also see a lot of semi-detached houses, which share just one side wall with another house.
metas.note: 61% of the population lives in terraced or semi-detached houses, significantly more than most other European countries. The only European countries where terraced houses are this common are Ireland and the Netherlands.

metas.title: Red Brick Architecture
metas.description: Red brick buildings are common in many parts of the UK.
metas.note: Red brick architecture is also common in the Netherlands, Belgium, and Denmark, as well as parts of northern France.

metas.title: Suburban Estates
metas.description: Suburbs in UK towns tend to have a recognizable look. They typically feature near-identical houses, often semi-detached, usually with well-manicured lawns. The road layout can be maze-like, with lots of cul-de-sacs and curvy roads.

metas.title: Chimney Pots
metas.description: Many British buildings have distinct-looking chimneys with multiple so-called chimney pots. These pots are usually round and brick-coloured.

metas.title: Timber Framing
metas.description: Some buildings, both old and new, feature black-and-white timber framing.
metas.note: This is less common in Ireland.

metas.title: Smallcam Meta
metas.description: The UK has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.

metas.title: Country Flags
metas.description: Occasionally, you can find one of the 4 country flags, which will tell you where in the UK you are.

metas.title: Road Numbers
metas.description:
A- and B-roads are grouped by their first digit, for example A380 and B3217 are located in the southwest of the country. Motorways also generally follow this pattern.

Beware that roads starting with any digit from 1 to 8 can also be found in Northern Ireland.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description:
Landline phone numbers in the UK always have nine or ten digits after the 0 trunk code. The first two to four digits after the 0 are the area code. Unfortunately for Geoguessr players, there is not much rhyme or reason to their geographic ordering.

However, the area codes of some large cities are still worth memorising. The most important ones are summarised in this infographic. Notably, all of Northern Ireland uses the phone code 028, and all of London uses 020.

A complete overview of all other area codes is available in this infographic.

metas.title: City Bins
metas.description: Bins in urban areas often have the city name on them.

metas.title: Scottish Highlands
metas.description: The Scottish Highlands can be distinguished by the semi-barren, very mountainous landscape.
metas.note:
A lot of Generation 4 coverage in the Highlands is from (early) spring, meaning that the vegetation often looks brown and yellow.

In addition, some of the most mountainous parts of Wales and Northern England can look similar.

metas.title: Scottish Bollards
metas.description:
In Scotland, you can often find these red and white bollards. They are round, bulky, and have a red-and-grey reflector that wraps all the way around.

They are sometimes found in other parts of the UK.
metas.note: The bollard looks similar to the French one. However, there are some small differences. For example, the Scottish bollard is round on the top, while the French one is more spiked.

metas.title: Passing Places
metas.description: These diamond-shaped ‘Passing Place’ signs are most commonly found in Scotland.

metas.title: Welsh Language
metas.description:
Welsh is a Celtic language that is spoken throughout Wales. Road signs in Wales are usually bilingual English and Welsh. Towns often have Welsh names too.

Welsh uses the letters D, W, and Y much more commonly than English. The double LL is also very distinct.
metas.note: Scottish Gaelic and Irish are both also Celtic languages. They can look somewhat similar to Welsh.

metas.title: Bilingual Markings
metas.description: In Wales, markings on the road are in both English and Welsh. One of the best examples of this is ‘Araf’, which means ‘Slow’. This marking is only found in Wales.
metas.note: Araf is not the only Welsh language marking you can find, it is just the most common. Whenever you see an obviously non-English marking next to an English one, consider guessing in Wales.

metas.title: Gaelic Signs
metas.description:
Scottish Gaelic is a Celtic language that is closely related to Irish. They have a very similar look and use accent marks commonly. Common and recognizable letter clusters include bh, dh, fh, mh, ai, ea, eo, and ui.

Scottish Gaelic on road signs is found most commonly in the Scottish Highlands, and is almost always found north of Glasgow.
metas.note: Scottish Gaelic on road signs will often be in green or yellow text. This will not happen with Welsh or Irish on road signs.

metas.title: Scottish Stone Architecture
metas.description: It is common to see houses made of large blocks of sandstone or granite in Scotland. Granite buildings are common in Aberdeen, red sandstone is common in Glasgow and Dumfries, and yellow sandstone is common in Edinburgh.

metas.title: Cornish Palms
metas.description: Cornish palms (Cordyline australis) in the UK are most commonly found in the far southwest along the coast and in Jersey. Although, they can rarely be found all along the west coast up to Scotland.

metas.title: Northern Ireland Stickers
metas.description: These black stickers with yellow text sometimes appear on lampposts in Northern Ireland.

metas.title: Isle of Man Gen 2
metas.description:
The Isle of Man is an island in the Irish Sea between the United Kingdom and Ireland. There is only Generation 2 coverage on the island. For country streak purposes, it is counted as part of the United Kingdom.

Plonk It has a more in-depth guide to the Isle of Man here.

metas.title: Jersey Gen 2
metas.description:
Jersey is an island in the English Channel between France and England. There is only Generation 2 coverage on the island. For country streak purposes, it is counted as part of the United Kingdom.

Plonk It has a more in-depth guide to Jersey here.

metas.title: Gibraltar
metas.description:
Gibraltar is a British Overseas Territory located at the southern tip of the Iberian Peninsula, bordering Spain. For country streak purposes, the territory is counted as part of the United Kingdom.

Plonk It has a more in-depth guide to Gibraltar here.

metas.title: Bermuda
metas.description:
Bermuda is a British Overseas Territory located in the North Atlantic Ocean.

Plonk It has a more in-depth guide to Bermuda here.

metas.title: Falkland Islands
metas.description:
The Falkland Islands is a British Overseas Territory located in the South Atlantic Ocean.

Plonk It has a more in-depth guide to the Falkland Islands here.

metas.title: South Georgia
metas.description:
South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands is a British Overseas Territory located in the South Atlantic Ocean.

Plonk It has a more in-depth guide to the territory here.

metas.title: Pitcairn Islands
metas.description:
The Pitcairn Islands is a British Overseas Territory located in the South Pacific Ocean.

Plonk It has a more in-depth guide to the Pitcairn Islands here.

metas.title: British Indian Ocean Territory
metas.description:
The British Indian Ocean Territory is a British Overseas Territory, unsurprisingly located in the Indian Ocean.

Plonk It has a more in-depth guide to the British Indian Ocean Territory here.

metas.title: The Lake District
metas.description: The Lake District is very hilly, with a lot of exposed rocks and stone walls. It can look like the Scottish Highlands, but Scotland is generally less rocky.

metas.title: London Street Signs
metas.description: London street signs have a distinct look. They usually feature the street name in black, followed by the postcode and borough in red.

metas.title: Aberdeen Signs
metas.description: Street name signs in Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire typically feature a simple blue background with white lettering.
metas.note: Central Aberdeen uses a different, black-and-yellow design.

metas.title: Townland Signs
metas.description:
Signs with green text underneath the street name, indicating the townland, can be found in the western part of Northern Ireland. 

Especially towards the north of the shaded area, there may be a metal divider between the two lines.

metas.title: London Electric Car
metas.description: Some of the Generation 4 coverage in London was taken by a white electric vehicle, with this distinct back of the car visible.
metas.note: A similar car was used in Dublin and Germany, so make sure to check out other clues as well.

metas.title: Birmingham Yellow Tape
metas.description: The majority of poles and signposts in Birmingham have either yellow tape or yellow paint wrapped around them. Lampposts will also usually have this yellow sticker.

metas.title: Twenty's Plenty
metas.description: Speed signs with green borders with the text “Twenty’s Plenty” are mostly found in and around Glasgow.

metas.title: Yellow Plates
metas.description: The most common and recognisable Alaskan licence plate is all yellow. In Generation 4 coverage you can also get a plate with a large orange circle in the middle. Front plates are required in Alaska.

metas.title: Alaskan Highway Shield
metas.description: The Alaskan highway shield has an image of the Big Dipper constellation on the bottom left.

metas.title: Alaska Features
metas.description: Trees in Alaska are generally thinner and have less broad leaves than those seen in the other 49 states.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description: On a lot of the Alaskan coverage you will be able to see tall, snow covered mountains.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description: In most of the US, Generation 2 is rare. However, Alaska has a fair amount of Generation 2 coverage.

metas.title: Alaska Has Generation
metas.description: Alaska has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front, with the front of the white car being very visible. The blur can also be fully transparent.

metas.title: Shitcam Coverage
metas.description: Alaska is the only state in the US where shitcam coverage is prevalent. This coverage is lower resolution with more faded colours, compared to other camera generations. Also, a large blur can be seen at the bottom of the page.

metas.title: Map Shows Which
metas.description: This map shows which parts of Alaska have coverage and which camera generation was used to cover each road.

metas.title: Alaska Features
metas.description: Generation 4 coverage in Alaska is concentrated around the city of Anchorage.

metas.title: Most Interior And
metas.description: Most of interior and northern Alaska lies in subarctic or tundra climate zones. These areas feature relatively low amounts of forest undergrowth and shorter trees.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description: The Alaskan towns in the Alexander Archipelago, on the British Columbia border have a unique look. Tall mountains with lush green forests can be seen in the background, with the majority of buildings made of wood. In addition, Generation 2 coverage is often overcast and misty.
metas.note: Coastal areas of Oregon and Washington can have a similar appearance in terms of landscape and foliage.

metas.title: Alaska Features
metas.description: The only two major urban areas in Alaska are Anchorage and Fairbanks.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Most of the suburban areas in Alaska are in and around Anchorage.These areas feature wide roads, commercial districts, and sometimes heavy traffic. Mountains can commonly be seen in the distance.
metas.note: Fairbanks has some similar areas, but mountains are less prevalent.

metas.title: Aspen Trees Populus
metas.description: Aspen trees (Populus tremuloides) can be found in lower elevation areas of interior and south-central regions of Alaska. These trees have white bark and rounded leaves.

metas.title: Valley Landscape
metas.description: Due to Alaska’s very cold climate; agricultural fields are mainly found in the south of the state, mostly in the Matanuska Valley and Kenai Peninsula.

metas.title: Alaskan Pipeline Which
metas.description: The Alaskan pipeline which is usually visible from main roads, can be seen at these points. This is an easy way to identify Alaska as there are no similar pipelines in the rest of the US.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Juneau, Alaska’s Capital city, is the largest settlement in the Alaskan panhandle. Therefore, it is much more ‘built up’ than other towns in this area. The city is surrounded by heavily forested mountains and hills.

metas.title: Anchorage Features
metas.description: Fire hydrants in Anchorage are typically pale pink or pale yellow in colour.

metas.title: Fairbanks Features
metas.description: Fire hydrants in Fairbanks are commonly either bright yellow or a combination of colours (most commonly yellow and blue).

metas.title: Shitcam Coverage
metas.description: Shitcam is only found around Anchorage and Fairbanks, and parts of the road that connects them.
metas.note: This map shows all places where this camera can be found. Keep in mind coverage may be updated in some places, therefore you may come across regular coverage in places highlighted here.

metas.title: North End Dalton
metas.description: The North end of the Dalton Highway features a flat and snowy landscape and an overcast sky. A small ridge of hills can be seen to the west of the highway in certain spots.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description: The Denali highway, stretching from Cantwell to Paxson in central Alaska, is a mostly gravel highway in the ‘Alaska’ mountain range. This road runs generally east to west, is covered in the generation 2 camera, and was taken in late summer, so wildflowers and green shrubby plants are common.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description: The Steese Highway is another gravel highway that goes from Fairbanks to the town of ‘Central.’ Similar to the Denali highway, this road runs generally east to west and is covered in generation 2. The difference, however, is that the mountains along this road are noticeably lower than the ones adjacent to the Denali Highway.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description: Highway 5, from the Yukon border to Tetlin Junction, can be recognized by the foggy, rainy weather, and Generation 2 camera.
metas.note: The Top of the World Highway on the Canadian side also has similar weather, but is mostly paved and has no outer lines, unlike the American side, which is only paved west of Chicken, and does have outer lines.

metas.title: Prudhoe City
metas.description: Prudhoe Bay, the northernmost town in America covered by street view, can be recognized by cold, dead landscape, overcast clouds and lack of tall buildings. A second Google car can sometimes be seen.

metas.title: Nome Unalakleet And
metas.description: Nome, Unalakleet and Galena are three isolated Alaskan towns which are covered only by trekker. The trekker’s lime green hat or black and white beanie can be seen.
metas.note: The trekker’s black and white bandana can only be seen in Nome.

metas.title: Bermuda Location
metas.description: Bermuda is a British overseas territory, located north of the Caribbean sea. As such, it is counted as the United Kingdom for country streaks purposes.

metas.title: Left-Hand Traffic
metas.description: Bermuda drives on the left side of the road.

metas.title: Black Google Car
metas.description: Bermuda features a black Street View car with the entire front sides of the vehicle typically visible.

metas.title: Vegetation & Houses
metas.description: The most typical look of Bermuda is somewhat dense vegetation, consisting of fairly small trees and a lot of bushes, combined with single family houses strewn across the landscape.

metas.title: Bermuda Plates
metas.description: Bermudan licence plates are all-white, fairly long, and with black digits, somewhat contained to the middle of the plate.

metas.title: Single Yellow Line
metas.description: Most roads in Bermuda contain a single solid yellow middle line with no outer road lines.

metas.title: Zig-Zag Lines
metas.description: You will occasionally see these white zig zag road lines on Bermuda.

metas.title: Pastel Architecture
metas.description: Most buildings on Bermuda are single family stone houses painted in pastel colours. They will almost always have completely white roofs.

metas.title: Palms
metas.description: Palms are very commonly found on Bermuda.

metas.title: Blue Water
metas.description: On Bermuda you will never be far away from the ocean, and the water will very often look distinctly light blue.

metas.title: Hamilton Architecture
metas.description: Hamilton is by far the largest town on Bermuda, and as such, the downtown area is distinct due to its many large, densely built multi-floor buildings.

metas.title: Grey Brick Buildings
metas.description: The northwestern tip of Bermuda can be recognised by the many large buildings made of unpainted grey brick.

metas.title: Boat Trekker
metas.description: A boat trekker can be seen on the eastern coast of Bermuda. It can be seen going around Saint George’s Harbour and past Fort St. Catherine on the northeast tip of the island.

metas.title: British English & Metric
metas.description: The English-speaking parts of Canada use British English spelling (e.g. centre; colour). In addition, Canada mostly uses the metric system. For example, speed is measured in kilometres per hour.
metas.note: This is useful to distinguish between the US, where American English spelling and (usually) the imperial system are used. For example, the US measures speed in miles.

metas.title: Gen 2 Halo
metas.description: Canada has a fair amount of Generation 2 coverage, especially in rural or remote areas. Generation 2 can be recognized by the big circular car blur and the halo-like colour distortion in the sky.
metas.note: Generation 2 is very rare in the US. If you are between Canada and the US, and the location is in Generation 2, you are much more likely to be in Canada.

metas.title: Gen 3 Mirrors
metas.description:
Generation 3 is significantly more common in Canada than in the US.

In addition, the side mirrors are blurred out differently: While they generally appear as two peaks in Canadian Gen 3 coverage, you will mostly see a single peak in the US.

metas.title: Smallcam Generation
metas.description: Canada also has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot. When the car isn’t blurred properly, you will usually see a mirror sticking out on the right side.

metas.title: Diamond T-Junctions
metas.description:
Canada uses unique diamond-shaped T-Intersection signs.

Some provinces use different designs. You can learn more about those in the region guessing section.
metas.note: Canada is the only country in the world where you can find these signs. The US, for example, uses rectangular T-Intersection signs.

metas.title: Maximum Speed
metas.description: Canada uses the word ‘maximum’ on speed signs. Because speed is measured in kilometres instead of miles, the numbers tend to be higher than the US which can be identifiable from afar.
metas.note: The US uses the words ‘speed limit’ on such signs. In addition, speed limits ending with 5 are more common in the US, and the ‘speed limit’ text takes up two lines versus one for ‘maximum’ in Canada.

metas.title: Single Yellow Line
metas.description: Canadian roads usually have single yellow centre lines. However, double middle yellow centre lines are still decently common.
metas.note: Double yellow centre lines are more common in the US. This is not a 100% reliable clue, so make sure to use this along with other clues.

metas.title: Community Mailboxes
metas.description:
You can sometimes find communal mailboxes in Canada. Personal mailboxes are still very common, though.

Canada Post has a red logo, which sometimes appears on mailboxes.
metas.note: These communal mailboxes are very rare in the US. In addition, the US Postal Service has a blue logo.

metas.title: Symbolic Signs
metas.description: Canadian road signs tend to be less wordy compared to their US counterparts. Good examples of this are railroad crossing and yield signs. In the US, these usually have the literal words ‘railroad crossing’ and ‘yield’ written on them, whereas in Canada, these signs are typically blank.

metas.title: Province Plates
metas.description: Each province has its own unique licence plates, some recognizable from afar even when blurred. Multiple provinces do not require front plates, which can be useful when deciding between provinces.
metas.note:
Since 2019, front plates are no longer required in New Brunswick. However, you should still expect to see them in older coverage. As well, all commercial vehicles in Newfoundland and Labrador are required to use front plates, and so it is possible to see them on vans and pickup trucks.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: French Language
metas.description: French is the majority language in Québec and parts of New Brunswick.
metas.note: At the federal level, French has official status alongside English, so you can sometimes find bilingual signs in other parts of Canada. In addition, French is also spoken in several communities in Nova Scotia, Ontario and Manitoba.

metas.title: Highway Shields
metas.description:
Each province has their own highway shields with unique designs.

The green Trans-Canada Highway shield, shown in the top right of the image, can be found in all 10 provinces.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Kilometer Markers
metas.description:
Each province has its own unique kilometre markers that vary slightly.

Notably, Ontario KM markers have a white square at the bottom, which is unique to the province.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Province Speed Signs
metas.description:
Some provinces have unique speed signs.

Ontario speed limit signs may have a black section on the bottom with the words ‘km/h’ or ‘begins’ written in white.

British Columbian signs also include the ‘km/h’ but lack the black section.

Québec can sometimes have French on their speed limit signs.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Alberta Bollard
metas.description: Alberta has a unique black and white bollard that is often found at intersections. It has a cylindrical shape and two black bands that wrap all the way around. It is one of the most useful Canadian bollards to learn because it appears so frequently.
metas.note: Some Alberta bollards have a yellow band between the two black bands, instead of a white one. Blue bands can also rarely be seen, particularly in and around Calgary, while green bands are rarely seen in and around Edmonton.

metas.title: Manitoba Bollard
metas.description:
Manitoba uses black and grey painted bollards. Most of the time an orange stripe will be present below the grey one.

Wooden, rectangular bollards of this form are typically found further north in Manitoba.
metas.note: Bollards in this format with just a black top are seen in Manitoba and Saskatchewan.

metas.title: BC Bollard
metas.description: British Columbia has black-and-white bollards with a thin, slightly curved shape. It is most commonly found on Vancouver Island, but can be found all throughout the province.
metas.note: They can look superficially similar to the Alberta bollard. However, the thin shape and the wider spacing of the two black bands should help you tell them apart.

metas.title: Quebec Guardrail Bollard
metas.description: Québec has unique bollards that are always attached to guardrails. They are long, thin white poles with a red or green reflector at the top.

metas.title: Quebec Fire Hydrants
metas.description:
You will often find these yellow fire hydrant markers atop signposts in Québec.

In Québec City these markers will usually have a blue rectangle and markers in Trois-Rivières are distinctly small.
metas.note: Sometimes the markers will have different colours. Beware that Edmundston, in New Brunswick, uses these too.

metas.title: Quebec Road Markers
metas.description: You can find these rectangular markers on the sides of the roads in Québec. The colours can vary.
metas.note: These can be rarely found on urban divided highways in New Brunswick.

metas.title: Ontario Road Markers
metas.description: You can find these diamond-shaped markers on the sides of the roads in Ontario. The colours can vary.

metas.title: Ontario Wire Guardrail
metas.description: In Ontario, you will often see these types of guardrails. They consist of cylindrical wooden posts, held together by precisely three metal wires. Some posts are marked by a reflective white band.

metas.title: New Brunswick Bollard
metas.description: These flat, yellow bollards can be found on the Trans-Canada highway in New Brunswick.

metas.title: NWT Bollard
metas.description: The Northwest Territories has a black and white bollard with a cylindrical shape and two thick, black bands.
metas.note: It looks very similar to the Alberta bollard. However, the Alberta bollard has thinner black bands.

metas.title: Transformer Orientation
metas.description: The transformers on poles will face the road in British Columbia and New Brunswick, while in other provinces, it will be parallel with the wires.

metas.title: 45-Degree Transformers
metas.description: Transformers on Prince Edward Island and Nova Scotia will be installed at a 45° angle relative to the road. On PEI, red numbers will usually be written on the side.

metas.title: Ontario Pole Tops
metas.description: These distinctive pole tops are most commonly found in Ontario. They have two insulators to the side, and one on top. The side insulators are affixed to the pole with a distinct attachment. Sometimes, multiple of them can be stacked on top of each other.
metas.note: They can occasionally appear in British Columbia, Nova Scotia, or other provinces more rarely.

metas.title: Quebec Angled Insulators
metas.description: Some Québec poles have recognizable pole tops with insulator rods that are angled slightly upwards.

metas.title: Quebec Pole Sticker
metas.description: Québec poles may sometimes have a vertical black and yellow label. There is a small ‘Q’ in the black part.

metas.title: PEI Pole Sticker
metas.description: Poles on Prince Edward Island usually feature a small white sticker.

metas.title: Saskatchewan Alternating Insulators
metas.description: Pole top insulators in Saskatchewan alternate. While one pole will have one insulator on the left and two on the right, the next will have two on the left and one on the right.

metas.title: Quebec T-Signs
metas.description: Québec T-Intersection signs do not feature the chequerboard pattern.

metas.title: Newfoundland T-Signs
metas.description: Newfoundland T-Intersection signs feature a rectangular yellow border around the diamond shape.

metas.title: Green Backed Signs
metas.description: Road signs in British Columbia can have green backsides.
metas.note: Green backsides are also somewhat common on Prince Edward Island.

metas.title: Hanging Signs
metas.description: Signs in British Columbia are sometimes hung down from these unique signposts.

metas.title: Concrete Barriers
metas.description: British Columbia predominantly uses concrete barriers instead of guardrails.

metas.title: Manitoba Sticker
metas.description: You can sometimes find a green and white striped sticker on signposts in Manitoba.

metas.title: Saskatchewan Triangles
metas.description: Signposts in Saskatchewan can feature these white triangles. The number can vary.

metas.title: Dashed Middle Line
metas.description: You can sometimes find white dashes between the yellow centre lines in Saskatchewan.

metas.title: Arrêt Signs
metas.description: Stop signs with the word ‘Arrêt’ are unique to Québec.

metas.title: Bilingual Stop Signs
metas.description: Stop signs with both ‘Stop’ and ‘Arrêt’ are most commonly found in New Brunswick.
metas.note: Such stop signs can rarely be found in other provinces.

metas.title: Alberta Grid Roads
metas.description:
Rural roads in Alberta are numbered sequentially. This makes it easy to figure out your exact location using just a road sign.

Township roads (Twp Rd) run east to west. Their numbers increase the more north you go.

Range roads (Rge Rd) run north to south. Their numbers increase the more west you go. These numbers reset a couple of times.

This infographic shows which numbers are found where. You need to multiply the numbers on the grid by 10 to get the road numbers. For example, the junction in the image example is found just north of Red Deer.
metas.note: Similarly named roads can also sometimes be seen in Saskatchewan, however they are more common in Alberta.

metas.title: Manitoba Grid Roads
metas.description:
Rural roads in Manitoba are organised in a grid and referred to only by their number and cardinal direction.

Roads ending in N run east to west. Their numbers increase by one for every mile north of the US border.

Roads with E or W run north to south. They tell you their position relative to the principal meridian, located just west of Winnipeg.

For instance, this image was taken 105 miles north of the US border and 147 miles west of the principal meridian.

metas.title: Alberta Wire Guardrail
metas.description: This guardrail, with small poles connected by three or four metal wires, can rarely be found on major highways in Alberta.

metas.title: Newfoundland Pyramids
metas.description: In Newfoundland and Labrador, most wooden posts on guardrails have this pyramid shaped top. Occasionally, you can spot them on standalone posts and signposts as well.

metas.title: Newfoundland Hydrants
metas.description: Fire hydrants in Newfoundland often have a diamond-shaped marker next to them.

metas.title: Newfoundland Sign Boxes
metas.description: You can spot these wooden boxes holding up signs in Newfoundland and Labrador.

metas.title: Within Eastern Canada
metas.description:
Within Eastern Canada, double yellow lines are most common in Nova Scotia, followed by Québec and Prince Edward Island. Ontario prefers single yellow lines for this purpose, but will occasionally use them.

For some empirical research, please see this document.

metas.title: Ontario Traffic Cones
metas.description:
Ontario uses distinct orange and black striped traffic cones.

Québec, on the other hand, has unique orange and white striped traffic cones.

metas.title: Quebec Chevrons
metas.description: Québec is the only Canadian province that uses red and white chevrons.
metas.note: The rest of Canada uses the classic yellow and black chevrons.

metas.title: Rectangular Lampheads
metas.description: New Brunswick and Nova Scotia commonly use lampheads with a rectangular shape.

metas.title: Curved Lamp Arms
metas.description: Lamp arms on utility poles in Nova Scotia are usually curved and much shorter than in the rest of Canada.
metas.note: Short lamp arms may occasionally be found in other parts of Canada.

metas.title: Western Mountains
metas.description: Western Canada is very mountainous. The highest mountains are in British Columbia, western Alberta, and parts of Yukon. Outside these provinces, large mountains are rare to non-existent in Canada.

metas.title: Yukon Landscape
metas.description: Yukon has a very northern, boreal landscape that is mostly hilly, sometimes with large mountains in the distance. Coniferous trees line the roads and the further north you go, the thinner and shorter the trees get. While this region recently got a lot of new Generation 4, older Generation 2 coverage is still very common.

metas.title: BC Interior Landscape
metas.description: The landscape in the interior of southern British Columbia, mostly centred around the towns of Kamloops and Kelowna, has a distinct look. It is generally hilly and a little more arid than the rest of BC, The vegetation consists of sprawling brown grasslands, and pine tree forests on the hillsides.

metas.title: Great Plains Landscape
metas.description: The Great Plains are mostly flat, with some rolling hills. There is a lot of agriculture, very few trees, and it is very sparsely populated. The landscape gets drier the further south-southwest you go, with the driest parts near the border with the US state of Montana.

metas.title: Canola Fields
metas.description: Canola is grown in the central southern prairies, and it can be found almost nowhere else in Canada. It is visually similar to a field of bright yellow flowers.
metas.note: Canola is also very common in the US state of North Dakota.

metas.title: Rouyn-Noranda Grid
metas.description: The region around Rouyn-Noranda in northwestern Québec can mainly be characterised by the north-south grid, along with the slightly hilly landscape featuring many agricultural fields nestled between the forests, which have many shorter trees as well as thin birches.

metas.title: Saskatchewan Hills
metas.description: Southern Saskatchewan has many river valleys, which means that the province can have a barren hilly landscape; much more so than the rest of the Canadian Great Plains, which tends to be really flat.
metas.note: Some of this hilliness extends into southern Alberta and Manitoba.

metas.title: Manitoba Aspen
metas.description: Aspen trees are common in the forested parts of Manitoba. They are recognizable by their white, birch-like trunks. In most seasons, they have regular green leaves, but in fall coverage, they turn a characteristic bright yellow colour.

metas.title: Canadian Shield
metas.description: The Canadian Shield extends through the eastern part of Canada. Therefore, you will commonly see exposed rocks on street view in the highlighted area.

metas.title: Quebec-Windsor Corridor
metas.description: The Québec City-Windsor Corridor is the most densely populated part of Canada. It is mostly flat and green, with a patchwork of agriculture and occasional forest cover.
metas.note: This area can look similar to the Great Lakes region in the US.

metas.title: PEI Red Soil
metas.description: Prince Edward Island soil has a distinct red tint to it. Potato farming is also very common on PEI.
metas.note: This type of soil can occasionally be seen in certain areas of New Brunswick and Nova Scotia.

metas.title: Balsam Fir
metas.description: The Balsam Fir is a very common species of tree found in Newfoundland. It has a Christmas tree-like appearance.
metas.note: While most commonly found in Newfoundland, the Balsam Fir can also grow in other parts of Eastern Canada and the US. For an overview, see this map.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description: Canadian phone numbers start with a three-digit area code. Both landlines and mobile phones use the same area codes.
metas.note:
Canadian phone numbers are formatted XXX XXX XXXX, with the area code being the first three digits. It is fairly common to see 7-digit numbers with the area code omitted.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Provincial Flags
metas.description:
Provincial flags appear decently often, so it is worth learning them. The Fleurdelisé of Québec in particular is very common.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Newfoundland Wooden Bins
metas.description: Bins made of wood planks can be seen on Newfoundland driveways. These are most commonly octagonal, however they can have other shapes.
metas.note: Although they are most common in Newfoundland, they can also sometimes be seen in other provinces, such as New Brunswick.

metas.title: Acadian Cultural Region
metas.description: Acadia is a French-speaking cultural region in the Canadian Maritimes. It does not have clearly defined borders, but is usually understood to at least include north and east New Brunswick. It has its own flag, which is very commonly seen in this region. The flag is a French-style tricolour with a yellow star in the blue band.
metas.note: There are some isolated Acadian communities in Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island (shaded pink on the minimap).

metas.title: Dempster Highway
metas.description:
The Dempster Highway (road numbers 5 and 8) connects the Klondike Highway (road number 2) in Yukon with the remote town of Inuvik in the Northwest Territories.

It is very recognizable: it is an unpaved road with Generation 2 coverage, dark brown soil, and a tundra landscape with short trees. It is mostly hilly and mountainous, but the section between Fort McPherson and Inuvik is flat. Closer to Inuvik, the weather gets cloudy.

metas.title: Top of the World Highway
metas.description: The Top of the World Highway west of Dawson City in Yukon has overcast Generation 2 coverage and is located mostly high up in the mountains, making it recognizable.

metas.title: Yukon Motorcyclists
metas.description: A group of motorcyclists can be seen in front of the Google car on this stretch of Highway 1 near Beaver Creek in Yukon.

metas.title: Banff/Jasper AB-93
metas.description: The AB-93 highway through Banff and Jasper National Park features distinct, gradual, and steep mountains with a sharp peak on either side of the road. Tall, somewhat thin trees can also be seen.

metas.title: Drumheller Canyons
metas.description: The area near Drumheller, Alberta has distinct canyon-like treeless rock formations that comprise the landscape.

metas.title: Trans-Labrador Highway
metas.description: The Trans-Labrador Highway (road numbers 500 and 510) is a recognizable road, covered by Generation 4, mostly during sunny weather conditions. Thin pine trees line the side of the road, and it has a remote, cold, and northern feel. On many parts of the road, the sun is low in the sky.

metas.title: Gaspe Peninsula
metas.description: The inland roads of the Gaspé Peninsula feature densely forested mountainous terrain. It is particularly common to encounter overcast coverage in this region.

metas.title: Cape Breton Highlands
metas.description: The Cape Breton Highlands in northeastern Nova Scotia have an unusual amount of elevation for Eastern Canadian standards. It is very forested, with a mix of broad-leaf trees and pine trees.

metas.title: Newfoundland Route 430
metas.description: Route 430 on Newfoundland runs in a roughly south-southwest to north-northeast direction, with the road lines slightly washed out. It is located in a remote and sparsely populated part of the island. On many sections of the road, the coast is visible to your west. To your east, you will usually see low pine tree forests, and occasionally an imposing wall of mountains in the far distance.

metas.title: Iqaluit Signs
metas.description: Iqaluit is the capital of Nunavut, meaning it is more urban, and built up compared to other Nunavut settlements. The city features bilingual turquoise street signs. Speed limit signs are also uniquely bilingual. And on the outskirts of the city, these unique road markers can be seen.

metas.title: Churchill Antenna
metas.description: The remote town of Churchill in northern Manitoba features a trekker with a distinct thin antenna visible on the front right side of the car. The town also has unique street signs.
metas.note: This coverage is also seen in the surrounding area.

metas.title: Tulita Car
metas.description: This unique Google car and dark-coloured soil is found in Tulita, NWT. The car will most often look like this, but can also be fully blurred with just the antenna visible, or with the hood of the car visible.

metas.title: Sanikiluaq Snowmobile
metas.description: Sanikiluaq is a remote town situated in Hudson Bay. This snowy town was covered by a snowmobile whose driver wore a dark brown coat.
metas.note: Snowmobile coverage can be found outside the town on the ice-covered sea, where the driver is not visible.

metas.title: Inukjuak Snowmobile
metas.description: Inukjuak is a town in northern Québec. This town can be recognized by the snowmobile that is visible through the blur.
metas.note: In Sanikiluaq, the other town with snowmobile coverage, you will always see the driver.

metas.title: Grise Fiord
metas.description: Grise Fiord is the northernmost covered town in Canada. It can easily be recognized by these unique mountains and the ice floes on the coast.

metas.title: Resolute Landscape
metas.description: The northern town of Resolute can be recognized by the barren landscape with visible patches of snow.

metas.title: Cambridge Bay Gen 2
metas.description: Cambridge Bay is the only Nunavut settlement to have Generation 2 trekker coverage.

metas.title: Qikiqtarjuaq Mountains
metas.description: The town of Qikiqtarjuaq features distinct mountains, and red tinted soil.

metas.title: Kangiqsualujjuaq Landscape
metas.description: Kangiqsualujjuaq is a town in northern Québec, surrounded by green rocky hills, with trees visible in the distance.

metas.title: Nain Coast
metas.description: Nain is a small town on the Northeastern coast of Labrador. The town features colourful wooden houses, and trees in and around the town. To the north, a big hill is usually visible. And to the south, rocky cliffs can be seen on the other side of the bay. Additionally, kids can sometimes be seen walking beside the trekker.

metas.title: Red Bay
metas.description: Red Bay is a town on the southern coast of Labrador, and as such, the coast is always visible. It features slightly red soil, and most of the houses are painted white.

metas.title: Ellesmere Island
metas.description: The northernmost Google Street View coverage in the world is a trekker on Ellesmere Island in northern Nunavut. It shows a glacier in a rocky, desolate landscape that is devoid of any vegetation.
metas.note: This coverage is sometimes used in maps to improve and standardise the scoring range. As a result, you might encounter this trekker in competitive maps like ACW, despite it not being pinpointable.

metas.title: Gen 3 Trekker
metas.description:
The vast majority of coverage in Costa Rica was taken with a Generation 3 trekker camera. It can typically be recognised by being closer to the ground than cameras mounted to cars. On urban rounds it can also often be recognised by the trekker being on sidewalks, rather than in the middle of the roads.

There are also some official tripods inside buildings.

metas.title: Spanish Language
metas.description: Like in most of Latin America, Spanish is the official language of Costa Rica.
metas.note: No other trekker-only country has Spanish as its main language.

metas.title: Costa Rica Plates
metas.description: Costa Rican licence plates are typically short and white, with blue text, giving it a light blue tint through the blur.

metas.title: Round Concrete Poles
metas.description: Utility poles are typically round and made of concrete.

metas.title: Alto Stop Sign
metas.description: Like Mexico and Guatemala, Costa Rican stop signs feature the word “ALTO”.

metas.title: Limited Coverage
metas.description: The coverage in Costa Rica is very limited, mainly being found in and around San José and by the northern west coast. There is also coverage on Cocos Island, located 500 kilometres southwest of the coast, as well as a boat trekker around Caño Island by the southern west coast.

metas.title: Beach Trekkers
metas.description: Beach trekkers are mostly found on the northern east coast, but can also be found west of San José and on Cocos Island.

metas.title: Rural Forest
metas.description: Most rural forest trekkers are found in central Costa Rica. Cocos Island also mainly consists of dense tropical forests.

metas.title: Urban Coverage
metas.description: Urban coverage is mainly found in and around San José and Cartago, but also exists in Liberia and Filadelfia de Guanacaste.

metas.title: Children's Museum
metas.description: The Children’s Museum in northern San José can be recognised by its grand castle-like exterior.

metas.title: National Museum
metas.description: Around the National Museum, you can find several wealthy-looking homes, as well as a small tower built in a style resembling towers on medieval European fortresses.

metas.title: Orange Pedestrian Bridge
metas.description:
An orange pedestrian bridge can be found going over a major highway at Parque de la Paz in southeastern San José.

While there is coverage throughout most of the park, you’re not likely to encounter anything but the bridge in a pinpointable map.

metas.title: La Sabana Park
metas.description: La Sabana Park has several sports facilities, including the National Stadium of Costa Rica, located in the western part of the park.

metas.title: University of Costa Rica
metas.description: The University of Costa Rica, in eastern San José, is fairly busy, with a lot of greenery and various medium-sized buildings strewn across the campus.

metas.title: Palacio de los Deportes
metas.description: Palacio de los Deportes is a stadium in Heredia, northwest of San José, which can be recognised by its boxy look combined with the red, blue and white colour scheme.

metas.title: San Jose Airport
metas.description: At the Juan Santamaría International Airport you can find the trekker walking in the middle of a major four-lane road. There is also coverage just outside the airport terminal.

metas.title: Bosque de la Hoja
metas.description: In Centro Recreativo Bosque de la Hoja, just east of San José de la Montaña, you can see the trekker being followed by three dogs through a pine forest.

metas.title: Los Manantiales
metas.description: In Recreational Park Los Manantiales, just southwest of Poás, you can find a road lined with sugarcane plantations and cornstalk dracaena plants.

metas.title: Laguna de Fraijanes
metas.description: At the entrance to Laguna de Fraijanes Recreational Park you can find a large orange wooden gate separating the road from a parking lot. As the name suggests, the park itself is situated around a small lagoon.

metas.title: Cartago Municipal Museum
metas.description: The Cartago Municipal Museum can be recognised by its palace-like facade with a neatly planted garden in front, as well as the railway in the middle of the street in front of the museum.

metas.title: Historical Site
metas.description: The Ruins of Cartago is the remains of a large catholic church near the centre of the city. The POI is one of the first things to show up when you zoom into the city.

metas.title: José Rafael Fello
metas.description: José Rafael “Fello” Meza Ivankovich Stadium in southern Cartago can be recognised by the dark blue walls surrounding it.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Costa Rica Institute of Technology can usually be recognised by the mountain range which can be seen to the south and east.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description:
By the entrance of Jardín Botanico Lankester, located southeast of Cartago, you can find a poorly maintained dirt road, surrounded by mountains in the distance, as well as a sign with the name of the garden.

Within the garden itself you will find a plethora of different plants, with the walkways having many soft curves, and almost never being straight.

metas.title: Turkey Features
metas.description: The Punta Leona Resort, which can be found by the “Playa Mantas” POI, can be recognised by the red brick pavement, with the bricks having the same shape as you’ll commonly find in Turkey.

metas.title: Liberia Features
metas.description: The coverage in Liberia can be recognised by a white building with rounded windows having brown wooden window frames. This building can be seen on all coverage in the town.

metas.title: Filadelfia Features
metas.description: Most of the coverage in Filadelfia de Guanacaste was taken on the edge of a park, with a distinct red brick pavement where the bricks are placed in the shape of an “L”.

metas.title: Dominican Republic Car
metas.description: This unique car was used for all street view coverage in the Dominican Republic. It can be recognized by the two metal bars, the thick black stripes on them, as well as the white hood visible at the front.
metas.note:
These stripes can also be found on one of the Mongolian cars, but the landscape should allow you to tell them apart.

Within the Americas, you will also see metal bars in Guatemala and Curaçao. However, they will not have thick black stripes.

metas.title: Square Concrete Poles
metas.description: Most electricity poles are square and concrete, with a reverse “L” shape at the top. Less commonly, round or octagonal poles are used.
metas.note: Within the Americas, only the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico and Uruguay use square poles.

metas.title: Yellow Top Plates
metas.description: DR licence plates are somewhat reminiscent of New Jersey plates, being pale yellow at the top and white at the bottom.
metas.note: The Dominican Republic is the only part of Latin America, apart from Puerto Rico and Panama, where front plates are not required.

metas.title: Dark Asphalt
metas.description: Roads in the Dominican Republic are often made of this smooth asphalt, which has a noticeably darker colour than in other countries.

metas.title: Pare Stop Signs
metas.description: Despite being located in Central America, stop signs in DR contain the South American “PARE”. Moreover, many signs are attached to yellow signposts.
metas.note: ‘PARE’ is also used in all of South America as well as Puerto Rico.

metas.title: Limited Coverage
metas.description: Street View coverage in the Dominican Republic is very limited. Only the capital Santo Domingo and the Northern city of Santiago de los Caballeros are covered.

metas.title: Northern Mountains
metas.description: If you have mountains to the North, you will always be in Santiago de los Caballeros.
metas.note: Although some parts of Santo Domingo are hilly, you will never see proper mountains like this one.

metas.title: Yellow Traffic Poles
metas.description: Yellow traffic light poles are typically found in the city of Santiago de los Caballeros.
metas.note: This only applies to traffic light poles - yellow signposts are common in both cities.

metas.title: Santo Domingo Downtown
metas.description: As the capital and largest city, Santo Domingo has a more developed downtown area, with tall buildings and wide avenues.

metas.title: ADN Street Signs
metas.description: Street name signs in Santo Domingo often contain the letters “ADN”, a reference to the Distrito Nacional, which the city is located in.

metas.title: Purple Pole Markings
metas.description: These black-and-purple pole markings are only found on poles in the Santo Domingo area.

metas.title: Santo Domingo Outskirts
metas.description: This type of landscape is found on the outskirts of Santo Domingo. It is characterised by narrow dirt tracks, whitish dirt, dried green shrubbery and debris next to the road.

metas.title: Santo Domingo Evening
metas.description: A small portion of the coverage in Santo Domingo was taken late in the evening. Similar imagery does not exist in Santiago de los Caballeros.

metas.title: Disjointed Coverage
metas.description:
The coverage in Greenland is divided into well over fifty small disjoint parts, with different weather conditions, seasons, landmarks and so on. Although the largest concentration is found on the southern half of the west coast, coverage can be found scattered along a lot of the coast. Since differentiating between some of them requires a lot of technical information, such as the position of the sun or clouds, this guide will only cover the parts with clear distinctive features, such as a unique Street View vehicle or an easily recognizable mountain.

Because of the limited coverage, this guide will be structured differently than most other guides. It will be divided into two main sections: one for land coverage and one for boat coverage. These two sections will each be divided into step 2, for larger towns and boats found in multiple locations, and step 3, for smaller settlements and boats found only in one place.

metas.title: Gen 3 Trekker
metas.description: All coverage in Greenland was taken with a Generation 3 trekker camera, which was often attached to a variety of vehicles.

metas.title: Greenland Vehicles
metas.description: Most locations with coverage will have their own odd and unique Street View vehicles, ranging from a red tractor to a snowmobile with a large box at the front.

metas.title: Colourful Wooden Houses
metas.description: Greenlandic architecture mainly consists of small, colourful, simple looking wooden houses, which even in cities are typically placed quite sparsely. The major cities have some larger buildings, which normally look fairly minimalistic.

metas.title: Barren Landscape
metas.description: The Greenlandic landscape is very barren, with no trees or taller vegetation and often featuring snow. Mountains and hills are common, with very limited flat areas. On top of that, almost all coverage was taken in coastal areas, so fjords and visible coastlines are very common.

metas.title: Boat Trekkers
metas.description: Boat trekkers are very common in Greenland, featuring a variety of different boats.

metas.title: Nuuk Grey Car
metas.description: While Nuuk is most easily recognized by the grey Street View car, it can also be recognized by being the largest city by far.

metas.title: Sisimiut Black Snowmobile
metas.description: The city of Sisimiut can be easily recognized by the black snowmobile with side mirrors pointing straight up. The coverage is generally very overcast and grey.

metas.title: Ilulissat Green ATV
metas.description: Most coverage in Ilulissat can be recognized by the green ATV with black bars and the driver wearing a beige hat. Note however that there are some small sections where the driver does not wear it. The coverage is fairly sunny and bright.

metas.title: Qaqortoq Red Car
metas.description: Qaqortoq can be recognized by the red rectangular car. The coverage is extremely sunny and the area is greener and less barren than most of the country.

metas.title: Aasiaat Thawing Snow
metas.description: The most noticeable feature of the coverage in Aasiaat is the windshield with a shiny red, white and black reflection. The large, round side mirrors can also be used to identify the town. The coverage is very sunny and has thick, thawing snow along most of the roads.

metas.title: Tasiilaq Grey Handguards
metas.description: The coverage in Tasiilaq can be recognized by the ATV with large grey handguards on either side. The coverage has a lot of very thin clouds and the area is somewhat green.

metas.title: Uummannaq Mountain
metas.description: Uummannaq has two distinctive features: a sharp mountain to the north and a green snowmobile with large black side mirrors. Neither of the two can be seen on all coverage but at least one can be seen on most.

metas.title: Narsaq Antenna
metas.description: Narsaq can be identified by the thin antenna seen on the right side of the car. The coverage is very sunny and fairly green.

metas.title: Maniitsoq Tractor
metas.description: The coverage in Maniitsoq was taken by a tractor, making it very recognizable. The coverage is overcast and fairly snowy.

metas.title: Narsarsuaq Black Hoodie
metas.description: The coverage in Narsarsuaq can be recognized by the driver wearing a black hoodie. The coverage was taken close to sunset on a very sunny day. There is also a fair amount of small bushes along the road, which is somewhat unusual in Greenland.

metas.title: Brattahlid ATV
metas.description: On the other side of the fjord from Narsarsuaq, a black ATV with an orange and purple bag in the front can be seen. The coverage has a lot of tall green grass and the dirt is unusually red for Greenland.

metas.title: Qeqertarsuaq Blue ATV
metas.description: Qeqertarsuaq is most easily recognized by the blue ATV with wide side mirrors. The coverage is fairly overcast and with a lot of yellow grass along the roads.

metas.title: Ittoqqortoormiit Wooden Box
metas.description: Most coverage in Ittoqqortoormiit can be recognized by the brown wooden box at the front of the ATV and the driver wearing a purple beanie. The ground is mostly grey and stony and the coverage is very sunny.

metas.title: Igaliku Mountains
metas.description: The coverage in and around Igaliku is most easily recognized by the wide, snow-covered mountain range to the northeast which looks very bright due to the setting sun. The green ATV, while not entirely unique on its own, can also be a useful hint.

metas.title: Paamiut Grey Car
metas.description: Paamiut can typically be recognized by the round, grey car which is often only barely visible. The coverage has a lot of thin clouds, but is still quite bright and the foliage consists of a mixture of yellow and green grass, and reddish moss.

metas.title: Kangerlussuaq Arid
metas.description: Kangerlussuaq can typically be recognized by the many streaky clouds in the sky, combined with the significant dryness. The roads near Kangerlussuaq can also be recognized by its unconventional look, with many small bushes, sandy soil with an almost arid climate.

metas.title: Kangerlussuaq White Truck
metas.description: The road east of Kangerlussuaq is easily recognized by the large white truck.

metas.title: Sisimiut-Kangerlussuaq Road
metas.description: The coverage connecting Sisimiut and Kangerlussuaq is easily recognized by the thick layer of snow on and around the road. The sun sets along the road, making the western parts very bright and the eastern parts very dark.

metas.title: Saattut Mountains
metas.description: To the north of Saattut you can see a wide mountain range shrouded in clouds, on the other side of a fjord. The paths covered are mostly dark, muddy dirt roads, and the foliage is mainly yellow grass tufts.

metas.title: Kulusuk Island
metas.description: The coverage on Kulusuk island has a round, red ATV, with a pyramid shaped mountain often seen to the northeast. The footage was taken right after sunset on a clear day, making it fairly dark.

metas.title: Kangaatsiaq Thawing Snow
metas.description: Kangaatsiaq has a large amount of thawing snow on the side of the roads. The sun is setting and there is a large body of water to the west.

metas.title: Ikerasak Monolith
metas.description: Ikerasak is most easily recognized by the large monolithic mountain to the west.

metas.title: Ukkusissat Cliff
metas.description: Ukkusissat is located below a tall cliffside to the east with mountains towering above it.

metas.title: Kuummiit Mountains
metas.description: Kuummiit can be recognized by two distinct mountains, a sharp one to the east and a rounder one to the north. The coverage is slightly dark due to clouds and the sun setting.

metas.title: Tiilerilaaq Grey Houses
metas.description: Unlike most houses in Greenland, the houses in Tiilerilaaq are commonly grey rather than colourful. The village can also be recognized by the ground, which is almost entirely made up of smooth, light grey rocks.

metas.title: Niaqornat Rocks
metas.description: Large, dark grey rocks towering over Niaqornat can be used to recognize the village.

metas.title: Siorapaluk Sand
metas.description: Siorapaluk can be recognized by the sandy, pyramid-shaped mountains to the north, combined with the wide sand beach below the village.
metas.note: Look for the store named “Pilersuisoq” to locate the village, as you have to zoom in very far on Google Maps to see the label of the village.

metas.title: Qaanaaq Icebergs
metas.description: To the southwest of Qaanaaq, you can see icebergs in a large body of water, and a wide mountain range on the other side, where the snow is bright white as it reflects the sunlight through the thick clouds.

metas.title: Kapisillit ATV
metas.description: A red and black ATV can be found in and around the village of Kapisillit, northeast of Nuuk. Many mountains in the distance are covered in a layer of snow.

metas.title: Kangerluk Mountains
metas.description: Kangerluk can be recognized by the evenly tall mountains with a particular shape on the other side of the fjord.

metas.title: Nuuk East Mountains
metas.description: On a small bit of coverage east of Nuuk you can see a large number of sharp mountains, powdered in snow. The coverage is somewhat dark due to the thick clouds and the sun being hidden behind the mountains.

metas.title: Narsarsuaq Ice Blocks
metas.description: About 20 km northeast of Narsarsuaq, you can find a small piece of coverage with large ice blocks in every direction.

metas.title: Upernavik Runway
metas.description: In Upernavik, the airport runway is covered on Street View, making it by far the widest paved road found on Street View in Greenland.

metas.title: Aasiaat Boat
metas.description: This boat, with a white cabin and a red roof, can be found by a multitude of towns and villages on the west coast. However, most of the coverage is in the general area around the city of Aasiaat.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: Similar to the previous boat, this one with a red square cabin can be found at multiple locations on the west coast, most significantly by and around Akunnaaq.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: A boat with a black box near the front, and a chequered pattern on the bow can be found fairly north on the east coast. While the western part of the coverage is very foggy and somewhat overcast, the eastern parts of the coverage is slightly less foggy and very sunny. A man wearing a black coat can also be seen captaining the boat.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: This bright red boat can be found on the east coast near the towns of Tiilerillaq and Kuummiit respectively. While the coverage near Tiilerillaq does not have a cloud in sight, the coverage near Kuummiit is somewhat overcast.

metas.title: Black And White
metas.description: A black and white boat, with a blue roof, is found between the towns of Kuummiit and Tasiilaq.

metas.title: Small White Boat
metas.description: This small white boat, with a brown wooden top and lights and monitoring devices, can be seen between Tiilerilaaq and Tasiilaq.

metas.title: Small Rounded Red
metas.description: A small, rounded red bow can be found on a boat going south of Tasiilaq.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: This small, red and black boat, with multiple people sitting in it, can be found in a fjord far north on the east coast.

metas.title: Wooden Fishing Boat
metas.description: This wooden fishing boat is found outside Ilulissat.

metas.title: Small White Boat
metas.description: This small, white boat with a silver handrail on the bow can be found west of Narsaq and east of Qaqortoq. While the sun is in the west on the coverage near Narsaq, it is in the east on the coverage near Qaqortoq.

metas.title: Large All White
metas.description: This large, all white boat can be seen in between Narsarsuaq with the opposing shore.

metas.title: Grey Boat Found
metas.description: A grey boat is found east of Nuuk.

metas.title: Mostly White Boat
metas.description: A mostly white boat, with extremely tall antennas on the rear can be found going into the fjord east of Nuuk.

metas.title: Blue Tinge Plates
metas.description: Guatemala has short licence plates, which when blurred will typically have either a blue tinge, or a hint of green on the left side.

metas.title: Guatemala Car
metas.description: This grey Street View car with a visible roof rack and side mirrors can be seen on all car coverage in Guatemala.
metas.note: The only other tropical country with a similar car is Laos.

metas.title: Tropical Landscape
metas.description: Guatemala is a tropical country, and is mainly covered by rainforests.

metas.title: Pastel Stone Houses
metas.description: Guatemalan architecture mainly consists of pastel painted stone houses, commonly with rusted sheet metal roofs. It is also somewhat common for buildings to be made out of exposed white brick.

metas.title: Thin Road Lines
metas.description: Similarly to Mexico, Guatemalan roads generally have solid white outer lines with a single yellow middle line. Road lines in Guatemala are generally significantly thinner than in Mexico.

metas.title: Alto Stop Sign
metas.description: Like Mexico and Panama, Guatemala uses the word “ALTO” on stop signs.

metas.title: Pink/Green Poles
metas.description: In Guatemala you will very commonly see poles painted with either pink, green or a combination of the two.

metas.title: Limited Coverage
metas.description: Guatemala has a fairly low amount of coverage, particularly in the north. Here you can see which roads are covered.

metas.title: Topography Map
metas.description: This is a topographic map of Guatemala. Generally speaking, the middle of the country is mountainous, while the south and north are fairly flat.

metas.title: Southern Flats
metas.description: The southern regions of Guatemala mainly consist of completely flat agricultural land. It is generally more built up than flat areas in the north.

metas.title: Central Mountains
metas.description: The central regions of Guatemala are generally mountainous.

metas.title: Northern Rolling Hills
metas.description: The northern regions of Guatemala are typically fairly flat. You will however usually see some hills or a slightly rolling landscape, rather than the complete flatness of the south.

metas.title: Oil Palm Plantations
metas.description: Oil palm plantations are primarily found in two general areas: in the southwest and just north of the central mountain range.

metas.title: Green Poles
metas.description:
Completely green utility poles are primarily found in the southeast of the country, but also on a road in the further north in the east and on a small stretch of road around Melchor de Mencos, near the end of the coverage in the far northeast.

These poles also feature small pole plates, which can further narrow down the road. This will be further explained in the next tip.

metas.title: Pole Plate Codes
metas.description: Most green utility poles contain a white pole plate, for which the top two characters will determine which road you are on. These roads and their corresponding characters are shown in this infographic.
