metas.title: Roof Rack Forward
metas.description: In most of the Guatemala coverage, the top right bar will be facing forward. This means that you can see this line on the side facing forward.

metas.title: Roof Rack Backward
metas.description: The opposite is true in southeastern Guatemala, where the line is facing backwards.

metas.title: Blue Rope Car
metas.description: In these regions, you can often see a blue rope on the bottom right bar.
metas.note: Sometimes it can be hard or almost impossible to see, in which case it might look like a normal backward facing bar.

metas.title: Missing Cap Car
metas.description: These regions in the south and northeast also have the backwards facing bar. The difference here is that the bottom right bar is missing the thin black cap, which is present in the other regions.

metas.title: Phone Code 2
metas.description: Phone numbers starting with a 2 are unique to Guatemala City.

metas.title: Phone Code 6
metas.description: Similarly, phone numbers starting with a 6 are unique to the Guatemala Department.
metas.note: Phone numbers starting with 7 are found anywhere except for Guatemala Department, and phones starting with 3, 4 or 5 can be found anywhere in the country.

metas.title: Lake Atitlan
metas.description: Lago de Atitlán is by far the largest lake in the mountainous regions of Guatemala. It is surrounded by mountains, and some volcanoes.

metas.title: Tikal Jungle Road
metas.description: A small dirt road in the middle of a dense jungle can be found north of Tikal, in the far north of the country.

metas.title: Quetzaltenango Bollards
metas.description: These small white bollards with two black stripes can be found on road 1 northeast of Quetzaltenango.

metas.title: PET-11 Alignment
metas.description: The PET-11, south of Las Pozas can be recognised by the slightly rolling landscape combined with its completely north-to-south road angle.

metas.title: CA9 Highway
metas.description: The CA9, going between Escuintla and the coast, can be recognised by being a divided highway with concrete pavement.

metas.title: Tikal Temples
metas.description:
A trekker featuring several Mayan temples can be found just west of the town of Tikal.

It is worth mentioning that while there are other Guatemalan trekkers featuring Mayan ruins, this is by far the most prominent and contains the largest and most intact temple structures.

metas.title: Electricista Stickers
metas.description: These white rectangular stickers that have the word ‘electricista’ written on them are unique to Guatemala City.

metas.title: Rainbow Plates
metas.description: The most common Hawaii licence plate is white with an arcing rainbow across the centre of the plate. When blurred, you can sometimes see the outline of the rainbow. Front plates are required in Hawaii.

metas.title: Hawaiian Language
metas.description:
Hawaii is the only state to use its own language, though English is still predominantly used. Most place names are in Hawaiian, so you can spot it on street signs, and other road markers.

Hawaiian is a vowel-oriented language that only uses eight consonants: H, K, L, M, N, P, W, and (ʻ), called an ʻOkina.

Every Hawaiian word ends in one of 5 vowels: A, E, I, O, or U.

Each vowel can also have a macron over it: Ā, Ē, Ī, Ō, and Ū.

These vowels are often combined to make Diphthongs. I.e. UI, AI, AE, etc...

metas.title: Smallcam Coverage
metas.description: Hawaii has a large amount of Generation 4 "smallcam" coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front, with parts of the car being visible. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot.

metas.title: Tropical Vegetation
metas.description:
Hawaii is known for its lush and tropical vegetation, with a variety of plants and trees. However, being a volcanic island chain, Hawaii has a wide range of landscapes, and as such vegetation as well.

You will often see plenty of ferns, tall grass, or other flowers on the sides of the roads.

metas.title: Volcanic Topography
metas.description: Topography on Hawaii is characterised by many sloping volcanoes, rugged cliffs, hills, valleys and craters. Such distinct topography combined with tropical vegetation is a good way to identify Hawaii.

metas.title: Hawaiian Homes
metas.description: Contemporary Hawaiian homes are typically 1 or 2 storey wooden structures, commonly lighter in colour. Many homes feature retaining walls made of volcanic rock.

metas.title: Yellow Pole Bands
metas.description: Thick yellow bands can sometimes be seen on poles in Hawaii.
metas.note: Make sure not to confuse this with the 3 stripes found on Californian poles.

metas.title: Guitar Pick Shield
metas.description: Hawaii uses highway shields that resemble a guitar pick, with the numbers on the bottom of the shield. Most highway signs also use yellow signposts.

metas.title: Gen 3 Antenna
metas.description: A stubby antenna can be seen in most Generation 3 coverage on Hawaii.
metas.note: The antenna is not always visible, so make sure to look out for other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Gen 2 Blur
metas.description: Hawaii has a fair amount of Generation 2 coverage, compared to other US states. Especially on more rural roads.
metas.note: Generation 2 can be recognized by the lower quality camera, and circular blur above and below the camera.

metas.title: Reflector Pattern
metas.description: Raised pavement markers in Hawaii will commonly be placed in a specific pattern: a single reflector, followed by four reflectors put close together and then a single reflector, repeating the pattern.

metas.title: Highway Numbering
metas.description:
State highways are grouped by their first digit, with 1 and 2 found on Hawaiʻi, 3 on Maui, 4 on Molokaʻi and Lānaʻi, 5 on Kauaʻi and 6 to 9 on Oʻahu.

Moreover, all four of the so-called interstate highways are located on Oʻahu.

metas.title: Black Car Islands
metas.description: On the three largest islands, namely Hawaiʻi, Maui and Oʻahu, smallcam coverage was taken with a black Google car.

metas.title: White Car Islands
metas.description: Smallcam imagery on the islands of Kauaʻi, Molokaʻi and Lānaʻi was captured by a white car. Just like with the black car, you will often be able to see the unblurred hood and mirrors.

metas.title: Gen 2 Islands
metas.description: Generation 2 and non-smallcam Generation 4 coverage can only be found on the islands of Hawaiʻi, Maui and Oʻahu. The other islands only have Generation 3 or smallcam coverage.

metas.title: Kauai Red Soil
metas.description: The Island of Kauaʻi is the furthest west island in Hawaii with official Google coverage. This island has deep red soil and has large rugged hills with lush, jungle-like vegetation.
metas.note: Other islands such as Maui and Molokaʻi have similar soil colours, but the hillsides on them will typically have less dense vegetation.

metas.title: Oahu Hills
metas.description: The Island of Oʻahu lies southeast of Kauaʻi. It is known for being home to the Honolulu urban area. It also is home to steep, lush hills, which can be commonly seen from all around the island, especially in Honolulu’s suburbs.

metas.title: Honolulu Skyline
metas.description: Honolulu, located on southern Oʻahu, is by far the largest city and urban area in Hawaii. If you are in a dense urban area and can see tall buildings, you will always be in or near Honolulu.

metas.title: Molokai Dryness
metas.description: The Island of Molokaʻi is just southeast of Oʻahu. It features deep red soil and a prominent volcano on the eastern end of the island. Especially in the older Generation 3 coverage, the vegetation appears very dry. Molokaʻi is also very sparsely populated.

metas.title: Lanai Cook Pines
metas.description: The Island of Lānaʻi is a small, yet distinct island that lies just south of Moloka’i. A volcano is found just east of the centre of the island, adjacent to the town of Lānaʻi. In this area, tall Cook pines are abundant. In addition, some main roads near the centre of the island are lined with younger Cook pines.

metas.title: Lanai Coastal Hills
metas.description: Towards the coasts of the island of Lānaʻi, hills dotted with dry grass and shrubby vegetation are commonly seen. These areas are very rural with few buildings.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The Island of Maui sits southeast of Molokaʻi. In the centre of the island, you will find dry and somewhat flat grasslands with one or both of the mountain ranges on the island visible.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Coastal areas of Maui are noticeably more lush and green. Banana plants, palm trees, and views of the mountains are all common.

metas.title: Grassy Plains
metas.description: The Island of Hawai’i (also referred to as The Big Island) is both the largest and farthest southeast island with Street View coverage in the state. The interior areas feature rolling, grassy plains and volcanic rocks. You can typically see one or more of the island’s volcanoes from the road.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: The coastal areas of the island of Hawai’i are where most of the towns and built-up areas on the island are located. These areas are typically more lush and have more trees and fern plants than the interior.

metas.title: Rural Roads Going
metas.description: Rural roads going through forests within a flat landscape are commonly found south of the city of Hilo, on the island of Hawaiʻi.
metas.note: Mountainous forests are dotted around Hawaii, but if you are in one, and you see red soil with Generation 3, consider guessing in Kauaʻi, the westernmost covered island.

metas.title: Hawaii Features
metas.description: Within Hawaii, a distinct green blur can only be seen on the island of Oʻahu.

metas.title: Infamous Hawaiian Lattice
metas.description: The infamous “Hawaiian lattice” can be recognized by the volcanic soil and rocks that are abundant in the region. Volcanic vegetation can also be seen lining the roads. Note that the angle of the roads is a big clue for the area, and that this lattice was built on the slope of Mauna Loa.

metas.title: Kaunakakai Features
metas.description: The town of Kaunakakai is the largest settlement on the Island of Molokaʻi. It is the only area on the island with an ‘urban’ vibe. As it is on Molokaʻi, the soil is somewhat red.

metas.title: Red Hill Easily
metas.description: The Red Hill can easily be recognised by this unique barren, red rocky landscape. Due to the high altitude, clouds are usually visible below you.

metas.title: Eastern Side
metas.description: On the eastern side of the island of Molokaʻi lies the Kamakou volcano, leading to a significantly hillier and slightly more vegetated landscape than the western parts of the island.

metas.title: Rolling Hills
metas.description: Kahoʻolawe is a small island that lies just to the southwest of Maui. It only has trekker coverage on small gravel roads and dirt trails, and is characterised by dry, shrubby vegetation, rolling hills, and dark red soil. On the western end of this coverage, several buildings can be seen.

metas.title: Gen 3 Trekkers
metas.description:
Martinique, officially the Department of Martinique, is an overseas department and region of France, in the Caribbean between Dominica and St Lucia. As such, for country streaks purposes, it is counted as France.

Coverage is very limited: there are just three Generation 3 trekkers. Instead of learning metas to identify the territory, it is more useful to just memorise what the trekkers look like.

metas.title: Rum Distillery
metas.description:
Habitation Clément is a rum distillery covered by a trekker. Due to it being pinpointable, some locations are on maps such as ACW. There are several landscapes in and around the distillery, including:

A warehouse with a truck and a forklift.

A view of the outside with hills in the background and machinery on display.

A rural dirt track outside with red soil and palm trees.

The inside of the distillery with the structure made of H-beam steel.

metas.title: Southern Trekker
metas.description:
The coastal southern trekker can be recognized by a few unique things:

In the north, the trekker starts off walking on a slightly hilly path, with other people.

Several houses with orange roofs can be seen.

A flatter and more open path can be seen, with the ocean slightly visible through the trees.

The coverage ends in the south with a car park and some stalls.

metas.title: Tropical Garden
metas.description: The Jardin de Balata trekker is the most tropical and humid feeling on Martinique. The trekker can be recognized by dark and damp feeling, the trees with buttress roots, ferns and bamboo. This man wearing a black shirt and grey cap can sometimes be seen with the trekker.

metas.title: Octagonal Poles
metas.description: Most utility poles in Mexico are made of concrete and have an octagonal shape. There will often be engravings on the side.
metas.note: Octagonal poles are also common in Colombia.

metas.title: Short Plates
metas.description: Mexico uses short licence plates with a large variety of designs. Front plates are required.
metas.note: For an overview of the most common regional designs, see step 2.

metas.title: Yellow Center Line
metas.description: The most typical Mexican road lines are white solid outer lines with a single unbroken yellow middle line.
metas.note: Single broken yellow middle lines and double yellow middle lines are also common.

metas.title: Mexican Bollard
metas.description: These small, cylindrical white bollards with a black base are unique to Mexico. A yellow reflector can sometimes be seen, as well as a flat version.

metas.title: Road Shields
metas.description: Mexico has two general road shields; one for national highways with “MEXICO” written at the top and a slightly curvy design, and one for state roads which have straight borders, and typically has the state initials written at the top.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: Mexican directional signs have a distinctly large, all-caps white font.

metas.title: Kilometre Markers
metas.description: Mexican kilometre markers are white, with black font and outline.

metas.title: Cacti Varieties
metas.description: Cacti, of many different species, are extremely common in Mexico.

metas.title: Alto Stop Sign
metas.description: Mexico uses the word “ALTO” on stop signs.
metas.note: All of South America uses the word “PARE”.

metas.title: Thick Arrow Signs
metas.description: Arrows on signs are noticeably very thick.

metas.title: Yellow Kerbs
metas.description: Yellow accents on kerbs and bridge barriers are quite common.

metas.title: Rooftop Water Tanks
metas.description: You will commonly see wide cylindrical, black or white water tanks on rooftops.

metas.title: Gas Stations
metas.description: OXXO and Pemex are two of the most popular gas station brands in Mexico.
metas.note: While less common, OXXO can still be found in other countries.

metas.title: Nahuatl Place Names
metas.description: Many place names in Mexico are of Nahuatl origin, featuring a lot of ‘x’ and ‘tl’ as well as ‘-ec’ and ‘-tlan’ suffixes.

metas.title: Circular Meters
metas.description: Mexico uses circular electricity counters.
metas.note: Circular electricity counters are not unique to Mexico and can also be found in the US, Guatemala, Dominican Republic and the Philippines.

metas.title: Pickup Trucks
metas.description: United States car brands are popular in Mexico. In particular, you will see a lot of pickup trucks.

metas.title: Gen 2 Availability
metas.description: Mexico is one of very few Latin American countries that has Generation 2 coverage.
metas.note: Brazil has some Generation 2, but it is considerably more rare, as most of it is overwritten.

metas.title: Gen 3 White Car
metas.description:
The Generation 3 coverage in Mexico mainly feature two cars:

A white car with a stubby antenna. There is a diagonal coil wrapped around the antenna.

A white car with a more visible back and a long red brake light instead of an antenna.

It is possible to find a white car without a stubby antenna, but with a tiny sliver visible where the antenna should be.

metas.title: Gen 4 Car
metas.description:
The Generation 4 cars in Mexico commonly have a visible front and can feature various different colour patterns. The three most common ones are:

Blue

White with a blue stripe

Black

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description: The first digit of Mexican area codes are regional and can be seen on this map.

metas.title: Postal Codes
metas.description: Similarly, Mexican postal codes can be seen on this map. They will commonly appear at the bottom of street signs, and are ordered alphabetically based on state names.

metas.title: State Plates
metas.description: Every state in Mexico has one or several unique licence plate designs. In this infographic you can find the most common and helpful ones.

metas.title: Prickly Pear Cacti
metas.description: Prickly pear cacti are distinct with their flat oval-shaped pads. They are noticeably more common centrally and are rarely seen in southern and coastal states.

metas.title: Pulque Agave
metas.description: Agave salmiana, also known as pulque agaves, have wide, smooth, curling leaves, and a crown-like appearance. They are common in the central Mexican valley and further north around the city of San Luis Potosi.

metas.title: Blue Agave
metas.description: Vast fields of blue agave (Agave tequilana), used to produce tequila, are mostly found in Jalisco and Nayarit.

metas.title: Tree Yucca
metas.description: Yucca filifera, also known as tree yucca, as well as yucca decipiens are most commonly seen in San Luis Potosi and Zacatecas as well as some of the bordering northern states. They can be recognised by their oblong rosettes of sharp green leaves branching from a single trunk, similar to a tree.

metas.title: Giant Cardon
metas.description: The Mexican Giant Cardon is an extremely common cacti in the Baja California peninsula. It can be identified through its large sprawling arms stemming from a singular trunk and ribbed exterior.

metas.title: Saguaro Cacti
metas.description: The Saguaro Cacti can be spotted in the western half of Sonora, featuring short curving arms that stem from a main trunk.

metas.title: Organ Pipe Cacti
metas.description: Organ Pipe Cacti have long thin stems that often come out from a stem that is around ground level. They are most commonly found in Sonora and occasionally in Baja California Sur.

metas.title: Blue Myrtle Cacti
metas.description: The Blue Myrtle Cacti have short arms that uniformly curve and point upwards. It is abundantly found in San Luis Potosi, but also common in Queretaro and Hidalgo.

metas.title: Sugar Cane
metas.description: Sugar cane can be found all over the country, but by far most common in Veracruz.

metas.title: Coconut Palms
metas.description: Coconut palms can be found all across the coast, but are often found in large groups in Guerrero and Colima.

metas.title: Sabal Palms
metas.description: Sabal palms are most commonly observed in the east coast of Mexico, the Yucatan peninsula, as well as the state of Nayarit. They feature a spiky, sun-shaped crown, giving the tree a lollipop-like appearance.

metas.title: Umbrella Palm
metas.description: The Attalea rostrata is a huge palm recognizable from its upright leaves, almost resembling an umbrella. It is mostly exclusive to Veracruz and Tabasco, and can be rarely found in Chiapas.

metas.title: Oil Palm Plantations
metas.description: Oil palm plantations are most common in Chiapas, and occasionally on the outskirts of the state in Veracruz, Tabasco, and Campeche.

metas.title: Boojum Trees
metas.description: Boojum trees can be recognized by their alien, tentacle-like appearance. They are almost exclusively found in the southern half of Baja California.

metas.title: Brittlebush
metas.description: Brittlebush are small shrubs with bright silver-grey leaves that are most commonly found in Sonora, especially around Hermosillo.

metas.title: White Bark Trees
metas.description: These thin, white-barked trees can be found in the Yucatan peninsula, but are most prevalent in Quintana Roo.

metas.title: Gold Grass Tufts
metas.description: These gold tufts of grass in a line right next to the road are most commonly found in Coahuila.

metas.title: Teardrop Grass
metas.description: These clumps of grass in almost a teardrop shape are common in the region around Tlaxcala.

metas.title: Red Fields
metas.description: Red agricultural fields are commonly seen in Zacatecas and occasionally southern Durango.

metas.title: Monterrey Mountains
metas.description: The Monterrey metropolitan area features tall stunning mountain ranges that surround the city.

metas.title: Northern Pine Forests
metas.description: The western parts of Chihuahua and Durango can feature a rocky mountainous landscape covered with pine forests. In general, these pines are shorter and more stunted in appearance than pine forests of the central or south.

metas.title: Dark Fields
metas.description: Extremely dark fields are common in Guanajuato.

metas.title: Baja Hills
metas.description: These reddish brown-tinged hills, often accompanied by large boulders, are a common sight for the northern half of Baja California.

metas.title: White Soil Yucatan
metas.description: Almost blindingly white soil in the Yucatan peninsula is most common in Quintana Roo.
metas.note: This is only consistent in Generation 3.

metas.title: Campeche Agriculture
metas.description: These red agricultural fields surrounded by dense forests of tropical trees are most common in northern Campeche.

metas.title: Red Brick West
metas.description: Red brick buildings are mostly concentrated in the states west of Mexico City, specifically Jalisco, Michoacan, Guanajuato, and Aguascalientes.

metas.title: White Block East
metas.description: White concrete block buildings are highly concentrated in the states surrounding Mexico city, and are generally more common to the east. They can however still be found all over the country.

metas.title: Mud Brick Buildings
metas.description: Mud brick buildings are most abundant in Durango, especially full houses constructed with mud brick. However, they can essentially be found in almost all of the dry desert states.

metas.title: Northern Bungalows
metas.description: Architecture in northern Mexico often features design elements from American style bungalows. Many houses are coloured with light or pastel colours, gated and commonly have front yards. Orange tiles inspired by Spanish colonial architecture are also typical.

metas.title: Thatched Roofs
metas.description: Thatched roofs are most common in the Yucatan peninsula and eastern San Luis Potosi. They can also be found elsewhere, mainly in the southeast.

metas.title: Yucatan Rock Walls
metas.description: These walls made of light coloured rock are found in the Yucatan peninsula, but most common in Yucatan state.

metas.title: Sign Back Cross
metas.description: A thick cross can be seen on the back of signs in Chihuahua.

metas.title: Nayarit Bollard
metas.description: Bollards with a red band near the top are unique to Nayarit, apart from one exception being Federal Highway 190 on the Oaxaca-Chiapas border.

metas.title: Jalisco Bollard
metas.description: Jalisco bollards will sometimes have a crown and the text ‘Jalisco’ written on it. These are usually barely legible unless very close, however no other Mexican bollard will have writing on it.

metas.title: Acorn Insulators
metas.description: White insulators that are shaped like acorns can be found along the coastal states of Mexico, but are by far most common in Michoacan, Colima, and Veracruz.

metas.title: Asymmetric Crossbar
metas.description: Poles with an asymmetric crossbar and double-stacked insulators are exclusive to Mexico City, State of Mexico, Hidalgo, and Morelos.

metas.title: Sinaloa Wooden Poles
metas.description: Wooden poles with a lowered crossbar are mostly found in Sinaloa and Sonora.

metas.title: Hanging Insulators
metas.description: These concrete poles with insulators suspended below the crossbars are unique to the Yucatan peninsula.

metas.title: Baja Hanging Poles
metas.description: The wooden variant of the hanging pole is found on the Baja California peninsula.

metas.title: Durango Mono-Brace
metas.description: Poles with a lowered crossbar and a single support beam that extend from one end of the crossbar to the pole itself can be found in Durango.

metas.title: Mesh Poles
metas.description: Poles with a mesh body are most commonly found in San Luis Potosi, Guanajuato, and Queretaro.

metas.title: White Middle Lines
metas.description: White middle roadlines are most commonly found in Tabasco.

metas.title: Red Tree Fences
metas.description: These fences made out of trees with red-coloured bark are commonly found in Veracruz.
metas.note: These tree fences can still be found in other coastal states and are best utilised when combined with other clues.

metas.title: Black Tar Lines
metas.description: Black tar on both sides of the yellow centre line can be seen in Sinaloa, Durango, and Guerrero.
metas.note: This is most reliable when the tar is not faded.

metas.title: Blue Grainy Pavement
metas.description: Grainy pavement with a blue-ish grey tinge is a common sight for the states of Tamaulipas and Nuevo Leon.
metas.note: In Tamaulipas, larger roads very commonly feature dashed outer lines.

metas.title: Irregular Cobblestone
metas.description: This style of cobblestone pavement, unorganised with irregular tiles, can be found in most of the central states, but is by far most commonly found in the states of Nayarit, Jalisco, Colima, and Queretaro.

metas.title: Hexagonal Pavers
metas.description: This pavement consisting of hexagonal tiles is found in Puebla and Tlaxcala.

metas.title: Three Line Cobble
metas.description: This exact pavement design with three lines of cobblestone patterning is mainly found in Oaxaca.

metas.title: CDMX Taxis
metas.description: Taxis in and around Mexico City have a white lower half with a pink upper half.

metas.title: Mexicali Farmland
metas.description: The area around Mexicali features flat farmland with a ridge to the west. Washingtonia palms are very common and these poles made out of brown wood can be found.

metas.title: Poza Rica Citrus
metas.description: The area around Poza Rica in Veracruz features a lot of citrus tree plantations. It is common to see large amounts of these trees grown right on top of the hills.

metas.title: Obregon Canals
metas.description: The area around Ciudad Obregon is distinct due to the pinkish-tan soil and canals found around the city’s agricultural areas.

metas.title: Twin Volcanoes
metas.description: The twin volcanoes of Iztaccíhuatl and Popocatépetl are found on the border between the State of Mexico and Puebla. Keep in mind that they are usually much less visible than depicted in the image, which is just for reference.

metas.title: Cerro del Bernal
metas.description: Cerro del Bernal is a distinct extinct volcano that is found in southern Tamaulipas. It can be found heading directly northwest of Tampico or west of Morón.

metas.title: Sierra del Abra
metas.description: This extremely long and flat ridge is found in the Sierra del Abra Tanchipa Biosphere Reserve in eastern San Luis Potosi.

metas.title: Maderas del Carmen
metas.description: This tall, flat ridge, with very prominent ridgelines, belongs to the Maderas del Carmen Biosphere Reserve in Northern Coahuila near the US border.
metas.note: The only road the mountain range can be observed from is the Federal Highway 53 that leads to Boquillas del Carmen.

metas.title: Juarez Outskirts
metas.description: The outskirts of Ciudad Juárez features a lot of dirt roads with a distinct shade of orange soil and low shrubs.

metas.title: Oaxaca Soil Change
metas.description: The area around San Cristóbal Suchixtlahuaca and south of it in Oaxaca often feature rolling hills with really distinct orange and beige-tinged soil, passing from one colour to the other with each hill. The beige-tinged soil can be seen more prominent in some locations.

metas.title: Guaymas Hills
metas.description: The town of Guaymas has a lot of jagged cliffs and mountains that make the area very distinct. The soil is also distinctly pinkish and organ-pipe cacti can be seen scattered on the hills and next to the road.

metas.title: Pink Lakes
metas.description: The town of Los Coloradas is famously known for the pink lakes around the area.

metas.title: Highway 54 Yuccas
metas.description: The 54 is a divided highway that runs through northeastern Zacatecas which features yucca trees spammed on both sides of the road. Additionally, the streetview car is often exposed and appears almost white due to the sunlight.

metas.title: Highway 40D
metas.description: The 40D that crosses the Sinaloa-Durango state line is recognizable by the stunning lush cliffs and mountains along the road. The highway commonly passes through tunnels and the road itself features double yellow middle roadlines.

metas.title: Highway 95D Divider
metas.description: This road divider with a yellow top and bottom edge is found all along the 95D from Mexico City to Acapulco.

metas.title: Eurus Wind Farm
metas.description: The Eurus Wind Farm is located in southeast Oaxaca and is the largest wind farm in Mexico. Rows of wind turbines can be found along the 190 around Juchitán de Zaragoza.

metas.title: Aguascalientes Lamps
metas.description: Most lamp posts and lamp arms in Aguascalientes city are yellow.
metas.note: They are not exclusive and are only very common.

metas.title: Cuernavaca Lamps
metas.description: This lamp with a black rectangular head is found in Cuernavaca.

metas.title: Queretaro Lamps
metas.description: This lamp with black front and back edges and a white middle section is found in Santiago de Queretaro.

metas.title: Cancun Dice Lamps
metas.description: This lamp with five circular bulbs that looks like a dice is found in Cancun.

metas.title: Matamoros Lamps
metas.description: This lamp with a rectangular head and a ring-shaped light bulb is found in Matamoros.

metas.title: Hermosillo Lamps
metas.description: This lamp with a zig-zag bent pole arm is found in Hermosillo.

metas.title: Cuernavaca Pole Paint
metas.description: The bottom half of poles in Cuernavaca are often painted green.
metas.note: In Generation 4, the paint usually looks faded, some to the point where it is barely visible.

metas.title: Chihuahua Pole Paint
metas.description: Poles in Chihuahua city occasionally have a strip of white pole paint with the street name written in black or blue text.

metas.title: La Malinche Car
metas.description: This Street View car with a yellow hood can be found by the La Malinche volcano in Tlaxcala.

metas.title: Cofre de Perote Car
metas.description: This white truck with visible rearview mirrors can be seen in the Cofre de Perote national park.

metas.title: La Seca Car
metas.description: This red Street View car with a black roof can be found in the town of La Seca in Sinaloa.

metas.title: Red Strip Plates
metas.description:
Panama features short licence plates, most commonly white with a horizontal turquoise strip on the top. Rarely, the strip can have other colours.

Front plates are not required in Panama.

metas.title: White Pickup Meta
metas.description: Panama features a large white pickup truck which can either be fully visible or mostly blurred. There is always a short black antenna attached to the front of the car. Beware that the antenna can sometimes be blurred.

metas.title: Rolling Hills & Tropical Plants
metas.description: Panama is a tropical country with a lot of hills. You will find a lot of palms and other tropical plants along with drier rolling hills and fields.

metas.title: Most Roads Paralleled
metas.description: Most roads are paralleled by fences that are partly or fully made out of small trees. The rest of the fence posts are also almost always wooden.

metas.title: Local Architecture
metas.description: Panamanian architecture often reflects Spanish colonial influences, featuring vibrant colours, and some ornate detailing. The most common type of building has painted concrete or sometimes brick walls with red metal sheets or tiles for a roof. Many windows have bars on them for security.

metas.title: White Outer Lines
metas.description: Panama features a diverse set of road lines, but the most common combination is solid outer white with an inner yellow line. However, those are not unique to Panama. Within Latin America, solid outer white lines with no middle line are almost unique to Panama.

metas.title: Painted Poles
metas.description: Panama uses a wide variety of poles, but the most common type is a round concrete pole, with a varying amount of insulators. Poles can also be wooden or metallic. They often have plates attached to them. Blue, white, or red numbers are commonly painted on them as well.

metas.title: Yellow Plates
metas.description: Yellow taxis with a chequerboard patterned horizontal stripe are a common sight in Panama. The licence plate will be drawn on the side, containing the city name and a regional code.

metas.title: Panama Uses Spanish
metas.description: Panama uses the Spanish word “ALTO” on stop signs.
metas.note: Mexico and Guatemala also use “ALTO”, but the font is thinner.

metas.title: Eye Stop Sign
metas.description: Red octagonal signs with an oddly realistic eye are unique to Panama.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: While Panama is quite well covered, there is barely any coverage on the north coast, or east of Panama City.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description:
The first digit of phone numbers can be used to regionguess Panama.

The numbers with a smaller font indicate potentially useful regional two-digit codes.
metas.note: Only phone numbers with 7 digits are helpful, and any numbers starting with 5, 6, or 8 are useless as well.

metas.title: Taxi Plates
metas.description: The first digit of taxi and bus licence plates can be used to regionguess Panama.
metas.note: Cars travel, so they are not always reliable, especially outside of cities.

metas.title: Colon Landscape
metas.description: Green tropical landscapes with palm trees and very tall grass are common around Colón and Panama City.

metas.title: David (Volcanic Rocks)
metas.description: Volcanic rocks that are either scattered on the ground, or built into rock walls, are common north of David.

metas.title: David Surroundings
metas.description: The area around David is very flat, with lots of fairly open fields. Usually, mountains will be visible to the north and northeast.

metas.title: Aguadulce (Brown/Orange Soil)
metas.description: The region around Aguadulce is relatively flat and features a lot of agricultural fields along with very brown or orange soil.

metas.title: Eastern Vertical Plates
metas.description: The eastern provinces often have tall vertical plates that can be yellow or white. They are commonly attached to poles by black zip ties.
metas.note: Be careful not to mix them up with these white vertical plates, often attached by metallic zip ties. They are slightly wider than the eastern plates and always have 6 digits.

metas.title: Western Horizontal Plates
metas.description: Many poles in the western provinces will have horizontal plates attached to them. However, if one of these is accompanied by an eastern vertical plate, the eastern plate takes precedence.

metas.title: Colon Plates
metas.description: Thin yellow plates, vertical or horizontal, with a visible black border are most common in the Colón Province.

metas.title: Penonome (Wind Farm)
metas.description: Wind turbines can be seen south and north of Penonome.

metas.title: Ngabe-Bugle Mountains
metas.description: The main covered road in the Ngäbe-Buglé province is very high-altitude and almost above the clouds. The surrounding mountains tend to be quite dry, and the altitude makes for many stunning views.

metas.title: Changuinola Road
metas.description: The road going to Changuinola features a lush and green hilly landscape. The weather is cloudy or overcast on the entire road.

metas.title: Highway 9 (Panama-Colón)
metas.description: Highway 9 going from Panama City north to Colón is a divided concrete highway. The road is visibly grainy and has a lot of tar lines. The landscape is lush and hilly.

metas.title: Road 407
metas.description: Most of Road 407 features a freshly paved road, with visibly orange soil on the sides of the road. The southern portion is hilly, right before the road quality deteriorates.

metas.title: Eastern Road (Car Dirt)
metas.description: A small cluster of dirt on the car can be found on the eastern road.

metas.title: Roof Dots
metas.description: In a lot of central Panama, the Google car will have either one or two black dots visible on the front.

metas.title: Panama Oeste Red Spot
metas.description: This small red spot can mostly be found in Panamá Oeste and on the road 2 going from southern Los Santos province to the Verguas province.

metas.title: Folded Antenna
metas.description: The antenna can be seen folded down, most commonly in Colón and Panamá provinces, and occasionally in the city of David.

metas.title: Panama City Skyline
metas.description: Panama City can be recognised by the large number of white high-rise buildings.

metas.title: Colon Warehouses
metas.description: Colón features a lot of warehouses and rundown multi-storey buildings.

metas.title: Changuinola (Banana Plantations)
metas.description: The region around Changuinola is filled with banana plantations.

metas.title: South Tonosi Road (Sunset)
metas.description: Sunset coverage can be found in southern Panama on a small road south of Tonosi.

metas.title: Volcán (Mountainous/Pines)
metas.description: A mountainous landscape with pine trees, volcanic rocks, dry grass, and gravel roads can be found northeast of Volcán.

metas.title: Gatún (Canal Pole Socks)
metas.description: Yellow pole socks can be found near the Panama Canal, around the town of Gatún.

metas.title: US Territory
metas.description: Puerto Rico is a United States overseas territory. As such, it is counted as the US for country streaks purposes.

metas.title: Smallcam Antenna
metas.description: Nearly all of the coverage was captured with smallcam, a variant of Generation 4, which in this case can be recognised by the wide blur and antenna that is often visible. The camera is lower and the front blur more round than pickup truck blurs.

metas.title: Gen 3 Antenna
metas.description: The Generation 3 Street View car found in Puerto Rico has an antenna at the front right. The antenna has a small white dot on the tip.
metas.note: The Google car on Guam and NMI also have an antenna at the front right. Make sure to look out for other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Phone Code 787
metas.description:
The entirety of Puerto Rico uses (787) as their regional phone code. This number can be seen in front of phone numbers using this format:

(787) XXX-XXXX
metas.note: While far less common, you may also encounter the phone code 939.

metas.title: Spanish Signs
metas.description: Spanish, instead of English, can commonly be seen on signs around Puerto Rico.

metas.title: American Chains
metas.description: American store chains, such as Wal-Mart, are very common in Puerto Rico. This will help distinguish Puerto Rico from other nearby Latin American countries and territories, where American stores are not common.

metas.title: No Front Plates
metas.description: Front plates are not mandatory in Puerto Rico. Therefore, seeing cars with front plates is rare. This helps differentiate from Guam and Northern Mariana Islands.

metas.title: Divided Highways
metas.description: A significant part of the coverage in rural Puerto Rico is taken on large divided highways.

metas.title: Highway Shields
metas.description: Here is an example of what highway shields in Puerto Rico look like. From top left to bottom right they are: primary highway shields, primary urban highway shields, secondary shields, and tertiary shields. These will not be present in any other state or territory of the US.

metas.title: Spanish Speed Limit
metas.description: Speed limit signs in Puerto Rico are identical in shape and size to speed limit signs seen in the mainland US. The major difference is that these signs will always be in Spanish, instead of English.

metas.title: Pare Stop Sign
metas.description: Stop signs in Puerto Rico say ‘PARE’ instead of stop.
metas.note: ‘PARE’ is also used in all of South America as well as the Dominican Republic.

metas.title: Vertical KM Markers
metas.description: Puerto Rican kilometre markers are tall, green and with “km” written at the top, followed by a number written vertically in large text.

metas.title: Concrete Homes
metas.description: Most homes in Puerto Rico are made of concrete and have flat rooftops. Metal gates in front of homes are common features as well, especially in urban areas.
metas.note: Homes in other areas of Latin America can have a similar appearance.

metas.title: Dry South
metas.description: Southern Puerto Rico can often look distinctly drier than the rest of the island.

metas.title: Coastal Plains
metas.description: The North and South coasts of Puerto Rico typically feature flat coastal plains or rolling hills.

metas.title: Mountain Coverage
metas.description: Most of the mountainous regions of Puerto Rico are located in the middle section of the country. Most of the coverage in these areas is limited to divided highways.

metas.title: Ponce Creole
metas.description: The Southern city of Ponce features many buildings in the style of Ponce Creole Architecture, which is a combination of Victorian and Spanish Revival styles. Buildings are typically made out of wood and masonry.

metas.title: Old San Juan
metas.description: Old Town San Juan is located at the far Northwest tip of the city of San Juan. This area has very narrow streets, colourful buildings, and a mix of Gothic, Renaissance, and Baroque architecture. Also, some streets in this area are made of bricks.

metas.title: French Territory
metas.description: Saint Pierre and Miquelon, officially the Territorial Collectivity of Saint-Pierre and Miquelon, is an overseas department and region of France, south of Newfoundland in Canada. As such, for country streaks purposes, it is counted as France.

metas.title: Blue Strip Plates
metas.description: Licence plates can be either white or yellow and either short or long. They all have a blue EU strip however, and the white plates will also have a blue strip on the right, as is custom in France. Vehicles may or may not have front plates.

metas.title: Gen 3 Trekker
metas.description: All coverage was taken with a Generation 3 trekker camera.

metas.title: Colourful Wooden Houses
metas.description: Most houses are made of wooden panels with a boxy look and often vivid colours.

metas.title: Grassy Landscape
metas.description: The landscape mainly consists of flat or rolling grasslands. The coast will be visible more often than not.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Coverage is fairly limited, being only found in the eastern parts of Saint-Pierre as well as at the northern tip of Miquelon-Langlade.

metas.title: Miquelon-Langlade
metas.description: Miquelon-Langlade is a small town in the north of St Pierre. It can be recognized by the houses with timber cladding painted in bold, vivid colours. A shadow of the ATV used to cover this town can also be seen.

metas.title: Saint-Pierre
metas.description: Saint-Pierre is the capital and largest town. The coverage in this town is made with a sidewalk trekker. Larger buildings and more cars can be seen, with a more populated feel compared to Miquelon-Langlade.

metas.title: Ile-aux-Marins
metas.description: A slightly hilly, grassy landscape with boxy houses spaced apart can be seen on Île-aux-Marins.

metas.title: Northern Rural Trekker
metas.description: This rural trekker in the far north can be recognized by the rolling, grassy landscape. The trekker can also be seen walking on a wooden path, with trees on either side.

metas.title: Saint Pierre Rural
metas.description: The rural trekker on Saint Pierre island has a more rocky landscape. The trekker also walks on a path with trees on both sides.

metas.title: Boat Trekker
metas.description: This boat trekker between Saint Pierre Island and Île-aux-Marins can be recognized by this man wearing a grey and black sweater.

metas.title: Midway Atoll Location
metas.description:
The US Minor Outlying Islands are a chain of islands that are US overseas territories. As such, it is counted as the US for country streak purposes.

The guide will be somewhat skewed towards the Midway Atoll, as that is the only island with pinpointable coverage.
metas.note: The easiest way to locate the Midway Atoll on the map is to zoom in slightly to the west of the North Pacific Ocean map label.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description: The coverage on the Midway Atoll was made with a Generation 2 camera.

metas.title: Albatrosses
metas.description: One of the most distinct features of the Midway atoll is the presence of multiple albatrosses on almost every single location.

metas.title: Large Part Coverage
metas.description: A large part of the coverage on the Midway Atoll was taken on two runways, which are the only areas where it can be difficult to spot the albatrosses.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: The islands other than the Midway Atoll can generally be characterised by three things. Firstly, the Generation 3 trekker coverage. Secondly, the low, bushy vegetation, and thirdly, the presence of numerous birds.

metas.title: Nicely Paved Runway
metas.description: A nicely paved runway can be seen going west to east on the southern side of the Midway Atoll.

metas.title: Poorly Paved Runway
metas.description: A poorly paved runway can be seen going north to south on the Midway Atoll. The pavement gets increasingly poor to the north.

metas.title: Eastern Side
metas.description: On the eastern side of the Midway Atoll, you can find a small village.

metas.title: Lake Views
metas.description: Southeast Island is arguably the least distinctive island in the chain. It has a small lake near the centre, and a large amount of birds in the sky.

metas.title: Regional Buses
metas.description: Lisianski Island only has coverage right by the shore and can typically be recognised by the large bushes going around the entire island.

metas.title: Island Features
metas.description: Laysan Island is the only island in the chain where the coverage has almost no clouds.

metas.title: Shoals Features
metas.description: The French Frigate Shoals is a fairly long and thin island with a shabby-looking runway. The island has by far the largest number of birds out of all islands in the chain.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: East Island is the smallest island in the chain. There is barely any vegetation and you can see the ocean in all directions.

metas.title: Western Corner Midway
metas.description: The western corner of the Midway Atoll runway is arguably the most common location on the official Geoguessr world map and may thus be worth remembering, particularly for a newer player.

metas.title: Eastern Island Situated
metas.description: Eastern Island, situated right next to the Midway Atoll, has two small areas of low-quality tripod coverage. It does not have any other official coverage.

metas.title: Islands Features
metas.description: The United States Virgin Islands are a group of islands that are US overseas territories. As such, it is counted as the US for country streaks purposes.

metas.title: Car Coverage Islands
metas.description: Car coverage on the islands will have a large, visible street view car, which will either be red or white. Details about where to find each car can be found in the region guessing section.

metas.title: Local Architecture
metas.description: A unique blend of architecture is found on the United States Virgin Islands. The primary influences are European Renaissance, Spanish Baroque, Rococo and Victorian styles. Facades with large arches are common; as well as central plazas and courtyards.

metas.title: Historical Site
metas.description: Owing to its former status as a Danish colony, some streets and localities still have Danish names (e.g. gade) or display bilingual signs. This is most common in the historical downtown areas.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Licence plates are short, typically either having a bright blue or a dark blue design.

metas.title: Primary Roads Southern
metas.description: Primary roads on the Southern US Virgin Island of St. Croix follow a loose grid pattern. Main roads are angled from WSW to ENE, with intersecting roads angled from NNW to SSE. In contrast, the Northern Islands of St. John and St. Thomas have much curvier roads.

metas.title: United States Virgin
metas.description: The United States Virgin Islands features 3 unique Google cars. The first of which is shown here. This red truck with a red cab can only be seen in the southern island of St Croix. This is the most common car that will be seen as St Croix has the most coverage.

metas.title: White Car Without
metas.description: A white car without an antenna can also be seen on St Croix, however it will be less common than the red car.

metas.title: White Car With
metas.description: A white car with an antenna can only be seen in the northern islands of St Thomas and St John. The cab is also noticeably shorter than the other two cars.

metas.title: Hilly Terrain
metas.description: Two boat trekkers are found on the north coast of St Croix. The boat cannot be seen, however the trekker can be identified by the blue waters and hilly islands. The area near Buck Island National Park also has a distinct pink tint to the camera.

metas.title: height of Bridge
metas.description:
The US uses American English spelling (e.g. center, color).

In addition, the US primarily uses the imperial system for measurements. For example, speed and distance are measured in miles. You will also often see feet and inches on signs, indicating the height of bridges.
metas.note: This is useful to distinguish between the English-speaking parts of Canada, where British English spelling and (usually) the metric system are used. For example, Canada measures speed in kilometres.

metas.title: Gen 2 Coverage
metas.description:
Generation 2 coverage is rare in the US. If you have a Generation 2 location in a North American setting, you are more likely to be in Canada.

The exception to this is Alaska, and to a lesser extent Hawaii, which have a fair amount of Generation 2. You can also rarely see generation 2 in rural areas of the deep south.

Generation 3 coverage is also significantly less common than in Canada.

metas.title: Road Signs Us
metas.description:
Road signs in the US tend to use more words compared to their Canadian counterparts. A good example are railway crossing signs, which feature the literal words ‘railway crossing’ on them. In Canada, these signs are typically blank.

This tendency is also noticeable on yellow diamond warning signs. In Canada, the words will usually be on a rectangular sign below the yellow diamond, which would have a diagram on it instead.

metas.title: Us Uses Phrase
metas.description:
The US uses the phrase ‘Speed Limit’ on their speed signs.

The numbers on American speed signs are usually lower than that of Canada’s, since they use miles instead of kilometres. In addition, speed limits ending in 5 are more common in the US.
metas.note: Canada uses the word ‘Maximum’ on their speed signs.

metas.title: Triangular Yellow Signs
metas.description: Triangular yellow signs with the phrase ‘No Passing Zone’ are exclusive to the US.

metas.title: American Yield Signs
metas.description: American yield signs are shaped like an upside down triangle with a red border, with a white field with the word ‘YIELD’.
metas.note: Canadian yield signs look similar, but lack the ‘YIELD’ text.

metas.title: American One-way Signs
metas.description: American one-way signs are usually a horizontal black rectangle with a white arrow inside of it. These signs will also always have the words ‘ONE WAY’ printed on them. In cities, they are a white vertical rectangle with the words ‘ONE WAY’ on them and an arrow underneath.
metas.note: Canadian one-way signs are of the same shape and colour, but might not have the words ‘ONE WAY’ on them.

metas.title: Parking Indicator Signs
metas.description: Parking indicator signs in the US are typically white metal signs with red, green, or black text. They may include specific information about when you can park on said road, and arrows indicating where parking is (or is not) allowed.
metas.note: Canadian parking signs use similar styles and colours, but typically are less ‘wordy,’ instead using more symbols when applicable.

metas.title: Large Highways Us
metas.description: Large highways in the US use large, rectangular, green metal signs with curved edges and white text to mark highway exits, distances to nearby towns, and the names of upcoming roads (mainly in cities).
metas.note: Canadian highway signs have a similar appearance, but will typically have squared edges, instead of curved edges.

metas.title: Leading Up Exits
metas.description: Leading up to exits on large highways you commonly see large, blue rectangular signs with white text, highlighting services, such as food, lodging and petrol, that are available at the upcoming highway exit.
metas.note: Canada uses similar signs on some of their highways.

metas.title: Rectangular Junction Signs
metas.description: These rectangular junction signs with a single or double arrow are found in the US.
metas.note: Canada uses diamond-shaped junction signs.

metas.title: White And Orange
metas.description: White and orange fibre optic cable markers are almost unique to the US.
metas.note: On very rare occasions, they can be found in Canada.

metas.title: Example
metas.description: This is an example of the most common type of orange construction barrel in the United States. They are made out of orange plastic with horizontal white stripes and a black rubber base. They are usually used to block off lanes to traffic during times of road construction.

metas.title: Road Median
metas.description:
The US uses yellow middle lines and white outer lines. Double middle lines are the most common.

On divided roads, the outer line closest to the median will be yellow, and the other lines will usually be white.
metas.note: Double middle lines are less common in Canada, but not rare – use this meta with caution. Furthermore, yellow road lines are very rare in Europe.

metas.title: Interstate Highways Us
metas.description: Interstate highways, US highways, and some state roads have rumble strips in each edge of the road; which are small indentations in the pavement perpendicular to the road. These can be located on the outside edges of the road and in between lanes on multi-lane highways.
metas.note: Rumble strips may appear in Canada, but are much more rare.

metas.title: Small Rectangular Manufactured
metas.description: Small, rectangular manufactured homes, also known as mobile or ‘trailer’ homes, are popular in rural areas of the US. In general, mobile homes are more common in the Southeast but they can be seen anywhere in the country.
metas.note: This style of home can sometimes be seen in Canada, but to a much lesser extent.

metas.title: Baptist Churches Very
metas.description: Baptist churches are very common in the United States. Similar to mobile homes, these are more common in the Southern Plains and Southeast United States, but can be found in all 50 states.
metas.note: Baptist churches are rare in Canada.

metas.title: Pictured Here Group
metas.description:
Pictured here is a group of gas stations and convenience store chains that operate in the United States, but not in Canada. This is not a comprehensive list, but some of the most common American-only chains. Regional gas station chains are found near the end of the ‘Step 2’ section of this guide.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Pictured Here Group
metas.description:
Pictured here is a group of restaurant chains that operate in the United States, but not in Canada (Chick Fil A is the only exception with a few locations in the Toronto area.) This is not a comprehensive list, but some of the most common American-only chains. Regional restaurant chains are found at the end of the ‘Step 2’ section of this guide.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: In addition to having less Generation 3 coverage than Canada, the side mirrors are also blurred out differently: While they generally appear as two peaks in Canadian Gen 3 coverage, you will mostly see a single peak in the US.

metas.title: Street Signs
metas.description: In the US and Canada, especially at large intersections, long metal bars with stop lights attached to them hang over the street. These bars also commonly have street signs, highway signs, or other signs attached to them.

metas.title: Thin Metal Sign
metas.description: Thin metal sign posts are common. They will typically either have several small holes or have a U-profile.

metas.title: Concrete Poles
metas.description:
North America primarily uses wooden utility poles.

Several European countries also primarily use wooden utility poles. However, a concrete pole in particular is mostly associated with Europe.

metas.title: Utility Poles
metas.description: This style of insulator, that is raised slightly on top of the utility pole, can be a good clue for the US and Canada. It is not typically found in Europe. It is especially apparent on simple poles with a single insulator.

metas.title: Style Mailbox Resting
metas.description: This style of mailbox, resting on top of a post and with a small flag on the side, is mostly associated with North America.

metas.title: North American Semi-trucks
metas.description: North American semi-trucks have a longer nose, since the engine is in front of the driver’s cab. In contrast, European and Asian semi-trucks are cabovers, meaning the driver sits on top of the engine, giving the truck an L shape.
metas.note: This is only useful to differentiate between North America and Europe, as these trucks are found throughout all of the Americas. Australian and New Zealand trucks are typically a mix of the two.

metas.title: Here Two Common
metas.description: Here are two common types of water towers seen in towns across the United States and Canada. They are typically very tall, and sometimes have the name of the town and state painted on them, so they can be useful for region guessing.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description:
Generation 3 coverage in the US and Canada generally has no visible antenna. This can be helpful to distinguish it from Europe in low-info rounds. Some European Generation 3 coverage has no visible antenna, but most of it does.

There is an important exception: in national parks in the US, you can find a Generation 3 car with a stubby antenna with diagonal coils around it. Still, this specific type of antenna is not found in Europe.

metas.title: Both Us And
metas.description: Both the US and Canada also have Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front. The blur can also be fully transparent, making it harder to spot. When the car isn’t blurred properly, you will usually see a mirror sticking out on the right side.

metas.title: Shown Here Population
metas.description:
Shown here is the population density of the United States. In General, areas east of the Missouri river are more densely populated than areas to the west.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description:
The US, as well as most of the Americas, uses short licence plates, in contrast to longer European ones. Each US state has their own unique licence plate design. Some of these are recognizable through the blur, and are thus worth learning. Around half of the states also do not require front plates, which can also be useful in determining the state.

You can click on the image to enlarge it. Here you can also find a map showing the locations of each plate.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description:
Interstate Highways are divided highways that often span large areas of the United States. Even-numbered Interstates run west to east, with the lowest numbers along the Gulf Coast and Mexico border. Odd-numbered highways run south to north, with the lowest numbers along the West Coast.

US Highways are also typically long roads that are sometimes (but not always) divided. The numbering system is generally the inverse of Interstate Highways, with low odd-numbered highways located along the East Coast and low even-numbered highways located close to the Canadian border in the north of the country.
metas.note:
There are generally more exceptions to the US Highway numbering system than the Interstate Highway numbering system, in terms of placement.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Area Code Map
metas.description:
US telephone numbers start with a three-digit area code. While these area codes are not clustered by initial digits, they are useful to learn.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Each 50 States
metas.description:
Each of the 50 states has its own state flag. These appear frequently enough that they are worth learning.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description:
Shown here is a topographic map of the US.

Most significant elevation is in the west: here you will find large mountain ranges, but also more flat, high plateaus. Some parts have lower elevation: good examples are the Central Valley and Imperial Valley in California.

Elevation in the east is generally much lower. The most significant amount of elevation is found in the Appalachians, low mountain ranges running through the eastern and northeastern US. Good examples of hills in otherwise fairly flat regions are the Driftless Area in the Midwest, and The Ozarks in Missouri and Arkansas.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Forest Density Map
metas.description:
This is a forest density map of the contiguous United States. Eastern and Northern regions of the country typically have much denser tree cover than Western and Southwestern regions.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Corn Fields Most
metas.description: Corn fields can most commonly be found in these regions. For a detailed overview, see this map.

metas.title: Valley Landscape
metas.description: Soybeans are short, dark green crops organised in long rows and are found in similar regions where corn is grown. They are most common in the Eastern Plains, Midwest, Lower Mississippi Valley, and areas of the Mid Atlantic.

metas.title: North Features
metas.description: Along the Canadian border in North Dakota, and rarely Montana, fields filled with short yellow canola flowers (Brassica napus) can commonly be seen from the road.

metas.title: Valley Landscape
metas.description: Cotton is a crop that produces large fields of fluffy white flowers. It is most commonly produced in coastal Southeast States, the Lower Mississippi River Valley, Western Texas, and parts of California and Arizona. You can click here for a more detailed map.
metas.note: When cotton is not fully grown (earlier in the year) cotton fields often look like this.

metas.title: Valley Landscape
metas.description: Rice production only occurs in a few areas of the US, so it is very useful for region guessing. It is typically grown in large, flat fields that resemble low prairies. It is only grown in north-central California and the Lower Mississippi River Valley in Arkansas, Louisiana, Texas, and Mississippi. You can click here for a more detailed map.
metas.note: When rice is not fully grown, rice fields often look similar to this.

metas.title: Oil Pumpjacks Short
metas.description: Oil pumpjacks are short, industrial-looking metal structures located at the surface of oil fields and are used to pump crude oil from the earth below. They are most common in western states, particularly in Texas, Eastern New Mexico, and North Dakota.

metas.title: Flat Agricultural Land
metas.description: The Great Plains are in the middle of the United States and stretch from the Canadian border in the North, to central Texas in the South. This area is primarily flat with few trees. Some areas feature agriculture fields, while others feature dry and barren grassy fields.

metas.title: Lake Views
metas.description: The area spanning from the Montana Border with Saskatchewan to the Western Great Lakes features many ‘prairie potholes.’ These are areas of low-lying wetlands that feature marshy grasses and small, shallow ponds.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The Appalachian mountain range is a low mountain range that runs through the eastern states. The general landscape consists of low, forested mountains, with beech and oak trees being a common sight.
metas.note: Houses in the south generally have less storeys. New England architecture, commonly consisting of wood panelling, high roofs and a porch, is also more common toward the north, especially in New England.

metas.title: Loblolly Pine Pinus
metas.description: The loblolly pine (Pinus taeda), and longleaf pine (Pinus palustris), commonly referred to as southern pines in the community, are found throughout the southeastern US. They are a great way to recognize this region, as they are abundant, recognizable and mostly limited to this part of the country. They tend to be tall, with fluffy-looking clusters of pine needles.

metas.title: Many Parts Deep
metas.description: Many parts of the Deep South, stretching from Oklahoma to South Carolina, have reddish soil. The exact tint of the soil can range from yellow to deep red.

metas.title: Grass Used Lawns
metas.description: Grass that is used in lawns in the southern US (colloquially known as Bermuda and St. Augustine grasses) go dormant in the winter months. This causes the lawns to turn beige or light brown in winter; whereas grasses used in more northern areas of the US stay much greener in winter.

metas.title: Valley Landscape
metas.description: The Lower Mississippi River Valley is a very flat and open landscape with red soil in areas of Tennessee, Arkansas, Mississippi, and Northeast Louisiana. Corn and other crops are common in this area.

metas.title: Pine Forests
metas.description: The area stretching from the Canadian border to Northern New Mexico is home to the Rocky Mountains. These jagged, rocky formations often feature many pine trees and visible snow all-year round at the highest peaks. Some areas of the Rocky Mountain Range are noticeably dry, with few trees.

metas.title: Snow-Capped Mountains
metas.description:
The Great Basin, centred around Nevada, can be recognized by the tall, sometimes snow-capped mountains in the background. There are dry, but grassy, and slightly shrubby plains leading up to the mountains.

The tallest mountains are in Nevada, Utah and California. More gradual, rocky hills can be seen in Oregon, and greener mountains can be seen in Idaho and central Utah.

Keep in mind that there are exceptions, so make sure to look out for other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Regional Buses
metas.description: Great Basin Sagebrush (Artemisia tridentata) is a short, shrubby blue-green bush that is common in the interior western United States.It is most common in arid areas.

metas.title: Saguaro Cacti Most
metas.description: Saguaro cacti are most commonly shaped like tall, straight tubes with several branches extending from the main tube. They are most commonly found in southern Arizona, on the Sonoran border.

metas.title: Extremely Tall Conifer
metas.description:
Extremely tall conifer trees (Douglas firs) with a dark brown bark, and dark green leaves, can most commonly be seen in Cascadia. Notably, they can also be found in northern California, Idaho and as far east as Montana.

Beware that they are also commonly found in British Columbia.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: Temperate rainforests are found in coastal areas of Washington, Oregon, and Northern California. These rainforests feature many broadleaf trees, large conifers, and ferns.
metas.note: These rainforests stretch north into coastal British Columbia and Southeast Alaska as well.

metas.title: Southwest Centred Around
metas.description: The Southwest, centred around the Four Corners region of Utah, Arizona, New Mexico, and Colorado, feature many mesas and tablelands. Often, these rock formations will be red in colour. Additionally, red soil is common in these areas.

metas.title: Desert Landscape
metas.description: Palm trees are common in coastal areas of the Southeastern states, as well as the Desert Southwest region. Shown here is the Mexican Fan Palm, which is most common in California and along the Gulf Coast, but other palm tree types have a similar range.

metas.title: Just West Metropolitan
metas.description: Just west of the metropolitan areas of Austin and San Antonio Texas lies a large area of dry, rocky hills featuring many yucca and prickly pear plants. Texas Live Oak trees are the predominant tree type in this area.

metas.title: Flat Agricultural Land
metas.description: The Rio Grande Valley in South Texas is extremely flat and features shrubby trees and agricultural fields. This area borders the Mexican state of Tamaulipas.

metas.title: Spanish Moss Appearing
metas.description: Spanish moss, appearing as greyish white drapes, can sometimes be seen on trees in the deep south.

metas.title: Agricultural Area
metas.description: Agricultural golden fields can commonly be seen in eastern Washington.
metas.note: Flat areas of northern and eastern Oregon can have a similar appearance.

metas.title: Rolling Hills
metas.description:
Central Valley, California can be recognized by its Mediterranean climate. This is reflected in its agriculture, seen in the vineyards and olive trees that can commonly be found here.

In addition, rolling hills can be seen toward the edges of the valley.

metas.title: Rolling Hills
metas.description: The Nebraska Sandhills are a recognizable region of rolling hills covered with prairie grass in the central-north part of the state.

metas.title: Rolling Hills
metas.description: In the Appalachian area stretching from southern New York to southern Virginia, there are a lot of forest-covered rolling hills, with flat valleys dividing them. A majority of the ridges are oriented Southwest to Northeast.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The Ouachita Mountains stretch from Eastern Oklahoma into West-Central Arkansas. Unlike the nearby Ozark Mountains, these mountains are typically more steep in nature and easier to see from a distance.

metas.title: Maximum Speed Limits
metas.description:
Maximum speed limits vary by state and territory. The maximum speed limits shown here will generally be seen on interstate highways. Some interstates and highways in their respective states or territories will have lower maximum speed limits than what is shown.

You can click on the image to enlarge it. Here is a map of the maximum speed limits on US territories.

metas.title: Each State Has
metas.description: Each state has their own highway shield. Some states have their own unique, recognizable highway shields that can be seen here.

metas.title: Most States Have
metas.description:
Most states have unique, distinct and learnable Adopt-a-Highway signs, which can be seen on the side of roads. A map of those can be seen here. Keep in mind, some states have slight variations in design.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Blue And Yellow
metas.description: Blue and yellow shields are used for county roads, and can be seen in certain states in the US. Keep in mind, unique designs can be found in some counties in certain states. For more information, see here.

metas.title: Massachusetts Features
metas.description: These rectangular raised pavement markers are found in the south and west of the US and also in Massachusetts.

metas.title: Snowplowable Raised Pavement
metas.description: Snowplowable raised pavement markers can only be found on highways in the eastern states shown in the image. They are built into the road and somewhat resemble the letter H.

metas.title: Some Roads And
metas.description: Some roads and highways in the state of Kentucky use uniquely-shaped rumble strips that are thin, relatively long recessed lines on the very outside edges of the road.

metas.title: in US Park
metas.description:
Guardrails, signs, and signposts are commonly painted a medium brown colour in US National Parks, which are often located in the west. Guardrails that are painted brown can be made out of both wood and metal. Rock walls can also sometimes be seen in place of guardrails.

Here you can find a map showing where all US National Parks are located.
metas.note: There are occasional exceptions to this rule, so consider other clues before guessing in a National Park.

metas.title: Wisconsin And Missouri
metas.description: Wisconsin and Missouri are the only two states that use a lettering system (A - ZZZ) for their county highways. Wisconsin signs typically have the word ‘county’ above the letter, while Missouri signs typically do not. The borders of the signs also vary slightly.

metas.title: Iowa Features
metas.description: Concrete paving on main highways is much more common in Iowa than in other states.
metas.note: Concrete paving on residential streets is commonly seen throughout the Midwest states and parts of the East Coast.

metas.title: Yellow Lines With
metas.description: Yellow lines with a noticeably larger gap in between them are most common in Texas, Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Oregon. They can also be found to a lesser extent in Washington, Alabama, and Michigan.
metas.note: Wide middle lines can also rarely appear in other states, so consider other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Yellow Road Lines
metas.description: Some roads in West Virginia, Virginia, and Maryland use middle yellow lines that are thicker than traditional yellow road lines.
metas.note: These are not present on all roads in these states, and can be found elsewhere, so use this tip in conjunction with other clues.

metas.title: Oregon Features
metas.description: Speed signs in Oregon often simply have the word ‘Speed’ instead of the standard ‘Speed Limit’.

metas.title: Yellow Road Lines
metas.description: A black stripe can sometimes be seen in between the two yellow, middle road lines in California.

metas.title: Utility Poles
metas.description: Utility poles in California usually have markings at the bottom of the pole that consist of 3 yellow stripes.

metas.title: California Features
metas.description: Some small roads in California lack a middle yellow line; instead only feature solid white lines on each side of the road.
metas.note: This can rarely be seen in other states.

metas.title: Angled Bollards
metas.description: This bollard is found in Nevada. It consists of a reflector on a thin stick. The reflector is a vertical rectangle that consists of a white field surrounded by a black outline.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: The most common type of roadside bollard in South Dakota and Montana features a dark metal post with a white diamond on each side of the top.
metas.note: These bollards can be found to a lesser extent in other western states.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Roadside bollards in Wyoming often feature a dark metal pole with a white circular reflector at the top. The top of the metal pole is sometimes painted white or grey, which is unique to Wyoming.

metas.title: Angled Bollards
metas.description: The state of Washington uses bollards that consist of a white or brown post with a white rectangle on the front of the bollard, and two smaller white or silver squares on the back of the bollard.

metas.title: Utah Features
metas.description: Streets in Utah and Idaho, particularly in urban areas, are often named by using a combination of a number and cardinal direction (i.e. ‘600 South.’)
metas.note: This style of street naming can be found rarely in other Western states.

metas.title: Texan Roads Often
metas.description: Texan roads often have a grainy, ‘salt and pepper’-like road surface.
metas.note: Similar pavement can sometimes be seen in adjacent states such as New Mexico, Oklahoma, and Colorado.

metas.title: Some Rural Roads
metas.description: Some rural roads in the Upper Midwest use a similar road pavement to Texas. They will have a grainy, ‘salt and pepper’-like road surface, but will vary in colour. These roads are most common in the state of Illinois.

metas.title: Texas Features
metas.description: Yellow or red bands can commonly be seen around signposts in Texas.
metas.note: Similar reflectors can sometimes be seen in other states, such as Hawaii.

metas.title: White Reflectors Signposts
metas.description: These white reflectors on signposts are unique to Kansas. They are most commonly seen on ‘stop’ signs in rural areas.

metas.title: placed before Bridge
metas.description: In Minnesota, these yellow signs with vertical, black triangles are placed before bridges at most major river crossings and at the beginnings and ends of guardrail sections on large highways.

metas.title: Minnesota Features
metas.description: On most rural ‘stop’ signposts in Minnesota, a black-and-white marker is attached to the posts horizontally. The shape may vary slightly.

metas.title: Green Atv Route
metas.description: These green ATV Route signs are unique to Wisconsin.

metas.title: Metal Poles
metas.description: A rectangular white metal plate, with an orange rectangle and diamond, can be seen on most poles in Wisconsin and the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.

metas.title: Striped Bollards
metas.description: These simple white bollards with black reflectors are unique to Wisconsin.

metas.title: Horizontal Blue Red
metas.description: A horizontal blue, red, or green sign can commonly be seen at the ends of driveways in Wisconsin and the Michigan peninsula. The house number is present, in addition to either the town name and or the road name (usually.)
metas.note: Nearby states often use similar markers, but typically lack any town or street name information and only feature numbers.

metas.title: Michigan Features
metas.description: Signs attached to two signposts can be seen in Michigan. Not all signs are attached to two signposts.
metas.note: Double signposts can also be seen in other states, but are not as common.

metas.title: Michigan Features
metas.description: Many large intersections in Michigan have stop lights and signs that hang from wires that stretch across the middle of the intersection. These markers are commonly in yellow boxes.
metas.note: These are not completely unique to Michigan, but are most commonly seen there.

metas.title: Properties Rural And
