metas.description: Properties in rural and exurban Ohio, Lower Michigan, and Indiana commonly feature a vertically-oriented metal sign with white numbers, indicating the house number of the adjacent building. These signs are most commonly blue or green, and are commonly attached to mailboxes.
metas.note: These may be rarely found in other states.

metas.title: Street Signs
metas.description: West Virginia sometimes features street signs with a symbol that resembles a fraction inside a circle.

metas.title: Street Signs
metas.description: North Carolina commonly uses a style of street signs showing street numbers and arrows in addition to the street name.
metas.note: Other states occasionally feature street signs with similar designs, so use other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Oklahoma Often Find
metas.description: In Oklahoma, you can often find a green rectangular sign with 3 rows of numbers attached to the back of stop signs at rural intersections.

metas.title: Pennsylvania Features
metas.description: Rectangular white signs can sometimes be seen attached to signposts at intersections in Pennsylvania. On top, the number of the converging state route is written.

metas.title: Virginia Features
metas.description: Rectangular white signs can sometimes be seen at intersections in Virginia.

metas.title: North Features
metas.description: White signs attached to signposts can commonly be seen in North Carolina.

metas.title: White Street Signs
metas.description: Black street signs with white text can commonly be found at intersections in South Carolina.

metas.title: Road Guardrails
metas.description: Square guardrails are the most dominant (but not the only) type of guardrail in the states of New York and Wyoming. They have a long bar across the top, with several square legs supporting them.
metas.note: These guardrails can be found, to a lesser extent, in some adjacent states.

metas.title: E2 Road Features
metas.description: In New Hampshire there will often be a white metal sign with the characters ‘E-2’ on it adjacent to the road, typically at either end of bridges.

metas.title: Vermont Features Small
metas.description:
Vermont features small rectangular green signs on stop sign posts with three rows of horizontal numbers. The top row of numbers correlates to the highway or road number that the road with the stop sign intersects with. For example, this image is taken from Vermont State Road 116, looking towards the intersecting road.

The State of New York uses similar style signs. However, these signs can be attached to different types of sign posts (town entry signs, highway signs, etc.)

metas.title: ends of Bridge
metas.description: Maine, New Hampshire, and Massachusetts use small green and red rectangular signs to mark the ends of bridges and guardrails.
metas.note: Not all bridges and guardrails in these states will have these markers.

metas.title: Rural Areas Connecticut
metas.description: In rural areas of Connecticut, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, and New Hampshire, short rock walls are commonly visible adjacent to the road.
metas.note: These rock walls can be found rarely in adjacent states.

metas.title: Dark-coloured Wooden Fences
metas.description: Dark-coloured wooden fences with several horizontal wooden supports are common in farming areas of central and southern Appalachia, stretching from Pennsylvania to Georgia.
metas.note: These types of fences can be found elsewhere to a lesser extent, so use other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: Stilt houses can sometimes be seen on the coast. These are especially common toward the south, and on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: Similar in style to aforementioned stilt houses, houses with much shorter stilts are common in the western and central Gulf Coast. These houses typically feature short stilts made of concrete or wood (1-3 feet off the ground) and are primarily found in areas near the coast and any adjacent rivers.

metas.title: Buildings With Very
metas.description: Buildings with very large, sloped roofs are most common in the states of Oklahoma, Texas, and Louisiana. They can also be seen in neighbouring states to a lesser extent.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description:
Houses in coastal New England often feature shingle walls, which are layered wood panels overlapping each other.

A similar style of panelling can also be seen, however, having a wider range than the one shown above.

metas.title: New Features
metas.description: Older three story wooden houses, also called ‘stacked triplexes,’ are very common in urban areas of the Northeast. They are most prevalent in New York, Connecticut, Rhode Island, and Massachusetts.
metas.note: These types of houses are also somewhat common in cities in Atlantic Canada.

metas.title: Local Architecture
metas.description: Brownstone buildings are typically row houses or government buildings made out of various types of brick and sandstone. They are most commonly found in dense urban areas of the Northeast US, as well as Chicago.

metas.title: Buildings With Red
metas.description: Buildings with red metal rooftops are most commonly found in the Mid-South and Southern Appalachia states of Virginia, West Virginia, Ohio, Kentucky, Tennessee, Arkansas, and North Carolina.
metas.note: These types of rooftops can be found in other areas, so use other clues before guessing.

metas.title: New Features
metas.description: Very narrow, one-storey houses made out of wood are called ‘shotgun houses.’ They are most common in and around New Orleans (LA,) Houston (TX,) Louisville (KY,) and the state of Mississippi.

metas.title: Pueblo Revival Style
metas.description: Pueblo Revival style houses are commonly seen in New Mexico. They are typically constructed of adobe or brick and concrete. They have rounded edges and flat roofs, and are usually sand-brown in colour.
metas.note: Pueblo style houses can also be seen in Arizona and Colorado to a lesser extent.

metas.title: Desert Landscape
metas.description: Spanish Colonial Revival Architecture can be categorised as buildings with lightly-coloured stucco walls and red clay-tile roofs. They can be found in the desert southwest states of California, Nevada, Arizona, and Texas. You can also find similar types of buildings in Florida and coastal Georgia.

metas.title: Houses And Commercial
metas.description: Houses and commercial buildings in the interior Western US are often made of lots of dark wooden boards and timbers. Buildings at high elevations also commonly have metal roofs, to avoid snow build-up.

metas.title: Shoprite Regional Supermarket
metas.description: ‘Shoprite’ is a regional supermarket chain that has locations in 6 states in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic region of the US; Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, and Maryland.

metas.title: Hy-vee Supermarket
metas.description: ‘Hy-Vee’ is a supermarket that is common primarily in the Upper Midwest states of Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Illinois.

metas.title: Supermarket Chain Piggly
metas.description: The supermarket chain ‘Piggly Wiggly’ is found mostly in the Southeast, as well as the state of Wisconsin.

metas.title: H-e-b Supermarket
metas.description: ‘H-E-B’ is a supermarket that is only located in the state of Texas. Most H-E-B stores are in large cities.

metas.title: Florida Features
metas.description: ‘Publix’ is a regional supermarket chain that has locations primarily in Florida and adjacent areas of the Deep South.

metas.title: Restaurant Chain Waffle
metas.description: The restaurant chain ‘Waffle House’ is a regional chain that is primarily found in the Southern and Southeast US. Some midwest and mid-atlantic states have some locations. Georgia, by far, is the state with the most Waffle House locations.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: ‘Carl’s Jr.’ and ‘Hardee’s’ are fast food restaurants that are operated by the same company and have a similar logo and colour scheme. However, Carl’s Jr. locations are all located on the West Coast and Southwest US, while Hardee’s are found in the central and Eastern areas of the country. Two states, Wyoming and Oklahoma, have both kinds of restaurants present.

metas.title: Zaxbys Fast-food Chicken
metas.description: ‘Zaxby’s,’ a fast-food chicken chain, is another restaurant that is most common in the Southeast US. There are several pockets outside the Southeast that have locations, such as Utah and Montana. Like Waffle House, Georgia has the highest number of locations.

metas.title: Whataburger Hamburger Restaurant
metas.description: ‘Whataburger’ is a hamburger restaurant with locations across the South Central US. The State that is home to the most locations, by far, is Texas.

metas.title: Pizza Ranch Restaurant
metas.description: ‘Pizza Ranch’ is a restaurant chain that is found in the middle of the country. Iowa and Minnesota have the highest number of locations.

metas.title: Tim Hortons Known
metas.description: ‘Tim Hortons’ is known for being the most popular restaurant chain in Canada. However, there are also many locations in the United States. They are primarily located in states adjacent to the Canadian Provinces of Ontario and Quebec, with a few locations also in Texas and Georgia.

metas.title: In-n-out Burger Regional
metas.description: ‘In-N-Out Burger’ is a regional fast food chain located primarily in the Southwest US. California has the most locations.

metas.title: Wawa Regional Gas
metas.description: ‘WaWa’ is a regional gas station and convenience store chain with locations in the Mid-Atlantic states and Florida. New Jersey and the Philadelphia, Pennsylvania area have the highest density of locations.

metas.title: Another Regional Gas
metas.description: Another regional gas station and convenience store chain in the Eastern US is called ‘Sheetz’. Most of their locations are in the Mid-Atlantic and Central Appalachian areas of the US. Pennsylvania has the highest number of locations.

metas.title: Kwik Trip Chain
metas.description: ‘Kwik Trip’ is a chain of gas stations and convenience stores that are located in the Upper Midwest states of Wisconsin and Minnesota. In Iowa, these stores are called ‘Kwik Star’ and have similar branding. Some stores may also have the name ‘Stop-N-Go’.

metas.title: Caseys Popular Gas
metas.description: ‘Casey’s’ is a popular gas station and convenience store chain that is found in the Midwest, Plains, and parts of the Mid-South. Illinois, Iowa, and Missouri have the highest number of locations.

metas.title: Kum Go Regional
metas.description: ‘Kum & Go’ is a regional gas station chain based out of the state of Iowa. They also have pockets of locations in the Ozarks, Colorado, Wyoming, and North Dakota.

metas.title: Buc-ees Small Chain
metas.description: ‘Buc-ee’s’ is a small chain of oversized gas stations located primarily in the state of Texas. These stores feature multiple rows of gas pumps, and a very large convenience store building.
metas.note: Some other nearby states have Buc-ee’s locations, but they are quite rare outside of Texas.

metas.title: Alaska Features
metas.description:
Alaska is the largest state and the north-, west-, and easternmost state in the US.

A separate Plonk It guide to Alaska can be found here.

metas.title: Hawaii Features
metas.description:
Hawaii is the youngest state in the US and the only US state outside of North America.

A separate Plonk It guide to Hawaii can be found here.

metas.title: Rico Features
metas.description:
Puerto Rico is a Caribbean US territory with official Commonwealth status.

A separate Plonk It guide to Puerto Rico can be found here.

metas.title: Samoa Features
metas.description:
American Samoa is a South Pacific island group and an unorganised US territory.

A separate Plonk It guide to American Samoa can be found here.

metas.title: Micronesia Features
metas.description:
Guam is an unincorporated territory of the US and the largest island in Micronesia.

A separate Plonk It guide to Guam can be found here.

metas.title: Islands Features
metas.description:
Northern Mariana Islands is a Northwest Pacific island chain and a Commonwealth US territory.

A separate Plonk It guide to Northern Mariana Islands can be found here.

metas.title: Left-Hand Traffic
metas.description:
The United States Virgin Islands is a Caribbean US territory and the only area of the US that drives on the left side of the road.

A separate Plonk It guide to the United States Virgin Islands can be found here.

metas.title: Us Minor Outlying
metas.description:
The US Minor Outlying Islands is a collective name for several small island US territories, with the Midway Atoll being the most relevant in Geoguessr.

A separate Plonk It guide to the US Minor Outlying Islands can be found here.

metas.title: As Part Promotional
metas.description:
As part of a promotional campaign, the TransAmerica Trail from Oregon to North Carolina was covered by a Ford Bronco. The car can recognised by its unblurred black roof and red hood, and is mostly found on unpaved rural roads.

Looking backwards, you will see two other Ford SUVs escorting the camera car.

metas.title: Arizona Features
metas.description: Interstate 19 in Arizona from Tucson to the Mexico border uses kilometres on the exit and distance signs. This is the only part of the country that uses kilometres instead of miles for highway signs.
metas.note: Speed limit signs in this area still use MPH instead of KPH.

metas.title: Many Bridge
metas.description: Many bridges are used to connect the various neighbourhoods of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. These expansive, steel bridges are commonly painted bright yellow. Additionally, Pittsburgh is easy to identify because of it being flanked by 3 rivers and steep bluffs on all sides.

metas.title: Local Architecture
metas.description: Row Houses and other buildings in San Francisco are often in the style of Victorian architecture, with many bay windows, turrets, and ornate exterior details. These homes are built close together and can be very colourful.

metas.title: Neighbourhoods All Around
metas.description:
Neighbourhoods all around the city of New Orleans feature many colourful, historic, shotgun-style houses.

Buildings in central areas of New Orleans often feature colourful facades with second story wrap-around balconies.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: Historical areas of Miami and Miami beach are home to many historical, multi-story art deco buildings. These buildings are commonly painted in bright colours and are located near the coast.

metas.title: Dry Tortugas Park
metas.description:
The main island of Dry Tortugas National Park, west of Key West, can be identified by the hexagonal brick structure and the surrounding moat.

The Loggerhead Lighthouse, situated on the Loggerhead Key, has a brown top-half and a white bottom. The path on which the trekker walks on is also made of bright concrete, and many palm trees can be seen around the lighthouse.

metas.title: Florida Keys Archipelago
metas.description:
The Florida Keys are an archipelago of tropical islands west of Miami. The highway connecting the islands can be recognized by green, tropical vegetation on the sides of the usually single lane road. The soil is also sandy white.

Urban locations are also similar, but with many more planted palm trees and mowed grass being a common sight.

metas.title: Deep South Florida
metas.description: Deep South Florida, between the metropolitan areas of Ft. Myers and Miami, features dense, jungle-like forests that have few inhabitants. Roads through these areas are commonly very straight and long.

metas.title: Rolling Hills
metas.description: The area between the cities of Orlando and Lakeland in Florida sometimes feature low, rolling hills. Lakes and agricultural fields are also common in this area. This is the only main hilly area in central or southern Florida.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Southwestern Oklahoma features a small area of rocky, shrubby peaks. Some of the mountains are also covered in trees, and the rocks can have a pinkish red tint to them.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: Central Colorado is home to a large North-to-South oriented mountain ridge. This divides the Rocky Mountains to the west and the Great Plains to the east.These mountains are adjacent to the major metropolitan areas of Boulder, Denver, and Colorado Springs.

metas.title: Desert Landscape
metas.description: Big Bend National Park is located along the Mexico border in Southwest Texas. It can be identified by its dry, rocky peaks and shrubby foliage. This park is adjacent to the Chihauhan desert, so plants such as yucca and prickly pear cactus are common.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description: Along the New Mexico and or Texas border there is a ridge of tall, dry peaks known as the Guadalupe Mountains. In adjacent areas of both states, smaller foothills of these mountains can be seen with relatively flat tops and shrubby foliage.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description: Death Valley National Park can be easily recognized by the dry, sandy, treeless mountains that can be seen from the roads that go through the park. In Generation 3 coverage, the sky can look particularly dusty.
metas.note: Many smaller roads in Death Valley only have Generation 1 coverage.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description: Along the Canadian border in Montana lies Glacier National Park. It is easily recognizable by its extremely tall and steep mountain peaks. Most coverage is also hazy and taken during summer.
metas.note: Other National Parks within the Rocky Mountain range of the US can have a similar appearance, so consider other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Badlands Park
metas.description: Badlands National Park features these distinct, sand-brown, eroded rock formations. The formations may sometimes appear more rounded, and lighter in colour.

metas.title: Fall Colors
metas.description: Theodore Roosevelt National Park features similar, sand-brown, eroded rock formations to Badlands National Park. The rock formations in this park tend to have more trees on them. Additionally, almost all coverage has fall colours visible.
metas.note: Similar formations can be seen in far eastern Montana as well.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description: In far Northeastern Wyoming lies Devil’s Tower, which is a very tall, standalone butte protruding from the surrounding land. This can sometimes be seen from many miles away because of the lack of nearby mountains.

metas.title: Tall Mountains
metas.description: The Black Hills, located in far Western South Dakota and far Eastern Wyoming, are a series of moderately tall mountains with large amounts of conifer trees and rocky outcroppings. The surrounding areas are typically much flatter with lesser tree cover.
metas.note: This area has a similar appearance to many areas within the Rocky Mountains, which lie further to the West.

metas.title: Coastal Coverage
metas.description: American Samoa is a group of islands east of Fiji, located in the Pacific Ocean. Since it is a US overseas territory, for country streak purposes, it is counted as the US.

metas.title: Mountain Terrain
metas.description: The general landscape consists of green, tropical mountains with many palm trees. Small roads are often made of concrete. Most houses are one storey, and have a simple box design. Plain metal sheet roofs are also very common.

metas.title: Slightly Rusted Black
metas.description:
A slightly rusted black truck bed can be seen on the main island of Tutuila.

This is the most common car that will be seen as it has the most coverage.

metas.title: Bridge Features
metas.description:
The front of a silver-grey truck with side mirrors can be seen on Manu’a and Olosega, which are connected by a bridge.

See below for more information.

metas.title: Front Similar Truck
metas.description: The front of a similar truck can be seen on the easternmost covered island of Tau. However, the truck will be glossy black, with side mirrors visible.

metas.title: lane Bridge
metas.description: The single-lane bridge, connecting the islands of Manu’a and Olosega, can be easily recognized by the thin wire guardrail, with the two islands on either side of the bridge.

metas.title: Airport Features
metas.description: Ofu Airport is small with a concrete runway. The Google Car covering it has two orange straps on the roof. Many palm trees can also be seen on the other side of the runway.

metas.title: Eucalyptus Trees
metas.description: Gum trees (eucalyptus) are by far the most common type of tree in Australia. Their bark is typically light-coloured, with puffy puffy clusters of leaves.
metas.note: Their look may vary significantly, depending on your location within the country. More details can be found in the region-guessing section.

metas.title: Australian Bollards
metas.description: Australian bollards are white, with a red reflector on the front, and a grey reflector on the back.
metas.note: New Zealand uses a bollard where the red reflector wraps around the back, meaning the reflector goes from end to end while the Australian one stops in the middle.

metas.title: Left-Hand Traffic
metas.description: Australia drives on the left.
metas.note: A handful of other countries also drive on the left. See this infographic for more information.

metas.title: White Road Lines
metas.description: Australia uses almost exclusively white road lines, with a few rare exceptions in alpine regions such as Mount Kosciuszko and Mount Hotham.
metas.note: If you are considering guessing in Australia, but see yellow outside lines or a yellow middle line, you will probably be in South Africa or New Zealand respectively. Note that New Zealand can have all white road lines as well.

metas.title: Rumble Strips
metas.description: Outside lines in Australia sometimes feature rumble strips that look like small white stripes perpendicular to the road line.
metas.note:
Northern Territory roads very rarely have rumble strips.

In addition, you can find similar rumble strips in New Zealand.

metas.title: Give Way Signs
metas.description: Give-way signs in Australia have a white border and black text.
metas.note: New Zealand’s give-way signs use red, instead of black, text. Give-way signs are very rarely seen in South Africa.

metas.title: Chevron Colors
metas.description: Australia uses white on black and black on yellow chevrons.

metas.title: Distance Signs
metas.description: Green signs with white arrows on either side can be seen at intersections which show nearby towns or cities. A number indicating the number of kilometres away the town can sometimes be seen.

metas.title: Speed Limit Signs
metas.description: Australian speed limit signs have black text in a red circle on a large white rectangle.
metas.note: New Zealand speed limit signs normally do not have the white rectangular background.

metas.title: Gen 3 Antenna
metas.description: A long antenna can be seen in Generation 3 coverage.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Different states use different licence plate designs, which can be somewhat visible through the blur.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description: Australian phone numbers are 8 digits with a 2-digit area code in front. A map of these by state can be seen here. Keep in mind, not all phone numbers will include an area code in front of it.

metas.title: Bus Stop Designs
metas.description: Each state has a unique bus stop design. These are quite common in urban rounds, so are worth learning. Darwin bus stops are usually concrete shelters.
metas.note:
The designs may vary slightly, but should still be recognisable. There are multiple versions of Tasmanian bus stops, but most of them should have the word ‘metro’ on it.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Stobie Poles
metas.description: The iconic Stobie pole, made of steel and concrete, is specific to South Australia. The pole tops (trident or rotated letter “E”) are also unique.
metas.note: A few thousand of these poles can be found in other states, most notably Tasmania.

metas.title: Northern Territory Poles
metas.description: These rusty metal poles, containing several holes, are unique to the Northern Territory.
metas.note: These poles can also sometimes be found in some areas of northern WA, such as Wyndham.

metas.title: Victorian Concrete Poles
metas.description: According to a 2006 review, 64% of all concrete poles are located in the state of Victoria.

metas.title: WA/Vic Trident Poles
metas.description: A trident-like pole top can sometimes be seen in Western Australia and Victoria.

metas.title: Queensland Angled Coils
metas.description: Queensland features these unique pole tops with coils that are angled upwards on the sides.

metas.title: Victorian Pole Tops
metas.description: Victorian pole tops feature 3 circular coils; 2 on the sides, and 1 vertical one at the top. At times, other extensions can be seen on these poles.

metas.title: Tasmanian Pole Tops
metas.description: Poletops in Tasmania often consist of a thin metal crossbar bent 90 degrees to form an L-shape.
metas.note: Regular Australian crossbars are usually made out of wood.

metas.title: Queensland Blue Stickers
metas.description: Circular blue stickers can be found on Queensland poles. You may occasionally see the same type of sticker in a different colour, or with the colour almost completely faded.
metas.note: Blue stickers can also be found on French poles.

metas.title: Queensland Black Markings
metas.description: These black markings are specific to electricity poles in Queensland. They are often accompanied by diagonal numbers.

metas.title: Tasmania Possum Guards
metas.description: Olive-green possum guards are only found on electricity poles in Tasmania.
metas.note: Possum guards are found all over Australia. The colour is what distinguishes them.

metas.title: WA Painted Poles
metas.description: Poles in Western Australia often have green painted bases, and sometimes a white sticker or a red and white band attached.

metas.title: Short Reflectors
metas.description: Reflectors that are shorter in height than the regular ones are most common in Queensland and South Australia.
metas.note: Short reflectors can be found in every state, but are much less common outside of QLD and SA.

metas.title: WA Brown Base Bollards
metas.description: Bollards with brown paint at the bottom are most commonly found in Western Australia.
metas.note: Brown paint at the bottom of exposed bollards can also rarely be seen in other states, however the brown section will not be as large.

metas.title: Striped Bollards
metas.description: These black-and-white stripy bollards are unique to Western Australia.

metas.title: Queensland Black Yellow Bollard
metas.description: This black-and-yellow bollard is exclusive to Queensland.

metas.title: WA Yellow Signposts
metas.description: Yellow signposts are specific to Western Australia.
metas.note: Although South Australia does not use yellow signposts for regular road signs, SA bus stops will have yellow posts.

metas.title: Flat Signposts
metas.description: Some signposts in South Australia and Western Australia are flat rather than round.
metas.note: These signposts are usually yellow in Western Australia.

metas.title: NT Yellow Stickers
metas.description: Signposts in the Northern Territory can feature these yellow stickers.

metas.title: Fluorescent Sign Border
metas.description: Road signs with a fluorescent border are almost exclusively found in Queensland.

metas.title: NSW No Stopping
metas.description: New South Wales is the only state to use red ‘No Stopping’ signs.
metas.note: All other states use white versions.

metas.title: ACT Parking Signs
metas.description: The white ‘No Stopping’ and ‘No Parking’ signs that include text are unique to the Australian Capital Territory.

metas.title: Tasmania Directional Signs
metas.description: White directional signs can only be found in Tasmania.

metas.title: C Roads
metas.description: Roads that start with the letter ‘C’ are only found in Victoria and Tasmania. In addition, South Australia has some C roads near the border with Victoria.
metas.note: Since these are smaller and less major roads, Generation 1 or 2 is common.

metas.title: SA School Zone
metas.description: South Australia is the only Australian state that uses a 25 speed limit in school zones.

metas.title: NT Speed Limit
metas.description: Within Australia, a speed limit of 130 km/h can only be found in the Northern Territory.

metas.title: Thin Keep Left Sign
metas.description: Some ‘Keep Left’ signs in New South Wales, Queensland, and the Northern Territory use this thinner version, which does not include an arrow.

metas.title: Traffic Light Borders
metas.description: Traffic lights with a white outline around the frame are found in the eastern and western states of WA, QLD, NSW, ACT and Tas. Traffic lights without a border are found in the remaining, central states.

metas.title: WA Property Markers
metas.description: You can find these dark green property markers on the sides of roads in Western Australia.

metas.title: SA Property Markers
metas.description: You can find these white property markers on the sides of roads in South Australia.

metas.title: NSW Guardrail Ending
metas.description: This guardrail ending, featuring a black dash on a yellow background, is almost exclusive to New South Wales and the ACT.

metas.title: Victorian Hydrant Poles
metas.description: You can find these white hydrant poles that feature a blue circle and a red section on top of it in Victoria.

metas.title: Victorian Fire Hydrants
metas.description: These fire hydrants with red painted tops are unique to Victoria.

metas.title: WA Red Soil
metas.description: Western Australia, and especially the Perth area, is known for its reddish-orange soil.
metas.note: Although this is very useful, there are numerous areas in WA with light soil, and conversely there are areas in other states with reddish-orange soil.

metas.title: WA Brush Plants
metas.description: These brush plants are commonly seen in Western Australia.

metas.title: Darwin Vegetation
metas.description: The vegetation in the area surrounding Darwin is extremely distinct. It features dark red soil, as well as rich green grass and trees. The tree trunks are typically black.

metas.title: Termite Mounds
metas.description: Termite mounds can sometimes be seen in the Northern Territory and rarely northern WA and QLD. They appear as brown, spiky formations rising out of the ground.

metas.title: Nullarbor Landscape
metas.description:
The area around Warramboo in SA to Madura in WA has a unique landscape. Vegetation is quite dry and is made up of shrubs and wide crowned eucalyptus. In addition, the soil is sandy with a slight orange tint.

The dry area east of Adelaide and into northwestern Victoria has a similar landscape, with the same vegetation but usually with whiter soil.
metas.note: The soil gets more red in the WA side. Redder soil can also be seen more inland on the Victorian side around Mildura. In addition, the Nullarbor Highway has a distinct landscape.

metas.title: Lush Green Fields
metas.description: Lush green or golden fields can be found in this band from the south of the Yorke Peninsula to Echuca. In the SA side, the landscape should be drier than the Victorian side and more wide crowned eucalyptus can be seen. On the Victorian side, the trees generally have more leaves and are taller.
metas.note: The area near Mount Gambier has a distinct landscape. For more information, see below.

metas.title: Tropical North Queensland
metas.description: Coastal northern Queensland is very tropical. Typical vegetation consists of palm trees and dark green vegetation.

metas.title: Sugarcane Plantations
metas.description: Sugarcane plantations are very common in Northern Queensland, due to its tropical climate.
metas.note: Sugarcane plantations can be seen as far south as northern NSW, however are most commonly found in northern Queensland. For a detailed overview, see this map.

metas.title: Inland NSW Landscape
metas.description: The landscape in inland NSW is mostly flat, and the soil gets redder the more inland you go. Vegetation consists of mostly dry pale-green shrubs. Further east and on the Queensland and Victorian borders, the climate gets more temperate but is still quite dry and more eucalyptus trees can be seen, with the soil transitioning into a more sandy colour as well as more hills being visible.

metas.title: Tasmania Rolling Hills
metas.description: Tasmania has a cool temperate climate which is uncommon in the rest of Australia and is comparable to central-southern Chile or New Zealand. Typical landscape consists of green rolling hills that can look dry in winter coverage. Eucalyptus trees can be seen on the side of roads and on hills in the distance. Rural Tasmania is also quite hilly with dense eucalyptus forests making up the landscape.
metas.note: Certain areas of Victoria can look similar so make sure to look for other clues.

metas.title: No Gen 2 in NT
metas.description: Generation 2 cannot be found in the Northern Territory.

metas.title: Rare Google Cars
metas.description:
Australia is home to dozens of rare Google cars, which can usually be found in natural reserves.

Most rare Google cars with snorkels are located in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory. The snorkels are dark grey or black extensions to the side of the car, to keep the engine dry when submerged in water.
metas.note:
The only snorkels outside NSW and ACT are found on two cars in Western Australia (1 and 2).

GeoHints has a complete overview of all rare cars, which can be found on this page.

metas.title: Island Territories
metas.description:
For country streak purposes, Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands are counted as part of Australia. For example, clicking Australia on Christmas Island counts as a country streak.

These islands have unique cars which makes them easily identifiable.

Plonk It has a more in-depth guide to Christmas Island here.

Plonk It has a more in-depth guide to Cocos (Keeling) Islands here.

metas.title: Tom Price Gen 2
metas.description: The area around Tom Price can be recognized by its red soil, Generation 2 camera and rocky hills.

metas.title: Alice Springs Rocks
metas.description: Alice Springs, an isolated town in the southern part of the Northern Territory, features distinct orange rocks that can be seen in the distance or at the end of roads.

metas.title: Cairns Mountains
metas.description: The northern QLD city of Cairns is distinct due to its tropical vegetation and big green mountains around the city.
metas.note: To differentiate Cairns from other northern Queensland towns, Cairns has many high rise buildings and should feel quite urban. Divided roads are also common in downtown Cairns, and only commonly seen in Mackay further south, where it is less tropical and more flat.

metas.title: Mount Gambier Pines
metas.description: The area around Mount Gambier, SA features white soil and extensive pine tree plantations, making it recognisable.

metas.title: Kangaroo Island Gen 2
metas.description:
Kangaroo Island in South Australia tends to have a distinct look. The vegetation mostly consists of bushes and low, stubby eucalyptus trees with puffy clusters of leaves. The orange soil colour is reminiscent of Western Australia.

In addition, the island only has Generation 2 and Generation 4 coverage.

metas.title: Nullarbor Highway
metas.description: The Nullarbor Highway (Latin for “no tree”) can be easily recognized thanks to the flatness, overall grey look and very low vegetation.
metas.note: Use the road angle or road lines to determine whether you are on the WA or SA side.

metas.title: Barkly Highway Wire
metas.description: On most of the Northern Territory section of the Barkly Highway and a small part of the Queensland section, a wire can be seen on the left side of the car.

metas.title: Dorat Road
metas.description: Dorat Road (23) in the Northern Territory can be easily recognized thanks to its distinct Darwin area landscape and lack of road lines.

metas.title: Sturt Highway Lines
metas.description: The Sturt Highway from Wentworth to Wagga Wagga can have triple broken centre lines.
metas.note: Triple broken centre lines can also be found on other major roads in NSW, such as the Gwydir Highway. However, they are most common on the Sturt Highway.

metas.title: Stuart Highway Pimba
metas.description: The Stuart Highway from Alice Springs to around Pimba, SA can be easily recognized by its bright orange dirt, short trees and blue car Generation 4.
metas.note: Use the road angle and whether there are rumble strips to determine whether you are in NT or SA. Rumble strips are much rarer on the NT side.

metas.title: Perth Sloped Kerbs
metas.description: You can sometimes see sloped kerbs in Perth, where it gradually declines to the road, whilst in other cities kerbs go straight down at a 90 degree angle.

metas.title: Melbourne Pole Stickers
metas.description: Melbourne poles commonly feature these white, rectangular stickers, with a smaller blue square inside it.

metas.title: Mount Kosciuszko Yellow Lines
metas.description:
All-yellow road lines can be seen on roads around Mount Kosciuszko.

In addition, a unique white truck with a snorkel, and cab guard can be found.
metas.note: All yellow road lines can also be found in other alpine areas in Victoria and New South Wales, so make sure to look at the landscape and other clues.

metas.title: Broken Hill Stobie Poles
metas.description: South Australian style Stobie poles can sometimes be found in the NSW town of Broken Hill.

metas.title: Brisbane Street Sign
metas.description: This street sign is unique to Brisbane City Council.

metas.title: Gold Coast Street Sign
metas.description: This street sign is unique to Gold Coast City Council.

metas.title: Sydney Street Sign
metas.description: This street sign is unique to the City of Sydney.

metas.title: Location Map
metas.description: Christmas Island is a small island territory south-southwest of Java. It is an Australian external territory, so for country streaks purposes it is counted as part of Australia.
metas.note: Do not get its location confused with the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, which are another Australian territory a little west of Christmas Island.

metas.title: Silver Pickup Truck
metas.description:
Christmas Island has two types of coverage: car coverage and a couple of trekkers.

The car coverage was done with a unique Google car: a silver pickup truck, with the bed of the truck visible. Usually, this is all you need to identify Christmas Island.

metas.title: Dense Tropical Forest
metas.description: Most of Christmas Island is covered by dense tropical forest. Some unpaved roads feature bright, white sandy soil. A small part of the coverage is in built-up areas. And in some places, palms can be seen.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Christmas Island uses the standard Australian bollard. It is a simple white bollard with a red reflector on the front, and a grey reflector on the back.
metas.note: In general, road infrastructure metas are similar to those found on mainland Australia, such as speed limit signs, green sign backgrounds, etc.

metas.title: Yellow License Plates
metas.description: Christmas Island has yellow licence plates.

metas.title: Rural Trails
metas.description: While much of the coverage is on regular roads, the Google car also drove on some very rural trails.

metas.title: Built-up Areas
metas.description: The built-up areas are in the northeast. The rest of the island is mostly covered by dense forest.

metas.title: Boat Trekker
metas.description: There is a boat trekker near the north coast of the island. Some of the boat’s white-coloured deck pokes through the blur. Much of the trekker closely hugs the coast; here you can see the steep, rocky coastline of Christmas Island.

metas.title: Trail Trekkers
metas.description: There is an abundance of smaller trail trekkers all over the island. These are mostly surrounded by very dense foliage, but occasionally you can encounter interesting sights like beaches and lookouts.
metas.note: Click here for a larger map of their locations.

metas.title: Jln Pantai Road
metas.description: An exception to the road coverage mostly having car meta is the coastal Jln Pantai road, where a regular trekker was used. On this road, you will not see the back of the car, just a trekker blur.

metas.title: Harbour Cranes
metas.description: The harbour area is recognizable by the large cranes that are visible from many vantage points.

metas.title: Golf Course Trekker
metas.description: This golf course trekker is on the northeast coast. In some places, the Google car also drove on this golf course.

metas.title: Red Crabs
metas.description: Christmas Island is famous for its red crabs. Near Ethel Beach, you can find a trekker walking among hundreds of these crabs. Another smaller trekker where you can see crabs is near The Dales, on the West Coast. Throughout the island, you can find references on signs to these crabs.

metas.title: Location Map
metas.description: The Cocos (Keeling) Islands consist of two coral atolls. It is an Australian territory, so for country streaks purposes, it is counted as Australia.

metas.title: White Sand Landscape
metas.description: The general landscape consists of bright white sand, many palms and mowed grass. Cocos Islands is significantly less forested or hilly compared to Christmas Island.

metas.title: West Island Car
metas.description: This unique car with a snorkel at the front right and the edges of the bed visible is found on West Island.

metas.title: Bantam White Car
metas.description: This white car with the rear edges visible is found in Bantam.
metas.note: The car may be fully blurred. Make sure to look out for other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Bantam Pavement
metas.description: Bantam Village can be recognized by the cross-hatched brick pavement.

metas.title: Runway
metas.description: The Cocos Islands runway can be recognized by it being the widest paved road on the island, with mowed grass on both sides of the runway and this follow car.

metas.title: Coastal Trekkers
metas.description: Cocos Islands has many trekkers along the coast. Most of them will be walking on white sand, with the ocean to one side and palms the other.

metas.title: Direction Island
metas.description:
Direction Island can be recognized by the beaches having significantly more litter compared to the other islands. Bricks, styrofoam and dead coral can be seen along some portions of the coast.

In addition, the trekker can be seen walking between many palms inland.

metas.title: Horsburgh Island
metas.description: The inland trekker on Pulau Luar (Horsburgh Island) can be recognized by the dry, yellow grass, and more sparse vegetation.

metas.title: Medium Boat
metas.description: This medium boat with a large seating capacity can be seen from West Island to Bantam.

metas.title: North Small Boat
metas.description: This small boat with black bars at the rear can be seen in the north.

metas.title: South Small Boat
metas.description: This small dark grey boat with a woman sitting at the back can be seen in the south.

metas.title: Location Map
metas.description: Guam is a United States overseas territory. As such, it is counted as the US for country streaks purposes.

metas.title: Antenna Roof Rack
metas.description: The entire Google car is blurred, however an antenna at the front right and a tiny part of the roof rack can be seen.
metas.note: You will not see a roof rack on the Northern Mariana Islands Google car.

metas.title: Thick Concrete Poles
metas.description: Poles on Guam are almost always concrete and commonly very thick.
metas.note: Northern Mariana Islands typically have wooden poles.

metas.title: Green Street Signs
metas.description: Guam uses green street signs, unlike the Northern Mariana Islands, which use blue street signs.

metas.title: Tropical Vegetation
metas.description: Guam has a tropical climate with a lot of dense and somewhat low vegetation.

metas.title: Reflector Spam
metas.description: Both Guam and Northern Mariana Islands often have a very large number of road reflectors.

metas.title: Asian Languages
metas.description: East Asian languages such as Japanese, Chinese, Korean, and even Russian are common to see in Guam.
metas.note: This is also the case in Northern Mariana Islands.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Coverage in Guam is fairly limited, particularly in the southern half, where there is almost no coverage inland.

metas.title: Southern Hills
metas.description: Hills are mostly found on the southern half of the island.

metas.title: Northern Flatness
metas.description: Similarly, the northern half of the island is mostly flat.

metas.title: Apra View Yellow Post
metas.description: Some Signposts near the town of Apra View are coloured yellow.

metas.title: LeoPalace Resort
metas.description: LeoPalace Resort can be recognised by the white, resort buildings with orange tiled roofs, which looks superficially similar to tiled roofs found on Java.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description: Bollards in New Zealand have a red strip which wraps around the top of the bollard. This strip wraps the whole way around the back and part of the front. The front or back of the bollard often contains a thin yellow or white reflector.
metas.note: These bollards are unique to New Zealand.

metas.title: Black-White Plates
metas.description: New Zealand uses white licence plates with black text, which appears mostly white through the blur.
metas.note: Some vehicles have custom licence plates which make the sides of the licence plate appear blue or black.

metas.title: Concrete Poles
metas.description: The most common pole type found in New Zealand is made of concrete and has one long indent which runs most of the way up the pole. Most concrete poles have small silver possum guards. Circular wooden poles can also be found, but are less common. You can also see concrete holey poles in New Zealand.

metas.title: Give Way Signs
metas.description: Give-way signs in New Zealand have a white border and red text.
metas.note: Australia’s give-way signs use black text.

metas.title: Give Way Triangles
metas.description: New Zealand intersections often use give-way triangles painted on the road.
metas.note: Australia does not use this design.

metas.title: Signposts
metas.description: The majority of directional and warning signs in New Zealand are held up by white posts. Warning signs are diamond-shaped and painted yellow.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description: New Zealand often uses blue street signs with white text, particularly in rural areas. While street signs of other colours can be often seen, blue is by far the most common.
metas.note: Australia almost never has blue street signs.

metas.title: Road Line Colors
metas.description: New Zealand normally uses white outer road lines. Yellow dashed outer road lines can be seen in populated areas. Roads with no outer lines can be seen on smaller roads. Inner lines are either a single dashed white line or unbroken double yellow lines.
metas.note: Australia does not have yellow inside lines, apart from regions with snow.

metas.title: Chevron Borders
metas.description: New Zealand uses black-on-yellow chevrons with a thin black border. White on black chevrons are very rarely used.
metas.note: Australia’s chevrons have the same colours, but do not have the border.

metas.title: Directional Signs
metas.description: New Zealand uses green directional signs. If the sign is on a state highway, the highway number will always be shown in a red crest.
metas.note: Brown signs indicate the direction to landmarks, which can be useful when pinpointing.

metas.title: Bridge Markers
metas.description: Bridge markers can be found on most paved roads in New Zealand. If the sign is on a state highway, the highway number will always be shown in a red crest on a white marker. The yellow marker indicates the name of the river or bridge.
metas.note: Some bridge markers indicate very small streams or culverdens which can be hard to find.

metas.title: Ferns
metas.description: It is very common to see ferns growing in forested areas in New Zealand.

metas.title: Highway Numbering
metas.description: Two-digit state highway numbers follow a sequential pattern from North to South, making them easy to find. Single digit highways run through large parts of the country, but are easy to remember due to the small number of them.
metas.note:
Bollards can sometimes have highway numbers written on them.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description: New Zealand phone numbers are seven digits with a two-digit area code in front of it. Numbers starting with 02 are mobile numbers.

metas.title: Fonterra Farm Signs
metas.description:
The first digit of Fonterra farm signs follows the regional pattern seen on the map.

This image was provided by snowf_lake and brainy. You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Bus Stop Designs
metas.description:
The cities of Auckland, Wellington and Christchurch all have unique bus stop signs.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Rubbish Bins
metas.description: Several New Zealand cities have distinctive rubbish bins. The distinguishing feature of the bins are the council logos on the front. The colour of the bin lid varies within cities.
metas.note:
It is rare to find bins with green lids outside of Christchurch.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Waikato Northland Hills
metas.description: The Waikato and Northland regions are characterised by their drier climate and rolling hills. In particular, the Northland region is quite hilly.
metas.note: This type of landscape can be found in other parts of the North Island, but is more common in the mentioned regions.

metas.title: West Coast Mountains
metas.description: The West Coast and part of the Tasman region on the South Island can be recognized by its temperate rainforests and rugged landscape. This can be seen through the hundreds of tall hills and mountains, as well as the dark, compact greenery which is due to the area’s high level of rainfall.

metas.title: Southland Landscape
metas.description: The flatter parts of the Southland and Otago regions can be recognised by their cold climate and sloping, alpine hills. The vegetation in this area is often quite stunted due to the climate.

metas.title: Southern Alps
metas.description: The Southern Alps, a large, snowy mountain range, stretches throughout the majority of the South Island. Vegetation on the mountains becomes rarer the further south it is.

metas.title: Hawke's Bay Hills
metas.description: Hawke’s Bay has dry, golden grassy hills, and in Generation 4 it will be sunny with a white Street View car.

metas.title: Sandy Cliffs
metas.description: Bright sandy cliffs are a common sight in the central region of Manawatū-Whanganui. They may also be found in parts of Taranaki, Waikato and a road going into Hawke’s Bay.
metas.note: Sometimes the cliffs may appear like sandy rocks.

metas.title: Glacial Lakes
metas.description: The area of the Southern Alps, north and south of Queenstown, contains many glacial lakes, which can be recognized by their teal colours and clear waters.

metas.title: Mount Taranaki
metas.description: Mount Taranaki, often referred to as Mount Egmont, is easily distinguished due to its relatively smooth slopes and its pointed, often snowy peak. It can frequently be identified from afar, as the surrounding area is flat.

metas.title: Northland Gen 2
metas.description: Generation 2 coverage and gravel roads are particularly common in the Northland region.
metas.note: These tips do not exclusively indicate Northland. Be sure to use other clues when making guesses.

metas.title: Tall Hedges
metas.description:
Tall hedge and tree rows are particularly common in the Canterbury region. They are mostly found in the Canterbury plains, which comprises very flat, large fields.

Due to Canterbury’s flat landscape, mountains can often be seen in the distance to the west.
metas.note: Hedges that are even taller are common near Tauranga.

metas.title: Tauranga Hedges
metas.description: Very tall hedges are found in the Bay of Plenty, mainly around Tauranga.
metas.note: Noticeably lower, but still tall, hedges are commonly found in Canterbury.

metas.title: Vineyards
metas.description: Vineyards are particularly common in the Marlborough and Hawke’s Bay regions.
metas.note: Vineyards can be found throughout New Zealand, so be sure to check other clues as well.

metas.title: Corn Fields
metas.description: Corn is almost exclusively found on the North Island.

metas.title: Flax Rows
metas.description: While New Zealand flax can be found across the country, if you see them in long neat rows, you should consider Southland.

metas.title: Marlborough Possum Guards
metas.description: Most utility poles in the Marlborough region have a long square shaped olive-brown possum guard. These can appear alongside the usual shorter silver possum guards.

metas.title: Southland Cylindrical Guards
metas.description: Many of the utility poles in Southland feature a long cylindrical silver possum guard. These are also more rarely found in western Otago.

metas.title: Utility Poles
metas.description: Holey poles are found most commonly in Southland and around Auckland.

metas.title: Square Concrete Poles
metas.description: Square concrete poles without the usual indent are most common in Southland, but can also be found in Otago, Taranaki and Manawatū-Whanganui.

metas.title: Uneven Crossbars
metas.description: Uneven crossbars, meaning they are off-centre, are found in Otago, Marlborough, Wellington and Taranaki.

metas.title: Metal Bar Insulators
metas.description: Poles with the middle insulator being installed on top of a tall metal bar are often found along the Auckland Waikato border, as well as in other parts of Waikato.
metas.note: Insulators installed on significantly shorter vertical bars are rarer and can be found all across the country.

metas.title: White Painted Crossbars
metas.description: Some concrete poles in eastern Waikato and Whanganui city have white paint on the middle part of their wooden crossbars. This white painted crossbar can also be found in parts of western Bay of Plenty, Taranaki, Manawatū-Whanganui and eastern Wellington.

metas.title: Gisborne Yellow Tag
metas.description: A yellow tag, similar in appearance to a cow-tag, is found on most poles in Gisborne. It is also found in a few spots on the South Island, as well as over the border in northern Hawke’s Bay.

metas.title: Warning Sticker
metas.description: A warning sticker attached to poles, which has a yellow danger triangle between two white rectangles, is found in Hawke’s Bay, from lake Taupo to lake Rotorua, in northern Waikato and south of Auckland city.

metas.title: 5 Digit Sticker
metas.description: A medium sized black vertical sticker with 5 digits is found in West Coast, Tasman, southern Canterbury and southern Northland.

metas.title: 6 Digit Sticker
metas.description: A long black vertical sticker with 6 digits with a small black square beneath it, is found on most of the North Island, in Southland and in Otago. On the North Island the first digit will be a 3 or a 4, while on the South Island it starts with an 8.
metas.note: There is a similar regional black sticker with 6 digits but without a small square below it. Additionally, the sticker can rarely be white.

metas.title: Timaru Orange Paint
metas.description: Poles near Timaru often have a tall rectangle of orange paint on them with the text “DANGER LIVE WIRES”.

metas.title: Black Horizontal Sticker
metas.description: A small black horizontal pole sticker, with several numbers, is often found in Taranaki and Wellington. The sticker may rarely be found in parts of Manawatū-Whanganui, Waikato, and southern Hawke's Bay.

metas.title: White Horizontal Sticker
metas.description: Similarly, a small white horizontal pole sticker with several numbers is found in several parts of the North Island.
metas.note: The edges of the plate must be straight, meaning they cannot be rounded. Rounded plates are seen all across the country.

metas.title: Gisborne Road Lines
metas.description: Solid outer white lines without middle lines are most common in Gisborne, but can also be found in northern Hawke's Bay and Wellington.
metas.note: The roads in Wellington are typically narrower.

metas.title: Green Striped Bollard
metas.description: A typical bollard, but with a green stripe, is common in southern Canterbury, as well as in some pockets in eastern Southland.

metas.title: Black Striped Bollard
metas.description: A typical bollard but with a black stripe instead of a red one is commonly found in Wellington, especially in older Generation 3 coverage.

metas.title: Northern Fences
metas.description: Wooden fences with tightly packed fence posts are most common on the Northern Island and the north of the South Island, as well as on Akaroa.

metas.title: Wide Wooden Fences
metas.description: Wooden fences with a big gap in-between them are most common on the South island as well as in Taranaki.

metas.title: Metal Fences
metas.description: Fences with thin metal fence posts are almost exclusive to the South island.

metas.title: Short Fence Extensions
metas.description: Short pieces of wood attached to a fence post, slightly extending it, can often be found on fences in Hawke’s Bay and occasionally in Manawatū-Whanganui and Gisborne.

metas.title: Long Fence Extensions
metas.description: Similar wooden extensions, which are significantly longer, are mainly found in Southland and Hawke’s Bay, but can also be seen in Otago.

metas.title: White Blue Front Car
metas.description: This car with a white and blue front is mostly found on the North Island. It can occasionally be found In Canterbury and Marlborough, on the South Island.

metas.title: Striped Car
metas.description: This Street View car features a white-blue-white pattern which is blurred out, and is mainly found on the South Island or around and north of Auckland.

metas.title: North Island Street Signs
metas.description:
There are many town and city specific street signs in northern New Zealand, which can be seen in this graphic.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: South Island Street Signs
metas.description:
There are many town and city specific street signs in southern New Zealand, which can be seen in this graphic.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Hilly Wellington
metas.description: An easy way to recognize the city of Wellington is by how hilly it is.

metas.title: Stewart Island Gen 3
metas.description: Stewart Island only has coverage around the settlement of Oban. It is easily recognized due to the distinct bay, which is often filled with small boats. There is only Generation 3 camera coverage.

metas.title: Tongariro Park
metas.description: The area around Tongariro National Park is identifiable due to the low-lying volcanic vegetation in the area. Mount Ruapehu and Mount Tongariro are in the vicinity, and their tops are often covered by clouds.

metas.title: Mount Ruapehu Mode
metas.description: Coverage on Mount Ruapehu is easily identifiable due to the dark volcanic landscape and distinct lack of vegetation.
metas.note: This type of coverage is limited to the roads around the Whakapapa Ski Village.

metas.title: Christchurch Earthquake
metas.description:
In 2011, Christchurch was hit by an earthquake. As a result, roads on coverage from 2012 often appear in quite bad shape. Water damage caused many driveways to be cut off from streets due to large puddles of water, dirt or mud.

Due to this reason, many residential houses in the city had to be removed, leading to several districts on newer coverage appearing like normal suburbs, but with almost no houses. This is noticeable when looking at where former driveways used to be.

metas.title: Highway 85 Snow
metas.description: Part of State Highway 85 in Otago has light snow coverage, specifically between the towns of Becks and Morisson.

metas.title: Hutt Valley
metas.description: The cities of Lower Hutt and Upper Hutt can be identified by the wide, green valley they are located in, which runs southwest to northeast.

metas.title: Blenheim Hills
metas.description: Blenheim can be recognized by having a large range of hills to the north and the south of the city.

metas.title: Fruit Farms
metas.description: Fruit farms covered in green netting are particularly common near Tauranga, but can also be seen near Gisborne.
metas.note: Fruit farms are not fully exclusive to these regions, so make sure to consider other clues as well.

metas.title: Banks Peninsula
metas.description: Banks peninsula, also known as Akaroa, is rocky with grassy hills, and small patches of trees.
metas.note: This region can sometimes have gorse, which are also commonly found on the Otago peninsula.

metas.title: Marlborough Sounds
metas.description: The region of northern Marlborough, known as Marlborough Sounds, has densely forested mountains protruding from water.
metas.note: Northern Marlborough is almost exclusively in Generation 4.

metas.title: Otago Peninsula
metas.description: The Otago peninsula east of Dunedin is recognizable from its combination of plants such as cabbage trees, yellow flowered bushes, small groves of cone-shaped pine trees, and New Zealand flax. Additionally, the peninsula’s poles often have off-centre crossbars.

metas.title: Arthur's Pass Pickup
metas.description: State Highway 73, located near Arthur’s Pass, can be recognised by the almost dried out river with an abundance of gravel on the river bed. Additionally, the Street View car in Arthur’s Pass drove behind a black pickup truck with two ladders on its roof.

metas.title: Milford Sound
metas.description: State Highway 94 is characterised by its dense red beech forest surrounded by snow-capped mountains.

metas.title: Highway 80
metas.description: State Highway 80 in the Southern Alps is recognizable by its north-south orientation up a glacial valley. The west side of the road is lined with snow-capped mountains, while the east side of the road runs alongside the Tasman River and Lake Pukaki.

metas.title: Pirongia and Kakepuku
metas.description: The mountains of Pirongia and Kakepuku are often seen together in an otherwise mostly flat landscape. To the west, we have Mount Pirongia which is a long mountain range, with 2 distinct small bumps. Meanwhile Mount Kakepuku is to the south and has a volcanic cone shape.

metas.title: Mount Putauaki
metas.description: The volcano of Putauaki in eastern Bay of Plenty has a seemingly cut-off top which vaguely resembles the shape of a frog, with two big “eyes” protruding on either side of the top.

metas.title: Location Map
metas.description: The Northern Mariana Islands is a United States overseas territory. As such, it is counted as the US for country streaks purposes.

metas.title: Antenna Placement
metas.description: The entire Google car is blurred, however an antenna at the front right can be seen. The antenna is also noticeably closer to the camera than in the Guam Google car.

metas.title: Wooden Poles
metas.description: Northern Mariana Islands have wooden poles, frequently with a crossbar at the top.
metas.note: Guam typically has concrete poles.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description: The Northern Mariana Islands uses blue street signs, unlike Guam, which use green street signs.

metas.title: Dense Vegetation
metas.description: Northern Mariana Islands have a tropical climate with a lot of dense and somewhat low vegetation.

metas.title: Flame Tree
metas.description: Royal Poinciana, Flamboyant Tree or Flame Tree (Delonix Regia) is the official tree of the Northern Mariana Islands and very common to see in the territory. Its wide crown with bright red flowers is easy to recognize.
metas.note: This tree is not common in Guam.

metas.title: Reflector Spam
metas.description: Both Northern Mariana Islands and Guam often have a very large number of road reflectors.

metas.title: Language Features
metas.description: East Asian languages such as Japanese, Chinese, Korean, and even Russian are common to see in the Northern Mariana Islands.
metas.note: This is also the case in Guam.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: The only island with car coverage is the main island of Saipan. The islands north of that have no coverage. Tinian and Sinapalu south of Saipan only have tripod coverage.

metas.title: Commercial Areas
metas.description: Dense commercial areas can be found on the southern half of the west coast.

metas.title: Suicide Cliff
metas.description: The Suicide Cliff is a steep cliff with a lot of exposed rock near the northern tip of the island.

metas.title: Location Map
metas.description: The Pitcairn Islands are a group of four islands in the South Pacific Ocean and a territory of the United Kingdom. As such, it is counted as the UK for country streaks purposes.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Coverage is limited to two islands: Pitcairn Island and Henderson Island. The following clues will be focused on Pitcairn Island, as Henderson Island only has a very small amount of beach coverage.

metas.title: Gen 3 Trekker
metas.description: All coverage was taken with a Generation 3 trekker.

metas.title: Dirt Tracks
metas.description: Pitcairn Island is a semi-tropical and densely forested island, with most of the coverage being taken on small dirt tracks going through the forest.

metas.title: Red Soil
metas.description: The soil is commonly very red.

metas.title: Adamstown Concrete Roads
metas.description: Adamstown is the only settlement on Pitcairn Island, and is found near the northeastern shore. Some of the roads going through the town are made of concrete rather than dirt.

metas.title: Henderson Island Coverage
metas.description: The coverage on Henderson Island is limited to two white sand beaches on the northern and eastern shore.

metas.title: Adamstown Dock
metas.description: A dock with the POI “The Landing” containing a large number of small ATVs can be found at the eastern end of Adamstown.

metas.title: Location Map
metas.description: Vanuatu is an island nation located in the Pacific Ocean, northeast of Brisbane between the Solomon Islands, New Caledonia and Fiji.

metas.title: Gen 3 Trekker
metas.description: All coverage in Vanuatu was taken with a Generation 3 trekker.

metas.title: Volcanic Soil
metas.description: The coverage was taken on a volcanic island, and as such you will often see dark volcanic soil.

metas.title: Tropical Forest
metas.description: Vanuatu is a tropical island chain, with a significant part of the coverage being taken in a dense tropical forest.

metas.title: Ambrym Island Coverage
metas.description: Although Vanuatu consists of 13 primary islands, only Ambrym Island has coverage. Look for the ‘Port Vato’ label on the map, north of Port Vila, to find the island.

metas.title: Volcano Trekker
metas.description: This unique volcano trekker can be found in the middle of the island.

metas.title: Volcanic Plateau
metas.description: A distinct plateau with dark brown soil and patchy grass is seen east of the volcano.

metas.title: Jungle Trekker
metas.description: Tropical plants and many ferns can be seen in this jungle further to the east. A man with a red cap is also seen with the trekker.

metas.title: Black Sand Beach
metas.description: A beach with black sand can be seen on the east side of the island.

metas.title: Purple Soil Road
metas.description: This dirt road with tire tracks and slightly purple soil can be seen east of the beach.

metas.title: Endu Pahakol Village
metas.description: Endu Pahakol, the only village with coverage on Ambrym Island, can be recognized by the small thatched huts and dark soil.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Argentina uses two types of licence plates: a black one, which will be visible on street view with a black dot in the middle, and a white one with a blue bar at the top.
metas.note: The black dot can only be found on Argentinian licence plates, while the blue bar can be found in Brazil as well.

metas.title: Black Gen 3 Car
metas.description: Argentina has a black Google car in Generation 3 coverage.
metas.note: Within South America, only Argentina, Peru and Uruguay have a black Google car.

metas.title: Alternating Concrete Poles
metas.description:
Round concrete poles sustaining three electricity lines in an alternating pattern are very common in Argentina.

Doubled up poles like in the second image is also a good clue for Argentina.
metas.note: Similar doubled concrete poles can occasionally be found throughout Bolivia.

metas.title: Wooden A-Frame Poles
metas.description: Wooden poles are somewhat common in Argentina, they can be found either with a crossbar or without.
metas.note: Wooden A-frame poles in South America are only found in Argentina.

metas.title: Red-White Chevrons
metas.description: Argentina typically uses white-and-red chevrons.
metas.note: Argentina is the only American country with these chevrons.

metas.title: Road Line Colors
metas.description: Road lines in Argentina are mainly dashed white, double yellow or a mix in between.

metas.title: Kilometre Markers
metas.description: Argentinian kilometre markers are typically white with a black strip displaying the road number at the top.
metas.note: The markers on national highways are indicated with RN, while RP indicates a provincial highway. National highways will be labelled white on the map, while provincial highways will be labelled green.

metas.title: Red Guardrail Reflectors
metas.description: Yellow and red rectangular reflectors can often be seen on Argentinian guardrails.
metas.note: Within South America, they can also be found in Uruguay. However, Uruguayan guardrails can be differentiated from Argentinian guardrails by the shape of their support.

metas.title: Flat Desolate Landscape
metas.description: While Argentina features a plethora of different landscapes, most of the country is relatively flat, mostly treeless, and sparsely populated. In the absence of better clues, you should consider Argentina when you see landscapes like this with a very “wide open”, desolate feel.

metas.title: City Taxi Designs
metas.description:
These Argentinian cities have unique and recognisable taxis.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Western Mountains
metas.description: Far western Argentina typically features a mountainous landscape.
metas.note: It is rare to find mountains in eastern Argentina.

metas.title: Misiones Red Soil
metas.description: Red soil is typically found in the Misiones province.
metas.note: Brazil and Argentina can look similar in this region. Make sure to look for other clues first.

metas.title: Chaco and Formosa Vegetation
metas.description: In the Chaco and Formosa provinces, you will often see sandy soil with an abundance of vegetation; mainly low trees and bushes.

metas.title: Grassland and Plantations
metas.description: Grassland with a few separated tree plantations is generally found in this area.

metas.title: Buenos Aires Lakes
metas.description: Small lakes near the road are occasionally seen in the province of Buenos Aires.

metas.title: San Luis Red Roads
metas.description: Roads with reddish pavement lined with long Argentine needle-grass are common in San Luis.

metas.title: Central South Barren
metas.description: Flat and barren landscapes like this are typically found in central southern Argentina.

metas.title: Southern Grasslands
metas.description: If you see this kind of vegetation with flat grass and a low number of bushes, you are almost certainly in the state of Tierra del Fuego or southeastern Santa Cruz.

metas.title: Entre Rios Plantations
metas.description: The majority of tree plantations in Argentina are located in the Entre Rios province.
metas.note: Uruguay and southern Brazil have them as well. Make sure to look at other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Tierra del Fuego Beech Forests
metas.description: Beech forests are commonly found in the state of Tierra del Fuego.

metas.title: Caranday Wax Palm
metas.description: Coperinicia alba, also known as the Caranday Wax Palm, have short, fan-like leaves that tend to grow in low-density, single-species forests. Most common in Formosa, they can also be found in Chaco, Corrientes and northern Santa Fe.

metas.title: Caranday Palm
metas.description: Trithrinax Campestris, or the caranday palm, not to be confused with the Caranday Wax Palm, is a rustic palm native to the Sierras de Córdoba with a broader distribution in San Luis and northern mountainous Argentina. It can be identified by its compact fan-like leaves with a trunk hidden by a coat of dead-leaves.

metas.title: Butia Yatay Palm
metas.description: The Butia yatay palm has arching, pinnate leaves and often grows at an incline with varying heights. It is most common in Corrientes and Parque Nacional El Palmar, Entre Rios.

metas.title: Macaw Palm
metas.description: The Macaw Palm has small thin leaves with a visible spear shaped top. It can be found as a decorational plant all across Argentina, however in the wild it is most common in Formosa, Chaco and Misiones.

metas.title: Cardon Cactus
metas.description: Trichocereus atacamensis, or the cardón, is a cactus native to the high elevation mountain ranges of Catamarca, Tucumán, Salta and Jujuy. It can be identified by its candelabra-like appearance and fuzzy golden brown spines.

metas.title: Toothpick Cactus
metas.description: Stetsonia coryne, or the toothpick cactus, is a large tree-like cactus with many branches and spines resembling toothpicks. Its habitat includes a hotspot between Catamarca and Cordoba as well as the border area between Chaco, Salta and Formosa.

metas.title: Wild Sunflowers
metas.description: Wild sunflowers (Tithonia tubaeformis) are often found in Salta, Jujuy and Tucumán.

metas.title: Calden Tree
metas.description: Prosopis caldenia, known as the caldén, is a decently large deciduous tree with small leaves and sinuous branches. It is mainly found in La Pampa.
metas.note: This tree can sometimes be confused with other trees such as the White Carob.

metas.title: Pampas Grass
metas.description: Pampas grass (Cortaderia selloana) is one of the most defining flora of the Pampas region. It is recognizable by its long bunched reeds and white fluffy flowerheads.

metas.title: Sugarcane Plantations
metas.description: Sugarcane plantations are most common in Tucumán, with hotspots appearing in Salta and Jujuy.

metas.title: Sorghum Fields
metas.description: Fields of sorghum can most commonly be seen in Santa Fe, Córdoba and Buenos Aires. It can be identified by its dark red flowerheads.

metas.title: Corn Fields
metas.description: Corn fields can be found in most of northern Argentina, however they are most common in Córdoba, Buenos Aires and Santiago del Estero.

metas.title: Sunflower Fields
metas.description: Fields of sunflowers are mainly found in southern Chaco, and less commonly in Buenos Aires and southern Córdoba.

metas.title: Poplar Tree Rows
metas.description: Single rows of poplar trees, characterised by their thin and tall appearance, are very common around Neuquén. The area is also very flat.

metas.title: Latvian Style Poles
metas.description: Within Argentina, these Latvian style wooden hook poles are unique to La Rioja and Mendoza.

metas.title: Mendoza Side Insulator
metas.description: In Mendoza, poles with a single insulator attached to the side of the pole can be found.

metas.title: Tucuman Pole Sticker
metas.description: White vertical pole stickers with several digits can be found in Tucumán.

metas.title: Cordoba Road Markers
metas.description: You can find these unique markers on provincial roads in Cordoba.

metas.title: La Pampa Chevrons
metas.description: T-Junctions in La Pampa sometimes have these yellow rectangular signs, with a chevron pattern on the bottom, and the Road Number(s) above, with an arrow on both sides.

metas.title: Northwest Red Bricks
metas.description: Red bricks, similar to what is common in Bolivia, can be found in the northwest of the country, especially in western Jujuy.

metas.title: Mar Del Plata Architecture
metas.description: In Mar Del Plata and surrounding cities (such as Miramar and Necochea), a unique style of architecture can be found. Its main features include quartzite stoned facades, orange tiled roofs, attached garages, and vault shaped porches.

metas.title: Pink Trumpet Tree
metas.description: The Pink Trumpet Tree (Handroanthus impetiginosus) can be found in cities in northern Salta such as Orán, Tartagal and General Mosconi.

metas.title: Jujuy Salt Pans
metas.description: Salt pans in Argentina are typically found in Jujuy.
metas.note: They can also be found in southwestern Bolivia and northeastern Chile.

metas.title: Salta Red Mountains
metas.description: These red mountains are unique to the RN68 valley in southern Salta.

metas.title: Catamarca Volcanic Rocks
metas.description: These volcanic rocks in Generation 4 coverage can only be found on the RP43 south of Antofagasta de la Sierra in northwestern Catamarca.

metas.title: RN65 Mountain Road
metas.description: The western part of the RN65 in western Tucumán can easily be recognized by this bendy unpaved road up in the mountains with its western part up in the clouds.

metas.title: Talampaya Red Soil
metas.description: Red soil with a barren landscape and mountain ranges, can often be seen on the RN76 in Parque Nacional Talampaya in western La Rioja.

metas.title: Cordoba Mountains
metas.description: These mountains are typically found west of Córdoba.
metas.note: They are not as high as the mountains in the west.

metas.title: San Juan Horse Trekker
metas.description: This horse trekker can be found in southwestern San Juan.
metas.note: A similar trekker can be found on the other side in Chile.

metas.title: Mendoza Vineyards
metas.description: If you see vineyards with mountains in the west and flatness in the east, you are most likely in the outskirts of Mendoza.
metas.note: There are multiple wine regions in Argentina, but the Mendoza wine region is the most recognisable one of them all.

metas.title: Buenos Aires Hills
metas.description: Semi-coastal grass hills are seen in southern Buenos Aires, especially northeast of Bahía Blanca.

metas.title: Monkey Puzzle Tree
metas.description: The monkey puzzle tree can be found in western Neuquen. The most specimens are seen on state road 23.
metas.note: They are seen on the other side in Chile as well.

metas.title: Neuquen Degraded Sunrise
metas.description: Sunrise coverage with degraded image quality is found on the RN40 just south of the Mendoza border with Neuquén.
metas.note: The quality of the coverage improves closer to the border.

metas.title: Rio Colorado Sunrise
metas.description: Sunrise coverage with bad image quality and multiple blurs is found on a short part of the RN251 and RN22, west of Río Colorado.

metas.title: Sawdust Car
