metas.description: The “sawdust” car is found in centre-south Argentina and has a unique sandy dust on its visible black back.

metas.title: Chubut Rock Formations
metas.description: Villa Dique Florentino Ameghino in northeastern Chubut is surrounded by these rock formations.
metas.note: Sometimes you will be able to see this dam in the west.

metas.title: Comodoro Rivadavia
metas.description: Comodoro Rivadavia is built on the slopes of Chenque hill, making the city recognisable.

metas.title: Eastern Santa Cruz Snow
metas.description: This snow coverage is found on the eastern RP25 in eastern Santa Cruz.

metas.title: Southwestern Santa Cruz Snow
metas.description: Melting snow coverage is seen on the eastern RN293 close to the Chilean border in southwestern Santa Cruz.

metas.title: Ushuaia Mountains
metas.description: These snowy mountains to the north can only be found in Ushuaia.
metas.note: Ushuaia is the southernmost city of Argentina and the province capital of Tierra del Fuego.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Bolivia has short, white licence plates with blue text. The blue text can be hard to see through the blur, so plates might appear as plain white.

metas.title: White Gen 3 Car
metas.description: Bolivia only has Generation 3 camera coverage. All of the country was covered by a solid white Google car with no antenna.
metas.note: In Latin America, white cars with no antenna can also be found in Peru and Chile.

metas.title: Unfinished Red Brick
metas.description: Many buildings in Bolivia consist of large red bricks. Buildings often have an ‘unfinished' look.
metas.note: This style of architecture is also common in parts of Peru.

metas.title: Road Line Colors
metas.description: Middle road lines can be all-yellow, yellow and white, or all-white, while outer road lines are always white.
metas.note: Road lines in Chile are always all-white or all-yellow, never a combination of the two. In Peru, you can find roads having outer lines with no middle line. Such outer line-only roads are very rare in Bolivia.

metas.title: Concrete Roads
metas.description: Bolivia has a lot of standard asphalt roads, but concrete slab roads are also fairly common.

metas.title: Cobblestone Patterns
metas.description: There are also a lot of cobblestone roads. These roads often have a specific pattern, with several neat lines of stones separating the more disorganised cobblestones in between.

metas.title: White Square Signposts
metas.description: Bolivia typically uses bulky, white square signposts.
metas.note: Peru typically uses black and white striped “zebra” signposts.

metas.title: Guardrail Markings
metas.description: Guardrails sometimes feature yellow and black markings. These markings always have the yellow stripes on the outside.
metas.note: Peru has similar markings. However, in Peru, the markings have the inverse colour scheme: the black stripes are always on the outside.

metas.title: Pole Types
metas.description:
Two types of utility poles are common in Bolivia:

Round concrete poles, often with small pinholes near the top.

Wooden poles.

Poles in Bolivia are very inconsistent and should not be relied on too much. Poles can have a variety of pole tops. On rare occasions, you can find Argentina-style concrete poles.

metas.title: Curvy Wooden Poles
metas.description: Many wooden utility poles, particularly in the eastern parts of Bolivia’s Street View coverage, are noticeably curvy and look like they are made from locally sourced tree trunks.
metas.note: While you may see slightly bent poles in other places, extremely curvy poles are a very good clue for Bolivia.

metas.title: Kilometre Markers
metas.description: Kilometre markers are black and white. The top part is black and features the abbreviation ‘Km’, while the bottom part is white and shows the distance. These markers do not have road numbers.
metas.note: They can look somewhat similar to Argentinian road markers, especially from a distance. The main difference is that the markers in Argentina feature a road number.

metas.title: Traditional Clothing
metas.description: Many Bolivians wear traditional clothing, especially women. Folk dress for women typically consists of bowler hats, colourful shawls, and big pleated skirts (pollera).
metas.note: Similar folk dress can sometimes be found in parts of Peru, especially those close to Bolivia.

metas.title: Political Graffiti
metas.description:
At the time Bolivia was covered by Street View, its ruling political party was the Movimiento al Socialismo (MAS). Political graffiti often features the words MAS and Evo, short for then-president Evo Morales.

Additionally, many random objects are painted in the party’s colours: black, white, and a large blue field. This distinctive colour scheme is a good clue for Bolivia.

metas.title: Wiphala Flag
metas.description: Bolivia has a second official flag, called the Wiphala. It is a square patchwork of seven diagonally arranged colours. It is sometimes seen on government buildings and project signs.

metas.title: Tigo Ads
metas.description: In urban areas, you will often see ads for the telecom company Tigo, with its distinct blue logo. Crucially, this company does not operate in Peru, meaning it can help you solve urban 50-50s.
metas.note: This company does operate in several other Latin American countries, so only use this tip to differentiate between Peru and Bolivia.

metas.title: Reddish Tint
metas.description:
If all else fails, and you have a tough 50-50, it can help to look at the colour of the rocks and soil, which often have a distinct reddish tint in Bolivia, more so than the other Andean countries.

This information should be used with a fair amount of caution, as there are many variables. Only use it when you have no other clues available.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
Coverage in Bolivia is very limited, both in geographic scope and the density of roads covered.

Only the central and central-western parts of the country have coverage. Most coverage is found in and around the six main cities of La Paz or El Alto, Cochabamba, Oruro, Sucre, Potosi, and Santa Cruz.

These aforementioned six cities have in-depth side-street coverage. Outside these cities, coverage is mostly limited to main roads. Beware that “main road” is a relative concept in Bolivia: many of these, even some that are marked yellow on the map, have large unpaved sections.

metas.title: Altiplano Landscape
metas.description: The Altiplano (“high plain”) is an immense highland plateau that dominates most of western Bolivia. It is covered in grasslands that range from green to arid. Some parts are suitable for agriculture, whereas other parts are extremely dry. Grass growing in tufts is common (sometimes referred to as “Bolivian hedgehogs” in the community).
metas.note: While it is generally fairly flat, you will often see hills and mountains around you. However, as a general rule, the road itself will be mostly flat.

metas.title: Northern Altiplano
metas.description: The grasslands of the Altiplano tend to look more lush in the more northern half: the area close to El Alto and La Paz.
metas.note: Due to seasonal coverage, there are some exceptions to this, but in general this is a good rule of thumb to distinguish between the different parts of the Altiplano.

metas.title: Southern Altiplano
metas.description: Conversely, the Altiplano looks more arid in the more southern half: around Oruro, and the roads going southwest towards Chile.
metas.note: There is one major exception to this: one driving side of the divided part of Ruta 1 looks somewhat green all the way up to Oruro (due to this coverage being captured in a different season).

metas.title: Lake Titicaca
metas.description:
Lake Titicaca, on the border with Peru, is the most significant body of water in Bolivia. It is located entirely within the Altiplano. It can be seen from two roads:

The section of Ruta 1 between Desaguadero and Guaqui. Here, the lake will always be to your north.

The section of Ruta 2 between San Pablo de Tiquina and Batallas. Here, the lake will mostly be to your south or west.

The landscape around Titicaca is very green, compared to most of the western half of Bolivia.

metas.title: Andes Mountains
metas.description: If you are surrounded by tall mountains, you are likely in the Andes, which goes roughly northwest to southeast in between the Altiplano and the Amazon rainforest.
metas.note: The Altiplano has several smaller and solitary mountains.

metas.title: East of Andes
metas.description: The area east of the Andes is very green and tropical, with lots of agriculture – especially around Santa Cruz. This area is mostly very flat, though you will see large hills on some of the roads closer to the Andes. The soil tends to have a pink colour.

metas.title: Santa Cruz Pink Soil
metas.description: Within this tropical area, coverage on unpaved roads is only found around Santa Cruz. These roads again prominently have the pink soil that is very characteristic of the area east of Andes.

metas.title: Cobblestone Distribution
metas.description: Aside from being a useful identifier for the country, cobblestone roads are mainly found in and southeast of Cochabamba. They also appear around Sucre and, very rarely, in La Paz.

metas.title: La Paz vs El Alto
metas.description: La Paz and El Alto are twin cities that together form one big metropolitan area. However, despite being located right next to each other, they each have a very different look. See the tips below for more information.

metas.title: La Paz Green Hills
metas.description: La Paz is a very hilly city. Most of La Paz itself is situated in meandering valleys, surrounded by hills that often tend to be covered in green vegetation (as opposed to the more dry hillsides found in many other Bolivian urban areas).

metas.title: Downtown La Paz
metas.description: Downtown La Paz is the only place in Bolivia where you will find very tall buildings (10+ storeys).

metas.title: La Paz Sandstone Formations
metas.description:
In many parts of La Paz, you can see these heavily eroded, pillar-like rock formations on the hillsides. They consist of a very recognizable yellow-beige sandstone.

Of the big cities with coverage in Bolivia, these rock formations are essentially unique to La Paz.

metas.title: El Alto Landscape
metas.description:
El Alto is situated on a very flat, highland plateau. It looks much drier and dustier than La Paz. The layout of its streets is also more regular and grid-like.

The city appears like an unending mess of semi-finished red brick buildings, even more so than other cities in Bolivia. Some neighbourhoods have a very rundown, desolate look.

metas.title: El Alto Pavement
metas.description: This type of pavement, consisting of rectangular grey bricks with slightly wavy edges, is very common in El Alto.

metas.title: Neo-Andean Architecture
metas.description: In El Alto, you can sometimes see a local type of architecture referred to as Neo-Andean. Buildings in this style are colourful, with elaborate, futuristic-looking façades. The style is really unique and is almost completely limited to El Alto.

metas.title: El Alto Gradient Doors
metas.description: Gates and doors in El Alto are sometimes painted with a gradient pattern, usually dark green to light green, or red to yellow.

metas.title: Cochabamba Mountains
metas.description: Cochabamba is situated in a large flat valley, where you will almost always see an imposing wall of mountains to your north. This is the single most useful and consistent way of distinguishing this city from other places in Bolivia.

metas.title: Oruro Landscape
metas.description:
Of all the major cities in Bolivia, Oruro is situated in by far the most dry landscape.

In Oruro, you will also usually be able to see a large dry hill to your west, in an otherwise mostly flat and very arid landscape.
metas.note: Potosí is also located in an arid landscape. However, it is considerably hillier.

metas.title: Sucre Hills
metas.description: Sucre is situated in a very hilly landscape, and as a result you can see many elevation changes in its streets. Uniquely, you can see these round, tree-covered hills in many parts of the city.

metas.title: Sucre Historic Centre
metas.description: Sucre has a well-preserved historic city centre, with lots of old colonial buildings. The downtown area can be recognized by the white walls, orange tiled roofs, and generally more historic look than other places in Bolivia.

metas.title: Potosi Arid Hills
metas.description: Potosí is also situated in a very hilly landscape, like Sucre. However, its landscape is much more arid, with little to no trees atop the hills.

metas.title: Cerro Rico Potosi
metas.description: In many parts of Potosí, you can see this colossal pyramid-shaped mountain called Cerro Rico. It is famous for having massive quantities of silver ore, and as a result its surface is stripped bare by extensive mining – which is distinctly visible in the street view coverage.

metas.title: Santa Cruz Tropical
metas.description:
Santa Cruz is the only large Bolivian city located in a tropical (and flat) landscape.

Note that there are several smaller towns around Santa Cruz that look essentially identical. Some of these have extensive side-road coverage too.

metas.title: Ruta 1 Lake Views
metas.description:
Ruta 1 west of El Alto is a paved road that runs through green grasslands. The road itself is mostly flat, but you will usually see hills nearby. On the road, you will often see numbers marked in white paint.

Near the western end of the road, close to Desaguadero and the border with Peru, you will be able to see Lake Titicaca to your north.
metas.note: This road can look very similar to Ruta 2 northwest of El Alto. Road angles can help if you are not sure.

metas.title: Ruta 3 Pongo
metas.description: The section of Ruta 3 around Pongo, northeast of La Paz, can easily be recognised by the breathtaking views of enormous mountains, which are often surrounded by low-hanging clouds. The mountains are also recognizable by their dark grey rocks lightly covered in greenish grass.

metas.title: Yungas Road
metas.description: The N Yungas Road (also popularly known as Death Road), is a bendy, small and unpaved road, high up in the mountains east of La Paz. The vegetation is very tropical. The coverage in the southern part of the road is very foggy. True to its unofficial name, this road looks like a very dangerous drive. You can sometimes see some daring cyclists.
metas.note: The northern half of this road looks less foggy and dangerous. However, it should still be recognizable, as it is the only dirt road meandering through jungle hills in Bolivia.

metas.title: Divided Highway 1 & 4
metas.description:
Ruta 1 and 4 between La Paz and Oruro is a large divided highway that runs through the Altiplano landscape of western Bolivia.

It is the only large, divided highway in the entire country. There are smaller, divided roads in and near some urban areas, but those should be easily distinguishable based on landscape and road size.

metas.title: Ruta 4 Square Smudge
metas.description: A long section of Ruta 4 has a distinctive square smudge on the front left of the camera. This coverage starts in the altiplano near Vila Vila, going east through Cochabamba, all the way to Buena Vista in the flat Amazonian part of Bolivia.

metas.title: Morochata Road
metas.description:
Around Morochata, northwest of Cochabamba on Ruta 25, there is a small isolated piece of coverage that looks extremely similar to Peru. It is a dirt road that meanders through a mountainous landscape. Knowing this road can be extremely helpful for country streak purposes.

The western part of this road is located in a green mountain landscape, with fields on the mountain slopes and lots of eucalyptus trees around.

Towards the east, it transitions into a more arid high altitude landscape that still looks very similar to Peru.

metas.title: Ruta 1 Snow
metas.description:
Ruta 1 between Machacamarca and Guindal runs through an arid landscape where you will often see patches of snow on the hilltops, and sometimes even next to the road. Weather conditions range from cloudy to fully overcast, lending this coverage a gloomy look.

The aforementioned road can be regionguessed even more precisely. See the next two tips.

metas.title: North of Challapata
metas.description: The section north of Challapata runs in a general NNW direction, with straight roads in flat terrain, with hills on one or both sides. Weather conditions are a little bit better, with some of the sky visible, especially when looking south.

metas.title: Southeast of Challapata
metas.description: The section southeast of Challapata tends to be more curvy and hilly. The weather is much worse, with grey skies.

metas.title: Ruta 7 Glitch
metas.description: The section of Ruta 7 between Mairana and the outskirts of Santa Cruz has coverage with a camera bug that causes a visual glitch. It is a distinctive, neon-like discoloration, that (depending on the road angle) is usually more or less to your north.
metas.note: This glitch can also rarely be found in some limited areas in and around Santa Cruz. In these areas, the glitch is often not as severe.

metas.title: Mataral Green Hills
metas.description:
The roads around the town of Mataral have recognizable coverage: a very green, hilly landscape, and sunny weather with only a couple of clouds. While the hills are very green, the vegetation is not very dense, and quite low.

This coverage is limited to Ruta 7 from Comarapa to Mairana, and Ruta 22 to Vallegrande. Other roads in Bolivia with similar vegetation tend to either have different weather (overcast) or terrain (more flat).

metas.title: Mataral Vegetation
metas.description: In the aforementioned Mataral area, you will often see large cacti hiding between the bushes, as well as trees with yellow flowers.

metas.title: Ruta 4 East
metas.description: The eastern section of Ruta 4, east of Santa Cruz, runs in a general east-west direction, through a mostly flat, green landscape. In some places, you can see some low hills. This road has both asphalt and concrete pad sections.

metas.title: Ruta 5 Sunset
metas.description: The section of Ruta 5 around Chaco, just north of Sucre, has distinct sunset coverage. Most of this road has concrete pavement, and meanders through semi-arid hills.

metas.title: Ruta 4 Grainy Asphalt
metas.description: The section of Ruta 4, southwest of Patacamaya, runs through a semi-arid grassland landscape. Many parts of that road between Patacamaya and Callapa have worn-down grainy asphalt.

metas.title: Nevado Sajama
metas.description:
On the southwesternmost section of Ruta 4, you can usually see the Nevado Sajama, an isolated snow-capped volcano that is very distinct and unlike any other mountain in Bolivia.

When you see Sajama, you will always be south of Callapa and the Desaguadero River. However, you will not always be able to see it on this section of the road, as it is often hidden by hills.
metas.note: The only other place where you can see Nevado Sajama is coverage in the National Park, which is recognizable by its unique Google car.

metas.title: Ruta 6 White Concrete
metas.description: The section of Ruta 6 between Tarabuco and Zudáñez is paved with extremely light-coloured concrete, bordering on white. This pavement is very recognizable and unique to this road.

metas.title: Coipasa Salt Flat Road
metas.description:
Between the villages of Villa Vitalina and Coipasa, there is an isolated stretch of coverage where the Google car drove through extremely arid desert terrain. This small road is located close to the southwestern end of Ruta 12, near the Chilean border. It can be hard to spot on the map, because it blends in with the salt flat.

Closer to Villa Vitalina, the car drove over the salt flat. Closer to Coipasa, the car drove on an unpaved dirt road, where you can see cone-shaped volcanic hills. In both parts, there is virtually no vegetation.

metas.title: Sajama National Park Car
metas.description:
Sajama National Park was covered by this unique Google car: it has a black roof rack with a series of metal bars.

The coverage is on an unpaved road surrounded by fluffy bushes. The Nevado Sajama volcano is always visible. The car briefly drove through the small village of Tomarapi, which can be recognized by its traditional buildings with adobe walls and thatched roofs.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Licence plates in Brazil were white until 2018. Now, a white plate with a blue stripe on top is used. Red is still used for commercial vehicles.

metas.title: Portuguese Language
metas.description: Portuguese is spoken in Brazil, as opposed to most Latin American countries which speak Spanish. Compared to Spanish, some essential differences are that Portuguese uses -ão rather than -ón, -ch instead of -ll and -nh instead of -ñ.

metas.title: Red Soil Map
metas.description: Soil in most of Brazil is distinctly red. It can range from a light pink around Mato Grosso to a deep maroon near the Paraná river. The soil is usually not red in the North East, or in the majority of Rio Grande do Sul, however.
metas.note: Parts of Paraguay and the nearby Argentine province of Misiones have deep red soil, as well a handful of other regions around the world.

metas.title: Ladder Poles
metas.description: The most common poles in Brazil have some resemblance to a ladder in the bottom portion. They are rectangular, have long segments running through the bottom, and small holes near the top.
metas.note: Paraguay uses similar poles.

metas.title: Black Sign Backs
metas.description: Most Brazilian road signs have the backs painted black.
metas.note: This is also common in Paraguay.

metas.title: Blue Kilometre Markers
metas.description: Blue road markers with the road number and kilometre can be seen on the sides of roads.

metas.title: Yellow-Black Chevrons
metas.description: Brazil uses yellow on black chevrons, as opposed to most of South America, which use black on yellow chevrons.

metas.title: Road Line Colors
metas.description: Roads in Brazil will usually feature double yellow middle lines, with white outer lines. Roads can occasionally have a single dashed yellow line.

metas.title: White Kerbs
metas.description: There are frequently white painted kerbs on Brazilian roads.

metas.title: Orange Tiled Roofs
metas.description: Many houses throughout Brazil have orange tiled roofs.

metas.title: Transparent Satellite Dishes
metas.description: It is fairly common to see transparent satellite dishes, which within Latin America is generally unique to Brazil.

metas.title: Fortlev Water Tanks
metas.description: Blue Fortlev water tanks are often seen on Brazilian roofs.

metas.title: Gen 3 Antenna Types
metas.description:
In Generation 3 coverage, you can see two different cars:

A white car with a stubby antenna. There is a diagonal coil wrapped around the antenna.

A white car with no antenna.

The car’s colour is not always visible, meaning you will often see either just the stubby antenna, or no hints of the car at all.

The stubby antenna with a diagonal coil can also be found in Ecuador, Colombia, and Mexico.

metas.title: Gen 4 Car Colors
metas.description:
The Generation 4 cars you can find in Brazil have a visible front, and have one of the following three colour patterns:

Blue

White with a blue stripe

White

metas.title: Gen 4 Small Cam
metas.description: Brazil also has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front.
metas.note: Brazil, Peru and Argentina are the only South American countries with smallcam.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
Most of the coverage in Brazil is along the eastern half, with only sparse coverage in the Amazon.

It is useful for beginning players to start forming a rough mental map of where the (limited) coverage is in the western half. When you get Amazonian rounds, this can prevent you from wildly plonking hundreds of kilometres away from the nearest road.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description:
Area codes are common to see in Brazil. They are often notated using parentheses, or at minimum as two separate numbers. Phone numbers are sometimes without area codes, and without them will be 8 numbers long for landline and 9 for mobile.

The pattern for each of the states is very learnable and useful. The area codes are grouped by first digit, so even just learning those can already help a lot. Notably, area codes ending in 1 will always be around major cities and state capitals.

metas.title: State Acronyms
metas.description:
Each Brazilian state has a two-letter acronym. These show up most prominently in the numbers of state roads (found on kilometre markers). They can also be found in other contexts however.

The state acronyms show up when you zoom out a little bit on Google maps, which is also possible in the minimap while in-game. However, for quick and or competitive games, it can be very useful to learn them by heart anyway, as this can help a lot with eliminating scanning time.

metas.title: CEP Postcodes
metas.description: Postcodes (CEP) are seen frequently on street signs in Brazil (though sometimes hard to read). The first two numbers will depict an area, a state or multiple states. The numbers go anti-clockwise from São Paulo, ending in Rio Grande do Sul.

metas.title: Elevation Map
metas.description: Shown here is an elevation map of Brazil. It can help to have a rough mental map of where you can find mountains, and which regions are more flat. The highest mountains are generally found near the southeastern coast.

metas.title: Caatinga Landscape
metas.description: Northeastern Brazil can be identified by its dry soil, shrubs and succulents (the Caatinga landscape). In rainy season coverage, the shrubs are still recognisable, but can be deceptively green.

metas.title: Amazon Rainforest
metas.description: The Amazon is a dense rainforest that comprises 40% of Brazil’s total area. Not many roads are within it, but those that are, mostly go through either biodiverse forest or grassy hills with sparse trees.

metas.title: Acre Landscape
metas.description: Acre has a unique landscape of small grass hills and sparsely growing trees. The roads often do not cut around the hills like in most of Brazil, but ride the hills instead. A similar landscape can also be seen near Maraba in the state of Pará.

metas.title: Roraima Landscape
metas.description: Rural locations in Roraima are mostly open grassy plains with large, distant mountains in the background. Occasionally, you are on roads within the mountains. Furthermore, the grass in Roraima is distinctly thin, and grows in bunches.

metas.title: Rio Grande do Sul Landscape
metas.description: The landscape in Rio Grande do Sul can be hilly or flat with lush, green fields. Southern areas can have some resemblance to Uruguay.

metas.title: Southeast Grassy Hills
metas.description: Minas Gerais, Rio de Janeiro and Espírito Santo often have rolling grassy hills.

metas.title: Espirito Santo Mountains
metas.description: Espírito Santo, and the surrounding areas, often have large mountains with exposed rock.

metas.title: Parana Pines
metas.description: These distinct trees, called Paraná pines, have long horizontal branches with leaves only at the end. They grow mainly in the southern Brazilian states of Paraná, Santa Catarina, and Rio Grande do Sul.

metas.title: Coconut Palms
metas.description: Coconut palm trees have long leaves, can grow very tall, and have thin trunks. They are common across the north eastern states and sometimes further west or south along the coast.
metas.note: Coconut palms grow across the world and are not unique to Brazil.

metas.title: Carnauba Palms
metas.description: Carnaúba palms have short but strong, fan-like leaves and a trunk that is smooth at the top and spiked at the bottom. They are common in Ceará but are also in Piauí and Rio Grande do Norte.

metas.title: Babassu Palms
metas.description: Babassu palms have long, robust leaves comprised of many leaflets. Trunk length can vary from short to tall. They are found throughout the Amazon, or more rarely, down the east coast.

metas.title: Acai Palms
metas.description: Açai palms produce fruits that are popular globally. Most of these palms are found near Belem, but can be seen across the Amazon. They are distinct in the way the leaflets droop downward along with their unusually thin trunks.

metas.title: Moriche Palms
metas.description: Moriche palms have leaves with a rounded fan shape. They are most common in Amazonas, Acre, and Roraima, but can be found in all of the Amazonian states.
metas.note: These palms can additionally be found very commonly in the Amazonian parts of Colombia and Peru.

metas.title: Macaw Palms
metas.description: Macaw palms have thin leaves compared to other palms, and often have a visible spear shaped top. They are very common around Mato Grosso do Sul and the surrounding states, but can be seen much further out sometimes. These palms should be used with caution, and single trees are much less of an indicator than multiple trees.

metas.title: Long Stem Plants
metas.description: This species of plant, with long stems and many leaves growing up, are very common in Ceará, Rio Grande do Norte, and Paraíba. In the dry season, you can still make out the distinct long stems without leaves.

metas.title: Tall Grass Region
metas.description: Very tall grass can be often seen in the centre of the country, most notably in the Tocantins, Goiás, Bahia, and Minas Gerais states.

metas.title: Eucalyptus Grandis
metas.description: Eucalyptus Grandis, when fully grown, is a very tall tree with plantations all over Brazil. You can find them in both large and very small plantations., as well as randomly growing anywhere. You can see them all over the south, but there are some large plantations in Amapá too.

metas.title: Sugarcane Plantations
metas.description: Sugarcane plantations are by far most common in the state of São Paulo, and in the coastal north east states, especially Alagoas and Pernambuco.

metas.title: Soybean Fields
metas.description: Soybeans appear as small, leafy soil grown plants. They are most commonly grown in Mato Grosso, Paraná, and Goiás.

metas.title: Coffee Plantations
metas.description: Coffee beans are by far the most common in Minas Gerais, but also can be found in Espírito Santo and northeastern São Paulo.

metas.title: Round Concrete Poles
metas.description: Alongside ladder poles, round poles can often be found across the south of Brazil, especially São Paulo. These poles are cylindrical and made of concrete.
metas.note: This map and the following wooden pole map was created using statistical analysis of semi-urban and rural locations. 434 locations of 3 poles per location were used across 16 states that were thought to have mixed poles. Regardless of the state, the centre of large cities will often have round poles.

metas.title: Wooden Poles
metas.description: Some states also use wooden poles. They are most commonly seen in Rio Grande do Sul, Roraima, Amazonas, and Rio de Janeiro.

metas.title: Pole Supports
metas.description: Brazil often uses supports on its electricity poles that connect the crossbar to the stem of the pole. The frequency of pole supports varies greatly state-to-state. It is notably rare in the northeast.
metas.note: This tip only works for poles that have a crossbar.

metas.title: Bahia and Pernambuco Pole ID
metas.description: Markings on poles are used by the electricity companies to identify them. This pole ID is long, yellow pole paint with a black code. The ones that start with a letter are found in Bahia and Pernambuco.

metas.title: Goias Pole ID
metas.description: Similar to the Bahia and Pernambuco poles, Goiás poles also use long, yellow pole paint with a black paint code, but it always starts with a number. They also have a rarer yellow on black pole ID, which can be either paint or a plate.

metas.title: RN and PE Pole ID
metas.description: This small yellow or orange plate attached onto the pole by thin metal or zip tie is found in Rio Grande do Norte and Pernambuco. This ID is usually much higher up the pole in Pernambuco than in Rio Grande do Norte.

metas.title: Parana Paint ID
metas.description: Pole IDs in Paraná are usually made up of black paint and yellow or white painted text.

metas.title: Maranhao Pole ID
metas.description: Most poles in Maranhão have a small beige plate with numbers built into the surface of the pole. This pole ID can be found in Pará and Piauí more rarely.

metas.title: Parana Street Names
metas.description: Utility poles in Paraná on intersections are sometimes painted with the street name. This can sometimes extend to Santa Catarina or Rio Grande do Sul if there are ladder poles in the city.

metas.title: Sao Paulo Poletop
metas.description: This poletop, consisting of an asymmetrical crossbar and a support reaching to the middle of the longer part of the crossbar, is the most common poletop in the state of São Paulo. It can also be frequently seen in the states of Rio Grande do Sul, Rio de Janeiro and Mato Grosso do Sul.

metas.title: Ceara and Rondonia Poletop
metas.description: This asymmetrical crossbar with no supports is exclusive to Ceara and Rondonia.
metas.note: While the crossbar in Ceara is usually made of concrete, the Rondonian variation features a metal crossbar, and is far less common.

metas.title: Ceara and Roraima Poletop
metas.description: This pole configuration, featuring a zigzag-shaped top bar resting atop a flat crossbar, is exclusive to Ceara and Roraima. The pole is usually much larger than a regular electricity pole.

metas.title: Pencil Poles
metas.description: Poles that have a smooth cone on top, often called a pencil pole, are common in the state of Rio de Janeiro and rarely in Brasília and Manaus.

metas.title: Gamma Poles
metas.description: Gamma-shaped poles containing electricity boxes at the end of the bar are most commonly seen in the state of Rio de Janeiro and in the cities of Belém, Salvador, Fortaleza and Maceió.
metas.note: A variation with a shorter bar is exclusive to Belém.

metas.title: Electricity Counters
metas.description: You may frequently see electricity counters attached to the poles in Cuiabá, Macapá and large cities in the state of Pará.
metas.note: The electricity counter may consist of one or several compartments.

metas.title: Mato Grosso Poletop
metas.description: Poles that have one insulator on top and alternating horizontal insulators can be found in Mato Grosso and southern Acre. It is also very rare in Rio Grande do Sul.

metas.title: Brown Mushroom Insulators
metas.description: Insulators that resemble brown mushrooms are only found in Pernambuco.

metas.title: White Mushroom Insulators
metas.description: Insulators that resemble white mushrooms are found in Bahia and rarely Brasília.

metas.title: Transparent Insulators
metas.description: Transparent insulators are mostly in Alagoas in the northeast, and Santa Catarina in the south. They can be seen rarely in Sergipe, Ceará, and Brasília.

metas.title: Spool Insulators
metas.description: These insulators have a shape resembling a spool of thread. They are found mostly in Rio de Janeiro and Espírito Santo, and have been seen in Ceará.

metas.title: Thin Insulators
metas.description: Insulators in Ceará can sometimes be uniquely long and thin. They are in Goiás too, but are rare.

metas.title: Para Horizontal Insulators
metas.description: Poles with horizontal insulators are very common in Pará and less so in Mato Grosso. They are rarely found in Acre, Amapá, Tocantins, Santa Catarina and Rio Grande do Sul.

metas.title: Long Grey Insulators
metas.description:
Long grey insulators, not including when they are horizontal, are most commonly found in Pará, Mato Grosso, Tocantins, Bahia, Mato Grosso do Sul, Paraná and Santa Catarina.

They are found rarely in Maranhão, Rio Grande do Norte, Alagoas, Sergipe, Rondônia, and Rio Grande do Sul. Other states have between 0 and 5%.

metas.title: Maranhao Trident Insulators
metas.description: Poles with these black double UFO-shaped insulators in a trident formation are common in Maranhão. The insulator itself is common across many states, but not in this configuration.

metas.title: Lollipop Insulators
metas.description: These insulators are spherical or cone shaped and suspended on a rod above the insulator bar. They are often referred to as “lollipop” insulators. They are very common in Rio Grande de Norte, Paraíba, Pernambuco, and more rarely, Sergipe.

metas.title: Santa Catarina Dark Insulators
metas.description: These dark brown insulators with grey bases are found almost exclusively in Santa Catarina and Rio Grande do Sul.

metas.title: Metal vs Concrete Bins
metas.description: Brazil often uses metal trash baskets outside houses. In Acre and Rondônia, however, it is much more common to see them made of concrete.

metas.title: Two-Part Lamps
metas.description: Lamps in Minas Gerais and Goias will often feature two parts to them. They can also be found in Rio Grande do Norte, Ceará, Rio Grande do Sul as well as the Federal District.

metas.title: Parana No-Arm Lamps
metas.description: Lamps in urban northern Paraná sometimes have no lamp arm. Styles contrast, and are either colourful, plastic and industrial, or look fancy and ornate. Both versions are most commonly found in northwest Paraná.

metas.title: Attached Lamp Arms
metas.description: The vast majority of poles in Mato Grosso, Mato Grosso do Sul, Pará, Amapá, Rio Grande do Norte, Pernambuco and Santa Catarina have the lamp arm attached to the pole, as opposed to it being attached with a plate, which is much more common generally.

metas.title: Roraima Lamp Colors
metas.description: Lamps in Roraima have a similar style but have different colours in the main cities. Boa Vista, Normandia, and Mucajaí have red lamps, Rorainópolis has blue lamps, Pacaraima and Iracema have green, and Caracaraí has yellow.

metas.title: Ceara Colorful Lamps
metas.description: Lamps in Ceará often have a fancy and colourful arm, whether as lampposts or attached to utility poles. It sometimes says the town on the arm.

metas.title: Divided Highways
metas.description: São Paulo has far more divided highways than any other state.

metas.title: Phone Numbers on Markers
metas.description: Phone numbers can sometimes be seen underneath kilometre markers in São Paulo.

metas.title: Cobblestone Pavement
metas.description: Cobblestone pavement is most common in the northeast and in Rio Grande do Sul.

metas.title: Hexagonal Concrete Tiles
metas.description: Roads with hexagonal concrete tiles can be found across Brazil, but they are more common in Santa Catarina and Minas Gerais.

metas.title: Red Brick Roads
metas.description: Some roads in Acre are made of red brick.

metas.title: Random Stone Roads
metas.description: Cobblestone roads with randomly sized stones are most common in southeast Rio Grande do Sul and Minas Gerais.

metas.title: Uneven Square Stone Roads
metas.description: These uneven but mostly square stone roads are seen in western Rio Grande do Sul and west Santa Catarina. The soil will often be very dark in these regions too.
metas.note: The same roads are seen in the Misiones province of Argentina.

metas.title: Jagged Brown Tiles
metas.description: You can often see pavements in Rio Grande do Sul that have brown tiles but are either jagged and random, or square. This style can sometimes be seen in Santa Catarina.

metas.title: German Architecture
metas.description: Buildings in the southern states, mainly Santa Catarina, can be of European influence (typically vaguely German) in design and style.

metas.title: Stilt Houses
metas.description: Wooden houses on stilts are very common in the state of Acre.
metas.note: They are also seen more rarely in low-lying Amazonas and Pará, as well as various other countries.

metas.title: Piaui Red Gravel
metas.description: Most roads in Piauí have red gravel on the side of the road. Some roads in Generation 4 now have tarmac and kerbs, but some gravel shoulders remain.

metas.title: Amapa Roof Smudge
metas.description: In all Generation 4 coverage in Amapá, the front right of the camera is smudged. In addition, all Generation 4 coverage in Amapá features the white car with the blue stripe.

metas.title: Alagoas Rifts
metas.description: You can often see rifts in Alagoas Generation 3 coverage.

metas.title: Joao-de-Barro Nests
metas.description: These spheres on top of utility poles are João-de-Barro nests. They are common across the south of Brazil.

metas.title: Uiramuta Folded Mountains
metas.description: The landscape near the town of Uiramuta, in northern Roraima, features a very distinct landscape. It is dry, with large mountains containing numerous “folds.”

metas.title: RS Coastal Wetlands
metas.description: Coastal regions in Rio Grande do Sul are recognisable due to being a rare flat wetland, which is uncommon in Brazil.

metas.title: Sao Paulo Pole ID
metas.description: São Paulo has a square, yellow pole ID paint. It has three letters on top followed by two numbers, a black line, and four more numbers. The three letters represent the municipality within São Paulo, but are rarely visible.

metas.title: Wrapped Sticker Signs
metas.description: Street signs in Campo Grande and Joinville are stickers wrapped around a pole at intersections. Campo Grande signs usually have extra information and a red and yellow stripe.

metas.title: Rio Curved Lamps
metas.description: Lamps in Rio de Janeiro are curved through the whole of the lamp arm, which is not seen anywhere else.

metas.title: Teresina Blue Lamps
metas.description: Teresina lamps are usually blue with an orange arm.

metas.title: Belem Orange Lamps
metas.description: Belém lamp heads are often orange.

metas.title: Cuiaba Green Lamps
metas.description: Cuiaba lamps are usually a light green, and is one of the few cities that has poles with multiple electricity metres, sometimes 6 to 12.

metas.title: MG Numbered Plaques
metas.description:
Lamps in Belo Horizonte and Uberaba in Generation 4 can have a white, numbered plaque attached to the lamp. In Belo Horizonte, the tag starts with 0 or 1, and in Uberaba, it starts with a 1 or 2.

Since this plaque is new, it may appear in other cities in Minas Gerais in the future.

metas.title: Caxias do Sul Zig-Zag Lamps
metas.description: Lamps in Caxias do Sul usually have a zig-zag bent pole and a yellow head.

metas.title: Florianopolis Pole Stripes
metas.description: Poles on Santa Catarina Island (Florianópolis) are painted white with blue and red stripes.

metas.title: NW Rio Grande glitch
metas.description: Northwest Rio Grande do Sul has coverage with this camera glitch in Generation 3.

metas.title: Acre 364 Rollercoaster
metas.description: The 364 through Acre is very recognisable due to the rollercoaster-like landscape and road: the road uniquely rides the hills rather than snaking around them. There is usually no traffic, and is covered mostly by Generation 3 with an antenna.

metas.title: Amazonas 319
metas.description: The Amazonas 319 has a very lush, bright green and tropical landscape, as it cuts through the Amazon rainforest. The road is flat and mostly unpaved, featuring bright orange soil. However, closer to Manaus the road becomes paved. There are wooden or ladder poles alongside the entire stretch. It is covered by the blue Generation 4 car.

metas.title: Para 163
metas.description: The Pará section of the 163 is often hilly, curvy, dry, and sometimes hazy. It has a wide range of amazonian vegetation. The road is frequently trafficked, usually by transportation trucks. It is covered by the blue Generation 4 car.

metas.title: Amazonian Boat Trekker
metas.description: This Amazonian trekker combines boat and walking coverage on and near the Madeira and Aripuana rivers, south of the 319. They are seen travelling through dense rainforest and small villages.

metas.title: Maranhao National Park
metas.description: The beautiful National Park of Northeast Maranhão, known for its sand dunes with pools of water, has walking trekker and vehicle coverage. The truck is white with a black bed. The landscape can vary from beach to sandy wetland.

metas.title: Fernando de Noronha
metas.description: Ilha de Fernando de Noronha is a Brazilian island with official coverage approximately 340 kilometres northeast of Rio Grande do Norte, and the country itself. It is covered by a white buggy, which is visible at the front. The island is similar in vegetation to the closest part of mainland Brazil, and has large exposed rocks. There is also boat coverage around the island.

metas.title: Road Line Colors
metas.description:
Chilean road lines are either all white, or all yellow:

All white road lines are most common. Within the Americas, they are a good clue for Chile, though not completely unique.

All yellow road lines are seen in National Parks or areas of high snowfall. Within the Americas, these all yellow road lines are essentially unique to Chile.

You will almost never see a combination of the two colours, apart from a few rare exceptions.
metas.note: It is important to note that Argentina has a decent amount of roads with all white road lines.

metas.title: Gen 3 Car Variants
metas.description:
Chile has a solid white Google Car with no antenna in Generation 3. There are two variants:

A plain white car (left).

A white car with a visible black section (right). This car is unique to Chile.

A blue Google Car can be seen in Generation 4.
metas.note: In Generation 3, a plain white Google Car with no antenna can also be seen in Peru and Bolivia.

metas.title: Square Concrete Poles
metas.description:
Chile uses square concrete poles with an indent on both sides. They are somewhat similar to Brazilian poles, however have fewer horizontal supports in the indent. The upper part typically has small pinholes.

Wooden poles are also fairly common.

metas.title: License Plates
metas.description: Regular vehicles have white licence plates, while commercial and taxi vehicles have orange plates.
metas.note: Orange plates can also be seen in Ecuador. Brazilian commercial plates are red, but can look similar in some lighting.

metas.title: Slotted Signposts
metas.description: Slots can often be seen at the top of signposts.

metas.title: Standard Bollards
metas.description: Chilean bollards are similar to Spanish style bollards, with a white reflector at the front and a yellow-orange reflector at the back. They are not super common.

metas.title: Temporary Bollards
metas.description: While regular bollards are somewhat rare in Chile, you may sometimes find this orange, temporary bollard, with two white stripes at the top.

metas.title: Red Fence Posts
metas.description: Bridges in Chile often have red painted fence posts.

metas.title: Climate Map
metas.description:
Shown here is a Köppen climate map of Chile.

Chile is a long and narrow country that spans more than 4,000 kilometres from north to south, meaning that its climate varies significantly due to latitude.

The northern parts of the country, which lie in the tropical zone, are dry and arid, leading to a mild desert climate. In the centre, around the capital, the climate becomes less arid, leading to a temperate mediterranean climate. In the southernmost regions of Chile, which lie in the subantarctic zone, the climate is cold and wet, leading to a cool oceanic climate.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Road Naming System
metas.description: Chile uses a memorable regional road naming system, where the first letter increases between A and Y from north to south. For more information on specific regions, see here.

metas.title: Phone Area Codes
metas.description: Chilean phone codes will sometimes have a two digit area code in front, followed by seven digits. The patterns of the codes are easily memorable. Most of the central states also have different area codes for specific provinces, which can help you make accurate guesses.

metas.title: Atacama Desert
metas.description: The Atacama is an extremely arid desert covering the northern third of Chile. Some parts of it experience the lowest rainfall on the planet. As a result, many locations in this desert are almost completely devoid of any vegetation: you will often just see sand and bare rock without any plants in sight anywhere.
metas.note: The Atacama Desert also covers parts of southern Peru, western Bolivia and northwestern Argentina.

metas.title: Arica Smooth Mountains
metas.description: The region of Arica y Parinacota can be recognized by the smooth, sandy mountains that may look slightly eroded, or have bulbous formations. Valleys are also common, which are rarely seen in other parts of Chile.

metas.title: Atacama Rocky Mountains
metas.description: These rocky, uneven mountains are most commonly seen in Atacama and northern Coquimbo.

metas.title: Atacama Red Soil
metas.description: This brownish red soil can sometimes be seen in Atacama region.
metas.note: This is most reliable in Generation 3. This soil can be seen in other regions in Generation 4.

metas.title: Valparaiso Eucalyptus
metas.description: Eucalyptus plantations combined with a somewhat dry climate are a good indicator that you are in southwestern Valparaíso.

metas.title: Santiago Landscape
metas.description: The region around Santiago can be recognized by its semi-arid climate, having dry hills and scattered vegetation.

metas.title: Maule Vineyards
metas.description: Compared to the area around Santiago, the Maule region has a similar look. However, it has a Mediterranean climate, and is generally greener. Vineyards are also commonly seen in this region.

metas.title: Concepcion Pines
metas.description: Concepcion pines, scientifically named Pinus radiata, can be recognized by their puffy needles. They are most commonly found in Bio Bio, where the city of Concepcion is located, and less commonly in Ñuble and Araucania.

metas.title: Narrow Tree-Lined Roads
metas.description: Narrow roads with trees on both sides can commonly be seen in the regions of Bio Bio and Araucania.

metas.title: Monkey Puzzles
metas.description: Monkey puzzles, scientifically named Araucaria araucana, are found in far eastern Araucania.
metas.note: Monkey puzzles can also be found on the other side of the Argentinian border.

metas.title: Chiloe Agriculture
metas.description: A rolling, agricultural landscape, comparable to New Zealand, can be seen on Isla Grande de Chiloé.
metas.note: Similar looking landscapes exist in some other parts of the country, but usually more level.

metas.title: Chilean Rhubarb
metas.description: Chilean rhubarb can commonly be found on Isla Grande, and on the mainland east of it. Chilean rhubarb can be recognized by its large, cabbage-like appearance.

metas.title: Southern Valleys
metas.description: Lush green valleys, with rocky mountains and often overcast coverage, can be seen in southern Los Lagos and northern Aysén.

metas.title: Aysen Autumn Colors
metas.description: Southern Aysén can be recognised by autumn coverage, having orange and red coloured vegetation. Keep in mind that not all coverage in this region will have fall colours.

metas.title: A-31 High Altitude
metas.description: The A-31 can be recognised by its high altitude, with a steep drop into a valley to the north. The road also has Gen 3 sunset coverage.

metas.title: Ruta 21 Sunset
metas.description: Generation 4 sunset coverage can be seen on Ruta 21 from Calama to San Francisco de Chiu Chiu. In the west near Calama, the sun has just started to set, causing a giant white dome in the sky. In the east, the sky has a warm gradient, and the tops of the volcanoes are seen glowing pink.

metas.title: B-710 Sunset
metas.description:
More Generation 4 Sunset coverage can be seen on B-710 and Ruta 5.

On the B-710, a slight ridge can be seen to the west, while Ruta 5 is more open. Make sure to use the road angle or other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Ruta 1 Coast
metas.description:
Ruta 1 is a coastal road that is easily recognized by the wall of mountains to the east, and the Pacific Ocean to the west. This image shows the various weather conditions faced on the road to help you make closer guesses.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Ruta 41 Valley
metas.description: Part of Ruta 41 is located in a valley, with snowy mountains seen in the distance. Many trees and vineyards can commonly be seen toward the west. Triple yellow lines can also be seen from this point.

metas.title: Large-leaved Lupines
metas.description: These purple flowers, named Large-leaved Lupines, can commonly be found along Ruta 240.

metas.title: Magallanes Yellow Lines
metas.description: All yellow lines on a concrete road are a good indicator that you are on a paved road in the Magallanes region, in the very south of Chile. The landscape tends to be barren, grassy, and treeless.
metas.note: Ruta 9 only appears in Generation 3, whereas the other roads only appear in Generation 4 coverage.

metas.title: Lauca National Park
metas.description: A distinct landscape consisting of a line of snow-capped mountains with two other isolated, symmetrical snow-capped volcanoes are seen in Lauca National Park. Most of the roads are newly paved and have a smooth, dark look.

metas.title: Pampa del Tamarugal
metas.description: The northern section of Pampa del Tamarugal National Reserve can be recognized by the Tamarugo trees lining the road. The road itself is mediocre quality, and in a consistent north-west direction.

metas.title: Alto Loa Reserve
metas.description: Alto Loa National Reserve can be recognized by the vast, open landscape, followed by salt pans leading up to snow-capped volcanoes. The road running through the reserve is paved.

metas.title: Los Flamencos Reserve
metas.description: Smooth mountains with a reddish tint are seen in Los Flamencos National Reserve. Salt pans are also a common sight. The reserve uses triple yellow lines, with short dashes in the west.

metas.title: Nevado Tres Cruces
metas.description:
In the west, Nevado Tres Cruces National Park can be recognized by the vast, open landscape, followed by salt pans leading up to a line of mountains. The sand has a reddish tint.

In the east, the Google Car drives up a mountain pass with views of lightly snow-capped volcanoes and snow on the side of the road. The roads in the National Park are paved.

metas.title: Llanos de Challe
metas.description: Llanos de Challe National Park can be recognized by the brown coloured dirt on the roadside, patches of light sand, juniper plants, and dark coloured mountains. The sky is overcast in most of the coverage.
metas.note: Pan de Azúcar National Park looks similar, however has less vegetation.

metas.title: Alto Bio Bio
metas.description: A vast, mostly treeless landscape combined with triple yellow lines are seen in Alto Bio Bio National Reserve. While the reserve may look dry, there is a distinct cold and high altitude feel. Monkey puzzles are also seen toward the east.
metas.note: Ruta 181 leading up to the reserve also has triple yellow lines, however, is less vast with more vegetation.

metas.title: Puyehue National Park
metas.description: Puyehue National Park can be recognized by the dense vegetation surrounding the road. The pavement itself has triple yellow lines, and tar snakes are frequently seen. In the east, many dead trees can be seen with a lack of leaves.

metas.title: Arica Sandy Ridge
metas.description: A slight, sandy ridge with a gradual incline can be seen in Arica.

metas.title: Iquique Towering Ridge
metas.description: A larger, towering ridge can be seen in Iquique.

metas.title: Antofagasta Uneven Ridge
metas.description: A rockier, and more uneven ridge can be seen in Antofagasta.

metas.title: San Pedro Adobe Walls
metas.description: San Pedro de Atacama can be recognized by its clay brick walls, commonly with triangles at the top.

metas.title: Lanco Orange Signs
metas.description: Orange street signs can be seen at almost every intersection in the city of Lanco, and occasionally in the nearby town of Malalhue.

metas.title: Villa O'Higgins Wood
metas.description: Villa O’Higgins can be recognized by the large mountains located immediately to the east. To the west, snow-capped mountains are seen in the distance. Street signs, fences and many other structures throughout the village are made of orange-stained wood.

metas.title: Orange Lamp Cities
metas.description: Orange lamps can most often be seen in Calama and Chañaral, and rarely in Antofagasta.
metas.note: Orange lamps can rarely be found in other smaller cities. Make sure to look out for other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Copiapo Green Domes
metas.description: Lamps that look like green domes can be seen in Copiapo.

metas.title: Santiago Photocells
metas.description: Lamps in Santiago very commonly have photocells. You will rarely find them in other cities such as Valparaiso, Osorno and Loncoche.

metas.title: Talca Grey Lamps
metas.description: Grey lamps with a thin, flat top and a rounded underside can be found in Talca.

metas.title: Concepcion Blue Lamps
metas.description: Blue rectangular lamps with a yellow stripe can be found in Concepción.

metas.title: Silver Top Lamps
metas.description: This lamp, with a silver top and grey bottom, can be found in Puerto Montt and Temuco.

metas.title: Atacama Pole Colors
metas.description: Poles in Arica feature white paint with a black number, while the other cities in the Atacama Desert feature poles with yellow paint. Keep in mind the paint may have faded, making it look white.

metas.title: El Salvador Black Poles
metas.description: Round poles with black paint can be seen in the town of El Salvador.

metas.title: Santiago Zoo Car
metas.description: The Google car can be seen towing a white and silver trailer with the word ‘Outback’ south of the Chilean National Zoo in Santiago.

metas.title: Banos Morales Trekker
metas.description: A grey Toyota Hilux, with various gear loaded and a snorkel on the front right, can be seen from around Baños Morales to this point, where the trekker continues the journey on foot.

metas.title: Conguillio White Truck
metas.description: Conguillio National Park can be recognized by this white truck with visible side mirrors and an antenna on the front right.

metas.title: Puerto Williams Pickup
metas.description: Puerto Williams, the southernmost town covered by street view, can be recognized by this white pickup truck with visible side mirrors.
metas.note: The Puerto Williams coverage is located fairly far away from the normal car coverage in Chile. The nearest normal car coverage is in Fuerte Bulnes, near Punta Arenas.

metas.title: ALMA Radio Telescopes
metas.description: The Atacama Large Millimetre Array can be recognized by the many radio telescopes in a barren, snowy environment.

metas.title: ALMA OSF Facilities
metas.description: ALMA OSF can be recognized by the large radio telescopes and rural facilities.

metas.title: San Felipe Horse Trekker
metas.description: This horse trekker can be seen to the northeast of San Felipe.
metas.note: A similar trekker can be found on the other side of the border in Argentina.

metas.title: Torres del Paine
metas.description: The Torres del Paine area can be recognized by the sharp peaked mountains, and the trekker walking on a glacier along with other people in orange helmets.

metas.title: Yellow License Plates
metas.description: Colombian licence plates are typically yellow.
metas.note: Within South America, yellow licence plates are almost exclusively found in Colombia.

metas.title: Antenna Car Variants
metas.description: In Generation 3 coverage, a short thick antenna is sometimes visible with a black, white or grey car. In Generation 4 coverage, a white or silver car is commonly found.
metas.note: Within the Americas, you can also find the antenna in Mexico, Ecuador and Brazil. However, Colombia is the only country with this antenna on a black Google car.

metas.title: White Cross Signposts
metas.description: Signposts in Colombia are made of white metal, and join to form a distinct cross on the back of signs.
metas.note: White metal signposts can also be found in Brazil, however these are usually wider.

metas.title: Kilometre Markers
metas.description: Colombia uses two types of kilometre markers: a tall green version with the letters “Pr” at the top, and the traditional stone marker with black lettering. Both designs are unique to the country.
metas.note: The first two digits at the bottom indicate the road number. In this case, the road number is 90. The last two digits indicate the section of the road, which increase west to east on even numbered highways, and south to north on odd numbered highways.You can use this resource to help identify each section.

metas.title: Striped Utility Poles
metas.description: Colombian poles are often marked with unique black-and-yellow or black-and-orange stripes.

metas.title: Wooden Fences
metas.description: Wooden fences are particularly common in Colombia.
metas.note: In addition to the unpainted variants, some fence posts are painted and sharp at the top. These are almost exclusive to Colombia.

metas.title: Yellow Taxis
metas.description: Colombian taxis are always this pastel yellow colour. As opposed to private vehicles, they have white licence plates, which are often printed on the side and roof. If unblurred, you will often see the city name.
metas.note: Ecuadorian taxis may look similar. However, they use a slightly more saturated yellow and typically have orange plates.

metas.title: Concrete Pole Tops
metas.description:
Colombian poles are generally concrete with a variety of pole tops.

Moreover, dark-coloured poles are more common in Colombia than in neighbouring countries.
metas.note: It is the only country in the Americas, apart from Mexico and Ecuador, where octagonal poles can be found.

metas.title: Red Tiled Sidewalks
metas.description: In Colombia, it is particularly common for sidewalks to be decorated with reddish tiles.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description: Coverage in Colombia is mainly found in the north and west. The islands of Providencia and San Andrés, northwest of the mainland, also have coverage.

metas.title: Northern Arid Landscape
metas.description: The Northern part of the country is characterised by white, sandy soil and an arid landscape.

metas.title: Llanos Landscape
metas.description: East of the Andes lies a vast lowland called Llanos. It is characterised by open tropical grasslands, savannas with scattered trees, small areas of forest and seasonal flooding.

metas.title: Antioquia Pole Stripes
metas.description: These pole markings with one short black strip on the top and bottom, and a longer yellow section in the middle, are most commonly found in the Antioquia department. Sometimes, you can find them in the Cordoba department as well.

metas.title: Pacific Coast Population
metas.description: As a result of slave trade, the Pacific coast of Colombia is home to an overwhelming majority of Afro-Colombians.

metas.title: Valle Sugarcane
metas.description: Sugar cane is grown along the Cauca river in Valle del Cauca and neighbouring departments.

metas.title: Southern Saturation Glitch
metas.description: A camera glitch that makes a part of the image look very saturated can be found in southern Colombia.

metas.title: La Guajira Landscape
metas.description:
This landscape is typical of the far Northern province of La Guajira: extreme dryness, low vegetation and occasional cacti.

In addition, you can often recognise the Uribia-Puerto Bolivar road because of this landscape, the straightness and the train track always present to the East.

metas.title: Ruta 90 Landbridge
metas.description: You can recognise the narrow Ruta 90 landbridge between Barranquilla and Cienaga thanks to the dashed yellow lines and shallow bodies of water next to the road. Open ocean can often be seen to the north.
metas.note: In the older Generation 3 coverage, you will also see tall mountains in the distance.

metas.title: Barranquilla Mojones
metas.description: Intersections in the coastal city of Barranquilla are commonly marked by small concrete poles (mojones) bearing street names. For example, this image was taken at the intersection of Carrera 42 and Calle 68.

metas.title: Leticia Vehicle
metas.description: This unique vehicle can be found in and around Leticia, the Southernmost town in Colombia.
metas.note: The long concrete blocks seen in the bottom left corner are a reliable way of recognising the road North of Leticia.

metas.title: San Andres Car
metas.description: Coverage on the Caribbean island of San Andrés was taken by this distinct white car.

metas.title: Providencia Truck
metas.description: The island of Providencia, located roughly 90 kilometres North of San Andrés, is home to this unique grey truck.

metas.title: Providencia Street Lamps
metas.description: Providencia street lights are green and supported by a trapezoidal sheet of metal underneath.
metas.note: The uniquely shaped supporting metal piece can also be found in Barranquilla.

metas.title: Curacao Location
metas.description: Curaçao is a constituent country in the Kingdom of the Netherlands located north of western Venezuela in the Caribbean Sea. As such, for country streaks purposes, it is counted as the Netherlands.

metas.title: Square White Plates
metas.description: Curaçao uses square licence plates that appear completely white through the blur.
metas.note: While front plates are mandatory, a minority will still not have front plates.

metas.title: Black Roof Rack Car
metas.description: This black car with a roof rack is unique to Curaçao.

metas.title: Cacti Landscape
metas.description: Due to Curaçao’s semi-arid climate, cacti can commonly be seen.

metas.title: Pastel Bungalows
metas.description: Much of the architecture on Curaçao consists of simple, one storey bungalows that are pastel coloured. Metal roofs are common on smaller shacks, while tiled roofs can be seen on more expensive houses. Additionally, multi storey villas can sometimes be seen.

metas.title: Coloured Sign Backs
metas.description: The coloured border or road signs can typically be seen continuing onto the back of the signs. These will generally be red or blue.

metas.title: Blue Street Signs
metas.description: Blue street signs attached to the top of yellow signposts are common in Curaçao.

metas.title: Striped Traffic Posts
metas.description: White and black striped traffic light posts can be seen in urban areas.

metas.title: Wooden Poles
metas.description: Wooden poles with three horizontal, alternating insulators are common.
metas.note: These poletops can also be found in Brazil, South Africa, and Eswatini.

metas.title: Western Curacao Landscape
metas.description: The western half of Curaçao is characterised by a semi-arid rural landscape with green, but dry hills. Houses are spread apart, with the roads in the west quite narrow in width.

metas.title: Wind Farm
metas.description: A line of wind turbines can be seen at this wind farm toward the southeast of Curaçao. The coverage is also notably rainy.

metas.title: Queen Juliana Bridge
metas.description: The Queen Juliana Bridge is a wide four lane bridge in Willemstad. It can be recognized by the yellow and blue guardrails, and the view over the city.

metas.title: Orange Or White Plates
metas.description:
The standard licence plates are white and can be short or long. In street view, you will often see a mix of both sizes.

Commercial vehicles, such as taxis or buses, can have older solid orange plates, or newer ones with an orange bar at the top.
metas.note: Ecuador is the only country in Latin America to use a mix of short and long licence plates.

metas.title: Antenna Variations
metas.description: All Generation 3 coverage is made with a white car, with a short and thick antenna (“stubby antenna”). The antenna and or car are not always visible.
metas.note:
Mexico, Brazil and Colombia can also have this same short antenna.

This antenna on a black car can only be found in Colombia, which can help with tough 50-50s with Ecuador. Note that Colombia can also simply have a white car.

metas.title: White Pickup Truck
metas.description: All Generation 4 coverage was captured using a white pickup truck with a black trunk and no antenna.
metas.note: The pickup truck in Panama has an antenna on the front.

metas.title: Low Quality Camera
metas.description: Google used a weird, low-quality camera in Ecuador. This camera is known as the official Ari (or “Shitcam”). It has a wide circular car blur and often somewhat brownish colours. You will sometimes see a unique red logo at the front of the car.
metas.note: Within Latin America, Ecuador is the only country that has shitcam coverage.

metas.title: Road Bollards
metas.description:
Ecuador is one of the few Latin American countries where bollards are very common.

You will find two main types of bollards:

A round bollard with two red stripes,

A flat bollard with two red reflectors on black.

Many other bollards can be found, however, they will almost always have the same colour scheme and style.
metas.note: A similar rectangular bollard can sometimes be found in Malaysia.

metas.title: Ladder Poles
metas.description:
Most poles in Ecuador are round and made of concrete. These poles are fairly generic and not all that useful to identify the country.

However, sometimes you will see another, more useful type of concrete pole: the ladder pole. It has a lot of small indents – resembling the steps of a ladder. Within Latin America, these poles are more or less unique to Ecuador.
metas.note: Brazilian waffle poles also have indents, but only a couple – as opposed to the large amount of indents that Ecuadorian ladder poles have.

metas.title: Concrete Roads
metas.description: Concrete roads are relatively common in Ecuador.

metas.title: Double Guardrails
metas.description: Double guardrails are very commonly used. This is much less common in other South American countries.

metas.title: Chevron Spam
metas.description: Ecuador often uses a lot of chevrons in road curves (“chevron spam”), usually considerably more than most other Latin American countries.
metas.note: Colombia also occasionally uses a lot of chevrons in curves.

metas.title: Square White Signs
metas.description: Ecuador uses a lot of square road signs with a white background, of the design shown in the image.

metas.title: Green Kilometre Markers
metas.description: Kilometre markers are green and have the distinctive Ecuadorian highway shields on them.

metas.title: Teal Sign Backs
metas.description: Sometimes, the back of the signs are painted a teal blue colour. The signposts are thin and made of metal.
metas.note: Ecuador is the only country in Latin America to use teal blue sign backs.

metas.title: One Way Signs
metas.description: Ecuador uses these signs to indicate one or two-way streets.
metas.note: The Dominican Republic and Puerto Rico are the only two other Latin American countries to use similar signs with text inside the arrow.

metas.title: Grey Brick Houses
metas.description: Most houses are made of grey bricks and have metal roofs.
metas.note: This is not unique to Ecuador, but is very common. Countries such as Peru, and especially Bolivia, commonly use red bricks.

metas.title: Hexagonal Pavement
metas.description: In urban areas, you can sometimes find this pavement consisting of hexagonal tiles.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
Most of the coverage in Ecuador is centred around the western part of the country. A large part of the Amazon rainforest has no coverage.

There is also some trekker coverage on the Galapagos Islands.

You can check out the extent of the official coverage on this website.

metas.title: Gen 4 Coverage Map
metas.description: Generation 4 coverage is found in most of Ecuador, with notable gaps in the northwest and southeast.

metas.title: Antenna Wire Types
metas.description:
The Google car antenna has two distinct variations:

The “high” antenna (purple), where the wire around the antenna is entirely above the halfway line of the antenna.

And the “low” antenna (blue) where the majority of the wire is below the halfway point of the line, and there can be a small bit poking up at the very top.

This is most useful when you have the high antenna, since it will always be in the northern half of the country.

metas.title: Elevation Map
metas.description: This is an elevation map of Ecuador. The imposing Andes mountains run through the middle of the country. The east and west of the country are more flat.

metas.title: Banana Plantations
metas.description: Banana plants, and especially plantations, are most commonly found in the southwestern part of the country.

metas.title: Dry Coastal Landscape
metas.description: This extremely dry landscape is only found in the coastal region between Guayaquil and Manta.

metas.title: Flat Coastal Roads
metas.description: The flattest region is located around the city of Guayaquil. This is most easily seen on the E-25 and E-48. The Amazon area is also very flat, and will be described below.

metas.title: Amazon Landscape
metas.description:
The Amazon area is very distinct. It is fairly flat, and contains many of these trees with white bark (Cordia trichotoma), and oil palms.

The vast majority of the coverage notably uses the rarer “high antenna”.

metas.title: Esmeraldas Landscape
metas.description: The province of Esmeraldas can look similar to the Amazon region, but it is significantly hillier.

metas.title: Southern Region Dirt
metas.description:
The southern regions have many winding mountain roads and exposed brownish red dirt.

The central provinces can have similar roads, but the exposed dirt will usually not be found in these areas.

metas.title: Chimborazo Pines
metas.description: The province of Chimborazo is semi-arid, and has an abundance of pine trees.

metas.title: Taxi Acronyms
metas.description: Taxis in Ecuador are very common, and the first letter on each taxi can be used to determine the province you are in. The first letter of the taxi and the first letter of the province name are often the same.
metas.note: This letter will also appear as the first letter on ordinary licence plates respectively in each region. Beware that the letter P, as the letter for Pichincha (the region containing Quito), shows up occasionally in several regions.

metas.title: Loja Oval Holes
metas.description: Electricity poles with oval, see-through holes are most common in Loja province. They are occasionally found in neighbouring provinces.

metas.title: Guayas Guardrails
metas.description: Guardrails in Guayas province are often painted black-and-yellow, as opposed to the generic silver or solid yellow versions.

metas.title: E-40 Highway
metas.description: The E-40 between Salinas and Guayaquil is one of the only divided highways in Ecuador, and the only one in the dry area near the southwestern coast.

metas.title: Brown Roadside Pipe
metas.description: A brown pipe can be seen on the side of a few north-eastern Ecuadorian roads.

metas.title: Galapagos Islands
metas.description: The Galapagos Islands are an archipelago located west of mainland Ecuador. There are only trekkers and boat coverage on and around the islands. There is a wide variety of landscapes, including volcanic soil, low shrubbery, and craters (with Galapagos turtles onlooking).

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage Map
metas.description:
The Falkland Islands are a British Overseas Territory east of the Tierra del Fuego Province of Argentina. As such, for country streaks purposes, it is counted as the UK.

Coverage is very limited: there are only a couple of Generation 3 trekkers. The trekkers are all located on and around three islands in the western part of the territory:

Carcass Island

West Point Island

New Island

Due to the sparse nature of the coverage, that is also entirely not on any streets, it is not useful to learn any territory identification metas. Instead, it is better to just memorise what the trekkers look like.

metas.title: Carcass Island
metas.description: The Carcass Island trekker can be recognized by the open plains, with the ocean clearly visible. The ground may also get rocky.
metas.note: Do not get this confused with the Faroe Islands trekker.

metas.title: West Point Island
metas.description: Open plains with slightly yellow grass can be seen on West Point Island. The ocean will not be clearly visible on this trekker.

metas.title: Boat Trekker
metas.description: This boat trekker can be seen in the West Point Bay, with yellow hills in the distance with the MS National Geographic Explorer in the bay with the trekker.

metas.title: New Island Beach
metas.description: This sandy beach with other people in red and blue jackets can be seen on New Island.

metas.title: Inland New Island
metas.description: Inland New Island can be recognized by the dark brown soil. Tire tracks may also be visible.

metas.title: New Island Cliffs
metas.description: Distinct steep cliffs can be seen on New Island.

metas.title: Yellow License Plates
metas.description:
Peruvian licence plates are either white or yellow. In contrast to the white plates, yellow plates are less likely to be seen.

Additionally, taxis in Peru typically use licence plates that are yellow on the top and white on the bottom.
metas.note: Within South America, yellow licence plates are only found in Peru, Colombia and rarely, Chile.

metas.title: Car Colors
metas.description: In Gen 3 coverage, Peru uses a solid black or white Google car.
metas.note:
In South America, these two cars are limited to the following countries:

The black Google car is only found in Peru, Argentina and Uruguay.

The white Google car is only found in Peru, Bolivia and Chile.

metas.title: Large Pickup Truck
metas.description: An important thing to note is that Peru has Generation 4 Street View coverage, whereas the neighbouring country of Bolivia does not. While Ecuador does have some Generation 4 coverage, it will always have a large pickup truck.

metas.title: Smallcam Coverage
metas.description: Peru also has Generation 4 “smallcam” coverage, which is mounted lower than regular Generation 4 and has a relatively big circular blur with a small protrusion at the front.
metas.note: Peru, Brazil and Argentina are the only South American countries with smallcam.

metas.title: Road Line Standards
metas.description: Peruvian roads always have white outer lines. On highways, you will find either single yellow dashed or double yellow middle lines. On rural mountain roads, you will most likely see white outer lines without any centre line. On divided highways, the road lines may be completely white in colour.
metas.note: In the continent of South America, rural mountain roads, with the features mentioned above, are predominantly found in Peru.

metas.title: Striped Signposts
metas.description: Peru is the only South American country to use black-and-white striped signposts. In some areas, black-and-yellow signposts can be seen.
metas.note: Uruguay sometimes uses black-and-white posts for its traffic lights, but not for road signs.

metas.title: Triangular Bollards
