metas.description: Bollards in Peru are painted red or yellow, and the country mainly uses a variety of triangular-shaped concrete bollards. Occasionally you will also spot other designs, such as these circular concrete variants.

metas.title: Striped Guardrails
metas.description: Black-and-yellow stripes on guardrails are seen throughout the country. You might sometimes find different designs, such as this sharp arrow design.
metas.note: Similar striped guardrails are also found in Bolivia. To differentiate them, just have a look at the outer stripe. Peru uses a black one, while Bolivia features a yellow one.

metas.title: Concrete Markers
metas.description: Kilometre markers in Peru are made out of concrete and are painted black and white.
metas.note: When entering and leaving urban areas, the markers will sometimes feature the road number.

metas.title: Signpost Concrete Base
metas.description: Peruvian metal signposts feature concrete blocks at the bottom.
metas.note: Within South America, Peru is the only country to do so.

metas.title: Concrete Poles
metas.description: The country uses a variety of poles. They are made out of either concrete or wood, and sometimes feature distinct horizontal concrete bars.
metas.note: Horizontal concrete bars are also found in Argentina.

metas.title: Painted Poles
metas.description: Some poles in Peru have painted bottom sections. Most commonly they will be black or black-and-yellow.
metas.note: This pattern of pole paint is unique to Peru within South America, however, similar ones can be seen in other South American countries, such as Colombia.

metas.title: Orange Bridges
metas.description: Bridges in Peru are commonly painted orange.

metas.title: Semi-Arid Mountains
metas.description: Peru largely consists of semi-arid mountain ranges and valleys.

metas.title: Mototaxis
metas.description: Tuk tuks, called mototaxis in Peru, are frequently seen in the country, especially in major cities such as Lima, Trujillo, Chiclayo, Piura, and Iquitos.

metas.title: Red White Stickers
metas.description: Wide red and white stickers will typically be attached to the side of taxis and commercial vehicles.
metas.note: While less common, these can be found in some neighbouring countries.

metas.title: Electricity Meters
metas.description: Peruvian electricity counters have a unique design: They are rectangular, metallic, and typically feature two or three horizontal slits.

metas.title: Currency Sol
metas.description: Sol is the currency of Peru. You will occasionally spot it on street view and its symbol is S/.
metas.note: The currency is unique to Peru.

metas.title: Political Party Logos
metas.description: Peru has many political party logos and all of them are unique to the country. Here is a list with other parties in Peru.

metas.title: Architecture Variety
metas.description:
Peru is home to diverse and somewhat unique architecture. Here are a few examples of types of buildings commonly seen in Peru; ranging from Colonial-era buildings, contemporary “boxy” buildings, and traditional red brick buildings.

Some of these styles are broken down further in Step 2 of this guide.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
Street View coverage in Peru is mostly located in the west and on main highways. There are some exceptions in the east near Iquitos and along the 30C.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Piura Desert
metas.description:
The country is generally flat in the east and mountainous in the west. However, an exception is the often flat desert near Piura in the northwest.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Climate Map
metas.description:
Peru has a diverse climate, dominated by a dry desert in the west, and a tropical rainforest in the east.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Highway Numbering
metas.description:
Highways in Peru are mainly located in the west, and the numbers increase from north to south. The 1, 3 and 5 are the longest and traverse through multiple departments.

You can click on the image to enlarge it.

metas.title: Tumbes Landscape
metas.description: These three landscapes are typically found along offroads in Tumbes. You will always see sandy soil with either green or withered bushes.
metas.note: In addition, Tumbes does not have black cars on off roads. Make sure to consider it whenever you see such landscapes with a white Street View car.

metas.title: Piura Southwest
metas.description: The southwestern landscape of Piura is generally dry, featuring a low amount of vegetation with a few shrubs and bushes. The landscape is mostly flat, but you will sometimes see rolling hills.

metas.title: Piura Northwest
metas.description: Northwest of the city of Piura lies an area with similar vegetation to the area mentioned previously. However, this area is noticeably hillier.

metas.title: Coastal Palms
metas.description: Coconut palms (and other species of tall palms) can sometimes be seen in coastal areas of Peru, mainly north of Lima. They are mainly found in the agricultural areas which are typically found around the major coastal cities.

metas.title: Tacna Olives
metas.description: Olive tree plantations can be found in the far southern region of Tacna.

metas.title: Sugar Cane Fields
metas.description: Most of the sugar cane production is found in the northern coastal regions of Peru near the cities of Chiclayo and Trujillo. Typically you see large fields of sugar cane in these areas. Smaller areas of sugar cane can be found further south in other valleys close to the Pacific coast.

metas.title: Northern Banana Plants
metas.description: Similarly to sugar cane plants, banana plants are generally found in agricultural regions adjacent to the coast in the northern half of the country.

metas.title: Puno Flat Mountains
metas.description: A flat landscape in the mountains of Peru is usually seen in central Puno and around Lake Chinchaycocha.
metas.note: This landscape might look similar to Bolivia. Make sure to look out for other clues before guessing.

metas.title: South Titicaca Landscape
metas.description: Low grass, a few hills, stone walls in villages and brown brick buildings are typical for the region south of Lake Titicaca in eastern Peru.

metas.title: Northern Shrubby Mountains
metas.description: Far north Peru features mountains that are often covered in shrubby trees and bushes. Closer to the coast and the Ecuador border, these mountains are often quite dry in appearance.

metas.title: High Elevation Pines
metas.description: Pine plantations are typically found in higher elevation areas of the country, away from the coastal deserts and Amazonian Regions. The most common types of pine trees planted are Pinus radiata and Pinus patula.

metas.title: Tarapoto Landscape
metas.description: The areas adjacent to the northern Amazonian city of Tarapoto feature moderately tall foliage-covered mountains and can bear a similar resemblance to the hilly areas of Colombia or Brazil.

metas.title: Rocky Outcrops
metas.description: In higher elevation areas near the centre of the country, exposed rocky outcroppings are commonly seen in the sides of hills and mountains. Some areas with the highest concentrations are near Lago Chinchaycocha (Junin District) stretching south towards the city of Ayacucho.
metas.note: Exposed rocks can rarely be seen anywhere in the country, so use this meta with some caution.

metas.title: Spiky Mountains
metas.description: Similarly, taller mountains near the middle of the country often feature rocky and sharp mountain tops. The main region of these mountains stretches from near the city of Huaraz southward to the city of Cusco; generally away from the coast.

metas.title: Green Lichen Rocks
metas.description: Patches of light green lichen can be seen covering rocks and growing on the ground in high elevation areas of central and southern Peru.

metas.title: Dark Red Soil
metas.description: Dark red-tinted soil is found in several areas of Peru. Some notable areas include the areas near Cusco and Ayacucho in the south of the country, as well as areas near the northern cities of Cajamarca and Tarapoto. It can be found to a lesser extent in adjacent regions.

metas.title: Southern Desert
metas.description: Areas near the cities of Ica, Arequipa, and Tacna feature barren and mostly flat desert landscapes that can resemble areas of northern Chile. You can typically see mountains in the distance, primarily while looking to the east.

metas.title: Coastal Dry Valleys
metas.description: Coastal agricultural valleys in the middle and south are commonly sandwiched between dry mountains with no vegetation. The general orientation of these valleys are southwest-northeast.
metas.note: Agricultural valleys in the north of Peru can look similar, but often feature more shrubs and trees on the mountains.

metas.title: Titicaca Brick Houses
metas.description: As a general rule, the closer you are to Lake Titicaca in Peru, houses and buildings made out of red brick become more common. This type of architecture resembles the predominant type of building seen in parts of western Bolivia, which is helpful for remembering where it is seen most commonly. Additionally, buildings with blue tinted glass can be seen most commonly in the same areas.
metas.note: Red brick buildings can be seen anywhere in the country, so use other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Northern Overhangs
metas.description: Buildings with overhanging roofs with wooden supports are mostly found in northern regions of Peru. These buildings are sometimes brightly coloured as well.

metas.title: Open Front Tuktuks
metas.description: Tuk-Tuks with open front compartments are primarily found in the northern half of Peru, and are especially common in northern Amazonian adjacent regions.
metas.note: This type of Tuk-Tuk can be found elsewhere to a lesser extent, so use other clues before guessing.

metas.title: Lima Curved Lamps
metas.description: Lamp posts in Lima and Lima Department often have a distinct, sweeping curve at the top, resembling an inverted "J" shape.
metas.note:
This design can occasionally be found in other parts of the country, such as Iquitos and Pucallpa.

For other, more specific patterns, please see this document.

metas.title: Moquegua Bollard
metas.description: This cylindrical bollard, with a black and yellow stripe at the top, is unique to the state of Moquegua, which is located in the south of Peru.

metas.title: 1N Overcast Gen 3
metas.description: The 1N near the Piura and Lambayeque border has a distinct looking landscape. It features a semidesert landscape and has overcast coverage in Generation 3. The new Generation 4 is drier but still looks somewhat similar.

metas.title: Divided Highway 1
metas.description: Highway 1N/S is divided in the highlighted area on the map.
metas.note: It is the only divided highway outside of cities.

metas.title: 1S Coastal Desert
metas.description: The 1S south of the city of Ica is not divided and mostly follows the coast. The soil is often red or orange in these areas, and there is little-to-no vegetation. This road is also entirely covered with the Generation 4 camera.

metas.title: Ruta 5N Rainforest
metas.description: Ruta 5N between the towns of San Alejandro and Esperanza is a relatively straight, flat road in good condition. This road primarily runs north-south through the rainforest.

metas.title: Ruta 30C Gen 3
metas.description: Ruta 30C in eastern Peru uses a white Street View car in Generation 3 between the cities of Planchon and Iñapari. It features dense forest, few villages, and resembles interior areas of Brazil. Some of this area has been overwritten with Generation 4. Most of this segment runs north to south.

metas.title: Ruta 28B Valley
metas.description: Ruta 28B between the towns of Kimbiri and Echarate is a paved road with very faded or missing road lines. It is also characterised by being a relatively small road with Generation 4 coverage, which hugs the hillside and is located next to a river valley.

metas.title: Jauja Huancayo Valley
metas.description: The valley connecting the cities of Jauja and Huancayo features a flat plain with plentiful trees, agricultural areas, and small villages. North-south oriented mountains can be seen on both edges of the valley.

metas.title: Titicaca North Season
metas.description: The coverage on the north side of Lake Titicaca was taken during a significantly wetter season than the coverage taken on the south side of Lake Titicaca.

metas.title: Lake Chinchaycocha
metas.description: North of the city of Huancayo lies a shallow lake called Lake Chinchaycocha (also referred to as ‘the middle lake.’). This lake is generally marshy and a range of mountains can be seen to the east of the lake. This lake can look similar to Lake Titicaca, but is generally less densely populated and features fewer trees.

metas.title: Arequipa Volcanoes
metas.description: Volcanoes are often seen in and around the city of Arequipa.
metas.note: Within Peru, volcanoes are only found in the southeast in the highlighted area.

metas.title: Lima Boulevards
metas.description: Most of the boulevard-type streets in Peru are in the city of Lima. These boulevards are typically long, straight streets divided by concrete or a grassy berm.

metas.title: Pucallpa Grid
metas.description: The east-central Amazonian city of Pucallpa, which lies close to the Brazil border, has a consistent street grid of WSW to ENE.
metas.note: Some northern and eastern areas of the city feature grids of different orientation.

metas.title: Iquitos Gen 3
metas.description: Iquitos is a city in northeast Peru. It is an isolated city with only Generation 3 Street View coverage. Three-wheeled tuk-tuks, overcast skies, and rolling Amazonian landscapes are commonly seen in the area. This coverage is isolated from other areas of northern Peru.

metas.title: Cusco Architecture
metas.description: The southern city of Cusco is recognizable by its prevalence of both red brick and Spanish colonial style buildings. Cusco is surrounded by mountains on all sides and features an airport in the middle of the city. Due to its proximity and similar architecture, Cusco superficially resembles the Bolivian city of La Paz.

metas.title: Tacna Dry Ridge
metas.description: The city of Tacna in the far south of Peru has this distinct dry ridge to the north.

metas.title: Machu Picchu Car
metas.description: Within Peru, this white Street View car is found in central Cusco. It drives from the remote town of Aguas Calientes up to Machu Picchu.

metas.title: Cusco Train Trekker
metas.description: A train track covered by a trekker is located between Aguas Calientes and Cusco.

metas.title: Stereotypical Landscape
metas.description: This is the stereotypical Uruguay round. The coverage often, but not always, features overcast weather. Most of the landscape consists of open grasslands with gentle hills. Occasionally, you might see separated tree plantations. Roads are generally in worse condition than in neighbouring countries.

metas.title: White License Plates
metas.description: Uruguayan licence plates are plain white with black characters.
metas.note: Neighbouring Argentina also uses white licence plates, but they will have either a black dot in the middle or a blue bar at the top.

metas.title: Gen 3 Coverage
metas.description:
Uruguay only has Generation 3 coverage. Coverage was taken by a black Google car without an antenna.

The car is not always visible.
metas.note: Within South America, you can also find this car in Argentina and Peru.

metas.title: Smudgy Camera
metas.description: In a lot of coverage, the camera quality is somewhat smudgy.
metas.note: This is significantly less common in Argentina.

metas.title: Thick Wooden Signposts
metas.description: Uruguay uses thick wooden signposts, which are typically painted white. They often have up to four rectangular notches at the back of the post.
metas.note: Thick wooden signposts can also be seen in Bolivia.

metas.title: Triple Road Lines
metas.description: Uruguay often has these triple road lines, that consist of double yellow roadlines with white dashes in between. This is a design not seen anywhere else in the Americas.

metas.title: Other Road Lines
metas.description:
You can also find two other, non-unique road line patterns:

Yellow-white lines (also found in Argentina)

Simple white lines (found in many other places).

metas.title: Uruguayan Bollards
metas.description: These white bollards, with one side often painted yellow, and stone barriers, are specific to Uruguay.

metas.title: Trident Poles
metas.description: Uruguay uses a handful of different utility poles. One very common and useful one are the so-called trident poles, which get their name from their distinctive pole tops with three insulators that point upwards.
metas.note: Similar trident poles can be found in the neighbouring Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul.

metas.title: Concrete Poles
metas.description:
You can also see a variety of other pole designs, including:

Round poles with a pole top consisting of flat metal sheets

Square concrete poles.

Both of these pole designs are also good clues for Uruguay.

In addition, you might see simple wooden poles with one insulator, as well as very rarely some Argentina-style poles.

metas.title: Red Reflector Guardrails
metas.description:
Uruguayan guardrails have a small, rectangular yellow or red reflector, which is the same as in Argentina. They can be differentiated by the shape of their support.

In Argentina, the supports are made up of three sides of a rectangle. Uruguayan supports have the same three sides, and additionally parts of the fourth side at the corners.

metas.title: Green Stone Marker
metas.description: This green-painted stone kilometre marker is unique to Uruguay.

metas.title: Yellow Black Chevrons
metas.description: Like most of Latin America, chevrons are yellow with black arrows.
metas.note: This is mostly useful to distinguish between Argentina, which uniquely uses chevrons that are white with red arrows.

metas.title: Hilly Terrain
metas.description:
As mentioned before, most of Uruguay is slightly hilly, even though the overall elevation is fairly low. Although it is by no means a mountainous country, roads generally have at least a slight incline.

Take note that this hilliness is usually very subtle: don’t expect immense rolling hills in most of the country.
metas.note: If your location is completely flat, consider that you might be in Argentina instead.

metas.title: Reddish Soil
metas.description: In many parts of Uruguay, you can find reddish soil. The tint can range from light pink (pictured here) to deep red.
metas.note:
This type of reddish soil is less common in the similar-looking parts of Argentina. Hence, it can be a good clue for Uruguay when you are faced with a tough decision.

However, be cautious with using this meta in the inverse way: the absence of this type of soil does not exclude Uruguay, as you can still find a lot of generic white and brown soil throughout the country.

metas.title: Boxy Concrete Houses
metas.description: Many Uruguayan houses are made out of concrete, and are somewhat cube-shaped. Walls often have drab colours and tend to look weathered. Flat roofs are relatively common.
metas.note: Architecture in Argentina often looks similar.

metas.title: Stocky Palm Trees
metas.description: Occasionally, you might see palm trees. These short and stocky species of palm tree are particularly common.

metas.title: Cattle Farming
metas.description: Cattle farming is an important part of Uruguay’s agriculture. Cattle outnumber people four by one, so you will see a lot of them around in rural rounds.

metas.title: Coverage Map
metas.description:
Coverage in Uruguay is somewhat limited. The densest coverage is in the south, in and around Montevideo. Outside of this area, most coverage is confined to yellow roads. This makes angle guessing a powerful tool to potentially get very close guesses.

For a zoomable overview of official street view coverage, see this site.

metas.title: Elevation Map
metas.description:
Subtle differences in elevation can help when trying to region-guess Uruguay.

The highest hills are mostly concentrated around two areas:

Near Minas, east of Montevideo.

North of Tacuarembo, in the far north of the country.

metas.title: Minas Hills
metas.description:
The landscape near the town of Minas is recognizable: some of the tallest hills in the country, with lots of exposed rocks, and often heavy bushland vegetation.

The image shown here is a fairly extreme example of this landscape, used for illustration purposes – usually it is more subtle. However, the exposed rock is always a good clue.
metas.note: The landscape in the Quebrada de los Cuervos nature reserve, situated further north, can look similar. In addition, there are also very tall hills in the north of the country. However, these look different (see the tip below).

metas.title: Northern Dark Hills
metas.description:
You can also find tall hills in the north of the country. These can be recognized by their noticeably darker soil. These hills also typically do not have the exposed rocks that are visible in the Minas hills.

The vegetation tends to be natural, and you will often see tree plantations.

This specific landscape tends to be most noticeable very close to the Brazil border, on Route 30 near Tranqueras.

metas.title: Tree Plantations
metas.description:
Tree plantations are a defining feature of much of Uruguay’s countryside, but they are especially common in two areas in the north and northwest.

Note that the highest density of plantations is in these areas, but more isolated plantations can be found all over the country.

metas.title: East Flatlands
metas.description: The region near Lagoa Mirim and the Brazil border in the southeast of the country is noticeably very flat, in contrast to the slight hills found in most of the rest of the country.

metas.title: Divided Highways
metas.description:
There are only a couple of divided highways in Uruguay, all of which are close to Montevideo:

Ruta 1 going west out of Montevideo, up until Colonia Valdense.

Ruta IB going east out of Montevideo, up until Punta del Este.

A short section of Ruta 5 going north out of Montevideo, up until Canelones.

The only exceptions to this are some divided avenues in urban areas, which should be easy to distinguish from actual highways.

metas.title: Rocha Bins
metas.description: These bins with orange lids are specific to Rocha Department. However, you can still find these black bins in both the Rocha and Canelones Department.

metas.title: Montevideo
metas.description:
Montevideo is by far the largest city in Uruguay. More than half the Uruguayan population lives within its metropolitan area.

Its relatively massive size may not always be as apparent in its suburbs. However, if you are in a densely populated, highly built-up area, consider guessing in downtown Montevideo, as there are very few places like that in other parts of Uruguay.

metas.title: Punta del Este Pines
metas.description:
Punta del Este is a seaside resort town with a recognizable look. It is an affluent and touristic place with a developed downtown that consists of many tall, modern apartment buildings. Its main attraction is its large, sandy beach.

Further away from the downtown area, you will see less highrises, but still a lot of expensive-looking villa neighbourhoods. Here, you will often see distinctive tall pine trees.

metas.title: Isla de Flores
metas.description: The small island of Isla de Flores is located off the coast of Montevideo. It has a trekker where you can see abandoned buildings, and usually also the lighthouse.

metas.title: Cabo Polonio Car
metas.description:
This unique Google car is found in the coastal town of Cabo Polonio. It can be recognized by the orange strap on the left.

The coverage is an off-road trekker line on the map. The town that it drives through has a unique vibe, consisting of makeshift-looking shacks, scattered around the seaside landscape. In some of the coverage, the car drives on the beach.

metas.title: Valle del Lunarejo Car
metas.description:
This unique Google car is found in the Valle del Lunarejo natural park, located west of the town of Tranqueras. The car has a white front and a curved black backside with a brown strap.

The coverage is an off-road trekker line on the map. The car drives on a small track through a grassy landscape.
metas.note: This park only shows up as a point of interest on the map, instead of the usual dark green polygon used for natural parks.
